column3: "title": "Stand with X to protect free speech"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Stand with X to protect free speech
            By
            
  
  
Saturday
column8: 18 November 2023\nLink copied successfully\nThis week Media Matters for America posted a story that completely misrepresented the real user experience on X
column9: in another attempt to undermine freedom of speech and mislead advertisers.\nAbove everything
column10: including profit
column11: X works to protect the public\u00e2\u0080\u0099s right to free speech. But for speech to be truly free
column12: we must also have the freedom to see or hear things that some people may consider objectionable. We believe that everyone has the right to make up their own minds about what to read
column13: watch
column14: or listen to \u00e2\u0080\u0093 because that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s the power of freedom of speech.\nDespite our clear and consistent position
column15: X has seen a number of attacks from activist groups like Media Matters and legacy media outlets who seek to undermine freedom of expression on our platform because they perceive it as a threat to their ideological narrative and those of their financial supporters. These groups try to use their influence to attack our revenue streams by deceiving advertisers on X.\nHere are the facts on Media Matters\u00e2\u0080\u0099 research:\nTo manipulate the public and advertisers
column16: Media Matters created an alternate account and curated the posts and advertising appearing on the account\u00e2\u0080\u0099s timeline to misinform advertisers about the placement of their posts. These contrived experiences could be applied to any platform.\u00c2\u00a0\nOnce they curated their feed
column17: they repeatedly refreshed their timelines to find a rare instance of ads serving next to the content they chose to follow. Our logs indicate that they forced a scenario resulting in 13 times the number of ads served compared to the median ads served to an X user.\u00c2\u00a0\nOf the 5.5 billion ad impressions on X that day
column18: less than 50 total ad impressions were served against all of the organic content featured in the Media Matters article.\nFor one brand showcased in the article
column19: one of its ads ran adjacent to a post 2 times and that ad was seen in that setting by only two users
column20: one of which was the author of the Media Matters article.\nFor another brand showcased in the article
column21: two of its ads served adjacent to 2 posts
column22: 3 times
column23: and that ad was only seen in that setting by one user
column24: the author of the Media Matters article.\nMedia Matters\u00e2\u0080\u0099 article also highlights nine posts they believe should not be allowed on X. Upon evaluation
column25: only one of the nine organic posts featured in the article violated our content policies
column26: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve taken action on it under our Freedom of Speech
column27: Not Reach enforcement approach.\nHere\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a summary on this all: \nX will protect the public\u00e2\u0080\u0099s right to free expression. We will not allow agenda-driven activists
column28: or even our own profits
column29:
to deter our vision.
Everyone has a choice on X. User and brand controls on X are superior to a year ago.Â 
Data wins over allegations. Media Matters does not reflect the user experience on X.
As weâve seen in some parts of the world
column30: when free expression is taken away
column31: it is very dangerous and hard to get back \u00e2\u0080\u0093 that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why the people who came before us fought so hard to protect. Without freedom of speech we lose the checks and balances critical to a thriving democracy. We must defend our individual rights as if our lives
column32: and flourishing society
column33: depend on it.\nIf you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re really in on protecting free speech
column34:
then we all need to protect it completely.Â 
Stand with X to protect free speech.
Â

column3: "title": "Maintaining the safety of X in times of conflict"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Maintaining the safety of X in times of conflict
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 14 November 2023\nLink copied successfully\nOver half a billion of the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s most informed and influential people come to X each month to freely express themselves. In times of uncertainty such as the Israel-Hamas conflict
column9: our responsibility to protect the public conversation is magnified. From the onset of the conflict
column10: we activated our crisis protocol and stood up the company to address the rapidly evolving situation with the highest level of urgency. That includes the formation of a cross-functional leadership team that has been working around the clock to ensure our global community has access to real-time information and to safeguard the platform for our users and partners. As we enter the second month of the conflict
column11: here\u00e2\u0080\u0099s an update on the key proactive measures we have taken: Policy Enforcement X has a comprehensive set of policies designed to promote and protect the public conversation. Below is a summary of the key enforcement actions we have taken based on those policies in response to the Israel-Hamas conflict. Enforcement actions can include restricting the reach of a post
column12: removing the post or account suspension. Additionally
column13: such posts are not eligible for monetization. Safety and cybercrime:\nTo date
column14: our escalations team has actioned over 325
column15: 000 pieces of content that violate our Terms of Service
column16: including violent speech and hateful conduct.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve taken action under our Violent and Hateful Entities policy to remove over 3
column17: 000 accounts by violent entities in the region
column18: including Hamas
column19: since the start of the conflict.\nIn parallel
column20: as we outlined in our update on this topic in September
column21: we have expanded our proactive measures to automatically remediate against antisemitic content and provided our agents worldwide with a refresher course on antisemitism.\n Platform integrity and authenticity:\u00c2\u00a0\nOur escalations team has actioned over 25
column22: 000 pieces of content under our synthetic and manipulated media policy.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also taken action \u00e2\u0080\u0093 including suspension \u00e2\u0080\u0093 on over 375
column23: 000 accounts as a result of our proactive investigations to protect authentic conversation regarding the conflict
column24: including coordinated/inauthentic engagement
column25: inauthentic accounts
column26: duplicate content and trending topic/hashtag spam. Additionally
column27: we continue to investigate and disrupt coordinated campaigns to manipulate conversations related to the conflict.\n Exceptions to our Sensitive Media policy:\nWe know that it's sometimes incredibly difficult to see certain content
column28: especially in moments like the one unfolding. While we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve always allowed media that meets our definitions of Graphic Content (so long as it is placed behind a sensitive media warning interstitial)
column29: we generally remove content that meets our definitions of Gratuitous Gore. However
column30: when certain newsworthy events occur X believes that it's in the public's interest to understand what's happening in real-time
column31: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve allowed a range of media to remain on the platform (so long as it too is placed behind an interstitial). People on X can control what media they see and we recommend reviewing your media settings to ensure you either see or do not see this sensitive media
column32: depending on your preferences.\n \u00c2\u00a0 Community Notes A critical topic during times of conflict is misleading information \u00e2\u0080\u0093 something that every publisher and platform is tackling. We believe it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important to add context to potentially misleading content
column33: and that a community-led approach is an effective solution. This led us to creating Community Notes
column34: which addresses a far wider range of sophisticated media types than our historical approaches. In the first month of the conflict
column35: notes have been viewed well over a hundred million times
column36: addressing topics from out-of-context videos to AI-generated media to claims about specific events. And when notes are added
column37: they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re effective \u00e2\u0080\u0093 they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re helpful to people across the political spectrum
column38: they measurably inform people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s understanding and people choose to share potentially misleading content less (and often delete it). On average
column39:
people are 30% less likely to agree with the substance of the original post after reading a note about it. We hold a high bar for both the quality of notes posted and the speed and scale at which they appear. Here are some improvements weâve made in just the past month: Notes are getting faster.
They are now visible 1.5 to 3.5 hrs more quickly than a month ago. Note previews directly on posts help contributors find and rate proposed notes faster.
 Notes are appearing on far more posts.
We have north of 200
column40: 000 contributors in 44 countries and are growing. That includes over 40
column41: 000 new contributors added from the beginning of the conflict.\nWe recently launched and have been enhancing notes on new media types. When a note is added to a photo or video
column42: it automatically shows on other posts with matching media. Because of this new feature
column43: notes related to the Israel-Hamas conflict have been displayed on 10
column44: 000+ posts.\u00c2\u00a0\nThis number grows automatically if the relevant images and video are re-used in new posts.\nAdditionally
column45: we have launched an update making it easier to see the post on which any given note was originally written
column46: enabling people to see the original context.\n Notes regularly appear on highly engaged content.\nThis helps to inform many people about a topic
column47: and also allows people to become familiar with the ways in which content can be misleading
column48: so they can better consume future information.\n We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re notifying more users after a Note has been added.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve ramped up notifications to people who Like
column49: Repost or Reply to a post that then later has a Community Note added to it. And during peaks of the ramp up
column50: we were sending nearly 1000 notifications per second.\n We are updating our policies to prevent posts with Community Notes from being monetized. \u00c2\u00a0 Brand Safety\u00c2\u00a0 X has robust products and policies that we enforce 24/7 to provide brand safety for all advertisers. As part of this commitment
column51: we do not monetize content that violates our policies. In response to the Israel-Hamas conflict we have proactively removed more than 100 publisher videos not suitable for monetization. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve updated our keyword blocklists with more than 1
column52: 000 terms related to the conflict
column53: preventing ad targeting and adjacency on Timeline or Search placements. And we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve implemented a change where Amplify Video campaigns from our content partners will only run in the Home Timeline. With many conversations happening on X right now
column54: we have also shared guidance on how to manage brand activity during this moment through our suite of brand safety and suitability protections and through tighter targeting to suitable brand content like sports
column55: music
column56: business and gaming.  Our work is ongoing We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to engage with communities
column57: governments
column58: nonprofits
column59:
customers and others who have constructive feedback and ideas to strengthen our approach. Protecting the public conversation and the safety of the platform is our priority. 
Â

column3: "title": "One year in
column4: the future of X is bright"
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/company/2023/one-year-in"
column8: "post_text": "Company\nOne year in
column9:
the future of X is bright
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column10:
26 October 2023
Link copied successfully
October 27 marks the one-year anniversary of this platform under new ownership and management.
I am incredibly proud of the work our team has been doing to accelerate the future of X.
So let me share with you where we stand today: 
Freedom of expression. X is now a place where everyone can freely express themselves
column11: so long as they do so within the bounds of the law. We believe open and respectful discourse is the single best way for humanity to thrive.\nSafety. Safety on X remains a critical priority \u00e2\u0080\u0093 our work is not done
column12: but we are making real progress. Our trust and safety team is working around the clock to combat bad actors and consistently enforce our rules in areas such as hate speech
column13: platform manipulation
column14: child safety
column15: impersonation
column16: civic integrity and more. We also remain committed to privacy and data protection.\nPartnerships. Our team also has ongoing dialogue with external groups to keep up to date with potential risks and support the safety of the platform \u00e2\u0080\u0093 partners like the Technology Coalition
column17: Anti-Defamation League
column18: American Jewish Committee and Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism.\nTime spent. Our fiercely loyal users are living more of their lives on X \u00e2\u0080\u0093 with 7.8B+ active minutes on X per day
column19: driven by growth in our Video and Communities products. Today
column20: the average user spends more than 32 minutes of their day on X.\nUser base. Over half a billion of the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s most informed and influential people come to X every month. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s inclusive of our efforts to aggressively remove spam and inauthentic accounts \u00e2\u0080\u0093 a step we believe is critical to improve the X user experience and grow the platform. We continue to see sign-ups average around 1.5 million per day.\nMisleading or inaccurate information. We have made real progress in our work to combat misinformation from all sides on X. Community Notes now has over 100K contributors in 44 countries and growing. This product is not perfect
column21: but it is improving rapidly. Notes are being seen tens of millions of times per day
column22: and they are getting much faster \u00e2\u0080\u0093 a necessity in a world where breaking information is inherently uncertain and X has outperformed traditional media.\nBrand safety and suitability. X advertisers now have a level of control that largely did not exist one year ago. Thanks to new products like Adjacency Controls
column23: Sensitivity Settings and third party measurement partnerships with industry leaders Integral Ad Science and DoubleVerify
column24: the average brand safety score on X is now >99%
column25: and we are now seeing brand suitability scores at >97% when these controls are applied.\nAdvertiser momentum. Our willingness to listen and take action on brand safety has been recognized by the advertising community. Since mid-May
column26: all major agencies have reversed their pause guidance against advertising on X. Last quarter alone over 1
column27: 700 advertisers returned to X
column28: from small businesses to major brands \u00e2\u0080\u0093 including 90 of the top 100 ad spenders from a year ago. We are committed to making X the best place for businesses to launch new products
column29: connect with culture and drive people to buy.\nFrom Twitter to X. We transformed Twitter into X
column30: the everything app
column31: where everyone is increasingly connected to everything they care about. This move enabled us to evolve past a legacy mindset and reimagine how users around the world consume
column32: interact
column33: watch and
column34: soon
column35: transact \u00e2\u0080\u0093 all in one seamless interface. We have become the modern global town square.\nProduct and infrastructure velocity. We shipped over 200 products and features post-acquisition with a significantly smaller team. How did we achieve this? We rebuilt and simplified large parts of the systems and infrastructure powering our main product surfaces from the ground up
column36: which allowed us to maintain platform stability and innovate faster. We also invested in our machine learning capabilities with model architecture improvements and investments in on-prem GPU clusters to increase content relevance for our users.\nVerification and premium subscriptions. We have incentivized quality content while at the same time combating spam and bots. Today
column37: the average X Premium subscriber spends three times longer on the platform than a non-subscriber. We have launched this offering in over 200 countries and territories worldwide
column38: and created more utility and fun with new features like longer posts and videos
column39: audio and video calls
column40: bookmarks
column41: edit posts
column42: prioritized rankings and verification \u00e2\u0080\u0093 to name a few.\nVerified Organizations. X is leading the market in business verification \u00e2\u0080\u0093 our Verified Organizations subscription enables organizations to verify and create a network of on-platform affiliate handles
column43: access all of our premium features and expand their organic reach. We have also rolled out the beta version of X Hiring
column44: our very own recruitment platform.\nX Hiring. Through a Verified Organizations subscription
column45: businesses can now post a job listing directly on the platform. Our engaged and educated audience makes for some of the most exceptional employees in the world. From software engineers
column46: to healthcare professionals
column47: to sales associates \u00e2\u0080\u0093 hundreds of companies are already finding their next hires on X.\nWelcoming the creator economy. You can now create
column48: connect and collect all on X. We have enabled the economic success of creators via our relaunching of Creator Subscriptions and our ad revenue sharing program. So far
column49: we have paid out more than $20 million to our creator community \u00e2\u0080\u0093 creators big and small are spurring our flywheel effect.\nBuilding communities. More people are getting together in X Communities
column50: now available to all countries in English plus Japan. The conversations are public
column51: discoverable and always lively. We see 70
column52: 000 people join a new Community each day
column53: with time spent rising 300% since May.\nMessaging and calling. Direct messaging on X is a completely enhanced experience from a year ago. We rolled out encrypted messaging to X Premium subscribers
column54: increased the limit on group DMs to 200 and added more message reply functionality. Just yesterday
column55: we launched audio and video calling
column56: enabling Premium subscribers to call any X handle in the world without having to give them their phone number.\nMake X yours. One of the most powerful things about X is how unique the experience can be to each and every one of us. From the \u00e2\u0080\u009cFor You\u00e2\u0080\u009d tab to adding bookmarks to making Lists and Communities pinnable to the Home Timeline
column57: we have introduced more personalization features to help make X yours. We also open-sourced our algorithm to increase transparency and invited our community to help us improve our recommendation algorithms. Any platform committed to transparency would do the same.\nLong form content. We added the ability for X Premium subscribers to post up to 2 hours of 1080p or 3 hours of 720p video content. In one month alone
column58: people watched 210 years worth of videos 30 minutes or longer
column59: with Sports
column60: Business
column61: Gaming
column62: Politics and Entertainment topping the charts. Meanwhile
column63: you can now write or read an essay by posting up to 25
column64: 000 rich-text characters and embed images within posts. Each day 150
column65: 000 new long form posts are published
column66: receiving more than 3 billion impressions.\nVertical video. As video consumption on the platform grows
column67: we have scaled the ability for users to watch a continuous loop of sound-on
column68: vertical video. This surface already has over 100 million daily users \u00e2\u0080\u0093 more than half of which are Gen Z
column69: the fastest growing segment on X. Soon
column70: we will GA Vertical Video Ads to all advertisers globally with a pre-bid
column71: vetted inventory solution via our brand safety partners Integral Ad Science.\nPremium content. X is now home to more than 750 of the industry's most premium content producers \u00e2\u0080\u0093 from the sports leagues
column72: to premium publishers
column73: broadcast networks
column74: and creators. We are poised to grow these partnerships further while bringing original programming to X for the first time in the platform's history
column75: in concert with both creators and brands.\nEnhanced advertising solutions. We have expanded our powerful advertiser solutions. Our new Keyword Ads product enables advertisers to pay for proximity to highly relevant conversations. Amplify Video continues to connect advertisers to their audiences via the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s most premium and brand safe publisher content. And Vertical Video Ads will soon enable full-screen
column76: sound-on advertising within our fastest growing video surface.\nAPI partners.\u00c2\u00a0The public conversation on X is a unique and powerful data set. We have streamlined and consolidated our subscription offering to cater to developers of all sizes
column77: while continuing to provide free support to public utilities such as MTA
column78: NWS and many more. By focusing on the value of our unique data we are quickly growing and expanding our data licensing business.\nPayments. We want money on X to flow as freely as information and conversation. We have already secured first money transmitter licenses in several states
column79: and we are moving toward launching a global payment system \u00e2\u0080\u0093 more soon!\nThis product innovation and business momentum stands on the shoulders of one of the most rigorous corporate restructurings in history. We are rebuilding our team and leadership to reflect the evolving needs of our customers and partners.\nAnd if we can achieve all of this in just 12 months
column80: just imagine the scope of our ambition for next year \u00e2\u0080\u0093 from expanded search to newswires to payments
column81: we are just getting started.\nTo our passionate and growing community and all of the teams
column82: partners and customers who have been a part of this transformation
column84:
the future of X is bright.

column3: "title": "X\u2019s community-led approach: tackling inaccurate & misleading information"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Xâs community-led approach: tackling inaccurate & misleading information
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 24 October 2023\nLink copied successfully\nThere are meaningful conversations happening on X right now \u00e2\u0080\u0093 with people in every part of the world posting hundreds of millions of times per day on every single topic
column9: relying on X for critical connection
column10: information and access. People want real-time information from voices around the world
column11: and they want accurate information. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s X\u00e2\u0080\u0099s ambition to make this a reality.\nX has long had policies designed to safeguard this platform from bad actors
column12: including teams that address coordinated accounts and similar problems. That remains true. In addition
column13: we believe it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important to add context to potentially misleading content.\nA year ago
column14: we widely launched a new approach to adding context \u00e2\u0080\u0094 a community-driven approach
column15: designed to be helpful and informative to people across viewpoints: @CommunityNotes. We want to share what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve observed
column16: and what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re working on.\nIn this first year \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and thanks to the incredible contributor community \u00e2\u0080\u0094 we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen remarkable results:\nCommunity Notes now address a far wider range of topics than our historic approaches to addressing misleading information. In the past two weeks alone
column17: notes have been seen well over 100 million times
column18: addressing an enormous range of topics from out-of-context videos to AI-generated media
column19: to claims about specific events and more. When notes are added
column20: they are effective \u00e2\u0080\u0094 they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re helpful to people across the political spectrum
column21: they measurably inform people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s understanding
column22: and they lead people to Like and Repost potentially misleading content less. Often
column23: post authors even choose to delete their posts after a note is added.\nWe believe innovation in this space has been important for the world. Here\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why
column24: and why we are so optimistic about a community-driven approach:\nTrust. A key challenge with traditional fact-checking driven by companies or institutions (and the resultant enforcement actions) is that it can be highly divisive. Significant portions of the public often dismiss such actions as biased. Community Notes was created to deliver context and information in a way that people would trust and feel to be fair \u00e2\u0080\u0094 we pursued it when we saw in research how positively people from different viewpoints respond to it. To build trust
column25: Community Notes has two unique features that differentiate it from other approaches: (1) Bridging-based ranking. For a note to become visible to all users on X
column26: it must be rated \u00e2\u0080\u009chelpful\u00e2\u0080\u009d by reviewers who\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve previously disagreed. (2) Open source. The code and all of the data that power Community Notes are open-source
column27: so anyone can audit
column28: analyze
column29: critique or help improve it.\nSpeed and scale. Traditional approaches also face challenges with speed and scale. It is challenging to cover the wide range of potentially misleading information out there
column30: and it is common for context to take many hours or days to be added
column31: particularly with new content and claims. We believe a community-led approach has the potential to scale much wider and respond more quickly
column32: and we already see impressive results that continue to improve over time.\nConsistently helpful to people across political and ideological spectrums. Community Notes' ability to produce visible notes that are broadly found helpful is remarkable given the strong opinions and divisions around the topics on which notes appear. We believe this is key to its effectiveness. To improve this even further
column33: we regularly launch updates to Community Notes\u00e2\u0080\u0099 open-source algorithm
column34: like yesterday\u00e2\u0080\u0099s note scoring improvement
column35: and to the core product experience
column36: like last week\u00e2\u0080\u0099s change that made sources required.\nWe put a high priority on note quality
column37: as it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s critical to trust and effectiveness. At the same time
column38: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been driving up speed and scale:\nNotes are fast and getting faster
column39: and are now seen 1.5 to 3.5 hrs more quickly than a month ago. Notes in the first few days of the Israel-Hamas conflict appeared at a median time of about 5 hours after post creation. And that doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t include the tens of thousands of notes that appear in just minutes on posts that reuse an image or video that has already received a note. We know some people will inevitably see posts before a note appears
column40: so we also send notifications to people who previously engaged with a post that later receives a note. We continue to improve speed with infrastructure improvements
column41: like a recent change to a real-time streaming architecture
column42: and experience improvements
column43: like note previews that help gather ratings on notes quickly.\nNotes are appearing on far more posts
column44: powered by media matching and our expansion to well over 100K contributors in 44 countries and growing. We recently launched and have been enhancing \u00e2\u0080\u009cnotes on media
column45: \u00e2\u0080\u009d meaning that when a note is added to a photo or video
column46: it automatically shows on other posts with matching media. In some cases
column47: individual notes match hundreds or thousands of posts.\u00c2\u00a0\nNotes often appear on viral and high-visibility content. This has the benefit of helping to inform a large number of people about a topic
column48: and also allows people to become familiar with the ways in which content can be misleading
column49: so they can better consume future information. \nFinally
column50: we listen closely to feedback on how Community Notes can improve. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve shipped more than one product update every week on average throughout 2023
column51: and in the last two weeks alone
column52: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve shipped eight. These improvements are often based on feedback from the public and contributors
column53: and improve things like note quality
column54: speed and experience. Community Notes regularly get better on a weekly basis.\nWe are asked regularly how Community Notes prevent gaming and manipulation. We built Community Notes with the expectation that people would attempt to game it from day one
column55: and designed it to deliver quality notes in the face of this. Notes takes multiple steps to achieve this \u00e2\u0080\u0094 from account signup requirements
column56: to writing ability and other capabilities needing to be earned through a track record of helpful contributions
column57: and most importantly to the core algorithm that shows notes only when they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re found helpful by people who disagree. In addition
column58: the open-source code and data make it possible for others to help identify weaknesses or make improvements. We will continue to be vigilant to ensure note quality stays high.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve heard people suggest there should be a mechanism to address cases where an account frequently receives Community Notes on their posts. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re evaluating whether an option exists that people would find helpful and fair. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important to note that Community Notes sometimes just add informative context to posts
column59: and do not always reflect a post being misleading. We welcome feedback and suggestions on this topic.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve heard that people want notes to be faster and cover more posts. A community-driven approach can maximize quality
column60: speed and scale
column61: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re always working to improve in those areas. Periodically
column62: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been challenged on these dimensions
column63: but those challenges often do not quantitatively compare the performance
column64: quality
column65: visibility and reach of Community Notes to other products
column66: publishers and news organizations. Being open-sourced
column67: we welcome feedback and critiques. And we believe that when it's done meaningfully and transparently
column68: there can be a great deal of improvements to build better models to address misleading information globally.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re a year in
column69: but we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re always on day one. We don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t expect perfection
column70: but we have high ambitions for quality
column71: speed and scale and helping people stay informed. As one person put it in an X post
column72: \u00e2\u0080\u009cIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not perfect
column73: but it IS working pretty [darn] well.\u00e2\u0080\u009d With the help of our contributors
column74: and feedback from the public
column75: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re going to keep making it work even more darn well. The world needs it. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to innovate
column76: and continue to openly share the data \u00e2\u0080\u0094 along with the code \u00e2\u0080\u0094 to show our progress.\nWe couldn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t do this without our contributors and all the people who provide feedback. Thank you
column77: we are grateful
column78:
and please keep it coming.
 Please follow us @CommunityNotes for more updates.

column3: "title": "Our ongoing commitment to combat antisemitism on X"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Our ongoing commitment to combat antisemitism on X
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 8 September 2023\nLink copied successfully\nOur teams at X constantly listen to feedback from users and maintain continuous dialogue with outside organizations to ensure our policies and enforcement balance free expression with platform safety. We firmly believe these two values can coexist
column9: and we work tirelessly to achieve that goal. \nAs part of this
column10: we are committed to combating hatred
column11: prejudice and intolerance \u00e2\u0080\u0093 particularly when they are directed at marginalized and persecuted groups. That means taking proportionate action on content that violates our Rules. And today we wanted to share the real progress we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re making in combating antisemitism on X.\nOur longstanding policies cover a wide range of behavior that targets an individual or group of people with abuse based on their perceived or real membership in any protected category.\nEarlier this year we expanded our Violent & Hateful Entities policy
column12: refreshed our policies around Violent Speech to reflect our zero tolerance approach and updated our Abusive Behavior policy to more clearly prohibit targeted harassment.\nOn an ongoing basis
column13: we add new slurs
column14: harmful terms and phrases to our operational handbook and proactive heuristics to ensure we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re capturing the evolving landscape and use of language to target members of protected categories
column15:
including members of the Jewish community.
We continuously improve our automated enforcement to more quickly identify and remediate instances of hateful conduct (including antisemitic conduct) on the platform by expanding the application of our machine learning models.Â 
We actively provide ongoing training support and mandatory refresher requirements for our frontline moderators to educate them about different types of antisemitic hate speech and how they may manifest on X.Â 
 Through our policies and enforcement
column16: active training of agents
column17: and working alongside our partners and users
column18:
X is committed to combating antisemitism on our platform. Our work is ongoing and weâll continue to make investments in this area and keep our community updated on our progress.

column3: "title": "Supporting people\u2019s right to accurate and safe political discourse on X"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Supporting peopleâs right to accurate and safe political discourse on X
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 29 August 2023\nLink copied successfully\nMore than half a billion people from around the world gather on X to talk about their interests in real-time
column9: and that includes elections. X enables people to directly engage on important topics with elected representatives
column10: local or national leaders and fellow citizens.\nDuring elections
column11: X works to get in front of a range of tactics that people use to target the process. To do this we hire the right people
column12: update our policies and evolve our product.\nOur people: We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re currently expanding our safety and elections teams to focus on combating manipulation
column13: surfacing inauthentic accounts and closely monitoring the platform for emerging threats.\nOur policies:\u00c2\u00a0We have rules in place to help protect the safety and authenticity of conversations on X. During elections
column14: our Civic Integrity Policy provides an extra layer of protection that is applied for a limited period of time before and during an election. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re updating this policy to make sure we strike the right balance between tackling the most harmful types of content\u00e2\u0080\u0094those that could intimidate or deceive people into surrendering their right to participate in a civic process\u00e2\u0080\u0094and not censoring political debate.\nThe policy will also be aligned with our updated enforcement philosophy
column15: Freedom of Speech
column16: Not Reach. We will add publicly visible labels to posts identified as potentially violating the Civic Integrity Policy
column17: letting people know when their reach has been restricted.\nBuilding on our commitment to free expression
column18: we are also going to allow political advertising. Starting in the U.S.
column19: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to apply specific policies to paid-for promoted political posts. This will include prohibiting the promotion of false or misleading content
column20: including false or misleading information intended to undermine public confidence in an election
column21: while seeking to preserve free and open political discourse. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll also provide a global advertising transparency center so that everyone can review political posts being promoted on X
column22: in addition to robust screening processes to ensure only eligible groups and campaigns are able to advertise.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nOur product: We continue to scale Community Notes
column23: an innovative tool that empowers a vetted and growing group of people to add context to posts when they see something that could be wrong
column24: misleading or requires another point of view. X shouldn't determine the truthfulness of disputed information; rather
column25: we should empower our users to express their opinions and openly debate during elections
column26: in line with our commitment to protecting freedom of expression.\nCommunity Notes is available globally with contributors in 44 countries
column27: and is fully open-sourced. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re already seeing real impact\u00e2\u0080\u0094people are on average 30% less likely to agree with the substance of a post after reading a Community Note about it
column28: and they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also less likely to reshare it. All promoted posts are eligible for Community Notes
column29: including promoted political posts.\nOur work is ongoing. These increased investments in people
column30: policy and product will further ensure our communities have access to open
column31:
accurate and safe political discourse on X.

column8: 22 August 2023\nLink copied successfully\nTo say that the FIFA 2023 Women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s World Cup was a historic moment for sports is an understatement. With record-breaking numbers for stadium attendance

column12: these last 30 days played out on X in a big way. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve compiled the numbers and the moments to illustrate the massive role the platform played during the event.\nConversation impressions surpassed the 11 BILLION mark There were a whopping 11.3B impressions of the\u00c2\u00a0#FIFAWWC\u00c2\u00a0conversation globally. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s 267% more impressions than the previous quadrennial event

column3: "title": "Protecting the public\u2019s right to free expression"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Protecting the publicâs right to free expression
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 31 July 2023\nLink copied successfully\nPlease note: this blog post was last updated on August 7
column10: 10PM EST.\u00c2\u00a0\nOn X
column11: people are free to be their true selves. We believe people of all backgrounds and beliefs should have the right to freely express themselves
column12: so long as they do so within the bounds of the law.\u00c2\u00a0\nFree expression is fundamental to a healthy functioning global society \u00e2\u0080\u0093 and if it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s taken away
column13: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s almost impossible to get back. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we will continue to stand up for people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s rights
column14: including over half a billion passionate users who turn to our platform continually.\u00c2\u00a0\nFree expression and platform safety are not at odds. We are proving this every day through innovative enforcement policies that have helped reduce hateful content viewed on the platform. Today
column15: more than 99.99% of post impressions are healthy.\nDespite our continued progress
column16: the Center for Countering Digital Hate (CCDH) and its backers have been actively working to assert false and misleading claims encouraging advertisers to pause investment on the platform. X is a free public service funded largely by advertisers.\nThrough the CCDH's scare campaign and its ongoing pressure on brands to prevent the public\u00e2\u0080\u0099s access to free expression
column17: the CCDH is actively working to prevent public dialogue. Recently Brandwatch made X aware that the CCDH gained access to X's data without Brandwatch\u00e2\u0080\u0099s authorization
column18: and that the purported CCDH \"research\" cited in a Bloomberg article \u00e2\u0080\u009ccontained metrics used out of context to make unsubstantiated assertions about X (formerly Twitter).\u00e2\u0080\u009d The CCDH gained this access with the cooperation of the European Climate Foundation
column19: which provided credentials to CCDH in violation of their contractual obligations to Brandwatch. Additionally
column20: the CCDH has recently scraped X's platform
column21: which is a violation of our terms of service.\nThat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why X has filed a legal claim against the CCDH its backers
column22: and the European Climate Foundation. X not only rejects all claims made by the CCDH
column23: but
column24: through our own investigation
column25:
we have identified several ways in which the CCDH is actively working to prevent free expression. That includes:
Targeting people on all platforms who speak about issues the CCDH doesnât agree with.
Attempting to coerce the deplatforming of users whose views do not conform to the CCDH's ideological agenda.
Targeting free-speech organizations by focusing on their revenue stream to remove free services for people.Â 
Attempting to illegally gain unauthorized access to social media platform data and to misuse that data.
We have a big responsibility to protect free expression. And we will continue to cooperate with all partners who want to both preserve peopleâs right to freely express themselves
column26:
and equally work to create a safe and healthy space for everyone. 
Â

column3: "title": "Freedom of Speech Not Reach: New Updates and Progress"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Freedom of Speech Not Reach: New Updates and Progress
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 12 July 2023\nLink copied successfully\nOn X people are free to be their true selves. Everyday
column9: we work to preserve free speech on X
column10: while equally maintaining the health of our platform. Since the launch of Freedom of Speech Not Reach
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen encouraging results. That's why in the coming weeks
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re expanding the application of this enforcement action from our Hateful Conduct policy to now include our policies on Abusive Behavior and Violent Speech.\u00c2\u00a0\nToday
column13: more than 99.99% of post impressions are from healthy content
column14: or content that does not violate our rules. For the small minority of content that is violative
column15: we apply proportionally appropriate enforcement action. We will continue to remove the most serious violations of our rules
column16: such as illegal content
column17: and suspend bad actors from our platform.\u00c2\u00a0\nMore than any other platform
column18: X's enforcement approach brings a new level of transparency to restricting the reach of posts identified as potentially violating our policies by making the content less discoverable.\nThe X community has also provided valuable feedback to help us make meaningful changes to the accuracy of our label application
column19: such as identifying instances where reach was not appropriately restricted and improving recognition of context in our detection.\nHere is some of the impact since we launched this new enforcement philosophy:\nLabels have been applied to more than 700
column20: 000 violative posts that fall under our Hateful Conduct policy. We also proactively prevent ads from appearing adjacent to content that we label.\nCompared to a healthy post
column21: posts with these labels\u00e2\u0080\u0094or restricted posts\u00e2\u0080\u0094 receive 81% less reach or impressions\u00c2\u00a0and we proactively prevent ads from appearing adjacent to content that we label.\nMore than one third of authors proactively choose to delete the post after they are informed that its reach has been restricted. \nOn average
column22: only 4 percent of authors have appealed labels.\n90 percent of all appeals receive a response within 30 minutes.\nWhile this progress is promising
column23: our work is ongoing. And as part of our commitment to transparency and results
column24:
weâll continue to provide periodic updates on our progress.
Â

column8: 25 April 2023\nLink copied successfully\nAs we review our approach to transparency reporting in light of innovations in content moderation and changes in the regulatory landscape
column9: we believe it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important to share data from H1 2022 on our health & safety efforts. We won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t be publishing a formal transparency report for this period (January 1 - June 30
column10: 2022) in our previous format.\nTwitter continues to take action on content that violates our Rules and protects users\u00e2\u0080\u0099 rights in response to government legal requests.\nOver the reporting period
column11: Twitter required users to remove 6

column14: an increase of 29% from H2 2021. We took enforcement action on 5

column62: South Korea
column63: Turkey and India.\u00c2\u00a0\nTwitter received over 16
column64: 000 government information requests for user data from over 85 countries during the reporting period. Disclosure rates vary by requester country. The top five requesting countries seeking account information in H1 2022 were India

column68: and Germany.\nWe intend to share more about our path forward for transparency reporting later this year. In the meantime

column3: "title": "Freedom of Speech
column4: Not Reach: An update on our enforcement philosophy"
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/product/2023/freedom-of-speech-not-reach-an-update-on-our-enforcement-philosophy"
column8: "post_text": "Product\nFreedom of Speech
column9:
Not Reach: An update on our enforcement philosophy
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column10:
17 April 2023
Link copied successfully
Our mission at Twitter 2.0 is to promote and protect the public conversation. We believe Twitter users have the right to express their opinions and ideas without fear of censorship. We also believe it is our responsibility to keep users on our platform safe from content violating our Rules.Â 
These beliefs are the foundation of Freedom of Speech
column11: not Freedom of Reach - our enforcement philosophy which means
column12: where appropriate
column13: restricting the reach of Tweets that violate our policies by making the content less discoverable.\nToday
column14: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to share an update on our approach to policy enforcement that better aligns this philosophy with our commitment to transparency.\u00c2\u00a0\nRestricting the reach of Tweets
column15: also known as visibility filtering
column16: is one of our existing enforcement actions that allows us to move beyond the binary \u00e2\u0080\u009cleave up versus take down\u00e2\u0080\u009d approach to content moderation. However
column17: like other social platforms
column18: we have not historically been transparent when we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve taken this action. Starting soon
column19:
we will add publicly visible labels to Tweets identified as potentially violating our policies letting you know weâve limited their visibility. 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Author Label 
          
          
        
          
            Viewer Label 
          
          
        
          
            Viewer Label 
          
          
        
These labels bring a new level of transparency to enforcement actions by displaying which policy the Tweet potentially violates to both the Tweet author and other users on Twitter. Tweets with these labels will be made less discoverable on the platform. Additionally
column20: we will not place ads adjacent to content that we label. You can learn more about the ways we may restrict a Tweet\u00e2\u0080\u0099s reach here.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nAuthors will be able to submit feedback on the label if they think we incorrectly limited their Tweet\u00e2\u0080\u0099s visibility. Currently
column21: submitting feedback does not guarantee you will receive a response or that your Tweet\u00e2\u0080\u0099s reach will be restored. We are working on allowing authors to appeal our decision.\nWhile these labels will initially only apply to a set of Tweets that potentially violate our Hateful Conduct policy
column22:
we plan to expand their application to other applicable policy areas in the coming months. This change is designed to result in enforcement actions that are more proportional and transparent for everyone on our platform. What remains unchanged is our commitment to keeping Twitter a safe place for conversation. We will continue to remove illegal content and suspend bad actors from our platform. Learn more about our range of enforcement options on our Help Center.Â

column3: "title": "A new era of transparency for Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
A new era of transparency for Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 31 March 2023\nLink copied successfully\nAt Twitter 2.0
column9: we believe that we have a responsibility
column10: as the town square of the internet
column11: to make our platform transparent. So today we are taking the first step in a new era of transparency and opening much of our source code to the global community.\nOn GitHub
column12: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll find two new repositories (main repo
column13: ml repo) containing the source code for many parts of Twitter
column14: including our recommendations algorithm
column15: which controls the Tweets you see on the For You timeline. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also sharing more information on our recommendation algorithm in this post on our Engineering Blog. For this release
column16: we aimed for the highest possible degree of transparency
column17: while excluding any code that would compromise user safety and privacy or the ability to protect our platform from bad actors
column18: including undermining our efforts at combating child sexual exploitation and manipulation. Today\u00e2\u0080\u0099s release also does not include the code that powers our ad recommendations.\nWe also took additional steps to ensure that user safety and privacy would be protected
column19: including our decision not to release training data or model weights associated with the Twitter algorithm at this point.\nUltimately
column20: this is our first step to be more transparent in this way
column21: and we plan to continue sharing more code that does not present a significant risk to Twitter or people on our platform.\nWe invite the community to submit GitHub issues and pull requests for suggestions on improving the recommendations algorithm. We are working on tools to manage these suggestions and sync changes to our internal repository. Any security concerns or issues should be routed to our official bug bounty program through HackerOne. We hope to benefit from the collective intelligence and expertise of the global community in helping us identify issues and suggest improvements
column22: ultimately leading to a better Twitter.\nAs the town square of the internet
column23: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re ultimately doing this to foster transparency and build trust with our users
column24: customers
column25:
and the general public. Weâll continue to share updates as we make progress in this area.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "An update on two-factor authentication using SMS on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
An update on two-factor authentication using SMS on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 15 February 2023\nLink copied successfully\nWe continue to be committed to keeping people safe and secure on Twitter
column9: and a primary security tool we offer to keep your account secure is two-factor authentication (2FA). Instead of only entering a password to log in
column10: 2FA requires you to also enter a code or use a security key. This additional step helps make sure that you
column11: and only you
column12: can access your account. To date
column13: we have offered three methods of 2FA: text message
column14: authentication app
column15: and security key.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhile historically a popular form of 2FA
column16: unfortunately we have seen phone-number based 2FA be used - and abused - by bad actors. So starting today
column17: we will no longer allow accounts to enroll in the text message/SMS method of 2FA unless they are Twitter Blue subscribers. The availability of text message 2FA for Twitter Blue may vary by country and carrier.\nNon-Twitter Blue subscribers that are already enrolled will have 30 days to disable this method and enroll in another. After 20 March 2023
column18: we will no longer permit non-Twitter Blue subscribers to use text messages as a 2FA method. At that time
column19: accounts with text message 2FA still enabled will have it disabled. Disabling text message 2FA does not automatically disassociate your phone number from your Twitter account. If you would like to do so
column20:
instructions to update your account phone number are available on our Help Center.
We encourage non-Twitter Blue subscribers to consider using an authentication app or security key method instead. These methods require you to have physical possession of the authentication method and are a great way to ensure your account is secure.  Learn more about two-factor authentication on Twitter on our Help Center.

#WorldCup on Twitter: The G.O.A.T.
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 20 December 2022\nLink copied successfully\nThe #WorldCup unfolded on the pitch in Qatar
column9: and it also played out on Twitter in a big way. Football fans across the globe came to Twitter to experience every exhilarating and emotional moment as it happened. The teams
column10: the action
column11: the world-class players transcended borders and connected people around the world on the platform.\u00c2\u00a0\nThere\u00e2\u0080\u0099s one universal truth that drives #WorldCup on Twitter: fans love the tournament and showed up to talk about all aspects of the game. After 64 thrilling matches
column12: including the epic final between France (@equipedefrance) and the 2022 champion
column13: Argentina (@Argentina)
column14:
weâve compiled the numbers and their visualizations to illustrate the massive role Twitter played for fans since the event began on November 20.

column16: watching highlights
column17: predicting the outcome of the next match
column18: or celebrating the star players

fans came to Twitter to discuss all aspects of the game.Â

column3: "title": "Twitter Blue is back. And gold checkmarks are here!"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Twitter Blue is back. And gold checkmarks are here!
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8:
12 December 2022
Link copied successfully
Twitter Blue is back! 
Starting today
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re re-enabling Twitter Blue sign ups on iOS and web. Twitter Blue subscribers will get access to subscriber-only features* such as Edit Tweet
column10: 1080p video uploads and reader mode. Subscribers will also receive a blue checkmark after their accounts are reviewed to ensure they meet all of our requirements
column11: including our rules against impersonation. Accounts found to be breaking our rules may be suspended without a refund.\nTwitter Blue is $8/month on web
column12: and $11/month for those who sign up on iOS. Subscribers who sign up on one platform will have Twitter Blue access on all supported platforms (iOS
column13: Android
column14: and web).\u00c2\u00a0Existing Twitter Blue subscribers will be able to upgrade
column15: cancel
column16: or auto-renew their subscription at the new price. Prices may vary by region. We plan to offer subscriptions on Android soon.\nSubscribing to Twitter Blue is now available in the United States
column17: Canada
column18: Australia
column19: New Zealand and the United Kingdom. We plan to roll out Blue to more countries soon.\nIn addition to reviewing all accounts at sign up
column20: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re taking a number of other steps to detect and prevent impersonation. Subscribers who change their profile information
column21: including display name
column22: profile photo
column23: and username (@handle)
column24: will temporarily lose their blue checkmark until those changes are reviewed by Twitter. Accounts created within the last 90 days
column25: inactive accounts
column26: accounts without a verified phone number
column27: and accounts with recent changes to their profile information will not be able to subscribe to Twitter Blue at this time.\nGold checkmarks and more\nIn addition to these changes
column28: starting today
column29: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re replacing the \u00e2\u0080\u009cofficial\u00e2\u0080\u009d label with a gold checkmark on some business accounts on Twitter. Soon
column30:
weâll also add a gray checkmark for government and multilateral accounts. Learn more about profile labels on Twitter here.
You can now apply for early access to Verification for Organizations.Â Apply nowÂ or read moreÂ here.
Thank you to our Twitter Blue subscribers and our advertisers for your feedback and support!
*Note: We continue to improve Twitter Blue. Subscriber-only features may be subject to change and some features are currently platform specific.

column3: "title": "Twitter 2.0: Our continued commitment to the public conversation "
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Twitter 2.0: Our continued commitment to the public conversation 
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 30 November 2022\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s mission is to promote and protect the public conversation--to be the town square of the internet. We have always understood that to reach this goal we must give everyone the power to create and share ideas and information
column9: instantly without barriers. Today
column10: we are a new company embarking on a new chapter
column11: but our steadfast commitment to this mission has not changed. In fact
column12: we are better positioned to realize our ambitions than ever before.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve always understood that our business and revenue are interconnected with our mission; they rely on each other. Brand safety is only possible when human safety is the top priority. All of this remains true today.\nWhat has changed
column13: however
column14: is our approach to experimentation. As you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen over the past several weeks
column15: Twitter is embracing public testing. We believe that this open and transparent approach to innovation is healthy
column16: as it enables us to move faster and gather user feedback in real-time. We believe that a service of this importance will benefit from feedback at scale
column17: and that there is value in being open about our experiments and what we are learning. We do all of this work with one goal in mind: to improve Twitter for our customers
column18: partners
column19: and the people who use it across the world.\nAs we carry out this work
column20: we want to assure you of a few things:\u00c2\u00a0\nFirst
column21: none of our policies have changed. Our approach to policy enforcement will rely more heavily on de-amplification of violative content: freedom of speech
column22: but not freedom of reach.\nOur Trust & Safety team continues its diligent work to keep the platform safe from hateful conduct
column23: abusive behavior
column24: and any violation of Twitter's rules. The team remains strong and well-resourced
column25: and automated detection plays an increasingly important role in eliminating abuse.\nWhen urgent events manifest on the platform
column26: we ensure that all content moderators have the guidance they need to find and address violative content.\u00c2\u00a0\nAs we improve our policies and processes
column27: bad actors will also develop new methods of disruption. This is not new. Our team of experts is constantly adapting to identify and defuse threats
column28: and we are proud of our early results: impressions on violative content are down over the past month
column29: despite the growth in overall usage on the platform.\nFinally
column30: as we embark on this new journey
column31: we will make mistakes
column32: we will learn
column33: and we will also get things right. Throughout
column34: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll communicate openly with our users and customers
column35: to get and share your feedback as we build.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe remain committed to providing a safe
column36: inclusive
column37: entertaining
column38: and informative experience for everyone. We will continue to be transparent as we move through this transition period. And we will listen to you
column39:
the people who make Twitter what it is: the town square of the internet.Â 
The Twitter Team
Â

column3: "title": "Twitter\u2019s curation program with AFP expands to LATAM
column7: "author": ""
column8: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/product/2022/twitter-curation-program-afp-expands-spain-latam-us"
column9: "post_text": "Product\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s curation program with AFP expands to LATAM
column10: Spain
column11: and the US\nThursday
column12:
27 October 2022
Link copied successfully
Estamos ampliando nuestros esfuerzos para identificar y elevar informaciÃ³n creÃ­ble en Twitter.
Itâs true: weâre expanding our efforts to identify and elevate credible information on Twitter.
Earlier this month
column13: we told you about Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s curation program with AFP in Brazil. This collaboration
column14: which began as a pilot in 2021
column15: helps our Curation Team add context to the wide range of Portuguese-language topics and conversations happening on Twitter.\nNow we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re expanding the scope of our work with AFP to include Spanish-language content curation in LATAM
column16: Spain
column17: and the US.\u00c2\u00a0\nWith the help of AFP
column18: our Curation Team is now able to better scale and provide informative context on timely topics being discussed on Twitter in Spanish. We can also detect topics that are generating widespread interest in a more proactive way
column19: including those that could potentially generate misleading information.\nHow and where does AFP curated content appear?\nJust like our content curated by other trusted news agencies such as Reuters and The Associated Press
column20:
the content curated by AFP teams Latin America (AFP Factual for Spanish and AFP Checamos for Portuguese) is visible in the form of Moments that appear in various places throughout Twitter. These include: 
Trends
Explore tab
Search
Prompts
Tweet labels
Another way we address misinformation via our Curation program is by publishing âdebunksâ relevant to the main misleading narratives circulating on Twitter. According to internal data
column21:
more than 9 million people per day come across at least one of these debunks while navigating our service.Â 
You may also see the information in Tweets posted by AFP or our other trusted curation partners.
Adding helpful context to Twitter
Our goal is to help people on Twitter easily access credible
column22: contextualized information and make informed decisions about the content they choose to engage with. The expanded collaboration with AFP is the latest in a series of ongoing efforts to help bring us closer to that goal. \nEarlier this month
column23: we announced that the visibility of Birdwatch notes was expanding to everyone in the US. These notes are written and selected by people on Twitter
column24: for people on Twitter
column25: to add helpful context to Tweets in a transparent and collaborative way. Alongside AP and Reuters
column26:
AFP will help us evaluate Birdwatch notes in the US to understand how the service is performing.
Keep your eyes here or follow @Birdwatch for more updates.

column3: "title": "Designing accessible sounds: The story behind our new chirps"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Designing accessible sounds: The story behind our new chirps
          
          
            and
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8:
26 October 2022
Link copied successfully
You may have noticed some new sounds on Twitter recently â things like the âchirpsâ you hear when refreshing your home timeline or requesting to speak in a Twitter Space.Â 
Thereâs a reason for that.Â 
As we work to improve the accessibility of our service
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re updating Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s sounds to help make them pleasing to more people
column10:
including those with sensory sensitivities. Hereâs a quick look at whatâs going on.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Designing new sounds together
Designing new
column11: more accessible sounds requires disability representation throughout the design process. Thankfully
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve had a lot of help.\u00c2\u00a0 \nOur neurodiverse team started by conducting research interviews and usability testing with people who self-identified as neurodivergent to better understand what kinds of sounds do and do not trigger sensory sensitivities. Guided by their input
column13: we got to work with the audio experts at Listen creating a growing collection of new Twitter sounds designed to meet the following criteria: Promoting accessibility for those with sensory sensitivities Blending the organic and digital Keeping sounds short and smooth Attracting attention without being distracting You can check some of them out for yourself below. This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. Your browser does not support the video element. Play Play Pause Seek 0% buffered 00:00 Current time 00:00 Duration 00:00 Toggle Mute Volume More sounds
column14: and where to hear them\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re happy to say that the first batch of new sounds for timeline refreshes and Twitter Spaces are now available globally on iOS and Android devices. Our design team is also working on additional audio updates for things like when you send a new Tweet or get a notification
column15: so keep your ears open for more new sounds to come!\u00c2\u00a0 \nOf course
column16: try as we might
column17: not all sounds are for everyone. If you prefer a silent Twitter experience
column18: you can toggle sound effects on and off by following these steps:\nOn iOS: Settings and Privacy > Accessibility
column19: display
column20: and languages > Display and Sound. Toggle Sound Effects off\nOn Android: Settings and Privacy > Accessibility
column21:
display and languages > Display. Toggle Sound effects off

column3: "title": "A meme is born: How people are taking mixed media viral on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
A meme is born: How people are taking mixed media viral on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 21 October 2022\nLink copied successfully\nFull disclosure: when Twitter releases a new feature into the wild
column9: we don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t know exactly how people are going to use it.\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s true.\u00c2\u00a0\nSure
column10: we have an idea. Usually it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a pretty good idea. But we can only ever give people what amounts to a new canvas to work with. They (and you) are the ones who ultimately get to decide what goes on it. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s the beauty of a public conversation that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s open to everyone \u00e2\u0080\u0094 it leaves plenty of room for surprises and creativity.\u00c2\u00a0\nAnd there may be no better example of this than mixed media
column11: a new feature that lets people mix and match up to 4 images
column12: videos
column13: and GIFs in a single Tweet.\u00c2\u00a0\nA meme is (re)born \nAlmost immediately after we announced the global release of mixed media in early October
column14: people on Twitter got to work creating things like side-by-side reactions using one photo and one video or four-panel memes composed of three images and either a video or a GIF.\u00c2\u00a0 \nTo see this in action
column15:
look no further than (of all things) the revived âPope Francis Holding Thingsâ meme that dates all the way back to 2013.
Who saw that coming?
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

People and brands get creative with mixed media 
Of course
column16: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not just one kind of mixed media meme (mixed meme-ia?) that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s getting all the attention.\u00c2\u00a0 \nPeople
column17: creators
column18: and brands on Twitter are experimenting with the feature in a variety of clever ways to rack up millions of views and engagements. For brands that rely on Twitter to express a more witty and playful side
column19: mixed media provides another way to jump on existing trends and even create new ones. And honestly
column20: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re absolutely loving it.\u00c2\u00a0\nKeep the creative ideas coming
column21:
and weâll keep developing more ways to help you share them with the world.

column3: "title": "Taylor Swift\u2019s \u201cMidnights\u201d reveals how music fans show up on Twitter"
column7: "post_text": "Insights\nTaylor Swift\u00e2\u0080\u0099s \u00e2\u0080\u009cMidnights\u00e2\u0080\u009d reveals how music fans show up on Twitter\nThursday
column8:
20 October 2022
Link copied successfully
Music isâ¦kind of a big deal on Twitter.
Every day
column9: more than 30 million Tweets are published about music around the world. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s more than 20
column10: 000 every minute. A couple thousand have probably even been added since you started reading this article.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn honor of Taylor Swift\u00e2\u0080\u0099s massively anticipated Midnights album
column11:
we thought weâd give you a peek under the hood at the different ways music fans (like âSwiftiesâ) show up on Twitter for their favorite artists.Â 
And scroll down for updated numbers on how "Swifties" have responded to MidnightsÂ on Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The Swift Report 
Thereâs a kind of poetic logic to examining music on Twitter through a âTaylor Swiftâ lens. Weâve quite literally grown up together â her self-titled debut album was released in 2006
column12: the same year Twitter was created. \nSince 2010
column13: Taylor Swift has been mentioned in 329 million Tweets. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s an average of more than 75
column14: 114 Tweets every day for the past
column15: oh
column17: 380 days. In fact
column18: when\u00c2\u00a0Red (Taylor\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Version)\u00c2\u00a0was released in November 2021
column19: there were more Tweets about Taylor Swift than about football and basketball combined.\n\u00f0\u009f\u0098\u00b3\u00f0\u009f\u0098\u00b3\u00f0\u009f\u0098\u00b3\nSwifties are loud and proud on Twitter
column20: too. The word \u00e2\u0080\u009cSwiftie\u00e2\u0080\u009d or \u00e2\u0080\u009cSwifties\u00e2\u0080\u009d has been Tweeted more than 18 million times over the past 12 years
column21: usually accompanied by emojis like the red scarf (\u00f0\u009f\u00a7\u00a3) which saw a 25x increase in use on the day\u00c2\u00a0All Too Well (Taylor\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Version)\u00c2\u00a0was released.\u00c2\u00a0\nSpeaking of\u00c2\u00a0All Too Well (Taylor\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Version)
column22:
since 2019 itâs the most Tweeted about Taylor Swift song alongsideÂ Love Story (Taylorâs Version)Â andÂ Wildest Dreams (Taylorâs Version).
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Swifties' response to Midnights
The response to Midnights from fans on Twitter has been
column23: well
column24: swift.\u00c2\u00a0\nSince the album's release
column25: there have been about 5 million Tweets about it
column26: and nearly 4 million of those were published by the end of October 22. To put that in some perspective
column27: Taylor Swift generated 2x more Tweet volume than NFL football on Thursday
column28: October 20!\nFans can't get enough of three songs in particular: Anti-Hero
column29: Lavender Haze
column30: and Snow on the Beach
column31: which make up the Top 3 most Tweeted-about songs since the release of Midnights. And there's lots of love to go around for Taylor's collaborators
column32: as well. Mentions of Jack Antonoff
column33: for example
column34: grew 14x compared to the day before the album release!\nMusic: The largest community on Twitter \nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s true: music is the largest community on Twitter. With 441 million unique followers
column35: people are more likely to follow a music-related account than any other type of account on Twitter. \nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s no surprise
column36: then
column37: that major music releases tend to be top events on Twitter. Take Harry Styles
column38: whose Harry\u00e2\u0080\u0099s House album was Tweeted about more than 10 million times around the time of its release in May 2022. The conversation around music spikes on Fridays
column39: when new albums usually drop.\nSo what will the conversation look like this Friday when Midnights is finally released? Keep your eyes here to find out
column40: and follow @TwitterMusic to keep up with what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening with your favorite artists
column41: albums
column42:
and more!
