column3: "title": "When natural disasters happen
column4: Twitter can be used to help. Here\u2019s how"
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/company/2022/when-natural-disasters-happen-twitter-can-help-heres-how"
column8: "post_text": "Company\nWhen natural disasters happen
column9:
Twitter can be used to help. Hereâs how
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column10: 13 October 2022\nLink copied successfully\nOver the years
column11: Twitter has become a critical communication tool for responding to natural disasters.\nOur teams have a longstanding commitment to working alongside global partners and developers to share important information
column12: provide real-time updates
column13: facilitate relief efforts
column14: and much more. We also take steps to address misleading information that can surface during these crises.\u00c2\u00a0\nTo help ensure our service remains a resource for as many people as possible
column15:
weâve put together a snapshot of some of the ways Twitter can be used to help during natural disasters.
Supporting preparedness and increasing awareness
Itâs important to raise awareness about natural disasters before they happen. Thatâs why Twitter regularly collaborates with organizations to keep people informed about and prepared for extreme weather and other potential emergencies. 
In September
column16: for example
column17:
Twitter Australia partnered with the Australian Red Cross on a Timeline and Trend Takeover campaign designed to help people prepare for weather-related emergencies. The #EmergencyReady campaign was viewed nearly 5 million times in 24 hours.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Being prepared for disasters means no one is left behind or overlooked. Twitter Australia generously provided national visibility of key safety messages about disaster preparedness
column18: at a critical time of year for all Australians.\nAndrew Coghlan\nHead of Emergency Services
column19:
Australian Red Cross
Twitter partners frequently with crisis response organizationsÂ  all over the world to help enhance the capacity of those communicating with populations affected by natural disasters.
Sharing information and best practices
When it comes to staying safe during natural disasters
column20: Twitter can be a powerful resource for sharing critical information. \nIn the wake of the 2017 Puebla earthquake in Mexico
column21: for example
column22:
we collaborated with the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) to put together a shareable list of best practices for communicating on Twitter during times of crisis. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Similarly in 2021
column23: as Japan approached the 10-year anniversary of the T\u00c5\u008dhoku earthquake and tsunami
column24: our team shared a set of illustrations with important information about how best to communicate on Twitter in an emergency situation.\u00c2\u00a0\nThis year we went further
column25:
organizing Twitter Spaces events with local Japanese media and other social media platforms to discuss reporting strategies for disaster prevention and readiness. We also created a custom origami crane emoji and hashtags to encourage participation in critical conversations around the subject.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Amplifying credible information using search prompts
When people search for keywords on Twitter related to active emergency situations
column26: we work to ensure they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re met with authoritative and credible information first.\u00c2\u00a0 \nSearch prompts are one important way we do this. When heavy flooding occurred in Pakistan beginning in June 2022
column27: Twitter launched a #ThereIsHelp prompt to redirect our Pakistani audience to an emergency helpline at the Pakistani Red Crescent Society. Similarly
column28: during this year\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Taal Volcano eruption in the Philippines and Typhoon Noru in Southeast Asia
column29:
search prompts were created to help quickly deliver credible information to people on Twitter impacted by these extreme weather events.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Organizing credible information in a centralized place
During natural disasters
column30: Twitter has tools such as Moments and Lists that can be used to create a centralized source of credible information.\u00c2\u00a0 \nIn anticipation of 2022\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Hurricane Ian in the United States
column31: for example
column32: a Twitter Moment was created to elevate public service information as well as amplify announcements from local law enforcement and emergency services. Moments can also be used to address and correct misleading information
column33: like when comments on hurricane preparedness made by the US president in August 2021 were mistakenly attributed to Hurricane Ian.\nIn addition to Moments
column34: Twitter Lists can be used to collect and quickly share information about natural disasters and emergency services. In Japan
column35: for example
column36: a dedicated TwitterLifeline List has been created highlighting the Twitter accounts of prefectures
column37: crisis organizations
column38:
and public transportation services. Twitter MÃ©xico recently published a list highlighting earthquake-related Tweets in real time.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Enabling partner initiatives and developer-built tools
Thereâs a long history of individuals and organizations finding innovative ways to harness the power of Twitter.Â  
For example
column39: in India
column40: partners in the medical industry came together to create @BloodDonorsIndia which amplifies the blood donation requests of individual patients dealing with a range of health problems. The account\u00e2\u0080\u0099s 1.2 million followers are able to reach potential donors that otherwise would have gone unreached
column41: resulting in eight lives a day being saved through its efforts according to its own reporting.\nIn another example
column42:
developers in California used our API to create an automated Twitter account that has been documenting earthquakes in the San Francisco Bay area since 2009.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitter also builds data partnerships to better understand the conversations happening on the platform. Most recently
column43:
we analyzed four extreme weather events to better determine patterns of those affected by natural disasters and build predictions for future events.Â Â 
Weâre continually working to improve the ways we help communities prepare for and communicate during emergencies. Keep your eyes on @Twitter for the latest updates.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The main reason I like [Twitter] as a source of data is that it integrates not just a measure of typical exposure â which is âDid the water come onto the land in a place where it wasnât supposed to be? [It also] measures âWhat are people noticing? What are people talking about?â Twitter can give us this aggregated measure of what those social consequences of that particular flood are.
Dr. Frances Moore
Assistant Professor in the Department of Environmental Science and Policy at University of California
column44:
Davis

column3: "title": "Inclusion
column7: "topic": "Company"
column8: "author": "James Loduca (he/him)"
column9: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/company/2022/inclusion-diversity-equity-accessibility-accessibility-October-20222"
column10: "post_text": "Company\nInclusion
column11: Diversity
column12: Equity
column13:
Accessibility Q3 2022: Accessibility
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column14: 11 October 2022\nLink copied successfully\nAs the seasons begin to change around the world
column15: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been reflecting a lot on our Inclusion
column16: Diversity
column17: Equity
column18: and Accessibility (IDEA) journey at Twitter. The wins
column19: the learning moments
column20: and the opportunities still to come. Despite the hurdles \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and there have been plenty \u00e2\u0080\u0094 you won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t find a company or group of employees more committed to this work. One of the things that makes this place so special is that it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s made up of individuals who show up each day with one powerful thing in common: the belief that we get to do great things with great people. We care deeply \u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00e2\u0080\u0093 about Twitter
column21: and about each other. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s what fuels the work
column22: and it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s what drives us toward becoming the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s most inclusive
column23: diverse
column24: equitable
column25:
and accessible tech company. And thatâs never changing.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In fact
column26: we remain more committed than ever. This quarter was a testament. As progress towards our diversity goals slows
column27: it can be dispiriting. But not at Twitter. We recognize that this work isn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t a moment in time; it's a continuous
column28: conscious effort that requires us to be unwavering toward our goal. Come what may
column29: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re firm in where we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re going. Sometimes
column30:
that just means being flexible with our route. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
So we flexed. We doubled down in areas that drive inclusion and where we knew weâd have immediate impact for our Tweeps. We built a framework for belonging
column31: zoomed in on our equity work
column32: and supercharged our accessibility efforts. And today
column33: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re proud to share more about our accessibility journey. Ultimately
column34: accessibility is what empowers everyone to use their unique strengths and knowledge to do their best work
column35:
and its cornerstone in building the Twitter â both the product and the workplace â that we love.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Letâs take a lookâ¦
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Forming our Accessibility Center of Excellence
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We recognized early on that having a centralized source of expertise was vital in moving towards a fully accessible Twitter. In February 2021
column36: we established our Accessibility Center of Excellence (COE) with Gurpreet Kaur
column37: Head of Global Accessibility
column38: at its helm. The Accessibility COE\u00e2\u0080\u0099s impact was immediate and widespread; working with partners across the business
column39: they set clear goals
column40: developed policies
column41: and worked to improve the way people experience Twitter \u00e2\u0080\u0093 in real life as Tweeps and on our service. Early wins included launch of new standards for accessible meetings and events
column42: introduction of an internal accessibility hub to share best practices and resources with Tweeps eager to lean in
column43:
and a new process to evaluate accessibility for third party suppliers.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In 2022
column44: we formally made accessibility part of our Inclusion & Diversity team
column45: expanding our scope \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and the opportunity for impact. From product development to marketing and communication strategies
column46: to legal and people standards
column47:
weâve made significant strides and are excited by the work weâve accomplished so far. But weâve only just begun to scratch the surface and thereâs much more to do.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Improving the way we work â a Global Accessibility Policy
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
This work is global. Solving for the needs of Tweeps and the people who use our service anywhere and everywhere is how weâll make Twitter truly accessible. With this in mind
column48: our accessibility team kicked off work on a new Global Accessibility Policy in the first half of the year
column49:
designed to support our IDEA goals and improve our company in a way that hadnât been done before.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The Global Accessibility Policy serves as a framework to ensure that we consistently participate in
column50: influence
column51:
and deliver accessible experiences and products to everyone around the world. It will ensure that any net-new product and internal tool launches or purchases prioritize accessibility for Tweeps or customers with disabilities. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Hereâs how:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
At Twitter:Â The policy facilitates accessible and inclusive working experiences for all Tweeps with disabilities. These virtual and in-person experiences include recruitment
column52: onboarding
column53: meetings
column54: career development tools
column55: training
column56: in our offices and more. \nOn Twitter: The planned policies will facilitate making our products
column57: services
column58: and communications (Tweets
column59: marketing campaigns
column60:
etc.) accessible to people who use our service.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Commitment and action are critical to advancing this policy. This year
column61: our Accessibility COE piloted the policy with three key organizations: Information Technology & Core Applications (IT)
column62: People & People Systems
column63: and Procurement. Additionally
column64: work on a Product policy is currently underway. Taking our Global Policy further
column65:
these org-specific policies are tailored for application and relevance:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
IT & Core Tech: Establish tools and processes to support accessible development
column66: including design systems
column67: manual testing
column68: and automated testing. \nPeople: Ensure that working experiences (from home
column69: from office
column70: or both) are built so that they are inclusive to people with disabilities. Tweep experiences (benefits
column71: compensation
column72:
recruitment) are inclusive to people with disabilities. 
Procurement: Ensure that all net-new purchases of software that impacts all Tweeps and/or Customers are accessible to people with disabilities. 
Product: Integrate accessibility best practices into every phase of the product development process and meet the latest published version of the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâre also proud to support Procure Access
column73:
a global cross-industry effort to grow the number of companies with accessible procurement programs. Weâve signed the Procure Access statement as a step to advance technology accessibility in our company and throughout the world.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Through our internal and external partnerships
column74: training programs
column75: and best practices documentation
column76: the Global Accessibility Policy will weave accessibility throughout our core business functions to increase efficiency and impact
column77:
without loss of velocity. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Continuing to learn â accessibility-focused courses
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâve said it before: this work takes all of us. No individual or team can carry us forward alone
column78:
and we know that our new Accessibility Policy will be most successful when supported by the understanding of both the âwhyâ and the âhowâ behind accessibility and disability inclusion at Twitter. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We built three foundational accessibility courses for Tweeps
column79: pulling in best practices and the latest research from our partners at Disability:IN and Business Disability Forum. This is intentionally \u00e2\u0080\u009c101\u00e2\u0080\u009d content to help broaden and expand awareness and understanding. To keep us accountable
column80:
the learnings are embedded in the roadmaps and goals of leaders across the business.Â Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Foundations of Accessibility: People come from different backgrounds and a variety of experiences and abilities. Accessibility is about removing barriers so everyone has fair and equal access. Take this course to broaden your perspective and understanding of the different ways and adaptations people may make for accessibility.
Disability Awareness: Thereâs no guidebook that tells us how to interact with people who have disabilities. But
column81: this course is for anyone\u00c2\u00a0\u00e2\u0080\u0094 with or without a disability\u00c2\u00a0\u00e2\u0080\u0094 who wants to learn basics on how to connect more effectively with people who have disabilities. So
column82: come with us on this journey to explore how to be more aware
column84: and more inclusive.\nPositive Communication: Get a 101 on positive language
column85: which is crucial in inclusive communication. Plus
column86:
hear first-hand experiences from Tweeps who have disabilities. Let's continue our journey to be more intentional and build an accessible foundation for all.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
And because we believe in sharing
column87: these courses have been added to our #UntilWeAllBelong toolkit
column88: available to everyone outside of Twitter too. Take a look
column89:
and join in on the journey.Â

column3: "title": "Helpful Birdwatch notes are now visible to everyone on Twitter in the US"
column7: "post_text": "Product\nHelpful Birdwatch notes are now visible to everyone on Twitter in the US\nThursday
column8: 6 October 2022\nLink copied successfully\nAs of November 2022
column9: Birdwatch is now\u00c2\u00a0Community Notes.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been\u00c2\u00a0piloting our Birdwatch program for over a year to bring helpful context to Tweets in a transparent and collaborative way.\nNow for the first time
column10: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re expanding the visibility of Birdwatch notes \u00e2\u0080\u0094 written and selected by people on Twitter
column11: for people on Twitter \u00e2\u0080\u0094 to everyone in the US.\nStarting today
column12: if you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re using Twitter in the US
column13:
youâll begin to see some Tweets accompanied by a note containing relevant information thatâs been rated âHelpfulâ by Birdwatch contributors. Most notes contain additional sources that can be clicked for an even deeper dive into a subject or conversation.
You'll also have the ability to rate the notes you see to help us understand if theyâre helpful or not.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Keeping Birdwatch notes helpful for everyone
Birdwatch is made up of independent contributors
column14: and individual notes are never written by Twitter
column15: Inc. This is intentional
column16: as it helps ensure our efforts to address potentially misleading information are informed by a diverse group of people who use our service. \nThe program is designed to surface notes that are informative and helpful to as many people as possible thanks in large part to what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s known as a bridging algorithm. Here\u00e2\u0080\u0099s how it works:\u00c2\u00a0\nIn order to be shown on a Tweet
column17: Birdwatch notes need to be found helpful by people who have tended to disagree in their past ratings. This means the algorithm takes into account not only how many contributors rated a note as Helpful or Not Helpful
column18:
but also whether people who rated it seem to come from different perspectives. Check out our Birdwatch guide for more info on this.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In many online spaces
column19: especially those using engagement-based ranking
column20: divisive content can be more likely to go viral. Bridging-based ranking systems aim to overcome this 'bias toward division'. Birdwatch\u00e2\u0080\u0099s use of bridging to elevate context found helpful by people that tend to disagree is an exciting step toward a better internet \u00e2\u0080\u0094 one that supports those building common ground.\nAviv Ovadya\nTechnology and Public Purpose Fellow
column21: Belfer Center at Harvard Kennedy School (2021-2022)\n\u00e2\u0080\u008e@metaviv\u00e2\u0080\u008e\nAdditionally
column22: to keep the quality of notes high and encourage contributors to write and rate notes in a thoughtful way
column23:
we developed aÂ Birdwatch onboarding processÂ through which new contributors earn the ability to write notes by consistently rating other contributorsâ notes and reliably identifying those that are Helpful and Not Helpful.Â 
Expanding Birdwatch based on positive results
Weâre opting to expand the visibility of Birdwatch notes to everyone in the US based on research that indicates the program is helpful and informative to people who hold different points of view. 
According to the results of four surveys run at different times between August
column24: 2021 and August
column26: a person who sees a Birdwatch note is
column27: on average
column28: 20-40% less likely to agree with the substance of a potentially misleading Tweet than someone who sees the Tweet alone. Survey participation ranged from 3
column29: 000 to more than 19
column30: 000 participants
column31: and the results were consistent throughout the course of the year
column32: even as news and Tweet topics changed.\nWe also see that Birdwatch informs sharing behavior. Analyzing our internal data
column33: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve found that a person on Twitter who sees a note is
column34: on average
column35: 15-35% less likely to choose to Like or Retweet a Tweet than someone who sees the Tweet alone.\nIn our most recent survey
column36: notes were found to be informative regardless of a person's self-identified political party affiliation \u00e2\u0080\u0094 there was no statistically significant difference in average informativeness across party ID.\u00c2\u00a0\nAn open and transparent process\nWe believe that earning trust starts with transparency. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made the Birdwatch algorithm\u00c2\u00a0publicly available on GitHub
column37: along with all the data that powers it
column38: so anyone can audit
column39: analyze
column40: or suggest improvements. Whether you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re a researcher
column41: a hobbyist
column42: or simply curious
column43: you can explore and run the Birdwatch algorithm on your own computer using the guide link shared above.\u00c2\u00a0 \nYou can also keep up to date with all things Birdwatch by following our official\u00c2\u00a0@Birdwatch\u00c2\u00a0Twitter account
column44:
orÂ click this linkÂ to apply to become a Birdwatch contributor and help improve the health of conversations on Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter

column9: "post_text": "Product\nIntroducing mixed media: Videos
column10: images
column11:
and GIFs together in one Tweet
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column12: 5 October 2022\nLink copied successfully\nSometimes you need more than one kind of media to express yourself the way you want. Don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t worry
column13: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve got you.\u00c2\u00a0\nToday Twitter is introducing a new way to share different types of visual content \u00e2\u0080\u0094 videos
column14: images
column15:
and GIFs â together in a single Tweet.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Adding âmixedâ media to a Tweet is simple and straightforward. When composing a Tweet
column16: tap the \u00e2\u0080\u009cMedia\u00e2\u0080\u009d or \u00e2\u0080\u009cGIF\u00e2\u0080\u009d icons and select the content you want to share (and don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t forget to add descriptive text to make your images more accessible). That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s it!\n You can add up to four videos
column17: images
column18: and/or GIFs per Tweet. The update is currently available on iOS and Android
column19:
however Tweets with different content types can be consumed on all platforms.
Helping creators express themselves
Weâre always looking for new and exciting ways to help creators share more and be seen.
Mixing different types of visual content together in a single Tweet allows creators to express themselves beyond 280 characters and gives them more ways to tell their story.
This Tweet is unavailable

Really loving this new tool here on Twitter. It has opened up a whole new world of opportunity to share my work & the behind the scenes. Excited to see how creatives can capitalize on this feature and share more of their process moving forward. Stoked to see Twitter caring about creatives and how they can share their work through this medium.
Twitter Creator

Iâm excited to use this feature to add some more interactive depth to the behind-the-scenes moments I share on Twitter.

Making Twitter the best place to share media
This update is the latest example of how weâre working to make Twitter the easiest and most convenient place to share images

It complements the rollout of two new video products \u00e2\u0080\u0094 full-screen videos and a new video carousel in the Explore tab \u00e2\u0080\u0094 that help make it easier than ever for people to find and watch what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening on Twitter.\nKeep your eyes on our blog for more upcoming launches
column23: or click\u00c2\u00a0here\u00c2\u00a0to start mixing up your timeline and telling stories with text

"post_text": "Product
New video products make it easier to watch whatâs happening on X
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 29 September 2022\nLink copied successfully\nVideos are a huge part of the public conversation
column9: and they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re one of the most engaging ways people can express themselves online. In fact
column10: videos shared on X receive billions of combined views every year (that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s billions with a \u00e2\u0080\u009cb\u00e2\u0080\u009d).\nTo help make it easier to find and watch what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re rolling out two new updates to how you experience videos on X starting today. Here\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a quick look at what you can expect
column12: and how to use them.\u00c2\u00a0\nImmersive viewing and easy discovery\nX's updated immersive media viewer expands videos to full screen with a single click
column13: allowing you to easily access the full
column14: immersive viewing experience. To activate it
column15: simply tap/click on a video in the X app. \nOnce the video has been launched in full screen mode
column16: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made video discovery easier as well. Just scroll up to start browsing more engaging video content. If you want to exit the viewer and go back to the original post
column17:
click the back arrow in the top left corner.

With our new video carousel

you can now easily find more videos you like alongside posts and Trends that might interest you. Just open the Explore tab to discover some of the most popular videos being shared on.Â

column3: "title": "Our approach to the 2022 elections in Brazil and partnership with AFP"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nOur approach to the 2022 elections in Brazil and partnership with AFP\nWednesday
column8: 28 September 2022\nLink copied successfully\nThe Brazilian presidential elections are happening
column9: and Twitter is working to encourage safe and informed civic participation.\nTo do that
column10: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve rolled out a series of products and initiatives designed to make credible information more accessible
column11: provide real-time insights and context on important issues
column12: highlight relevant conversations happening on Twitter
column13:
and more.
Here are some of the things weâve done to promote healthy and informed Twitter conversations in Brazil.
Seeing whatâs happening in the elections
Twitter has introduced a new âEleiÃ§Ãµes 2022â section in our Explore tab ðthatâs regularly updated with the latest news and information related to the election.Â  
The tab is localized to include regional office races in 10 states across Brazil. For those who have Twitter notifications enabled
column14:
we send notices whenever an important moment or conversation around the election is taking place.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâve also made it easier to identify candidates running for President
column15: Vice-President
column16: Senator
column17: and Governor by including easily visible labels on the profile page of each candidate\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Twitter account.\nFocusing on civic integrity\nTwitter created our Civic Integrity Policy to prevent our service from being used to interfere in elections or other civic acts. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s an additional layer of protection whose purpose is to ensure that the public debate taking place on Twitter doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t harm people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s right or ability to vote. This extra policy is applied for a limited period of time before
column18: during
column19: and after an election \u00e2\u0080\u0094 an interval determined by consulting with civic integrity experts. \nWith the Civic Integrity Policy in place in Brazil
column20:
Twitter will take measures in relation to content:
Intended to intimidate people from participating in civic acts or to mislead them about how to take part in them
That makes any false or misleading statements undermining public confidence in the election
That intentionally indicates false or improper affiliation
column21: own or of third parties
column22: to candidates
column23: parties and other institutions\nDepending on the severity of the violation
column24: corrective measures may include tagging or removing the Tweet or even suspending the account.\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important to note that this policy does not cover all types of political content. Its focus is on misleading information that may harm the progress
column25: popular participation
column26: and/or outcome of a democratic electoral process.\nKeeping people informed\nTo help people find answers to their most common questions about the elections
column27: we teamed up with Politize!
column28: a civil society organization focused on political education. Anyone who sends a Direct Message (DM) to @Politize! will receive information that helps answer questions about the 2022 elections
column29: politics in general
column30: tips on how to spot fake news and have healthy conversations
column31:
and suggestions for reliable data sources. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâve also partnered with Brazilâs Superior Electoral Court (TSE) to create a series of search prompts that appear as the first result of Twitter searches related to the election
column32: among other initiatives. These prompts direct people to the TSE\u00e2\u0080\u0099s official and reliable information on things like electronic voting machines
column33: voter registration cards
column34: and more.\nCurating reliable content\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to expanding people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s access to reliable content related to the elections. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re making \u00e2\u0080\u009cpre-bunk\u00e2\u0080\u009d Moments available \u00e2\u0080\u0094 Tweets with credible information that are presented in Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Explore tab
column35: Trends
column36: and search area. \nPre-bunks bring factual context to the most common misleading claims related to elections thanks to our collaboration with trusted national and regional partners
column37: allowing us to preemptively inform people of potential misinformation that may be circulating during the electoral period.\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Curation team also provides \u00e2\u0080\u009cdebunk\u00e2\u0080\u009d Moments to clarify
column38: contrast
column39: or contextualize misinformation narratives. Specific criteria are taken into account for both pre-bunks and debunks
column40: including large volumes of conversations on a public health topic
column41: electoral processes
column42:
or involving manipulated media.
Encouraging participation in the conversation
We know that the 2022 elections are important to Brazilians. The topic was Tweeted about more than 56 million times in the first eight months of 2022 alone.Â  
To help encourage people to engage in the conversation
column43: Twitter has introduced a series of unique emojis around the elections in Brazil. These emojis appear whenever popular hashtags such as #Ele\u00c3\u00a7\u00c3\u00b5es2022
column44: #VoteConsciente
column45:
and #ProjetoEleiÃ§Ã£o are used.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâll be adding in additional hashtag-prompted emojis around specific events such as debates and on election day itself.Â 
Beyond the elections: Twitterâs partnership with AFP
Healthy conversations are informed by reliable information.Â  
Thatâs why Twitter has been partnering with AFP
column46: a leading global news agency
column47: to help elevate credible news and information in Portuguese. The collaboration started as a pilot in 2021 and has recently been renewed for a one-year term. It specifically focuses on Brazil
column48:
enabling our Curation Team to increase the speed and scale of our efforts to add context to the wide range of global topics and conversations happening on Twitter.
AFP has joined trusted news organizations Reuters and The Associated Press in working with Twitter to identify and elevate credible information. We then show this curated information to people in various locations throughout our service to give context to some of the most important and talked-about issues as they happen. These locations include:
Trends
The Explore tab
Search
Prompts
Tweet labels
Learn moreÂ 
For more on what weâre doing to encourage civic participation in Brazil
column49:
check out our Portuguese-language articles here and here. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

#OnlyOnTwitter

column3: "title": "The Twitter Moderation Research Consortium is now open to researchers"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
The Twitter Moderation Research Consortium is now open to researchers
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8:
22 September 2022
Link copied successfully
Twitter is committed to data-driven transparency.Â 
In 2018
column9: this commitment led us to publish the first comprehensive public archive of data related to state-backed information operations. Then
column10: earlier this year
column11: we launched the Twitter Moderation Research Consortium (TMRC) \u00e2\u0080\u0094 a global group of experts studying platform governance issues.\u00c2\u00a0\nThese combined efforts have given tens of thousands of researchers access to 52 datasets spanning nine terabytes of media and more than 220 million Tweets
column12: all with one goal in mind: empowering an unprecedented level of empirical research into state-backed attacks on the integrity of the conversation on Twitter.\nNow we want to take it a step further. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why
column13: starting today
column14: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re offering researchers the opportunity to apply for membership in the TMRC.\nHow to apply for the Twitter Moderation Research Consortium\nMembership in the TMRC is open to global researchers from across academia
column15: civil society
column16: NGOs
column17:
and journalism. Our goal is simple: prioritize transparency by sharing more data on more issues to those who are studying content moderation.Â  
We developed our application process in consultation with members of our Trust & Safety Council and other global experts. You can learn more about the Consortium here or review eligibility criteria and apply for membership here.Â 
Why is transparency such a priority at Twitter?
Over the years
column18: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve learned and shared a lot about the importance of combating manipulation and interference in political conversations on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0 \nBy providing academics and researchers with access to specific
column19: granular data (not just aggregated reports)
column20: we enable them to find insights and contextualize information in a way that increases the visibility of the reports themselves.\nFor example
column21: earlier this year we shared data from about 15 information operations as a pilot for the TMRC. This data has already enabled critical
column22: independent research by TMRC\u00e2\u0080\u0099s partners at the Stanford Internet Observatory
column23: the Cazadores de Fake News
column24: and the Australian Strategic Policy Institute.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to share platform manipulation campaigns and information operations with the Consortium
column25: in line with our platform manipulation and spam policy. This includes sharing data with TMRC researchers about the networks we remove and technical information about the presumptive country of origin of information operations. However
column26: as we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve said previously
column27: we'll no longer share our own attribution information for these datasets.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur goal is to remain transparent about the activity we identify on Twitter while addressing the considerable safety
column28: security
column29: and integrity challenges\u00c2\u00a0that come with disclosures of this kind.\u00c2\u00a0\nOver time
column30: we intend to share similarly comprehensive datasets about other content moderation policy areas and enforcement decisions
column31:
such as data about Tweets labeled under our misinformation policies.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet
Twitter logo icon
Tags:
data
transparency

column3: "title": "How recommendations help you discover more on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
How recommendations help you discover more on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8:
20 September 2022
Link copied successfully
Twitter is always working to make it easier for you to discover the conversations and accounts that interest you the most. Recommendations are one of the ways we do that.Â 
If youâve ever seen a Tweet you enjoyed from someone you didnât follow
column9: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve probably seen a recommendation. Think of them as personalized suggestions that are shown to you based on actions you take on Twitter.\nRecommendations are designed to enrich your Twitter experience
column10: and the more you know about them
column11: the better they can be. In fact
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve put together a whole Help Center article detailing what types of content we recommend
column13: where recommendations appear
column14: and how you can control them (definitely worth a read).\nIf you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re pressed for time
column15: however
column16: here\u00e2\u0080\u0099s the tl;dr on recommendations and how we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re working to improve them.\nHow and where Twitter recommends content\nThe content we recommend to you is informed by actions you take on Twitter
column17: also known as signals. \nSignals can include things like interests you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve told us about
column18: Topics you follow
column19: Tweets you engage with
column20: and even Tweets people in your network like. Based on these signals and more
column21: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll show you content we think you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be interested in.\u00c2\u00a0\nRecommendations can appear in your Home timeline
column22: certain places within the Explore tab
column23:
and elsewhere on Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Maintaining a high standard for recommendations
Because recommended content doesnât always come from people and accounts you follow
column24: we work to surface conversations that are relevant
column25: healthy
column26: and authentic. \nOur recommendations team partners closely with our Health
column27: Trust & Safety
column28: and Machine Learning Ethics teams to make sure we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re recommending high-quality content. You can read more about our standards for recommendations in the Help Center article linked above.\u00c2\u00a0\nControlling your recommendations \nIn addition to improving the quality of our recommendations
column29: we also provide tools to manage recommendations and clear ways to tell us when we do and don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t get it right. This is an important part of enabling you to use Twitter on your own terms.\u00c2\u00a0 \nOne of these options is the \u00e2\u0080\u009csparkle icon\u00e2\u0080\u009d\u00c2\u00a0 \u00e2\u009c\u00a8 located at the top right corner of your Home timeline. This lets you toggle between seeing top \"For You\" Tweets
column30: which include recommendations from accounts and Topics you don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t follow
column31: and \"Latest\" Tweets from only the accounts you do follow.\u00c2\u00a0\nYou can also give us feedback on recommendations you see on your Home timeline. For example
column32: liking or Retweeting recommended content will send us a signal that you find it interesting. Selecting \u00e2\u0080\u009cNot interested in this Tweet/Topic\u00e2\u0080\u009d from the Tweet menu
column33: on the other hand
column34:
will tell us youâd like to see less of that type of content.
How weâre Improving recommendations 
Finding Tweets and accounts you like should feel effortless. Thatâs why weâre investing in improving the quality of recommendations across Twitter and continuing to explore ways to make them easier to understand and control.Â 
This includes a new design with an âXâ on Tweets making it simple to remove them from your Home timeline and share your feedback with us. Weâre also testing new ways to clearly distinguish and switch between your âFor Youâ Home timeline view that includes recommendations and the âLatestâ view that doesnât.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
With millions of people signing up for Twitter every day
column35: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also testing new ways for people who are new to our service to tell us more about what they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re interested in. This way we can easily recommend content
column36: accounts
column37: and Topics you truly want to see.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue working to improve the way you discover timely and interesting content on Twitter
column38:
and weâll keepÂ sharing our progress with you along the way.

column3: "title": "We\u2019re making images on Twitter more accessible. Here\u2019s how"
column7: "post_text": "Product\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re making images on Twitter more accessible. Here\u00e2\u0080\u0099s how\nMonday
column8: 19 September 2022\nLink copied successfully\nNot everyone experiences Twitter in the same way. For those who are blind or have low vision
column9:
image descriptions are an important tool for clarifying and enriching their experience.Â 
Thatâs why weâre rolling out a new image description reminder to encourage more people on Twitter to add helpful descriptions to the images they Tweet.Â 
Hereâs how it works â and why itâs important.
Activating Twitterâs new image description reminder
Whenever you add a photo to a Tweet
column10: you have the option to describe it using alt text
column11: also known as a digital image description. Our new image description reminder is a feature that prompts you to make a good habit of adding alt text to every image you upload and share on Twitter. \nOnce enabled
column12: the feature sends you a prompt on web and mobile reminding you to add alt text whenever you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re about to Tweet an image.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re rolling out our new image description reminder globally
column13: and most people on Twitter have access to it already (those who don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t will have it very soon). To activate it
column14: open the main menu and select:\nSettings and privacy > Accessibility
column15: display
column16:
and languages > Accessibility > Receive image description reminder
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Why is it important to add image descriptions?Â 
Adding descriptions to an image helps create a more inclusive experience for everyone on Twitter. The descriptions are useful not only to people using screen readers
column17: but to those in low-bandwidth areas
column18: those with web phones
column19: and anyone who wants to learn more about an image.\u00c2\u00a0 \nImage descriptions help describe the image to people who aren\u00e2\u0080\u0099t able to view it
column20: so it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important to keep the text focused: capture what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important
column21: be succinct
column22: and be objective. For example
column23: if you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re Tweeting a photo of your favorite beach
column24: you can write:\u00c2\u00a0\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cAn empty beach at sunset with red
column25: orange
column26: purple
column27: and blue colors in a cloudless sky. Palm trees are visible in the foreground.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nYou can read more about how to write great image descriptions.\nPhotos with descriptions appear with an ALT badge in the lower left corner
column28: making it clear that additional descriptive text is available for the image. Similar to Tweet text translations
column29:
Twitter translates image descriptions to allow people from around the world to benefit from image descriptions.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Improving accessibility at Twitter
Our new image description reminder is part of our continuing efforts to make the public conversation more accessible to everyone. Other work weâve done recently includes adding an ALT badge
column30: a Closed Captions toggle button
column31:
and captions for audio conversations on Spaces and Voice Tweets. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
This work is made possible by our Accessibility Experience Team that works within our product organization on new and existing features and products
column32: providing resources and tools that promote greater accessibility on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn addition to the Accessibility Experience Team
column33: Twitter has also created an Accessibility Center for Excellence whose role it is to consult and partner with teams across the company to ensure that everything from our legal and policy standards to our marketing strategies and office spaces are more accessible.\nYou can learn more about how we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re making Twitter more accessible by following @TwitterA11y
column34:
or Tweet your first image using an image description.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Moments that defined a record-breaking summer on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Moments that defined a record-breaking summer on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8:
16 September 2022
Link copied successfully
Some of the biggest moments from around the world are discussed on Twitter.
From long awaited movie and album releases to sports highlights and global events that shape the course of history
column9: Twitter is where people come to share and talk about the moments that impact them the most.\nAnd the summer of 2022 has been no different.\nSeptember has already set the record for the biggest day in Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s history
column10: but there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s much more to a record-breaking summer than just 24 hours. Take a look below at just a few of the moments that helped define the summer of 2022 on Twitter.\nMusic\nIn late July
column11: a one word Tweet from Beyonc\u00c3\u00a9 \u00e2\u0080\u0094 \u00e2\u0080\u009cRENAISSANCE\u00e2\u0080\u00a6\u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\u0094 drove more than 6.1 million video views and sent people across Twitter scrambling to listen to \u00e2\u0080\u009cQueen Bey\u00e2\u0080\u0099s\u00e2\u0080\u009d newest album. \nK-pop superstars BLACKPINK dropped the teaser for their hit single Pink Venom on Twitter on August 17
column12: racking up more than 300
column13:
000 likes and nearly 4 million views.
And who could forget BTSâ Jung Kook showing millions of viewers on Twitter how he likes to groove on his 25th birthday?
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Movies and TV
When Thai actors/models Bright Vachirawit and Win Metawin touched down in Singapore on July 13 for the Burberry TB Summer Monogram Takeover event
column14: Twitter lit up with more than 1.8 million Tweets talking about them.\u00c2\u00a0 \nJust ten days later
column15: Marvel\u00e2\u0080\u0099s WAKANDA FOREVER Tweet
column16: with its official teaser set to a modern version of Bob Marley\u00e2\u0080\u0099s No Woman
column17: No Cry
column18:
made millions of people around the world watch and ask: who is the next Black Panther?
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Current Events
The US Supreme Courtâs decision to overturn Roe v. Wade sparked strong debate on Twitter surrounding important issues like health
column19: politics
column20: and women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s rights. More than 10 million Tweets about these subjects were posted on June 24
column21: the day of the court\u00e2\u0080\u0099s ruling. \nThen on September 8
column22: the world learned via the Royal Family\u00e2\u0080\u0099s official Twitter account that Queen Elizabeth II
column23: the UK\u00e2\u0080\u0099s longest reigning monarch
column24:
died peacefully in her home at Balmoral.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Sports
The Twitter world celebrated Lionel Messiâs 35th birthday in style on June 24 with more than 600
column25: 000 Tweets mentioning the Argentine soccer (football) superstar.\u00c2\u00a0 \nAnd speaking of \u00e2\u0080\u009cthe beautiful game\u00e2\u0080\u009d
column26: Brazil\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Campeonato Brasileiro was Tweeted about more than 12 million times throughout the summer. Ava\u00c3\u00ad vs Flamengo\u00e2\u0080\u0099s July 24 match alone saw nearly 800
column27: 000 conversations on Twitter.\nIn Dubai
column28: the 2022 Asia Cup prompted a surge in Tweets about cricket: more than 1.4 million on August 28 when Pakistan and India squared off
column29: and more than 1.5 million 11 days later when Virat Kohli scored his 71st international 100 in India\u00e2\u0080\u0099s match against Afghanistan.\nAnd of course
column30: in early September during the US Open tennis tournament
column31:
Serena Williams cemented her legacy both on the court and as the most Tweeted about female athlete ever.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We come together on Twitter
These are just a few of the incredible Twitter moments that have helped make the summer of 2022 so memorable. We canât wait to see what youâll talk about next. 
Click here to add your voice to the conversation.

column3: "title": "How many people come to Twitter for news? As it turns out
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/insights/2022/how-many-people-come-twitter-for-news"
column8: "post_text": "Insights\nHow many people come to Twitter for news? As it turns out
column9:
a LOT
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column10: 12 September 2022\nLink copied successfully\nPeople come to Twitter for many reasons. As it turns out
column11: one of the biggest is to stay informed about current events.\nWhether it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s politics
column12: world & local news
column13: entertainment
column14: sports
column15: technology
column16: or health & wellness
column17: Twitter has become home to some of the most relevant conversations about news and current events happening around the world.\nWhy is this important information to know? First
column18: it helps us understand and better serve people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s interests. Second
column19: it reinforces the importance of the work we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re doing to address misinformation
column20: add helpful context to Tweets
column21: and keep people better informed about the news they consume on Twitter.\nTo help give you visibility into some of these findings
column22: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve compiled learnings from studies Twitter has performed with YouGov and Sparkler
column23: as well as internal Twitter data and third party research from groups like YouGov and Pew Research. Unless otherwise noted
column24:
these studies and surveys have been conducted with respondents in the US.Â 
Read on to learn more about the ways people engage with current events on Twitter.
People engage regularly with news on TwitterÂ 
People on Twitter are avid news consumers. Many of them are interested in politics and current events
column25: and they regularly Tweet about it. \n94% of people on Twitter express interest in current events\n85% of people on Twitter watch
column26: read
column27:
or listen to the news at least once a day
83% of people on Twitter Tweet about news
3 in 4 people who come to Twitter for news do so at least once a day
55% of people on Twitter get their news from Twitter
column28: more than other social media platforms\n75% of people who come to Twitter for news follow news about politics and current events on Twitter\nIn the first 6.5 months of 2022
column29:
there were 4.6B Tweets about news in the US (#1) and 10.4B Tweets about news globally (#2)
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitter connects people with news outlets and journalists
In addition to helping people learn about and share current events
column30: Twitter facilitates the discovery of news outlets and journalists. People regularly follow news-related Twitter accounts
column31:
and more than 80% of young journalists rely on Twitter for their jobs. 
62% of Twitter news consumers say âTwitter helps me find new news outlets to followâ
60% of people on Twitter say they have followed an account related to US national news in in the past year
55% of people on Twitter say they have followed an account related to local news in in the past year
50% of people on Twitter say they have followed an account related to international news in in the past year
50% of people on Twitter say they have followed a journalist on social media in in the past year
83% of young journalists (ages 18-29) say Twitter is the social media site they use most or second most in their job
Stay informed 
Keep your eyes here for more information
column32: or follow @TwitterNews for best practices and innovative uses of Twitter by journalists and newsrooms. \nSources \nTwitter x YouGov

column34: n = 1257 Pew Research

column36: June-Aug 2021
column37: US

column40: US

column43: July-Aug 2021

column48: US

column51: global and US. Top 50 disaggregated topics were aggregated based on overarching topic Twitter x Sparkler via Twitter Insiders

column55: December 2021
column56: US Twitter Insiders
column57: December 2021
column58: US

column60: Feb-March 2022
column61: US Journalists

889

Serena by the numbers: The most Tweeted about female athlete of all time

column8: 8 September 2022\nLink copied successfully\nSerena Williams has been a dominant force on the tennis court for 27 years \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and while Twitter hasn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t been around quite that long
column9: she continues to rack up the W\u00e2\u0080\u0099s here as well.\nLast week
column10: in addition to shattering ESPN\u00e2\u0080\u0099s all-time tennis viewership record during her farewell match at the US Open
column11:
Serena was officially crowned the most Tweeted about female athlete of all time.

Itâs true. During the course of 2022's US Open alone
column12:
sheâs been mentioned in over a million Tweets and counting. Here are some more stats you might be interested to know:
Serena has over 10.7 million Twitter followers and still ranks among the top 20 female athletes with the most new followers in 2021 â more than two decades after her career began
@serenawilliams is the most mentioned player handle in the tennis conversation globally since the start of the US Open
All of the top 5 most Retweeted Tweets about tennis since the start of US Open are about Serena
Serena continues to bring new audiences to tennis
column13: with approximately 30% of users who Tweeted about Serena in August having not Tweeted about tennis all year\u00c2\u00a0\nWe just wanted to give credit where credit\u00e2\u0080\u0099s due. Here\u00e2\u0080\u0099s to 367 major match victories

column3: "title": "Birdwatch is getting a new onboarding process and more visible notes"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Birdwatch is getting a new onboarding process and more visible notes
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 7 September 2022\nLink copied successfully\nAs of November 2022
column9: Birdwatch is now\u00c2\u00a0Community Notes.\nBirdwatch is a collaborative way to add helpful context to Tweets and keep people better informed.\nAs a recap
column10: the program is made up of a group of people
column11: or contributors
column12: who help identify information in Tweets they believe is misleading and write notes that provide informative context. Only notes that are rated Helpful by a diverse group of contributors
column13: or that \u00e2\u0080\u009cbridge\u00e2\u0080\u009d across groups of people who have tended to disagree in their past ratings
column14: are made visible on Twitter. \nThe program began testing in 2021 and is regularly being updated and improved thanks to analysis from our research team and feedback from our academic advisory board and Birdwatch contributors. Now
column15: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re rolling out a new onboarding process and expanding the visibility of notes to increase the positive impact of Birdwatch and enable healthier Twitter conversations.\u00c2\u00a0 \nHere\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a look at what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s new
column16:
along with some important new findings that highlight the impact Birdwatch is already having on Twitter.
A better way to join and contribute to Birdwatch
We're rolling out an updated Birdwatch onboarding process that better incentivizes contributors to write and rate notes in a thoughtful way. 
New Birdwatch contributors who have met the eligibility criteria* will begin with an initial Rating Impact score of zero
column17: which they can increase by consistently rating other contributors\u00e2\u0080\u0099 notes and reliably identifying those that are Helpful and Not Helpful. Once a contributor\u00e2\u0080\u0099s score has risen to five
column18: they can start writing notes.\nContributors can further increase their Writing and Rating Impact scores by both writing Helpful notes and continuing to rate notes written by others. Repeatedly writing notes that reach a status of Not Helpful
column19: however
column20:
will result in a decreasing score and could temporarily lock a contributorâs note writing ability.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
*Birdwatch contributors must have a verified phone number from a trusted US-based carrier
column21: no recent Twitter Rules violations
column22: and a minimum six months on Twitter.\nExpanding the Birdwatch contributor base and the visibility of notes\nWith the new onboarding process in place
column23: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re ready to begin expanding our contributor base.\u00c2\u00a0 \nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll start by adding larger groups of eligible applicants to the pilot on a more frequent basis. The process will be adjusted as needed as we closely monitor whether this change has any impact on either the quality or the frequency of contributions.\u00c2\u00a0 \nThe visibility of notes on public Tweets will also be increasing. In the coming weeks
column24: more people using Twitter in the US will start to see notes on Tweets that Birdwatch contributors have collectively identified as Helpful. Importantly
column25: this doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t mean you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll start seeing notes on every Tweet
column26:
simply that a larger number of you will start seeing notes that have been rated Helpful.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Understanding the impact of Birdwatch
Our research indicates that Birdwatch is an effective way to keep people better informed on Twitter. 
According to the results of three surveys
column27: people who see a Birdwatch note are
column28: on average
column29: 20-40% less likely to agree with the substance of a potentially misleading Tweet than someone who sees the Tweet alone. By analyzing our internal data
column30: we also estimate that people on Twitter who see notes are
column31: on average
column32: 15-35% less likely to Like or Retweet a Tweet than someone who sees the Tweet alone. \nNotes are intentionally designed to be as informative and helpful as possible \u00e2\u0080\u0094 no matter who sees them \u00e2\u0080\u0094 thanks in large part to the \u00e2\u0080\u009cbridging algorithm\u00e2\u0080\u009d we mentioned above. Here\u00e2\u0080\u0099s how it works:\u00c2\u00a0 \nIn order to be shown on a Tweet
column33: Birdwatch notes need to be found helpful by people who have tended to disagree in their past ratings. This means the algorithm takes into account not only how many contributors rated a note as Helpful or Not Helpful
column34: but also whether people who rated it seem to come from different perspectives.\u00c2\u00a0\nThis approach appears to be having an impact. In our most recent survey
column35: notes were found to be informative regardless of a person's self-identified political party affiliation \u00e2\u0080\u0094 there was no statistically significant difference in average informativeness across party ID. The algorithm and all data it uses are publicly available on GitHub so anyone can audit
column36: analyze
column37: or suggest improvements.\nIf you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re interested in joining Birdwatch and contributing to a healthier
column38: more well-informed Twitter conversation
column39:
click this link to get started.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "This is a test of Twitter\u2019s new Edit Tweet feature. This is only a test"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
This is a test of Twitterâs new Edit Tweet feature. This is only a test
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 1 September 2022\nLink copied successfully\nThe screenshot below may look a lot like an edited Tweet. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s because it is
column9:
and you could be seeing more of them soon (like the one at the bottom of this article).
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Itâs true: Edit Tweet is being tested by our team internally. The test will then be initially expanded to Twitter Blue subscribers in the coming weeks. 
Given that this is our most requested feature to date
column10: we wanted to both update you on our progress and give you a heads up that
column11: even if you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re not in a test group
column12: everyone will still be able to see if a Tweet has been edited.\nWhat is Edit Tweet?\nSo what is Edit Tweet
column13: you ask? Great question. Edit Tweet is a feature that lets people make changes to their Tweet after it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s been published. Think of it as a short period of time to do things like fix typos
column14: add missed tags
column15: and more. \nFor this test
column16: Tweets will be able to be edited a few times in the 30 minutes following their publication. Edited Tweets will appear with an icon
column17: timestamp
column18: and label so it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s clear to readers that the original Tweet has been modified. Tapping the label will take viewers to the Tweet\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Edit History
column19: which includes past versions of the Tweet. \nFor context
column20: the time limit and version history play an important role here. They help protect the integrity of the conversation and create a publicly accessible record of what was said. \nWho will be testing Edit Tweet? \nLike any new feature
column21: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re intentionally testing Edit Tweet with a smaller group to help us incorporate feedback while identifying and resolving potential issues. This includes how people might misuse the feature. You can never be too careful. \nLater this month
column22: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be expanding Edit Tweet access to Twitter Blue subscribers. As part of their subscription
column23: Twitter Blue subscribers receive early access to features and help us test them before they come to Twitter. \nThe test will be localized to a single country at first and expand as we learn and observe how people use Edit Tweet. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll also be paying close attention to how the feature impacts the way people read
column24: write
column25: and engage with Tweets.\nParticipating on Twitter in a way that makes sense to you \nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re hoping that
column26: with the availability of Edit Tweet
column27: Tweeting will feel more approachable and less stressful. You should be able to participate in the conversation in a way that makes sense to you
column28: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll keep working on ways that make it feel effortless to do just that. \nTurn on Tweet notifications for @TwitterBlue
column29:
because weâll have more to share soon!

          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Introducing Twitter Circle
column4: a new way to Tweet to a smaller crowd"
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/product/2022/introducing-twitter-circle-new-way-tweet-smaller-crowd"
column8: "post_text": "Product\nIntroducing Twitter Circle
column9:
a new way to Tweet to a smaller crowd
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column10: 30 August 2022\nLink copied successfully\nSometimes you just want to talk to your people. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we created Twitter Circle
column11: a new way to Tweet to a smaller crowd.\u00c2\u00a0\nWith Twitter Circle
column12: people now have the flexibility to choose who can see and engage with their content on a Tweet-by-Tweet basis. This makes it easier to have more intimate conversations and build closer connections with select followers.\nWe began testing Twitter Circle in May
column13: and the response was overwhelmingly positive. So starting today
column14: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re making this highly-requested feature available to everyone on iOS
column15: Android
column16:
and Twitter.com globally.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Take a look below to learn more about Twitter Circle
column17: how it works
column18: and what our community has to say about it.\u00c2\u00a0\nSelecting your circle\nBefore you post on Twitter
column19: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll now see an option to share your Tweet with either your circle or your full followers list. Circles can contain up to 150 people
column20: and you can adjust who\u00e2\u0080\u0099s in and who\u00e2\u0080\u0099s out at any time. Don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t worry
column21:
no one will be notified of any changes you make to your circle.Â  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweets sent to your circle will appear with a green badge underneath them. They can only be seen by those youâve selected to be in your circle and cannot be Retweeted or shared. Additionally
column22: all replies to these Tweets are private
column23:
even if your Twitter account is public.Â 
You can find more info about Twitter Circle here.Â  
Personalizing your Twitter experience
We want to ensure everyone on Twitter has the choice
column24: control
column25: tools
column26: and transparency to join the conversation how and when they want
column27: and Twitter Circle is another important step in that direction. \nGiving people the option to share thoughts with a select group of followers helps make Tweeting more accessible. This is true whether you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re brand new to Twitter or you have millions of followers. Since the feature began testing
column28: people have been sharing how it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s helped them personalize their Twitter experience
column29:
including:
Feeling more comfortable Tweeting and expressing themselves
Eliminating the need for alternate or secondary accounts
Sharing content with a close and evolving group of friends
Avoiding toggling between protected and public account settings
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
I love Twitter Circle because we all have those Tweets that we donât want the entire world to see so itâs nice to be able to have a space where we can share and laugh with the people we are in community with! Twitter Circle eliminates the fear of the wrong person seeing the wrong Tweet and has allowed me to connect more honestly and purposefully with my followers which is what Twitter is all about.
Twitter Creator
â@itszaeokâ
I love Twitter Circle because it allows you to curate a community within your community. Someone like me who has a larger platform canât always be as open and connected with my friends the way I want to on Twitter
column30: so this allows me to be able to connect with my broader audience
column31:
as well as my personal friends all on the same timeline!
Twitter Creator
â@seangarretteâ
Some results from our Twitter Circle test include:
Increased overall TweetingÂ 
Increased Tweet engagement rate on circle Tweets (Likes and replies)
Twitter is also committed to incorporating feedback from trusted partners and online safety experts
column32: including the Twitter Trust & Safety Council
column33:
into the products and features we build. These groups regularly emphasize the importance of online customization tools in helping people express themselves freely online.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
LGBTQ+ youth often opt to creating separate private accounts to feel more comfortable sharing online with people who accept their sexual orientation or gender identity. Twitter Circle puts power into the hands of people on Twitter by creating a new way for them to control how they show up online and feel safe expressing themselves.
Twitter Trust & Safety Council member
â@Belong_Toâ
Whatâs next
Want to check out Twitter Circle for yourself? Click here to compose your first circle Tweet. Weâll continue to observe how itâs working and explore ways to make it even better.Â  
Donât forget to keep your eyes here for additional features and tools that enable you to use Twitter on your own terms.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter

column3: "title": "Listen up: Podcasts are coming to Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Listen up: Podcasts are coming to Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 25 August 2022\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter helps people connect with unique and compelling voices around the world. With podcasts
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re taking that connection to a whole new level.\u00c2\u00a0\nStarting Thursday
column10: August 25
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re integrating podcasts into Twitter as a part of our newly redesigned Spaces Tab.\u00c2\u00a0We know that some discussions need more than 280 characters
column12: and bringing people closer to the ideas
column13: content
column14: and creators they know and love is core to Twitter no matter where the conversations take place. \nSo how will it all work
column15:
and how can you check out Twitterâs new podcasts for yourself? Take a look below for everything you need to know about this exciting update.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Integrating podcasts into Twitter Spaces
Integrating podcasts into Spaces
column16: where audio conversations happen on Twitter
column17: is another way we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re continuing to invest in audio creators. To do this in a simple and intuitive way that allows listeners to simply hit play and go
column18: we started with a redesigned audio experience in the Spaces Tab. \nThis redesign introduces personalized hubs that group audio content together by specific themes like News
column19: Music
column20: Sports
column21:
and more. Now Twitter listeners will be able to easily access a more personalized selection of live and recorded Spaces discussing the topics that are most relevant to them.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
But the selection doesnât stop there. These new hubs will also feature the most popular and engaging podcasts from around the world. Our internal research indicates that 45% of people who use Twitter in the US also listen to podcasts monthly
column22: so we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll automatically suggest compelling podcasts to help people easily find and listen to the topics they want to hear more about. For example
column23: if someone regularly interacts with Vox content on Twitter
column24: they\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll probably see a Vox podcast in a Spaces hub.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cVox Media has a rich array of popular podcasts across many categories
column25: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re thrilled that Twitter is expanding its audio capabilities to help more listeners discover them
column26: \u00e2\u0080\u009d said Ray Chao
column27: general manager of audio at Vox Media. \u00e2\u0080\u009cWhether it's Kara Swisher and Scott Galloway\u00e2\u0080\u0099s \u00e2\u0080\u0098Pivot
column28: \u00e2\u0080\u0099 our daily news explainer \u00e2\u0080\u0098Today
column29: Explained
column30: \u00e2\u0080\u0099 or \u00e2\u0080\u0098Stay Tuned with Preet Bharara
column31:
' we're excited Twitter is offering users and podcast fans an exciting new frontier." 
Want to build a more customized experience? Just give a podcast a âthumbs upâ or âthumbs downâ to let us know if the content is more or less interesting to you.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Testing the new Twitter Spaces
column32: including podcasts\nFrom Spaces and podcasts to newsletters and Notes
column33: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re working every day to improve the way people connect with creators and make Twitter the home of the most engaging conversations in the world. \nStarting today
column34: the reimagined Spaces Tab
column35: including the addition of podcasts
column36: will be visible to a group of global English-speaking audience on iOS and Android. Share your feedback with us to help us get it right
column37:
and keep your eyes (and ears) here for more announcements and feature releases designed to help you enjoy Twitter on your own terms.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
