column3: "title": " Our approach to the 2022 US midterms"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
 Our approach to the 2022 US midterms
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 11 August 2022\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter is the place to find real-time
column9: reliable information about the 2022 midterms\u00c2\u00a0 \u00e2\u0080\u0093 whether you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re looking for breaking news from reporters
column10: information on voting
column11: or policy positions from candidates. We aim to enable healthy civic conversation on Twitter
column12: while ensuring people have the context they need to make informed decisions about content they encounter. Because we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re a global service
column13: there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s almost always an election happening on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nToday
column14: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re announcing steps we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re taking ahead of the US midterms to protect civic conversation on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0 \nOur Civic Integrity Policy\u00c2\u00a0 \nAs a key part of the Twitter Rules
column15: since 2018
column16: our Civic Integrity Policy has helped people find credible information during elections and other civic processes \u00e2\u0080\u0094 including in the Philippines
column17: Kenya
column18: Australia
column19: Brazil
column20: and India \u00e2\u0080\u0093 just this year.\nToday
column21: as we do ahead of other global elections
column22: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re activating enforcement of our Civic Integrity Policy for the 2022 US midterms.\nThe Civic Integrity Policy covers the most common types of harmful misleading information about elections and civic events
column23: such as: claims about how to participate in a civic process like how to vote
column24: misleading content intended to intimidate or dissuade people from participating in the election
column25: and misleading claims intended to undermine public confidence in an election \u00e2\u0080\u0093 including false information about the outcome of the election. Tweets with this content may be labeled with links to credible information or helpful context
column26: and Twitter will not recommend or amplify this content in areas of the product where Twitter makes recommendations. People on Twitter will see a prompt prior to liking or sharing labeled tweets
column27: and in cases where there is potential for harm associated with the false or misleading claim
column28: the Tweet may not be liked or shared to prevent the spread of the misleading information.\nFake accounts that misrepresent affiliation to a candidate or elected official are prohibited under our existing Misleading & Deceptive Identities Policy \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and we remain vigilant against potential coordinated manipulation efforts. And during this election period
column29: and year-round
column30: we continue to enforce our safety policies \u00e2\u0080\u0093 including for conduct targeting election workers. \nRedesigned labels \nLate last year
column31: we tested new misleading information labels and saw promising results. The new labels increased click through rates by 17%
column32: meaning more people were clicking labels to read debunking content. We also saw notable decreases in engagement with Tweets labeled with the new design: -13% in replies
column33: -10% in Retweets and -15% in likes.\u00c2\u00a0\nFinding reliable information \nTwitter wants to empower voters to find reliable information about how to register
column34: how to vote
column35: and the choices on their ballot. To make it easier to find reliable news and accurate information about participating in the civic process
column36:
weâre launching a number of product updates.
Hereâs what you can expect to see on Twitter as election day approaches in the US: 
PrebunksÂ  
In the lead up to election day
column37: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll share prompts with information about how and where to vote
column38: directly to people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s timelines.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also bringing back prebunks \u00e2\u0080\u0094 in English
column39: Spanish
column40: and all other languages supported on Twitter \u00e2\u0080\u0094 to get ahead of misleading narratives on Twitter
column41: and to proactively address topics that may be the subject of misinformation. Over the coming months
column42: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll place prompts directly on people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s timelines in the US and in Search when people type related terms
column43: phrases
column44:
or hashtags.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
State-specific event hubsÂ 
Weâve begun rolling out state-specific event hubs as primaries take place across the country. These localized pages feature real-time election information from state election officials
column45: plus local news outlets and journalists.\u00c2\u00a0\nSoon
column46: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll roll out an additional
column47: nationally focused Event page
column48: available to everyone in the US.\u00c2\u00a0 \nDedicated Explore tab \nAs elections take place around the world
column49: Twitter often serves as the centralized hub for real-time political conversation
column50: resources
column51: and breaking news. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be launching a dedicated Explore tab that will include:\nNational news in both English and Spanish by reputable news outlets
column52: curated by Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Curation team;\nLocalized news and resources by state;\nVoter education public service announcements (PSAs) in English and Spanish
column53:
created using information from nonpartisan government and voting advocacy organizations.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Image of example Explore tab 
          
          
        
Identifying whoâs running for office
Our candidate account labels make it easier to identify whoâs running for office. We began rolling out these labels in May
column54: as primary elections kicked into full swing
column55: and you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to see these labels until the end of the general election. These labels:\nAppear on designated candidate accounts for those running for US Senate
column56: US House of Representatives
column57: or Governor
column58: who\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve qualified for the general election ballot;\nContain critical candidate information; including the office the candidate is running for
column59: the state the office is located in
column60:
and the district number (for US House candidates);
Appear at the top of the candidateâs profile page and on all of their Tweets. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Image of example candidate label 
          
          
        
Improving recommendations
Weâve also made â and continue to make â updates to how and what we recommend on Twitter. Earlier this year
column61: in the US and Brazil
column62: we tested ways to prevent misleading Tweets from being recommended through notifications. Early results show that impressions on misleading information dropped by 1.6 million per month
column63:
as a direct result of the experiment.Â Â 
Weâve since applied this intervention to notification recommendations on Twitter and are exploring possibilities for other surfaces on Twitter. 
Protecting accountsÂ  
Weâre helping to protect and secure accounts of government officials
column64: candidates for office
column65: journalists
column66: and more ahead of the midterms.\u00c2\u00a0\nAccounts will be reminded to use a strong password
column67: encouraged to enable two-factor authentication
column68: and asked to check the third-party apps they\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve connected to their accounts. We will also enable password reset protection for accounts by default to help prevent unauthorized password changes. \nIn the coming weeks
column69: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll apply additional proactive safeguards for these accounts
column70: including: \nMore sophisticated detections and alerts to help us
column71: and account holders
column73: facilitating meaningful political debate
column74: and providing information on civic participation \u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00c2\u00a0 not only in the US
column75: but around the world. People deserve to trust the election conversations and content they encounter on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re exploring other ways to help people make sense of content they encounter during these critical times. Keep an eye on @TwitterSafety for media literacy tips and suggestions
column76: like how to spot misinformation
column77:
which were developed in partnership with educational experts.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Example of media literacy tip 
          
          
        
The features and tools outlined above
column78: in combination with continued enforcement of the Twitter Rules
column79: help make this possible.\u00c2\u00a0\nAs election day nears
column80: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to share real-time information about our approach.\u00c2\u00a0 \nKeep up with the latest at @TwitterGov
column81: @Policy
column82: and @TwitterSafety. Or
column83: visit the revamped elections.twitter.com \u00e2\u0080\u0093 you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll find information about how we approach elections around the world
column84: including how our policies
column86:
and partnerships work together to ensure the election information you see on Twitter is credible and relevant.Â  
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

#OnlyOnTwitter

column3: "title": "The 2022 Kenyan General Election is happening on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
The 2022 Kenyan General Election is happening on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8:
3 August 2022
Link copied successfully
More on our approach in English and Swahili
On Tuesday 9th August
column9: Kenyan voters will be heading to the polls for the 2022 General Elections
column10: where they will vote to elect a new President
column11: as well as voting to elect members of the National Assembly
column12: and members of the Kenyan Senate. In addition to this
column13: local county governors and candidates for the country's 47 county assemblies will also be on the ballot this year for voters\u00e2\u0080\u0099 consideration.\u00c2\u00a0\nElections on Twitter\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0 \nDuring any election
column14: Twitter serves as a centralised hub for real-time political conversation and commentary
column15: electoral resources
column16: journalistic reports live from the campaign trail as well as a tool for people to hear directly from political representatives themselves.\u00c2\u00a0 \nOur work to make Twitter an engaging and healthy platform for political discourse is long standing; in 2019 we banned political ads as we believe political messaging should be earned
column17: not bought; we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve expanded our policies around election misinformation and continue to add context and notices to Tweets with manipulated media
column18: to ensure people have the context they need.\u00c2\u00a0 \n2022 Kenyan Elections\u00c2\u00a0 \nToday
column19: we wanted to share the steps we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve taken and the trusted local partnerships we have
column20: ahead of the 2022 Kenyan elections
column21: ensuring the debate on Twitter is healthy
column22: open and safe. Our work also ensures that Twitter continues to serve as the go-to place for people to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening
column23: participate in the conversation
column24: track campaign trails and consume verified information
column25: so voters can make informed choices about what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s most important to them in this election.\u00c2\u00a0\nPartnerships\nAs we work to improve the health of the public conversation - particularly during civic events like elections - we are committed to reaching beyond Twitter to intergrate diverse perspectives that make our service better for everyone. As part of that
column26: we have partnered with a number of organisations to further amplify credible information during the Kenyan election.\nElevate Credible Information: One such partner is Africa Check; established in 2012 as the continent\u00e2\u0080\u0099s first independent
column27: nonpartisan fact-checking organisation that debunks dangerous statements
column28: and empowers people to engage with information critically
column29:
while also building a culture of fact-checking across Africa.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We are pleased to collaborate with Twitter as part of our election work in Kenya. The collaboration will allow us to address dis- and misinformation by fact-checking claims and identifying potential misinformation...Notably
column30: the partnership with Twitter will deepen the impact of our media literacy project as it will allow us to reach a broader audience. \nAfrica Check\nIndependent
column31: nonpartisan fact-checking organisation\n\u00e2\u0080\u008e@AfricaCheck\u00e2\u0080\u008e\nIn the build-up to the Kenyan elections
column32: Africa Check - which is part of the\u00c2\u00a0Fumbua\u00c2\u00a0collective
column33: continues to combat false narratives
column34: amplify accurate information and lead the activation of critical media literacy work across the region.\n\"We are pleased to collaborate with Twitter as part of our election work in Kenya. The collaboration will allow us to address dis- and misinformation by fact-checking claims and identifying potential misinformation. We will also highlight accurate
column35: verified information ahead of the election on the platform so that voters can make informed decisions. Media literacy programmes are a proactive strategy to fight misinformation and allow us to use our fact-checking work to inoculate people against false information proactively and empower them to critically understand
column36: analyse
column37: and evaluate information instead of simply consuming and sharing it. We believe this enables them to make evidence-based decisions vital ahead of elections. Notably
column38: the partnership with Twitter will deepen the impact of our media literacy project as it will allow us to reach a broader audience.\" - Africa Check\nThis work is key to the protection of the election conversation and we look forward to continued partnerships and collaboration with Africa Check and all our other partner organisations

column3: "title": "Sharing our latest transparency update
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/company/2022/ttr-20"
column8: "post_text": "Company\nSharing our latest transparency update
column9: marking decade long commitment\nThursday
column10: 28 July 2022\nLink copied successfully\nThis year marks a decade of transparency reporting for Twitter
column11: and today we are publishing our 20th Transparency Report.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhy does this matter? Over the last 10 years how governments attempt to control free expression
column12: remove content
column13: and reveal the identity of account owners on Twitter has evolved significantly. Meaningful transparency helps people understand the rules of online services and hold governments accountable for their actions
column14: and in turn
column15: helps keep us accountable for principled content moderation and responsiveness to government demands. Transparency is a key guiding principle in our mission to serve the public conversation
column16: protect the Open Internet
column17: and advance the internet as a global force for good. We have and will continue to fight for the people who use Twitter to raise their voice.\nHighlights from our latest report\u00c2\u00a0\nWe continue to see a concerning trend toward attempts to limit global press freedom
column18: with an increase in government legal demands targeting journalists
column19: as well as an overall increasing number of legal demands on accounts \u00e2\u0080\u0093 both represent record highs since reporting began.\u00c2\u00a0 \u00c2\u00a0\nRecord number of legal demands on accounts (47
column20: 572 demands on 198
column21:
931 accounts)
An increase of 103% in legal demands from governments targeting verified journalists and news outlets since the last reporting period
The United States accounted for 20% of all global requests Tweet impressions that violated Twitter rules accounted for less than 0.1% of total impressions on all Tweets
We objected to 29 US civil requests for account information that sought to unmask the identities of anonymous speakers
See the full report here.
Governmentsâ role in transparency reporting
This update comes at a time when government requests for account information and content removal continually hit new records
column22: including demands to reveal the identity of anonymous account owners. This is why we continue to advocate for greater transparency from governments themselves about how these powers are used. People who use our service should know that we take a principled approach to how we handle government requests and legal demands and how we share information about people who use our service.\nFor July 1
column23: 2021 through December 31
column24: 2021 (the reporting period of the update we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sharing today) we saw an increase in global legal demands received
column25: a continued upward trend for Twitter.\nFor this reporting period
column26: Twitter received 47
column27: 572 legal demands for 198
column28: 931 unique accounts
column29: the largest number of accounts we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve reported in the past 10 years. This number has continued to increase throughout each reporting period
column30: and we also continue to see similar trends in government requests for information. This reporting period
column31: we received 11
column32:
460 such requests.
Globally during the latest reporting period:
Twitter narrowed (meaning we disclosed some information but not all information demanded in the request) or did not disclose any information in response to 60% of global government information requests.
For the latest reporting period
column33: 349 accounts of verified journalists and news outlets located all around the world were subject to 326 legal demands
column34: a 103% increase since the previous reporting period and a record high since we started tracking this important metric
column35:
which is all the more important at a time when freedom of the press is strained globally.
From the US during the last reporting period:
Government information requests originating from the US made up the highest percentage among requesting countries from around the world.
With the exception of the second half of 2020
column36: US information requests have represented the largest share of total global volume in a reporting period since Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s first transparency report in 2012.\n20% of all global requests for account information originated from the United States during this reporting period.\nThese requests accounted for 39% of all accounts specified from around the world. Twitter complied
column37: in whole or in part
column38: with 69% of these U.S. information requests.\nWe objected to 29 US civil requests for account information that sought to unmask the identities of anonymous speakers on First Amendment grounds.\u00c2\u00a0\nOf those 29 requests
column39:
we filed lawsuits to fight back in two instances and succeeded in convincing courts to apply First Amendment protections in one case. The other case remains pending.

As in past reports
column40: Twitter is not reporting on any other requests for information deemed to be related to national security processes because of limitations imposed on us by the U.S. government. We have been fighting for more transparency around this process for years
column41: and continue to fight this issue in our court case
column42: Twitter v. Garland
column43: and are currently awaiting a decision on appeal.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe strongly believe in providing data and information that is straightforward and provides insights into the types of requests we receive from governments and others around the world. To this end
column44: we also upload legal requests directly into the Lumen Database
column45: a project by the Berkman Klein Center for Internet & Society at Harvard University. We encourage the public to explore this site to get a sense of the day-to-day queries we receive from governments and other entities around the world.\nInvestments in technology\u00c2\u00a0\nIn 2012
column46: we were the first social media company to publish a transparency report
column47: and since then it has become an industry standard. Over the past decade
column48: we have made significant investments and developed our reporting including more data
column49: insights and metrics. Since we first reported data behind our enforcement of the Twitter Rules in 2018
column50: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve significantly evolved our approach to how we detect and take down content that is against our rules. The biggest impact we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen in this work is through our use of technology to proactively take down content quickly
column51: oftentimes without that content ever needing to be reported by people on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re iterating on the way that we measure our effectiveness and have worked to move beyond the binary \u00e2\u0080\u009cleave up\u00e2\u0080\u009d or \u00e2\u0080\u009ctake down\u00e2\u0080\u009d traditional approach to content moderation. For this reporting period
column52: we required the removal of more than four million Tweets that violated the Twitter Rules. We also deploy less aggressive enforcement actions by labeling Tweets to add important context when the information shared doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t warrant Tweet deletion
column53: and have improved the way we make certain questionable content from accounts you don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t follow don't appear in replies
column54: search
column55: or on your Home Timeline. In future transparency reporting
column56: we aim to share details on these measures in more specific ways
column57: eventually making this data core to our reporting.\nOne way we measure the efficacy of our investments in technology is by sharing how many impressions violative Tweets received before they are removed. For this reporting period
column58: impressions on these violative Tweets accounted for less than 0.1% of total impressions on all Tweets. Of the Tweets removed
column59: 71% received fewer than 100 impressions prior to removal
column60: with an additional 21% receiving between 100 and 1
column61: 000 impressions. These numbers have remained consistent since we first began reporting this data in 2020
column62:
even as the volume of rule-violating content we remove has generally trended upward â indicating that our efforts at proactive detection are keeping pace with changing behavior. We continue to invest heavily in improving both the speed and comprehensiveness of our detections.

Getting better at tackling platform manipulation and spam
As a result of continued investment in our approach and our ongoing efforts to disrupt spam attacks on our service
column63: for this reporting period
column64: our teams deployed a 2% increase in global anti-spam challenges compared to the last reporting period. When we detect suspicious levels of activity
column65: accounts may be locked and prompted to provide additional information (e.g.
column66: a phone number) or to solve a reCAPTCHA. This nominal increase is related to ongoing efforts to disrupt spam attacks on our service. Further
column67: during the second half of 2021
column68: we received 6% more spam reports from people using Twitter compared to the previous reporting period.\nDuring the past 10 years
column69: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made significant investments \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and seen significant progress \u00e2\u0080\u0094 in how we detect and take action against spam and platform manipulation
column70: and give people on Twitter more context in their experience. One such example is around automated accounts. Automated accounts can be a source of useful
column71: entertaining
column72: and relevant information on Twitter. We launched Automated Account Labels in September 2021 to make it easier for people to be able to identify these \u00e2\u0080\u009cgood bots\u00e2\u0080\u009d. As of February 2022
column73: all automated accounts globally have the option to self-identify.\nTo view more on our work

Transparency with our data
From Twitterâs beginnings in 2006
column75: our uniquely open and public APIs (application programming interfaces) \u00e2\u0080\u0093 which
column76: at a high level
column77: are the way computer programs \u00e2\u0080\u009ctalk\u00e2\u0080\u009d to each other so they can request and deliver information \u00e2\u0080\u0093 have given researchers and developers the opportunity to tap into what is happening in the world. Twitter is the only major service to make public conversation data available via an API
column78: for research purposes.\u00c2\u00a0\nOpen access to public data is critical for advancing research objectives on a wide range of topics in a safe way that ensures public privacy is protected. It raises general awareness and understanding of the scale and nature of the challenges impacting public conversation online
column79: and it also helps to keep services like Twitter accountable for our own response to these challenges.\u00c2\u00a0\nAdditionally
column80: throughout the pandemic
column81: we launched a COVID-19 endpoint to empower public health research
column82: and a new academic platform to encourage cutting-edge research using Twitter data. This is one of the reasons you hear more about reports featuring Twitter as core to the research methodology \u00e2\u0080\u0094 we intentionally empower this.\nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next?\nTransparency is key to building and sustaining trust
column84: and preserving a free and secure Open Internet. People should understand the rules of online services and the way that governmental legal powers are used. Without transparency
column85: there can be no accountability.\u00c2\u00a0\nFor our part
column86: Twitter aims to continually evaluate and improve the way we share information with the public. This year
column87: we are launching the Twitter Moderation Research Consortium (TMRC). Through the Consortium
column88: Twitter shares large-scale datasets concerning platform moderation issues with a global group of public interest researchers from across academia
column89: civil society
column90: NGOs and journalism studying platform governance issues. This program will initially focus on sharing data about accounts and networks Twitter has removed in connection with platform manipulation and state-backed information operations
column92: reputable academics and researchers to find insights in and contextualize the data.\nWhile the way that we have reported this information has continually developed and improved over the past 10 years
column93: our commitment to protecting the people who use Twitter remains unchanged. That includes protecting activists and journalists
column94: accounts that wish to remain anonymous
column95: and those who speak up against their own governments.\u00c2\u00a0\nTo view the full report
column96:
click here.

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "IDEA Q2 2022: #UntilWeAllBelong Toolkit"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
IDEA Q2 2022: #UntilWeAllBelong Toolkit
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 21 July 2022\nLink copied successfully\nIn every journey
column9: headwinds are\u00c2\u00a0inevitable. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve experienced our fair share at Twitter\u00c2\u00a0\u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00e2\u0080\u0093 and\u00c2\u00a0across our industry\u00e2\u0080\u0094 and yet our focus remains steady. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re continuing our work to support our Tweepforce with our global Business Resource Groups (BRGs) front and center. As we welcome change
column10: our commitment does not waver: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re on a journey to become the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s most inclusive
column11: diverse
column12: equitable
column13:
and accessible (IDEA) tech company.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Along the way
column14: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve experienced a global pandemic
column15: war outbreaks
column16: waves of inequity and unfair treatment
column17: and violence toward historically-excluded communities
column18:
and ongoing global uncertainty. Each new challenge adds more urgency to our work ââÂ to do even more and keep showing up for our Tweeps around the world when and where they need us most.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
While the global macro-economic environment has triggered a slowdown in hiring across the industry
column19: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re still making progress against our 2025 Tweepforce representation goals
column20: just not as fast or evenly as before. (Take a look at our Q2 2022 diversity data.) As\u00c2\u00a0 we navigate the challenges
column21: our new reality also presents an opportunity for us to double down on inclusion. In fact
column22: during times of macro-economic uncertainty
column23:
investments in the principles of inclusion and allyship improve outcomes for everyone.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Calling all allies
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Simply put
column24: it's during times of uncertainty when allies are needed most. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re focused on empowering even more allies to stand in solidarity with Tweeps and continue to cultivate a truly inclusive culture. To recap
column25:
our allyship principles are:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Learn.Â Challenge your assumptions. Seek out information that expands your worldview.
Ask.Â Ask people about their unique lived experiences. Learn the personal journeys of others.
Show up.Â Go where youâre invited. Be present
column26:
engage authentically. 
Speak up.Â Your voice has power. Use it to intervene on behalf of and advocate for others.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Allyship is not who you are
column27: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s what you do. At Twitter
column28: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve introduced a portfolio of IDEA learning and development courses in recent years to underscore our first principle of allyship and empower all Tweeps with the knowledge and understanding to show up and do the work every day. Today
column29:
we share how we got there.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
#UntilWeAllBelong Toolkit
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We introduced the first iteration of our Inclusion & Diversity (I&D) trainings in 2019. Initially designed as an allyship resource
column30:
the coursework eventually evolved into three learning modules:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Allyship 101:Â A deep dive into our four principles.
Words Matter:Â Geared towards unlearning microaggressions.
Healthy Conversations:Â Learn the skills and practices that make everyday conversations on tough topics healthy and straightforward.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As Tweeps dove into the coursework
column31:
they shared feedback and we learned a lot. Hereâs our key takeaways:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Thereâs a high demand for this type of coursework. It should be ongoing and always-on. 
Not all courses should be mandatory for all Tweeps â but managers are expected to understand the fundamentals.
Weâre a global company
column32:
but regional context matters.
We need to meaningfully embed equity and accessibility into everything we do.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Based on those findings
column33: our IDEA and Learning & Development (L&D) teams joined forces to create the #UntilWeAllBelong Toolkit. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a new
column34:
expanded portfolio of self-paced e-learnings that empowers Tweeps to double down on their IDEA learning journey and ensure that our entire Tweepforce is equipped with the tools and resources to drive inclusion at the individual and team level. The toolkit complements the many outstanding courses available for Tweeps via our L&D team including our leadership development programs for Women (WELead and Chief) and underrepresented Tweeps (The Power of Choice and McKinseyâs Black & Latinx Leadership Academy).
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The #UntilWeAllBelong Toolkit is available to all Tweeps
column35: from day one
column36:
as they begin (or continue) their IDEA learning journey with us. Itâs also required coursework for all managers at Twitter. We took this approach with managers because of the unique role they play in promoting the health of their teams and fostering a truly inclusive environment. It introduces five new e-learnings that focus on IDEA topics frequently requested across our Tweepforce:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Allyship 101:Â Practicing authentic allyship is critical. This e-learning will introduce you to Twitter's Four Principles of Allyship and ways you can practice allyship right now.
Anti-Racism 101:Â Begin to understand and practice anti-racism as a mindset and learn how to apply it to your everyday work.
Breaking Down Bias:Â Having biases is a normal part of the human brain function. But we all need to work to recognize
column37: unpack
column38: and interrupt those biases to maintain a more inclusive and diverse workplace.\nInclusive Leadership:\u00c2\u00a0Anyone
column39: regardless of level of seniority
column40: role
column41: or tenure can be a part of creating an inclusive workplace. Learn the principles of Inclusive Leadership. \nWords Matter: Microaggressions communicate messages of exclusion
column42:
based on someone's identity. They are not always intentional or obvious so it's important to be aware of them and how they impact people.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
To ensure the coursework is globally inclusive
column43: our IDEA team offers live sessions that serve as companions to the e-learnings and allow for exploration and workshopping of regional/country issues or with a particular team. For example
column44: following all-team participation in our \u00e2\u0080\u0098Breaking Down Bias\u00e2\u0080\u0099 e-learning
column45: teams can opt to participate in a Bias Disruption Workshop. This allows Tweeps who work together to explore their IDEA maturity levels\u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00e2\u0080\u0093 both as a team and individually\u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00e2\u0080\u0093 and where bias may show up in their working environment
column46:
as well as develop a charter of practical interventions and behaviors to disrupt that bias.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The courses in the #UntilWeAllBelong Toolkit were designed for Tweeps
column47: with our unique culture and needs in mind. But the coursework covers important topics that are timely and relevant beyond the walls of Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00e2\u0080\u0093 many companies and communities grapple with the same themes. And because this work takes all of us
column48:
weâre pleased to share the courses from Twitterâs #UntilWeAllBelong Toolkit publicly here today for anyone to take.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
While weâre proud of this new offering
column49:
it's just the beginning. The toolkit and coursework is intended to grow and evolve with us as we drive our work forward.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Prioritizing equity and accessibility
At the end of last year
column50: we expanded the remit of our team from Inclusion & Diversity (I&D) to Inclusion
column51: Diversity
column52:
Equity & Accessibility (IDEA). We did this to reflect work thatâs already underway to center equity and accessibility across all that we do.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Equity lens We define Equity as ensuring that each individual has access to what they need to be successful
column53: acknowledging that
column54: given our unique identities and different relationships to power and privilege
column55: we all start from different places. Distinct from equality
column56: this concept of fairness and justice takes into consideration historical and current privilege
column57: marginalization
column58: and challenges systemic oppression.  Tactically
column59: that means we practice \"equity-mindfulness\" by centering the needs and experiences of our most vulnerable populations\u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00e2\u0080\u0093 both in the annual planning process (with the help of equity impact assessments) and on an ongoing basis (through equity primers).  Building on our longstanding public work in pay equity and our internal efforts around performance and promotion equity
column60: our IDEA business partnering team\u00c2\u00a0(working across Twitter to create equitable and meaninful connections) is currently piloting an equity training aimed at developing equity fluency in program design. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to share more about that program in upcoming blogs.\nAccessibility Making Twitter more accessible is all of our work. Our Center of Excellence for Accessibility\u00c2\u00a0 regularly hosts internal trainings and provides support to embed accessibility principles across Twitter including Marketing and Communications
column61: People
column62: Studio
column63: Twitter Next
column64: Customers
column65: Real Estate & Workplace (REW)
column66: and ArtHouse teams. This work complements the efforts already underway on the product accessibility team (AET) to ensure our service is accessible to everyone who uses Twitter. As we build on this work
column67: we hope to eventually evolve the materials into a stand-alone e-learning focused on accessibility that will become part of the #UntilWeAllBelong toolkit for everyone to experience.  In addition to launching workshops to support our business partners
column68: our Center of Excellence for Accessibility also launched an accessible meetings and events policy and a new internal
column69: streamlined process to enable meeting and event hosts to provide accessibility features for in-person and virtual events
column70:
as well as meetings by default. The new policy has removed the burden on Tweeps with disabilities to request accommodations for company-wide meetings/events.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Taking our toolkit public
Transparency drives the work we do at Twitter. Itâs how we make strides in serving the public conversation. Thatâs why
column71: with the publishing of today\u00e2\u0080\u0099s IDEA Q2 Report
column72: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re making the resources in the #UntilWeAllBelong Toolkit available to everyone. We believe equipping candidates
column73: customers
column74: peers
column75: and the people who use our service the opportunity to join us on our IDEA journey will create a stronger
column76: more equitable world. \u00c2\u00a0So
column77: while learning is the first step to our allyship principles
column78: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s also a critical part of cultivating a culture of belonging \u00e2\u0080\u0093 wherever you are. Taking our toolkit public is one step forward but our work is not done.  Change is inevitable
column79:
but while the road ahead is long â progress is certain. And we wonât stop #UntilWeAllBelong.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@TwitterTogether
#UntilWeAllBelong
Tweet

diversity
#UntilWeAllBelong

column8: 12 July 2022\nLink copied successfully\nIn the first half of 2022
column9: there were approximately 1.5 BILLION Tweets about gaming \u00e2\u0080\u0093 a record half following up on a record year for gaming conversation in 2021. The 36% increase in Tweets about gaming year-over-year* was driven by big-time conversations around game releases like Elden Ring

column12: Playstation\u00e2\u0080\u0099s State of Play and Summer Game Fest.\nGamers around the world continued to come to Twitter to discuss all of the latest happenings and trends. From new game releases to patch notes to highlights from major esports events \u00e2\u0080\u0093 it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s all happening on Twitter. \nGenshin Impact remained atop the charts for Most Tweeted About Video Game globally

column3: "title": "Be part of the hype: Introducing Product Drops"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Be part of the hype: Introducing Product Drops
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 8 June 2022\nLink copied successfully\nEditor\u00e2\u0080\u0099s note:\u00c2\u00a0As of July 2022
column9: Product Drops and Product Details Page are now supported on Android devices in the US.\u00c2\u00a0As of October 2022
column10: Product Drops is available to all qualifying merchants in the U.S. and can be accessed through the Twitter Shopping Manager. Last updated: October 26
column11: 2022.\nPicture this: Your favorite brand announces that it's dropping a new collection in a few weeks. The weeks fly by and on drop day\u00e2\u0080\u00a6 you completely forget about it. And that hot new item you wanted? All gone.\nIf this sounds familiar
column12:
weâve got something for you.
People come to Twitter to talk about products and product drops every day. And merchants have long been dropping products on Twitter without any native product support. Weâre excited to change that and introduce new shopping features that empower shoppers to stay on top of the launches that matter most to them and provide merchants with another way to engage shoppers around big product moments.
Meet Product Drops â the newest member of the Twitter Shopping family.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
With Product Drops
column13: when a merchant Tweets about an upcoming launch
column14: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll see a \u00e2\u0080\u009cRemind me\u00e2\u0080\u009d button at the bottom of the Tweet. With one tap
column15: you can request to be reminded of the Drop. On launch day
column16: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll get an in-app notification in your Notifications tab 15 minutes before and at the time of the drop
column17: so you can be among the first to shop on the merchant\u00e2\u0080\u0099s website and (hopefully) beat out other shoppers. When you click on the notification
column18: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll see a \u00e2\u0080\u009cShop on website\u00e2\u0080\u009d button to purchase the item on the merchant\u00e2\u0080\u0099s website.\nBefore you click the \u00e2\u0080\u009cRemind me\u00e2\u0080\u009d button
column19: we know you probably want to know a little more about what you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re even signing up for. What\u00e2\u0080\u0099s the product? How much is it? What are people saying about it? We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve got your back: when you click on the merchant\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Tweet
column20: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll open the Product Details Page \u00e2\u0080\u0093 a full-screen space where you can see all the information you need to make informed and confident purchase decisions. This includes the price
column21: pictures
column22: a description of the product
column23: and a clickable hashtag that will show you what other shoppers on Twitter are saying about the product.\nProduct Drops are available to all qualifying merchants in the United States and can be managed in the\u00c2\u00a0Twitter Shopping Manager.\u00c2\u00a0We've tested Product Drops with brands including\u00c2\u00a0@Dior
column24: \u00c2\u00a0@Fossil\u00c2\u00a0x\u00c2\u00a0@JeffStaple
column25: \u00c2\u00a0@HomeDepot
column26: \u00c2\u00a0@LEGO_Group
column27: and\u00c2\u00a0@unionlosangeles. Shoppers in the U.S. who use Twitter in English on iOS and Android devices will be able to see and engage with Product Drops.\nDon\u00e2\u0080\u0099t miss out on these drops! Follow these merchants on Twitter today and keep an eye on @TwitterBusiness for news about other drops. \nStay tuned! We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll share more as we iterate on these new features and bring them to more merchants and more shoppers. If you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re curious about our other shopping features check out the Shop Spotlight
column28: Live Shopping
column29:
and Twitter Shops.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

#OnlyOnTwitter

column3: "title": "FTC settlement: Our commitment to protecting your privacy and security"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
FTC settlement: Our commitment to protecting your privacy and security
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 25 May 2022\nLink copied successfully\nOn May 25
column10: Twitter reached a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) regarding a privacy incident disclosed in 2019 when some email addresses and phone numbers provided for account security purposes may have been inadvertently used for advertising. This issue was addressed as of September 17
column12: and today we want to reiterate the work we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to do to protect the privacy and security of the people who use Twitter.\nKeeping data secure and respecting privacy is something we take extremely seriously
column13: and we have cooperated with the FTC every step of the way. In reaching this settlement
column14: we have paid a $150M USD penalty
column15: and we have aligned with the agency on operational updates and program enhancements to ensure that people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s personal data remains secure and their privacy protected.\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s commitment to security and privacy is not a point-in-time exercise for us but a core value we constantly enhance by updating our practices to meet the evolving needs of our customers. The recently announced Data Governance Committee is an embodiment of our dedication to strengthen the implementation of our privacy and security policies and standards
column16: as well as to expand our internal privacy and security review processes during the product development life cycle.\nMoving forward
column17: we will continue to make investments in this work
column18: including building and evolving processes
column19: implementing technical measures
column20: and conducting regular auditing and reporting to ensure we are mitigating risk at every level and function at Twitter. We will also continue to partner with the FTC
column21: and our security and privacy regulators around the world
column22:
on our shared mission of building useful products and services that meet our customersâ needs while keeping the information they share with us secure and respectful of their privacy.Â 
Â

column3: "title": "Celebrating Twitter for Good"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nCelebrating Twitter for Good\nFriday
column8: 20 May 2022\nLink copied successfully\nToday
column9: May 20
column10: marks our 26th Twitter For Good Day
column11: a company-wide biannual day when Tweeps around the world\u00c2\u00a0 come together for the communities that we serve. Every day
column12: the Twitter for Good team brings company and community together as a force for good through various partnerships and activations. However
column13: on Twitter for Good Day
column14: everyone at Twitter is encouraged to participate in activities that benefit their local communities. This year marks a return for many to in-person volunteering
column15: something that was largely paused due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Because of the pandemic
column16: our teams were able to adapt and still hold four virtual Twitter for Good Days.\nWhether it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s training students in online safety and media literacy skills
column17: serving meals and playing bingo with seniors
column18: or conducting mock interviews with aspiring tech professionals
column19: Twitter for Good Day is a chance to get out and learn about our neighbors and collectively make a difference where we live and work. Follow #TwitterForGood to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening around the world.\nMilestones for our employee matching program\nToday also marks a total of $10 million dollars donated through our employee matching program since its launch in August of 2018. Since its inception
column20: the program has evolved significantly
column21: including a ten-fold increase in the number of organizations we support. Tweeps have been especially successful at launching their own personal campaigns
column22: raising dollars from friends and family to then use against our employee match.\u00c2\u00a0\nDuring major world events
column23: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also increased the number of dollars matched by Twitter
column24: surging to match three times the amount donated during events of particular interest to Tweeps and in support of causes and organizations they care about. Thus far
column25: our employees have donated to 3
column26: 318 organizations in 50 countries.\nLaunching ArtHouse for Good\nArtHouse
column27: Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s in-house content creation team for brands
column28: and Twitter for Good have joined forces to launch ArtHouse for Good
column29: a new social impact initiative that helps nonprofit organizations amplify their voice on Twitter.\nOver the past year
column30: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve collaborated with partners around the world to elevate their content through pro bono
column31: world-class creative content production and consultation. This includes editing and optimizing content
column32: bringing in\u00c2\u00a0 talented artists and creators
column33:
and providing strategic guidance around best practices on Twitter. Weâve also worked in lockstep with our creative colleagues on Twitter NEXT to bring these projects to life. Here are a few examples:Â 
Promoting environmental conservation with IPAM Amazoni
We partnered with the Amazon Environmental Research Institute (IPAM) to raise awareness of the deforestation crisis happening in the Amazon forest. The key element of the campaign was to create and introduce a new persona to the Twitter timeline: Maya.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Maya was created as a new and innovative way to connect with audiences on Twitter through IPAMâs handle. Our team worked with activist
column34: creator
column35: and journalist Alice Patax\u00c3\u00b3 to develop Maya\u00e2\u0080\u0099s voice and tone
column36: and collaborated with creative agency
column37: Clint Studio
column38: to bring Maya to life through illustrations and artistry.\u00c2\u00a0\nAmplifying Dalit History Month with the National Campaign on Dalit Human Rights\nFor Dalit History Month in India
column39: we worked with the National Campaign on Dalit Human Rights (NCDHR) to showcase
column40: highlight and support the presence and work of 5 key nonprofit partners from India focused on supporting marginalized communities and furthering their voices
column41:
both on and off the service. Optimized content that was produced for this campaign resulted in over 11 million impressions and over 500K Tweet engagements.Â¹Â  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Whatâs next?
At Twitter
column42: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to uniting profit and purpose and harnessing the power of our company to strengthen healthy public conversation. To learn more about Twitter ArtHouse and Twitter for Good
column43: follow @ArtHouse and @TwitterForGood and read more about our initiatives here.\n\u00c2\u00b9 [Source: Twitter Internal Data. Time Frame: April 13
column45:
2022.]

column3: "title": "Introducing our crisis misinformation policy"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Introducing our crisis misinformation policy
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 19 May 2022\nLink copied successfully\nAround the world
column9: people use Twitter to find reliable information in real time. During periods of crisis \u00e2\u0080\u0093 such as situations of armed conflict
column10: public health emergencies
column11: and large-scale natural disasters \u00e2\u0080\u0093 access to credible
column12: authoritative information and resources is all the more critical.\u00c2\u00a0\nToday
column13: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re introducing our crisis misinformation policy \u00e2\u0080\u0093 a global policy that will guide our efforts to elevate credible
column14: authoritative information
column15: and will help to ensure viral misinformation isn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t amplified or recommended by us during crises. In times of crisis
column16: misleading information can undermine public trust and cause further harm to already vulnerable communities. Alongside our existing work to make reliable information more accessible during crisis events
column17: this new approach will help to slow the spread by us of the most visible
column18: misleading content
column19: particularly that which could lead to severe harms. \nDeveloping the policy \nTeams at Twitter have worked to develop a crisis misinformation framework since last year
column20: drawing on key input from global experts and human rights organizations. For the purposes of this policy
column21: we define crises as situations in which there is a widespread threat to life
column22: physical safety
column23: health
column24: or basic subsistence. This definition is consistent with the United Nations\u00e2\u0080\u0099 definition of a humanitarian crisis and other humanitarian assessments.\nDown the line
column25: as we expand our approach
column26: we will enforce around other emergent global crises
column27: informed by the United Nations Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC)\u00e2\u0080\u0099s emergency response framework
column28: and other global humanitarian frameworks. \nAddressing the most severe harms \nDuring moments of crisis
column29: establishing whether something is true or false can be exceptionally challenging. To determine whether claims are misleading
column30: we require verification from multiple credible
column31: publicly available sources
column32: including evidence from conflict monitoring groups
column33: humanitarian organizations
column34: open-source investigators
column35: journalists
column36: and more.\u00c2\u00a0\nConversation moves quickly during periods of crisis
column37: and content from accounts with wide reach are most likely to rack up views and engagement. To reduce potential harm
column38: as soon as we have evidence that a claim may be misleading
column39: we won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t amplify or recommend content that is covered by this policy across Twitter \u00e2\u0080\u0093 including in the Home timeline
column40: Search
column41: and Explore. In addition
column42: we will prioritize adding warning notices to highly visible Tweets and Tweets from high profile accounts
column43: such as state-affiliated media accounts
column44: verified
column45: official government accounts.\u00c2\u00a0 \nSome examples of Tweets that we may add a warning notice to include:\u00c2\u00a0\nFalse coverage or event reporting
column46: or information that mischaracterizes conditions on the ground as a conflict evolves;\nFalse allegations regarding use of force
column47: incursions on territorial sovereignty
column48: or around the use of weapons;\nDemonstrably false or misleading allegations of war crimes or mass atrocities against specific populations;\nFalse information regarding international community response
column49: sanctions
column50: defensive actions
column51: or humanitarian operations.\nStrong commentary
column52: efforts to debunk or fact check
column53:
and personal anecdotes or first person accounts do not fall within the scope of the policy.
What youâll see on Twitter
Tweets with content that violate the crisis misinformation policy will be placed behind a warning notice that looks like this:Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Image of crisis misinformation warning notice 
          
          
        
People on Twitter will be required to click through the warning notice to view the Tweet
column54: and the content won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t be amplified or recommended across the service. In addition
column55: Likes
column56: Retweets
column57: and Shares will be disabled
column58: and the notice will link to more information about our approach to crisis misinformation.\u00c2\u00a0\nContent moderation is more than just leaving up or taking down content
column59: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve expanded the range of actions we may take to ensure they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re proportionate to the severity of the potential harm. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve found that not amplifying or recommending certain content
column60: adding context through labels
column61: and in severe cases
column62: disabling engagement with the Tweets
column63: are effective ways to mitigate harm
column64: while still preserving speech and records of critical global events.\u00c2\u00a0 \nWhile this first iteration is focused on international armed conflict
column65: starting with the war in Ukraine
column66: we plan to update and expand the policy to include additional forms of crisis. The policy will supplement our existing work deployed during other global crises
column67: such as in\u00c2\u00a0Afghanistan
column68: Ethiopia
column69:
and India. 
You can read more about our crisis misinformation policy in the Help Center. 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet

column3: "title": "Accelerating our climate commitments on Earth Day"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Accelerating our climate commitments on Earth Day
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 22 April 2022\nLink copied successfully\nThis month
column9: the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change published a new and alarming report
column10: underscoring the urgency of the climate crisis \u00e2\u0080\u0093 \u00e2\u0080\u009cimmediate and deep emissions reductions
column11: \u00e2\u0080\u009d they wrote
column12: are necessary to turn the tide on global warming.\nNow more than ever
column13: meaningful climate action
column14: from all of us
column15: is critical. Today \u00e2\u0080\u0093 on #EarthDay2022 \u00e2\u0080\u0093 we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sharing more about our work to serve the climate conversations happening across Twitter
column16: plus the latest on our own sustainability commitments.\u00c2\u00a0 \nClimate-forward approach to ads\u00c2\u00a0\nPeople around the world use Twitter to connect with others passionate about protecting our planet. Last year
column17: we introduced a dedicated Topic to help people find personalized conversations about climate change. And
column18: to support conversation around #COP26
column19: we rolled out pre-bunks \u00e2\u0080\u0094 hubs of credible
column20: authoritative information across a range of key themes
column21: like the science backing climate change
column22: made available in the Explore tab
column23: Search
column24: and Trends.\u00c2\u00a0\nTo better serve these conversations
column25: misleading advertisements on Twitter that contradict the scientific consensus on climate change are prohibited
column26: in line with our inappropriate content policy. We believe that climate denialism shouldn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t be monetized on Twitter
column27: and that misrepresentative ads shouldn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t detract from important conversations about the climate crisis. This approach is informed by authoritative sources
column28: like the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change Assessment Reports.\u00c2\u00a0 \nWe recognize that misleading information about climate change can undermine efforts to protect the planet. In the coming months
column29: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll have more to share on our work to add reliable
column30: authoritative context to the climate conversations happening on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0 \nSustainability at Twitter \nWe continue to accelerate our sustainability efforts
column31: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re laser focused on reducing our own carbon footprint. Through targeted work
column32: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve lowered our emissions for the second straight year \u00e2\u0080\u0093 even as the company grew.\nIn 2019
column33: we shared plans to achieve 100% carbon-neutral power sourcing in our current data centers by the end of 2022. With the help of our partners at Watershed
column34: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be utilizing zero-carbon electricity for all of our data centers
column35: and for surrounding offices in the US and Canada. Our Renewable Energy Certificates (RECs) are sourced from solar and wind power projects in the same geographic region in which energy was used
column36: and cover 100% of Scope 2 emissions from these sites.\u00c2\u00a0 \nEarlier this year
column37: we joined the EU climate pact
column38: committing to ambitious North Star and Pathway pledges
column39: in line with Paris Agreement goals. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to transitioning to renewable electricity in all our EU leased operations; using 100% carbon-neutral energy in our directly leased buildings by 2025; and upping our investments in carbon removal technologies.\u00c2\u00a0 \nIn 2021
column40: we were proud to join the Science Based Target Initiative (SBTi)
column41: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re actively pursuing those targets. By 2030
column42: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re set to have significantly reduced our greenhouse gas emissions
column43: paving the way for our net-zero journey.\u00c2\u00a0 \nSince 2020
column44: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve measurably advanced our CDP score
column45: achieving a B grade for our comprehensive reporting on Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s sustainability efforts. We believe\u00c2\u00a0that transparency should be central to our approach to sustainability.\u00c2\u00a0We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to report on our progress
column46: providing regular
column47:
public-facing updates against our declared targets.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Climate community 
Tackling the climate crisis requires meaningful
column48: sustained collaboration. Through #AdsForGood grants
column49: on-service support
column50: trainings
column51: and more
column52: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re partnering with organizations committed to environmental conservation and sustainability. These include\u00c2\u00a0Earth Day Network
column53: \u00c2\u00a0United Nations (UN) Environment Programme
column54: \u00c2\u00a0UN Framework Convention on Climate Change
column55: \u00c2\u00a0UN Development Programme
column56: \u00c2\u00a0Greenpeace
column57: \u00c2\u00a0Voice for the Planet
column58: \u00c2\u00a0Let Me Breathe
column59: \u00c2\u00a0WWF
column61: \u00c2\u00a0FridaysForFuture
column62: \u00c2\u00a0We Don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t Have Time
column63: \u00c2\u00a0Climate Reality Project
column64: and others.\nWhat people are saying \nThe climate conversation happening on Twitter is ever-expanding and uniquely global. Since 2021
column65: conversation about sustainability has grown by more than 150%. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen a 60%+ increase in terms like \u00e2\u0080\u009crestoring\u00e2\u0080\u009d and \u00e2\u0080\u009crebalancing.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Discussion around waste reduction has increased by over 100%
column66: and decarbonization by more than 50%. We know that protecting the environment is something that people on Twitter care about
column67: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re always thinking about other ways to serve these conversations.\u00c2\u00a0\nHow to get involved \nWe all have a part we can play in tackling this urgent
column68: global crisis. From volunteering with an environmental organization in your community
column69: to joining a Twitter Space with environmental experts
column70: to learning more about protecting our planet
column71:
there are lots of ways to get involved.Â 
We encourage you to Tweet along with the #EarthDay2022 conversation happening on Twitter and follow the Climate ChangeÂ TopicÂ for more.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet

column3: "title": "Inclusion
column7: "topic": "Company"
column8: "author": "James Loduca (he/him)"
column9: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/company/2022/inclusion-diversity-equity-accessibility-report-our-global-approach-April-2022"
column10: "post_text": "Company\nInclusion
column11: Diversity
column12: Equity
column13:
Accessibility Q1 2022: Our Global Approach
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column14: 19 April 2022\nLink copied successfully\nOur sights remain on the horizon. Since we announced our five-year Tweepforce representation goals at the top of 2020
column15: we have made great strides in Inclusion
column16: Diversity
column17: Equity
column18: and Accessibility (IDEA). We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve accelerated in the United States and are purposefully investing more IDEA resources globally because this work isn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t bound to one region or country. Simply put
column19:
we canât serve a global public conversation without a globally inclusive approach.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In our recent 2021 Annual Report
column20: \u00e2\u0080\u009cLift as we rise\u00e2\u0080\u009d we shared more diversity data
column21: which included three new global populations (military veterans
column22: Tweeps with disabilities and those who identify as LGBTQIA+) and for the first time retention rates among Global Women Tweeps
column23: US Black Tweeps
column24:
and US Latinx Tweeps.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Three months later
column25: I\u00e2\u0080\u0099m pleased to share that we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve continued to make good progress\u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00e2\u0080\u0093 although not as evenly as we would like. We are particularly conscious of the need to do even more to diversify our leadership
column26: invest in Women talent globally
column27:
and close the gap for representation of US Latinx talent. View our latest numbers on our Careers site.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
One thing is clear from these numbers: we are on track to achieve our 2025 vision for representation of talent from underrepresented US populationsââ a full two years early.Â  As we approach that milestone
column28: we are mindful that we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll need a new vision for Tweepforce representation
column29: and it must be globally inclusive. With that
column30:
hereâs a deeper look at the global work that will inform our approach: 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Expanding Global Self-ID
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Our path always starts with cultivating a company that reflects the diversity of the amazing people who use our service every day. Until 2021
column31: Tweeps had the opportunity to voluntarily self-report race and ethnicity (in the US) and gender (globally). We knew we needed to go further if we were to build out a globally inclusive approach
column32:
so we redesigned our Self-ID program. Hereâs an overview:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
What is Self-ID?Â Self-ID refers to the process by which employers invite employees to voluntarily share certain personal information with their employer to inform inclusion
column33: diversity
column34: equity and accessibility efforts.\u00c2\u00a0At Twitter
column35: we expanded Self-ID to include more categories for all Tweeps around the world. Categories on our new Self-ID questionnaire include disability
column36: gender identity
column37: military service
column38: race
column39: and sexual orientation. We also ask about caregiver status
column40: education
column41: language
column42: religion
column43:
and socio-economic background. Weâre taking these bold steps to propel our company and industry forward. Check out our Self-ID questionnaire below.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
PDF
Self-ID Questionnaire
#UntilWeAllBelong
Download
How did we approach expanding Self-ID?Â Our new Global Self-ID system was built from the ground up with input from a number of cross-functional stakeholders
column44: including:\nGlobal Business Resource Group (BRG) Leaders: Knowing we cannot accurately capture 100% of all identities that make up our Tweepforce
column45: our first step was to align with our BRG communities. The cultural insights and competencies they brought to the work from the very outset ensured the questions we asked were relevant and as inclusive as can be. They also played a key role as champions and advocates to drive participation across Twitter.\nSystems & Testing: Our People Systems team reviewed a number of survey tools and systems
column46: assessing each for accessibility
column47: capability and suitability to achieve optimum user experience and data analysis. We ultimately decided on a bespoke Workday/AEM (Adobe Experience Manager) platform that allowed for key functionality
column48: including the ability to multi-select answers and next level drop down options based on what a Tweep selected.\nAccessibility: Our Center Of Excellence for Accessibility and IT teams worked to ensure compliance with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines \u00e2\u0080\u009cAA\u00e2\u0080\u009d standards so that Self-ID is free from barriers which could prevent access for assistive technology users. While this represents a significant step forward
column49: we have more work to do to ensure we are accessible to all\u00e2\u0080\u0094 at Twitter
column50: and on Twitter.\nLegal: Our Legal teams led efforts to adhere to local laws enabling us to invite 97% of all Tweeps to voluntarily share who they are. Acknowledging there are some markets where it is not advisable/legally permissible to ask for certain sensitive personal information
column51: we provided an anonymous survey.\nPrivacy: Our Privacy team ensured we adhered to complex data privacy issues globally. In offices with a very small number of employees and where Self-ID disclosures would be potentially identifiable
column52: raising data privacy concerns
column53: we were unable to expand the Self-ID program. Additionally
column54: we aligned with our Privacy team on data access
column55: storage and deletion to ensure we build trust in the Self-ID program.\nCommunications: Our internal communications team partnered on a multi-channel socialization strategy that our HRBPs and BRGs evangelized for maximum Tweep awareness and participation
column56: including: how-to videos
column57: data privacy and consent messaging
column58: extensive FAQs
column59: dedicated intranet landing site
column60: executive champions & messaging
column61:
and a campaign video.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Global Diversity Framework
As a global company
column62: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re mindful that the diversity of our Tweeps across regions is vast. Against this backdrop
column63: it is not always easy to even define diversity categories at a global level. So
column64: to complement what we learned about our Tweeps through our expanded Self-ID
column65: we conducted research to learn about the global markets where Twitter has a presence and developed a Global Diversity Framework to help us define diversity and inform how we approach this work across regions. Two key findings inform our Global Diversity Framework:\nThere are a number of categories and underrepresented populations that all international regions have in common
column66: including Gender
column67: Ethnicity & Race
column68: Disability
column69: and LGBTQ+
column70: which we are adapting as priority focus areas.\u00c2\u00a0\nThere is also a range of country-specific underrepresented and historically-excluded communities related to language
column71: religion
column72:
and socio-economic status in International regions.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
So whatâs ahead?
Self-ID and our Global Diversity Framework are just the beginning and have already provided us a lens to ensure our IDEA programming is regionally relevantââ especially for historically-excluded communities.
In short
column73: these two programs are designed to consciously include. They will help us evaluate the equity of our policies
column74: procedures
column75: and programs like professional development
column76: mentorship
column77: and sponsorship
column78: as well as promotions and performance management. Critically
column79: the combination of Self-ID and the Global Diversity Framework helps us identify representation gaps in every part
column80: level
column81: and region of Twitter \u00e2\u0080\u0094 along with the evidence base to set goals and targets for global inclusion into the future.\nAs we prepare to introduce a new globally-inclusive Tweepforce representation five-year vision at the end of this year
column82: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re not waiting around.\u00c2\u00a0This year
column83: we will pilot targeted hiring programs in each of the international regions focusing on Women in engineering and tech in Ireland
column84: India
column86: as well as Black talent in Brazil.\nWe know increasing representation is as much about talent retention as it is about talent acquisition so we will continue to focus on our inclusion programming and leadership development globally. Building on what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve detailed in our Cultivating Inclusion blog from July 2021
column87:
hereâs some recent work weâve done and what weâre looking forward to next:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Global BRG Leadership:Â Weâve made great progress in expanding our global BRG leadership in international regions. In 2019 we set a goal to have at least 25% of our BRG Global Leadership team outside the US. Today
column88: 30% of our Global Chairs/leadership now hail from International regions including Australia
column89: Brazil
column90: Canada
column92: Ireland
column93: Japan
column94: Mexico
column95: Singapore
column96: UAE
column97: and the UK.\n#UntilWeAllBelong Toolkit:\u00c2\u00a0We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re expanding our IDEA-focused Learning & Development courses designed to cultivate inclusive Tweeps and leaders. The self-paced e-learnings will include Words Matter
column98: Allyship 101
column99: Working Across Cultures
column100: Inclusive Leadership
column101: Anti-Racism 101
column103: and Accessibility 101. To further enhance international region-specific learning
column104: we also provide tailored IDEA Training to allow for exploration and workshopping of live issues in a particular country or team. \nExpanding Global Mentorship:\u00c2\u00a0Mentorship is crucial for professional development and career advancement
column105: and yet we know that access to mentorship is historically inequitable. Mentoring@ was created to be intentionally inclusive and globally accessible. Initially piloted across our BRG communities and welcoming 1
column106: 000 participants in the first round
column107: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve just launched the second round and will expand company-wide this year. \nSponsorship:\u00c2\u00a0We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to introduce a Sponsorship program for mid-level talent in 2022. Building on Mentoring@
column108: this program will pair executives as sponsors with talent from historically-excluded backgrounds and senior Women Tweeps
column109: and will facilitate expedited career advancement opportunities.\nExecutive development:\u00c2\u00a0To complement our existing suite of development programs
column110: we introduced a new executive development program for women at the highest levels to expand their influence. We also have a personalized leadership development initiative to increase and accelerate the impact of high performers and critical talent from under-represented populations. \n#UntilWeAllBelong Summit:\u00c2\u00a0Following the sun
column111: the 2021 summit kicked off in Singapore and featured live programming across JAPAC
column114: and the US. We tackled timely regional topics and normalized important discussions about culture
column118: and social justice. We also celebrated the progress and had frank conversations about the work that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s left to do. Planning for the 2022 summit is underway. In the meantime
column119:
we have kicked off a Twitter Together speaker series for Tweeps in International regions which will run throughout 2022. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We know we need to be both intentional and tenacious to ensure we are truly globally inclusive. With the company continuing to grow at pace
column120: we are determined to ensure our IDEA work has the same positive impact wherever our Tweeps are in the world.\nGlobally integrated
column121:
locally experienced. #UntilWeAllBelong
