column3: "title": "Our ongoing approach to the war in Ukraine"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Our ongoing approach to the war in Ukraine
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 16 March 2022\nLink copied successfully\nEditorial note: This blog was first published on the 16th of March 2022
column9: and last updated on the 7th of September 2022 to include updates to our metrics on the impact of our work.\nMore on our approach in English
column10: Ukrainian
column11: and Russian\nLike so many around the world
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re disturbed and deeply saddened by the Russian invasion of Ukraine and the humanitarian crisis unfolding there. Our top priority is to promote the safety of people on and off the service
column13: and our teams are working diligently to that end.\nWe believe we have a responsibility to the public \u00e2\u0080\u0093 particularly during periods of crisis \u00e2\u0080\u0093 to proactively enforce our rules
column14: preserve access to Twitter
column15: elevate credible and reliable information
column16: protect the privacy and safety of the people who use our service and others
column17: and guard against efforts to manipulate the public conversation. \nOver the past several weeks
column18: people in Ukraine
column19: Russia
column20: and around the world have used Twitter to share critical information in real-time
column21: locate support
column22: connect with one another
column23: and raise their voices. Unfortunately
column24: we are also aware that Twitter is being restricted for some people in Russia. As we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve said previously
column25: we believe that a free and open internet is vital
column26: and that people around the world should have the same access to information. We take our collective role
column27: and the role of our service
column28: seriously.\u00c2\u00a0\nBelow
column29:
weâre sharing updates to our approach and more detailed information about our efforts.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Elevating reliable information
Given the important role that algorithms play in recommending and amplifying content online
column30: we believe that content moderation must extend beyond the leave-up-take-down binary. Our approach is two-fold:\nIf content is in violation of the Twitter Rules
column31: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll take enforcement action against it at the Tweet or account level \u00e2\u0080\u0093 this includes content removal.\nWhen the risks for immediate harm associated with a Tweet are less severe
column32: but where left uncontextualized may mislead people
column33: we focus on reducing its reach and not proactively amplifying the Tweets into peoples\u00e2\u0080\u0099 timelines. De-amplifying content significantly reduces its visibility and labels add important context.\nFrom Home Timeline to Explore
column34: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re making it easier to find reliable updates and information and enhance safety.\nOur curated Twitter Moments about the war in Ukraine share real-time news and resources in multiple languages
column35: and since the beginning of the conflict
column36: the moments have had more than 38.6 billion impressions.**\nCurators have contextualized ~3
column37: 000 related Trends\u00c2\u00a0in 17 countries and seven languages since the beginning of the crisis
column38: helping Twitter users answer the question \u00e2\u0080\u009cWhy is this trending?\u00e2\u0080\u009d by attaching representative Tweets
column39: writing explanatory titles and descriptions
column40: or associating these Trends to Moments to give users even more context.** \nOur Search and Home Timeline prompts surface critical digital safety and security resources in English
column41: Ukrainian
column42: and Russian.\nOur dedicated event pages are available in 12 languages and in more than 67 countries \u00e2\u0080\u0093 we continue to expand this tool.\nWe created a Topic to help people stay informed right in the Home Timeline
column43: as well as a Twitter List featuring reliable news sources.\nFor people using Twitter in Ukraine and Russia
column44: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve paused some Tweet recommendations from people not followed on Home Timeline to reduce the risk of spreading unhealthy content.\u00c2\u00a0\nMore broadly
column45: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re working across features like Topics
column46: Lists
column47:
and Spaces to reinforce safety measures and guard against misuse â itâs important these tools are reliable and trustworthy.
Our approach to state-affiliated mediaÂ 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Since 2020
column48: we have not recommended or amplified state-affiliated media accounts from certain countries and have added labels
column49: including to Russian-linked entities. Last month
column50: we expanded our approach
column51: adding labels to Tweets that share links to Russian state-affiliated media websites. Much of the content from state-affiliated media came from these link shares
column52: and not just from the accounts we\u00e2\u0080\u0099d been labeling as state-affiliated media.\u00c2\u00a0\nSince February 28
column53: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve labeled more than 910
column54: 175\u00c2\u00a0unique Tweets\u00c2\u00a0that contain links to Russian state-affiliated media.** As noted above
column55: and as is standard with our labels
column56: these Tweets are not eligible for amplification
column57: meaning they aren\u00e2\u0080\u0099t recommended in your home timeline
column58: notifications
column59: and other places on Twitter. Our interventions continue to make a difference in decreasing the reach of this content. (a selection of early results from the effect of these interventions showed a 30% reduction of the reach of this content*).\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve now begun adding additional labels to multiple state-affiliated media accounts from Belarus. We have also labeled one state-affiliated media account in Ukraine. As the conflict \u00e2\u0080\u0093 and online conversation \u00e2\u0080\u0093 evolves
column60: we want to equip people on Twitter with context and enable informed experiences on the service.\u00c2\u00a0 We believe that people have the right to know when a media account is affiliated with a state actor. \nDuring periods of conflict
column61: enabling access to factual
column62: reliable information
column63: and making clear which accounts are controlled by participating states
column64: is critical.\u00c2\u00a0 To serve this mission
column65: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll apply government and state-affiliated media labels to states engaged in inter-state conflict
column66: in addition to those countries already covered by our existing work. The policy will help ensure we add context to conversations about global conflicts equitably. We intend to expand on our approach
column67: labeling more countries over time.\u00c2\u00a0 \nThe recently announced European Union (EU) sanctions legally require us to withhold certain state-affiliated media content in EU member states
column68:
and we are complying with this requirement. Our global approach outside of the EU will continue to focus on de-amplifying this type of state-affiliated media content across our service and providing important context through our labels.Â  
Our approach to government labels 
We are labeling qualifying government accounts to provide additional context. Weâll be rolling out government account labels to Ukrainian government accounts.
5 April 2022
A free and open internet is vital
column69: and people around the world should have equal and shared access to information. When a government blocks or limits access to online services within their state
column70: undercutting the public\u00e2\u0080\u0099s voice and ability to freely access information
column71: but continues to use online services for their own communications
column72: a severe information imbalance is created. Particularly in moments of active
column73: armed interstate conflict
column74: the harms created by this imbalance are acute; access to information
column75: and to the ability to share information
column76: are of paramount importance.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe seek to promote open access to information through public conversation. To address the harmful dynamics created by blocks and limitations on online services
column77: we will not amplify or recommend government accounts belonging to states that limit access to free information and are engaged in armed interstate conflict \u00e2\u0080\u0093 whether Twitter is blocked in that country or not. This means these accounts won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t be amplified or recommended to people on Twitter
column78: including across the Home Timeline
column79: Explore
column80: Search
column81: and other places on the service. We will first apply this policy to government accounts belonging to Russia. \nAttempts by states to limit or block access to free information within their borders are uniquely harmful
column82: and run counter to Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s belief in healthy and open public conversation. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to treating conversations about global conflicts more equitably
column83: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to evaluate whether this policy may be applied in other contexts
column84: beyond interstate armed conflict.\u00c2\u00a0\nOn broader rule enforcement \nAs we do around major global events
column85: our safety and integrity teams are actively monitoring for potential risks. We recognize some high-profile accounts
column86: including those of journalists (especially female journalists)
column87: activists
column88: agencies
column89: and government officials
column90: may be particularly vulnerable. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re working to mitigate any attempts at targeted account takeover or manipulation and have made account security resources available in English
column92: and Russian. We are also working with our partners around the world
column93: including members of our Trust and Safety Council
column94: to identify and escalate urgent requests for support from journalists
column95: activists
column96: and others in need of assistance.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe continue to proactively assess for inauthentic behavior and other violations of our rules. As of April 2022
column97: we had removed more than 100
column98: 000 accounts*\u00c2\u00a0for violations of our platform manipulation and spam policy and this work continues today through proactive detection and human review. These accounts represent a wide range of attempts to manipulate the service \u00e2\u0080\u0093 including opportunistic
column99: financially-motivated spam \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and we don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t currently believe they represent a specific
column100: coordinated campaign associated with a government actor.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe have also seen a substantial increase in the volume of media shared with deceptive
column101: misleading
column103: including old videos of conflicts
column104: shared as if they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re taking place in Ukraine. In line with our synthetic and manipulated media policy
column105: we have labeled or removed more than 66
column106: 407 pieces of content.** \nOur teams are proactively monitoring for violations of our hateful conduct policy and rules prohibiting the promotion of violence
column107: and will continue to enforce against accounts or Tweets targeting people on the basis of their nationality and other groups as new narratives emerge. In line with our abusive behavior policy
column108: specifically regarding the denial of violent events
column109: we have taken enforcement action on numerous accounts that denied or shared misleading claims about violent actions and those affected during the war.\u00c2\u00a0 \nWe value transparency in this work
column110: and in the coming months we intend to release targeted datasets about the conflict to the Twitter Moderation Research Consortium (TMRC) for further analysis.\u00c2\u00a0\n5 April 2022\nIn the development and enforcement of our rules
column111: we remain focused on enabling public conversation
column112: and protecting the safety of people both online and offline. We are guided by international humanitarian law
column113: specifically Article 13 of Geneva Convention III (on protecting prisoners of war (PoWs) from any physical or psychological abuse or threat thereof
column114: and encompasses a prohibition on humiliating them) and do not want Twitter to be used by state actors to infringe this law. Our work to protect the conversation is informed by consultation with a wide range of trusted partners
column116: to ensure our approach considers the number of factors at play.\nTo that end
column117: we will now ask government or state affiliated media accounts to remove any media published that features prisoners of war (PoW) under our private information and media policy. \nWe will also add a warning interstitial to media published by government or state affiliated media accounts featuring PoWs
column118: that has a compelling public interest.\u00c2\u00a0\nLastly
column119: we will now require the removal of any Tweets
column121: if there is PoW content shared with abusive intent
column124: mocking/taking pleasure in suffering of PoWs
column125: or for any other behavior that violates the Twitter rules.\u00c2\u00a0 \n10 May 2022\nIn April
column126: we announced that we would not amplify or recommend government accounts of states that limit access to free information and are engaged in armed interstate conflict
column127: beginning with Russian government accounts. Our approach has proven effective \u00e2\u0080\u0093 for Russian government accounts
column129: at scale.\u00c2\u00a0 \nWe consider a range of enforcement actions
column130: and aim to ensure they're proportionate to the risk of harm created by the content. People's choices also influence how and what they see on Twitter; in this case
column131: content from these accounts will still be shown to their followers
column132:
but won't be recommended to other people on Twitter.
Our approach to monetization
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Since the week of February 21
column133: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve paused advertising in Ukraine and Russia to ensure that critical public safety information is elevated
column134: and that ads don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t detract from the conversation on Twitter.\nContent that discusses or focuses on the war
column135: or that is considered false or misleading under the Twitter Rules
column136: is not eligible for monetization. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also demonetized Search terms related to the war
column137: preventing ads from appearing on the Search results pages for certain words. \nTaking a step back
column138: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important to keep in mind that since 2017 we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve banned advertising from all accounts owned by Russia Today (RT) and Sputnik and donated the profits to NGOs working on digital literacy
column141: we banned all state-backed news media advertising and political advertising. \nSupporting impacted communities \nWe continue to engage and support humanitarian organizations on the ground. Through our giving campaign for Twitter employees
column142: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re routing donations to recognized organizations directly supporting Ukrainian refugees
column144: and making direct contributions to partner organizations.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also providing high-value product donations and Ads for Good grants to help further these organizations\u00e2\u0080\u0099 critical work and amplify their message on Twitter. So far
column145: these campaigns have made more than\u00c2\u00a0118
column147: 185 impressions*\u00c2\u00a0on Twitter. \nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next? \nAs the situation in Ukraine evolves
column148: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to iterate on our approach
column149: focusing on reducing potential harm and surfacing reliable information. Follow @TwitterSupport

column3: "title": "Twitter Shops: More space to shop"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Twitter Shops: More space to shop
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 9 March 2022\nLink copied successfully\nEditor\u00e2\u0080\u0099s note: As of March 2022
column9: the Shop Module is now referred to as the Shop Spotlight. As of June 2022
column10: Twitter Shops is now available to all merchants in the US. Last updated: August 1
column11: 2022.\nToday
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re launching a beta experiment for the newest member of the Twitter Shopping family: Twitter Shops.\u00c2\u00a0\nWith Twitter Shops
column13: merchants can handpick a collection of up to 50 products to showcase to shoppers on Twitter. The feature
column14: which is free to use
column15: gives people the chance to view products from the profiles of their favorite brands
column16: so when you talk about and discover products on the timeline
column17: you can now browse them on Twitter
column18:
too.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
When you go to the profile of a merchant that has Twitter Shops enabled
column19: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll see a \u00e2\u0080\u009cView shop\u00e2\u0080\u009d button just above their Tweets. When you tap the button
column20: it will open up that merchant\u00e2\u0080\u0099s shop
column21: where you can scroll through items. When you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re ready to purchase
column22: you can click on the product of your choice which will open an in-app browser where you can learn more about the product and checkout on the merchant\u00e2\u0080\u0099s website.\nWhile our Shop Spotlight\u00c2\u00a0allows merchants to showcase up to five products directly on their profile
column23: Twitter Shops gives merchants a larger
column24: fully-immersive space to highlight a longer catalog of products.\nLike all of our Twitter Shopping features \u00e2\u0080\u0093 the Shop Spotlight
column25: Live Shopping
column26: and our Shopping Manager \u00e2\u0080\u0093 Twitter Shops is part of a larger effort to better support professionals of all kinds \u00e2\u0080\u0093 from small businesses and creators to big brands \u00e2\u0080\u0093 who come to Twitter to do business.\nTwitter Shops is available to all merchants in the U.S. Businesses who have their Shops enabled today include @Verizon
column27: @ArdenCove
column28: @LatinxInPower
column29: @GayPrideApp
column30: and @AllIDoIsCookUS. For now
column31: people in the U.S. who use Twitter in English on iOS and Android devices will be able to view and interact with Twitter Shops.\nPeople are already talking about products on Twitter. We want Twitter Shops to be the home for merchants on Twitter where they can intentionally curate a catalog of products for their Twitter audience and build upon the product discussions already happening on our service by giving shoppers a point of action where a conversation can become a purchase.\nAs we continue to test
column32: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll explore how to make Shops more discoverable; adding new ways for merchants to tell their brand story through their Shops; expanding the number of products merchants can showcase
column33:
and bringing Twitter Shops to more merchants and more people.
Stay tuned â we look forward to making shopping easier than ever on Twitter.

column3: "title": "Building a better Birdwatch "
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Building a better Birdwatch 
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 3 March 2022\nLink copied successfully\nAs of November 2022
column9: Birdwatch is now\u00c2\u00a0Community Notes.\nLast year we launched the Birdwatch pilot \u00e2\u0080\u0094 a new
column10: collaborative way for people to add context to Tweets they believe are misleading. By empowering people to do this together
column11: they can add helpful and informative context for people from different points of view.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made a slew of improvements to Birdwatch based on feedback from contributors
column12: the public
column13: and academic researchers
column14: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re seeing promising results. In surveys with randomly sampled people on Twitter in the US
column15: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve found:\nThe majority of people found Birdwatch notes (specifically those designated helpful by Birdwatch contributors) helpful. This includes people from across the political spectrum.\nPeople in the survey were 20-40% less likely to agree with the substance of a potentially misleading Tweet after reading a note about it
column16:
compared to those who saw a Tweet without a note.Â Â 
These are encouraging signs that Birdwatch can be helpful and informative to people on Twitter. Thatâs why weâre now expanding the visibility of the pilot so we can make additional improvements with feedback from more people on Twitter.Â 
Expanding the visibility of Birdwatch
Starting today
column17: a small (and randomized) group of people on Twitter in the US will see Birdwatch notes directly on some Tweets. They\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll also be able to rate notes
column18:
providing input that will help improve Birdwatchâs ability to add context that is helpful to people from different points of view.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
To appear on a Tweet
column19: notes first need to be rated helpful by enough Birdwatch contributors from different perspectives. Difference in perspectives is determined by how people have rated notes in the past
column20: not based on demographics. You can learn more about how we assess this\u00c2\u00a0here.\nHow we got here \nWhen we started a year ago
column21: we set out to build Birdwatch in public
column22: with input from people on Twitter
column23: Birdwatch contributors
column24: academic advisors
column25: and researchers. We made all data contributed to Birdwatch publicly available
column26: along with the code that uses that data to rank notes
column27:
and we continue to do so.Â 
Feedback and insights from the Twitter community has led to key improvements to Birdwatch:
Strengthening the way Birdwatch identifies notes that a diverse set of people find helpful.
Doing more to protect contributors and help them feel more comfortable contributing to Birdwatch by rolling out auto-generated aliases for everyone in the pilot.
Helping participants understand the impact of their Birdwatch contributions by notifying them if their notes are rated helpful or if notes they rated are elevated.
Encouraging participants to include sources and clear explanations in their notes with in-app prompt reminders.
Improving the discoverability of notes that need a broader range of feedback by adding a personalized âNeeds Your Helpâ tab for pilot participants.
We recently announced a collaboration with the Associated Press and Reuters to help our teams assess the quality of information elevated by Birdwatch participants. Weâve also onboarded an advisory board of scholars and researchers who study misinformation
column28: polarization
column29: online manipulation
column30: and harassment. Advisors are from institutions including MIT
column31: the University of Washington
column32: the University of Michigan School of Information
column33:
and more.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As online misinformation continues to spread
column34: addressing false or misleading narratives at scale warrants a multi-pronged approach. As a member of the Birdwatch advisory board
column35: I\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve weighed in on its unique approach to explore a community-based tool for adding context to Tweets
column36: including its ranking system to surface the most helpful pieces of context
column37: and I look forward to seeing how this community grows.\nAmy Zhang\nProfessor
column38: University of Washington \n\u00e2\u0080\u008e@amyxzh\u00e2\u0080\u008e\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re thankful for all 10
column39: 000 pilot contributors that have played a key role in making Birdwatch what it is today. Along with the time and effort they invest in writing and rating notes
column40: Birdwatch contributors have consistently provided priceless feedback on their Birdwatch experience and shared thoughtful and honest feedback about what's working and what could be better.\nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to build in the open as we learn
column41: iterate
column42:
and expand the pilot. Follow @Birdwatch for the latest updates and to provide feedback on how weâre doing.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter

column3: "title": "#KpopTwitter reaches new heights with 7.8 billion global Tweets"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
#KpopTwitter reaches new heights with 7.8 billion global Tweets
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 27 January 2022\nLink copied successfully\nWith a massive 7.8 billion global Tweets in 2021
column9: #KpopTwitter once again showed its power by breaking its previous record of 6.7 billion Tweets in 2020. Registering a notable 16% increase in Tweet volume globally
column10:
#KpopTwitter conversations became more diverse and vibrant in 2021.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Diving deeper into the flurry of Tweets
column11: Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s analysis reveals the Top 20 countries Tweeting most about K-pop
column12: the Top 20 countries with the most K-pop fans
column13:
as well as rankings of the most Tweeted about K-pop artists and rising K-pop artists.Â  Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
With its legion of passionate and active fans
column14: Indonesia tops the list for most number of K-pop Tweets for the second consecutive year. Meanwhile
column15: the Philippines
column16: South Korea
column17: Thailand
column18: the United States
column19: Mexico
column20: Malaysia
column21: Brazil
column22: India
column23:
and Japan made it into the top 10.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
While the list of countries with the most number of fans (analyzed by unique authors) looks similar to the list for most number of Tweets
column24: with Indonesia coming in first and the others like Japan and the Philippines close behind
column25: countries like Peru
column26: Colombia
column27: Singapore
column28: and Ecuador were featured among the top 20 this year (after missing out in 2020). Meanwhile
column29: as the number of fans continues to grow in various countries
column30: Chile and Vietnam climbed the ranks by four and five positions
column31:
ultimately securing the 16th and 13th spots respectively.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Of course
column32: the 21st century pop icon
column33: BTS (@BTS_twt)
column34: takes the top spot as the most Tweeted about K-pop artist globally - with the band\u00e2\u0080\u0099s concert \u00e2\u0080\u0098BTS PERMISSION TO DANCE ON STAGE - LA\u00e2\u0080\u0099 alone contributing more than 68 million Tweets from all over the world. For the second year in a row
column35: NCT (@NCTsmtown) comes in second.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn addition to K-pop sensation BLACKPINK (@BLACKPINK) and heavyweights EXO (@weareoneEXO) being featured on the top 20 list
column36: younger groups also cemented their positions with TOMORROW X TOGETHER (@TXT_members) rising from 8th place in 2020 to 6th in 2021
column37: ATEEZ (@ATEEZofficial) climbing one spot to 9th
column38: and Stray Kids (@Stray_Kids) at 10th.\n2021 also proved to be a breakthrough year for the 4th generation of K-pop idols. ENHYPEN (@ENHYPEN_members) who were 5th on the 2020 list of rising K-pop artists impressively came in as the 3rd most Tweeted about band in 2021 (just after BTS and NCT). Within a year of their debut
column39: the group celebrated a huge achievement with their first studio album \u00e2\u0080\u009cDIMENSION:DILEMMA\u00e2\u0080\u009d becoming a \u00e2\u0080\u0098million-seller\u00e2\u0080\u0099 and placing 11th on the Billboard 200 chart. Fellow 4th generation idols aespa (@aespa_official) and ITZY (@ITZYofficial) also hit significant milestones as they first entered the top 20 list
column40: being 14th and 16th respectively.\nOther K-pop idols on the top 20 list include TREASURE (@treasuremembers)
column41: SEVENTEEN (@pledis_17)
column42: TWICE (@JYPETWICE)
column43: GOT7 (@GOT7Official)
column44: THE BOYZ (@IST_THEBOYZ)
column45: iKON (@YG_iKONIC)
column46: ASTRO (@offclASTRO)
column47: MonstaX (@OfficialMonstaX)
column48: Red Velvet (@RVsmtown)
column49:
and SHINee(@SHINee).
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Unsurprisingly ENHYPEN (@ENHYPEN_members) is first on the list of the Top 10 rising Artists
column50: followed by TOMORROW X TOGETHER (@TXT_members)
column51: TREASURE (@treasuremembers)
column52: aespa (@aespa_official)
column53: and ITZY (@ITZYofficial). Newer generation groups like IVE (@IVEstarship)
column54: CRAVITY\u00c2\u00a0 (@CRAVITYstarship)
column55: WEi (@WEi__Official)
column56: ONEUS (@official_ONEUS)
column57: and CIX (@CIX_twt) are also featured on the Top 10.\n2021 saw growing global interest in Korean entertainment beyond music\nWhile the reach of K-pop continued to skyrocket
column58: we also saw a variety of conversations as Korean dramas
column59: movies
column60: webtoons
column61: and other types of entertainment steadily cemented their place on the world stage. In particular
column62: webtoons turned K-dramas were embraced by the global audience
column63: with True Beauty
column64: Sweet Home
column65: and Navillera among the top most Tweeted about webtoons on Twitter. Of course
column66: the influence of K-pop also had a part to play. When official soundtracks included famous K-pop artists
column67: dramas and webtoons enjoyed a boost in viewership - such as BTS V\u00e2\u0080\u0099s song \u00e2\u0080\u0098Sweet Night\u00e2\u0080\u0099 for Itaewon Class.\nAs the place to be for both fans and artists to connect
column68: Twitter is a home for many celebrities from the different facets of Korean entertainment. In addition to well-known rapper Youngji (@dokgodieinsaeng) and actress Lee SeYoung (@seyoung0703)
column69: stars from the hit show Street Woman Fighter such as Monika (@monikaaashin)
column70: Honey J (@__honey_j__)
column71: and no:ze (@noze_world) started new Twitter accounts in the second half of 2021.\u00c2\u00a0\nFans enjoyed more #OnlyOnTwitter content connecting themselves closely to stars\nTwitter continues to launch new features and programs that deliver #OnlyOnTwitter content to fans everywhere. Beyond providing support to the K-pop community
column72: Twitter is also expanding our capabilities and evolving into a service to promote K-content. We have already hosted #TwitterBlueroom live sessions for movies and dramas including Q&As with the cast of The Book of Fish
column73: King Maker
column74: The Red Sleeve
column75: and One Ordinary Day. Twitter also brought #FanTweets and #BehindTheTweets to K-pop starting with BLACKPINK\u00e2\u0080\u0099s ROS\u00c3\u0089. With the introduction of Twitter Spaces in 2021
column76: Twitter has also created more opportunities and channels for fans and artists to connect and communicate
column77: building stronger relationships with each other.\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Head of Global K-pop Partnerships
column78: YeonJeong Kim says
column80: with BTS and NCT leading the conversation
column81: we could also see an increase in conversation related to rising artists such as ENHYPEN
column82: aespa
column84: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also seen discussions about Korean content across the board on Twitter growing with K-pop fans talking about not just their favorite music
column86: concerts
column87: and daily lives
column88: but showing increasing interest in dramas and webtoons with K-pop soundtracks or starring K-pop idols. As the global consumption of Korean content grows
column89:
we look forward to seeing even more diverse conversations on Twitter and providing more content you can see #OnlyOnTwitter in 2022.â
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter

column3: "title": "An update to the Twitter Transparency Center"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
An update to the Twitter Transparency Center
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 25 January 2022\nLink copied successfully\nTrust in the information we consume every day is critical to how we engage online. Trust in information found online can be established and enhanced when companies
column9: civil society and regulators are transparent about the data and processes they rely on. This
column10: alongside thoughtful policies developed by governments around the world
column11: can help elevate many of the core principles of the Open Internet. For our part
column12: since 2012 we have consistently published bi-annual updates
column13: detailing our enforcement actions housed in the Twitter Transparency Center.\u00c2\u00a0\nCoupled with this
column14: we have been explicit in our advocacy for an Open Internet that is global
column15: available to all
column16: built on open standards and rooted in the protection of human rights. As we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve said
column17: protecting the Open Internet \u00e2\u0080\u0094 which continues to be under threat \u00e2\u0080\u0094 requires meaningful transparency
column18: which is essential to holding companies and governments to account. This work is core to who we are as a company \u00e2\u0080\u0093 connecting back to the very first Twitter Transparency Report in 2012
column19:
one of the first such reports in the industry.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâre facing unprecedented challenges as governments around the world increasingly attempt to intervene and remove content. This threat to privacy and freedom of expression is a deeply worrying trend that requires our full attention. Todayâs update to the Twitter Transparency Center highlights our long-standing commitment to meaningful transparency and the pressing
column20: urgent need to defend the free
column21: secure
column22:
and global Open Internet. 
SinÃ©ad McSweeney
VP of Global Public Policy and Philanthropy
â@smcsâ
Today
column23: we continue to build on our commitment to sharing meaningful insights about the work we do through the publication of the latest update to our Twitter Transparency Center
column24: including relevant data from January 1
column26: through June 30
column27: 2021.\nInformation and removal requests\u00c2\u00a0\nAs important regulatory discussions take place across the globe
column28: we believe it is crucial for citizens to be aware of the requests made by their governments. Throughout this reporting period
column29: Twitter continued to receive requests from governments for account information and account preservations.\nGovernment preservation requests (requests to preserve account information) decreased by 4% from our most recent publication
column30: with the United States accounting for 57% of all global preservation requests.\nIn a change from our last reporting period
column31: the United States became the single largest source of government information requests with 3
column32: 026 requests
column33: accounting for 24% of the global volume we received during this period. These requests accounted for 27% of all accounts specified from around the world and Twitter complied
column34: in whole or in part
column35: with 68% of these U.S. information requests.\nTwitter partially disclosed or did not disclose information in response to 64% of global government information requests
column36: a decrease of 9% during this reporting period
column37:
under our guidelines for requesting information.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As of this reporting period
column38: Twitter has now received non-government information requests from 35 different countries since 2014
column39: including Argentina
column40: Israel
column41: and Switzerland
column42: which appeared in this report for the first time. These requests come from third parties seeking account information from Twitter
column43: for example
column44: as non-parties in a civil action
column45: or on behalf of defendants in criminal cases.\u00c2\u00a0\nJapan
column46: Brazil
column47: and the United States were the top three requesting countries when it comes to non-government requests
column48:
with all three accounting for 89% of all requests and 87% of the total accounts specified for this period.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In terms of legal demands from governments
column49: in the six month period covered in this report
column50: Twitter received 43
column51: 387 legal demands to remove content
column52: specifying 196
column53:
878 accounts. This is the largest number of accounts ever subject to removal requests in a reporting period since releasing our first transparency report in 2012.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Of the total global volume of legal demands
column54: 95% originated from only five countries (in decreasing order): Japan
column55: Russia
column56: Turkey
column57: India
column58: and South Korea. We withheld or required account holders to remove some or all of the reported content in response to 54% of these global legal demands.\nEnforcement of the Twitter Rules\nTwitter required account holders to remove 4.7M Tweets that violated the Twitter Rules. Of the Tweets removed
column59: 68% received fewer than 100 impressions prior to removal
column60: with an additional 24% receiving between 100 and 1
column61: 000 impressions. In total
column62: impressions on these violative Tweets accounted for less than 0.1% of all impressions for all Tweets during that time period.\nIn these six months
column63: Twitter permanently suspended 453
column64: 754 unique accounts for violations of our child sexual exploitation (CSE) policy \u00e2\u0080\u0094 89% of those accounts were proactively identified and removed by deploying a range of internal tools and/or by utilizing the industry hash sharing (e.g.
column65: PhotoDNA) prior to any reports filed via the designated CSE reporting channel.\nIn the first half of 2021
column66: Twitter suspended 44
column67: 974 unique accounts for promotion of terrorism and violent organizations \u00e2\u0080\u0094 93% of those accounts were proactively identified and removed.\nBroadly
column68: Twitter continues to see an overall downward trend in the number of violating accounts which is likely due to changing behaviors of these actors coupled with continued improvements of our defenses in this area.\u00c2\u00a0\nAs the Open Internet continues to be under threat around the world
column69: we will continue our advocacy and build on our work to increase meaningful transparency and accountability in the industry \u00e2\u0080\u0094 with the Twitter Transparency Center as our single source of truth in this space.\u00c2\u00a0\nTo track this work
column70:
follow @Policy and @TwitterSafety for year-round updates.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet

column3: "title": "Twitter's report in compliance with Regulation (EU) 2021/1232"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nTwitter's report in compliance with Regulation (EU) 2021/1232\nSaturday
column8:
1 January 2022
Link copied successfully
Submitted and uploaded on 3 February 2022
TWITTER REPORT (PERIOD OF AUGUST 2
column9: 2021 - DECEMBER 31
column10: 2021)\nUnder Article 3(1)(g)(vii) of Regulation (EU) 2021/1232 on a temporary derogation from certain provisions of Directive 2002/58/EC as regards the use of technologies by providers of number-independent interpersonal communications services for the processing of personal and other data for the purpose of combating online child sexual abuse
column11: came into force on the 2nd of August 2021
column12: Twitter is required to publish and submit a report to the Irish Data Protection Commission and to the European Commission.\nOverview\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s mission is to serve the public conversation. As part of this mission
column13: we have a zero tolerance approach to combating child sexual exploitation (CSE) on our service. Any content that features or promotes child sexual exploitation (CSE) is prohibited on Twitter. This may include media
column14: text
column15: illustrated
column16: or computer-generated images. Regardless of the intent
column17: viewing
column18: sharing
column19: or linking to child sexual exploitation material contributes to the re-victimisation of the depicted children. This also applies to content that may further contribute to victimisation of children through the promotion or glorification of child sexual exploitation.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe are actively working to protect children around the world from CSE. We are achieving this via advancing technology solutions
column20: intensive training and support to law enforcement
column21: and expanded education and partnerships.\nWe use a combination of machine learning and human review \u00e2\u0080\u0094 our systems are able to surface content to human moderators who use important context to make decisions about potential rule violations. This work is led by an international
column22: cross-functional team with 24-hour coverage and the ability to cover multiple languages.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhen we are made aware of CSE media
column23: including links to images of or content promoting child exploitation
column24:
the material will be removed from the site without further notice and immediately reported to The National Center for Missing & Exploited Children ("NCMEC"). The latter makes reports available to the appropriate law enforcement agencies around the world to facilitate investigations and prosecutions. NCMEC has strong relationships with law enforcement authorities and NGOs worldwide as well as with the INHOPE network.
We also have an appeal process for any potential errors that could occur.Â 
For further information on our approach please visit thisÂ page and our Transparency Center.
---
(1) the type and volumes of data processed;Â 
During this reporting period Twitter suspended 532
column25: 898 accounts for violating our CSE policy. At this time
column26: Twitter does not track the accounts which are reviewed and not actioned for any policy violations. However
column27: \u00c2\u00a0 Twitter may review personal information
column28: including account information
column29: text
column30:
and media to investigate possible violations of our CSE policy.Â 
(2) the specific ground relied on for the processing pursuant to Regulation (EU) 2016/679;Â 
Information regarding the grounds for processing relied upon by Twitter are available in our Privacy Policy and our Data Processing materials.Â Â 
(3) the ground relied on for transfers of personal data outside the Union pursuant to Chapter V of Regulation (EU) 2016/679
column31: where applicable;\u00c2\u00a0\nAs outlined in our Privacy Policy
column32: Twitter relies on Standard Contractual Clauses for such transfers.\n(4) the number of cases of online child sexual abuse identified
column33: differentiating between online child sexual abuse material and solicitation of children;\nBoth types of actions violate Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s CSE Policy
column34: but at this time we are unable to distinguish between online sexual abuse material and the specific context of each peice of material
column35: such as the solicitation of children. However
column36: during this reporting period we suspended 532
column37:
898 accounts for violating our CSE Policy.
(8) the retention policy and the data protection safeguards applied pursuant to Regulation (EU) 2016/679;Â 
The relevant retention periods for data Twitter collects are outlined in our Privacy Policy. Twitter operates a security and privacy programs which comport with the ISO standards and undergo third party audits as needed to ensure the security and the privacy of the data it processes.
(9) the names of the organisations acting in the public interest against child sexual abuse with which data has been shared pursuant to this Regulation
The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children (NCMEC) in the United States of America (https://www.missingkids.org/).

column3: "title": "Our continued collaboration with trusted partners    "
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Our continued collaboration with trusted partners    
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 17 December 2021\nLink copied successfully\nAs we work to improve the health of the public conversation
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to reaching beyond Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s virtual walls to integrate diverse perspectives that make our service better for everyone. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we regularly collaborate with trusted partners on our Trust and Safety Council\u00c2\u00a0to\u00c2\u00a0develop products and programs
column10: and to improve the Twitter Rules.\u00c2\u00a0\nToday
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sharing a recap of some of the work we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve accomplished hand-in-hand with these trusted partners
column12: as well as more about our ongoing commitment to incorporating the expertise of global experts
column13: researchers
column14: and developers to support healthy public conversation on Twitter.\nIncorporating feedback to make Twitter safer\nWe know the best version of Twitter is the one built by the people who use it. Over the past year
column15:
weâve engaged with the Trust and Safety Council on thirteen projects early in the development process. We distilled and put to use their feedback on ways we can offer a better and safer experience for people using Twitter. Their feedback directly informed our approach on several products.
Communities: We incorporated feedback on the need to manage expectations on the role that moderators play by limiting the number of responsibilities and building tools to help them manage potential harassment.
Tips: We incorporated feedback on the need to emphasize that the people on our service are responsible for transactions in a user-friendly way by asking people to agree to terms of service when enabling the feature.
Safety Mode: To mitigate the effect on limiting counter-speech
column16: a concern raised by the council particularly for people in positions of power
column17:
we decided to automatically time out interventions for seven days.
Conversation settings: We started testing a notification that reminds people they can change who can reply to their Tweets to increase awareness and adoption as a direct recommendation from the council.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitter has become an extremely important communication tool in India
column18: and it is encouraging to see Twitter take active interest and respond to the feedback given by council members. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re happy to be part of a team of trusted partners which gets heard and is able to make Twitter a safer platform for all
column19:
especially women.
Centre for Social Research
â@CSR_Indiaâ
As a founding member of the Trust and Safety Council
column20:
weâve worked alongside Twitter to help influence positive change for over a decade. We believe that everyone should benefit from technology free from abuse and harassment and bring this perspective to all council meetings. We look forward to continued collaboration with Twitter to ensure that matters raised by our organization and the people we support are integrated into Twitterâs products and policies.
 SWGfL
UK Safer Internet Centre partner
â@SWGfL_Officialâ
Transparency is core to Twitterâs approach. Through initiatives such as our open developer platform
column21: our information operations archive
column22: and our disclosures in the Twitter Transparency Center and Lumen
column23: we continue to support third-party research of what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening on Twitter. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to build on these efforts and inform the public as we improve Twitter in the open. The following are highlights from the past year.\nTwitter API for Academic Research: In early 2021
column24: we launched a dedicated Academic Research product track on the new Twitter API giving qualified researchers access to the entire history of public conversation and elevated access to real-time data for free.\u00c2\u00a0\nAlgorithmic bias bounty challenge: When we introduced our commitment to responsible machine learning
column25: we also said
column26: \u00e2\u0080\u009cthe journey to responsible
column27: responsive
column28: and community-driven machine learning systems is a collaborative one.\u00e2\u0080\u009d That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we introduced the industry\u00e2\u0080\u0099s first algorithmic bias bounty competition to draw on the global ethical AI community\u00e2\u0080\u0099s knowledge of the unintended harms of saliency algorithms to expand our own understanding and to reward the people doing work in this field.\nTwitter Moderation Research Consortium (TMRC): We announced the creation of a new global expert group\u00c2\u00a0 of academics
column29: members of civil societies and NGOs
column30: and journalists to study platform governance issues. We look forward to deeper analysis from this range of global experts and expect the collaboration to result in expanded disclosures beyond information operations to include sharing data in areas like misinformation
column31: coordinated harmful activity
column32: and safety.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nLaunch of an API curriculum:\u00c2\u00a0\u00e2\u0080\u009cGetting started with the Twitter API for Academic Research\u00e2\u0080\u009d is now being used at universities
column33: enabling students and teachers to learn how to use Twitter data for academic research. It is currently starred by over 200 academics on Github.\u00c2\u00a0\nCreation of a Developer Platform Academic Research advisory board: This group of 12 scholars began work with our team this year to better understand how we can enhance the use of the Twitter API for academic research
column34:
while increasing meaningful dialogue between the Twitter Academic program and the academic community.
Developer research highlights: We published and continued to spotlight key research areas Twitter teams are working on today in an effort to inspire even more researchers to pursue these topics.
Whatâs next? Increasing transparency and understanding on our approach to content moderation
As we continue to invite trusted partners and the public to share feedback on ways to make Twitter safe
column35: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important to be transparent about how we develop and enforce the Twitter Rules. Our newly formed Content Governance Initiative (CGI) aims to do this by developing a governance framework that provides a consistent and principled approach to the development
column36: enforcement
column37: and assessment of our global rules and policies. To build our governance framework
column38: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re engaging external stakeholders and have created an additional advisory group on our Trust and Safety Council. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue collaborating with this group and cross-functional teams across Twitter to establish standardized guidelines on policy development
column39: enforcement
column40:
and appeals that help drive a common understanding of Twitterâs approach to content moderation. The framework's principles and guidelines will aim to fulfill the following objectives:
Build legitimacy and trust through transparency and accountability.
Deepen our commitment to good governance and human rights.
Provide additional clarity on Twitterâs content moderation processes.
Affirm our commitment to serving a diverse and inclusive global community.
We recognize that achieving these objectives will not be easy. Content moderation at scale is a highly complex and challenging process. This initiative reflects our ongoing commitment to working systematically â in partnership with external stakeholders around the world â to improve the transparency and consistency of our content moderation processes.
Hereâs to another year of building togetherÂ 
We want to acknowledge the members of the Trust and Safety Council
column41: research partners
column42: civil society representatives
column43: and you
column44: the people using Twitter
column45: for continuing to hold us accountable. You challenge us
column46: offer different perspectives
column47:
and support us in our mission to safeguard the public conversation. Weâre looking forward to this next chapter and canât wait to see what we build together.Â 
Â

column3: "title": "The state of social intelligence: 2021 year in review"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
The state of social intelligence: 2021 year in review
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 14 December 2021\nLink copied successfully\nAs we exit year two of the Covid-19 Pandemic
column9: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s encouraging to see that a great many organizations have stayed the course and continued investing in their strategic use of social data alongside other data sources to solve real business problems. In my 2020 year in review I spoke about how necessity had yet again proved to be the mother of invention
column10: with pandemic related lockdowns accelerating the use of underutilized data sources
column11: such as social
column12: to understand consumer opinion and sentiment in real time. And as organizations quickly saw the value in these new sources of insight
column13: it was hard to imagine them going back to the slower
column14: more costly data and opinion gathering techniques of the past.\nThis year has proven that to be correct
column15: and with customer experience and customer centricity now all the rage
column16: social data is proving its worth by surfacing the real voice of the customer in real time. Combine this with the push to democratize insight and integrate these customer voices across the organization
column17: and I believe we are now at a tipping point in the use of social intelligence. In my conversations with dozens of brands over the past year
column18: five main themes stood out to me: \n1. The great consolidation \nYou\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve probably heard about \"the great resignation\" but in the world of social intelligence
column19: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s \"the great consolidation\" that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s top of mind. Spurred on by pandemic lockdowns and restrictions
column20: organizations took to digital transformation with gusto
column21: accelerating the digitization of their customer interactions and internal operations by three to four years according to a 2020 McKinsey study. And
column22: for many
column23: a key step in that transformation journey was to address an unwieldy and duplicative social marketing and customer experience (CX) tech stack. I observed countless organizations turning to social suites
column24: who could offer the core capabilities of content publishing
column25: customer care and listening
column26: as well as many secondary features such as advocacy
column27: content management and influencer marketing to name a few.\nBrands also realized they didn't need a dozen different social listening providers
column28: prompting them to consolidate down to one or opt for a social suite to deliver everything. They also started to ask tougher questions of prospective vendors about the quality of their AI
column29: in some cases manually auditing the vendors' annotations with human ones to compare accuracy.\u00c2\u00a0 \n2. The strategic acquisition \nAs buyers were busy consolidating their social media tools
column30: vendors from a variety of diverse backgrounds sought to broaden and strengthen their offerings by acquiring social capabilities. These acquisitions took several forms. First
column31: the merger of traditional media monitoring with social media monitoring continued with Cision's acquisition of Brandwatch
column32: Meltwater's purchase of Linkfluence and Access Intelligence's (Pulsar) merger with Isentia. Secondly
column33: a great many acquisitions fell under the CX umbrella. This included the customer feedback and voice of the customer vendors adding social expertise such as Qualtrics's acquisition of Clarabridge and Reputation's purchase of Nuvi. It also included customer care and engagement vendors adding social capabilities to improve their core offering such as Verint's pickup of Conversocial
column34: Hootsuite's acquisitions of Sparkcentral and Heyday
column35: and Khoros\u00e2\u0080\u0099s purchase of Topbox. We also witnessed a huge IPO
column36: with Sprinklr taking their \u00e2\u0080\u0098Unified CXM Platform\u00e2\u0080\u0099 public.\u00c2\u00a0\nAll of these moves suggest a vendor landscape beginning to coalesce around three main categories: Communications Clouds
column37: CX Clouds and Insights Clouds. Key to the success of them all has been the integration of social data into their solutions and the ability to blend it with other data sources providing a more\u00c2\u00a0comprehensive picture. Which brings me to... \n3. The death of the social silo \nSome time ago
column38: social listening vendors began to reframe themselves as 'consumer intelligence platforms
column39: ' offering clients the ability to combine social data with other digital sources such as surveys and first-party data. This seemed a natural progression as these tools could already analyze unstructured social posts
column40: so why not apply that to other unstructured data sources and provide brands with a more complete view of consumers. When Forrester released their New Wave on AI-Enabled Consumer Intelligence Platforms in July
column41: it seemed that the era of social listening as a category was coming to an end. And to hammer home the point
column42: just a few months later Zendesk announced its acquisition of Momentive (formerly SurveyMonkey) with the goal of creating a \"powerful new customer intelligence company.\" This combination of CX or behavioral data with solicited and unsolicited feedback seems to be the future of the consumer insights world and would suggest more 'Insights Clouds' are on the horizon.\n4. The growth of social intelligence as a profession and the dearth of talent \nWhile social listening as a category continues to fade
column43: social intelligence is just getting started. A LinkedIn search finds 15
column44: 000 people globally mentioning social intelligence in their profile while another 22
column45: 000 mention social media data. And
column46: this phenomenon is not exclusive to those working in agency land or for technology suppliers
column47: but within brands themselves who have been actively recruiting to bring talent in-house.\nThe challenge is in finding people with the right skills and experience to fill these vacancies. I\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve heard many times that this dearth of talent is one reason why specialist research agencies have never been busier. Jeremy Hollow
column48: Founder & MD of Listen + Learn Research
column49: a social data insights agency
column50: commented
column51: \"The market seems to be expanding and maturing
column52: with more of the routine analytical work being brought in-house while agencies are being used to bring deeper strategic insights.\u00e2\u0080\u009d \n5. The evolution of market research from question-based to observational approaches \nMarket research
column53: specifically research tech
column54: is in the midst of an investment frenzy with numerous SaaS upstarts raising funds to disrupt various parts of the research supply chain. In my view
column55: a great many are simply automating manual processes (survey creation
column56: sample access
column57: etc.) while a few are fundamentally challenging the question-based approach to primary research and how we understand consumer needs.\nThey are looking instead to the billions of online conversations on every imaginable subject to collect organic consumer opinions and predict future trends. This data science led approach is allowing insight professionals the ability to analyze huge amounts of unstructured social commentary
column58: providing qualitative insights on a quantitative scale. And it seems that this is a key priority of research buyers as well. A recent GreenBook Report found that the analysis of social media data was their number one area of focus when it came to the adoption of automation. \nOnwards to 2022 \nThese themes suggest that social intelligence has truly come into its own over the past year with numerous trends conspiring to drive awareness and adoption. Despite that
column59: many organizations still consider social data a marketing-specific resource and undervalue its business impact. Sprout Social\u00e2\u0080\u0099s recent Index survey highlighted this very point
column60: reporting that 46% of respondents saw social data strictly as a marketing resource. Clearly
column61: there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s still work to be done and people to win over
column62: however this shouldn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t take away from the 54% who saw social data in a more strategic light. And after such a challenging year
column63:
why not see the glass as half full?
Interested to learn more about how Twitter and our partners can support your social intelligence journey? Get started atÂ partners.twitter.com.

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Our Holiday Wish List for the Digital Services Act"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Our Holiday Wish List for the Digital Services Act
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8:
9 December 2021
Link copied successfully
Jointly written by;
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As we come to the end of 2021
column9: the Digital Services Act (DSA) and the European Union\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Digital Single Market (DSM) face an uncertain future. Countries are pulling at the threads of the DSM \u00e2\u0080\u0093 such as the Country of Origin Principle \u00e2\u0080\u0093 without fully appreciating the damage they might cause to Europe\u00e2\u0080\u0099s digital ecosystem. Small-to-medium size tech companies
column10: including homegrown enterprises
column11: are asking the EU to preserve the regulatory frameworks that underpin their existence.\u00c2\u00a0\nAutomattic
column12: Jodel
column13: Seznam
column14: Twitter and Vimeo are today building on their joint advocacy over the past year (letter
column15: June 2021) with a DSA Holiday Wish List. We seek to encourage fair and progressive regulation
column16: both in Europe and globally
column17:
that works for companies and countries of all sizes.Â 
Hereâs our 2022 wish list for the DSA:
A harmonised definition and enforcement framework across Member States for âillegal contentâ. This avoids excessive takedowns or conflicting rules that will build digital borders.
A strong Country of Origin principle that supports a diverse online marketplace. Without it
column18: we risk entrenching the largest players
column19: reducing consumer choice and irreparably splintering the Digital Single Market. At least ten Member States have submitted positions that align with our view \u00e2\u0080\u0093 highlighting the shared interests between smaller companies and smaller countries.\nNo general monitoring obligations or stay-down provisions. If you really mean it
column20: don't include it.\u00c2\u00a0\nA clear and harmonised notice and action mechanism in Article 14. This removes legal uncertainty
column21: duplication
column22: conflict and demonstrates a commitment to a coherent content regime for the EU.\u00c2\u00a0\nNo more removal timelines. With conflicting definitions of illegal content
column23: this approach does not do justice to the complexity and context of user expression and would incentivise a \u00e2\u0080\u009cdelete first\u00e2\u0080\u009d approach.\nRemove law enforcement back doors in Article 15a. Ensure transparent and rigorous judicial processes are firmly established with respect to content takedown and user data requests from law enforcement.\u00c2\u00a0\nGatekeepers / Very Large Online Platform (VLOP) Criteria Alignment. The criteria for defining \u00e2\u0080\u009cGatekeepers\u00e2\u0080\u009d and VLOPs should be aligned across the Digital Markets Act Article 3 and the DSA\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Article 25. These criteria should reflect the commercial reality of the sector
column24: as shown here.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nRecognise that search engines are often different to social or commercial platforms. The obligations put on search engines
column25: particularly those not in the VLOP category of services
column26: should be carefully considered and must be feasible and scalable. European search start-ups
column27: such as Seznam
column28: could easily be hurt.\u00c2\u00a0\nSigned;\n@automattic
column29: @jodelapp
column30: @seznam_cz
column31:
@Twitter and @Vimeo

column3: "title": "2021 #OnlyOnTwitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
2021 #OnlyOnTwitter
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 9 December 2021\nLink copied successfully\nLast year
column9: Dionne Warwick famously Tweeted \u00c2\u00a0\u00e2\u0080\u009cdo not bring that foolishness into 2021\u00e2\u0080\u009d and as we close out the year
column10: we can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t help but wonder if we did right by the queen of Twitter. Turns out we did\u00e2\u0080\u0094from reconnecting with people and places that we hadn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t seen in months
column11: to providing a space to champion human rights concerns in all forms and rediscovering the familiar while still adjusting to a new reality
column12: we all made sure foolishness became a thing of the past
column13: and we have endless Tweets to prove it.\nYou really had to be there
column14: but fortunately we made sure to capture the magic that lived #OnlyOnTwitter in 2021. Read on as we revisit some of the top global moments of the year.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nNote: We only feature one Tweet per account and we don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t consider Tweets that offer reward in exchange for followers or engagement.\u00c2\u00a0\nA new year means a new beginning
column15: and the top Liked Tweet of the year reflects just that as Joe Biden was inaugurated as the 46th president of the United States in January. The fourth and fifth top Liked Tweets
column16: from Barack Obama and Kamala Harris
column17: respectively
column18: took a similar tone celebrating a new era. The second place Tweet features a selfie from BTS' JungKook with a simple kissing face emoji caption. Sadly the emoji didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t make it to our list of most Tweeted emojis (more on that later). Rounding out the top three
column19: our colleagues behind @Twitter captured the collective feeling of the world with a simple three-word Tweet as literally everyone flocked to Twitter on that fateful day in October
column20: proving that less is sometimes more when Tweeting.Â Â  This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. Your browser does not support the video element. Play Play Pause Seek 0% buffered 00:00 Current time 00:00 Duration 00:00 Toggle Mute Volume The most Retweeted Tweet of 2021 takes a more serious tone and brings us back to the social movements that dominated the conversation and brought people across the globe together in support of a mutual cause. During a period in which we saw a rise in hate crimes against Asians
column21: BTS put their influence and massive following to good use
column22: sharing a powerful message in an effort to #StopAsianHate. BTS' fans also used Twitter to celebrate their Billboard Hot 100 hit \"Butter\" and their\u00c2\u00a0\u00e2\u0080\u009cDynamite\u00e2\u0080\u009d\u00c2\u00a0#GRAMMYs performance
column23: and ARMY didnât stop thereâ#BTS was also the top hashtag of 2021. This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. Your browser does not support the video element. Play Play Pause Seek 0% buffered 00:00 Current time 00:00 Duration 00:00 Toggle Mute Volume In 2021
column24: competition was bigger than ever\u00e2\u0080\u0094and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re not just talking about sports. The most Tweeted TV shows included reality TV competition favorites Big Brother Brasil and A Fazenda 13
column25: while K-drama Squid Game changed how we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll view children\u00e2\u0080\u0099s games forever
column26: taking the third spot for most discussed TV show worldwide. Escapism was another big theme from TV this year
column27: creating a movement which manifested through meme creations
column28: costume wearing
column29: and more.Â  This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. Your browser does not support the video element. Play Play Pause Seek 0% buffered 00:00 Current time 00:00 Duration 00:00 Toggle Mute Volume 2021 was also about bringing back some of the familiar and that includes movies. Can you spot the recurring theme? This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. Your browser does not support the video element. Play Play Pause Seek 0% buffered 00:00 Current time 00:00 Duration 00:00 Toggle Mute Volume Superheroes dominated the most discussed movies worldwide. As the home to Hollywood
column30: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s also no surprise #thesuicidesquad was in the top five most Tweeted hashtags in Los Angeles too.\nFor people on Twitter
column31: the support for their teams is so loud that it spans across continents. Manchester United moved up a spot from 2020 to be the most discussed sports team worldwide
column32: while the teamâs Tweet welcoming Cristiano Ronaldo home was the second most Retweeted Tweet worldwide. This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. Your browser does not support the video element. Play Play Pause Seek 0% buffered 00:00 Current time 00:00 Duration 00:00 Toggle Mute Volume This year
column33: everyone was thrilled to welcome back large-scale sporting events and the Olympics took the top honor as the most discussed sports match/event worldwide. This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. Your browser does not support the video element. Play Play Pause Seek 0% buffered 00:00 Current time 00:00 Duration 00:00 Toggle Mute Volume Around the globe
column34: we saw a strong sense of national pride and unity as people proudly supported their country\u00e2\u0080\u0099s teams. In Indonesia
column35: the most Retweeted Tweet celebrated Greysia Polii and Apriyani Rahayu becoming the first women's doubles pair from Indonesia to win gold at the Olympics.\u00c2\u00a0\nLast but not least
column36: and proving once again that this year was about connection whether that was through tears of sadness or joy
column37: the crying face and the face with tears of joy emoji took the first and second spot
column38: respectively
column39: as the most Tweeted emoji. The eyes emoji also entered the top ten for the first time

column3: "title": "Season 2 of I Wish I Knew
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/company/2021/season-2-i-wish-know"
column8: "post_text": "Company\nSeason 2 of I Wish I Knew
column9: a @TwitterResearch Podcast\nMonday
column10: 6 December 2021\nLink copied successfully\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to announce Season 2 of I Wish I Knew
column11: a @TwitterResearch podcast. \nEach episode is presented by a different pair of hosts who share their journeys into their respective fields
column12: discuss how Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Research team is elevating conversations across the company
column13: and celebrate the people and culture surrounding the work. This season
column14: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re joined by several special co-hosts from across Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Design and Product teams and a tech policy advocate in the academic community.\u00c2\u00a0\nListen and subscribe on your favorite podcast platform: Apple Podcasts
column15: Spotify
column16: Google Podcasts
column17: TuneIn
column18: and Stitcher.\nSeason 2 premieres with four brand new episodes:\nI Wish I Knew... How Twitter Designs and Researches In Public Hosted by @Mr_DannySingh
column19: Staff Experience Researcher
column20: and @mayagpatterson
column21: Sr. Staff Product Designer. \nI Wish I Knew... How to Do Fast
column22: Impactful Research Hosted by @anniemollie
column23: Manager
column24: Experience Research
column25: and @isabellaturch
column26: Sr. Product Manager. \nI Wish I Knew... How to Make the Transition From Academia Hosted by @DrJazzWalker
