column3: "title": " Expanding access beyond information operations "
column7:
"post_text": "Company
 Expanding access beyond information operations 
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Thursday
column8:
2 December 2021
Link copied successfully
Editorial note: This blog was first published on 2 December 2021 and last updated 24 August 2022 to include updates to our approach.
In October 2018
column9: we published the first comprehensive
column10: public archive of data related to state-backed information operations. Since then
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve shared 37 datasets of attributed platform manipulation campaigns originating from 17 countries
column12: spanning more than 200 million Tweets and nine terabytes of media. More than 26
column13: 000 researchers have accessed these datasets
column14: empowering an unprecedented level of empirical research into state-backed attacks on the integrity of the conversation on Twitter.\nWe strive to provide timely updates
column15: alongside comprehensive data
column16: whenever our teams identify and remove these campaigns
column17: however
column18: this year
column19: due to technical issues and significant risks to the physical safety of our employees posed by certain disclosures
column20: we have only provided one update. During this time
column21: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been working to identify a sustainable path forward
column22: without compromising on our goals of providing meaningful transparency.\nToday
column23: in addition to disclosing eight additional datasets in our archive
column24: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sharing an update on what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve learned from these efforts and how we intend to advance data-driven transparency in 2022 and beyond.\nWhat we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve learned so far\nMeaningful transparency begins with access to data. The data we publish about information operations allows researchers to understand not just that a platform manipulation campaign took place and that Twitter removed it \u00e2\u0080\u0094 but precisely which narratives that campaign aimed to advance
column25: and how widely they spread on Twitter. Access to raw content
column26: rather than limited samples and aggregate information
column27: is important.\nRaw data isn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t accessible to everyone. Many of the datasets we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve released include hundreds of thousands of Tweets and gigabytes of media. Processing this information often requires advanced tooling and capabilities. Academics
column28: independent researchers
column29: NGOs and data journalists play a key part in translating raw data into meaningful insights
column30: as well as providing critical context in understanding how bad actors operate. Partnerships with the Stanford Internet Observatory and Australia Strategic Policy Institute have helped put these datasets in analytic and narrative context
column31: along with a conference dedicated to studying this data we held in conjunction with the Carnegie Institute.\nConfident attribution isn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t always possible. Our transparency approach has focused on activity we can confidently attribute to a state actor. Emergent behaviors
column32: including the use of disinformation-for-hire vendors and increasing operational security
column33: sometimes make confident attribution impossible based solely on Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s own data. This doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t make the activity in question less important to analyze
column34: but our policies presently prevent dataset disclosure in these cases. Moreover
column35: access to this data
column36: without attribution
column37: may allow experts to piece together operations across multiple platforms and services that is not possible by just one company.\nInformation operations are just one area of public concern. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve provided an unprecedented level of transparency about state-backed information operations
column38: given their severe impact on public discourse around the world. As Camille Fran\u00c3\u00a7ois and evelyn douek have pointed out
column39: other content moderation domains of equal public concern don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t receive the same treatment.\nWhere we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re headed in 2022\nWith these lessons in mind
column40: as well as the emergent risks we see to the physical safety of our employees around the world tied to potential disclosures
column41: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re changing our approach in an effort to continue to provide expanded transparency about our content moderation actions. Here\u00e2\u0080\u0099s what you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll see in the coming months:\nIn early 2022
column42: we will launch the Twitter Moderation Research Consortium (TMRC) \u00e2\u0080\u0094 a global group of experts from across academia
column43: civil society
column44: NGOs
column45: and journalism studying platform governance issues.\nMembership in the consortium will be granted to groups or individuals with:\n- A proven track record of research on content moderation and integrity topics (or affiliation with a group that does such research
column46: such as a university
column47: research lab
column48: or newspaper).\n- Appropriate plans and systems for safeguarding the privacy and security of the data provided by the consortium.\nWe will be fully public about the standards used to determine membership in the consortium
column49: and will bias towards inclusion and access
column50:
particularly for emerging researchers and researchers from historically under-represented communities and parts of the world.
Twitter will not exercise any control or judgment over the findings or focus areas of the research produced using this data by members of the consortium.
The more than 200 researchers around the world with existing access to our unhashed information operations datasets will be invited to join the consortium through an expedited process. Other qualifying individuals and institutions are welcome to apply. We will share additional details about this process in early 2022 in advance of any disclosures to the consortium.
We will provide comprehensive data about attributed platform manipulation campaigns to members of the consortium
column51: who may independently choose to publish their findings on the basis of the data we share and their own research. Under this model
column52: we will also begin to share data about platform manipulation campaigns for which we have not been able to arrive at confident attribution to a state actor
column53: and campaigns where we are unable to provide broad access due to employee safety concerns.\nLater in 2022
column54: we will for the first time share similarly comprehensive data about other policy areas
column55: including misinformation
column56: coordinated harmful activity
column57: and safety.\u00c2\u00a0\nAs part of this change
column58: we will discontinue our fully public dataset releases
column59: prioritizing release to the consortium. Existing datasets will continue to be available for download indefinitely \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and our public data offerings
column60: including free access to our APIs (including the full archive of Tweets) remain available. \nOur efforts in this space are underpinned by our Privacy Policy which has long informed people how we may use the data they share with us. This includes sharing or disclosing information if we believe that it is reasonably necessary to protect the safety or integrity of our platform
column61: including to help prevent spam
column62: abuse
column63: or malicious actors
column64: or to explain why we have removed content or accounts from our services. As we highlighted in our position paper setting out principles for policymakers drafting new regulations
column65: we urge policymakers to build protections for this kind of data sharing into the laws that govern data privacy. \nTransparency is core to our mission. Our goal with these changes is to provide more transparency about more issues
column66: while grappling with the considerable safety
column67: security
column68:
and integrity challenges in this space. Weâll continue to learn and iterate on our approach over time and share those findings publicly along the way. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
7 June 2022
Today
column69: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re opening up the Twitter Moderation Research Consortium to a limited group of researchers. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll use this initial period to gather learnings and make adjustments to program design
column70: where needed
column71: ahead of our forthcoming public launch. Feedback from these researchers will help shape and inform our work.\u00c2\u00a0\nDuring this period
column72: membership will be open to applicants who were granted access to our information operation data sets during prior disclosures. Researchers with prior access may re-apply for the Consortium during this phase
column73: and will be evaluated in line with the below updated criteria:\nHold a primary institutional affiliation with an academic
column74: journalistic
column75: nonprofit
column76: or civil society research organization. If they are students
column77: they must be master\u00e2\u0080\u0099s or PhD level students; undergraduate students are ineligible at this time.\nHave prior experience and relevant skills for data-driven analysis. Consortium datasets are primarily shared as JSON files and require technical skills to analyze.\u00c2\u00a0\nDemonstrate a specific public interest research use case for the data provided by the Consortium. (\u00e2\u0080\u009cPublic interest research use case\u00e2\u0080\u009d means non-commercial research for journalistic
column78: academic
column79: or non-profit/civil society purposes.)\nEquipped with industry-standard plans and systems for safeguarding the privacy and security of the data provided by the Consortium. Consortium members are required to sign a data use agreement.\nLater this year
column80: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll open up the application for Consortium membership to the wider public and share key learnings from the beta period.\nAs we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve said previously
column81: transparency is core to our work here. Through this updated approach
column82: we aim to share more about what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re seeing on the Twitter service
column84: security
column85: and integrity challenges that accompany these disclosures. Down the line
column86: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll disclose data about other policy areas
column87: including misinformation
column88: coordinated harmful activity
column89:
and safety. More to come.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
24 August 2022
Weâre sharing an update on our Twitter Moderation Research Consortium (TMRC) program. In the coming days
column90: our TMRC global partners \u00e2\u0080\u0093 the Stanford Internet Observatory
column92: and Cazadores de Fake News \u00e2\u0080\u0093 will publish independent research about Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s latest information operation data sets. These 15 data sets include platform manipulation campaigns originating from the Americas
column93: Asia Pacific (APAC)
column94: Europe
column95: the Middle East and North Africa (EMEA)
column96: and Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA).\u00c2\u00a0\nAs we noted last year (above)
column97: we will now prioritize sharing information operations data with the Consortium. While we continue to share data with researchers about the networks we remove \u00e2\u0080\u0093 including Twitter's assessment of the presumptive country of origin
column98: based on the technical signals that we observe \u00e2\u0080\u0093 we will no longer provide specific attribution information. Meaning
column99: we won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t publicly disclose whether an information operation was carried out by a specific state actor
column100: or other actor.\nOur goal is to remain transparent about the activity we identify on Twitter
column101: while addressing the considerable safety
column103: and integrity challenges that come with disclosures of this kind. Information operations are also increasingly hard to attribute to specific actors \u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00c2\u00a0 this change allows us to disclose data from a broader set of coordinated campaigns. Further
column104: this change will allow researchers to piece together operations across multiple platforms and services
column105: beyond what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s possible with just one platform. \nWe continue to draw learnings from the initial early access period. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re focused on developing a global group of Consortium members
column106: and to date
column107: have accepted applications from researchers around the world. Later this year
column108: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll open the TMRC application process to a broader group of researchers.\u00c2\u00a0 \nDown the line
column109:
we intend to share data about a wider range of Safety and Integrity policy areas. 
Â

column3: "title": "Disclosing state-linked information operations we've removed"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nDisclosing state-linked information operations we've removed\nThursday
column8: 2 December 2021\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter first published a comprehensive
column9: public archive of data related to state-backed information operations three years ago. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made improvements
column10: outlined our principles
column11: and iterated on our approach over time. Since that first disclosure in October 2018
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve shared 37 datasets of attributed platform manipulation campaigns originating from 17 countries
column13: spanning more than 200 million Tweets and nine terabytes of media.\u00c2\u00a0\nToday
column14: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re disclosing an additional 3
column15: 465 accounts to our archive of state-linked information operations \u00e2\u0080\u0094 the only one of its kind in the industry. The account sets include eight distinct operations we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve attributed to six countries \u00e2\u0080\u0093 Mexico
column16: the People's Republic of China (PRC)
column17: Russia
column18: Tanzania
column19: Uganda
column20: and Venezuela
column21: respectively. Every account and piece of content associated with these operations has been permanently removed from the service.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn addition
column22: we have shared relevant data from this disclosure with three leading research partners: the Australian Strategic Policy Institute (ASPI)
column23: Cazadores de Fake News
column24: and the Stanford Internet Observatory (SIO). In most instances
column25: accounts were suspended for various violations of our platform manipulation and spam policies. See more via our Transparency Center.  Below
column26: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve outlined information about our latest disclosure. In the future
column27: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll share key insights with the public
column28: and more comprehensive data will be shared with our global consortium.  Mexico\nWe removed a network of 276 inauthentic accounts that shared primarily civic content
column29: in support of government initiatives related to public health and political parties.\nPeople\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Republic of China\nWe removed a network of accounts that amplified Chinese Communist Party narratives related to the treatment of the Uyghur population in Xinjiang. Today
column30: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re releasing a representative sample of 2
column31: 048 accounts.\nWe also removed a network of 112 accounts connected to \u00e2\u0080\u009cChangyu Culture
column32:
â a private company backed by the Xinjiang regional government.
Russia
We removed a network of 16 accounts linked to the IRA that attempted an information operation in the Central African Republic.
The operation relied on a mix of inauthentic and real accounts to introduce a pro-Russia viewpoint into Central African political discourse.
We also removed a network of 50 accounts that attacked the civilian Libyan government and actors that support it
column33: while voicing significant support for Russia\u00e2\u0080\u0099s geopolitical position in Libya and Syria.\nTanzania\nWe removed a network of 268 accounts utilized to file bad faith reports on Twitter
column34:
targeting members and supporters of FichuaTanzania and its founder.
A subset of accounts also Tweeted pro-government content primarily associated with #chaguamagufuli2020.Â 
Uganda
We removed a network of 418 accounts engaged in coordinated inauthentic activity in support of Ugandan presidential incumbent Museveni and his party
column35: National Resistance Movement (NRM).\nVenezuela\nWe removed a network of 277 Venezuelan accounts that amplified accounts
column36: hashtags
column37: and topics in support of the government and its official narratives.\nMany of the individuals behind this abuse had authorized an app
column38: \u00e2\u0080\u009cTwitter Patria
column39: \u00e2\u0080\u009d to access their accounts and timelines.\nWe suspended the \u00e2\u0080\u009cTwitter Patria\u00e2\u0080\u009d app
column40: a set of account holders leveraging and managing it
column41: and a series of similar apps.\nWe believe we have a responsibility to protect the integrity of the public conversation and to offer meaningful transparency into our findings. Disclosing these datasets remains core to that mission. We continue to assess our principles and approach to these critical disclosures
column42: and have learned a number of lessons along the way. As we look ahead
column43: learn more about our future disclosures here
column44:
and keep up with the latest at @TwitterSafety.Â  
Â

column3: "title": "Our new search prompt to help people find credible information about HIV"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Our new search prompt to help people find credible information about HIV
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 1 December 2021\nLink copied successfully\nToday we launched another global expansion of our\u00c2\u00a0#ThereIsHelp notification service with a dedicated search prompt for HIV-related information across Asia Pacific and the Americas: Brazil
column9: Hong Kong
column10: Indonesia
column11: India
column12: Japan
column13: Malaysia
column14: Philippines
column15: Singapore
column16: SP-Latam
column17: Taiwan
column18: Thailand
column19: and the United States. This notification prompt will provide valuable and authoritative resources around HIV and encourage people to reach out and get help when they need it. Building on our #ThereIsHelp notification service currently available for mental health and suicide prevention
column20: vaccination
column21: child sexual exploitation
column22: COVID-19
column23: gender-based violence
column24: and freedom of expression; this work is part of our efforts to ensure people have access to high-quality public health information and resources.\nWhen people search for keywords associated with HIV
column25: the top search result will now include a notification in local languages
column26:
encouraging them to reach out for credible information and sources of help â be it websites or hotlines of local public health authorities or nonprofit organizations. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitter will continue to work closely with public health authorities and leading NGOs that provide critical emergency care
column27: testing
column28: emotional support
column29: and counselling services to ensure that the keywords that generate the notification prompt remain relevant. Some of the search keywords include but are not limited to:\nEnglish: #AIDS
column30: #HIV
column31: #PEP
column32: #PrEP
column33: #KnowYourStatus\nBahasa Indonesia: penyakit menular seksual
column34: #LSL\nBahasa Melayu: ditularkan secara seksual

Kesihatan Seksual

column37: #HIV

column42: #VIH
column43: #PEP
column44: #PrEP
column45: #Serolog\u00c3\u00ada\nThai: #\u00e0\u00b9\u0080\u00e0\u00b8\u00ad\u00e0\u00b8\u0094\u00e0\u00b8\u00aa\u00e0\u00b9\u008c
column47:
#ä¸çææ»çæ¥
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Forty years since the first AIDS cases were reported
column48: HIV still threatens the world. But ending AIDS requires ending inequalities
column49: which necessitates transformative change. The course corrections we need to end AIDS will also protect the world against future pandemics. Therefore
column50: we are very pleased to partner with Twitter in our journey ahead. This World AIDS Day
column51: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099d encourage everyone to use #ThereIsHelp to access critical information around HIV
column52: and remind ourselves that global inequalities affect us all
column53: no matter who we are or where we are from. Together with Twitter
column54: we hope to move societies from commitment to action by widening access to authoritative information
column55: encouraging dialogue and shaping public discourse towards creating healthy and inclusive societies.\nMahesh Mahalingam\nDirector
column56: Communications and Global Advocacy
column57: UNAIDS\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to protecting the health of the public conversation on Twitter \u00e2\u0080\u0094 ensuring individuals can find credible information from authoritative sources is a key part of that mission. We also recognized that it is crucial for the public to have access to a free and #OpenInternet in combating the stigma around HIV. Therefore
column58:
we are partnering with public health authorities and local nonprofit organizations across Asia Pacific and the Americas to provide people with access to accurate information about HIV via launching a dedicated #ThereisHelp notification prompt for HIV.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
HIV stigma during COVID-19 HIV remains a major issue to public health in 2021
column59: despite significant progress having been made in recent decades. Division and disparity for human rights have long been the contributing factors to the difficulty faced by people living with HIV. The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has made it more difficult by exacerbating inequities and disruptions to services related to HIV. In 2020
column60: around 800
column61: 000 children aged 0-14 years were living with HIV with no access to HIV treatments.\nThis year\u00e2\u0080\u0099s theme of World AIDS Day is \u00e2\u0080\u009cEnd inequalities. End AIDS.\u00e2\u0080\u009d with a special focus on highlighting the growing inequalities in access to essential HIV services.\u00c2\u00a0WHO is calling on global leaders and citizens to rally to confront the inequalities that drive AIDS and to reach people who are currently not receiving essential HIV services.\nData from Twitter shows that conversations about HIV spikes around\u00c2\u00a0#WorldAIDSDay on December 1 every year. In 2020
column62: there were close to 9 million Tweets about HIV globally
column63: out of which over 1 million Tweets were generated in December 2020.\nAt Twitter
column64: we recognize our role and responsibility to help ensure that people can access and receive support on our service when they need it the most. The various communities on Twitter are a source of positive support and are thriving; encouraging each other who may be struggling with stigma or lack of information around HIV
column65:
and to reach out for professional help.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
United to help provide more access to information  We recognize that access to a free andÂ #OpenInternetÂ and collaboration â public
column66: private and community \u00e2\u0080\u0094 is the key to combating the stigma around HIV. As local organizations continue to use Twitter as a channel to identify and reach out to vulnerable people who they may otherwise not have contact with
column67:
and to raise awareness of their important services; we hope that the #ThereIsHelp notification service will complement these efforts.
Below are our trusted NGO and government partners in this initiative that have made the #ThereIsHelp HIV notification prompt possible in 30 markets and in 12 languages. We will continue to expand these prompts in other markets in the near future.
Brazil: UNAIDS Brasil (@UNAIDSBrasil)

HIV info NIH (@HIVinfo_NIH)

#WorldAIDSDay Emoji  In partnership with UNAIDS (@UNAIDS)

column75: which is the symbol for World AIDS day

2021. It will automatically appear in your Tweet when you Tweet with the following hashtags:

We understand our role in disseminating important public health information. It's important to help people find reliable information that enhances their health and wellbeing. We believe #ThereIsHelp and Twitterâs other partnerships and initiatives in this area make a valuable contribution to the ongoing and larger efforts required to address this serious issue. column3: "title": "The evolution of social intelligence: Q&A with Dr. Jillian Ney"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
The evolution of social intelligence: Q&A with Dr. Jillian Ney
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 30 November 2021\nLink copied successfully\nDr. Jillian Ney is founder of the Social Intelligence Lab
column9: a membership organization for people leading social listening programs. I recently spoke with her about the evolution of social intelligence within organizations and what the most successful ones are getting right.\nJoe: To start
column10: who\u00e2\u0080\u0099s your favorite Twitter follow? Jillian: Generally
column11: I love following Scottish Twitter
column12: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s very funny! My favourite account is Daily Overview (@DOverview) where you view the world looking down from the sky. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s beautiful.\nJoe: Tell us about the history of The SILab and where the idea came from? Jillian: All of this started off as a passion project for me. I was in Scotland doing my PhD on social media and looking to connect with others with an interest in the space.\u00c2\u00a0 This was 2018 and I found that people in the research and insights industry didn't understand it properly and treated social insights with a bit of skepticism. But I kept looking and interestingly enough
column13: I found that there was quite a community of practitioners out there
column14: but they weren't connected.\u00c2\u00a0 So
column15: the whole premise of the Social Intelligence Lab was to bring these people together to further our knowledge of this emerging source of insight. Key to this was it being driven by the practitioners themselves and not the vendors who would have their own agenda.\nJoe: We first met in the autumn of 2018 at your conference which was probably the first dedicated to this idea of social intelligence. Has it since matured and spread as much as you had hoped? Jillian: The idea that organizations need to be aware of signals from social media data is quite mainstream these days
column16: however in many cases it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not true social intelligence but rather a narrower focus on using social data to better optimize your social media marketing strategy. This is a legitimate use case of course
column17: but it misses out on the value social data brings to making better decisions across the organization. If you are not doing that
column18: and just tracking mentions
column19: then you are just doing social listening.\nJoe: What is your definition of social intelligence by the way? Jillian: Social intelligence is the analysis of digital conversations to answer questions
column20: test hypotheses or find insights that can be used to guide decision making. It has recently morphed into consumer intelligence or digital consumer intelligence
column21: which I would say is an effort by the tech companies to differentiate their products as they begin to explore a wider variety of data sources rather than being a whole new discipline. Most practitioners would typically use these data sources anyway. If you Google \u00e2\u0080\u0098social intelligence\u00e2\u0080\u0099 you'll get a lot of links to do with emotional intelligence
column22: which is quite interesting to me because I think they're very similar. A real strength of social data is the ability to understand people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s authentic emotions on a topic.\nJoe: Covid and the ensuing lockdowns were a big shock to the consumer insights industry forcing many to pivot their opinion gathering techniques. Do you think this experience has opened the industry\u00e2\u0080\u0099s eyes to the value of social insights? Jillian: I think it has
column23: but the bigger issue is the ability to get the work done successfully. I know of several brands that went out and procured new solutions to help them gather social insights but once they had them
column24: realized they couldn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t use them because they lacked the expertise to get value from these solutions. This highlights the skills gap that exists and probably also highlights why the specialist social intelligence agencies are doing so well: brands can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t do this analysis work themselves and are having to outsource it. All the specialist agencies we work with have reported dramatic increases in their work and are hiring staff to keep up.\nJoe: Can you talk more about the skills gap you mentioned? Jillian: Social listening solutions are often billed as DIY insight tools with this idea that you can give it to anybody in the organization
column25: train them up and off they go. This democratization of social data certainly sounds great in theory
column26: but we know from the more mature
column27: advanced organizations that this approach of onboarding half the company on a tool doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t work
column28: and what you need to democratize instead is the insights. And that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s because it's time consuming to cleanse and segment data and interpret the findings in a meaningful way. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s certainly not for a novice to do or someone who is only logging-in once a week to take a quick look at a dashboard.\nJoe: You\u00e2\u0080\u0099re therefore arguing for a \u00e2\u0080\u0098Centre of Excellence\u00e2\u0080\u0099 that can feed different parts of the organization with social insights tailored to their specific needs? Jillian: Yes
column29: definitely. We are seeing many enterprise organizations building out listening teams or social intelligence teams that often are part of the org\u00e2\u0080\u0099s broader insights function. Their job is to embed themselves into specific business units or departments delivering social insights to those teams and educating them on the kinds of problems or questions that social data can answer. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s one part delivery and another part education.\nJoe: What\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a best practice for getting this set up? Jillian: Many organizations\u00e2\u0080\u0099 success has started with their senior leadership promoting the importance of not just social intelligence
column30: but data driven decision making
column31: of which social data is one part. Your interview with Adam Mills highlighting British Telecom\u00e2\u0080\u0099s journey is a great example. I\u00e2\u0080\u0099d also say that a vast majority of the time
column32: when an organization is investing in social data heavily
column33: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s because social insights helped them come through some sort of crisis where it provided a real-time pulse of what was happening that they couldn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t get anywhere else. Utilizing this type of experience to your advantage is important. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also seen organizations grow internal adoption by sending daily briefings customized to specific departments and personas. This makes it more tangible
column34: and people get interested.\nJoe: You mentioned that more and more organizations are seeing the value in insights from social data. What\u00e2\u0080\u0099s keeping it from being used more consistently in market research? Jillian: I think a big part of it is in the data access models available to market researchers. Most of the social listening solutions have historically required a year-long contract which doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t always fit well with the episodic
column35: project-based world of market researchers who may only need access for a few weeks at a time. More flexible consumption models would certainly make it easier for them to access the data they need. Another challenge is that most of the solutions haven\u00e2\u0080\u0099t been built with market researchers in mind. They [market researchers] tend to want to get the data out of the solution so they can create their own code frames and segmentations and that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not particularly easy. I do see it improving however as the listening solutions see a huge growth opportunity in market research.\nJoe: On that point of technology
column36: text and image analytics have come a long way in just the past few years. Are these advances the missing link allowing new personas to unlock more insight across new use cases? Jillian: There has been technological development in the area
column37: but it is not the technology that unlocks the value. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re not in a place yet where having the technology is going to be the missing link and I\u00e2\u0080\u0099d argue that we should never sell social intelligence in this way. Businesses need to invest in skills
column38: the experts with social insight experience. It is these people who are going to unlock more insight and use cases across the organization. We need to identify the use cases and questions where social data can support the business
column39: not be led by new functionality in technology to tell us what we should be doing. If we look at image analysis
column40: there is huge potential for insights here but if you speak to a semiotician they would say the tech does not help them gain insights from the data easily. I think this is the main reason organizations are struggling to make visual listening work for them
column41: as just one example.\nJoe: Final question then...what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Twitter data\u00e2\u0080\u0099s superpower? Jillian: In wider society
column42: it's the surfacing of cultural trends
column43: meaning what big trends are becoming important. Your cultural trends report is always a good read. At a brand level
column44: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s customer experience - instead of looking at cx data at the individual level
column45: go macro and you can learn a lot.\nJoe: Many thanks for your time today
column46:
Jillian!
Â 
Interested to learn more about how Twitter and our partners can support your social intelligence journey? Get started at partners.twitter.com.

column3: "title": "Expanding our private information policy to include media"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nExpanding our private information policy to include media\nTuesday
column8: 30 November 2021\nLink copied successfully\nAs part of our ongoing efforts to build tools with privacy and security at the core
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re updating our existing private information policy and expanding its scope to include \u00e2\u0080\u009cprivate media.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Under our existing policy
column10: publishing other people's private information
column11: such as phone numbers
column12: addresses
column13: and IDs
column14: is already not allowed on Twitter. This includes threatening to expose private information or incentivizing others to do so.\u00c2\u00a0\nThere are growing concerns about the misuse of media and information that is not available elsewhere online as a tool to harass
column15: intimidate
column16: and reveal the identities of individuals. Sharing personal media
column17: such as images or videos
column18: can potentially violate a person\u00e2\u0080\u0099s privacy
column19: and may lead to emotional or physical harm. The misuse of private media can affect everyone
column20: but can have a disproportionate effect on women
column21: activists
column22: dissidents
column23: and members of minority communities. When we receive a report that a Tweet contains unauthorized private media
column24: we will now take action in line with our range of enforcement options.\nWhile our existing policies and Twitter Rules cover explicit instances of abusive behavior
column25: this update will allow us to take action on media that is shared without any explicit abusive content
column26: provided it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s posted without the consent of the person depicted. This is a part of our ongoing work to align our safety policies with human rights standards
column27: and it will be enforced globally starting today.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nWhat is in violation of this policy? Under our private information policy
column28: you can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t share the following types of private information or media
column29: without the permission of the person who it belongs to:\nhome address or physical location information
column30: including street addresses
column31: GPS coordinates or other identifying information related to locations that are considered private;\nidentity documents
column32: including government-issued IDs and social security or other national identity numbers \u00e2\u0080\u0093 note: we may make limited exceptions in regions where this information is not considered to be private;\ncontact information
column33: including non-public personal phone numbers or email addresses;\u00c2\u00a0\nfinancial account information
column34: including bank account and credit card details; and\nother private information
column35:
including biometric data or medical records.
NEW: media of private individuals without the permission of the person(s) depicted.  Â 
The following behaviors are also not permitted:Â 
threatening to publicly expose someoneâs private information;
sharing information that would enable individuals to hack or gain access to someoneâs private information without their consent
column36: e.g.
column37: sharing sign-in credentials for online banking services;\nasking for or offering a bounty or financial reward in exchange for posting someone\u00e2\u0080\u0099s private information;\nasking for a bounty or financial reward in exchange for not posting someone\u00e2\u0080\u0099s private information
column38: sometimes referred to as blackmail.\nWhen private information or media has been shared on Twitter
column39: we need a first-person report or a report from an authorized representative in order to make the determination that the image or video has been shared without their permission. Learn more about reporting on Twitter.\nSharing private media\u00c2\u00a0 When we are notified by individuals depicted
column40: or by an authorized representative
column41: that they did not consent to having their private image or video shared
column42: we will remove it. This policy is not applicable to media featuring public figures or individuals when media and accompanying Tweet text are shared in the public interest or add value to public discourse.\nHowever
column43: if the purpose of the dissemination of private images of public figures or individuals who are part of public conversations is to harass
column44: intimidate
column45: or use fear to silence them
column46: we may remove the content in line with our policy against abusive behavior.. Similarly
column47: private nude images of public individuals will continue to be actioned under our non-consensual nudity policy.\nWe recognize that there are instances where account holders may share images or videos of private individuals in an effort to help someone involved in a crisis situation
column48: such as in the aftermath of a violent event
column49: or as part of a newsworthy event due to public interest value
column50: and this might outweigh the safety risks to a person. \nWe will always try to assess the context in which the content is shared and
column51: in such cases
column52: we may allow the images or videos to remain on the service. For instance
column53: we would take into consideration whether the\u00c2\u00a0 image is publicly available and/or is being covered by mainstream/traditional media (newspapers
column54: TV channels
column55: online news sites)
column56: or if a particular image and the accompanying tweet text adds value to the public discourse
column57: is being shared in public interest
column58: or is relevant to the community.\nFeeling safe on Twitter is different for everyone
column59: and our teams are constantly working to understand and address these needs. We know our work will never be done
column60:
and we will continue to invest in making our product and policies more robust and transparent to continue to earn the trust of the people using our service.

column12: 22 November 2021\nLink copied successfully\nEditor\u00e2\u0080\u0099s note: As of March 2022
column13: the Shop Module is now referred to as the Shop Spotlight. Last updated: March 28
column14: 2022.\nLive video has been transforming the way we shop for years. Earlier this year we announced our plans to better support shopping on Twitter
column15:
and today weâre excited to announce the next step in that journey: Live Shopping.
Live Shopping on Twitter
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
While watching a Live Shopping stream on Twitter
column16: people can take several actions that make the shopping experience on Twitter seamless
column17: such as:\nCheck out the Shoppable Banner and Shop Tab on the Live event\u00e2\u0080\u0099s page.\nToggle back and forth between the Latest Tab and the Shop Tab throughout the livestream
column18: allowing them to be a part of the conversation as they check out products.\u00c2\u00a0\nContinue to watch the livestream on the merchant\u00e2\u0080\u0099s website within an in-app browser
column19:
so they donât miss a thing while making a purchase.Â  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We are conducting our first test of Live Shopping in collaboration with Walmart
column20: where they will be kicking off Cyber Week with singer
column21: songwriter
column22: dancer and social media superstar Jason Derulo for the first-ever shoppable livestream on Twitter. Starting at 7pm ET on Sunday
column23: November 28
column24: people can watch and shop from @Walmart (on iOS and desktop)
column25: where Jason will host a 30-minute variety show highlighting electronics
column26: home goods
column27: apparel
column28: seasonal d\u00c3\u00a9cor
column29:
surprise special guests and much more.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
âTwitter continues to be an important platform for Walmartâs business and our customers. Weâve been focused on charting new territory in shoppable livestreams and are excited to celebrate an important milestone together with the first Livestream Shopping event on Twitter. Weâre meeting customers where they are and making it easier to shop incredible deals and find inspiration through dynamic
column30:
interactive experiences. We look forward to continuing to bring engaging experiences to our customers that allow them to shop seamlessly while also being entertained.â
William White
Chief Marketing Officer at Walmart
People naturally come to Twitter during major cultural events. Livestreaming on Twitter gives businesses the power to engage with their most influential fans
column31:
and adding the ability to shop into this experience is a natural extension to attracting and engaging with receptive audiences. 
Whatâs Next for Twitter Shopping?
Expanding our Shop Spotlight Test
Earlier this year
column32: we began testing the\u00c2\u00a0Shop Spotlight\u00c2\u00a0with select brands
column33: and we are pleased to share that we will be launching it to more merchants in the United States in the coming weeks.\nIntroducing Twitter Shopping Manager\nIt is crucial to build foundational products to support our global community of merchants on Twitter
column34: so we will also start testing a new way to house merchant onboarding and product catalog management tools via the Twitter Shopping Manager. This will give merchants a one-stop-shop for managing how they show up on Twitter.\nWe know there is so much more for us to explore
column35: test
column36:
and iterate upon - and weâre looking forward to rolling out more products that will make shopping on Twitter easier than ever. Stay tuned for more.Â Â

column3: "title": "Our work to protect the integrity of the conversation in Ethiopia"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nOur work to protect the integrity of the conversation in Ethiopia\nWednesday
column8: 17 November 2021\nLink copied successfully\nWe continue to monitor the ongoing conflict and humanitarian crisis in Ethiopia closely
column9: and our focus remains to protect the safety and integrity of the conversation on Twitter. This is an exceptionally volatile time
column10: where certain types of content online can have a very real impact offline. Today
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099d like to share more on our response to date.  In times of crisis
column12: there are a number of tools we deploy to ensure harmful content is not amplified and to limit the visibility of such content across Twitter.  In Ethiopia
column13: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re focused on proactively reviewing Tweets for violative content
column14: along with ongoing enforcement of our policies against dehumanizing speech and content that promotes violence and discrimination. Though we aim to enforce our rules as equitably and even-handedly as possible
column15: our first priority is the safety of the people on Twitter and those on the ground.  We operate in favor of action. We look at specific indicators of offline harm to guide our product interventions
column16: and
column17: in a crisis situation
column18: are willing to risk potential false positives and reverse our decisions
column19: if appealed.  Specifically
column20:
weâve:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
PausedÂ TrendsÂ in Ethiopia
column21: given the potential for harm and attempts to manipulate trending topics.\nPaused\u00c2\u00a0List\u00c2\u00a0discovery
column22:
to limit the targeting and harassment of individuals.
Launched a search prompt with relevant keywords that points to aÂ Twitter MomentÂ with digital safety and security resources.
Halted advertisements in the region.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We also continue to:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Monitor the service for signs ofÂ platform manipulation and spamÂ based on behavior and building new detections and mitigations for âcopypastaâ and other types of platform manipulation that weâve observed in the context of the crisis.
Deamplify harmful content
column23:
including claims that create risk of harm to humanitarian workers on the ground.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Our action is informed by conversations with a wide range of trusted partners including local and international civil society organizations and experts to ensure diverse perspectives and understand what theyâre seeing.  We believe Twitter is a place for different voices and perspectives to be heard. Our rules are enforced objectively on content and accounts â we remain neutral to political identity and ideology. And
column24: when possible
column25: we strive to ensure our actions are proportionate to the propensity for harm.  We are constantly updating our approach and reviewing remediations holistically before deciding on a course of action
column26:
while doing everything we can to reduce harm.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet

column3: "title": "Our continued work to protect your privacy and security"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Our continued work to protect your privacy and security
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 10 November 2021\nLink copied successfully\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to keeping you informed on our work to protect your privacy and the data you share with Twitter. Today we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sharing an update on recent improvements to our internal processes
column9: teams
column10:
and infrastructure so you understand the continued investment weâre making in protecting the security and privacy of the people who use our service around the world.Â Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Launching a new Data Governance Committee
To strengthen the implementation of our privacy and security policies and standards
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re establishing an internal Data Governance Committee (DGC). This committee will ensure we are making consistent and balanced decisions around how we use and protect your data. The Committee will oversee all decisions to collect
column12: maintain
column13: use
column14: disclose
column15: or provide access to customer data internally. They will also review and approve updates to our Privacy Policy
column16: ensure that teams are adhering to those policies
column17:
and make the decisions on what is and is not acceptable use of your data.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Infusing security and privacy into everything we buildÂ 
Keeping your data secure and respecting your privacy will always be ongoing work for us. In collaboration with teams across Twitter and external partners
column18:
some of our most recent efforts include:
Expanding the privacy and security reviews conducted before a product or service can be launched to include a mandatory assessment of our Software Development lifecycle;
Revamping our proactive internal audits of systems and services to ensure that they happen more frequently;Â 
Expanding our privacy and security teams; and
Providing annual reports from our CISO and CPO to our full Board of Directors to drive awareness
column19: alignment and accountability on privacy and security.\nThis work builds on our efforts to improve the security of our internal tools and systems which includes strengthening our access management processes and authentication systems for support tools
column20: improving our detection and monitoring capabilities
column21: and investing in additional penetration testing and scenario planning to help secure Twitter from a range of possible threats. It also goes hand in hand with our ongoing work to tackle technical debt and build security and privacy into everything we launch. \nWe believe that
column22: ultimately
column23:
this work and these changes will keep the data you trust us with secure and private.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Whatâs next
Twitterâs commitment to strengthening our privacy and security practices continues to expand and is a top priority for the company. While much of the work weâre doing in this space is not visible on Twitter
column24: we will continue to communicate about these efforts.\u00c2\u00a0\nWith transparency and accountability as the backbone of this work
column25:
weâll share lessons learned and update you on the latest work to protect your privacy and security on Twitter. 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet

data

security

column3: "title": "Twitter smarter
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/product/2021/twitter-smarter--twitter-harder-with-twitter-blue"
column8: "post_text": "Product\nTwitter smarter
column9:
Twitter harder with Twitter Blue
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Tuesday
column10: 9 November 2021\nLink copied successfully\nWe are excited to share that Twitter Blue is now available in the United States and New Zealand across iOS
column11: Android and web. Twitter Blue is available for a monthly price of US $2.99 / NZ$ 4.49 and with it
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re bringing subscribers even more features
column13: more content
column14: and more ways to participate in the conversation.\nEarlier this year
column15: we introduced Twitter Blue in Australia and Canada. Since then
column16: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been listening to and learning from the most passionate and vocal people on Twitter as to what will make their experience more customizable
column17: more frictionless
column18: and simply put - better.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re invigorated by the feedback we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve received so far. The work continues and there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a lot more to build
column19:
but in the meantime hereâs the latest look inside Twitter Blue.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Read news without the noise: Ad-free articles (formerly known as Scroll)
On iOS and desktop
column20: Twitter Blue members will enjoy a fast-loading
column21: ad-free reading experience when they visit many of their favorite news sites available in the US from Twitter
column22: such as The Washington Post
column23: L.A. Times
column24: USA TODAY
column25: The Atlantic
column26: Reuters
column27: The Daily Beast
column28: Rolling Stone
column29: BuzzFeed
column30: Insider and The Hollywood Reporter.\nThis is just the beginning for Ad-free Articles with much more ad-free content to come as we continue to build more partnerships
column31: with more publishers
column32: in more markets.\nSupport a thriving free press.\nIn continuing our commitment to strengthen and support publishers and a free press
column33:
a portion of the revenue from Twitter Blue subscription fees goes directly to publishers within our network. Our goal is to help each publishing partner make 50% more per person than they wouldâve made from serving ads to that person. A better experience for readers - and more support for the journalism they care about.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Donât miss a beat with Top Articles1
Designed with Nuzzel lovers in mind
column34: subscribers can easily view the most-shared articles in their network over the last 24 hours
column35:
so they can immediately see whatâs important in their community. This gives subscribers a new and complementary way of catching up on the latest on Twitter.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Customize your TwitterÂ Â 
Subscribers can add more flair to their Twitter experience with exclusive app icons and colorful themes2 and Bookmark Folders. We are also introducing Custom Navigation3
column36:
which gives subscribers the ability to customize what appears in their navigation bar for quick access to the Twitter destinations they care about most.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet smarter
column37: read better\u00c2\u00a0\nWith Undo Tweet
column38: subscribers can preview and perfect Tweets before they are sent. Subscribers also have access to Reader
column39:
which turns long threads into an easier-to-read experience. They can also change the text size within Reader to tailor their experience even further.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitter Blue Labs: Get early access to new features
Finally
column40: subscribers get early access to features we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re testing \u00e2\u0080\u0094 before anyone else! These features might eventually become available to the rest of Twitter
column41: graduate to a feature of Twitter Blue
column42: or sunset based on feedback we hear from subscribers.\nThey will change often
column43: but for now
column44:
subscribers will be able to upload videos of up to 10-minutes (as opposed to the standard ~2 minutes for non-subscribers) via Longer Video Uploads4 and pin their favorite conversations to the top of their DMâs with Pinned Conversations.5
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Adapting as we go - with your feedback in mind
From our initial launch
column45: we learned that existing subscribers loved many of the features we brought to market
column46: including the ability to customize and tailor their experience on Twitter to meet their needs and personalities
column47: and of course
column48: to review their Tweets before they go out in the wild. We also learned they want even more customization
column49: exclusive first-looks
column50: and the ability to make their Twitter experience more functional. And we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re building towards exactly that.\nWith Twitter Blue
column51: we are not only bringing the most active people on Twitter more of what they want
column52: but we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also supporting local
column53: national
column54: and ad-free journalism in a more direct way. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s early days for Twitter Blue and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re looking forward to listening
column55: learning
column56: and building out even more features and tools over the coming months. As we look ahead
column57: you can anticipate more features in Labs
column58: more customization opportunities on different types of surfaces
column59: and perhaps a few surprises along the way!\nSubscribe now
column60: Tweet feedback anytime\nFor those of you in the US
column61: Canada
column62: Australia
column63: and New Zealand - visit Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s main menu via your app or desktop to subscribe and unlock Twitter Blue. And be sure to follow @TwitterBlue to stay up to date on our latest features and announcements.\u00c2\u00a0As always
column64:
Tweet us your feedback - weâre listening.

column3: "title": "#COP26 is happening on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
#COP26 is happening on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 1 November 2021\nLink copied successfully\nThe climate conversation happening on Twitter continues to accelerate
column9: generating more than 40 million Tweets in 2021 alone. As global leaders convene in Glasgow for #COP26
column10: people around the world are using Twitter to get the latest
column11: connect with the environmental community
column12:
and galvanize around pressing climate challenges.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
#COP26 event page
Weâre committed to elevating the latest
column13: most authoritative information about #COP26. Starting this week
column14: people on Twitter can tap into our global #COP26 event page
column15: featuring resources and commentary from key organizations and environmental experts and the latest #COP26 news. The event page will be localized
column16: available to anyone on Twitter in English
column17: Spanish
column18: Arabic
column19: Portuguese
column20: and Japanese.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nPre-bunks\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re rolling out pre-bunks \u00e2\u0080\u0094 hubs of credible
column21: authoritative information
column22: available in the Explore tab
column23: Search
column24: and Trends. These pre-bunks will surface reliable
column25: factual context across a range of key themes
column26: like the science backing climate change and global warming realities.\n#COP26 hashtags and emoji\nPeople around the world can use #COP26 hashtags and the official #COP26 Twitter emoji to join the conversation
column27: engage with conference participants
column28: and more. To access the exclusive emoji
column29: Tweet #COP26
column30: #RaceToZero #RaceToResilience
column31: or #TogetherForOurPlanet.\u00c2\u00a0\nTwitter Spaces\nOrganizations like UNFCCC
column32: an official #COP26 partner
column33: are hosting real-time
column34: global conversations on Twitter. Check out featured Spaces at @Policy and on the official #COP26 event page
column35: set reminders
column36: and join in.\nClimate change topic\nWe know that people use the service to find credible information during events like #COP26
column37: as well as during environmental crises. This year
column38: we rolled out a climate change Topic to make it easy to find personalized conversations about climate change
column39: including Tweets from environmental and sustainability organizations
column40: environmental activists
column41: and scientists. These Tweets will appear in your Home timeline when you follow the Topic.\nLists\nKeep up with climate change experts and environmental journalists via localized lists
column42:
available on the #COP26 Event page.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitterâs Climate CommitmentsÂ 
Tackling the climate crisis requires ongoing
column43: meaningful action
column44: and at Twitter
column45: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re stepping up our own commitments and doing this work out in the open.\nEarlier this year
column46: we committed to significantly reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 2030
column47: in partnership with the Science Based Target Initiative (SBTi). This ambitious reduction goal
column48: in alignment with the Paris Climate Agreement
column49: is a key component of our net-zero journey.\u00c2\u00a0 We continue to collaborate with environmental leaders
column50: the scientific community
column51: and industry partners
column52: such as through work with the global We Mean Business coalition and the United Nations\u00e2\u0080\u0099 Race to Zero campaign.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe know there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s more to do. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve escalated our efforts to achieve 100% carbon-neutral power sourcing in our current data centers by the end of 2022. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve partnered with Cool Effect
column53: a nonprofit organization that helps offset emissions from our data centers and employee travel
column54: to fund green projects around the world. So far
column55: 95% of our global office spaces are \u00e2\u0080\u009cGreen Building Certified\u00e2\u0080\u009d\u00c2\u00a0 with more to come. And
column56: we remain committed to supporting organizations leading the charge
column57: including through Ads for Good grants.\n#COP26 on Twitter \nTwitter is where #COP26 is happening. Stay connected for the latest #COP26 news
column58: tune into Twitter Spaces for real-time conversation
column59:
and join in by Tweeting with the #COP26 official hashtags or by tapping the hashtags on your feed.
Â

column3: "title": " Expanding access beyond information operations "
column7:
"post_text": "Company
 Expanding access beyond information operations 
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Thursday
column8:
2 December 2021
Link copied successfully
Editorial note: This blog was first published on 2 December 2021 and last updated 24 August 2022 to include updates to our approach.
In October 2018
column9: we published the first comprehensive
column10: public archive of data related to state-backed information operations. Since then
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve shared 37 datasets of attributed platform manipulation campaigns originating from 17 countries
column12: spanning more than 200 million Tweets and nine terabytes of media. More than 26
column13: 000 researchers have accessed these datasets
column14: empowering an unprecedented level of empirical research into state-backed attacks on the integrity of the conversation on Twitter.\nWe strive to provide timely updates
column15: alongside comprehensive data
column16: whenever our teams identify and remove these campaigns
column17: however
column18: this year
column19: due to technical issues and significant risks to the physical safety of our employees posed by certain disclosures
column20: we have only provided one update. During this time
column21: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been working to identify a sustainable path forward
column22: without compromising on our goals of providing meaningful transparency.\nToday
column23: in addition to disclosing eight additional datasets in our archive
column24: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sharing an update on what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve learned from these efforts and how we intend to advance data-driven transparency in 2022 and beyond.\nWhat we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve learned so far\nMeaningful transparency begins with access to data. The data we publish about information operations allows researchers to understand not just that a platform manipulation campaign took place and that Twitter removed it \u00e2\u0080\u0094 but precisely which narratives that campaign aimed to advance
column25: and how widely they spread on Twitter. Access to raw content
column26: rather than limited samples and aggregate information
column27: is important.\nRaw data isn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t accessible to everyone. Many of the datasets we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve released include hundreds of thousands of Tweets and gigabytes of media. Processing this information often requires advanced tooling and capabilities. Academics
column28: independent researchers
column29: NGOs and data journalists play a key part in translating raw data into meaningful insights
column30: as well as providing critical context in understanding how bad actors operate. Partnerships with the Stanford Internet Observatory and Australia Strategic Policy Institute have helped put these datasets in analytic and narrative context
column31: along with a conference dedicated to studying this data we held in conjunction with the Carnegie Institute.\nConfident attribution isn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t always possible. Our transparency approach has focused on activity we can confidently attribute to a state actor. Emergent behaviors
column32: including the use of disinformation-for-hire vendors and increasing operational security
column33: sometimes make confident attribution impossible based solely on Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s own data. This doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t make the activity in question less important to analyze
column34: but our policies presently prevent dataset disclosure in these cases. Moreover
column35: access to this data
column36: without attribution
column37: may allow experts to piece together operations across multiple platforms and services that is not possible by just one company.\nInformation operations are just one area of public concern. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve provided an unprecedented level of transparency about state-backed information operations
column38: given their severe impact on public discourse around the world. As Camille Fran\u00c3\u00a7ois and evelyn douek have pointed out
column39: other content moderation domains of equal public concern don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t receive the same treatment.\nWhere we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re headed in 2022\nWith these lessons in mind
column40: as well as the emergent risks we see to the physical safety of our employees around the world tied to potential disclosures
column41: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re changing our approach in an effort to continue to provide expanded transparency about our content moderation actions. Here\u00e2\u0080\u0099s what you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll see in the coming months:\nIn early 2022
column42: we will launch the Twitter Moderation Research Consortium (TMRC) \u00e2\u0080\u0094 a global group of experts from across academia
column43: civil society
column44: NGOs
column45: and journalism studying platform governance issues.\nMembership in the consortium will be granted to groups or individuals with:\n- A proven track record of research on content moderation and integrity topics (or affiliation with a group that does such research
column46: such as a university
column47: research lab
column48: or newspaper).\n- Appropriate plans and systems for safeguarding the privacy and security of the data provided by the consortium.\nWe will be fully public about the standards used to determine membership in the consortium
column49: and will bias towards inclusion and access
column50:
particularly for emerging researchers and researchers from historically under-represented communities and parts of the world.
Twitter will not exercise any control or judgment over the findings or focus areas of the research produced using this data by members of the consortium.
The more than 200 researchers around the world with existing access to our unhashed information operations datasets will be invited to join the consortium through an expedited process. Other qualifying individuals and institutions are welcome to apply. We will share additional details about this process in early 2022 in advance of any disclosures to the consortium.
We will provide comprehensive data about attributed platform manipulation campaigns to members of the consortium
column51: who may independently choose to publish their findings on the basis of the data we share and their own research. Under this model
column52: we will also begin to share data about platform manipulation campaigns for which we have not been able to arrive at confident attribution to a state actor
column53: and campaigns where we are unable to provide broad access due to employee safety concerns.\nLater in 2022
column54: we will for the first time share similarly comprehensive data about other policy areas
column55: including misinformation
column56: coordinated harmful activity
column57: and safety.\u00c2\u00a0\nAs part of this change
column58: we will discontinue our fully public dataset releases
column59: prioritizing release to the consortium. Existing datasets will continue to be available for download indefinitely \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and our public data offerings
column60: including free access to our APIs (including the full archive of Tweets) remain available. \nOur efforts in this space are underpinned by our Privacy Policy which has long informed people how we may use the data they share with us. This includes sharing or disclosing information if we believe that it is reasonably necessary to protect the safety or integrity of our platform
column61: including to help prevent spam
column62: abuse
column63: or malicious actors
column64: or to explain why we have removed content or accounts from our services. As we highlighted in our position paper setting out principles for policymakers drafting new regulations
column65: we urge policymakers to build protections for this kind of data sharing into the laws that govern data privacy. \nTransparency is core to our mission. Our goal with these changes is to provide more transparency about more issues
column66: while grappling with the considerable safety
column67: security
column68:
and integrity challenges in this space. Weâll continue to learn and iterate on our approach over time and share those findings publicly along the way. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
7 June 2022
Today
column69: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re opening up the Twitter Moderation Research Consortium to a limited group of researchers. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll use this initial period to gather learnings and make adjustments to program design
column70: where needed
column71: ahead of our forthcoming public launch. Feedback from these researchers will help shape and inform our work.\u00c2\u00a0\nDuring this period
column72: membership will be open to applicants who were granted access to our information operation data sets during prior disclosures. Researchers with prior access may re-apply for the Consortium during this phase
column73: and will be evaluated in line with the below updated criteria:\nHold a primary institutional affiliation with an academic
column74: journalistic
column75: nonprofit
column76: or civil society research organization. If they are students
column77: they must be master\u00e2\u0080\u0099s or PhD level students; undergraduate students are ineligible at this time.\nHave prior experience and relevant skills for data-driven analysis. Consortium datasets are primarily shared as JSON files and require technical skills to analyze.\u00c2\u00a0\nDemonstrate a specific public interest research use case for the data provided by the Consortium. (\u00e2\u0080\u009cPublic interest research use case\u00e2\u0080\u009d means non-commercial research for journalistic
column78: academic
column79: or non-profit/civil society purposes.)\nEquipped with industry-standard plans and systems for safeguarding the privacy and security of the data provided by the Consortium. Consortium members are required to sign a data use agreement.\nLater this year
column80: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll open up the application for Consortium membership to the wider public and share key learnings from the beta period.\nAs we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve said previously
column81: transparency is core to our work here. Through this updated approach
column82: we aim to share more about what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re seeing on the Twitter service
column84: security
column85: and integrity challenges that accompany these disclosures. Down the line
column86: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll disclose data about other policy areas
column87: including misinformation
column88: coordinated harmful activity
column89:
and safety. More to come.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
24 August 2022
Weâre sharing an update on our Twitter Moderation Research Consortium (TMRC) program. In the coming days
column90: our TMRC global partners \u00e2\u0080\u0093 the Stanford Internet Observatory
column92: and Cazadores de Fake News \u00e2\u0080\u0093 will publish independent research about Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s latest information operation data sets. These 15 data sets include platform manipulation campaigns originating from the Americas
column93: Asia Pacific (APAC)
column94: Europe
column95: the Middle East and North Africa (EMEA)
column96: and Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA).\u00c2\u00a0\nAs we noted last year (above)
column97: we will now prioritize sharing information operations data with the Consortium. While we continue to share data with researchers about the networks we remove \u00e2\u0080\u0093 including Twitter's assessment of the presumptive country of origin
column98: based on the technical signals that we observe \u00e2\u0080\u0093 we will no longer provide specific attribution information. Meaning
column99: we won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t publicly disclose whether an information operation was carried out by a specific state actor
column100: or other actor.\nOur goal is to remain transparent about the activity we identify on Twitter
column101: while addressing the considerable safety
column103: and integrity challenges that come with disclosures of this kind. Information operations are also increasingly hard to attribute to specific actors \u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00c2\u00a0 this change allows us to disclose data from a broader set of coordinated campaigns. Further
column104: this change will allow researchers to piece together operations across multiple platforms and services
column105: beyond what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s possible with just one platform. \nWe continue to draw learnings from the initial early access period. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re focused on developing a global group of Consortium members
column106: and to date
column107: have accepted applications from researchers around the world. Later this year
column108: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll open the TMRC application process to a broader group of researchers.\u00c2\u00a0 \nDown the line
column109:
we intend to share data about a wider range of Safety and Integrity policy areas. 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
