column3: "title": "An update to the Twitter Transparency Center"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
An update to the Twitter Transparency Center
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 14 July 2021\nLink copied successfully\nTransparency drives the work we do at Twitter and underpins our efforts to promote and protect the Open Internet around the world. Over the past year
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve experienced and continue to navigate severe global challenges
column10:
including the coronavirus pandemic. Weâve also seen concerted attempts by governments to limit access to the Internet generally and to Twitter specifically. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Since 2012
column11: the Twitter Transparency Report has offered a window into our work to enforce the Twitter Rules
column12: protect privacy
column13: navigate increased requests from governments around the world
column14: disrupt state-backed information operations
column15: and more. Now
column16: amid an increasingly complex global landscape
column17: continued transparency around our own efforts to protect the public conversation is paramount.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur latest Twitter Transparency Center update includes data from July 1 to December 31
column18: 2020. While we continue to share data across consistent
column19: recurring categories
column20: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re introducing new data that can provide meaningful insights into the impact of our actions. Our new impressions metric captures the number of views violative Tweets received prior to removal. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also including more information about the adoption of two-factor authentication
column21: part of our work to keep accounts safe and secure. \nAs we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve noted previously
column22: Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s operations were severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic during the latter half of 2020
column23: as was the case with the prior reporting period. Varying country-specific COVID-19 restrictions and adjustments within our teams affected the efficiency of our content moderation work and the speed with which we enforced our policies. We increased our use of machine learning and automation to take a wide range of actions on potentially misleading and manipulative content. Like many organizations \u00e2\u0080\u0093 both public and private around the world \u00e2\u0080\u0093 the disruptions caused by COVID-19 made an impact on our company and are reflected in some of the data shared today.\u00c2\u00a0 \nImpressions\u00c2\u00a0 \nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to enabling safe and healthy conversations on the service
column24: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re always looking for ways to share more context about our enforcement of the Twitter Rules. Our impressions metric captures the number of views a violative Tweet received prior to removal.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn total
column25: impressions on violative Tweets accounted for less than 0.1% of all impressions for all Tweets globally
column26: from July 1 through December 31. During this time period
column27: Twitter removed 3.8 million Tweets that violated the Twitter Rules; 77% of which received fewer than 100 impressions prior to removal
column28: with an additional 17% receiving between 100 and 1
column29: 000 impressions. Only 6% of removed Tweets had more than 1
column30: 000 impressions.\u00c2\u00a0\nMore broadly
column31: as we work to remove harmful
column32: violative content quickly and at scale
column33: whether amid a global health crisis or during a high stakes election
column34: these numbers represent both our present efficiency and where improvement is needed. Our goal is to improve these numbers over time
column35: taking enforcement action on violative content before it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s even viewed.\nCOVID-19\nAs the COVID-19 pandemic evolves around the world
column36: we continue to take enforcement action on misleading information about COVID-19
column37: particularly that which puts people at risk and could lead to harm.\u00c2\u00a0\nFrom July to December 2020
column38: we challenged 10
column40: 924 accounts. The account challenge number represents a large volume of proactive anti-spam challenges we issued
column41: targeting platform manipulation focused on COVID-19 discussions. We rolled out a set of proactive challenges specifically focused on COVID-19. We suspended 597 accounts
column42: and removed 3
column43: 846 pieces of content. Since introducing our COVID-19 guidance last year
column44: to the time of this publication
column45: we have challenged 11.7 million accounts
column46: suspended 1
column47: 496 accounts
column48: and removed over 43
column49:
010 pieces of content worldwide.
You can learn more about our COVID-19 misinformation policy here.
Global legal requests
Information Requests
Protecting the privacy of people who use Twitter is important to us.Â  We produced some or all of the requested information in response to 30% of these information requests; 4
column50: 367 total.\nIndia is the single largest source of government information requests
column51: accounting for 25% of the global volume and 15% of the global accounts specified.\u00c2\u00a0\nThe second highest volume of information requests originated from the United States
column52: comprising 22% of global information requests.\nThe United States submitted the highest volume of global emergency requests (34%)
column53: followed by Japan (17%)
column54: and South Korea (16%).\nRemoval Requests \u00c2\u00a0(legal demands for content removal)\nDuring this reporting period
column55: Twitter received 38
column56: 524 legal demands to remove content specifying 131
column57: 933 accounts. We withheld or otherwise removed some or all of the reported content in response to 29% of these global legal demands; 11
column58: 091 total.\nAlthough there was a 9% decrease in the number of legal demands Twitter received
column59: compared to the previous reporting period
column60: these requests sought removal of content from the largest number of accounts ever in a single reporting period.\u00c2\u00a0\nAccounts of 199 verified journalists and news outlets from around the world were subject to 361 legal demands
column61: a 26% increase in these requests since the previous reporting period.\u00c2\u00a0\nAnd
column62: 94% of the total global volume of legal demands originated from only five countries (in decreasing order): Japan
column63: India
column64: Russia
column65: Turkey
column66: and South Korea.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur reporting processes are designed to be transparent and to enable real accountability. Where possible
column67: we provide user notice when we receive these requests. Importantly
column68: unless we are prohibited from doing so
column69: when we remove or withhold content in a certain country
column70: Twitter will provide a copy of the request to the publicly available Lumen Database. When content is withheld
column71:
it is only withheld in the country making the removal demand and remains visible in all other jurisdictions.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitter Rules enforcement
We continue to step up the level of proactive enforcement across the service and invest in technological solutions to respond to ever-evolving malicious online activity. Today
column72: by using technology
column73: 65% of the abusive content we action is surfaced proactively for human review
column74: instead of relying on reports from people using Twitter.\nAbuse and harassment\nWe launched a number of initiatives
column75: like more precise machine learning
column76: to better detect and take action on content that violated this policy. As a result
column77: there was a 142% increase in accounts actioned*
column78: compared to the previous reporting period; 964
column79: 459 in total.\u00c2\u00a0\nChild sexual exploitation\nWe do not tolerate child sexual exploitation (CSE) on Twitter. In the majority of cases
column80: the consequence for violating our CSE policy is immediate and permanent suspension
column81: and violators are prohibited from creating any new accounts in the future. Violative content is removed and reported to the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children (NCMEC).\nThere was a 6% increase in the number of accounts suspended for violations of our child sexual exploitation policy during this reporting period. In total
column84: 90% of which were proactively identified by employing internal proprietary tools and industry hash sharing initiatives.\nNon-consensual nudity\nWe took enforcement action on 27
column86: an increase of 194% from the prior reporting period. From July to December 2020
column87:
weÂ  saw the largest increase in the number of accounts actioned under this policy.
*"Accounts actioned" reflects the number of unique accounts that were suspended or required content removal for violating the Twitter Rules.
Terrorism and violent extremism
There was a 35% decrease in the number of accounts permanently suspended for violations of our terrorism and violent extremism policies â 96% of those accounts were proactively identified using a combination of machine learning and human review. Action was taken on 58
column88:
750 unique accounts under this policy during this reporting period.
We continue to utilize and contribute to the shared industry hash database supported by the Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism (GIFCT).
Civic integrity
Civic integrity policy enforcements increased significantly
column90: compared to the previous reporting period
column91: largely driven by Tweets related to the United States 2020 election.\nDuring the United States 2020 election
column92: we enacted a set of policy
column93: enforcement and product changes to add context
column94: encourage thoughtful consideration
column95: and reduce the potential for misleading information to spread on Twitter. From October 27 to November 11
column96: for example
column97: we labeled approximately 300
column98: 000 Tweets that contained claims that were disputed and potentially misleading.\u00c2\u00a0\nHateful conduct\nThere was a 77% increase in the number of accounts actioned for violations of our hateful conduct policy during this reporting period \u00e2\u0080\u0093 from 635
column99: 415 accounts
column100: to 1
column103: we began enforcing our hateful conduct policy against content that incites fear and/or fearful stereotypes about protected categories
column104: as we were seeing increased harassment of some protected categories during the COVID-19 pandemic. In December 2020
column105: we further expanded our hateful conduct policy to include content that dehumanizes on the basis of race
column106: ethnicity
column107: or national origin.\u00c2\u00a0\nPromoting suicide & self-harm\nFrom July to December 2020
column108: we actioned 188
column109: 561 accounts compared to 64
column111: accounting for a 192% increase in enforcement.\nSuicide and self-harm are significant social and public health challenges
column112: and we recognize that we have a responsibility to help people access support when they need it. We continue to offer resources to support those experiencing thoughts of self-harm or suicide
column113: like our #ThereIsHelp search prompt. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve introduced new initiatives to better detect and take action on content that violates our policy on suicide and self-harm.\nPlatform manipulation\nAnti-spam challenges increased by approximately 6% compared to the previous reporting period. In addition
column114: we observed an approximate 14% decrease in the number of spam reports from the previous reporting period.\nCopyright\nSubmissions of Digital Millennium Copyright Act takedown notices decreased by 2%
column115: and we saw a 44% decrease in accounts affected. Tweets withheld and media withheld also dropped by 25% and 43% respectively
column116: as Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s operations were affected due to the COVID-19 pandemic and a security incident in July 2020.\nAccount security\u00c2\u00a0\nWe continue to encourage two-factor authentication (2FA) for all accounts
column117: and a number of other best practices to help keep accounts safe and secure. Over time
column118:
we hope to see more people on Twitter adopt enhanced security measures for their accounts.
Approximately 2.3% of accounts have enabled at least one 2FA method during the reporting period.
Conclusion
Weâre committed to increasing our transparency and improving our accountability to you
column120:
and weâll continue to publish updates to the Twitter Transparency Center on a biannual basis.
Follow @Policy and @TwitterSafety for updates on our policies and our work on transparency throughout the year.Â 
Â

column3: "title": "Stronger security for your Twitter account"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Stronger security for your Twitter account
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 30 June 2021\nLink copied successfully\nKeeping people safe and secure on Twitter is one of our top priorities
column9: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to helping people understand the security tools we offer and how to use them. Starting today
column10: people on Twitter have the option to use security keys as their only form of two-factor authentication (2FA)
column11: which is the most effective way to keep your Twitter account secure.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhile any form of 2FA is better than no 2FA
column12: physical security keys are the most effective. Security keys are small devices that act like keys to your house. Just as you need a physical key to unlock the door to your home
column13: you need a security key to unlock access to your account. Security keys offer the strongest protection for your Twitter account because they have built-in protections to ensure that even if a key is used on a phishing site
column14: the information shared can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t be used to access your account. They use the FIDO and WebAuthn security standards to transfer the burden of protecting against phishing attempts from a human to a hardware device. Security keys can differentiate legitimate sites from malicious ones and block phishing attempts that SMS or verification codes would not. \nTwitter has long encouraged the use of some form of 2FA. In 2018
column15: we added the option to use security keys as one of several 2FA options. However
column16: this initial support only worked for Twitter.com
column17: not the mobile app
column18:
and required accounts to have another form of 2FA enabled as well. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In 2019
column19: we upgraded our security key support to use the latest WebAuthn standard
column20: which provides an up-to-date and secure authentication method recognized across the web. We also enabled the ability to use 2FA on a Twitter account without requiring a phone number
column21: allowing people to protect their accounts from SIM-swapping attacks and opening up 2FA to more people. In 2020
column22: we made additional improvements by enabling support for security keys on iOS and Android
column23: in addition to the web. And earlier this year
column24: we added the ability to register multiple security keys on your Twitter account
column25: allowing you to have backup security keys and making it easier for accounts managed by multiple people to enable 2FA with multiple security keys.\u00c2\u00a0\nToday
column26: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re adding the option to use security keys as your sole 2FA method \u00e2\u0080\u0094 meaning you can enroll one or more security keys as the only form of 2FA on your Twitter account without a backup 2FA method. We know this is important to people because not everyone is able to have a backup 2FA method or wants to share their phone number with us. With this update
column27:
we want everyone to feel empowered to enable security keys to better secure their Twitter account. 
Weâll continue to make updates and improvements to the ways you can keep your Twitter account secure. 
Â

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Listening to the real voice of the customer on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Listening to the real voice of the customer on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 28 June 2021\nLink copied successfully\nThe oldest documented customer complaint wasn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t in response to a request for feedback but rather an unsolicited salvo against a perceived injustice. Dating from around 1750 BC in Mesopotamia
column9: the small clay tablet describes how a man named Nanni was delivered the wrong grade of copper ore from a merchant named Ea-nasir. And Nanni wasn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t happy
column10: writing in a now extinct East Semitic language
column11: \u00e2\u0080\u009cWhat do you take me for
column12:
that you treat somebody like me with such contempt?â1
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Complaint tablet to Ea-nasir
column13:
The British Museum 
          
          
        
We unfortunately donât know how or if Nanniâs complaint was ever addressed
column14: but this ancient artifact does highlight that as a species we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been complaining for a very long time. \nToday we call feedback like Nanni\u00e2\u0080\u0099s customer experience
column15: a term that has taken on many meanings recently. At its most basic
column16: customer experience (CX) is the combination of all the interactions or touchpoints an organisation has with its customers. And it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a relatively new phenomenon
column17: for it wasn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t until the mid-20th century
column18: with the rise of consumerism
column19: that businesses started to take customer experience seriously as a way to differentiate themselves from the competition. And as these newly empowered consumers now had many choices
column20: businesses realized they needed to do a better job of understanding their customers\u00e2\u0080\u0099 preferences and needs. This led to the birth of the market research industry and of various data collection techniques to capture consumer opinion and feedback. \nToday
column21: we have an abundance of research methodologies
column22: data analysis techniques and measures such as NPS and CSAT
column23: but
column24: by and large
column25: customer experience programs are built on feedback collection methods that are 50+ years old. Forrester recently found that an astonishing 70% of organizations rely solely on surveys for customer feedback and a large percentage of these are email surveys.2 Ask yourself
column26: when was the last time you actually completed one?\nPeople are inundated with survey requests these days resulting in low participation rates which ultimately leads to poor data and a lack of customer insight. To try and remedy this survey fatigue
column27: organizations are increasingly incentivizing participation. There\u00e2\u0080\u0099s certainly nothing wrong with this
column28: peoples\u00e2\u0080\u0099 time is valuable and should be compensated
column29: however the introduction of incentives has led to fraud driven by \u00e2\u0080\u0098professional\u00e2\u0080\u0099 responders as well as the plague of distributed survey farms and bots. As a result
column30: data quality is suffering. \nSo
column31: is there another way? The good news is
column32: people haven\u00e2\u0080\u0099t stopped sharing their experiences and opinions
column33: in fact
column34: they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re doing so now more than ever
column35: they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re just doing it in different places. And this is increasingly in the apps and social networks where they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re already spending considerable time. The customer care component of CX has seen massive growth on Twitter throughout the pandemic as stores shuttered and phone lines were clogged. However
column36: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s the customer feedback element of Twitter that remains untapped and presents a huge opportunity for organizations to understand the real voices of their customers. \nBut these voices are different from the ones you commonly hear via surveys
column37: which encourage filtered
column38: rationally processed and controlled retrospective responses. Voices on Twitter are raw and emotive because they are expressed while people are actually having that experience. And because they are not directed by specific questions
column39: they often surface feedback you wouldn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t think to ask about. \nTwitter has always been a great place for organizations to engage with consumers
column40: not only to resolve their issues and enquiries
column41: but also to learn from the wealth of opinions they freely share. So instead of chasing people around the web or bombarding their inbox for feedback
column42:
what if you listened to what they were already saying?
Interested to learn more about how Twitter can support your customer feedback initiatives? Find a partner who can support you at partners.twitter.com or build your own solution at developer.twitter.com.
1 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complaint_tablet_to_Ea-nasir 2 Forresterâs Q2 2020 State of VoC and CX Measurement Programs Survey
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Digital Services Act: Defending the Open Internet"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Digital Services Act: Defending the Open Internet
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8:
23 June 2021
Link copied successfully
This letter was jointly written by;Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The Digital Services Act (DSA) represents a unique opportunity to build on the laws that laid a foundation for the flourishing of the Open Internet
column9: which has been an unprecedented catalyst of economic and social development. We believe in a fair and forward-looking approach to regulation that protects what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s best about our online environment and promotes the values of innovation
column10: strong competition
column11: and consumer choice that underpin the global
column12:
Open Internet.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Before addressing the DSA directly
column13: we note our concern regarding the ongoing fragmentation of Internet rule-making across the EU. Instead of recognising that a borderless utility like the Internet benefits from regional and global agreement of standards
column14: countries are moving ahead with national models of regulation. This has the fundamental effect of undermining the foundational principle of the Digital Single Market (DSM)
column15: namely that its purpose is to create one set of rules for one market. Each national legislative initiative that overlaps or directly conflicts with the DSA picks at the threads of the DSM
column16: fraying it further and further
column17: making Europe a more challenging business environment for companies of all sizes. This challenge becomes greater for smaller companies that are already facing the formidable task of competing with the very largest players in our industry. We urge the Commission and the EU institutions to state clearly that the DSM must be preserved by coherent and regional rule-making
column18:
and that national measures should be discouraged. This issue goes to the heart of whether Europe is committed to creating a digital economy thatâs built on the Open Internet.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Further
column19: we see a worrying trend whereby the EU or a member state will enact legislation with onerous and highly local requirements
column20: or prescribe severe sanctions. The fairness of enforcement is dependent on due process protections embedded in the legal system around the law. Another country may then copy that law
column21: often outside the EU
column22: but its legal and political system places less emphasis on due process. In this way
column23: more repressive regimes can exert pressure on platforms to comply with requests that would restrict certain businesses
column24: freedom of expression
column25: political dissent
column26: journalism
column27: and activism.\nThe EU and its member states must be careful to build due process protections into legislation that may be exported across borders. As Access Now has said
column28: \u00e2\u0080\u009cthe DSA will set a precedent for content governance beyond the European Union. If not done right
column29: the negative impact of this legislation could be far-reaching for human rights protection in the online ecosystem.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Europe\u00e2\u0080\u0099s example here is critical and must be considered in an international context.\nWe urge policymakers across Europe to be mindful of their unique role at this time. The DSA is breaking new ground
column30: largely for the positive
column31: and this process of regional standard-setting should be allowed to play out before further action is taken at member state level. Done right
column32: the introduction of harmonised standards across the EU will avoid stifling competition and innovation
column33: leading to a more diverse online ecosystem
column34: and they\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll set a global benchmark for others to follow.\nPut simply
column35:
the DSA must defend the ideal of the Digital Single Market as Europeâs commitment to the Open Internet.Â 
LEGISLATING FOR THE FUTURE OF THE INTERNET
We welcome the maintenance of a prohibition on general monitoring and the legislative focus on illegal content. We encourage policymakers to further clarify what content is considered illegal across the EU.
However
column36: we believe that focusing excessively on increasingly outmoded models of content moderation stifles competition and undermines freedom of expression. The DSA should encourage judicious and deliberate decision-making on content
column37: rather than impose overreaching notice and takedown requirements that would incentivise risk-averse removal of content. European Digital Rights (EDRi) has noted that \u00e2\u0080\u009cin a world in which people upload millions of hours of video and billions of photos and texts every day
column38: it has become impossible to determine the legality of every single piece with certainty\u00e2\u0080\u00a6 Most of those instances require an informed legality assessment by a trained professional in order to avoid a large number of wrongful removals.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nWe ask the EU to adopt the principle that actual knowledge of illegality is only obtained by intermediaries if it comes through a legally defined judicial process.\nWe further believe that a more nuanced approach would be in the best interests of the regulator
column39: companies of all sizes
column40: and the user. As we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve said before
column41: content policy can shape the competitive marketplace
column42: and as such
column43: overly rigid and intensive proposals (such as those set out in Articles 14 to 21) risk setting regulatory barriers that only a handful of companies have the resources to meet. Stanford\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Daphne Keller says these provisions
column44: as a whole
column45: require that platforms of all sizes and varieties be \u00e2\u0080\u009cdeeply regulated
column46: and regulable
column47: or stop existing.\u00e2\u0080\u009d It seems intuitive that the outcome of the system currently proposed will be to the benefit of the largest companies in our industry. Indeed
column48: Keller goes on to say that \u00e2\u0080\u009cthe DSA effectively forfeits competition and consumer choice as a way of shaping platform behavior
column49: in favor of having a few heavily regulated entities.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\u00c2\u00a0\nTherefore
column50: we encourage regulators to include additional flexibility for deliberation
column51: while placing more focus on business structure and incentives. The DSA should enshrine the principle that content moderation should be proportionate to the perceived harm. This will move us towards a more balanced approach to moderation
column52: moving past the leave-up-take-down models of the past. In the long term
column53: the question of how users encounter content may be more important than whether content exists
column54: particularly as swathes of the Internet shift to a more decentralised existence.\nFurther
column55: an assessment of how platforms offer users meaningful choice and control in their online experience will go to the heart of societal concerns regarding the Internet\u00e2\u0080\u0099s effect on democracies and the health of our information environment. By placing emphasis on these areas
column56: regulators will have taken more holistic measures to counter potential online harms. Such policies will also stand the test of time
column57: enduring beyond technological cycles.\u00c2\u00a0\nREAL CHOICE AND FAIR COMPETITION\nThe Open Internet thrives because of its architecture
column58: with consumer choice and open standards between platforms. Open architectures
column59: done properly
column60: do not lock-in dominant business or service models. As several members of the European Parliament recently pointed out
column61: interoperability protects users and competition. We welcome the European Commission\u00e2\u0080\u0099s proposals in this area but also encourage decision-makers to include more robust provisions fostering interoperability in Chapter 3 of the DSA.\nThe Internet is more than a handful of companies. We call on policymakers to recognise this by including more precision in the criteria for very large online platforms (VLOPS) in Chapter 3
column62: Section 4. Although a certain degree of latitude is needed to guarantee the flexibility of legislation
column63: this should not be done at the expense of the online ecosystem by requiring smaller actors to meet requirements that only the largest
column64: wealthiest
column65: and market-dominant companies can shoulder. There is the perception of Internet companies and there is the reality \u00e2\u0080\u0093 sometimes the latter starkly differs from the former and the criteria for VLOPs should be grounded in practical reality.\u00c2\u00a0\nTRANSPARENCY AND ACCOUNTABILITY\nThere is a need to strike the right balance between technical transparency and things that actually empower consumers with more choice and control. We support simple yet meaningful ways for users to exercise privacy and data choices
column66: for example through greater control of ad targeting
column67: while also requiring companies to set out their Terms of Service in simple
column68: understandable terms.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe commit to continue increasing transparency around policy enforcement and data access to empower research and more disclosures around coordinated efforts to manipulate platforms. It is crucial that transparency requirements outlined in Articles 13 and 23 of the DSA should not undermine these efforts to protect users
column69: or inadvertently expose services to potential harm
column70: for example
column71: exposing enforcement methods or techniques that could be leveraged to undermine those efforts.\nOur services are part of a larger information ecosystem that includes companies of all sizes
column72: nonprofit organisations
column73: publishers
column74: academic institutions
column75: and more. To ensure meaningful transparency
column76: it is necessary that we have flexible and differentiated requirements across all sectors. These requirements should recognise how each entity approaches transparency in ways that reflect their operations. Horizontal requirements will only create an apples to oranges comparison between organisations large and small
column77: centralised and decentralised.\nSigned:\n@automattic
column78: @jodelapp
column79: @seznam_cz
column80:
@Twitter and @Vimeo
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
First Letter: Crossroads for the Open Internet

December 2020

column3: "title": "A new Arabic language setting
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/product/2021/a-new-arabic-language-setting"
column8: "post_text": "Product\nA new Arabic language setting
column9:
from ØºØ±ÙØ¯ to ØºØ±ÙØ¯Ù 
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Tuesday
column10:
15 June 2021
Link copied successfully
Â 
People across the world come to Twitter to discuss whatâs happening
column11: and we want our service to better reflect the many voices that shape the conversation. In some languages
column12: such as Arabic
column13: words can be feminine or masculine
column14: but we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve missed a way for people to tell us how they want to be addressed. So today
column15: we're introducing a new language setting that acknowledges and better supports the Arabic feminine form. \nPeople who select this setting will be addressed in the feminine form. For example
column16: \u00e2\u0080\u009cTweet\u00e2\u0080\u009d will be \u00d8\u00ba\u00d8\u00b1\u00d9\u0091\u00d8\u00af\u00d9\u008a (which addresses women) rather than the default Arabic today
column17: which is \u00d8\u00ba\u00d8\u00b1\u00d9\u0091\u00d8\u00af (addressing men). Also
column18: \u00e2\u0080\u009cExplore\u00e2\u0080\u009d will be \u00d8\u00a5\u00d8\u00b3\u00d8\u00aa\u00d9\u0083\u00d8\u00b4\u00d9\u0081\u00d9\u008a rather than \u00d8\u00a5\u00d8\u00b3\u00d8\u00aa\u00d9\u0083\u00d8\u00b4\u00d9\u0081.\u00c2\u00a0\nHere\u00e2\u0080\u0099s how to use it:\nLog in to Twitter.com
column19: go to \u00e2\u0080\u009cSettings and privacy
column20: \u00e2\u0080\u009d then \u00e2\u0080\u009cAccessibility
column21: display
column22: and languages.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Next
column23:
select âLanguagesâ and go to âDisplay languageâ.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Select âArabic (feminine)â from the âDisplay languageâ drop down menu. The display language onÂ Twitter.com will then address you in the feminine form.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Together with the update
column24:
weâre launching a campaign titled #FeminineArabic Ø£ØªØ­Ø¯Ø«_Ø¨Ø§ÙÙØ¤ÙØ«# to share our approach and partner with others to do so. We created an emoji that gets unlocked with the following English and Arabic hashtags: #FeminineArabic and Ø£ØªØ­Ø¯Ø«_Ø¨Ø§ÙÙØ¤ÙØ«# .Â  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Join the conversation to see how a number of organizations
column25: brands
column26:
and personalities are supporting the campaign so far.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâre adding this language support toÂ Twitter.com and working to bring it to Twitter for iOS and Android as well. Weâre committed to using inclusive language at Twitter
column27: regardless if it's written down
column28: shown on our site and apps
column29: or embedded in our code. We know there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s more work to be done for our service to reflect the variety of voices around the world
column30:
and weâll continue to share what we learn and how we update Twitter based on your feedback.

column3: "title": "Introducing Twitter Blue - Twitter\u2019s first-ever subscription offering "
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Introducing Twitter Blue - Twitterâs first-ever subscription offering 
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 3 June 2021\nLink copied successfully\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve heard from the people that use Twitter a lot
column9: and we mean a lot
column10: that we don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t always build power features that meet their needs. Well
column11: that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s about to change. We took this feedback to heart
column12: and are developing and iterating upon a solution that will give the people who use Twitter the most what they are looking for: access to exclusive features and perks that will take their experience on Twitter to the next level.\nAnd for those wondering
column13: no
column14: a free Twitter is not going away
column15: and never will. This subscription offering is simply meant to add enhanced and complementary features to the already existing Twitter experience for those who want it.\nMeet Twitter Blue\nStarting today
column16: we will be rolling out our first iteration of Twitter Blue in Australia and Canada. Our hope with this initial phase is to gain a deeper understanding of what will make your Twitter experience more customized
column17: more expressive
column18:
and generally speaking more ð¥.Â 
Those who sign up for a Twitter Blue subscription will get a set of features and perks that include the following:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Bookmark Folders: Want an easy way to better organize your saved content? Bookmark Folders let you organize the Tweets youâve saved by letting you manage content so when you need it
column19:
you can find it easily and efficiently.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Undo Tweet: Typo? Forgot to tag someone? Preview and revise your Tweet before it goes live. With Undo Tweet
column20: you can set a customizable timer of up to 30 seconds to click \u00e2\u0080\u0098Undo\u00e2\u0080\u0099 before the Tweet
column21: reply
column22:
or thread youâve sent posts to your timeline. Correct mistakes easily by previewing what your Tweet will look like before the world can see it.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Reader Mode: Reader Mode provides a more beautiful reading experience by getting rid of the noise. We are making it easier for you to keep up with long threads on Twitter by turning them into easy-to-read text so you can read all the latest content seamlessly.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Subscribers will also get access to perks
column23: such as customizable app icons for their device\u00e2\u0080\u0099s home screen and fun color themes for their Twitter app
column24:
and will have access to dedicated subscription customer support.
This initial set of features was developed based on feedback we received from our very own power Twitter community:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As a Twitter Blue subscriber
column25: you will get these features and perks for the monthly price of $3.49 CAD or $4.49 AUD. We will be listening to feedback and building out even more features and perks for our subscribers over time. As always
column26: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be keeping you updated as we progress right here
column27: so be sure to check back in.\u00c2\u00a0\nFor those of you in Australia and Canada
column28:
get your Tweet on and sign up for Twitter Blue! And be sure to follow @TwitterBlue to keep up to date with the latest and share your feedback. Weâll be listening ð.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Elevating credible climate change information this World Environment Day"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Elevating credible climate change information this World Environment Day
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 3 June 2021\nLink copied successfully\nPeople around the world use Twitter to raise awareness about the climate crisis
column9: organize for change in their communities
column10: and connect with others passionate about protecting our planet. Ahead of World Environment Day
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re partnering with organizations committed to tackling climate change and making it easier to find credible climate information from global experts.\u00c2\u00a0\nThis week
column12: we took additional steps to better serve the climate conversation happening across Twitter. We know that people use the service to find credible information during global crises. Starting this week
column13: you can follow the Climate Change\u00c2\u00a0Topic\u00c2\u00a0to find personalized conversations about climate change
column14: including Tweets from environmental and sustainability organizations
column15: environmental activists
column16: and scientists. These Tweets will appear right in your home timeline when you follow the Topic.\nAddressing the climate emergency requires collaboration
column17: community
column18: and widespread mobilization. Through #AdsForGood grants
column19: events
column20: on-service support
column21: and trainings
column22: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re partnering with organizations promoting and amplifying environmental conservation and sustainability. These include Earth Day Network
column23: United Nations (UN) Environment Programme
column24: UN Framework Convention on Climate Change
column25: UN Development Programme
column26: Greenpeace
column27: Voice for the Planet
column28: Let Me Breathe
column29: WWF
column30: 350.org
column31: FridaysForFuture
column32: We Don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t Have Time
column33: Climate Reality Project
column34: and others.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also made new environmental commitments and expanded Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s sustainability efforts. In partnership with the Science Based Target Initiative (SBTi)
column35: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve committed to significantly reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 2030
column36: paving the way for our net-zero journey.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe recognize that transparency and accountability should be central to our approach to sustainability. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited about the SBTi pledge because it advances Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s environmental efforts in a clear and measurable way.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to protecting the environment
column37: reducing our carbon footprint
column38: and using our service to make a positive difference in the world. We continue to work toward our goal of achieving 100% carbon-neutral power sourcing in our current data centers by the end of 2022. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve partnered with Cool Effect
column39: a nonprofit organization that helps offset emissions from our data centers and employee travel
column40: to fund green projects around the world. So far
column41: 92% of our global offices have achieved the \"Green Building Certified\" standard
column42: with more to come.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re mobilizing our workforce around the globe to participate and to make change at Twitter
column43: but we know there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s more to do. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why
column44: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re ramping up our sustainability goals company-wide.\nHow can you participate?\nWe all have a part we can play in tackling this global crisis. From volunteering with an environmental organization in your community
column45: to learning more about protecting our planet
column46: there are lots of ways to get involved. Promote sustainable causes and ideas
column47: advocate to your elected representatives
column48:
and join the conversation. Every little bit matters. We encourage you to Tweet along with the #WorldEnvironmentDay conversation happening on Twitter and follow the Climate ChangeÂ TopicÂ for more.
Â 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter

column3: "title": "Relaunching verification and what\u2019s next"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Relaunching verification and whatâs next
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 20 May 2021\nLink copied successfully\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to share that starting today
column9: we'll begin rolling out our new verification application process and reviewing public applications for verification on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nOver the past several months
column10: we've been working to bring clarity to the verification eligibility criteria and launched a new policy\u00c2\u00a0shaped by public feedback. We also started enforcing that policy by automatically removing the verified badge from accounts that no longer meet the updated criteria for verification
column11: such as those that are inactive or incomplete. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re grateful for all who participated in our public feedback period and shared ideas for how we can improve verification on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nToday\u00e2\u0080\u0099s application rollout marks the next milestone in our plans to give more transparency
column12: credibility and clarity to verification on Twitter. Below
column13: we share more about this application process and what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next in our work to help people understand who they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re interacting with on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhat it means to be verified on Twitter\nThe blue badge is one of the ways we help people distinguish the authenticity of accounts that are of high public interest. It gives people on Twitter more context about who they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re having conversations with so they can determine if it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s trustworthy
column14: which our research has shown leads to healthier
column15: more informed conversations.\u00c2\u00a0\nWith today\u00e2\u0080\u0099s application launch
column16: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also introducing new guidelines for verified accounts on Twitter. These verification guidelines are intended to encourage healthy conversations for the betterment of the Twitter community overall. They follow the philosophy to lead by example
column17: Tweet others how they want to be Tweeted
column18: and serve the public conversation authentically
column19: respectfully
column20: and with consideration. As always
column21: all accounts
column22: including verified accounts
column23: must follow the Twitter Rules. And as we previously shared
column24: verified accounts that repeatedly violate the Twitter Rules are subject to have the blue badge removed.\nWho\u00e2\u0080\u0099s eligible?\nTo qualify for verification
column25: you must fit the criteria of one of the six categories listed below:\u00c2\u00a0\nGovernment\nCompanies
column26:
brands and organizations
News organizations and journalists
Entertainment
Sports and gaming
Activists
column27: organizers
column28: and other influential individuals\nIn addition to the category-specific eligibility criteria outlined in our verification policy
column29: your account must be complete
column30: meaning you have a profile name
column31: a profile image and either a confirmed email address or phone number. Your account must also be active within the last six months and have a record of adherence to the Twitter Rules. You can read more about ineligible accounts in the policy\u00c2\u00a0as well.\u00c2\u00a0\nHow can you apply to get verified?\u00c2\u00a0\nOver the next few weeks
column32: everyone on Twitter will start to see the new verification application directly in the Account Settings tab. If you don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t see this update immediately today
column33:
donât worry! We're gradually rolling it out to everyone to ensure that we can review applications in a timely manner.Â 
Hereâs what the application flow will look like:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Once you submit your application
column34: you can expect an emailed response from us within a few days
column35: but this could take up to a few weeks depending on how many open applications are in our queue. If your application is approved
column36: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll see the blue badge automatically on your profile. If you think we made a mistake
column37: reapply 30 days after receiving our decision on your application.\nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next\nWe know that the current verification policy may not represent all of the people who should be eligible to be verified on Twitter
column38: so we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re planning to introduce more categories later this year
column39: such as those for scientists
column40: academics
column41: and religious leaders. To stay up-to-date with verification
column42: be sure to follow @Verified.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also excited to continue expanding the ways people can express themselves on Twitter through their profile and launching new account types. Since our last update
column43: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been doing ongoing research on automated accounts and plan to introduce a way to denote this account type in the next few months
column44: with memorialized accounts to follow. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also exploring improvements to the Twitter profile to allow people to better express themselves
column45: such as through an About page. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll share more on all of this soon!\nWe look forward to continuing our work to give people more ways to identify and express themselves on Twitter to lead to more informed
column46:
healthier conversations.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet

column3: "title": "How British Telecom is leveraging Twitter data"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
How British Telecom is leveraging Twitter data
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 17 May 2021\nLink copied successfully\nSocial data is becoming an increasingly important source of consumer insight for many organizations. British Telecom (BT) has been on a five year journey to better utilize these social insights and so I spoke with Adam Mills
column9: Brand Strategy & Planning Insight Manager
column10: to learn more about their experience and how they are leveraging social intelligence to make better decisions across their business.\n JR: To start
column11: who\u00e2\u0080\u0099s your favourite Twitter follow? AM: I love @Nigella_Lawson
column12: in particular how she talks and interacts with other people. But my absolute favourite is @rebuildingmcr \u00e2\u0080\u0093 there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s something so incredible about looking back at our city through the years and to see how it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s changed and developed. JR: Ah
column13: so not me? AM: Well
column14: um...\nJR: So let\u00e2\u0080\u0099s kick things off then. Give us some context on your role Adam. AM: I joined BT in 2017 as a brand analyst in the Group Digital Brand team
column15: which supported business units across the organisation. My job was to gather the data needed to support our big digital transformation programmes
column16: whether that was supporting app infrastructure and app consolidation or the group SEO strategy. At about that time our marketing and comms leadership team realized we needed to have a better understanding of what people were saying about us on social and therefore I also took on social listening.\nOver the next 18 months
column17: social became an increasingly important part of my role
column18: which evolved beyond just social listening to focus on our social capabilities and the infrastructure that supported them. I helped us analyze all the social accounts we maintained across multiple brands and to rethink their purpose. We sought to understand what was strategic and what wasn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t
column19: where to spend and where to pull back. This allowed me to take social listening beyond just listening and to start feeding it into new areas such as NPS and customer experience measurement. \nI then moved to a new team two years ago but took my role with me as we realized that social insights deserved a formal place within our larger insights function. This was great recognition of our work and the importance of social intelligence to the business. \nJR: How is BT\u00e2\u0080\u0099s consumer insights team structured and what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s the main focus? AM: About three years ago a new insights director arrived and took a look around and realised that there were pockets of insight scattered across the business with lots of duplication as a result. She decided to bring everyone together under a Centre of Excellence which became a group function allowing it to serve the entire business. We are now a team of 80
column20: broken up into a few teams covering topics such as commercial insights
column21: market and competitive intelligence
column22: brand insight and CX and group performance.\nOur purpose within the business is to put the customer at the heart of everything that we do
column23: championing the customer at the very heart of decision making. We find ourselves forever overcapacity
column24: which is a blessing and a curse as it shows the organization is getting value from our work
column25: but clearly we need to find ways to scale as we can only do so much. Last year
column26: for example
column27: mid-pandemic we relaunched our internal insights hub and have since had thousands of employees take advantage of it. Next up we want to think more about the new sources of digital insight available to us and how that complements the traditional research methodologies we use. For example
column28: we want to build Brandwatch dashboards connected via our APIs that can deliver real-time social data within our platform providing the right data at the right time to the right people. \nJR: DIY and agile seem to be the latest buzz words in market research.\u00c2\u00a0Has your Centre of Excellence structure allowed you to bring work in-house? AM: Yes and no. Some things we can do in-house and are doing more of. Our NPS program for example is pretty much run entirely in house
column29: which is amazing given the size and the scale of the surveys that we run and the amount of data we collect. But I\u00e2\u0080\u0099d also say no in that there are some projects where we really value our research agency partners' perspectives and want them to challenge our thinking. BT has always been open to accepting that challenge. So while we don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t necessarily run everything in house
column30: in some ways it feels like we do because our research partners are an extension of our team and have supported us for a long time and therefore know us very well.\nJR: You mentioned NPS. Can you tell us about the program? AM: Sure
column31: we run NPS monthly for our B2C and B2B customers. We relaunched the program a couple of years ago with the messaging that everyone in the business can own and impact this metric
column32: regardless of role or level. We really wanted to emphasize that every customer touchpoint has a direct impact on this metric and therefore we all need to go the extra mile. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a core metric for us.\nJR: What type of research methodologies do you use? AM: It's a mix of qualitative and quantitative. From a qual perspective
column33: we used to do a lot of face to face and focus groups before the lockdowns began and since then we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve pivoted to virtual focus groups which have been eye-opening
column34: to say the least and have allowed us to expand the types and locations of people we speak with. For example
column35: last week I had a group that had someone from all four nations of the UK
column36: which is the first time I can remember that. So I suspect even when things open up again
column37: the virtual focus groups will be here to stay given their benefits in terms of panel diversity and flexibility. With respect to our quantitative studies
column38: these can take a myriad of different forms from a very standard five minute online survey to a 20-minute in-person survey. We've got experts and specialists across these approaches.\nJR: And what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s your approach to collecting feedback across the customer journey? AM: We've invested a significant amount into automating feedback collection into our analysis process and therefore our market research engines. Building in customer trigger points is crucial for this
column39: especially in our business where our customers have contracts with us. We think a lot about relationship stages and the right time to trigger various types of requests for feedback as we don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t want to overburden our customers.\nJR: I\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve read that survey participation rates are in decline. Is BT seeing this? AM: I can only speak about it from the surveys I run which are mainly in the realm of brand tracking
column40: but yes
column41: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen a significant decline in participation this past year
column42: certainly in B2B more than B2C. It seems pretty understandable to me
column43: given the circumstances of the past 12 months
column44: that people don't want to be glued to their computer screens for any longer than they absolutely have to and don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t want to think about completing surveys.\nSo it is a problem and we are thinking about the things we can do to change that
column45: but certainly
column46: the trend that we are seeing over the past five years is that attention spans are falling through the floor. And I think it's a really interesting dynamic now because you've got a generation of people that are going to be coming through
column47: whether making decisions for themselves or for their companies
column48: who have different approaches to engaging with brands. \nSo
column49: how do you deal with that? How do you build a business that is going to allow you to gain information from your customers in a world like that? And that's when it gets really interesting in my space. How do you build a brand tracking questionnaire that was historically 25 minutes and now needs to be no longer than three and yet still provides the same level of value and insight to the business? It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a big challenge for sure. \nJR: Do you believe social can provide unique insight and pick up some of the slack? AM: It certainly adds another dimension to our understanding of customer needs and concerns. The verbatims we capture via surveys provide a lot of context and social for me is so important because it adds colour and context to these verbatims. So for example
column50: if you see a sudden spike in negative NPS responses or brand tracking you can dive into those social comments and understand that there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s been a network outage or perhaps a competitor has launched something new.\nI can remember a situation a few years back when we had a sudden spike in people complaining about mobile coverage at 10 am in the morning. Upon further analysis
column51: we realized that a local morning television program had invited a money-saving expert as a guest and he told the viewers that if you complain about coverage and prices on a public forum such as Twitter
column52: you might get a better deal. We actually found this out via our competitor monitoring program
column53: as they were also seeing increased traffic. A powerful aspect of social data is the ability to analyze competitors
column54: which we wouldn't have necessarily been able to do within brand tracking or other methods.\nJR: Can social augment or even replace brand tracking metrics? AM: The engagement our customers have with us on social media tends to be service driven and reactive rather than proactive
column55: and so while it provides really helpful insight into the voice of the customer
column56: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s been difficult for us to correlate accurately with NPS. That said
column57: we have managed to correlate social conversations with several of our other brand tracking metrics and will continue to look into this more.\nJR: What\u00e2\u0080\u0099s been BT\u00e2\u0080\u0099s journey with social intelligence to date? AM: It has definitely been a journey. Just before I joined the business in 2017
column58: the group digital brand team was created and was asked to do a complete review of social including output
column59: social care
column60: everything. At that point we had nearly 400 branded social accounts across the group but no coordination in terms of their use of brand guidelines. In addition
column61: some of these accounts had ad spend associated with them while others did not and some used third-party social tools while some published content natively. So in reality there was no consistent
column62: coherent social strategy across the business and no visibility as to what was really going on. We were just sending social posts out into the ether which had the potential to be quite damaging reputationally.\nSo we had to educate our staff on what social could be
column63: the importance of speaking with a unified voice
column64: of measuring in a consistent way and of using the data to help us make better decisions across the business. And thankfully the business bought into the idea that social was so much more than funny cat memes. This allowed us to define a new social strategy with multiple stakeholders which we then launched as part of our B2C brand refresh in October 2019. We came out the back of this work with 12 strategic social accounts
column65: all of which now had proper funding
column66: performance management and KPIs. \nThe reason I tell you all of this is that a lot of the work we've done over the last four years has allowed us to build an understanding of 1) what social insight and social data can do and 2) how that links with digital insight and 3) how it provides a real time voice of the customer. It will never replace qualitative focus groups
column67: if you want robust and reliable data you have to go with focus groups
column68: but it can provide directional accuracy. People really started understanding the value of this when we stopped describing it as social listening and instead as the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s largest focus group. This change of language helped people make the connection to the world of research
column69: making it more reputable. \nJR: Your team has many research methodologies at their disposal to get at consumer opinion. Where does social data fit into this and how is it being used today? AM: Even after the strides we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made the past few years
column70: we are still at the very beginning of our work with social data. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve gone from just six users of social listening to over 400 staff who now have access to several social solutions depending on their role. So as we get more familiar with social data we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be able to do much more. But as for today
column71: we lean on social data to help us do a great many things. Reputational insight for example is proving hugely valuable for us. We are also working with our customer care team on proactive care where there is a big opportunity to prevent churn and improve overall brand sentiment. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re using social data to help with network outage detection and communication. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re using it for audience analysis and to better understand how distinct groups think about our products. And finally
column72: we are starting to use logo and image analysis as one input to identify sponsorship opportunities. So as you can see
column73: a variety of use cases that add value across the business.\nJR: Final question then...what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Twitter data\u00e2\u0080\u0099s superpower? AM:\u00c2\u00a0Its spontaneity
column74: its real-time nature. The fact that it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not forced
column75:
but unsolicited. People speak differently on social than they do to researchers so it provides a different way to understand consumers and their needs.
JR: Many thanks for your time today Adam!
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Tweeting with consideration"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Tweeting with consideration
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 5 May 2021\nLink copied successfully\nPeople come to Twitter to talk about what's happening
column9: and sometimes conversations about things we care about can get intense and people say things in the moment they might regret later. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why in 2020
column10: we tested prompts that encouraged people to pause and reconsider a potentially harmful or offensive reply before they hit send.\nBased on feedback and learnings from those tests
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made improvements to the systems that decide when and how these reminders are sent. Starting today
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re rolling these improved prompts out across iOS and Android
column13:
starting with accounts that have enabled English-language settings.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
How we got here
We began testing prompts last year that encouraged people to pause and reconsider a potentially harmful or offensive reply â such as insults
column14: strong language
column15: or hateful remarks \u00e2\u0080\u0094 before Tweeting it. Once prompted
column16: people had an opportunity to take a moment and make edits
column17: delete
column18: or send the reply as is.\nIn early tests
column19: people were sometimes prompted unnecessarily because the algorithms powering the prompts struggled to capture the nuance in many conversations and often didn't differentiate between potentially offensive language
column20: sarcasm
column21: and friendly banter. Throughout the experiment process
column22: we analyzed results
column23: collected feedback from the public
column24: and worked to address our errors
column25: including detection inconsistencies.\nThese tests ultimately resulted in people sending less potentially offensive replies across the service
column26: and improved behavior on Twitter. We learned that:\u00c2\u00a0\nIf prompted
column27: 34% of people revised their initial reply or decided to not send their reply at all.\nAfter being prompted once
column28: people composed
column29: on average
column30: 11% fewer offensive replies in the future.\nIf prompted
column31: people were less likely to receive offensive and harmful replies back.\nSince the early tests
column32: here\u00e2\u0080\u0099s what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve incorporated into the systems that decide when and how to send these reminders:\nConsideration of the nature of the relationship between the author and replier
column33: including how often they interact. For example
column34: if two accounts follow and reply to each other often
column35: there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a higher likelihood that they have a better understanding of preferred tone of communication.\nAdjustments to our technology to better account for situations in which language may be reclaimed by underrepresented communities and used in non-harmful ways.\nImprovement to our technology to more accurately detect strong language
column36:
including profanity.
Created an easier way for people to let us know if they found the prompt helpful or relevant.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Whatâs next
Weâll continue to explore how prompts â such as reply prompts and article prompts â and other forms of intervention can encourage healthier conversations on Twitter. Our teams will also collect feedback from people on Twitter who have received reply prompts as we expand this feature to other languages. Stay tuned for more updates as we continue to learn and make new improvements to encourage more meaningful conversations on Twitter.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter

column10: 4 May 2021\nLink copied successfully\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to introduce\u00c2\u00a0I Wish I Knew
column11: a new podcast that brings you directly into the world of @TwitterResearch.\nEach episode in Season 1 will be co-hosted by a different pair of researchers who will share their journeys into the field
column12: discuss how the team is elevating conversations across the company through insights
column13: explore why research matters
column14:
and celebrate the people and culture surrounding the work.

column18: and Stitcher. \nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also hosting a Space from @TwitterResearch this Friday
column19: May 7th at 12:30p PT / 3:30p ET to celebrate premiere week. We hope you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll join to hear more about the season and discuss all of the things you wish you knew about the Research team at Twitter.\nI Wish I Knew launches with its first episode
column20: I Wish I Knew\u00e2\u0080\u00a6 How Research at Twitter Works

they share advice about must-have skills for aspiring researchers.
Want to have your questions answered in a future episode of I Wish I Knew? Tweet us @TwitterResearch.

column3: "title": "A better way to publish and read on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
A better way to publish and read on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 4 May 2021\nLink copied successfully\nPeople come to\u00c2\u00a0Twitter every day to discover and read about what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening. Publishers
column9: journalists
column10: and writers drive this conversation
column11: keeping the world informed and igniting discussions around the news
column12: issues
column13: and topics we collectively care about. If Twitter is where so much of this conversation lives
column14: it should be easier and simpler to read the content that drives it.\u00c2\u00a0 \nThat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to announce that Twitter is acquiring Scroll. Scroll has built a way to read articles without the ads
column15: pop-ups
column16: and other clutter that get in the way
column17: cleaning up the reading experience and giving people what they want: just the content. Meanwhile
column18:
publishers who work with Scroll can bring in more revenue than they would from traditional ads on a page. Itâs a better Internet for readers and for writers.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Scroll gives readers what they want: clean
column19:
ad-free reading across the web. 
          
          
        
This is an exciting opportunity for us to introduce this proven model to publishers on our service and make reading the news better for everyone involved. Looking ahead
column20: Scroll will become a meaningful addition to our subscriptions work as we build and shape a future subscription service on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0 \nImproving the reader experience\nThose who create and consume news know that reading \u00e2\u0080\u0093 and more broadly
column21: journalism \u00e2\u0080\u0093 deserve a better future. Scroll will help us build that future
column22: solving one of the most frustrating parts about reading content online. We want to reimagine what they\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve built to deliver a seamless reading experience to our hyper-engaged audiences and allow publishers to deliver cleaner content that can make them more money than today\u00e2\u0080\u0099s business models.\nTo do this
column23: we plan to include Scroll as part of an upcoming subscription offering we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re currently exploring. As a Twitter subscriber
column24: picture getting access to premium features where you can easily read articles from your favorite news outlet or a writer\u00e2\u0080\u0099s newsletter from Revue
column25:
Â with a portion of your subscription going to the publishers and writers creating the content.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            With Scroll
column26:
publishers can make more money than they would through ads on their site. 
          
          
        
Whatâs next for ScrollÂ  
Scroll will temporarily pause new sign-ups. Following the acquisition
column27: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be working to include their product into our subscription plans and prepare to grow Scroll\u00e2\u0080\u0099s publisher network. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll keep supporting the existing community of customers and publishers on Scroll
column28: and new publishers interested in joining Scroll can\u00c2\u00a0sign up on their website for the latest updates.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to help build a better Internet for readers and writers on Twitter and beyond. Welcome to the flock
column29:
Scroll!Â

column3: "title": "Making Spaces accessible"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Making Spaces accessible
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 3 May 2021\nLink copied successfully\nServing the public conversation means continuously taking steps to make Twitter more accessible for people with disabilities \u00e2\u0080\u0093 from what we build
column9: to the programs and policies we implement globally \u00e2\u0080\u0093 both within the company and on our service. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to ensuring our service is accessible to everyone \u00e2\u0080\u0093 that's why we created two teams to focus on accessibility last year.\u00c2\u00a0\nToday
column10: I want to talk about Spaces
column11: our live audio conversation feature on Twitter. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re progressively rolling Spaces out to more people
column12: and we want to share where we are on our journey to make this feature more accessible.\nLet\u00e2\u0080\u0099s talk about accessibility in Spaces\u00c2\u00a0\nThe Spaces team has been working in the open
column13: in full view of the world
column14: since December 2020. The ongoing conversation around Spaces accessibility both internally and on Twitter has helped us identify and address accessibility gaps in the product. By working in the open
column15: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re showing you our ideas
column16: our works in progress
column17:
and areas for improvement. Twitter is becoming a more accessible company and product in real-time.
Whatâs accessibleÂ 
CaptionsÂ 
Folks who are deaf
column18: hard of hearing (HoH)
column19: or prefer the support of captioning for audio
column20: will be able to turn on captions and follow along with conversations.\nLabels\u00c2\u00a0\nEvery element in Spaces has an accessible label
column21: so people using assistive technology will know what every button does
column22:
and what actions are available.
What needs workÂ 
Work on captionsÂ 
Captions are incredibly important for Spaces
column23:
so weâre going to make them as accurate and versatile as possible. Here are some of the things weâll be working on first:
Improve accuracy and synchronization of captions with audio
Provide scrollback and enable pausing
Improve support for multiple speakers speaking synchronously
Customization of captions appearance (e.g.
column24: font color
column25: size
column26: background
column27:
etc.)
Remove the requirement for the Speaker to enable captions on iOS. (Theyâre automatic on Android because of the difference in caption service provider.)
Explore ways to improve automatic captioning algorithm and minimize inaccuracies
Explore options for increased language support
Work in other areasÂ 
Match accessibility system settings (larger fonts
column28: display
column29: etc.)\nPresent emoji reactions via assistive technologies\nExplore options for multi-modal participation beyond speech
column30:
such as text input mode
We're not doneÂ 
Â 
As James Loduca
column31: our Senior Director of Global Inclusion and Diversity
column32: has said
column33: \u00e2\u0080\u009cWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re on a journey
column34: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re closer to the beginning than we are to the end.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Our teams are working hard to make Twitter more accessible
column35: and we have a long way to go. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re learning as we build
column36: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to getting better. Continue to ask questions and hold us accountable. This will help us grow in service to the public conversation that includes everyone.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll Tweet accessibility happenings at @TwitterA11y
column37: follow along with the Spaces team at @TwitterSpaces
column38:
and you can learn about upcoming Spaces features in this blog post.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

#OnlyOnTwitter
