column3: "title": "Spaces is here
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/product/2021/spaces-is-here"
column8: "post_text": "Product\nSpaces is here
column9:
letâs chat
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column10: 3 May 2021\nLink copied successfully\nLast year we introduced Spaces: live audio conversations on Twitter. Since then
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been building and testing with a limited group
column12: and have found that hearing people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s voices bring conversations on Twitter to life in a completely new way.\u00c2\u00a0\nSince we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been building this
column13: the ability to create a Space has become available to millions of people
column14: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve continued to make improvements based on your feedback. Today
column15: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re bringing the ability to host a Space to all accounts with 600 or more followers on Twitter. Based on what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve learned so far
column16: these accounts are likely to have a good experience hosting live conversations because of their existing audience. Before bringing the ability to create a Space to everyone
column17: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re focused on learning more
column18: making it easier to discover Spaces
column19: and helping people enjoy them with a great audience.\u00c2\u00a0\nPeople already come to Twitter to talk about what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening. You\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve always followed people for their Tweets
column20: now Spaces lets you hear their voices and talk about what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening now and what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s most important to you \u00e2\u0080\u0093 live. From Tweeting to talking
column21: reading to listening
column22: Spaces encourages and unlocks real
column23: open conversations on Twitter with the authenticity and nuance
column24: depth and power only the human voice can bring. Spaces are for small and intimate conversations with just a few others
column25: or for big discussions about what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s unfolding right now with thousands of listeners. From connecting to your favorite musician to a post show about the game or a recap of news that just dropped
column26:
dig into the topics and conversations you care about with people you know and people you want to know.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
So how do you join or create a Space? Glad you asked.Â 
How Spaces work
On Twitter for iOS and Android
column27: when someone you follow starts or speaks in a Space
column28: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll appear at the top of your timeline as a purple bubble for as long as it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s live. When you join a Space as a listener
column29: you can react to what you hear with emojis
column30: check out any pinned Tweets
column31: follow along with captions
column32: Tweet or DM the Space
column33:
or request to speak.Â  
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Join a Space 
          
          
        
          
            Request to speak in a Space  
          
          
        
          
            Captions in a Space 
          
          
        
When you join a Space as a speaker
column34: in addition to talking
column35: you can pin Tweets to the Space
column36: turn on captions so everyone can follow along with what you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re saying
column37:
and Tweet the Space so your followers can join.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Tweets in a Space youâre speaking in 
          
          
        
When you create a Space
column38: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re in control \u00e2\u0080\u0093 who\u00e2\u0080\u0099s speaking
column39: the topics
column40: and the vibe. Invite people to join by Tweeting or DM\u00e2\u0080\u0099ing them to jump in and then invite them to speak directly from your Space. From there
column41:
talk about whatever is happening in your world.

column3: "title": "Supporting local journalists on #WorldPressFreedomDay"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Supporting local journalists on #WorldPressFreedomDay
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 3 May 2021\nLink copied successfully\nToday Twitter is proud to mark World Press Freedom Day
column9: an annual reminder of our shared responsibility to support and advocate for a free press around the world.\u00c2\u00a0\nAs journalists continue to selflessly report from the front lines of conflicts
column10: in the face of hostile interests
column11: and
column12: especially during this past year
column13: risk their personal health to cover a global pandemic
column14: we believe it is pivotal that they and their industry are supported.\nTo that end
column15: Twitter is launching a campaign to spotlight
column16: elevate and support local journalism \u00e2\u0080\u0094 which is a vital resource for communities around the world
column17: especially now for people seeking COVID-19 information.\nBelow we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve outlined what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re doing
column18: and how you can get involved:\n#FollowLocalJournalists on Twitter\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve organized a global day of action on Twitter on May 3rd centered around the hashtag #FollowLocalJournalists. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re encouraging everyone \u00e2\u0080\u0094 prominent national reporters
column19: journalism advocacy organizations
column20: and everyday passionate news consumers \u00e2\u0080\u0094 to share impactful examples of local journalism and elevate the reporters who contributed to it. The goal is to spotlight these reporters\u00e2\u0080\u0099 work and increase their audience.\nLocal Newspaper Ad Campaign\nTwitter is running an ad campaign in 28 local newspapers across the United States
column21: including The Detroit Free Press
column22: The Des Moines Register
column23: The Miami Herald
column24: and The Kansas City Star to support these outlets and amplify the #FollowLocalJournalists initiative. The ads
column25: which will run in print and online
column26:
will direct readers to Twitter Lists of journalists created by each newspaper and by Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tune in on Spaces
Twitter has organized Twitter Spaces around the world where people will be able to hear directly from journalists about the issues facing their industry
column27: including:\nIn the Philippines
column28: journalists from Rappler will host a Space focused on the idea that \u00e2\u0080\u009cWhen journalists can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t ask
column29: we can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t act.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nIn Myanmar
column30: the @ViceWorldNews team based across Southeast Asia will bring a group of Burmese journalists together to talk about #whatshappeninginmyanmar in the aftermath of the bloody coup there
column31: and how so many journalists are risking their lives and freedom to tell this story.\nIn India
column32: with journalists reporting from the frontlines of the ongoing COVID-19 crisis
column33: newsrooms are facing incredible challenges. To discuss the impact of this crisis on the media
column34: Twitter is hosting a Space for senior editors from across the country (Delhi
column35: Bengaluru
column36: Mumbai and Guwahati) in conversation with the Twitter India news team.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn Japan
column37: @TwitterNewsJP is hosting two Spaces with journalists to discuss ways to support the needs of local news outlets
column38: and the state of journalism nationally.\nIn Thailand
column39: Sutichai Yoon is hosting a Space with local journalists to discuss what inspires and challenges them and how social media has impacted their work.\nIn Brazil
column40: @Abraji and @RSF_pt is hosting a Space with five local journalism organizations focused on the state of journalism in Brazil.\nPartnership with UNESCO and NGOs working on protecting journalists\nTwitter has also continued our partnership with UNESCO this year to help drive conversation around World Press Freedom Day. We were proud to attend Asia Pacific Regional Consultation for World Press Freedom Day 2021 to discuss our commitment to a free press
column41: and join UNESCO and global experts to discuss the role of technology in promoting media and information literacy. Together
column42: we also launched Twitter emojis for the hashtags #FollowLocalJournalists
column43: #WorldPressFreedomDay
column44: #PressFreedom and #WPFD2021 in 20 languages.\nAdditionally
column45: as a part of our commitment to freedom of expression and an open internet
column46: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve provided trainings and Ads for good grants to non-profit organizations such as Committee to Protect Journalists
column47: Reporters sans fronti\u00c3\u00a8re
column48: Philippine Center for Investigative Journalism
column49: National Union of Journalists of the Philippines
column50: Engage Media
column51:
and PEN America.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Throughout the year
column52: #FollowLocalJournalists will be the theme of @TwitterNews\u00e2\u0080\u0099 events
column53: trainings and advocacy work. Our commitment to strengthening and supporting a free press is year-round
column54:
so please follow @TwitterNews for updates on initiatives that support local journalism.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet

column3: "title": "Introducing our Responsible Machine Learning Initiative  "
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Introducing our Responsible Machine Learning Initiative  
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 14 April 2021\nLink copied successfully\nThe journey to responsible
column9: responsive
column10: and community-driven machine learning (ML) systems is a collaborative one. Today
column11: we want to share more about the work we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been doing to improve our ML algorithms within Twitter
column12:
and our path forward through a company-wide initiative called Responsible ML. 
Responsible ML consists of the following pillars:
Taking responsibility for our algorithmic decisions
Equity and fairness of outcomes
Transparency about our decisions and how we arrived at them
Enabling agency and algorithmic choice
Responsible technological use includes studying the effects it can have over time. When Twitter uses ML
column13: it can impact hundreds of millions of Tweets per day and sometimes
column14: the way a system was designed to help could start to behave differently than was intended. These subtle shifts can then start to impact the people using Twitter and we want to make sure we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re studying those changes and using them to build a better product.\u00c2\u00a0\nWho\u00e2\u0080\u0099s involved and the actions we're taking\nTechnical solutions alone do not resolve the potential harmful effects of algorithmic decisions. Our Responsible ML working group is interdisciplinary and is made up of people from across the company
column15: including technical
column16: research
column17: trust and safety
column18: and product teams.\u00c2\u00a0\nLeading this work is our ML Ethics
column19: Transparency and Accountability (META) team: a dedicated group of engineers
column20: researchers
column21:
and data scientists collaborating across the company to assess downstream or current unintentional harms in the algorithms we use and to help Twitter prioritize which issues to tackle first.
Hereâs how weâre approaching this initiative:
Researching and understanding the impact of ML decisions. Weâre conducting in-depth analysis and studies to assess the existence of potential harms in the algorithms we use. Here are some analyses you will have access to in the upcoming months:
A gender and racial bias analysis of our image cropping (saliency) algorithm
A fairness assessment of our Home timeline recommendations across racial subgroups
An analysis of content recommendations for different political ideologies across seven countriesÂ 
Applying our learnings to improve Twitter. The most impactful applications of responsible ML will come from how we apply our learnings to build a better Twitter. The META team works to study how our systems work and uses those findings to improve the experience people have on Twitter. This may result in changing our product
column22: such as removing an algorithm and giving people more control over the images they Tweet
column23: or in new standards into how we design and build policies when they have an outsized impact on one particular community. The results of this work may not always translate into visible product changes
column24: but it will lead to heightened awareness and important discussions around the way we build and apply ML.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also building explainable ML solutions so you can better understand our algorithms
column25: what informs them
column26: and how they impact what you see on Twitter. Similarly
column27: algorithmic choice will allow people to have more input and control in shaping what they want Twitter to be for them. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re currently in the early stages of exploring this and will share more soon.\nSharing our learnings and asking for feedback. Both inside and outside of Twitter
column28: we will share our learnings and best practices to improve the industry\u00e2\u0080\u0099s collective understanding of this topic
column29: help us improve our approach
column30: and hold us accountable. This may come in the form of peer-reviewed research
column31: data-insights
column32: high-level descriptions of our findings or approaches
column33: and even some of our unsuccessful attempts to address these emerging challenges. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to work closely with third party academic researchers to identify ways we can improve our work and encourage their feedback.\nThe public plays a critical role in shaping Twitter and ResponsibleML is no different. Public feedback is particularly important as we assess the fairness and equity of the automated systems we use. Better
column34: more informed decisions are made when the people who use Twitter are part of the process
column35: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re looking to create more opportunities for people to share their thoughts on how ML is used on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Next?\u00c2\u00a0\nResponsible ML is a long journey in its early days. We want to explore it with a spirit of openness with the goal of contributing positively to the field of technology ethics. If you have any questions about Responsible ML
column36: or the work META\u00e2\u0080\u0099s doing
column37: feel free to ask us using #AskTwitterMETA. If you\u00e2\u0080\u0099d like to help
column38:
join us.Â 
Â

column3: "title": "Establishing Twitter's presence in Africa"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Establishing Twitter's presence in Africa
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 12 April 2021\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s mission is to serve the public conversation
column9: and it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s essential
column10: for the world and for Twitter
column11: to increase the number of people who feel comfortable participating in it. To do this
column12: we need to make it easier for everyone to join in and provide more relevant experiences for people across the world.\nToday
column13: in line with our growth strategy
column14: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to announce that we are now actively building a team in Ghana. To truly serve the public conversation
column15: we must be more immersed in the rich and vibrant communities that drive the conversations taking place every day across the African continent.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe are looking for specialists to join several teams including product
column16: design
column17: engineering
column18: marketing and communications. Full details on current job openings can be found on the Twitter Careers site. Aligned with our existing WFH policies
column19: we look forward to welcoming and onboarding our new team members remotely so that we can make an immediate impact while we explore the opportunity to open an office in Ghana in the future.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhy Ghana?\nAs a champion for democracy
column20: Ghana is a supporter of free speech
column21: online freedom
column22: and the Open Internet
column23: of which Twitter is also an advocate. Furthermore
column24: Ghana\u00e2\u0080\u0099s recent appointment to host The Secretariat of the African Continental Free Trade Area aligns with our overarching goal to establish a presence in the region that will support our efforts to improve and tailor our service across Africa.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhenever we enter new markets
column25: we work hard to ensure that we are not just investing in the talent that we hire
column26: but also investing in local communities and the social fabric that supports them. We have already laid foundations through partnerships with Amref Health Africa in Kenya
column27: \u00c2\u00a0Afrochella in Ghana
column28: Mentally Aware Nigeria Initiative (MANI) in Nigeria
column29: and The HackLab Foundation in Ghana. As part of our long-term commitment to the region
column30: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to explore compelling ways we can use the positive power of Twitter to strengthen our communities through employee engagement
column31: platform activation
column32: and corporate giving.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe still have much to learn but we are excited to listen
column33: learn
column34: and engage. Public conversation is essential to solving problems
column35: building shared ideas
column36:
and pushing us all forward together. We canât wait for the next step on that journey.

column3: "title": "5 alternative food trends to add to your plate"
column7:
"post_text": "5 alternative food trends to add to your plate
                By
                
  
  
              
                and
                
  
  
Saturday
column8: 10 April 2021\nLink copied successfully\nYou can always count on food to bring people together. And Twitter is the place where people go to talk about their passions and interests
column9: especially when it comes to good eats.\nWe teamed up with Brandwatch
column10: a pioneering digital consumer intelligence company
column11: to uncover top consumer trends around food alternatives by looking at share of voice. To do this
column12:
Brandwatch observed a random smaller sample (33%) of the overall conversation on Twitter from 2019 to 2020.Â  Read on for the top consumer trends theyâre picking up around food alternatives.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
01 #TrendyDiets
As veganism and vegetarianism continue to dominate online conversations
column13: two trends within these categories have surfaced: eating for awareness and eating for a higher purpose. These purpose-driven trends are priming consumers to look for ways they can take responsibility for the impact of their food choices.\nEating for awareness is seen in popular trends like Veganuary
column14: which encouraged people to commit to veganism for the month of January. And considering everyone loves a good challenge
column15: Veganuary commanded attention.\nEating for a higher purpose cropped up throughout popular discussions on Twitter
column16:
as users challenged each other to think beyond the individual by choosing a vegan diet to help reduce our carbon footprint.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
02 #MindfulMilk
Alternative options for milk are extremely popular and include a wide range of choices for consumers. But what about them is driving interest?
To a large extent
column17: the discussions around dairy alternatives have a lot to do with sustainability \u00e2\u0080\u0093 but not in the way you might expect. In fact
column18: conversations have surfaced environmental concerns within the alternatives themselves
column19: revealing both interest and debate.\nIn that context
column20: one milk alternative has pulled away from the pack. Oat milk saw the largest growth in online discussions (an increase of 66% YoY). Meanwhile
column21: other milk alternatives have maintained some relevance
column22:
gaining traction in commentary around hugely popular recipes like overnight oats.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
03 #MeatlessMeat
When it comes to choices around meat substitutions
column23: trends like #MeatlessMondays are leaving plenty on the bone.\u00c2\u00a0 Consumers can now enjoy a variety of meat alternatives while enjoying favorite snacks like jerky
column24: crisps
column25: and more. In fact
column26: popular meat-free ingredients like tofu
column27: jackfruit
column28: seitan
column29: tempeh
column30: and pea protein have even made their way into beloved desserts like brownies. Pea protein in particular has seen a 42% increase YoY in its share of voice.\nAnd as meatless meal options are proliferating
column31: they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also speeding up\u00e2\u0080\u0094which is to say that fast food outlets are talking up their own branded meat alternatives
column32:
offering new vegan and vegetarian options to mainstream markets.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
04 #SuperFoodsÂ 
Superfoods are healthy ingredients packed with vitamins
column33: minerals
column34: and plenty to talk about on Twitter. Everyone already loves avocados
column35: a superfood powerhouse
column36: which is now almost an essential ingredient to premium salads
column37: tacos
column38: and (of course) toast.\u00c2\u00a0 Blueberries were often included in conversations surrounding cakes
column39: oatmeals
column40: and pancakes. Meanwhile
column41: \u00c2\u00a0 ginger
column42: kale
column43: chia
column44: matcha
column45: and acai berries were mentioned around juicing.\nIn short
column46: superfoods have shown supergrowth. Take flax
column47: for example
column48:
whose share of voice has seen an increase of 991% year over year! Other options like matcha have grown by 74% compared to last year.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
05 #CrunchyCravings
No food discussion would be complete without a bag of chips
column49: and chips are seeing a rise in popularity too.\nVegetable and legume-based crisps like lentils
column50: kale
column51: and sweet potato have some major buzz. Air fryers are currently in the spotlight
column52: which are becoming known for their ability to make delicious kale chips. Their overall share of voice went up 24% year over year.\nThe benefits of rice crackers have become a popular topic too
column53:
with a share of voice that went up 19% year over year.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Food brings people together and so does Twitter. Like a good meal
column54: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a space for passion
column55: where people get to the heart of what matters. With Brandwatch Consumer Research
column56: we can learn from the conversation to better inform products
column57: launches
column58: and more
column59: giving brands and marketers an edge.\nTo learn more
column60:
head to partners.twitter.com to download the full trend report.

column3: "title": "Introducing Twitter\u2019s Global Impact Report"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Introducing Twitterâs Global Impact Report
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 7 April 2021\nLink copied successfully\nToday
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to share our first Global Impact Report
column10: a cohesive representation of the work we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve done across environment
column11: social
column12: and governance issues since Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s founding in 2006.\nNow more than ever
column13: building trust through transparency and accountability is key to delivering on our purpose of serving the public conversation. Over the years
column14: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been open about our work and where we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re making an impact - from our quarterly I&D Reports that highlight our commitments to inclusion and diversity
column15: to our Transparency Reports which reflect our work to protect the integrity of the conversation on Twitter.\nThis report aims to bring these and other initiatives together in one place
column16: showcasing Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s work across corporate responsibility
column17: sustainability
column18: and philanthropy. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a big step in our commitment to sharing more about the work we know is important to the people we serve - from our employees
column19: or Tweeps
column20: to partners
column21: investors and the people around the world who use Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nFor our 2020 report
column22: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve organized our work into five key areas:\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nOur service: Earning trust is one of our core operating principles
column23: and it begins with how we act. We want people to have safe
column24: inclusive and authentic conversations on Twitter
column25: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re working to promote healthy conversations on our service while continuing to grow our audience and our business in socially responsible ways.\nGovernance: We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to sound corporate governance
column26: strong ethics and compliance practices
column27: which promote the long-term interests of the diverse communities we serve and help build public trust in Twitter.\nPeople and culture: We often say that\u00e2\u0080\u008b Tweeps come for the purpose and stay for the people
column28: along with the unique experience and knowledge gained from working at Twitter. This includes building a company and culture that reflects the incredibly vibrant and diverse conversations happening on our service every day.\nTwitter for Good: Strengthening our communities is core to our social impact philosophy. Our goal is to bring our company and community together as a positive societal force around the world.\nPlanet: Climate change is one of the greatest challenges of our time. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to protecting the environment
column29: reducing our carbon footprint
column30: and fostering long-term sustainability projects to play our part.\nOur hope is that by presenting and organizing our work in this way
column31:
weâll be able to clearly showcase what weâve done and provide a roadmap of where weâre headed.Â Â  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
PDF
2020 Global Impact Report
View our full report
Download
Whatâs next
Weâve made an impact - both as a company and as a service supporting the public conversation. While our work is not done
column32: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re confident that our progress and our clarity of purpose position us well to continue making an impact and improving the health of the public conversation. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to make progress on these important initiatives and share more about our efforts in the future.\nIn the meantime
column33: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll keep listening to your ideas and feedback. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re grateful to our dedicated employees
column34: our extraordinary NGO partners
column35: and the diverse communities around the world that we serve. We will make Twitter and the world stronger
column36:
together.Â

column3: "title": "Survey fatigue is real
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/insights/2021/survey-fatigue-is-real-insight-from-twitter-can-help"
column8: "post_text": "Insights\nSurvey fatigue is real
column9:
insight from Twitter can help
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column10: 31 March 2021\nLink copied successfully\n\"Survey finds 95% of people don't like taking surveys
column11: \" could be the headline of your favourite satirical website
column12: which wouldn't be far from the truth. Overwhelmed by the increasing number of requests for feedback
column13: consumers are avoiding surveys all together which is impacting response rates. The telephone survey
column14: for example
column15: has seen a steep decline in response rates since the mid-90s
column16: dropping from 36% in 1997 to just 6% in 2018
column17: according to Pew Research1. Of course
column18: many variables are at play when it comes to response rates across different types of surveys
column19: but the reality is that survey fatigue is real and it impacts both the volume and quality of feedback received. The insight they provide is also limited to the questions asked. So
column20:
is there another way?
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
I recently ran an experiment to understand if insights from Tweets could answer many of the same questions that customer surveys commonly ask. To do this I chose a consumer-focused industryâ âairline travelâ âand focused on a specific carrier (who shall remain anonymous). Given the disruption to the industry brought on by COVID-19
column21: I chose to analyse the month of January 2020
column22: as this was one of the last few months of unaffected travel. \nIn January 2020 alone
column23: the airline was mentioned 70
column24: 000 times on Twitter which provided a large amount of content to sift through. In particular
column25: I was looking for Tweets from travellers sharing their preflight
column26: inflight and postflight experiences and was guided by the topics that bubbled to the surface organically. Here are some examples of what I found:\nPreflight Experience\nCheck-in: 567 mentions including app check-in
column27: visa checks and bag drop\nLounge: 443 mentions including food quality
column28:
shower cleanliness and staffing
Boarding: 223 mentions including express boarding and shuttle buses
Inflight Experience
WiFi: 34 mentions of connectivity issues or lack of service
Entertainment system: 27 mentions of small or dirty video screens
Food quality: 372 mentions including lack of vegan options
column29: pricing and selection\nPostflight Experience\nBaggage collection: 374 mentions including delayed
column30:
lost and damaged baggage
Loyalty program: 438 mentions of air mile collection and usage policies
Compensation claims: 131 mentions of confusing rules
These comments alone constituted nearly 2
column31: 600 pieces of customer feedback covering the entire customer journey\u00e2\u0081\u00a0\u00e2\u0080\u0094insights that the airline could potentially use to improve the experience for all passengers. Crucially
column32:
they uncovered specific pieces of feedback that might not normally be surfaced by surveys due to the limitations of the questions asked. For example:
Departures check-in: One person lamented that her elderly parent struggled to follow the prompts on the check-in kiosks.
Onboard WiFi purchase: One traveller asked why there was no pay-as-you-go option.
Onboard electrical plugs: Several travellers mentioned the placement and number of electrical plugs and some even provided suggestions on where they should be placed.
Meal choices: Several passengers expressed their annoyance that gluten-free meal options had to be pre-ordered.
This analysis did not attempt to create a representative sample of customer views nor to draw any type of causal relationship between these comments and overall satisfaction with the airline. I simply set out to prove that the breadth and depth of conversations happening on Twitter can provide a real-time voice of the customer at every touchpoint in the customer journey.
The findings suggest that insights from Twitter can indeed shed light on many facets of the customer experience
column33: providing a unique window into real observed human behaviours with several advantages over traditional insight gathering techniques.\nFirst
column34: the unsolicited nature of Twitter feedback circumvents one of the biggest challenges of research\u00e2\u0080\u0094the introduction of bias by the questions being asked. Secondly
column35: as Tweets are sent at the moment people are actually having the experience
column36: they tend to be more emotive as a result and represent a more authentic view of a customer\u00e2\u0080\u0099s true feelings. This is much different than being asked to recount your experience with the onboard WiFi a few days later via an email prompted survey. At that point
column37: the moment is gone and you might not even bother to respond. This strength of social data should not be underestimated
column38: for very little market research delivered today is conducted with the context in mind.\nAnd finally
column39: the open
column40: continuous nature of Twitter allows you to see trends emerge over time and benchmark yourself against your competitors. It also has the advantage of allowing you to go back and analyze a topic retrospectively
column41: uncovering feedback preserved in time
column42: forever.\nCustomer experience measurement has come a long way over the past few years as new technologies and techniques have emerged to ascertain consumers\u00e2\u0080\u0099 true feelings. The reality is that it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not just one approach that will provide the insight organizations need but rather a combination of many
column43: used at the right time and leveraging their respective data gathering strengths. Insights from Twitter won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t fully replace surveys
column44: but they can complement them
column45:
providing context to common metrics such as NPS while helping to focus the questions you do want to ask of your customers. Perhaps Twitterâs greatest strength then is in providing answers to the questions you didnât even think to ask.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Interested to learn more about how Twitter can support your customer feedback initiatives? Get started at data.twitter.com.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
1. âResponse rates to telephone public opinion polls.â Pew Research Center
column46: Washington
column47: D.C. (February 27
column48:
2019)Â https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2019/02/27/response-rates-in-telephone-surveys-have-resumed-their-decline/
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet

column3: "title": "An update on Twitter in Turkey"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
An update on Twitter in Turkey
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 19 March 2021\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s mission is to serve the public conversation and ensure the service is a place where people can connect
column9: find credible information
column10: and express themselves \u00e2\u0080\u0093 anywhere in the world.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe are committed to protecting and defending the Open Internet
column11: and as part of this work
column12: have called for the establishment of regional and global standards for online services. We believe that global and not fragmented frameworks protect online communities and their rights
column13: and ensure they can experience the Internet in the same way across the world. Additionally
column14: in an open
column15: competitive environment
column16: smaller companies are not only able to operate alongside the very largest companies
column17: but can thrive.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn our continuing effort to provide our service in Turkey
column18: we have closely reviewed the recently amended Internet Law No. 5651. To ensure that Twitter remains available for all who use it in Turkey
column19: we have decided to establish a legal entity.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn coming to this decision
column20: we were guided by our core mission: defending open
column21: public conversation and ensuring our service is available to people everywhere.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe remain committed to protecting the voices and data of people in Turkey who use Twitter. We will continue to be transparent about how we handle requests from government and law enforcement.\u00c2\u00a0\nTwitter was founded on freedom of expression
column22: and we respect people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s universal right to express their views online. We have a designated human rights function at Twitter and hold our processes
column23: product
column24: and policies accountable \u00e2\u0080\u0094 we have and will
column25: as always
column26: enforce our rules impartially and judiciously.\nWe will continue to work to protect the public conversation in Turkey
column27: empowering people to have access to that conversation
column28:
and advocating for our values.Â

column3: "title": "Calling for public input on our approach to world leaders"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nCalling for public input on our approach to world leaders\nThursday
column8: 18 March 2021\nLink copied successfully\nWe first explained how we define the public interest on Twitter
column9: as well as our principles and approach to world leaders on our service in 2019.\nPoliticians and government officials are constantly evolving how they use our service
column10: and we want our policies to remain relevant to the ever-changing nature of political discourse on Twitter and protect the health of the public conversation. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re reviewing our approach to world leaders and seeking your input.\u00c2\u00a0\nGenerally
column11: we want to hear from the public on whether or not they believe world leaders should be subject to the same rules as others on Twitter. And
column12: should a world leader violate a rule
column13: what type of enforcement action is appropriate.\nStarting on March 19
column14: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be calling for responses to a public survey that will help inform the development of our policy framework. The questionnaire will be available in the coming days in 14 languages:\nArabic\nChinese (Simplified
column15:
Traditional)
English
Farsi
Filipino
French
Hindi
Indonesian
Japanese
Korean
Portuguese
Russian
Spanish
Urdu
This is to ensure a global perspective is reflected in the feedback and mirrors the approach we've taken with previous public surveys. The survey will close on Monday
column16: April 12 at 5 p.m. PT. \nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also in the process of consulting with a range of human rights experts
column17: civil society organizations
column18: and academics worldwide whose feedback will be reflected in forthcoming revisions to the policy framework.\nWe want to serve the public conversation and allow the public to hear from and engage with leaders around the world. Ultimately
column19:
our aim is to have a policy that appropriately balances fundamental human rights and considers the global context in which we operate.Â 
We welcome your feedback and will keep you updated.Â

column3: "title": "Advancing our efforts to make Twitter a safer place for advertisers"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Advancing our efforts to make Twitter a safer place for advertisers
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 9 March 2021\nLink copied successfully\nWe are continuing on our path to learn
column9: iterate and expand our efforts specific to brand safety.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn December 2020
column10: we shared a few priority areas for us in 2021 - including continuing to partner with industry leaders and developing innovative solutions for our customers to feel confident in being a part of the conversation on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nSince then
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been hard at work building out third-party brand safety measurement solutions in partnership with DoubleVerify and Integral Ad Science
column12: and continue on our path towards MRC accreditation. In parallel
column13: we have also been focused on attaining another global brand safety accreditation
column14:
and on providing advertisers with more control over the conversations they start on Twitter. We are excited to share two updates on this front:Â 
Twitter receives global Brand Safety certification through TAG
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâre excited to share that Twitter has successfully earned the Trustworthy Accountability Group (TAG) Brand Safety Certified Seal
column15: which covers Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s global operations*.\nTAG is a leading global certification program fighting criminal activity and increasing trust in the digital advertising industry. TAG advances its mission of eliminating fraudulent traffic
column16: facilitating the sharing of threat intelligence and promoting brand safety by connecting industry leaders
column17: analyzing threats and sharing best practices worldwide.\u00c2\u00a0\nThe TAG Brand Safety Certified program sets global brand safety standards that apply to digital advertising agreements
column18: monetized content takedown practices
column19: the use of inclusion/exclusion lists
column20: and the documentation of specific policies and procedures used to minimize the risk of ad misplacement. These standards impact direct buyers
column21: direct sellers and intermediaries. This certification affords advertisers and agencies the assurance that Twitter has been independently audited to ensure compliance with TAG\u00e2\u0080\u0099s guidelines. Our partnership with TAG supplements our ongoing work with the MRC
column22: and further reinforces our commitment to independent brand safety accreditation. Learn more about program requirements here.\nTwitter earned its first brand safety accreditation in 2019
column23: when Twitter UK became certified through JICWEBS\u00e2\u0080\u0099 DTSG Good Practice Principles. Last September
column24: JICWEBS merged with TAG in order to create a global certification for brand safety
column25: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been actively working with TAG over the past several months to extend Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s TAG Brand Safety Certification to cover our global operations. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re proud to have been among the first companies to attain TAG\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Brand Safety Certification
column26:
and weâre proud to expand that certification globally today.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In our global ad supply chain
column27:
threats to brand safety can extend across oceans and borders. By achieving the TAG Brand Safety Certified Seal for its global operations. Twitter is helping lead the industry in tackling those complicated global challenges. We look forward to continuing to work closely with Twitter to raise the bar on brand safety across our industry.
Mike Zaneis
CEO of TAG
Introducing Conversation Settings for advertisersÂ 
Twitter is whatâs happening and itâs the best place to have conversations with the people that matter most to brands
column28: but we know that sometimes advertisers may need more control over the conversations they have with their customers. That is why we have made it easier for brands to curate their conversations with the introduction of conversation settings for ads.\nIn August 2020
column29: we made new conversation settings available to everyone on Twitter
column30: allowing people to have more control over the conversations they start. Now
column31: we are making these capabilities available to all advertisers when they compose Tweets directly through Tweet Composer or through our Ads API. This update will extend the ability to apply conversation settings to Promoted-only Tweets and to those that use our most popular ad formats
column32: in addition to organic Tweets. You can learn more about how this works here.\nWe are committed to continuing the work on our ongoing brand safety efforts
column33: and will continue to lead with policy
column34: protect with product
column35: and drive industry-wide change through partnerships. We look forward to sharing more updates as we move along.\u00c2\u00a0\n\u00c2\u00a0\n*Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s policies and procedures for minimizing ad misplacement were independently audited and deemed compliant with the TAG Certified for Brand Safety Guidelines Version 1.0. Twitter was validated as a Direct Seller and Intermediary (Consumer Facing Platform)
column36: and these procedures were validated globally. The audit did not include processes for Twitter Audience Platform or MoPub
column37:
which were excluded from the audit.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": " Updates to our work on COVID-19 vaccine misinformation "
column7: "post_text": "Company\n Updates to our work on COVID-19 vaccine misinformation \nMonday
column8: 1 March 2021\nLink copied successfully\nEffective November 23
column10:
Twitter is no longer enforcing the COVID-19 misleading information policy.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As the distribution of COVID-19 vaccines expands
column11: people continue to turn to Twitter to discuss what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening and find the latest authoritative public health information.\nIn December
column12: we shared updates on our work to protect the public conversation surrounding COVID-19. Starting today
column13: we will begin applying labels to Tweets that may contain misleading information about COVID-19 vaccines
column14: in addition to our continued efforts to remove the most harmful COVID-19 misleading information from the service. Since introducing our COVID-19 guidance
column15: we have removed more than 8
column16: 400 Tweets and challenged 11.5 million accounts worldwide.\nWe are also introducing a strike system that determines when further enforcement action is necessary. We believe the strike system will help to educate the public on our policies and further reduce the spread of potentially harmful and misleading information on Twitter
column17:
particularly for repeated moderate and high-severity violations of our rules.Â 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Example of COVID-19 misinformation label 
          
          
        
Enforcement details:Â 
Labels will first be applied by our team members when they determine content violates our policy. Those assessments will be used to further inform our automated tools and to advance our proactive capacity to identify and label similar content across the service. Our goal is to eventually use both automated and human review to address content that violates our COVID-19 vaccine misinformation rules. Machine-learning and automated language processing takes time to be effective. As such
column18: we will begin with English-language content first and use this same process as we work to expand to other languages and cultural contexts over time.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nLabels will appear in your set display language and may link to curated content and official public health information or the Twitter Rules. Our goal with these product interventions is to provide people with additional context and authoritative information about COVID-19.\nThrough the use of the strike system
column19:
we hope to educate people on why certain content breaks our rules so they have the opportunity to further consider their behavior and their impact on the public conversation. This strike system is similar to our recent update to the Civic Integrity Policy. Individuals will be notified directly when a label or required Tweet removal results in additional account-level enforcement. Repeated violations of the COVID-19 policy are enforced against on the basis of the number of strikes an account has accrued for violations of the policy.
One strike: no account-level action
Two strikes: 12-hour account lock
Three strikes: 12-hour account lock 
Four strikes: 7-day account lock 
Five or more strikes: permanent suspension
As always
column20: if you believe that your account was locked or suspended in error
column21:
you can submit an appeal.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Example of COVID-19 misinformation label with engagements limited 
          
          
        
Partnerships:
We are not only focused on enforcing the Twitter Rules
column22: but also helping people find credible health information and partnering with the experts. We continue to work in close consultation with local
column23: national
column24: and global public health authorities around the world
column25: most recently:\u00c2\u00a0\nFinding reliable information.\u00c2\u00a0Since January 2020
column26: we have had a dedicated COVID-19 search prompt feature in place within the product. This means when someone searches for COVID-19
column27: they are met with credible
column28: authoritative content at the very top of their search experience. This has been expanded to over 80 countries worldwide and is currently available in 29 languages. In some countries the prompts now also include an additional button which links to COVID-19 vaccine specific information.\nPro bono advertising.\u00c2\u00a0Through our Ads for Good grants
column29: we continue to partner with nonprofits and NGOs around the world to elevate authoritative information on COVID-19. Throughout the pandemic we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve supported these efforts across more than 35 countries on a pro bono basis. In addition
column30: we have donated premium advertising products
column31: including Promoted Trend and\u00c2\u00a0First View\u00c2\u00a0products
column32: to elevate critical public health information such as @FEMA\u00e2\u0080\u0099s message about the agency's vaccination efforts and emergency relief locations during winter storms.\nGlobal cooperation.\u00c2\u00a0In February 2021
column33: we participated in a global WHO policy consultation to present Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s views on finding and implementing \u00e2\u0080\u009cinnovative ways and best practices to address health misinformation in the social media sector.\u00e2\u0080\u009d We continue to host a weekly live Q&A\u00c2\u00a0event page\u00c2\u00a0for the WHO at #AskWHO. \nAddressing public questions on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0This month
column34: we facilitated a\u00c2\u00a0Twitter Q&A\u00c2\u00a0from\u00c2\u00a0@WHCOVIDResponse. The Q&A\u00c2\u00a0featured\u00c2\u00a0Dr. Anthony Fauci
column35: US President Biden\u00e2\u0080\u0099s chief medical advisor
column36: and other members of the White House COVID-19 response team. In India
column37: we worked with the Ministry of Health to organize Vaccine Vartha
column38: a weekly expert talk hosted on Twitter that enables vaccine experts to answer citizen questions.\u00c2\u00a0\nEncouraging healthy conversation.\u00c2\u00a0In January
column39: in partnership with\u00c2\u00a0Team Halo
column40: \u00c2\u00a0UNICEF
column41: \u00c2\u00a0NHS
column42: and\u00c2\u00a0the Vaccine Confidence Project
column43: we activated an emoji hashtag #vaccinated to show support for vaccination. This builds upon our earlier efforts to encourage people to\u00c2\u00a0#StayHome
column44: #WashHands
column45: and #WearAMask.\nAs health authorities deepen their understanding of COVID-19 and vaccination programs around the world
column46: we will continue to amplify the most current
column47: up-to-date
column48: and authoritative information. We are all in this together
column49:
and we will continue to update you on our progress as we strive to play our part to protect the public conversation at this critical time.
Â

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Disclosing networks of state-linked information operations "
column7: "post_text": "Company\nDisclosing networks of state-linked information operations \nTuesday
column8: 23 February 2021\nLink copied successfully\nToday we are disclosing four networks of accounts to our archive of state-linked information operations; the only archive of its kind in the industry. The networks we are disclosing relate to independent
column9: state-affiliated information operations that we have attributed to Armenia
column10: Russia and a previously disclosed network from Iran.\nOnce our investigations were complete
column11: the 373 associated accounts across the four networks were permanently suspended from Twitter for violations of our platform manipulation policies. As with previous disclosures
column12: we shared early access to the data we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re releasing today with the Stanford Internet Observatory for independent investigation and analysis.\u00c2\u00a0\nIran\nAs we proactively communicated in October 2020
column13: and based on information provided to us by the FBI
column14:
we removed approximately 130 accounts originating in Iran that were attempting to disrupt the public conversation during the first 2020 US Presidential Debate.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
After the final investigation was complete
column15: we have suspended a total of 238 accounts operating from Iran for various violations of our platform manipulation policies. As previously stated
column16: the accounts had low engagement and did not make an impact on the public conversation. Today
column17: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re adding these accounts to the archive to empower independent research and analysis.\u00c2\u00a0 \nArmenia\u00c2\u00a0\nUnder our platform manipulation policy
column18: we investigated and removed 35 accounts that had ties to the Government of Armenia. These accounts were created in order to advance narratives that were targeting Azerbaijan and were geostrategically favorable to the Armenian government. In some cases
column19: the fake accounts purported to represent government and political figures in Azerbaijan
column20:
as well as news entities claiming to operate in Azerbaijan. The accounts engaged in spammy activity to gain followers and further amplify this narrative.
Russia 
Today weâre disclosing two separate networks that have Russian ties.
1.Â Our first investigation found and removed a network of 69 fake accounts that can be reliably tied to Russian state actors. A number of these accounts amplified narratives that were aligned with the Russian government
column21: while another subset of the network focused on undermining faith in the NATO alliance and its stability.\n2.\u00c2\u00a0As part of our second investigation in this region
column22: we removed 31 accounts from two networks that show signs of being affiliated with the Internet Research Agency (IRA) and Russian government-linked actors. These accounts amplified narratives that had been previously associated with the IRA and other Russian influence efforts targeting the United States and European Union.\nOur work in this area\u00c2\u00a0\nWith every disclosure we make
column23: we want to continue to educate people on the tactics used by state actors in order to manipulate or undermine the open democratic conversation that happens on Twitter. Since we launched our first archive in October 2018
column24: we have disclosed data related to more than 85
column25: 000 accounts associated with platform manipulation campaigns originating from 20 countries
column26: to our information operations archive.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe believe we have a responsibility to protect the integrity of the public conversation and to offer transparency on our findings.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur partnerships in this area are key to the work we undertake and we will continue to keep our archive updated so the public
column27: journalists
column28:
and the research community can access and analyze these networks.Â 
Keep on top of regular updates from us over at @TwitterSafety.

column3: "title": "Allyship right now: #StandForAsians"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Allyship right now: #StandForAsians
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 17 February 2021\nLink copied successfully\nAs anti-Asian racism and xenophobia continue to grow
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen an increase in attacks against Asian communities and individuals around the world. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important to know that this isn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t new; throughout history
column10: Asians have experienced violence and exclusion. However
column11:
their diverse lived experiences have largely been overlooked.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We also cannot forget historical efforts to create rifts â often perpetuated by the model minority myth â between Asian and Black communities. The time for allyship is long overdue. The time for allyship is now.Â Â 
At Twitter
column12:
our principles of allyship are straightforward:Â 
Learn
Ask
Show up
Speak up
Hereâs how you can practice allyship right now:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Learn
Do your research to understand what Asian communities have faced and are facing right now â at home
column13:
and around the world. Hereâs just a few resources to check out:
Twitter thread aboutÂ recent and historical anti-Asian violence
News coverage on The Cut aboutÂ rising anti-Asian hate crimes in the US
A Washington Post article on theÂ history of anti-Asian xenophobia
Michelle Kimâs Medium blog postÂ detailing historical context of the Model Minority Myth to today
A short from AJ+Â video on Why We Call Asian Americans the Model Minority
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Ask
Check in on your folks. Approach questions with empathy and curiosity as a way to understand peopleâs lived experiences. Do not approach asking questions from a place of disbelief. Especially as a leader or a manager
column14: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important to create the space for people on your team who may be experiencing fear
column15: anger
column16:
or anxiety. 
Questions you can ask:
Do you feel comfortable sharing your experience with me?
How are you feeling/coping?
How can I help?
When someoneâs sharing their experience with you
column17: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s enough to simply say
column18: \u00e2\u0080\u009cI hear you.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t feel like you need to respond
column19: or provide your own story. Instead
column20: center them
column21:
and listen to what theyâre sharing with you.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Show up
In a time when weâre all social distancing
column22: it may seem difficult to show up physically for your colleagues or community members. Try doing it virtually. Engage with Tweets amplifying Asian voices and experiences
column23: attend virtual events
column24: sign petitions
column25: find and reach out to local Asian community centers
column26:
and ask how you can support.Â 
Here are some accounts you can follow:
Esther Choo: @choo_ek
Jenny Yang: @jennyyangtv
HuffPost Asian Voices: @HPAsianVoices
William Yu: @its_willyu
Karen Han: @karenyhan
Alice Wong: @SFdirewolf
Amanda Nguyen: @nguyen_amanda
Michelle Kim: @mjmichellekim
Act to Change: @ActToChange
Dion Lim: @DionLimTVÂ 
Stop AAPI Hate:Â @StopAAPIHate 
Consider shopping from an Asian-owned businesses. Place orders for food
column27: goods
column28: or even gift cards. Now is the time to show your support for local Asian businesses that have been struggling since the start of the pandemic.\nDonate! If you can
column29: support organizations that are supporting Asian communities. Using a restorative justice and community based approach
column30: Stop AAPI Hate launched in March of last year to track and respond to incidents of hate
column31: violence
column32: harassment
column33: and discrimination against Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders. The Asian American Journalist Association (AAJA)\u00c2\u00a0 works towards the visibility and inclusion of AAPI journalists in newsroom leadership
column34: and towards equitable and accurate coverage of Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders (AAPIs) and AAPI issues. The Chinatown CDC is a community development organization that serves as neighborhood advocates
column35: organizers and planners
column36:
and as developers and managers of affordable housing. And Asian Americans Advancing Justice is an organization dedicated to fighting for civil rights and empowering Asian Americans to create a more just America for all.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Speak up
In meetings
column37: on Twitter
column38: in conference calls
column39: in chats with friends and family
column40:
speak up. Be mindful of misinformation and jokes that are actually offensive and racist. Call out or call in to address harmful behavior.Â Â 
Leverage your voice and privilege to amplify the experiences of Asian communities. Instances of xenophobia arenât isolated incidents â theyâre happening everywhere. Hereâre some examples of how you can use your voice:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Allyship is not about who you are
column41: but about what you do \u00e2\u0080\u0094 daily
column42: and in times of need. Everyone is dealing with a lot these days
column43: but be especially mindful of those who are facing unsafety
column44: violence
column45: and hate because of their identity. There is no better time to stand up for what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s right. Be an ally today
column46: as you may need one tomorrow.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re in this together
column47:
#UntilWeAllBelong.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@TwitterTogether
#UntilWeAllBelong
Tweet
Twitter logo icon

diversity
#UntilWeAllBelong

column3: "title": "Expanding our work to identify state-affiliated accounts"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Expanding our work to identify state-affiliated accounts
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 11 February 2021\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter is where people come to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening and to hear from their governments and government officials. We believe that safety and free expression go hand-in-hand
column9: especially when interacting with these leaders and associated institutions
column10: and adding context to what people see on Twitter helps them have a more informed experience on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn August 2020
column11: we expanded account labels to two additional categories: 1) the accounts of key government officials and 2) accounts belonging to state-affiliated media entities. Included in this initial action were accounts from countries represented in the five permanent members of the UN Security Council.\u00c2\u00a0\nAfter receiving feedback on this initial action from a range of stakeholders \u00e2\u0080\u0094 including civil society
column12: academia
column13: and those who use our service \u00e2\u0080\u0094 on Wednesday
column14: February 17
column15: we will expand these labels to accounts from Group of Seven (G7) countries
column16: and to a majority of countries that Twitter has attributed state-linked information operations to. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll also apply labels to the personal accounts of heads of state for these countries.\nHere is the full phased plan:\nPhase 1 Countries (August 2020) China
column17: France
column18: Russian Federation
column19: United Kingdom
column20: and United States\nPhase 2 Countries (February 17
column21: 2021) Canada
column22: Cuba
column23: Ecuador
column24: Egypt
column25: Germany
column26: Honduras
column27: Indonesia
column28: Iran
column29: Italy
column30: Japan
column31: Saudi Arabia
column32: Serbia
column33: Spain
column34: Thailand
column35: Turkey
column36: and the United Arab Emirates\nWe will add labels to the following categories of Twitter accounts:\nVerified accounts of key government officials
column37: including foreign ministers
column38: institutional entities
column39: ambassadors
column40: official spokespeople
column41: and key diplomatic leaders. At this time
column42: our focus is on senior officials and entities who are the official voice of the state abroad;\nPersonal accounts of heads of state
column43: from phase 1 and phase 2 countries.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also updating the label text to add more specificity to the government account labels by differentiating between individuals and institutions
column44: and expanding labels to the personal accounts of heads of state to give people on Twitter additional context.\u00c2\u00a0\nAs the next phase of this project
column45: we will work to apply additional labels on state-affiliated media accounts over the next several months
column46:
taking an iterative approach to ensure we capture all relevant accounts.
Our principled approach
Our mission is to serve the public conversation and an important part of that work is providing people with context so they can make informed decisions about what they see and how they engage on Twitter. Twitter provides an unmatched way to connect with and directly speak to public officials and representatives.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
How do we define government accounts for these new labels?
Our focus is on senior officials
column47: heads of state
column48: and institutions that are the voice of the nation state abroad
column49: specifically the account categories listed above. We believe this is an important step so that when people see an account discussing geopolitical issues from another country
column50: they have context on its national affiliation
column51:
and are better informed about who they represent. Weâre also focused on those within the respective administrations underneath the head of state that offer its policy perspective abroad.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
To offer even more context to the public
column52: clicking on a label directs people to this article explaining the policy and referring them to the Twitter Transparency Report for additional information.\nNotification and appeals process\u00c2\u00a0\nTwitter notifies accounts when they receive a label
column53: and account owners can communicate with Twitter directly if they have feedback.\nNext steps\nThe immediate next phase will be to apply these labels to state-affiliated media entities of these phase two countries. Beyond this
column54:
we will continue expanding labels to additional countries over time and look forward to providing additional updates as those plans take shape.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet

column3: "title": "#SaferInternetDay 2021: Together for a better Internet"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
#SaferInternetDay 2021: Together for a better Internet
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 9 February 2021\nLink copied successfully\nJust as Safer Internet Day has grown from being a European event in 2004 to being celebrated globally 17 years later
column9: Twitter has also grown and has continued to make the safety of those on the service a priority
column10:
with each year that passes. Today weÂ  join safety partners from over 140 countries to mark #SaferInternetDay2021 and play our part in creating a safer internet for all.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
To celebrate the global conversation around Internet safety
column11: we launched a special emoji that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s activated by using the hashtags #SaferInternetDay\u00c2\u00a0and #SID2021. The emoji helps to unify and strengthen the conversation on Twitter
column12: around Safer Internet Day.\u00c2\u00a0\nThe theme for Safer Internet Day 2021 (@safeinternetday)
column13: \u00e2\u0080\u0098Together for a better Internet\u00e2\u0080\u0099 \u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00c2\u00a0 speaks to a set of beliefs we share as an online service: that the Internet can always be better
column14: that it remains a force for good
column15: and that it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s all of our jobs to make it safe and healthy. We all contribute
column16: we all have our part to play.\nThe safety of Twitter and the health of the public conversation is one of our highest priorities. In the last year
column17: we have made strides in tackling abusive content on our service globally and have seen a 105% increase in accounts actioned by Twitter (locked or suspended for violating the Twitter Rules).\u00c2\u00a0\nThere will always be more to do
column18: but we have made meaningful progress.\u00c2\u00a0\nCOVID-19: Staying safe and informed on Twitter\nAs the world faced the COVID-19 pandemic
column19: people turned to Twitter to discuss what was happening and find the latest authoritative public health information.\nIn March 2020
column20: we launched a COVID-19 misleading information policy to protect the health of the public conversation.Since then
column21: our teams have removed 8
column22: 493 Tweets and our automated systems have challenged 11.5 million accounts which were targeting discussions around COVID-19 with spammy or manipulative behaviors.\nIn order to bring awareness to gender-based violence as cases surged during the so-called \u00e2\u0080\u009cshadow pandemic\u00e2\u0080\u009d
column23: Twitter has supported nonprofit partners globally by providing Ads for Good grants.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn September 2020
column24: around World Suicide Prevention Day
column25: we worked with the International Association for Suicide Prevention to amplify #SuicidePrevention resources with over 20 NGOs globally.\nIn December 2020
column26:
we expanded the COVID-19 misleading information policy to address Tweets that contain potentially harmful misleading information about COVID-19 vaccines.
#ThereIsHelp
Twitter partners with authorities and nonprofit organizations around the world on our #ThereIsHelp notification service. This service provides resources to vulnerable people and encourages them to reach out and get support when people search certain terms on Twitter.Â 
This year we expanded the prompts to several new markets in consultation with global and local partners to ensure that we are sharing the latest and most helpful resources in our #ThereisHelp prompts across the globe. We expanded this service to provide information on gender-based violence in 24 markets and on suicide or self harm in 30 markets.Â Â 
Expaning our policiesÂ 
Throughout 2020
column27: we updated our rules against Hateful Conduct
column28: to prohibit language that dehumanizes people on the basis of age
column29: disability
column30: disease
column31: race
column32: ethnicity
column33: national origin as well as to include abusive language promoting \u00e2\u0080\u009cconversion therapy\u00e2\u0080\u009d targeting individuals or the entire LGBTQ+ community.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe expanded our policies to further protect the civic conversation: Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s goal is to further protect against content that could suppress the vote and help stop the spread of harmful misinformation that could compromise the integrity of an election or other civic process.\nThe work we do in order to make Twitter safer
column34: must be done in collaboration with our safety partners around the world -\u00c2\u00a0 that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why taking part in #SaferInternetDay2021 is key for us. Across the world today and throughout February
column35: we will work with and support our network of safety partners to amplify their guidance
column36: provide Ads for Good grants to elevate their voices and support their campaigns
column37: and collaborate together on helping shape a better Internet. Across 4 continents
column38: we will run safety training
column39: deliver presentations and participate in events to commemorate the day.\nIn Europe
column40: we will be participating in the Safer Internet Day event organised by the European Commission with Better Internet for Kids Youth Ambassadors
column41: and on February 24th we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be running a Youth Summit event to promote a safer internet for all citizens
column42: especially young people
column43: as well as to to empower young people to talk about topics that matter to them.\nAlso in Europe
column44: we have partnered with Maldita.es
column45: an independent and non-profit organization focused on fact-checking techniques
column46: on a week-long course on Twitter
column47: specifically designed to educate young people on becoming critical thinkers and identifying misinformation. The course will be available in English through @maldita_es and will be localized in Spain through their @MalditaEduca. It will also be localized in Germany through @correctiv_org within the next weeks. We provided Ads for good for all partners.\nIn the UK
column48: Safer Internet Day 2021 will be celebrated with the theme
column49: \u00e2\u0080\u009cAn Internet we trust: exploring reliability in the online world\u00e2\u0080\u009d. The Internet has an amazing range of information and opportunities online. This year
column50: in the UK
column51: Safer Internet Day aims to explore how we can separate fact from fiction when online. We have provided Ads for Good to the UK Safer Internet Centre
column52: which is made up of organisations including Childnet International
column53: Internet Watch Foundation and South West Grid for Learning
column54: in order to help support their work toward a better internet for all.\nIn Spain
column55: we have partnered with and provided Ads For Good to PantallasAmigas on the joint campaign with Fundaci\u00c3\u00b3n Mapfre to educate young people on Internet Safety. We will also be participating in the Safer Internet Day event organized by INCIBE
column56: specifically in the session \u00e2\u0080\u009cFavoring safe and positive digital experiences\u00e2\u0080\u009d.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn MENA
column57: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be running an online safety workshop with the UAE TRA Virtual Academy. This partnership is an opportunity to educate the audience on multiple elements of online and Internet safety
column58: ranging from digital footprint controls to media information literacy and security best practices. We also aim to create an open dialogue to discuss the Twitter Rules and provide feedback on our global efforts to create a safer Internet for everyone.\nIn the United States
column59: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve issued #AdsForGood grants to partners across the country to help people thrive in a digital world. Through these investments
column60: we will amplify conversations to educate families
column61: schools
column62: and young people to support their online safety
column63: privacy
column64: and security.\nIn Spanish Speaking LatAm
column65: @TwitterLatam will hold a virtual Twitter for Nonprofits workshop focused on Safety and Security. In this training we will discuss the Twitter Rules and enforcement
column66: reporting channels
column67: tools that people have to control their experience on Twitter
column68: and account security best practices.\nIn Thailand
column69: we will host a virtual panel discussion on Twitter to raise awareness on internet safety and promote media literacy with our NGO partners @HugProjectTH
column70: @EcpatFoundation
column71: and @saidek1387 (Childline Thailand). We provided #AdsForGood for all partners. The session will be moderated by Hug Project. People can Tweet their questions with hashtag #\u00e0\u00b8\u00a7\u00e0\u00b8\u00b1\u00e0\u00b8\u0099\u00e0\u00b8\u0081\u00e0\u00b8\u00b2\u00e0\u00b8\u00a3\u00e0\u00b9\u0083\u00e0\u00b8\u008a\u00e0\u00b9\u0089\u00e0\u00b8\u00ad\u00e0\u00b8\u00b4\u00e0\u00b8\u0099\u00e0\u00b9\u0080\u00e0\u00b8\u0097\u00e0\u00b8\u00ad\u00e0\u00b8\u00a3\u00e0\u00b9\u008c\u00e0\u00b9\u0080\u00e0\u00b8\u0099\u00e0\u00b9\u0087\u00e0\u00b8\u0095\u00e0\u00b8\u0097\u00e0\u00b8\u00b5\u00e0\u00b9\u0088\u00e0\u00b8\u009b\u00e0\u00b8\u00a5\u00e0\u00b8\u00ad\u00e0\u00b8\u0094\u00e0\u00b8\u00a0\u00e0\u00b8\u00b1\u00e0\u00b8\u00a2\u00e0\u00b8\u0082\u00e0\u00b8\u00b6\u00e0\u00b9\u0089\u00e0\u00b8\u0099.\nIn the Philippines
column72: we will host a virtual panel discussion on Twitter together with support on #AdsForGood during #SaferInternetDay to promote safer Internet and better collaboration with @planphilippines
column73: @ECPATPh
column74: @PCWgovph and @unicefphils. The discussion will be moderated by Plan International Philippines and there will be a Q&A session. People can Tweet their questions using hashtag #SID2021.\nIn Singapore
column75: together with the Singapore Media Literacy Council (@MLCSingapore) we will host a conversation on Twitter to discuss the community's role in promoting a safer Internet
column76: and shared digital literacy resources to help keep people safe online. We also conducted a virtual safety workshop for Roses of Peace and its youth ambassadors to talk about safety and security tips for young people.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe are encouraging conversations with a special emoji for the hashtags #SaferInternetDay\u00c2\u00a0and #SID2021
column77: available in eighteen languages to encourage conversations around a safer Internet.\nThroughout 2021
column78: we will continue to support our safety partners
column79: and work to ensure the public conversation on Twitter stays healthy
column80:
open and safe.Â Â 
Check out our continuing updates to promote a safer Twitter at @TwitterSafety and @TwitterSeguro.Â Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
