column3: "title": "Listen here SMBs
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/insights/2021/listen-here-smbs--you-can-t-afford-not-to"
column8: "post_text": "Insights\nListen here SMBs
column9:
you can't afford not to
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column10: 8 February 2021\nLink copied successfully\nThe plight of small businesses makes for grim reading these days. Lockdowns imposed around the world have brought significant pain to the sector and most have struggled to make up revenue shortfalls online. And as we look to vaccinations as the path back to normality
column11: it's unclear how many small businesses will survive that long. A recent McKinsey study found that more than half of the 2
column12: 200 small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) they surveyed across Europe felt their businesses may not survive longer than 12 months. Meanwhile
column13: in the US
column14: 59% of small businesses surveyed in a Goldman Sachs study reported a negative revenue impact from the pandemic. Considering that SMBs employ just under half of the US workforce1 and two-thirds of Europe's2
column15: you quickly see the importance of this sector to the wider economy.\nEven before the pandemic
column16: small businesses in numerous industries were struggling to compete against the industry goliaths
column17: who used their scale
column18: technology and access to capital to muscle into new markets and keep upstarts out of theirs. Incumbency has therefore proven a powerful thing: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s no wonder the rate of new business creation has been in decline for decades and is at its lowest level since the late \u00e2\u0080\u009870s.3 And due to successive waves of mergers
column19: some industries have never been more concentrated. The pandemic could accelerate this consolidation
column20: making it even tougher for small businesses to succeed. \nDavid vs. Goliath \nFaced with these two existential threats
column21: what can small businesses do to compete in what feels like a David vs. Goliath world? From my perspective
column22: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s really all about the customer. In a world where it's increasingly difficult to differentiate on product or service features
column23: price or quality
column24: customer experience is one of the main ways you can stand out in the crowd.\nBy focusing on listening to and understanding your customers you can build loyalty while identifying new opportunities to serve them. How? By listening. Your customers
column25: prospective customers
column26: and competitors are sharing their experiences
column27: feedback and ideas openly on social media every day. And due to its open nature
column28: Twitter is a great place to both connect with your customers and learn more about what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important to them.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0 \nJust about anything and everything is shared on Twitter
column29: from the trendy to the mundane
column30: often answering questions you didn't think to ask. This hints at an important characteristic of Twitter data: unsolicited opinions and feedback shared by consumers in the moment they are actually having that experience. These perspectives are unfiltered
column31: raw and emotional
column32: shedding light on underlying motivations
column33: emerging behaviors and new norms. Surveys can be helpful
column34: but they are guided by the questions asked and it can be a struggle to get people to complete them. Social listening on the other hand allows you to instantly tap into millions of conversations on topics important to your business. We like to think of it as the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s largest focus group. \nHow to get started? \nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s never been easier to tap into the public conversation on Twitter to support your business\u00e2\u0080\u0099s growth. Social media management tools such as Sprout Social
column35: a Twitter Official Partner
column36: make it easy to deliver social customer service and listen to customers for ideas on how to improve your products or services while gathering inspiration for new ones. From the florist to the pharmacist and the retailer to the restaurateur
column37: small businesses of all shapes and sizes can gather insights that help move themselves forward. And as we enter 2021 with the hope of recovery on the horizon
column38: investing in market awareness is a truly wise investment
column39:
which just might help some of the Davids out there take on their Goliaths.
Looking to get inspired? Check out data.twitter.com for case studies that highlight the value of social listening.

          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Sources: 1. https://www.sba.gov/sites/default/files/FAQ_Sept_2012.pdf 2. https://ec.europa.eu/growth/smes_en 3. https://eig.org/dynamism

And itâs been an amazing journey. Hereâs a behind-the-scenes look at how we got hereâ¦

We wanted an art-first approach to our brand identity that encompassed emotion and expression. So rather than build the system up from each component part or build around a specific element
column11:
we embarked upon building a creative design system thatâs intentionally imperfect.
This Tweet is unavailable

Instead of working with some of the larger
column12: more well-known companies
column13: we reached out to @AtelierIrradie in Paris. They had a global perspective
column14: a portfolio of fashion and beauty
column15: and a design aesthetic that we knew was right for what we wanted to do. They were great partners
column16: and captured the attitude
column17: vibe
column18: and energy of Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nExpression and emotion vary depending upon topic
column19: mood
column20: locale
column21:
or simply the tilt of the sun; our system allows for that range. We can turn up or down the expressiveness of the brand based upon the situation or conversation.
The work...
This Tweet is unavailable

...is ripped. Torn. Bold. Digital. Layered. And courageous. It has energy and motion.Â 
Tears are used to reveal information or to focus on something.Â 
Layers and textures represent the constant stream of overlapping and intersecting conversation.Â 
The use of color that POPS conveys humor
column22: intensity
column23: and authenticity.\nAnd we ground everything in our iconic logo
column24: Twitter blue
column25:
AND Tweets.
Because words matter.
This Tweet is unavailable

We worked withÂ @grillitype in Switzerland to develop Chirp
column26: our first-ever proprietary typeface. Chirp strikes the balance between messy and sharp to amplify the fun and irreverence of a Tweet
column27: but can also carry the weight of seriousness when needed.\u00c2\u00a0\nTo get there we blended American Gothic and European Grotesque styles
column28:
adding specific handmade quirks of early woodcut specimens. This gives us a versatile and contemporary family with international sensibilities. Weâre in the process of extending Chirp to languages beyond the Latin alphabet.
This Tweet is unavailable

Finally
column29: the core of our product isn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t changing
column30:
weâre just changing how we show up.Â 
We feel this work is the truest form and reflection of who we are as a company and what our service represents. We are being Twitter.
Twitter is what's happening and what people are talking about right now.

column3: "title": "Making Twitter a better home for writers"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Making Twitter a better home for writers
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 26 January 2021\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter is where people go to see and talk about what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in the world. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s where writers
column9: experts and curators \u00e2\u0080\u0093 from individual creators to journalists to publishers themselves \u00e2\u0080\u0093 go to share their written work
column10: spark meaningful conversations and build a loyal following. These writers and long-form content curators are a valuable part of the conversation and it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s critical we offer new ways for them to create and share their content
column11: and importantly
column12: help them grow and better connect with their audience.\nTo jumpstart our efforts
column13: Twitter has acquired Revue
column14: a service that makes it free and easy for anyone to start and publish editorial newsletters. Revue will accelerate our work to help people stay informed about their interests while giving all types of writers a way to monetize their audience \u00e2\u0080\u0093 whether it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s through the one they built at a publication
column15: their website
column16: on Twitter
column17:
or elsewhere.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Compose a newsletter quickly and easily in Revue. Drag links
column18: videos
column19:
and Tweets into the issue. 
          
          
        
Supporting writers across our service
With a robust community of writers and readers
column20: Twitter is uniquely positioned to help organizations and writers grow their readership faster and at a much larger scale than anywhere else. Many established writers and publishers have built their brand on Twitter
column21: amassing an audience that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s hungry for the next article or perspective they Tweet. Our goal is to make it easy for them to connect with their subscribers
column22: while also helping readers better discover writers and their content. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re imagining a lot of ways to do this
column23: from allowing people to sign up for newsletters from their favorite follows on Twitter
column24: to new settings for writers to host conversations with their subscribers. It will all work seamlessly within Twitter.\nAnd for those looking to generate revenue
column25: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re creating a durable incentive model through paid newsletters. Bringing Revue to Twitter will supercharge this offering
column26: helping writers grow their paid subscribers while also incentivizing them to produce engaging and relevant content that drives conversations on Twitter. You can expect audience-based monetization to be an area that we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to develop new ways to support
column27:
whether itâs helping broaden revenue streams or serving as a cornerstone of someoneâs business.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Audience insights by Revue. Track growth and examine engagement in aggregate or by issue. 
          
          
        
Whatâs next for Revue and Twitter
Starting today
column28: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re making Revue\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Pro features free for all accounts and lowering the paid newsletter fee to 5%
column29: a competitive rate that lets writers keep more of the revenue generated from subscriptions.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe will continue to invest in Revue as a standalone service
column30: and its team will remain focused on improving the ways writers create their newsletters
column31: build their audience and get paid for their work. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also expanding their team and hiring for key roles across engineering
column32: design
column33: research and data science. Over time
column34: this team will build more discovery
column35: reading
column36: and conversational experiences centered around long-form content on Twitter.\nThis is just the first step for us as we continue to enhance the public conversation on Twitter
column37: and we welcome all creators \u00e2\u0080\u0093 from experts and curators to journalists and publishers \u00e2\u0080\u0093 to join us on our journey. We can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t wait to share more on our progress soon.\u00c2\u00a0\nWelcome to the team
column38:
Revue!

column3: "title": "Introducing Birdwatch
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/product/2021/introducing-birdwatch-a-community-based-approach-to-misinformation"
column8: "post_text": "Product\nIntroducing Birdwatch
column9:
a community-based approach to misinformation
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column10: 25 January 2021\nLink copied successfully\nAs of November 2022
column11: Birdwatch is now Community Notes.\nPeople come to Twitter to stay informed
column12: and they want credible information to help them do so. We apply labels and add context to Tweets
column13: but we don't want to limit efforts to circumstances where something breaks our rules or receives widespread public attention. We also want to broaden the range of voices that are part of tackling this problem
column14: and we believe a community-driven approach can help. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why today we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re introducing Birdwatch
column15: a pilot in the US of a new community-driven approach to help address misleading information on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nHere\u00e2\u0080\u0099s how it works\nBirdwatch allows people to identify information in Tweets they believe is misleading and write notes that provide informative context. We believe this approach has the potential to respond quickly when misleading information spreads
column16: adding context that people trust and find valuable. Eventually we aim to make notes visible directly on Tweets for the global Twitter audience
column17: when there is consensus from a broad and diverse set of contributors.\nIn this first phase of the pilot
column18: notes will only be visible on a separate Birdwatch site. On this site
column19: pilot participants can also rate the helpfulness of notes added by other contributors. These notes are being intentionally kept separate from Twitter for now
column20: while we build Birdwatch and gain confidence that it produces context people find helpful and appropriate. Additionally
column21: notes will not have an effect on the way people see Tweets or our system recommendations. This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. Your browser does not support the video element. Play Play Pause Seek 0% buffered 00:00 Current time 00:00 Duration 00:00 Toggle Mute Volume Building togetherÂ  To date
column22: we have conducted more than 100 qualitative interviews with individuals across the political spectrum who use Twitter
column23: and we received broad general support for Birdwatch. In particular
column24: people valued notes being in the community\u00e2\u0080\u0099s voice (rather than that of Twitter or a central authority) and appreciated that notes provided useful context to help them better understand and evaluate a Tweet (rather than focusing on labeling content as\u00c2\u00a0 \u00e2\u0080\u009ctrue\u00e2\u0080\u009d or \u00e2\u0080\u009cfalse\u00e2\u0080\u009d). Our goal is to build Birdwatch in the open
column25: and have it shaped by the Twitter community.\nTo that end
column26:
weâre also taking significant steps to make Birdwatch transparent:Â 
All data contributed to Birdwatch will be publicly available and downloadable in TSV filesÂ 
As we develop algorithms that power Birdwatch â such as reputation and consensus systems â we aim to publish that code publicly in the Birdwatch Guide. The initial ranking system for Birdwatch is already available here.Â  
We hope this will enable experts
column27: researchers
column28: and the public to analyze or audit Birdwatch
column29: identifying opportunities or flaws that can help us more quickly build an effective community-driven solution.\nWe want to invite anyone to sign up and participate in this program
column30: and know that the broader and more diverse the group
column31:
the better Birdwatch will be at effectively addressing misinformation. More details on how to apply here.Â 
Whatâs next
We know there are a number of challenges toward building a community-driven system like this â from making it resistant to manipulation attempts to ensuring it isnât dominated by a simple majority or biased based on its distribution of contributors. Weâll be focused on these things throughout the pilot.
From embedding a member of the University of Chicagoâs Center for RISC on our team to hosting feedback sessions with experts in a variety of disciplines
column32: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also reaching beyond our virtual walls and integrating social science and academic perspectives into the development of Birdwatch.\nWe know this might be messy and have problems at times
column33:
but we believe this is a model worth trying. We invite you to learn alongside as we continue to explore different ways of addressing a common problem. Follow @Birdwatch for the latest updates and to provide feedback on how we are doing.

column3: "title": "What to expect on Twitter on US Inauguration Day 2021"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nWhat to expect on Twitter on US Inauguration Day 2021\nThursday
column8: 14 January 2021\nLink copied successfully\nOn Wednesday
column9: January 20
column11: President-elect Joe Biden and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris will both be sworn into office during the United States\u00e2\u0080\u0099 59th Presidential Inauguration.\nThis year
column12: multiple challenging circumstances will require that most people experience this historic ceremony virtually. As Twitter will serve as both a venue for people to watch and talk about this political event
column13: and play a key role in facilitating the transfer of official government communication channels
column14: we want to be transparent and clear about what people should expect to see on the platform.\nProtecting the public conversation \nIn our January 12 update following the riots in Washington
column15: DC
column16: we outlined the steps we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re taking to protect the public conversation on Twitter from attempts to incite violence
column17: organize attacks
column18: and share deliberately misleading information about the election outcome. These efforts
column19: including our open lines of communication with law enforcement
column20: will continue through the inauguration and will adapt as needed if circumstances change in real-time.\nWatching Inauguration 2021 live\nPeople on Twitter will be able to watch the inauguration ceremony and the coverage surrounding it via live streams from multiple news outlets and official inauguration feeds
column21: including @JCCIC and @BidenInaugural
column22: through Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s US Elections Hub.\nAlongside the livestream of inauguration events
column23: the hub will also include curated Moments
column24: Lists and accounts-to-follow recommendations from trusted and official sources.\nTransferring Institutional White House Twitter accounts\nAs we did in 2017
column25: Twitter is actively working with the US government to support the archival and transition of Twitter accounts across administrations.\nAs President-elect Biden is sworn in on January 20
column27: Twitter will facilitate the transfer of institutional White House Twitter accounts
column28: including: @WhiteHouse
column29: @POTUS
column30: @VP
column31: @FLOTUS
column32: and @PressSec.\nFirst
column33: Twitter will transfer current institutional accounts to the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) where the Tweets and account history will remain publicly available and the account usernames will be updated to reflect their archived status. For example
column34: the Trump administration\u00e2\u0080\u0099s @POTUS account will be publicly archived as @POTUS45
column35: just as the Obama administration\u00e2\u0080\u0099s account was archived as @POTUS44.\nOnce this archival process is completed
column36: Twitter will transfer the institutional accounts to the Biden administration to assume ownership
column37: along with a new account: @SecondGentleman.\nPeople on Twitter will be able to watch the transition of power take place in real-time as accounts for the White House
column38: President
column39: Vice President
column40: First Lady and White House Press Secretary inherit their new institutional usernames: @Transition46 will become @WhiteHouse
column41: @PresElectBiden will become @POTUS
column42: @SenKamalaHarris will become @VP
column43: @FLOTUSBiden will become @FLOTUS
column44: and @PressSecPsaki will become @PressSec. The Tweets
column45: account history
column46: and followers will transition between these accounts.\nThese institutional accounts will not automatically retain the followers from the prior administration. People on Twitter who previously followed institutional White House Twitter accounts
column47: or who currently follow relevant Biden or Harris Twitter accounts
column48: will receive in-app alerts and other prompts that will notify them about the archival process
column49: as well as give them the option to follow the new administration\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Twitter accounts. The new institutional accounts will also be listed in Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s US Elections Hub during the presidential inauguration.\nYou can follow along with @TwitterGov
column50: @Policy and @TwitterMoments
column51:
where we will continue to share updates and information on #Inauguration2021.
Â

column95: 2020 Launch of a new dedicated #KnowTheFacts search prompt\nAs the global conversation continues around the spread of COVID-19

column98: and to highlight credible information on this emerging issue. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen tens of millions of Tweets on this topic in the past four weeks and that trend looks set to continue.\nGiven the rapidly evolving nature of the issue and the growing international response

July 14
column160:
2020Â 
Clarifying how we assess misleading information
Today we are further clarifying our rules against potentially misleading information about COVID-19.Â  This update includes additional details on what factors we take into account when considering content for removal.
Our primary goal with addressing misleading information about COVID-19 has not changed. We will continue to remove demonstrably false or potentially misleading content that has the highest risk of causing harm. However
column161: we are providing additional details about our framework for evaluating a potentially misleading claim
column162: including when we would or would not require Tweets to include an explicit call to action (e.g. \u00e2\u0080\u009ceveryone should stop wearing masks!\u00e2\u0080\u009d) in order to take action.\nWhen evaluating whether or not to remove the most harmful misinformation on our platform
column163: we consider three criteria:\u00c2\u00a0\n1. Is the content advancing a claim of fact regarding COVID-19?\nFor a Tweet to qualify as a misleading claim
column164: it must be an assertion of fact (not an opinion)
column166: and intended to influence others\u00e2\u0080\u0099 behavior. Some examples include information about:\nthe origin
column168: and characteristics of the virus;\npreventative measures
column170: and other precautions;\nthe prevalence of viral spread
column171: or the current state of the crisis;\nofficial health advisories
column174:
and public-service announcements;
how vulnerable communities are affected by/responding to the pandemic.
2. Is the claim demonstrably false or misleading?Â  
Under this policy
column175: we consider claims to be false or misleading if (1) they have been confirmed to be false by subject-matter experts
column176: such as public health authorities; or (2) they include information which is shared in a way that could confuse or deceive people. Some of the factors we consider include:\nWhether the content of the Tweet
column183: lead to harm?\nWe will not be able to take enforcement action on every Tweet that contains incomplete or disputed information about COVID-19. Our focus in the COVID-19 policy is narrowed to address those claims that could adversely impact an individual
column187: and likely to cause harm\u00e2\u0080\u0094may not be shared on Twitter and are subject to removal. Accounts that break this rule repeatedly may be permanently suspended. Further details about some of the most common types of misleading claims which we will remove under this policy are provided below.\nWe may label or place a warning on tweets to provide additional context in situations where the risks of harm associated with a Tweet are less severe but where people may still be confused or misled. This will make it easier to find facts and make informed decisions about what people see on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0In line with our existing enforcement approach
column188: Tweets that are labeled under this expanded guidance will have reduced visibility across the service. Reducing the visibility of Tweets means that we will not amplify the Tweets on a number of surfaces across Twitter. However
column189: anyone following the account will still be able to see the Tweet and Retweet.\nThe world has changed since this pandemic was first declared and public health experts
column191: scientists and researchers now know more about how we can best stay safe and healthy. As the situation evolves and as global health advisories shift to cope with the pandemic
column192:
we are committed to ensuring our rules and enforcement actions reflect that evolution.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
May 11
column193: 2020\u00c2\u00a0\nUpdating our approach to misleading information\u00c2\u00a0\nIn serving the public conversation
column194: our goal is to make it easy to find credible information on Twitter and to limit the spread of potentially harmful and misleading content. Starting today
column195:
weâre introducing new labels and warning messages that will provide additional context and information on some Tweets containing disputed or misleading information related to COVID-19. For more information see the full update to our approach on misleading information here.

April 22
column196: 2020\nBroadening our guidance on unverified claims\nGoing forward and specific to COVID-19
column197: unverified claims that have the potential to incite people to action
column198: could lead to the destruction or damage of critical infrastructure
column199: or cause widespread panic/social unrest may be considered a violation of our policies. Examples include
column200:
âThe National Guard just announced that no more shipments of food will be arriving for two months â run to the grocery store ASAP and buy everythingâ or â5G causes coronavirus â go destroy the cell towers in your neighborhood!".
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable

          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
April 2
column201: 2020\nOur ads policy for COVID-19\nIn response to the shifting advertising landscape
column202: and in order to support helpful causes during this time
column203: we're now allowing managed clients and partners to advertise content containing implicit or explicit reference to COVID-19 in the following use cases
column204:
with restrictions:
Adjustments to business practices and/or models in response to COVID-19
Support for customers and employees related to COVID-19
The following restrictions apply to these use cases:
Distasteful references to COVID-19 (or variations) are prohibited
Content may not be sensational or likely to incite panic
Prices of products related to COVID-19 may not be inflated
The promotion of certain products related to COVID-19 may be prohibited. We currently prohibit the advertising of medical facemasks and alcohol hand sanitizers. Please note that other products may be added to this list and enforcement can be retroactive.
The mention of vaccines
column205: treatments and test kits is permitted
column206: only in the form of information
column207: from news publishers which have been exempted under the Political Ads Content policy.\nRead more about the policy. For more COVID-19 Twitter resources for advertisers
column208:
visit marketing.twitter.com/covid19.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
April 1
column209: 2020 Broadening our definition of \"harm\"\nWe have broadened our definition of harm to address content that goes directly against guidance from authoritative sources of global and local public health information. Rather than reports
column210: we are enforcing this in close coordination with trusted partners
column211: including public health authorities and governments
column212: and continue to use and consult with information from those sources when reviewing content.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to prioritize removing content when it has a clear call to action that could directly pose a risk to people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s health or well-being
column213: but we want to make it clear that we will not be able to take enforcement action on every Tweet that contains incomplete or disputed information about COVID-19. This is not meant to limit good faith discussion or expressing hope about ongoing studies related to potential medical interventions that show promise.\nSince introducing these policies on March 18
column215: 100 Tweets containing misleading and potentially harmful content from Twitter. Additionally
column216:
our automated systems have challenged more than 1.5 million accounts which were targeting discussions around COVID-19 with spammy or manipulative behaviors. We will continue to use both technology and our teams to help us identify and stop spammy behavior and accounts.
We may also apply the public interest notice in cases where world leaders violate the COVID-19 guidelines.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Automated technology and what to expect if you file a report
How are we using automated technology during this time?
To help us review reports more efficiently by surfacing content that's most likely to cause harm and should be reviewed first.
To help us proactively identify rule-breaking content before it's reported. Our systems learn from past decisions by our review teams
column218: the technology is able to help us rank content or challenge accounts automatically.\nFor content that requires additional context
column219: such as misleading information around COVID-19
column220: our teams will continue to review those reports manually.\nWhat you can expect if you file a report during this time:\nIf you've reported an account or Tweet to us
column221: it will take longer than normal for us to get back to you. We appreciate your patience as we continue to make adjustments.\nBecause these automated systems don't have all of the context and insight our team has
column222: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll make mistakes. If you think we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made a mistake
column223: you can let us know and appeal here.\nWe appreciate your patience as we work to keep our teams safe
column224: while also making sure we're protecting everyone on Twitter. You can always continue to use hide replies
column228:
and the other tools we offer you to control conversations on the service.
Read the original post.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
March 27
column229: 2020  An update on our content moderation work\nWe have broadened our definition of harm to address content that goes directly against guidance from authoritative sources of global and local public health information. Rather than reports
column230: we are enforcing this in close coordination with trusted partners
column231: including public health authorities and governments
column232: and continue to use and consult with information from those sources when reviewing content.\nUnder this guidance
column233: we will require people to remove Tweets that include:\nStatements which are intended to influence others to violate recommended COVID-19 related guidance from global or local health authorities to decrease someone\u00e2\u0080\u0099s likelihood of exposure to COVID-19
column234: such as: \u00e2\u0080\u009csocial distancing is not effective
column236: you don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t need a mask anymore
column237: so don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t wear your mask!\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nNote: We will not require the removal of Tweets that include information about or encouragement to participate in demonstrations or protests.\u00c2\u00a0 \u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0 \nMisleading claims that unharmful but ineffective methods are cures or absolute treatments for COVID-19
column238: such as \u00e2\u0080\u009cCoronavirus is vulnerable to UV radiation - walking outside in bright sunlight will prevent COVID-19.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nDescription of harmful treatments or preventative measures which are known to be ineffective or are being shared out of context to mislead people
column239: such as \u00e2\u0080\u009cdrinking bleach and ingesting colloidal silver will cure COVID-19.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nDenial of established scientific facts about transmission during the incubation period or transmission guidance from global and local health authorities
column240: such as \u00e2\u0080\u009cCOVID-19 does not infect children because we haven\u00e2\u0080\u0099t seen any cases of children being sick.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nFalse or misleading information that would allow the reader to diagnose themselves as either having or not having COVID-19
column241: such as \u00e2\u0080\u009cIf you can hold your breath for 10 seconds
column242: you don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t have coronavirus.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nUnverified claims that have the potential to incite people to action
column243: could lead to the destruction or damage of critical infrastructure
column244: or could lead to widespread panic/social unrest may be considered a violation of our policies. Examples include
column245: \u00c2\u00a0 \u00e2\u0080\u009cThe National Guard just announced that no more shipments of food will be arriving for two months \u00e2\u0080\u0094 run to the grocery store ASAP and buy everything\u00e2\u0080\u009d or \u00e2\u0080\u009c5G causes coronavirus \u00e2\u0080\u0094 #BURN5G.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nTweets offering the sale or facilitation of non-prescription treatments/cures for COVID-19
column246: or those which advertise cures or treatments for COVID-19 that require a prescription or physician consultation.\nSpecific and unverified claims made by people impersonating a government or health official or organization such as a parody account of official public health advisors claiming that hydroxychloroquine will prevent COVID-19.\nClaims that specific groups or nationalities are never susceptible to COVID-19
column247: such as \u00e2\u0080\u009cpeople with dark skin are immune to COVID-19 due to melanin production\u00e2\u0080\u009d or are more susceptible
column248:
such as âavoid businesses owned by Chinese people as they are more likely to have COVID-19.â
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
March 16
column249: 2020 Our use of automated technology\nWe have increased our use of machine learning and automation to take a wide range of actions on potentially abusive and manipulative content. We want to be clear: while we work to ensure our systems are consistent
column250: they can sometimes lack the context that our teams bring
column251: and this may result in us making mistakes. As a result
column252: we will not permanently suspend any accounts based solely on our automated enforcement systems. Instead
column253:
we will continue to look for opportunities to build in human review checks where they will be most impactful. We appreciate your patience as we work to get it right â this is a necessary step to scale our work to protect the conversation on Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Additional triage
column255:
and our ongoing review of Twitter Rules
Here are a few more things we are doing to protect the public conversation:
Building systems that enable our team to continue to enforce our rules remotely around the world.
Weâre also increasing our employee assistance and wellness support for everyone involved in this critical work
column256: and ensuring people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s privacy and security stay a top priority.\nInstituting a global content severity triage system so we are prioritizing the potential rule violations that present the biggest risk of harm and reducing the burden on people to report them.\nExecuting daily quality assurance checks on our content enforcement processes to ensure we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re agile in responding to this rapidly evolving
column257:
global disease outbreak.
Engaging with our partners around the world to ensure escalation paths remain open and urgent cases can be brought to our attention.
Continuing to review the Twitter Rules in the context of COVID-19 and considering ways in which they may need to evolve to account for new behaviors.
As weâve said on many occasions
column258: our approach to protecting the public conversation is never static. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s particularly relevant in these unprecedented times. We intend to review our thinking daily and will ensure we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sharing updates here on any new clarifications to our rules or major changes to how we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re enforcing them.\nFinally
column259: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re encouraged that our service is being used around the world to provide free
column261: and to ensure that everyone has access to the conversations they need to protect themselves and their families. For more
column262: our dedicated COVID-19 Event page has the latest facts right at the top of your timeline
column263:
and weâll continue to share updates @TwitterSafety and @TwitterSupport.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
March 4
column264: 2020 Our zero-tolerance approach to platform manipulation\nThe power of a uniquely open service during a public health emergency is clear. The speed and borderless nature of Twitter presents an extraordinary opportunity to get the word out and ensure people have access to the latest information from expert sources around the world.\nTo support that mission
column265: our global Trust & Safety team is continuing its zero-tolerance approach to platform manipulation and any other attempts to abuse our service at this critical juncture. At present
column266: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re not seeing significant coordinated platform manipulation efforts around these issues. However
column267: we will remain vigilant and have invested substantially in our proactive abilities to ensure trends
column269: and other common areas of the service are protected from malicious behaviors. As ever
column270:
we also welcome constructive and open information sharing from governments and academics to further our work in these areas â weâre in this together.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
January 29
column271: 2020 Preventing platform manipulation\nAs the global conversation continues around the spread of COVID-19
column272: we want to share the work we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re doing to surface the right information
column274: and to highlight credible information on this emerging issue.\nAt present
column275: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re not seeing significant coordinated attempts to spread disinformation at scale about this issue. However
column276: we will remain vigilant and have invested significantly in our proactive abilities to ensure trends
column278: and other common areas of the service are protected from malicious behaviors. As ever
column279:

column291: 2020 Protecting and supporting journalists\nAll around the world
column292: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen our service connecting people with the authoritative health information they need to protect themselves and their loved ones. That work can only be successful if people have access to the news and information they need.\nRight now
column293: every journalist is a COVID-19 journalist. From the stories of healthcare workers on the front lines
column294: to analysis of the real human and economic cost of the pandemic
column295: reporters around the world are still writing
column297:
still giving us the facts. Journalism is core to our service and we have a deep and enduring responsibility to protect that work. This week weâre contributing to two critical organizations that are working tirelessly to uphold the fundamental values of a free press during this pandemic.
Weâre donating 1 million dollars evenly distributed between the Committee to Protect Journalists and the International Womenâs Media Foundation. These funds will be used to ensure these organizations can continue their work in the face of new economic strains and to directly support journalists. Their shared efforts to advocate for the rights of vulnerable reporters and to guarantee an equal share of voice for women in the industry has never been more relevant or important.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We are grateful for Twitterâs generous support. Our efforts at CPJ are focused on ensuring that journalists around the world have the information and resources they need to cover the COVID-19 pandemic safely. And we are pushing back against governments that are censoring the news
column298: and restricting the work of the press. We need timely
column299: accurate information flowing within countries and across borders so that political leaders
column301: and the public at large can make informed decisions at this critical moment.\nJoel Simon\nExecutive Director
column303: there is a great need to support our community of journalists covering
column305: this global pandemic. Based on our decades of work with journalists who operate in dangerous and difficult environments
column306: the IWMF understands the critical role that safety and security plays in the industry. Thanks to the incredible support of Twitter
column307: the IWMF will be able to address the needs of our community of journalists more deeply and robustly. By supporting journalists from diverse communities
column308: together we can support the most representative news possible in this evolving time.\nElisa Lees Mu\u00c3\u00b1oz\nExecutive Director
column309:
International Womenâs Media Foundation (IWMF)
â@ElisaLeesMunozâ
COVID-19 has been with us for months but the power of the virus is now being felt on all corners of the globe. Weâre witnessing real-time public conversation on an issue that connects us all on a core human level and our purpose has never been stronger. We will continue to work with our partners as the crisis evolves and are grateful for their journalistic leadership and commitment to the power of the pen.Â 
For more

and @IWMF.

column317: 2020 Building partnerships to protect the public conversation\nOur entire company is stepping up its internal and external efforts to build partnerships
column319: help people find authoritative health information
column321: and contribute pro bono advertising support to ensure people are getting the right message

column326: our goal is to elevate and amplify authoritative health information as far as possible.\nGlobal expansion of the COVID-19 search prompt\u00c2\u00a0\nLaunched six days before the official designation of the virus in January
column327: we continue to expand our dedicated search prompt feature to ensure that when you come to the service for information about COVID-19
column329: authoritative content at the top of your search experience. and Yemen.

#AdsForGood support and additional protections
Based on our Inappropriate Content Policy
column379: we will halt any attempt by advertisers to opportunistically use the COVID-19 outbreak to target inappropriate ads. Government entities that want to disseminate public health information will be permitted to promote ads on COVID-19. In the case of COVID-19
column380: we have put additional safeguards into place in order to facilitate the sharing of trusted public health information and to reduce potential harm to users. We are currently prohibiting the promotion of all medical masks and alcohol hand sanitizers due to strong correlation to COVID-19 and instances of inflated prices globally.\nIn addition
column381: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committing Ads for Good credits to nonprofit organizations to ensure they can build campaigns to fact-check and get reputable health information to the widest possible audiences. For example
column382: as part of the International Fact-Checking Network (IFCN/@factchecknet)
column383: we have supported the Spanish organization @maldita_es and @malditobulo
column384: which focuses on mitigating the impact of disinformation on public discourse through fact-checking and data journalism techniques. In Asia
column385: we have partnered with the Taiwan Fact Checking Center (@taiwantfc)
column386:
which has been using Twitter to connect with IFCN fact checkers around the world via #CoronavirusFacts. They are working in real time to find credible information and debunk rumors in Chinese.

column388: numerous global government and public health organizations
column390: to ensure they can troubleshoot account issues
column392: and seek strategic counsel as they use the power of Twitter to mitigate harm.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also in close contact with our industry peers and will attend all relevant cross-functional meetings. As a uniquely open service

our data is being used in research every day and our researchers hub is publicly available. We welcome applications for the use of Twitter data to support research on COVID-19. We will also explore further #DataForGood partnerships to assess how our data products can enhance academic and NGO understanding of public health emergencies now and into the future.

column403: 2020\nEnabling study of the public conversation in a time of crisis\nTo further support Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s ongoing efforts to protect the public conversation
column404: and help people find authoritative health information around COVID-19
column405:
weâre releasing a new endpoint into Twitter Developer Labs to enable approved developers and researchers to study the public conversation about COVID-19 in real-time.Â 
The COVID-19 stream endpoint provides access to COVID-19 and Coronavirus related public Tweets in real-time as defined by the criteria used to power this topic on Twitter. This is a unique dataset that covers many tens of millions of Tweets daily and offers insight into the evolving global public conversation surrounding an unprecedented crisis. Making this access available for free is one of the most unique and valuable things Twitter can do as the world comes together to protect our communities and seek answers to pressing challenges.Â  
You can read more about this endpoint and the application process on our developer blog.

March 27
column406: 2020 \nHow we're keeping the service running and the Tweets flowing\nKeeping the service running and the Tweets flowing is one of our top priorities in these difficult times. Our work has never been more critical and our service has never been in higher demand. In the past few weeks
column407: we have seen more and more people turn to Twitter to participate in the public conversation and follow what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in real time.\nThe global conversation about COVID-19 and ongoing product improvements are driving up total monetizable DAU (mDAU)
column408: with quarter-to-date average total mDAU reaching approximately 164 million
column409: up 23% from 134 million in Q1 2019 and up 8% from 152 million in Q4 2019.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also seen a 45% increase in our curated events page usage and a 30% increase in Direct Message (DM) usage since March 6.\nWhile many of our teams are transitioning to working from home
column410: some of our infrastructure teams have physical responsibilities that are critical to keeping our data centers
column412: up and running. These teams are operating under the \u00e2\u0080\u009cessential services\u00e2\u0080\u009d provisions dedicated in City
column414: and State orders to ensure business continuity. We couldn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t keep the Tweets flowing without their daily dedication and hard work.\nThe combination of the new work environment and the increased load on our platform has placed unique stresses on our operations
column415: requiring our engineering teams to work more closely together than ever to respond to new demands
column416: and to plan for the future. From our IT
column418: and Product Engineering teams to our Infrastructure and Data Center teams
column419: we have collectively mobilized to ensure we are able to stay safe and productive under the stress of the new levels of traffic we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re seeing on our service.\nThe effects of COVID-19 on Twitter have already surpassed any event we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen
column420: and it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s possible that as the pandemic continues
column421: we will see additional stress on our service. Beyond Twitter
column422: COVID-19 has also had a far-sweeping impact on our supply chain partners. Whereas normally we'd have months of lead time to add hardware capacity for expected growth
column424: manufacturing delays in China have compromised the supply chain
column425: resulting in delays in deliveries to our data centers. Our Data Center
column429: and Mission Critical teams continue to manage the physical infrastructure that underlies the service \u00e2\u0080\u0094 expertly innovating to unlock additional capacity in existing supply.\nOur teams are actively addressing areas where we need to add capacity to critical services
column430: looking at how we can optimize existing technology to perform better
column431: and planning for how we might adjust to the way people are using Twitter during this time.\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s critical for Twitter to stay up and running through this global crisis. Our teams are focused
column432: and as we make changes to our systems to meet these new demands
column433: we will communicate openly. We will share what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve done
column436:
what we will do to recover as quickly as possible. Follow @TwitterEng to stay up to date.

May 12
column439: 2020 \n#LoveWhereverYouWork\nTwitter was one of the first companies to go to a work from home model in the face of COVID-19
column440: but we don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t anticipate being one of the first to return to offices.\u00c2\u00a0 \nWe were uniquely positioned to respond quickly and allow folks to work from home given our emphasis on decentralization and supporting a distributed workforce capable of working from anywhere. The past few months have proven we can make that work. So if our employees are in a role and situation that enables them to work from home and they want to continue to do so forever
column441: we will make that happen. If not
column442: our offices will be their warm and welcoming selves
column444: when we feel it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s safe to return.\u00c2\u00a0\nHere\u00e2\u0080\u0099s how we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re thinking about the next few months:\nOpening offices will be our decision
column445: when and if our employees come back
column446: will be theirs.\u00c2\u00a0\nWith very few exceptions
column447: offices won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t open before September. When we do decide to open offices
column448: it also won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t be a snap back to the way it was before. It will be careful
column450: office by office and gradual.\u00c2\u00a0\nThere will also be no business travel before September
column452:
and no in-person company events for the rest of 2020. We will assess 2021 events later this year.
Weâre proud of the early action we took to protect the health of our employees and our communities. That will remain our top priority as we work through the unknowns of the coming months.
#LoveWhereverYouWork

March 11
column453: 2020 \nMandatory work from home and supporting our employees\nOur top priority remains the health and safety of our Tweeps
column454: and we also have a responsibility to support our communities
column456: and the healthcare providers who are on the front lines of this pandemic. To continue this push
column457: we are moving beyond our earlier guidance of \u00e2\u0080\u009cstrongly encouraging work from home\u00e2\u0080\u009d provided on March 2 and have now informed all employees globally they must work from home.\nWe understand this is an unprecedented step
column458: but these are unprecedented times. And we will continue to do all that we can to support our Tweeps
column460: vendors and hourly workers\nFor contractors and hourly workers who are not able to perform their responsibilities from home
column461: Twitter will continue to pay their labor costs to cover standard working hours while Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s work-from-home guidance and/or travel restrictions related to their assigned office are in effect.\nAdditional resources to support parents\nAs part of our ongoing global benefits support
column462: Twitter is stepping in to ease additional expenses parents may be experiencing when their normal daycare closes due to COVID-19 by providing reimbursement for the additional daycare expenses incurred.\nHelping Tweeps set up their at-home offices\nAll employees
column464: will receive reimbursement toward their home office set up expenses
column465: and we are working with our vendors to ensure our contractors' work-from-home needs are met as well. We listened to employee feedback and expanded our policy to include home office equipment
column468: and ergonomic chair cushions. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also allowing Tweeps to expense online fees while working from home.\n#FlockTalk\nLast year
column470: a program activated when Tweeps want to come together during difficult times to share what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s going on with them
column472: and be heard by our leaders. News around COVID-19 is impacting people in a number of different ways \u00e2\u0080\u0094 from schools and offices being closed
column475: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re all dealing with a lot. The Twitter Inclusion & Diversity team (@TwitterTogether)
column477: will host a virtual #FlockTalk that acknowledges there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a direct correlation between conversations between us
column479: and the health of our service.\nResource guides to make the work-from-home transition easier\nWorking from home can be a challenging transition
column480: so we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve provided a variety of resource guides to help our employees continue to get the job done. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re listing them here as well because at times like this
column481: sharing insights and learning is so important. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re all in this together and we want to help others outside of Twitter make their transitions to working outside of their offices easier.\nWorking-from-home best practices: We have shared the factors to consider to make sure Tweeps are ready to be productive and healthy. Some factors include workspace
column485: working from home doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t change your day-to-day work
column486: it just means you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be doing it from a different environment.\nManaging a distributed team: Being a people manager means providing a consistent and positive employee experience for everyone on your team
column487: regardless of location. This manager resource guide highlights the three key pillars of management: strategy
column488: growth and care. So what changes when your team is fully distributed? The good news \u00e2\u0080\u0094 not much! These pillars still apply whether you manage a distributed or co-located team.\nVirtual interview guide: All interviews at Twitter will be done via video conferencing. A completely virtual interview has its benefits. It is ideal for introducing candidates to remote work cultures
column489: and it is a great opportunity for candidates who will work remotely to get a sense for the experience of interacting with other team members remotely. While this virtual interview guide is not a holistic interview guide
column490: it instead focuses on the aspects of interviewing candidates remotely that differ from interviewing candidates in-person.\nWe have also shared guides for working across time zones
column491: using collaboration tools to stay connected
column492:
and ergonomic tips for working from home and on-the-go.
Weâll continue sharing information as we navigate these changes. Itâs all in dedication to keeping our Tweeps and everyone around us healthy. Weâre all in this together!

column493: 2020 Encouraging employees to work from home\nIn addition to the travel
column495: and visitor restrictions that we previously shared
column496: today we provided additional guidance as we look to protect the health and safety of our workforce. Beginning today
column497: we are strongly encouraging all employees globally to work from home if they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re able. Our goal is to lower the probability of the spread of the COVID-19 for us \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and the world around us. We are operating out of an abundance of caution and the utmost dedication to keeping our Tweeps healthy.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe are working to make sure internal meetings
column499: and other important tasks are optimized for remote participation. We recognize that working from home is not ideal for some job functions. For those employees who prefer or need to come into the offices
column500: they will remain open for business. Our Real Estate & Workplace team is increasing deep-cleaning and sanitizing in all spaces
column501: as well as more visual reminders for personal hygiene best practices and prepackaged
column503: and preplated food options.\nWorking from home will be mandatory for employees based in our Hong Kong
column505: and South Korea offices due in part to government restrictions. Our criteria will evolve over time as we get more information
column506: and we will communicate to affected Tweeps as appropriate.\nWhile this is a big change for us
column507: we have already been moving toward a more distributed workforce that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s increasingly remote. We're a global service and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to enabling anyone
column509:
to work at Twitter.

column510: 2020 Suspending noncritical business travel and events\nWe recently shared information about the work we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re doing to surface the right information to promote constructive engagement and to highlight credible information around the spread of #coronavirus COVID-19. We will continue to update the public on these efforts this week.\nWe also have the responsibility of ensuring that the health and safety of our employees and partners is not compromised. We have continued to monitor the situation closely and are adjusting our internal policies to respond to this rapidly evolving situation. On February 29
column511:
we informed our people and started notifying partners that we are suspending all noncritical business travel and events.Â 
This policy is effective immediately and will continue until the World Health Organization or Centers for Disease Control deem it appropriate to step back from pandemic precautionary measures or when a vaccine becomes available.Â 
Our goal is to reduce the risk that anyone at Twitter might contract or inadvertently spread the virus. It is important that we take these proactive steps to protect ourselves and others and minimize the spread of COVID-19.Â 
There are enormous transnational efforts underway to tackle this virus. As a global company with a global workforce
column512: we want to do what we can to help the success of these multistakeholder containment efforts. Temporarily suspending travel is an immediate and important step.\nWe want to thank our people
column514:
and customers for their patience and understanding.

column8: "post_text": "Company\nAn update following the riots in Washington
column9:
DC

column10: 12 January 2021\nLink copied successfully\nFollowing the horrific events in Washington
column11: DC
column12: last week
column13: here are some of the steps we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve taken to protect the conversation on our service from attempts to incite violence
column14: organize attacks
column15: and share deliberately misleading information about the election outcome. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important to be transparent about all of this work as the US Presidential Inauguration on January 20
column17: approaches.\nUpdated our coordinated harmful activity policy\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been clear that we will take strong enforcement action on behavior that has the potential to lead to offline harm. Given the violent events in Washington
column18: DC
column19: and increased risk of harm
column20: we began permanently suspending thousands of accounts that were primarily dedicated to sharing QAnon content on Friday afternoon.\nMany of the individuals impacted by this updated enforcement action held multiple accounts
column21: driving up the total number of accounts impacted. Since Friday
column22: more than 70
column23: 000 accounts have been suspended as a result of our efforts
column24: with many instances of a single individual operating numerous accounts. These accounts were engaged in sharing harmful QAnon-associated content at scale and were primarily dedicated to the propagation of this conspiracy theory across the service.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur updated enforcement on QAnon content on Twitter
column25: along with routine spam challenges
column26: has resulted in changes in follower count for some people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Twitter accounts. In some cases
column27: these actions may have resulted in follower count changes in the thousands.\u00c2\u00a0\nAs stipulated in this policy that we announced ahead of the 2020 US election
column28: accounts that have Tweeted or Retweeted associated content will continue to be subject to limited visibility across search
column29: replies
column30:
and on timelines and are prohibited from being recommended to others by Twitter. Itâs important that these types of accounts â that are not predominantly engaged in sharing this material â can see different perspectives in the open public conversation that Twitter uniquely provides.
Our teams are discussing ways we can empower research into QAnon and coordinated harmful activity on Twitter.Â 
Escalated enforcement measures for our Civic Integrity Policy
During the past several weeks
column31: misleading and false information surrounding the 2020 US presidential election has been the basis for incitement to violence around the country. We took action on these claims in line with our Civic Integrity Policy.\nNow that the results of the election have been officially certified by Congress
column32: we updated our Civic Integrity policy on Friday to aggressively increase our enforcement action on these claims. The updated policy provides details about how we enforce against violations of this policy
column33: including repeated sharing of Tweets that receive warning labels. Ultimately
column34:
repeated violations of this policy can result in permanent suspension.
Deployed tech to surface potentially harmful Tweets for urgent human review
Our teams are continuing to aggressively deploy technology to surface potentially harmful Tweets for human review in an effort to take action as quickly as possible on violative content. Using this combination of technology and human review helps our teams work at scale during this critical time. We continue to update these tools as terminology and behaviors evolve on Twitter.
Limited engagement on labeled Tweets
On Tuesday
column35: we limited engagement by no longer allowing any Tweets labeled for violations of our civic integrity policy to be replied to
column36: Liked or Retweeted. People on Twitter are still able to Quote Tweet to share this content with additional context or their own perspective.\nBlocked violative keywords from Search and Trends\nWe want Trends to promote healthy conversations on Twitter. This means
column37: at times
column38: we may prevent certain content from trending. There are rules for Trends
column39: and if we identify Trends that violate these rules
column40: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll take enforcement action.\nSince last week
column41:
we've prohibited certain terms from surfacing in Trends and Search based on the following Twitter Rules:
Coordinated harmful activity
Civic integrity
Hateful conduct
Glorification of violence
Violent threats
Sensitive mediaÂ 
We will also continue to prioritize reviewing and adding context to Trends. Our goal is to help people see whatâs happening while ensuring that potentially confusing trends are presented with context.
Fought spam and challenged potentially inauthentic accounts
It is against the Twitter Rules to engage in spamming behavior
column42: including bulk
column43: aggressive
column44: or deceptive activity. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we routinely deploy anti-spam challenges to accounts to fight this behavior and protect the public conversation. During these challenges
column45: account owners must verify their authenticity through a variety of measures
column46: such as reCAPTCHA or providing a functional email address.\u00c2\u00a0\nAs always
column47: while accounts are undergoing these challenges
column48: they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re temporarily removed from follower counts. This
column49: along with our updated enforcement around coordinated harmful activity
column50: means some people may notice drops or fluctuations in their follower count.\u00c2\u00a0\nAhead of the inauguration
column51: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to monitor the situation
column52: keep open lines of communication with law enforcement
column53:
and keep the public informed of additional enforcement actions.
Â

column3: "title": "Insights from the 17th Twitter Transparency Report"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Insights from the 17th Twitter Transparency Report
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 11 January 2021\nLink copied successfully\nMeaningful transparency between companies
column9: regulators
column10: civil society
column11: and the general public is fundamental to the work we do at Twitter \u00e2\u0080\u0094 this transparency is a key tenet of our efforts to preserve and protect the Open Internet. In line with this philosophy
column12: in August we launched our new Twitter Transparency Center to make our data easier to understand and analyze for those who access our biannual Twitter Transparency Report.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur latest Twitter Transparency Report includes data from January 1
column14: through June 30
column15: 2020.\u00c2\u00a0\nCOVID-19\nThe COVID-19 pandemic severely impacted business operations for all of us around the world. Given the changes in workflows
column16: coupled with country specific COVID-19 restrictions
column17: there was some significant and unpredictable disruption to our content moderation work and the way in which teams assess content and enforce our policies - a disruption that is reflected in some of the data presented today. We increased our use of machine learning and automation to take a wide range of actions on potentially abusive and misleading content
column18: whilst continually focusing human review in areas where the likelihood of harm was the greatest.\nIn March
column19: we launched a COVID-19 misleading information policy to further protect the health of the public conversation. During this reporting period
column20: our teams took enforcement action against 4
column21: 658 accounts for violations of this policy. As we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve further invested in technology
column22: our automated systems challenged 4.5 million accounts that were targeting discussions around COVID-19 with spammy or manipulative behaviors.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur work on information operations\nTwitter discloses state-backed actors\u00e2\u0080\u0099 attempts to disrupt the conversation on the service. During this reporting period
column23: we took action on more than 52
column24: 000 accounts that we reliably attributed to information operations originating within China
column25: Russia
column26: Turkey
column27: Serbia
column28: Honduras
column29: Egypt
column30: Indonesia
column31: Ghana and Nigeria as well as a KSA-affiliated actor.\u00c2\u00a0\nPlatform manipulation\nWe continued our zero-tolerance approach to platform manipulation and any other attempts to undermine the integrity of our service. During this latest reporting period
column32: our teams saw a 54% increase in anti-spam challenges \u00e2\u0080\u0094 an increase that is due in part to the proactive measures we put in place to protect the conversation around COVID-19. We also saw a 16% increase in the number of spam reports
column33:
compared to the last reporting period.Â 
Terrorism & violent extremism
There was a 5% increase in the number of accounts removed for violations of our terrorism and violent extremism policies during this reporting period â 94% of those accounts were proactively identified. Our current methods of surfacing potentially violating content for human review include leveraging the shared industry hash database supported by the Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism (GIFCT).
Child sexual exploitation
We do not tolerate child sexual exploitation (CSE) on Twitter. CSE material is removed from the service without further notice and reported to The National Center for Missing & Exploited Children (NCMEC). As we have expanded our teams and increased operational capacity in this area
column34: we saw a 68% increase in our enforcement under our Child Sexual Exploitation Policy.\nCopyright and trademark\nUnder our Copyright Policy
column35: we received 15% more Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) takedown notices affecting 87% more accounts during this reporting period. Under our Trademark Policy
column36:
our trademark notice compliance decreased by 30% during this time.
Twitter Rules enforcement
Abuse/harassment
Targeted harassment of someone
column37: or inciting other people to do so
column38: is against the Twitter Rules. There was a 34% decrease in the number of accounts actioned for violations of our abuse policy.\nCivic integrity\nWe saw a steady increase in the number of accounts actioned under our Civic Integrity Policy
column39: as elections happened around the world during this reporting period. There was a 37% increase in the number of accounts actioned for violations of this policy during this reporting period.\nHateful conduct\nOver the six month reporting period and amidst the COVID-19 disruptions to workflow
column40: we saw a 35% decrease in the number of accounts actioned under our Hateful Conduct Policy. In March 2020
column41: our Hateful Conduct Policy expanded to cover new facets of our dehumanization guidance
column42: specifically prohibiting language that dehumanizes people on the basis of age
column43: disability
column44: and disease.\nPromoting suicide & self-harm\nWe do not permit people to promote
column45: advocate
column46: and persuade another individual to engage in self-harm or suicide. There was a 49% decrease in the number of accounts actioned for violations of our suicide or self-harm policy.\u00c2\u00a0\nPrivate information\nWe have clear rules around the sharing of private information on our service. During this reporting period
column47:
we continued to see an upward trend in our enforcement under this policy â up by 68%. This increase was due to our proactive efforts in this area.Â 
Non-consensual nudity
Enforcement numbers for non-consensual nudity (NCN) on the service experienced a 58% decrease. We'll continue working to improve processes and models to be as proactive as possible in maintaining a healthy environment for the people on Twitter.
Information requests (legal requests for account information):Â 
Twitter received 12
column48: 657 legal requests for account information specifying 25
column49: 560 accounts during this period
column50: from 68 different countries.\nRemoval requests (legal requests for content removal)*:\nTwitter received 42
column51: 220 legal demands to remove content specifying 85
column52: 375 accounts during this period
column53: from 53 different countries.\u00c2\u00a0\n96% of the total global volume of requests originated from five countries: Japan
column54: Russia
column55: South Korea
column56: Turkey
column57: and India.\u00c2\u00a0\nThese requests impacted approximately 13% fewer accounts compared to the previous reporting period.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe received 19% more reports based on local law(s) from trusted reporters and non-governmental organizations
column58: impacting approximately 7% more accounts
column59: compared to the previous reporting period.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next?\u00c2\u00a0\nAs noted throughout the report
column60: the COVID-19 pandemic did significantly disrupt our content moderation work during this time - a disruption that is reflected in much of the data presented today. Our enforcement teams have adjusted their approach in the context of a pandemic and are continuing to increase their capacity to get back to the strong pre-COVID levels of enforcement that is expected.\nThere will always be more work to do in this space
column61: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to provide biannual Twitter Transparency Reports that offer more clarity into our operations and work to protect the public conversation.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe also recognize the importance of measuring prevalence of certain content on Twitter
column62: and we have begun a multi-year initiative to enable us to provide more consistent transparency on these issues. We look forward to sharing more details in due course.\u00c2\u00a0\nFollow @Policy and @TwitterSafety for updates on our policies and our work on transparency throughout the year.\u00c2\u00a0\n*Unless prohibited from doing so
column63: we continue to publish these legal requests when we take action directly to the Lumen Database
column64:
a partnership with Harvardâs Berkman Klein Center for Internet & Society.

column3: "title": "Permanent suspension of @realDonaldTrump"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Permanent suspension of @realDonaldTrump
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8:
8 January 2021
Link copied successfully
After close review of recent Tweets from the @realDonaldTrump account and the context around them â specifically how they are being received and interpreted on and off Twitter â we have permanently suspended the account due to the risk of further incitement of violence.Â 
In the context of horrific events this week
column9: we made it clear on Wednesday that additional violations of the Twitter Rules would potentially result in this very course of action. Our public interest framework exists to enable the public to hear from elected officials and world leaders directly. It is built on a principle that the people have a right to hold power to account in the open.\u00c2\u00a0\nHowever
column10: we made it clear going back years that these accounts are not above our rules entirely and cannot use Twitter to incite violence
column11:
among other things. We will continue to be transparent around our policies and their enforcement.Â 
The below is a comprehensive analysis of our policy enforcement approach in this case.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Overview
On January 8
column13: President Donald J. Trump Tweeted:\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cThe 75
column15: 000 great American Patriots who voted for me
column16: AMERICA FIRST
column17: and MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN
column18: will have a GIANT VOICE long into the future. They will not be disrespected or treated unfairly in any way
column19: shape or form!!!\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nShortly thereafter
column20: the President Tweeted:\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cTo all of those who have asked
column21: I will not be going to the Inauguration on January 20th.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nDue to the ongoing tensions in the United States
column22: and an uptick in the global conversation in regards to the people who violently stormed the Capitol on January 6
column24: these two Tweets must be read in the context of broader events in the country and the ways in which the President\u00e2\u0080\u0099s statements can be mobilized by different audiences
column25: including to incite violence
column26: as well as in the context of the pattern of behavior from this account in recent weeks. After assessing the language in these Tweets against our Glorification of Violence policy
column27: we have determined that these Tweets are in violation of the Glorification of Violence Policy and the user @realDonaldTrump should be immediately permanently suspended from the service.\nAssessment\nWe\u00c2\u00a0assessed the two Tweets referenced above under our Glorification of Violence policy
column28: which aims to prevent the glorification of violence that could inspire others to replicate violent acts and determined that they were highly likely to encourage and inspire people to replicate the criminal acts that took place at the U.S. Capitol on January 6
column29: 2021.\nThis determination is based on a number of factors
column30: including:\nPresident Trump\u00e2\u0080\u0099s statement that he will not be attending the Inauguration is being received by a number of his supporters as further confirmation that the election was not legitimate and is seen as him disavowing his previous claim made via two Tweets (1
column31: 2) by his Deputy Chief of Staff
column32: Dan Scavino
column33: that there would be an \u00e2\u0080\u009corderly transition\u00e2\u0080\u009d on January 20th.\nThe second Tweet may also serve as encouragement to those potentially considering violent acts that the Inauguration would be a \u00e2\u0080\u009csafe\u00e2\u0080\u009d target
column34: as he will not be attending.\u00c2\u00a0\nThe use of the words \u00e2\u0080\u009cAmerican Patriots\u00e2\u0080\u009d to describe some of his supporters is also being interpreted as support for those committing violent acts at the US Capitol.\nThe mention of his supporters having a \u00e2\u0080\u009cGIANT VOICE long into the future\u00e2\u0080\u009d and that \u00e2\u0080\u009cThey will not be disrespected or treated unfairly in any way
column35: shape or form!!!\u00e2\u0080\u009d is being interpreted as further indication that President Trump does not plan to facilitate an \u00e2\u0080\u009corderly transition\u00e2\u0080\u009d and instead that he plans to continue to support
column36: empower
column37: and shield those who believe he won the election.\u00c2\u00a0\nPlans for future armed protests have already begun proliferating on and off-Twitter
column38: including a proposed secondary attack on the US Capitol and state capitol buildings on January 17
column39: 2021.\u00c2\u00a0\nAs such
column40: our determination is that the two Tweets above are likely to inspire others to replicate the violent acts that took place on January 6
column42:
and that there are multiple indicators that they are being received and understood as encouragement to do so.
