column3: "title": "Looking ahead to 2021: Twitter Data Partners weigh in"
column7: "post_text": "Insights\nLooking ahead to 2021: Twitter Data Partners weigh in\nFriday
column8:
18 December 2020
Link copied successfully
Itâs hard to believe almost an entire year has gone by since our first blog featuring our Twitter Official Data partners who shared their 2020 perspectives on Twitter data and future trends. Weâve brought them back to hear their thoughts on what 2021 has in store and how brands should think about using data to inform their strategy next year. Hereâs what they had to say:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Social offers brands a real-time view of culture as it evolves. Marketers who tap into social data effectively can spot rising trends
column9: uncover new perspectives and challenge assumptions about their customers. These social data leaders are the brands to watch in 2021.\nJamie Gilpin\nCMO
column10: Sprout Social\n\u00e2\u0080\u008e@jamiewo\u00e2\u0080\u008e\nThe spread of COVID-19 has significantly changed our ways of living
column11: including behavioral patterns. Many communications that were traditionally done offline are now moving online. We live in a world where those VoC and engagements happening on Twitter are critically important for marketers to drive business gains.\nTakumi Ryujin\nExecutive Manager
column12: NTT Data\n\u00e2\u0080\u008e@nttdata_nazuki\u00e2\u0080\u008e\nCustomer Experience Management (CXM) is the next CRM. As brands focus on building their CXM practices
column13: they will discover that Twitter is strategically critical because Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s open format makes it the perfect place for brands to Listen to
column14: Learn from
column15: and Love their customers.\nGrad Conn\n Chief Experience Experience Officer
column16: Sprinklr\n\u00e2\u0080\u008e@gradconn\u00e2\u0080\u008e\nConsumer needs in the pandemic forced years of digital transformation into months. Our clients and our data tell us there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s no slow down in how those needs are evolving. So agility is the core theme: how well can your org loop through input
column17: adjust
column18: execute? Repeatedly.\nWill McInnes\nChief Marketing Office
column19: Brandwatch \n\u00e2\u0080\u008e@willmcinnes\u00e2\u0080\u008e\nThe fastest and most relevant real-time information is vital for corporate enterprises as they navigate a world of unexpected events that can impact their people
column20: assets and brand. Enterprises must equip themselves with new technologies to meet the challenges of this environment.\nTed Bailey\nCEO and Chairman
column21: Dataminr\n\u00e2\u0080\u008e@TedBailey\u00e2\u0080\u008e\nAs we look into 2021
column22: there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s one thing that we know is true: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s never been more important for brands to stay agile and adapt business strategies to the evolving needs of customers. Twitter will continue to be the heart of what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening
column23: and with the help of Twitter Official data partners
column24: brands can stay tapped into the pulse of the ever-changing conversation.\u00c2\u00a0\nTo learn more about the Twitter Official data partners
column25:
head to partners.twitter.com.

column3: "title": "Our plans to relaunch verification and what\u2019s next"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Our plans to relaunch verification and whatâs next
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 17 December 2020\nLink copied successfully\nA couple of weeks ago
column9: we announced that we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re planning to bring back our public verification program in 2021
column10: shared a draft of our new policy
column11: and asked for public feedback to help shape our approach. This new policy will lay the foundation for future improvements by defining what verification means
column12: who is eligible for verification and why some accounts might lose verification to ensure the program is more equitable.\nPublic feedback has become a critical part of our policy development process by making sure our policies reflect the global nature of our service and the people who use it. In the two weeks during our public feedback period
column13: we received more than 22
column14:
000 survey responses and learned so much about how we can improve our policy. Thank you for all you shared!Â 
How your feedback shaped our policy
Here are some of the areas weâve updated in our new verification policy based on your feedback: 
We heard feedback that some of the criteria for a profile to be considered âcompleteâ feels too restrictive
column15:
so we updated our definition to no longer require a profile bio or header image.Â 
We updated our references to Wikipedia to better align with the encyclopedias' published standards for notability and article quality.
Weâve clarified the titles of the âNewsâ category to include âNews and Journalistsâ and the âSportsâ category to include âSports and esports'' to be more inclusive. We also added a reference in our âEntertainmentâ category to more clearly include digital content creators.Â 
We heard feedback that measuring the minimum follower count requirement on a per-country basis wasnât always the right approach
column16: so we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve updated this to be on a per-region basis to make our follower count requirements less susceptible to spam and more equitable across geographies.\nMany of you suggested we add categories for verification including academics
column17: scientists and religious leaders
column18: and we plan to explore adding dedicated categories for these to the policy some time next year. Until then
column19: any of these individuals may qualify under the \u00e2\u0080\u009cActivists
column20: organizers
column21: and other influential individuals\u00e2\u0080\u009d category. For example
column22: since March 2020
column23: we have been working with global public health authorities to identify experts Tweeting about COVID-19 and have already verified hundreds of accounts as a part of this collaboration. These verifications will not be impacted by the new policy given the ongoing commitment to elevating credible information as it relates to the current public health crisis.\u00c2\u00a0\nYou can read our new verification policy here
column24: or you can tap on the blue verified badge in-app or on the web to learn more.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll begin enforcing this policy on January 22
column26:
which is also when weâll begin automatically removing the verified badge from inactive and incomplete accounts. Our new policy defines a complete account as one that has all of the following:Â 
either a verified email address or phone number
a profile image
a display name
If your account is at risk of losing its verified badge
column27: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll receive an automated email and an in-app notification informing you of what changes need to be made to avoid automatic removal of your blue verified badge. As long as you make those changes before January 22
column29: your account will not lose its badge. We are not planning to automatically remove the verified badge from inactive accounts of people who are no longer living
column30: and are working on building a way to memorialize these accounts in 2021. \nUnder our policy
column31: we may also remove verification from accounts that are found to be in severe or repeated violation of the Twitter Rules. We will continue to evaluate such accounts on a case-by-case basis
column32: and will make improvements in 2021 on the relationship between enforcement of our rules and verification. As always
column33: everyone on Twitter is subject to the Twitter Rules
column34:
and you can read more about our range of enforcement actions here.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
How to apply for verification in 2021
We are excited to relaunch public applications for verification in 2021 through a new
column35:
self-serve application process that will be available on the Account Settings page on the web and in-app. The process will include asking applicants to select a category for their verified status and confirming their identity via links and other supporting materials.Â 
We plan to use both automated and human review processes to ensure that we are reviewing applications thoughtfully and in a timely manner. We also plan to give people the option to share demographic information after completing the new verification application so that we can better measure and improve the equity of our verification process. Weâll share more details about the application process soon.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Whatâs next?
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Verification is just one part of our work to help people understand who theyâre interacting with on Twitter. We know that itâs not always easy to evaluate the authenticity of accounts on the internet
column36:
and that understanding who youâre interacting with is core to the public conversation.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
When it comes to helping people trust who theyâre interacting with on Twitter
column37: bios
column38: Tweet content
column39: mutual follows and profile information provide helpful context. This is why we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve started rolling out profile labels for political candidates
column40: government accounts
column41: and state-affiliated media. In addition to the changes we're making as we re-introduce verification
column42: we're also working on new ways to designate different account types
column43: starting with:\nAutomated Accounts: Accounts that post to Twitter automatically
column44: also called bots
column45: can bring a lot of value to the service when they share things like\u00c2\u00a0earthquake reports\u00c2\u00a0or\u00c2\u00a0self care reminders. But it can be confusing to people if it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not clear that these accounts are automated. In 2021
column46: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re planning to build a new account type to distinguish automated accounts from human-run accounts to make it easier for people to know what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a bot and what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not.\nMemorial Accounts: We know how important it is to preserve a Twitter account in memory of someone who has passed and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve talked about building Memorial Accounts\u00c2\u00a0before. In 2021
column47: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re planning to build a new account type specifically designed for memorialized accounts. This will also come with an updated policy for memorialization and a new application flow to request the memorialization of an account.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur work here is far from finished
column48: but we want to give you a look ahead at what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re doing in this space so you can understand our approach. We are excited to relaunch verification and start rolling out these new account types
column49: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll share more soon. Thank you to everyone who provided feedback during the public comment period for helping us shape our new policy!\u00c2\u00a0\n\u00c2\u00a0\n* We\u00c2\u00a0had originally planned to begin enforcing this policy on January 20
column51: but we have changed the date to January 22
column52:
2021.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "COVID-19: Our approach to misleading vaccine information"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nCOVID-19: Our approach to misleading vaccine information\nWednesday
column8: 16 December 2020\nLink copied successfully\nEffective November 23
column10:
Twitter is no longer enforcing the COVID-19 misleading information policy.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As the world continues to fight the COVID-19 pandemic and prepare for the global distribution of vaccines
column11: people continue to turn to Twitter to discuss what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening and find the latest authoritative public health information.\u00c2\u00a0\nEarlier this year
column12: we shared our approach around the conversation surrounding COVID-19 on Twitter and today we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re providing additional guidance on how we plan to address misleading information around COVID-19 vaccinations. Starting next week
column13: we will prioritize the removal of the most harmful misleading information
column14: and during the coming weeks
column15:
begin to label Tweets that contain potentially misleading information about the vaccines.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Our expanded approach
In the context of a global pandemic
column16: vaccine misinformation presents a significant and growing public health challenge \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and we all have a role to play. We are focused on mitigating misleading information that presents the biggest potential harm to people's health and wellbeing. Twitter has an important role to play as a place for good faith public debate and discussion around these critical public health matters.\nUnder our current policy
column17: we already require the removal of Tweets that include false or misleading information about:\u00c2\u00a0\nThe nature of the virus
column18: such as how it spreads within communities;\nThe efficacy and/or safety of preventative measures
column19: treatments
column20: or other precautions to mitigate or treat the disease;\u00c2\u00a0\nOfficial regulations
column21: restrictions
column22:
or exemptions pertaining to health advisories; andÂ 
The prevalence or risk of infection or death.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Moving forward and beginning next week
column23: we are expanding the policy and may require people to remove Tweets which advance harmful false or misleading narratives about COVID-19 vaccinations
column24: including:\u00c2\u00a0\nFalse claims that suggest immunizations and vaccines are used to intentionally cause harm to or control populations
column25: including statements about vaccines that invoke a deliberate conspiracy;\nFalse claims which have been widely debunked about the adverse impacts or effects of receiving vaccinations; or\nFalse claims that COVID-19 is not real or not serious
column26: and therefore that vaccinations are unnecessary.\nStarting in early 2021
column27: we may label or place a warning on Tweets that advance unsubstantiated rumors
column28: disputed claims
column29:
as well as incomplete or out-of-context information about vaccines. Tweets that are labeled under this expanded guidance may link to authoritative public health information or the Twitter Rules to provide people with additional context and authoritative information about COVID-19.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Whatâs next
Using a combination of technology and human review
column30: we will begin enforcing this updated policy on December 21
column31: and expanding our actions during the following weeks. We will enforce this policy in close consultation with local
column32: national and global public health authorities around the world
column33: and will strive to be iterative and transparent in our approach. We remained focused on helping people find credible health information
column34: verifying public health experts
column35:
and updating our policies in an iterative and transparent approach.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet

column3: "title": "Expanding our commitment to brand safety"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Expanding our commitment to brand safety
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 14 December 2020\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s purpose is to serve the public conversation and we are committed to creating a healthy environment where everyone
column9: including advertisers
column10: can participate and engage safely. We know there is a lot of work to be done to achieve this
column11:
and we are actively working with key industry partners to advance brand safety as a central component of the advertising and measurement solutions on Twitter.
Hereâs a look at our areas of focus ahead of 2021:Â 
Doubling down on third-party brand safety measurement solutions.
Today
column12: we're excited to announce that we've selected DoubleVerify (DV) and Integral Ad Science (IAS) to be Twitter's preferred partners for providing independent reporting on the context in which ads appear on Twitter. We see this as an opportunity to build solutions that will give advertisers a better understanding of the types of content that appear adjacent to their ads
column13: helping them make informed decisions to reach their marketing goals. These solutions will complement our existing third-party viewability measurement solutions with DV and IAS.\nOver the past five months
column14: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve engaged in a rigorous process to select partners from a slate of third-party measurement vendors. We are excited to make this announcement
column15: knowing that there has never been a third-party brand safety solution built to measure for adjacency to brand unsafe content in an environment like Twitter
column16:
which is both real-time and dynamic.Â We look forward to partnering with both DV and IAS to create custom solutions for our unique platform and we intend to start testing solutions in early 2021.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Measuring brand safety and suitability across in-feed environments is critically important for brands. DV is ready to tackle this challenge by leveraging our technology and expertise to evaluate the context of real-time
column17:
user-generated content. We are pleased to partner with Twitter to ensure a brand safe and suitable advertising environment on their platform.
Mark Zagorski
CEO at DoubleVerify
â@markzagsâ
IAS is excited to partner with Twitter to pioneer in-feed brand safety and suitability solutions that will help advertisers navigate this dynamic social environment. Measurement is more critical than ever as marketers seek even greater transparency for their social media spend
column18:
and together with Twitter we can offer advertisers the trusted solutions they need.
Lisa Utzschneider
CEO at Integral Ad Science
â@Lisa_Utzâ
Our commitment to MRC accreditation.Â 
Last week
column19: we also shared our commitment to undergo the accreditation process across all four of the Media Ratings Council\u00e2\u0080\u0099s offered Accreditation Services: Viewability
column20: Sophisticated Invalid Traffic Filtration
column21: Audience Measurement
column22: and Brand Safety. We will be prioritizing the Brand Safety audit first
column23: and have already started the proposal process for this accreditation.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe believe that all four accreditations are critical in demonstrating our enduring commitment to transparency and are pleased to be in a position to expand on and sustain this collaborative process. We look forward to working with the MRC and further aligning on scope
column24: sequencing
column25: and timing.\nContinued partnership with industry leaders.\u00c2\u00a0\nTwitter is an active and founding member of the Global Alliance for Responsible Media (GARM). In conjunction with our ongoing efforts to better align our brand safety solutions with GARM\u00e2\u0080\u0099s principles
column26: we support\u00c2\u00a0DV and IAS in their efforts to adapt their current categorization frameworks to better map to the harmful monetized content categories identified by the GARM
column27: the 4A\u00e2\u0080\u0099s APB
column28: and the ANA. We will continue to partner with industry leaders to define and refine the work that is needed to keep platforms safe for advertisers.\u00c2\u00a0\nUnlocking research to learn more.\u00c2\u00a0\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s personalized feed-based environment makes content adjacency inherently unique when considering brand safety questions. It is critical to understand where associations occur
column29: where they don't
column30: and how those associations affect brands as we continue to invest in this area. Early research done by Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s data science teams indicates that on our platform
column31: adjacency between ads and divisive content has not yet been found to affect brand favorability. Currently
column32:
we are working on additional research to gain more knowledge and insight around the impact of adjacency on Twitter ads. We look forward to incorporating these findings into our ongoing work with DV and IAS and using it to inform how we build and iterate on our advertising products.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Source: Twitter Brand Surveys last exposure respondent level data from April - July 2020
column33: Studies n = 82
column34: Observations n = 150
column36:
US 
          
          
        
Marching towards 2021.Â 
We are excited to build on the existing momentum with our brand safety partners and to develop innovative solutions for our customers that help push our industry forward. We will continue to be transparent in all our efforts and keep you updated along the way. Most importantly
column37: we are ready to do the work.\nStudy Methodology: We analyzed Twitter Brand Survey data from April to July 2020
column38: which included 50
column39: 000 respondents who were exposed to 1
column40: 200 Promoted Tweets. For the purposes of this study
column41: we used a broad definition of divisive content
column42: inclusive of 11 content categories including Politics
column43: Social Movements
column44: Ongoing News and Protests. For the purposes of this study
column45: adjacency was defined broadly as any of the two Tweets above and the two Tweets below each of the Promoted Tweets and we analyzed results based on content both 1 and 2 spots away from ads. Analysis was performed both in aggregate and specific to each of the 11 categories of divisive content to determine if adjacency to certain types of divisiveness alter people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s opinion of adjacent brands. Results showed no evidence of any effect on brand favorability when ads were adjacent to any of the studied categories of divisive content
column46:
regardless of the distance of the adjacency.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet

ads
brands
health
partnerships
transparency

column3: "title": "Inclusion & Diversity Q4 2020: Leadership
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/company/2020/inclusion-and-diversity-report-q4-2020-leadership-transparency-and-accountability"
column8: "post_text": "Company\nInclusion & Diversity Q4 2020: Leadership
column9: transparency & accountability\nThursday
column10: 10 December 2020\nLink copied successfully\nAs 2020 comes to a close
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll see a proliferation of year-in-review pieces highlighting how companies have navigated a remarkably unprecedented year. At Twitter
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re proud of how we have continuously pivoted
column13: first to protect and support employees during a global pandemic
column14:
and next by doubling down on our commitment to understanding and combating systemic racism and anti-Blackness in the United States and around the world.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
But it would be a disservice to all of the hard work thatâs occurred across our business to solely focus on the curveballs the year has thrown us. At the beginning of the year we unveiled a bold new vision for 2025 and our initial plan for the hard work required to drive progress across the company. Iâm proud to say that despite the unpredictable nature of 2020
column15: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve still made meaningful progress against these goals
column16: and I want to tell you about it.\nFirst
column17: a quick refresher on the vision we set forth early this year: by 2025
column18: at least half of our global workforce will be women
column19: and at least a quarter of our US workforce will be underrepresented minorities. Check out our Q4 diversity numbers to see the steady progress we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made in 2020.\nAlong with that bold vision
column20: as a company we doubled down on deeper commitments across leadership
column21: transparency
column22:
and accountability â all to drive progress along our journey to be the worldâs most diverse and inclusive tech company.Â  Here are a few highlights from our work across the company:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Accountability
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Accountability starts at the top. So in addition to the company-wide goals set for workforce representation
column23: we worked with our executive team to clearly define their proportional share of responsibility for driving progress
column24: taking into account the size of the businesses they lead
column25: their open headcount
column26: projected pace of hiring
column27: and average attrition rates.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn order for our approach to work
column28: every employee at Twitter needs to be aligned on what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re trying to achieve \u00e2\u0080\u0094 not just the executive team. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why in 2019 we created an internal diversity dashboard so any Tweep can track in real time how we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re doing against our workforce representation goals by gender (global) and race/ethnicity (US)
column29: with filters for leadership and technical/nontechnical roles \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and hold us accountable.\nWe recently launched version 3.0 of our diversity dashboard which dramatically expands transparency across these metrics
column30: providing visibility across the board to give Tweeps the opportunity to critically examine how their team is doing and be part of the solution. In version 3.0
column31:
the only instances where we restrict visibility on the diversity dashboard is when the size of the team is too small to maintain the privacy of our Tweeps.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Note: For illustration purposes only 
          
          
        
Responsibility for I&D progress belongs to all of us. Thatâs why the new dashboard also includes an action roadmap that outlines five simple steps every Tweep can take to drive progress in their part of the business.
Remind their teams about voluntary Self ID in Workday. By choosing to participate
column32: each Tweep can help ensure the numbers above reflect the true makeup of their team.\nJoin a Global Business Resource Group (BRG) and participate as a team in BRG events. BRGs are Tweep-led
column33: and advocate for underrepresented communities while fostering a diverse and inclusive workplace.\nCheck to ensure everyone on their team has completed our I&D trainings: \u00e2\u0080\u009cHealthy Conversations
column34: \u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\u009cWords Matter
column35:
â and âAllyship 101.â
Develop an action plan to improve their teamâs Inclusion Scores on the next employee engagement. 
Schedule an hour for their team to watch a #TwitterTogetherTalk (e.g. âHow to be an Anti-Racistâ or Criminal Justice Reform) and host a debrief using our discussion guides.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Transparency
We also spent 2020 exploring ways to build on our industry-leading transparency on workforce representation to include impact or outcome-based metrics. One of the things we are looking at is representation in leadership roles and pay equity. Our first step in this new area examines differences by gender
column36: which we will share in our annual report early next year. Work is also underway to increase pay transparency and starting in 2021
column37: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll share with Tweeps the pay bands for their individual position.\u00c2\u00a0\nAnother important body of work this year was around promotions. Like most companies
column38: we often get questions from Tweeps who want to better understand how promo decisions are made. So in addition to sharing with Tweeps the results of a review of the audit of promo data that we conducted
column39: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve launched a Consistency & Fairness Taskforce to review our promotions process across Twitter from end to end. This work will explore new measures to disrupt potential bias: a data-informed promotion readiness pipeline; increased transparency and consistency in the frequency
column40:
makeup and process of promotion committees; and increased communications and training about the process.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Finally
column41: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re pleased to have made even more strides this year in inclusive hiring (check out our\u00c2\u00a0career site\u00c2\u00a0for open roles!). Building on learnings from a pilot program in 2019
column42: we have expanded our Diverse Slates Initiative (DSI) from Senior Director roles to all Manager and above roles across the company. Moving forward
column43: for a hiring decision to be made on any open role
column44:
at least one woman (global) and one Black or Latinx candidate (US) must have been considered by the interview panel.Â 
The expanded DSI is complemented by an Inclusive Hiring e-learning module centered on five principles we want every Tweep to understand and follow:
Always hire the most qualified candidate.
Start with a candidate pool that reflects our communities.
Ensure a fair and equitable hiring process.
Map candidates to core competencies and our values â hire for culture add not culture fit.
Lead with diversity and inclusion throughout the interview experience.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Taking stock of what actually went right in 2020 is quite the flex. But in retrospect
column45: the strides we made across our inclusion and diversity efforts in leadership
column46: transparency and accountability are significant. They represent the extraordinary efforts of Tweeps across every part of our business. Thanks to them
column47: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re continuing to take bold steps. Each is intended to push us
column48: and our industry
column49: forward. And we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re not stopping
column50:
#UntilWeAllBelong.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@TwitterTogether
#UntilWeAllBelong
Tweet

diversity
#UntilWeAllBelong

column3: "title": "Crossroads for the Open Internet"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Crossroads for the Open Internet
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8:
9 December 2020
Link copied successfully
This letter was jointly written by;Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The future of the Internet is at a crossroads
column9: in Europe and around the world.\u00c2\u00a0 \nThe laws that laid a foundation for the spectacular growth of the Internet \u00e2\u0080\u0093 with its economic
column10: social
column11: and cultural revelations \u00e2\u0080\u0093 are now being reviewed to assess whether they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re fit for the next generation. Indeed
column12: as concern grows in Europe regarding the impact of digital technology and repressive regimes around the world use draconian legal frameworks to stifle online freedoms
column13: the norms that inform new EU legislation has never been more important.\u00c2\u00a0\nThe Digital Services Act and the Democracy Action Plan will either renew the promise of the Open Internet or compound a problematic status quo \u00e2\u0080\u0093 by limiting our online environment to a few dominant gatekeepers
column14:
while failing to meaningfully address the challenges preventing the Internet from realising its potential.
Weâre writing to you today as a group of companies to advocate for a regulatory conversation around illegal and harmful content that firmly roots Open Internet principles at the heart of the EUâs digital future.Â 
There are many other companies and organisations that share the views set out here â we welcome their collaboration in the coming discussions.
CONTENT AND SPEECH
Unfortunately
column15: the present conversation is too often framed through the prism of content removal alone
column16: where success is judged solely in terms of ever-more content removal in ever-shorter periods of time. Without question
column17: illegal content \u00e2\u0080\u0093 including terrorist content and child sexual abuse material \u00e2\u0080\u0093 must be removed expeditiously. Indeed
column18: many creative self-regulatory initiatives proposed by the European Commission have demonstrated the effectiveness of an EU-wide approach.\u00c2\u00a0\nYet by limiting policy options to a solely stay up-come down binary
column19: we forgo promising alternatives that could better address the spread and impact of problematic content while safeguarding rights and the potential for smaller companies to compete. Indeed
column20: removing content cannot be the sole paradigm of Internet policy
column21: particularly when concerned with the phenomenon of \u00e2\u0080\u0098legal-but-harmful\u00e2\u0080\u0099 content. Such an approach would benefit only the very largest companies in our industry.\nWe therefore encourage a content moderation discussion that emphasises the difference between illegal and harmful content and highlights the potential of interventions that address how content is surfaced and discovered. Included in this is how consumers are offered real choice in the curation of their online environment.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe believe that it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s both more sustainable and more holistically effective to focus on limiting the number of people who encounter harmful content. This can be achieved by placing a technological emphasis on visibility over prevalence
column22: supporting measures towards algorithmic transparency and control
column23: setting limits to the discoverability of harmful content
column24: further exploring community moderation
column25: and providing meaningful user choice. The tactics will vary from service to service but the underlying approach will be familiar.\u00c2\u00a0\nBy focusing on these kinds of metrics and developing corresponding transparency standards
column26: EU policy interventions can better tackle the harms associated with problematic content online
column27: while mitigating the negative impact on freedom of expression that blunt content removal obligations entail.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe further support a harmonised notice-and-action mechanism for illegal content as proposed by the D9+ group
column28: which would clarify obligations and provide legal certainty in situations where content removal is the most appropriate solution
column29: without overburdening SMEs or limiting users\u00e2\u0080\u0099 rights to redress. Notice-and-action mechanisms should also include measures proportionate to the nature and impact of the illegal content in question.\u00c2\u00a0\nREGULATION FOR A NEW GENERATION\nIn the digital world
column30: content policy can influence the shape of markets. \u00e2\u0080\u009cOne-size-fits-all\u00e2\u0080\u009d approaches that fail to consider the vast array of differentiated services that make up our online environment risk having a disproportionate \u00e2\u0080\u0093 and potentially crippling \u00e2\u0080\u0093 impact on smaller players
column31: thereby inadvertently helping to entrench large companies that have greater compliance resources.\u00c2\u00a0\nTherefore
column32: as regulatory mechanisms are considered
column33: we recommend a tech-neutral and human rights-based approach to ensure legislation transcends individual companies and technological cycles. Interventions like the recent EU Copyright directive remind us that there are major drawbacks in prescribing generalised compliance solutions. These solutions have a regressive impact on smaller players and perversely incentivise the deployment of flawed technology. Moreover
column34: we simply cannot anticipate how burgeoning technology will shape the services and platforms we use today. Consequently
column35: our rules must be sufficiently flexible to accommodate and allow for the harnessing of sectoral shifts
column36: such as the rise of decentralised hosting of content and data.\u00c2\u00a0\nThis far-sighted approach can be ensured by developing regulatory proposals that optimise for effective collaboration and meaningful transparency between three core groups: companies
column37: regulators and civil society. While companies must take primary responsibility for designing and operating their services with diligence and care
column38: co-regulatory oversight grounded in regional and global norms can ensure these efforts are effective
column39: durable
column40: and protective of individuals\u00e2\u0080\u0099 rights.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe believe these positions and principles offer a path to an online society that renews the original promise of the Internet while deftly meeting our shared challenges. We ask the Commission
column41: Parliament
column42: Member States
column43: and all stakeholders to consider our collective views while developing these historic laws which will likely govern our online lives for a generation
column44: while setting another groundbreaking precedent for the world to follow.\u00c2\u00a0 \nIn sum
column45: we ask the EU to defend the Open Internet.\u00c2\u00a0\nSigned
column46: \n@Policy
column47: @Mozilla
column48: @Automattic
column49:
@VimeoÂ

Spending 2020 Together on Twitter

Monday
column8: 7 December 2020\nLink copied successfully\nFor over a decade
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve released a year in review report
column10: recapping the trends
column11: the moments
column12: and the memes that dominated Twitter that year. But 2020 is different. The world saw heartbreaking loss but also tremendous courage. How do we possibly recap a year like this? By turning our attention to how we all got through it together: the ways we kept ourselves entertained
column13: the changes we made
column14: and the messages of support that we shared with each other. If you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re over 2020
column15: we get it; if you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re curious to see how the world conversed
column16: coped
column17: and even celebrated this year
column18: read on for a brief tour through the Tweets of 2020.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn the midst of everything that happened in the world this year
column19: Twitter was the place where we came together to keep our sanity during quarantine
column20: be forces of change
column21: and yes
column22: still jump in on the latest viral meme.\n#ThisHappened on Twitter:\u00c2\u00a0\nThe most Retweeted and top Liked Tweets of the year encapsulate the full spectrum of life in 2020: loss

making the Tweet announcing his tragic passing the most Retweeted of the year and the most Liked of all time.

column3: "title": " The state of social intelligence: 2020 year in review"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
 The state of social intelligence: 2020 year in review
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 7 December 2020\nLink copied successfully\nAlthough it seems like a lifetime
column9: it was only a year ago that I published my\u00c2\u00a02019 social intelligence year in review. Back then
column10: I observed that individuals and organizations were finally discovering the unique role that social data
column11: in concert with other data sources
column12: can play in helping to solve real business problems.\nWhile the uptake in digital data sources by\u00c2\u00a0 the research industry was well underway
column13: little could I have imagined that a global pandemic would soon accelerate these dynamics
column14: as almost overnight the world moved online. As one research agency friend put it: \u00e2\u0080\u009cCovid-19 probably condensed three to four years of market research evolution into three or four months.\" And as brands have become accustomed to these new approaches to conducting research and gathering insight
column15: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s hard to imagine a rush back to the more traditional resource-heavy
column16: set-piece approaches of the past.\nSo
column17: as we exit this most unusual of years
column18: what are the main trends driving the awareness and adoption of social intelligence today? In my conversations with social intelligence practitioners
column19: four themes emerged that are changing market research more broadly
column20: thus presenting an opportunity for social intelligence to shine.\u00c2\u00a0 \n1. Speed to insight\u00c2\u00a0 Clients are pushing to reduce the use of traditional
column21: ad hoc market research projects in favour of quicker
column22: more cost-effective approaches that provide real-time
column23: behavioural insights. Speed to insight has always been a strength of social data. Not only does it give researchers instant access to millions of public consumer opinions on just about any topic imaginable
column24: accessing that treasure trove of insight is a fraction of the cost of traditional research methods with similar sample sizes. Furthermore
column25: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s reusable
column26: with multiple projects able to repurpose the same data sets in support of different research questions. If you are looking for speed and value for money
column27: social delivers.\n2. Explosion of external data sources 20 years ago
column28: if you wanted market share data
column29: you had a very small group of providers to choose from. Today
column30: you can get this data from dozens of sources. And as the importance and value of data have grown
column31: many companies are now monetizing their own unique data sets. Everyone
column32: it seems
column33: is a data provider. The challenge now is in choosing the most relevant data set for the problem at hand or the question being asked. And far from being lost among these myriad data sources
column34: social data is carving out an important place for itself
column35: chiefly as a unique window into real observed human behaviours
column36: with several advantages over traditional insight gathering techniques. \nFirst
column37: its unprompted nature gets around one of the big challenges of research\u00e2\u0080\u0094the introduction of bias by the questions being asked. Secondly
column38: social posts are sent in the moment
column39: when the consumer is actually having the experience
column40: therefore representing a much richer and authentic view of\u00c2\u00a0consumers\u00e2\u0080\u0099 true feelings\u00c2\u00a0on a topic
column41: as opposed to asking them to recount that experience days or weeks later and out of the context in which they had it. This feature of social data should not be underestimated
column42: for very little market research delivered today is conducted with that type of context in mind.\nAnd finally
column43: social data\u00e2\u0080\u0099s continuous nature allows you to move away from the one-and-done practice that has historically characterized market research projects and towards a longitudinal approach to data gathering. This allows you to see trends emerge over time. It also has the added advantage of allowing you to go back and analyze a topic retrospectively
column44: uncovering views and attitudes preserved in time
column45: forever.\n3. DIY meets data integration Historically
column46: full-service research agencies provided both the data and the insights
column47: but they are now increasingly seeing competition from their very own clients. The growth of DIY research platforms has allowed brands to insource market research capabilities such as survey creation and distribution. And brands have made data gathering and customer feedback collection an integral part of the user journey and experience
column48: and therefore already know a lot about their customers. When combined
column49: brands are better able to use their customers\u00e2\u0080\u0099 behavioural and transactional data to ask the right questions at the right times
column50: thus providing even more relevant customer insight. \nTo date
column51: social listening tools
column52: a form of DIY research
column53: have been the primary gateway for\u00c2\u00a0organizations to access social data. This is quickly changing as\u00c2\u00a0social data feeds are becoming\u00c2\u00a0increasingly embedded within a wide variety of solutions
column54: ranging from Enterprise Feedback Management to digital data analytics. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s this combination of social data with other data sets that is so promising and
column55: with a little help from artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML)
column56: should provide unique new insights into how people think and behave.\n4. Truly game-changing innovation From the phone survey to the online survey and from social intelligence to artificial intelligence
column57: new sources and techniques have emerged over the years that have improved the diversity and efficiency of data collection and analysis. They have also brought with them a host of new entrants into the industry
column58: whether they be technology providers or tech-enabled specialist consultancies. The adoption of these type of digital analytics providers
column59: for lack of a better term
column60: has expanded the definition of the market research industry and doubled its size
column61: now reckoned to be valued at $90 billion.1\nOne of the big underlying drivers behind this has been a slow but steady move away from question-based research methods and towards observational methodologies such as neuroscience
column62: behavioural economics and data science. Dave Soderberg
column63: Chief Data Officer at Black Swan Data
column64: touched upon this revolution in his excellent blog post on the end of question-based market research. \nData Science in particular
column65: aided by advances in different types of AI such as Natural Language Processing
column66: has allowed us to understand and classify vast amounts of unstructured data (such as social) in a way that was unimaginable even a few years ago. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s this continued innovation that will allow researchers and analysts the ability to finally leverage social data as the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s largest focus group. As Jeremy Hollow
column67: Founder & MD of\u00c2\u00a0Listen + Learn Research\u00c2\u00a0succinctly put it: \u00e2\u0080\u009cWhy are we struggling to recruit people to talk about things they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re already freely talking about on social?\u00e2\u0080\u009d\n2021 and the slope of enlightenment After a year like 2020
column68: it would be foolish to make any predictions about 2021 (as I attempted for 2020)
column69: other than to say that the importance and adoption of social intelligence within the insights world will only continue to grow. Even Gartner now thinks it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s finally entering the \u00e2\u0080\u009cSlope of Enlightenment.\u00e2\u0080\u009d It has certainly been a journey
column70: with social intelligence reaching its formative
column71: teenage years just as market research hits a midlife crisis and tries to redefine itself. So where do we go from here then? I\u00e2\u0080\u0099m reminded of the Royal Society\u00e2\u0080\u0099s motto
column72: \u00e2\u0080\u009cNullius in verba\u00e2\u0080\u009d\u00c2\u00a0- \u00e2\u0080\u009ctake nobody\u00e2\u0080\u0099s word for it.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nIf you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re ready to start your move to social intelligence
column73:
get inspired at data.twitter.com.
1 ESOMAR Global Market Research Study 2020

column3: "title": "Nation states exerting power online - sharing data can guard against it "
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Nation states exerting power online - sharing data can guard against it 
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 26 November 2020\nLink copied successfully\nManipulation of the public conversation is a shared threat we all face
column9: and must all address together.\u00c2\u00a0 \nIt is a human activity that - we all know - has been around for quite some time
column10: and isn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t showing any signs of going away. It pre-dates the Internet and modern communications technology of course
column11: but has adapted and changed as online spaces have emerged to become contested territories of geo-political competition.\nIt would be naive to think that events and conversations in the future will not be targeted by bad actors - in addition to elections
column12: conversations around Covid-19
column13: climate action
column14: identity and civil rights
column15: to name a few
column16: are all vulnerable to similar techniques. We have to respond. The first step towards doing so is by understanding the problem in detail \u00e2\u0080\u0094 a goal that Twitter and think tank Demos believe can best be advanced through transparency and open access to data.\u00c2\u00a0\nPlatforms like Twitter have taken a number of important steps to confront this problem
column17: for example - having a dedicated site integrity team and continuous investment in technology to detect
column18: understand and neutralize these campaigns as quickly and robustly as possible - but technology companies can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t do it alone. Academics
column19: journalists and civil society groups must all be strong - and genuinely independent - voices in the debates related to information operations and how to respond to them. And to achieve this
column20: one thing - above all - is needed: data.\u00c2\u00a0\nData is the bedrock of a strong civic societal response to information operations. It is vital to allow researchers to detect information operations
column21: understand what they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re targeting
column22: what effects they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re having
column23: the interests and organisations that are conducting them and measuring the effectiveness of responses to them. It is the way of making the information operations themselves
column24: and the responses to them
column25: transparent and inclusive.\nTransparency is foundational
column26: indeed
column27: to the kind of Internet that we all want to see - empowering consumers
column28: building trust and strengthening democracies. And it is worth noting here that Twitter is the only major service to make public conversation data available via an API
column29: for the purposes of study. Making this type of data available to researchers has resulted in a number of important benefits.\u00c2\u00a0\nFirst
column30: publicly available data can advance research objectives on a wide range of topics and in a safe
column31: compliant way with the public\u00e2\u0080\u0099s basic expectation of privacy. This has been the case particularly during Covid-19
column32: where we have seen research teams use public Twitter data to map and examine aggregate increases in reported symptoms or anxiety levels.\u00c2\u00a0\nSecond
column33: it raises general awareness and increases understanding more widely of the scale and nature of the challenges impacting the integrity of public conversation online
column34: . This is why in 2018
column35: Twitter committed to disclose publicly
column36: any state-backed information operations that were reliably identified on the service
column37: and to make the full datasets of those operations available for investigation and analysis. Since this first release over two years ago
column38: Twitter has now disclosed over 35 separate state-backed information operations designed to nefariously shape and manipulate public opinion online. Independent analysis of this activity by researchers is a key step toward promoting shared understanding of these threats and to help develop a holistic strategy for addressing them.\nAnd third
column39: making this data available keeps platforms like Twitter accountable for their own response to these challenges. The nature of conversations taking place on Twitter is well-documented and
column40: critically
column41: members of the public
column42: governments
column43: and researchers can bring their expertise to bear to develop solutions for a range of online harms.\u00c2\u00a0However
column44: as Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s CEO
column45: Jack Dorsey has said
column46: there is much more to do when it comes to transparency; and the team within Twitter who work with researchers are part of that
column47: constantly looking for opportunities to provide new data while balancing privacy considerations.\u00c2\u00a0\nThe reality
column48: however
column49: is that there are very different standards for transparency across the industry. One challenge is that so much research of online harms is built on Twitter data because they are one of the few companies to offer it. Another is the amplification of poor quality
column50: non peer-reviewed and misleading \u00e2\u0080\u009cresearch\u00e2\u0080\u009d by some pockets of media and
column51: on occasion
column52: elected officials to suit a predetermined narrative. More broadly
column53: we continue to encourage peer-reviewing of research and data before publication. To not engage in these practices
column54: more often than not
column55: results in public scare-mongering.\nIndependent analysis of these activities by researchers is a key step toward promoting shared understanding of these threats
column56: and this level of transparency can enhance the health of public conversation online
column57: and protect the Open Internet for all. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s our shared responsibility in academia
column58: industry
column59: policymaking
column60: and research to consider how greater data transparency and support for civil society can be at the centre of our response to online harms. That need
column61: much like information operations itself
column63: Twitter and Demos hosted a panel discussion on Data
column64: Research and Information Operations. Moderated by Head of UK Public Policy for Twitter
column65: Katy Minshall
column66: we heard from the expert panel of Carl Miller from Demos
column67:
Nahema Marchal from Oxford Internet Institute and Alex Martin from Sky News.Â 
Highlights of the discussion can be found via #OpenDataUK on Twitter and a recording of the discussion can be found here.Â

column3: "title": "Our work to combat the \u2018shadow pandemic\u2019 "
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Our work to combat the âshadow pandemicâ 
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 24 November 2020\nLink copied successfully\nCases of violence against women have surged in 2020. According to the United Nations Population Fund
column9: for every three months the COVID-19 lockdown continues
column10: an additional 15 million women are expected to be directly affected by violence. As this so-called \u00e2\u0080\u009cshadow pandemic\u00e2\u0080\u009d continues
column11: Twitter will continue to support nonprofit partners working to bring awareness to the uniquely intense strain the pandemic has had on women.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe recognize that access to a free and open internet is essential
column12: as people across the globe turn to social media services like Twitter to discuss women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s rights and other important social issues. In fact
column13: women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s rights have dominated conversations on Twitter this year with 40 million Tweets so far and counting.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn addition
column14: since the start of COVID-19 shelter-in-place orders
column15: there have been 1 million Tweets per month about domestic violence and related issues. Services like Twitter that rely on the open internet are not only a medium for discussing the issues
column16: but
column17: for many
column18: can be a lifeline and a means to seek help.\nAmplifying the conversation on Twitter\nIn partnership with UN Women and the UN Human Rights Office
column19: we are launching custom emojis to spread awareness on International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women on November 25 and Human Rights Day on December 10. The emojis will appear when people Tweet with the hashtags #GenerationEquality
column20: #OrangeTheWorld
column21: #16Days
column22: #HumanRightsDay
column23: and other localized hashtags.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe are supporting local nonprofits across the world by providing Ads for Good grants to several partners to ensure that they can use the power of Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s advertising platform to reach more people. Throughout the next #16Days
column24: we will also amplify various regional campaigns and messages about the importance of gender equality and combatting violence against women to increase engagement and awareness.\u00c2\u00a0\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cWe have seen the whole world respond to the coronavirus pandemic with all hands on deck
column25: and with responsive investment and protocols backed by determination. Violence against women is also a pandemic \u00e2\u0080\u0094 one that predates the virus and will outlive it. As we face COVID-19\u00e2\u0080\u0099s devastation
column26: there has never been a more important moment to put our combined resources and commitment behind the biggest issues
column27: and work with partners like Twitter to end violence against women and girls for good.\u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\u0094 Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka
column28: Executive Director
column29: UN Women\nProviding support and safety resources\u00c2\u00a0 \u00c2\u00a0\nIn addition to elevating the public conversation
column30: we have partnered with health authorities and nonprofit organizations in various markets to expand our #ThereIsHelp notification service. When people search terms associated with gender-based violence on Twitter
column31: they will receive a notification with contact information for local hotlines and other resources to encourage them to reach out for help.\nSince our initial rollout at the start of the COVID-19 pandemic
column32: we have expanded the prompts to reach 24 markets spanning countries such as Australia
column33: India
column34: Mexico
column35: Spain
column36: Thailand
column37: the UK
column38: the US
column39: and more. This month
column40: we rolled out dedicated gender-based violence #ThereIsHelp prompts in Belgium
column41: Canada
column42: France
column43: Germany
column44: and Italy to broaden our support and efforts to provide helpful resources to people in need.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nThe open internet has played a foundational role in the efforts of social media platforms like Twitter to connect people to helpful resources
column45: healthy conversation
column46:
and community. We look forward to continued work to ensure that Twitter remains a safe place for people to shine light on critical and timely issues.
Letâs continue to #OrangeTheWorld one Tweet at a time.Â

column3: "title": "Help us shape our new approach to verification "
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Help us shape our new approach to verification 
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 24 November 2020\nLink copied successfully\nThree years ago
column9: we paused our public verification program after hearing feedback that it felt arbitrary and confusing to many people. A year later
column10: we deprioritized this work further to focus on protecting the integrity of the public conversation around critical moments like the 2020 US election. Since then
column11: we haven\u00e2\u0080\u0099t been clear about who can become verified and when
column12: why an account might be unverified
column13: or what it means to be verified.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe know how important it is to be able to express yourself and understand who you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re talking to on Twitter. So today
column14: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sharing the start of our plans to revamp how people can identify themselves on Twitter
column15: starting with verification and asking the public to share feedback on a draft of our new verification policy. Calling for public feedback has become an important part of our policy development process because we want to ensure that
column16: as an open service
column17: our rules reflect the voices of the people who use Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nBuilding our verification policy\nWe plan to relaunch verification
column18: including a new public application process
column19: in early 2021. But first
column20: we need to update our verification policy with your help. This policy will lay the foundation for future improvements by defining what verification means
column21: who is eligible for verification and why some accounts might lose verification to ensure the process is more equitable.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe're starting by more clearly defining some of the core types of Notable Accounts that are served by verification. Per the proposed policy
column22: \u00e2\u0080\u009cthe blue verified badge on Twitter lets people know that an account of public interest is authentic. To receive the blue badge
column23:
your account must be notable and active.âÂ 
The six types of accounts weâve identified to start are:
Government
Companies
column24:
Brands and Non- Profit Organizations
News
Entertainment
Sports
Activists
column25: Organizers
column26: and Other Influential Individuals\nYou can find more detailed definitions of the criteria above in the draft policy here.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also added proposed criteria to automatically remove verification from an account if
column27: for example
column28: it's inactive or if the profile is incomplete
column29: as well as grounds to deny or remove verification from certain qualified accounts that are found to be in repeated violation of the Twitter Rules. We recognize that there are many verified accounts on Twitter who should not be. We plan to start by automatically removing badges from accounts that are inactive or have incomplete profiles to help streamline our work and to expand this to include additional types of accounts over the course of 2021.\nWe know we can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t solve verification with a new policy alone -- and that this initial policy won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t cover every case for being verified -- but it is a critical first step in helping us provide more transparency and fairer standards for verification on Twitter as we reprioritize this work. This version of the policy is a starting point
column30:
and we intend to expand the categories and criteria for verification significantly over the next year.Â 
We want to hear from you
What do you think? Here is a brief surveyÂ on our draft verification policy. We are also working with local non-governmental organizations and our Trust and Safety Council to ensure as many perspectives are represented as possible.
If you prefer to Tweet your feedback
column31: we'll be listening there
column32: too. Use the hashtag #VerificationFeedback. \nThe public feedback period starts today
column33: November 24
column35: and continues until December 8
column36: 2020. At that point
column37: we'll review public feedback on this policy and train our teams on this new approach. Our goal is to introduce the final policy on December 17
column38: 2020. \nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to serving the public conversation by helping people find credible information
column39: hear important voices
column40: and trust the authenticity of the accounts people find on Twitter. Thank you for taking the time to be part of this process \u00e2\u0080\u0094 we look forward to hearing what you think. \nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next? \nBeing able to express yourself is core to the public conversation
column41: and who you talk to is as important as what they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re saying. We want to make space for everyone on Twitter to express their authentic voices by giving people more ways to identify themselves in their Profiles. The blue verified badge and account labels are two of the ways we help distinguish notable
column42: authentic accounts on Twitter. This year
column43: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve verified medical experts Tweeting about #COVID19 and added account labels to identify candidates running for office.\u00c2\u00a0\nBut the blue verified badge isn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t the only way we are planning to distinguish accounts on Twitter. Heading into 2021
column44: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to giving people more ways to identify themselves
column45:
such as new account types and labels. Weâll share more in the coming weeks. This is just the beginning of what we have planned for 2021.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@TwitterSupport
#VerificationFeedback

column3: "title": "#TwitterForGood Day \u2014 Fall 2020 "
column7:
"post_text": "Company
#TwitterForGood Day â Fall 2020 
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 20 November 2020\nLink copied successfully\nOn October 16
column10: we kicked off our second remote Twitter for Good Day. Even amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic
column11: social unrest
column12: and other challenges this year has brought
column13: Tweeps across the globe were eager to give back and mirror the momentum and morale our nonprofit partners bring to their work everyday.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur #OneTeam had one mission; to bring our company and local communities together to be a force for good. We supported over 80 organizations working on the frontlines of causes ranging from homelessness to breast cancer awareness and all together
column14: our employees volunteered 2
column15:
600 hours around the world! Check out a few highlights from this yearâs #TwitterForGood Day activations.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
APAC 
Twitter Singapore organized an APAC #AuctionForGood
column16: inviting Tweeps from across the region to bid on fellow Tweeps\u00e2\u0080\u0099 auction items which ranged from baked goods to 1:1 training sessions. The #AuctionForGood proceeds were donated to eight charities in the region.\u00c2\u00a0\nTwitter India partnered with our Inclusion and Diversity partners to host an allyship workshop. After the workshop
column17: we hosted a conversation with groups including the\u00c2\u00a0National Campaign on Dalit Human Rights\u00c2\u00a0and Blank Noise\u00c2\u00a0to deepen our understanding of issues marginalized communities in India face as well as how they use Twitter.\nIn addition
column18:
Tweeps in APAC amplified the #MagingMabuti (#BeKind) campaign in an online Tweetchat with Phillipines-based organizationsÂ Mental Health PHÂ andÂ Silakbo PhilippinesÂ and supported the #AkuBarhakBahagia Twitter campaign with suicide prevention activistÂ @bennysiauw89Â and clinical psychologistÂ @nagotejenaÂ to raise awareness on mental health issues that people may experience during the COVID-19 pandemic. We also wrote letters to seniors experiencing loneliness forÂ Connected AUâs Letter Box Project and sewed Yut Nori kits (a traditional Korean board game) with Braille for visually impaired children.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Canada
Twitter Canada hosted a conversation with @LalaaWrites
column19: the creator of #ThisBlackGirl reads
column20: to elevate and discuss her top 5 books about diversity and inclusion. Tweeps from around the world loved hearing about Lalaa's story
column21: her book recommendations
column22:
and her tips and tricks for navigating life as a working Mom.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
EMEA 
In addition to a bake-off to raise breast cancer awareness and support local cancer NGOS
column23: Tweeps across EMEA participated in various Twitter for Good Day activities
column24: including a session with\u00c2\u00a0Age UK Westminster\u00c2\u00a0where we provided one-on-one assistance over video to help isolated older people with their digital devices to ensure that they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re able to stay connected with friends and family throughout this difficult time. Tweeps across the region also came together for a pay-to-participate regional quiz which raised money for\u00c2\u00a0Beat Eating Disorders\u00c2\u00a0in the UK
column25: the\u00c2\u00a0Red Cross\u00c2\u00a0in Spain\u00c2\u00a0and\u00c2\u00a0Emmaus France.\nThe Twitter Dublin office ran a number of online fundraising events to support the\u00c2\u00a0Irish Cancer Society
column26: which included a yoga class and gaming competition. The Public Policy team trained over 60 Irish Cancer Society advocates on best practices for using Twitter to spread awareness of their work. In addition
column27: members of our Human Resources team partnered with\u00c2\u00a0Project 668
column28: a Brussels-based nonprofit working to fight unemployment through professional development
column29:
to help people prepare for job interviews. Tweeps also joined a session hosted byÂ Twitter AbleÂ andÂ Be My EyesÂ to learn more about ways to make the world more accessible to the blind community.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
LATAM 
Our Brazil team learned about the #PrisonLivesMatter campaign from activistsÂ @TatiNefertariÂ andÂ @_Queenrino
column30: and donated basic cleaning and personal hygiene supplies to support their mission. We also participated in a Wikipedia edit-a-thon in partnership with\u00c2\u00a0Wiki Movimento Brasil\u00c2\u00a0to add more Wikipedia content on Black
column31: Indigenous
column32: and LGBT+ women in order to increase the representation of these groups on the platform.\nOver in Mexico
column33: we supported\u00c2\u00a0La Cana
column34: a project that seeks to create job opportunities for women in prison through programs and workshops on personal development and work training. Tweeps also donated money
column35: clothes
column36: hygiene products
column37:
shoes and toys to the organization.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
US
Washington
column38: DC Tweeps teamed up with\u00c2\u00a0Food for Others\u00c2\u00a0to assemble meal kits for elementary school kids in northern Virginia. Over in Miami
column39: we partnered with\u00c2\u00a0TransSOCIAL\u00c2\u00a0to amplify the organization\u00e2\u0080\u0099s mission to expand resources for the transgender and\u00c2\u00a0gender-nonconforming population in South Florida.\nOn the West Coast
column40:
we virtually created masks for young people experiencing homelessness withÂ Larkin Street Youth Services. We also hosted a virtual career panel for high school students and recent alumni with theÂ San Francisco 49ers Community Impact team.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Though Twitter for Good Day happens only twice a year
column41:
the spirit and mission of giving back is central to our company and lives within us every day.Â 
A recap of our first remote Twitter for Good Day is availableÂ here.

column3: "title": "Fleets: a new way to join the conversation"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Fleets: a new way to join the conversation
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 17 November 2020\nLink copied successfully\nThis blog was updated on November 18
column10: to share additional ways we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re working to keep people safe when using Fleets.\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s purpose is to serve the public conversation \u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00c2\u00a0it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s where you go to see what's happening and talk about it. But some of you tell us that Tweeting is uncomfortable because it feels so public
column11: so permanent
column12: and like there's so much pressure to rack up Retweets and Likes. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why
column13: unfortunately
column14: there are so many \u00f0\u009f\u0094\u00a5 Tweets left in drafts! To help people feel more comfortable
column15: we've been working on a lower pressure way for people to talk about what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening. Today
column16:
we're launching Fleets so everyone can easily join the conversation in a new way â with their fleeting thoughts.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Fleets are for sharing momentary thoughts â they help start conversations and only stick around for 24 hours. Through our tests in Brazil
column17: Italy
column18: India
column19: and South Korea
column20: we learned Fleets helped people feel more comfortable joining the conversation \u00e2\u0080\u0093 we saw people with Fleets talk more on Twitter. Those new to Twitter found Fleets to be an easier way to share what's on their mind. Because they disappear from view after a day
column21: Fleets helped people feel more comfortable sharing personal and casual thoughts
column22: opinions
column23: and feelings. These are early findings from our tests and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to learn more about how Fleets are used by you.\nYou can Fleet text
column24: reactions to Tweets
column25: photos or videos and customize your Fleets with various background and text options. To share a Tweet in a Fleet tap the \u00e2\u0080\u009cShare\u00e2\u0080\u009d icon at the bottom of the Tweet and then tap
column26: \u00e2\u0080\u009cShare in Fleet.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Then
column27: add what you think about it with some text or emojis. Soon
column28: stickers and live broadcasting will be available in Fleets. This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. Your browser does not support the video element. Play Play Pause Seek 0% buffered 00:00 Current time 00:00 Duration 00:00 Toggle Mute Volume Your followers can see your Fleets at the top of their home timeline. Anyone who can see your full profile can see your Fleets there too. Also
column29: anyone who can send you a Direct Message can reply to your Fleets. If you want to reply to a Fleet
column30: tap on it to send a Direct Message or emoji reaction to the author; replying or reacting to a Fleet starts a conversation in your Direct Messages. Fleet authors can see who views their Fleets
column31: including accounts with protected Tweets
column32: by clicking into their Fleets and tapping on the \u00e2\u0080\u0098Seen By\u00e2\u0080\u0099 text at the bottom. Learn more about how Fleets work here. Fleets will be updated over time with new features
column33: based on your feedback. \nJust like Tweets
column34: Fleets must follow the Twitter Rules. To report a Fleet
column35: tap the \u00e2\u0080\u0098v\u00e2\u0080\u0099 icon at the top of a Fleet; you can also mute the account posting the Fleet from here. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll take action if a reported Tweet breaks our rules. If you Fleet a Tweet with a label or warning
column36: it will carry over to Fleets. In some cases
column37: you may need to tap through a warning before you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re able to view a Fleet.\nThis format may sound familiar to you! We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve learned that some people feel more comfortable joining conversations on Twitter with this ephemeral format
column38: so what they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re saying lives just for a moment in time. In the coming days
column39:
everyone globally will have Fleets on Twitter for iOS and Android. Fleet or @ us with what you think!
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet
Twitter logo icon
