column3: "title": "An update on our work around the 2020 US Elections"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
An update on our work around the 2020 US Elections
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 12 November 2020\nLink copied successfully\nUpdated on December 16
column10: to share some of our learnings from prompting Quote Tweets and sharing an update that we are re-enabling the standard Retweet behavior.\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s been just over a week since Election Day in the US and the culmination of an unprecedented voting period that resulted in the highest voter turnout rate in 50 years. While we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re still seeing record levels of election-related conversation on Twitter and our teams continue to actively enforce our rules to protect the integrity of this public conversation
column11: we want to provide an update about this ongoing work.\nWe also want to be very clear that we do not see our job as done \u00e2\u0080\u0094 our work here continues and our teams are learning and improving how we address these challenges. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be sharing a comprehensive report on the election early next year.  In the months leading up to Election Day
column12: we announced a set of policy
column13: enforcement and product changes to add context
column14: encourage thoughtful consideration
column15: and reduce the potential for misleading information to spread on Twitter.  Here\u00e2\u0080\u0099s what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve learned about the impact of those changes so far
column16:
and how we plan to adapt based on those findings:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Labels
column17: warnings
column18: and prebunks More than a year ago
column19: the public told us they wanted Twitter to offer context on misleading information. This is the exact approach we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve implemented on Tweets about COVID-19
column20: synthetic and manipulated media
column21: and the 2020 US election that could contribute to offline harm. We continue to apply labels to add context and limit the risk of harmful election misinformation spreading without important context.  Below are some key statistics about the labels
column22: warnings
column23:
and additional restrictions we applied to Tweets that included potentially misleading information about the US Election from October 27 to November 11: 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Approximately 300
column24: 000 Tweets have been labeled under our\u00c2\u00a0Civic Integrity Policy\u00c2\u00a0for content that was disputed and potentially misleading. These represent 0.2% of all US election-related Tweets sent during this time period.\n456 of those Tweets were also covered by a warning message and had engagement features limited (Tweets could be Quote Tweeted but not Retweeted
column25:
replied to or liked).
Approximately 74% of the people who viewed those Tweets saw them after we applied a label or warning message.
We saw an estimated 29% decrease in Quote Tweets of these labeled Tweets due in part to a prompt that warned people prior to sharing.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We also got ahead of potentially misleading information by showing everyone on Twitter in the US a series of pre-bunk prompts. These prompts
column26: which were seen 389 million times
column27: appeared in people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s home timelines and in Search
column28: and reminded people that election results were likely to be delayed
column29:
and that voting by mail is safe and legitimate.  These enforcement actions remain part of our continued strategy to add context and limit the spread of misleading information about election processes around the world on Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Product changes In the weeks leading up to and during election week
column30: we implemented significant product changes intended to increase context and encourage more thoughtful consideration before Tweets are amplified. Starting today
column31: we are reverting some of these changes and providing more detail on the impact they had.  Encouraging Quote Tweets We encouraged people to add their own commentary when amplifying content by prompting Quote Tweets instead of Retweets. This change introduced some friction
column32: and gave people an extra moment to consider why and what they were adding to the conversation. Since making this change
column33: we observed a 23% decrease in Retweets and a 26% increase in Quote Tweets
column34: but on a net basis the overall number of Retweets and Quote Tweets combined decreased by 20%. In short
column35: this change slowed the spread of misleading information by virtue of an overall reduction in the amount of sharing on the service. We are taking more time to study and fully understand the impact of this change and are leaving it in-place for now. \nUpdated on December 16
column36: 2020: We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll no longer be prompting Quote Tweets
column37: and are re-enabling the standard Retweet behavior. We hoped this change would encourage thoughtful amplification and also increase the likelihood that people would add their own thoughts
column38: reactions and perspectives to the conversation. However
column39: we observed that prompting Quote Tweets didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t appear to increase context: 45% of additional Quote Tweets included just a single word and 70% contained less than 25 characters. \nRemoving Tweet recommendations in Home Timeline & Notifications We stopped providing \u00e2\u0080\u009cliked by\u00e2\u0080\u009d and \u00e2\u0080\u009cfollowed by\u00e2\u0080\u009d Tweet recommendations from accounts you don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t follow in the Home Timeline and through notifications. While we had initially hoped that this would help reduce the potential for misleading information to spread on our service
column40: we did not observe a statistically significant difference in misinformation prevalence as a result of this change (nor any meaningful reduction in abuse reports). Instead
column41: we found that pausing these recommendations prevented many people from discovering new conversations and accounts to follow. As of today
column42: we are reverting this change.  Our goal is to eventually replace these \u00e2\u0080\u009cliked by\u00e2\u0080\u009d and \u00e2\u0080\u009cfollowed by\u00e2\u0080\u009d recommendations with ones that are based on the Topics you follow or Topics we think you might like. We believe this will provide you greater control to tell us what you are and aren\u00e2\u0080\u0099t interested in
column43: which will make our recommendations more relevant to you. Also
column44: we don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t believe the \u00e2\u0080\u009cLike\u00e2\u0080\u009d button provides sufficient
column45: thoughtful consideration prior to amplifying Tweets. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve grown our coverage of Topics recommendations significantly in the last year
column46: with now more than 5
column47: 000 Topics available
column48: and hope to be able to complete this transition soon.  Required context before showing Trends in \u00e2\u0080\u009cFor You\u00e2\u0080\u009d We only showed Trends in \u00e2\u0080\u009cFor You\u00e2\u0080\u009d that had added context
column49: meaning our team added a description
column50: representative Tweet
column51: or article to help people more quickly gain an informed understanding of high volume public conversation.  While we saw a significant reduction in reports (on Trends
column52: and Tweets within Trends result pages) as a result of this change
column53: we also recognized that it placed a significant limitation on the number and breadth of Trends that we could show people
column54: making \u00e2\u0080\u009cFor You\u00e2\u0080\u009d less relevant for many people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s interests. Moving forward
column55: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to prioritize reviewing and adding context to as many Trends as possible
column56: but won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t make this a requirement before a Trend can appear in \u00e2\u0080\u009cFor You.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Our goal is to help people see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening
column57: while ensuring that potentially misleading trends are presented with context.  Next steps We remain vigilant and will continue working to protect the integrity of the election conversation on Twitter. As we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve done for many elections around the world
column58: we will produce a longer-form retrospective of all of our work around the 2020 US Election in early 2021. We will continue to research
column59: question
column60: and change features that may incentivize or encourage behaviors on Twitter that negatively affect the health of the public conversation. For more
column61:
follow @TwitterGov and @Policy.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet

elections

column9: how it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s going: Performance advertising on Twitter\n        \n            By Joost Arnoudt
column10: Sr. Product Manager and Tong Wang
column11:
Staff Product Manager
          
Product updates
Editorâs note: As of April 7
column13: \u00c2\u00a0Website Cards and App Cards are now known and referred to as Image or Video Ads for Website Traffic and App Installs

column18: 2022\nScaling our performance advertising and measurement solutions for advertisers\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to share that the new and improved Twitter Pixel
column19: Conversion API
column20: and App Purchase Optimization are launching globally to all Twitter Advertisers. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been hard at work since our last update
column21:
and have now hit an important milestone that creates value on top of the measurement and optimization solutions we launched earlier this year.Â 
Hereâs a closer look at what weâve been up to:Â 
Our new and improved Twitter Pixel
The new Twitter Pixel is a new measurement solution that enables conversion tracking. Conversion tracking is the backbone of performance advertising - it enables advertisers to measure their return on ad spend by tracking the actions people take after viewing
column22: clicking or engaging with ads on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhat does the new Twitter Pixel do?\u00c2\u00a0\nImproved Web attribution: This new Pixel comes with additional functionality
column23: such as allowing advertisers to measure more actions than before
column24: such as when someone adds an item to their digital shopping cart.\u00c2\u00a0\nEasier measurement set-up and troubleshooting: We also simplified our event creation process
column25: which helps advertisers more seamlessly set up their measurement solutions
column26:
and introduced updates to our Pixel Helper Chrome extension. This will help advertisers better understand the impact of their web campaigns and provide clearer support when checking to see if the Pixel is implemented properly.
Introducing: Conversion API (CAPI)Â 
We are also introducing Conversion API (CAPI) to all advertisers. CAPI is a measurement solution that enables advertisers to connect to our API endpoint and send conversion events to Twitter from their servers without using third-party cookies. This launch is a part of our efforts to improve value for businesses while maintaining our privacy and security commitments by relying less on third-party cookies.Â 
CAPI can also help improve optimization and ad targeting without the need for a Twitter Pixel
column27: which is the first time an advertiser can finally connect data to see conversions without placing a tag on their site. Multiple data signals with Conversion API (CAPI) can be used\u00e2\u0080\u0094including Twitter Click ID or email addresses to send conversion events to the API endpoint and help advertisers further understand actions that people are taking as a result of their advertising.\u00c2\u00a0\nYou can read more about how advertisers are tapping into CAPI in this success story
column28: and more about the Twitter Pixel and Conversions API on the Twitter Ads Help Center.\u00c2\u00a0\nIntroducing: App Purchase Optimization\u00c2\u00a0\nIn the world of App ads
column29: performance talks - and the performance that most app advertisers care about are not simply installs
column30:
but driving lower funnel actions such as purchases. We are taking the first step towards fulfilling our promise of making Twitter a great place for driving lower funnel outcomes for performance advertisers with App Purchase Optimization.
App Purchase Optimization enables advertisers to deliver ads to people most likely to install an app or make a purchase by using machine learning to identify audiences that are more likely to take an action. In early testing* we saw the following results:Â 
89% of advertisers saw a reduction in cost-per-purchase
A median 30.4% decrease in cost-per-purchase compared to Install Optimization
column31: when using Click Billing and a median 12.8% decrease in cost-per-purchase compared to Install Optimization
column32: when using Impressions Billing\nThis product is now currently available via Android for all advertisers
column33: with an iOS launch to follow in the future.\u00c2\u00a0\n*Source: Data from internal Twitter testing in Q2 2022 comparing campaigns optimizing for Purchases vs. campaigns optimizing for Installs.\u00c2\u00a0\nIf you need help setting up your campaign
column34: \u00c2\u00a0connect with a Twitter Ads specialist.\nLooking ahead\u00c2\u00a0\nTo build a more effective performance advertising business
column35: we are increasing our investment across various initiatives
column36: including updates to our optimization models
column37: conversion options
column38: and measurement solutions. As we continue to build upon our performance roadmap
column39: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to continue to drive value for our customers with upcoming product launches
column40: such as:\u00c2\u00a0\nCollection Ads: This new format will bring a new way for advertisers to storytell and showcase their products to consumers. Brands can display a primary hero image with smaller thumbnail visuals below. Each image can drive consumers to a different website or product landing page
column41: driving various advertiser objectives.\u00c2\u00a0\nWeb Conversion Optimization: We will be conducting a major rebuild of our Website Conversions optimization model that will help improve the way we reach people who are more likely to convert on a lower-funnel Website action
column42: such as making a purchase or adding an item to their cart.\u00c2\u00a0\nDynamic Product Ads: This is a new ad product that will dynamically deliver relevant products to the right person
column43: at the right time
column44: based on their activity both on and off Twitter
column45:
in order to help drive sales or conversions.Â 
The work continues and we are looking forward to sharing more along the way. Stay tuned!Â

          Improving Performance advertising and measurement at scale
        
To kick-off the year
column62: we are launching three new products that improve performance for campaigns trying to drive traffic to a website
column63: all while maintaining our commitment to people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s privacy: Site Visit Optimization
column64: Aggregated Measurement
column65: and Events Manager.\nSince we last shared an update
column66: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been hard at work and have now hit an important milestone that creates value on top of the measurement and optimization solutions launched in 2021.\nImproving your ability to reach audiences most likely to visit your website\u00c2\u00a0\nThe Website Clicks & Conversions objective has evolved since the objective was initially launched. Based on the expanded product offering and to better meet your expectations of the results you can achieve from this product
column67: we are renaming this objective to Website Traffic.\u00c2\u00a0\nSite Visits Optimization is a new optimization goal under the Website Traffic objective dedicated to finding and serving your ads to audiences most likely to visit your website. By enabling the Twitter Website Tag

This is aimed at providing conversion metrics by counting events in aggregate for audiences who have opted out of tracking on iOS devices.\u00c2\u00a0\nHow does this work?\u00c2\u00a0\nWithin the Twitter Ads Manager Reporting you will be able to see an aggregated view of site metrics and conversion events

we want to ensure that you are able to efficiently and effectively manage tracking your ad campaigns.Â

Streamlined interface that provides more clarity on setting up your Twitter Website TagÂ

Throughout this year we will continue to provide enhancements to Events Manager to improve diagnostic capabilities

and integrate App-based events so this can become the central hub for advertisers to manage their website tag and conversion events.

2022 will be a banner year for performanceÂ 
We see a lot of opportunities for us to continue to improve how businesses run advertising campaigns on Twitter

you can expect even more updates as we continue to make it easier for you to grow your business and understand the performance and impact of your ad campaigns.Â 
          A year in Performance
        
We have come a long way since we created this Performance hub as a way to be transparent about our efforts to help meet the needs of more marketers and their performance goals. Today
column89: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to share the latest progress we are making against our Performance ads product roadmap. We continue to work off the foundations we have rebuilt and are launching key App and Web products in-market.\u00c2\u00a0\nAs part of our broader Performance advertising strategy
column90: our first focus has been to drive app discovery for people
column91: while supporting app developers in growing their user acquisition and increasing their return on investment. Our second area of focus is on driving action to websites: we are exploring the development of ad products that help people find relevant information and products
column92: or guide them to take action on a website. These elements could unlock the ability for us to enable advertisers to drive discovery of goods and services
column93: eventually supporting our broader commerce opportunities.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe are no stranger to the new platform standards influencing digital advertising
column94: such as Apple\u00e2\u0080\u0099s App Tracking Transparency enforcement that began in April. These shifts in the industry are an opportunity for us to move quickly and help our partners navigate these changes as effectively as possible. We continue to build our products with these privacy-focused developments at the core of all we do.\nApp Installs: Building upon our progress\nWe made significant progress to delivering a performant App Installs objective
column95: which helps advertisers drive installs to their app(s). With a privacy-led mindset
column96: we heavily invested in supporting SKAdNetwork to enable post App Tracking Transparency user acquisition. Our work here allowed us to open up over 30%+ more inventory and scale on iOS after enabling privacy-preserved measurement. We then quickly launched support of view-through attribution and SK-campaign ID management features in Twitter Ads Manager
column97: in addition to updated optimization models.\u00c2\u00a0\nSupporting our partners through these changes is not limited to investment in SKAdNetwork alone. We continued to iterate off of our\u00c2\u00a0rebuilt foundation
column98: \u00c2\u00a0launching new Ad Format improvements to reduce download friction
column99: releasing an updated Learning Period model aimed at driving more consistent campaign performance
column100: and making additional improvements to campaign creation.\nImage of an overlaid install action pops up in-feed
column101:
allowing people to immediately download the app.
We are also actively planning and testing for the next iteration of App Installs on Twitter. This will include:Â 
More unique formats to engage audiences
Updated optimization models
Development of new post-install products
column103:
which would allow advertisers to run campaigns focused on finding people more likely to make in-app purchases

Website Traffic: Introducing Multi-Destination Carousels
We also made progress on our Website Traffic product
column104: which helps advertisers drive traffic to websites. Last year
column105: we announced the\u00c2\u00a0launch of Carousel Ads.\u00c2\u00a0We are pleased to share that we are now launching multi-destination functionality for Carousels driving to a website. With Multi-Destination Carousels
column106: advertisers can now customize headlines and landing pages to help drive the right actions for their audiences.\u00c2\u00a0\nAdvertisers will have greater flexibility to diversify their message with unique headlines and URLs per Carousel Card. With just a swipe
column107: people can engage with multiple images or videos
column108: and click through to land on different destinations.\nWe are encouraged by the results we saw during our Beta testing of this new functionality. For Multi-Destination Website Carousels
column109: we saw on average:\u00c2\u00a0\n~20% increase in click-through rate across all objectives
column110: relative to single-asset ads*\n~25% lift in click-through rate for campaigns that optimize for site visit conversions
column111: relative to single-asset ads*\nWe are also testing additional key Website Traffic products
column113: an improved buying model dedicated to finding and serving ads to audiences most likely to visit an advertiser\u00e2\u0080\u0099s website.\nAd formats
column114: identifying opportunities to improve ad engagement on Twitter. These tests include updates to usability
column117: actively testing and building 1st party measurement and experimentation solutions for a privacy-preserved future for our Website ad products.\u00c2\u00a0\nJust getting started\nWe see our Performance advertising products as discovery tools. They should be able to help our partners bring people to the relevant goods and services that are important to them. If Twitter is to become a place for commerce
column118: discovery will need to be effective and accessible. In order to make this all work
column119: we also need to build the right organic tools and resources for businesses
column120: which we are doing in our recent work for Twitter for Professionals.\nAll of these advances have put us in a strong position for the next phase of Performance advertising on Twitter. While this is an exciting milestone
column121: it is still an early step. We have more work ahead of us
column122: and are looking forward to continuing to share our progress.\n*Source: Twitter internal data from Carousels while in Beta testing July - September 2021. Multi-Destination website Carousels compared to single-asset Website Cards. These numbers are averages across iOS and Android

          An update on our progress on Performance advertising
        
Updated February 8
column127: new blog post. Since we last shared an update
column128: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve built on our recent Carousel Ads launch
column129: and we concluded two crucial product milestones: the rebuilds of our App Installs and Website Traffic objectives. \nThese rebuilds are focused on getting our fundamentals right
column130: and include improvements across five areas: Campaign management
column134: and Measurement. Our commitment to developing the critical tools that advertisers need to launch campaigns and drive customer acquisition is working - and we are excited to share more about the progress we have made.\u00c2\u00a0\nCompleted the rebuild of our App Installs objective\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve rebuilt the foundation of our App Installs objective to help advertisers launch
column136: and measure app install campaigns even better than before. As part of this rebuild
column137: we redesigned several of our most popular formats to drive higher engagement
column140: and developed a faster and more intuitive campaign creation experience.\u00c2\u00a0\nHere\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a look at the changes we have made:\u00c2\u00a0\nEnhanced creative formats \u00e2\u0080\u0094 In addition to our recent new and improved Carousels announcement
column141: we also made improvements to Twitter App Cards
column142: making them even more engaging than before by adding more context and information
column145: and download details \u00e2\u0080\u0094 all of which help us better serve up-and-coming apps by giving them more credibility. This has led to a +8.88% install per impression improvement2.\u00c2\u00a0\nImproved prediction and supply \u00e2\u0080\u0094 We launched a combination of prediction
column147: supply and supply quality improvements to deliver more stability and performance. We also upgraded our infrastructure and how our ad serving works within the Twitter timeline
column148: which has resulted in a significant number of impressions that App Install advertisers are now winning in our auction.\nEasier campaign setup and management \u00e2\u0080\u0094 We improved aspects of the Ads Manager experience to be more intuitive. This includes a single tab Tweet creation experience for advertisers to build their entire creative in one go
column149: reducing the amount of time and number of interfaces advertisers must navigate. We also updated our Ad Group Details page to simplify optimization and bidding combinations.\u00c2\u00a0\nImproved Measurement \u00e2\u0080\u0094 Lastly
column150: we implemented measurement solutions to help advertisers more accurately attribute installs and navigate iOS 14\u00e2\u0080\u0099s upcoming app tracking transparency framework (ATT). You can read more about our approach specific to the ATT changes here. We also expanded our Advanced Mobile Measurement Program
column151: allowing advertisers to enable advertisers to conduct LTV and ROAS measurement.\nIntroducing Twitter Click ID and improved conversion optimization\nFor advertisers focused on driving website outcomes
column152: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been hard at work improving formats
column154: and optimization models to increase click-to-land rates and reduce reporting discrepancies between Twitter reporting and third-party reporting.\nAs the industry shifts away from using third-party cookies to determine if an ad resulted in a site visit
column155: we improved the Twitter Website Tag (javascript version) by developing a first-party click ID parameter. Twitter Click ID provides a reliable method to measure the people who visited a site after clicking on a Twitter ad
column157: giving advertisers better data and a long-term measurement solution in a cookie-less advertising world.\u00c2\u00a0\nHow it works\nWhen someone clicks on a website ad
column158: the Twitter Click ID\u00e2\u0080\u0099s unique identifier will be appended automatically in the URL. When the person lands on the website and the Twitter pixel fires
column161: and used to attribute the site visit to the click. Based on our test results
column162: we have seen a 10X increase in Site Visits3\u00c2\u00a0reported in Twitter Ads Manager.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe also upgraded our conversion optimization model
column163: improving campaigns that optimize for site visits. Our system is now better at identifying people who are more likely to visit your website. In recent testing
column164: we observed a median increase in click-to-land rate of +26% and a significant decrease in cost per site visit4\u00c2\u00a0in Twitter Ads Manager.\nAdditionally
column165: we made improvements to the Website Card format - including better navigation to a full-screen browser
column167:
and improved usability of media controls - all of which resulted in a click-to-land rate improvement of +8%5.Â 
Whatâs next
Our focus is on making it easier and more efficientÂ  than ever to advertise on Twitter - helping advertisers reach a full-funnel marketing approach from the top-down.
These products can help marketers take their launches and campaigns and extend them into always-on media plans that may ultimately help marketers drive customer acquisition and reach their goals. Weâre so excited for whatâs next - stay tuned for more.Â

          Introducing New and Improved Carousels
        
Updated November 2020Â 
We know there is an opportunity to better equip businesses on Twitter to run advertising campaigns that help them effectively reach their goals
column172: whether that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s driving people to websites or to download mobile apps. We have been hard at work on a roadmap that will help us deliver better performance at a greater scale and establish a more efficient performance-driven advertising business on Twitter. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made a lot of progress in the last year
column174: which improved the state of our systems and reinforced the foundation of Twitter's ad business.\nLaunching our Advanced Mobile Measurement (AMM) program
column175: to give advertisers enhanced measurement of Lifetime value.\nReleasing\u00c2\u00a0the new Tweet Composer\u00c2\u00a0to help enable faster creative development and iteration.\u00c2\u00a0\nAdding support of SKAdNetwork
column177: to attribute installs and provide campaign reporting for iOS 14.\nImproving our advertising algorithms
column178: such as the launch of Learning Period
column179: which allows our prediction models to learn and optimize campaign delivery.\u00c2\u00a0\nThis investment in performance advertising also includes expanding the capabilities of our ad formats to enable advertisers with more options to show and tell their brand story
column181: engaging experience for people on Twitter. We recently redesigned the video controls on our Video Website Cards to make it easier for people to navigate
column182: and launched improvements to our App Cards.\u00c2\u00a0\nAnd today
column183: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to share the global release of the new and improved Carousel ads
column184: now available to all.\u00c2\u00a0\nCarousel ads are designed to help drive better performance by providing a more immersive and interactive experience for consumers to engage with
column185: as well as enable future opportunities within our Mobile App and Website performance objectives. We are excited to share that this ad format is now available to all advertisers
column186: globally.\u00c2\u00a0\nCarousel ads are made up of two to six horizontally swipeable images or videos that drive people to an app or website. Any advertiser can create Carousel ads via Tweet Composer in Ads Manager or via the Ads API
column187: and is able to use them either organically or promoted.\nThe Carousel ad format also includes an edge-to-edge design
column191: such as swipes within the Carousel and breakdowns to measure individual Carousel card performance.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe are encouraged by the strong results we saw during our Beta testing:\u00c2\u00a0\nFor Website Carousels
column193: a ~15% increase in click-through rate relative to single-asset formats*.\nAnd for App Carousels
column195: a ~24% increase in installs per impression relative to single-asset formats*.\nWe expect these results to change in general availability
column196: and to vary across different regions
column198: however it is a positive sign as we release this format globally and continue to invest in performance products.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next?\u00c2\u00a0\nThis is an early step in our journey. To build a more effective performance advertising business
column199: we are increasing our investment across various initiatives
column200: including updates to our Mobile App objectives
column201: such as stronger bidding and optimization options
column202: enhancements to the Twitter Website Tag that aim to drive up the accuracy of key advertiser campaign metrics
column203: such as return on ad spend
column204: and improved creative advertising formats.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe know there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s still a lot more for us to do
column205: but we are encouraged by what we have accomplished thus far and the clear path ahead. We will be updating this page with all our performance-specific developments in the upcoming months
column206:
so be sure to check back in!Â

column3: "title": "National Disability Employment Awareness Month 2020 with Twitter Able"
column7:
"post_text": "National Disability Employment Awareness Month 2020 with Twitter Able
                By
                
  
  
              
                and
                
  
  
Friday
column8: 30 October 2020\nLink copied successfully\nThis October
column9: we celebrated National Disability Employment Awareness Month (NDEAM). We used this as an opportunity to re-introduce Twitter Able with a new campaign that represents who we are
column10: what we do
column11: and our intersections: #DisabledAndAble. We want it known that people can be both disabled workers and able workers \u00e2\u0080\u0094 that disabled employees are not less than
column12: not there to simply accommodate. Disabled employees are equal employees who\u00e2\u0080\u0099s perspectives make Twitter
column13: and the world
column14: better for all.\u00c2\u00a0\nTwitter Able began a year ago
column15: as a community of disabled and ally Tweeps working together to raise awareness
column16: provide resources
column17: and prioritize the needs of our community. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re one of nine global Business Resource Groups (BRGs)
column18: working toward making Twitter a more inclusive and accessible company. Our work also includes healthy conversations with the people who use Twitter
column19: as to further understand all that we can do to foster belonging. In a virtual world
column20: there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s no better time to work together
column21: and closer
column22:
even while weâre apart.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As two engineers on Twitter Able we stayed busy this month with #DisabledAndAble global programming. We hosted a company-wide National Disability Employment Awareness Month kick-off event
column23:
where we shared Twitterâs journey to be a better employer and service to folks with disabilities.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In Singapore
column24: we hosted an event with SG Enable
column25: an organization dedicated to enabling persons with disabilities and discussed mentoring and internship programs
column26:
and how Tweeps can get engaged.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In Dublin
column27: we hosted Mark Pollock
column28: who shared his story of resiliency. He became the first blind person to race to the South Pole
column29:
and shared his story of strength after a fall which left him paralyzed.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We also held an internal watch party for âRising Phoenixâ and invited a Paralympian for a fireside chat.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
And finally
column30: on October 27
column31: we also hosted #BehindThePlatform
column32: a virtual event that discussed how @Twitter is working on #accessibility to develop a platform for anyone
column33: anywhere
column34:
to use on any device.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Empowerment
column35: belonging
column36: and community are our three BRG pillars. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s how we will foster an environment that welcomes
column37: that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s receptive
column38: and that makes future Tweeps feel at home. And although we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re one BRG
column39: our shared experiences range across intersectional identities
column40: job functions
column41: and interests - throughout Twitter. In a world where there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s so much uncertainty
column42: accountability is prime for our progress. With 200+ global members
column43: our work
column44: advocacy
column45:
and community is evergrowing - not because of our numbers but because of our proximity to the problems weâre solving.Â 
We arenât perfect and weâve got a lot of work to do to make Twitter a more inclusive and accessible company. Want to track our progress? Follow @TwitterAble and @TwitterA11y. Want to help us? Follow @TwitterCareers and #JoinTheFlock ðÂ  careers.twitter.com.

Serving the public conversation during the 2020 New Zealand Election
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 28 October 2020\nLink copied successfully\nThe #NZElection2020 has come to a close
column9: delivering a second term for Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern (@jacindaardern) and a landmark win for the New Zealand Labour Party (@nzlabour)
column10: which secured its largest mandate in 50 years. During the election
column11: New Zealanders turned to Twitter for breaking news and to have conversations about topics close to their heart
column12: to stay connected with their communities
column13:
and interact with candidates and elected leaders.
Hereâs a look back at how the election conversation unfolded on Twitter.
Election conversation resulted in 1.5M Tweets (a potential 7B impressions globally) during the campaign period from 18 August - 18 October 2020*
Conversations spiked on election night with Tweet volume jumping 530% once the media silent period lifted
There was a 200% increase in the number of mentions of Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern on Twitter during this campaign
column14:
compared to the 2017 general election when @JacindaArdern accounted for 24% of the mentions in conversations about the election
Twitter lit up during the 24 hours prior to polls closing on Election Day

column3: "title": "Hispanic Heritage Month 2020 recap"
column7:
"post_text": "Hispanic Heritage Month 2020 recap
                By
                
  
  
              
                and
                
  
  
Thursday
column8:
22 October 2020
Link copied successfully
Twitter celebrated Hispanic Heritage Month with #JuntosSomos!
The Latinx and Hispanic community moves the world forward in small ways that shift moments
column9: and big ways that shift culture. This year
column10: Twitter Alas shared our global stories
column11: wins
column12: and experiences so that the world can fully recognize that power.\u00c2\u00a0\nFrom September 15 to October 15
column13: we hosted events
column14: amplified voices on platform
column15: commissioned artists
column16:
and celebrated our first-ever virtual Hispanic Heritage Month.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Being exclusively virtual
column17: while not ideal
column18: actually brought us together in more ways than in past years. Twitter Alas is a global community \u00e2\u0080\u0094 connecting
column19: learning
column20: uplifting each other
column21:
and celebrating our power.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitter Alas (âwingsâ in Spanish) is the global business resource group (BRG) for employees of Latino and Latin American descent
column22: and anyone with an interest in Latinx culture and issues. From listening to great playlists and learning authentic Latinx recipes
column23: to helping our community
column24:
our BRG helps create a sense of belonging for Tweeps.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
All month
column25:
we let our Tweeps do the talking. Around the world they came together to tell their most powerful moments and experiences in an inclusive narrative.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
These stories made so many feel heard and understood. There are certainly many obstacles we face being Latinx in tech
column26:
but to know that we all went through a powerful experience that allowed us to feel empowered to accomplish our goals was wholesome. Seeing how our Tweeps and community responded was reassuring that we are together in more ways than one. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Throughout the month
column27: we held many events
column28: from cooking demos to Super Bowl choreography lessons to an event geared at tackling mental health stigmas in our community. We also held an event with four incredible Latinx leaders around the concept of Latinidad
column29:
moderated by our very own James Loduca.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
To celebrate our Latinx heritage we worked with three artists from around the world to visualize what Latinidad meant to them
column30:
and highlighted their work in our virtual Wall for a Cause.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As the month came to a close
column31: it was bittersweet. We were sad to see it go
column32: but inspired to keep this energy going all year round. We are excited to take that energy we built during HHM to continue to find ways to bring our community closer together. BRG work is not just about our tentpole months
column33:
but about creating an environment that makes our Tweeps feel welcome and ensure that we are all able to bring our full selves to work. This is what makes BRG work so critical and what sets Twitter apart. BRGs help us all #LoveWhereYouWork.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We are on a journey to become the worldâs most diverse and inclusive company. Come help us make Twitter better. Join the flock. Follow @TwitterAlas
column34:
@TwitterCareers and visit careers.twitter.com for all of our job listings.
This Tweet is unavailable

column3: "title": "How Twitter is helping people vote early"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
How Twitter is helping people vote early
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 22 October 2020\nLink copied successfully\nAs voters face unprecedented challenges when casting their ballot in the upcoming 2020 US elections
column9: Twitter is doing what we can to ensure that people have access to the reliable information they need in order to exercise their right to vote.\nWe strongly believe that everyone who is eligible should be empowered to vote
column10: and we know that for many people this year
column11:
the safest and most reliable way to do so is to vote early. 
A recent Ipsos poll* of people in the US who use Twitter daily and found that:
Nine out of 10 say they are registered and plan to vote in the 2020 elections
Two thirds have already voted or plan to vote before Election Day
One-in-three people are still seeking information about where and when to vote
With this clear need for reliable early voting information in mind
column12: Twitter is making our biggest early voting effort to date.\nWhat you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll see\nStarting today and through the weekend
column13: every person with a Twitter account located within the United States will see:\nA home timeline prompt designed to encourage them to vote early and look up their early voting options via BallotReady \u00e2\u0080\u0094 a nonpartisan voting advocacy organization. People will also be encouraged to Tweet out these resources to help spread the word.\nInteractive features on all Tweets with the hashtags #VoteEarly
column14: #IVoted
column15: #IVotedEarly
column16:
#YoVotÃ© including a custom emoji and an animated like button.
A push alert directing to an on-Twitter Public Service Announcement with additional early voting resources.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Engaging with the authoritative sources
This election season
column17: we also encourage voters to stay connected to their local election officials
column18: which is why Twitter is a member of the #TrustedInfo2020 Initiative. We recently partnered with NASS and NASED to host more than a dozen Twitter Q&As from Chief Election Officials during National Voter Education Week to answer constituent questions about the election process. People in the US can also follow these lists from NASS and NASED for the latest information.\nAs we approach Election Day in the US
column19: Twitter will continue to share reminders with voting deadlines and resources.\nFor a comprehensive list of the significant policy and product changes Twitter has made to protect the integrity of the US Election conversation
column20: please check out this blog post.\nFor future updates
column21:
follow @TwitterGov.
*Twitter/Ipsos national study

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "The 2020 New Zealand election is happening on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
The 2020 New Zealand election is happening on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 13 October 2020\nLink copied successfully\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re in the final countdown for Election Day in New Zealand. On October 17
column9: Kiwis will go to the polls to have their say in the 2020 New Zealand General Election and on two referendums. The campaign period might look a little different this year due to COVID-19
column10: but one thing has remained the same \u00e2\u0080\u0094 the election conversation is happening on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur research indicates that Kiwis use Twitter to stay connected and get informed
column11: with 1 in 3 Twitter users in New Zealand saying it's their main source of news on politics*. During campaigning
column12: Twitter has lit up with conversation about candidates
column13: policies
column14:
and the issues that matter the most to New Zealanders.Â 
Here's everything you need to know about the #NZElection2020 conversation on Twitter:Â 
Special election emoji
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâve launched a Twitter emoji featuring one very civically engaged kiwi bird to add some colour to your election Tweets. It will appear when you Tweet with any of the following hashtags.
#nzpolÂ 
#Decision20Â Â 
#NZElection2020Â 
#YourVote2020
Find key information at Twitterâs dedicated Event page
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitterâs one-stop shop Event page has all the key information New Zealanders need to know ahead of polling day. Voters at home and abroad can find credible information on the topics they care about
column15: including candidates
column16: how to enrol and vote
column17: and what key policies are being discussed.\u00c2\u00a0\nProtecting the integrity of the New Zealand Election on Twitter\u00c2\u00a0\nIn New Zealand and around the world
column18: Twitter has consistently worked to protect the public conversation around elections \u00e2\u0080\u0094 the cornerstone of our democracies.\nOur expanded Civic Integrity Policy
column19: Political Content Policy
column20: and overarching Twitter Rules are in place to protect the election conversation as New Zealanders express their critical rights this October.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve connected with political parties to provide an overview of our election policies and our work around civic integrity
column21: as well as sharing practical tips for staying safe on Twitter. We have also engaged with the parties and the New Zealand Electoral Commission (@ElectoralCommNZ) to ensure the right support channels are in place to escalate concerns and report any violations of our Rules or policies.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur cross-functional elections team\nWe have formed a high-level internal group to lead our election integrity work throughout the election period. The group consists of several of the company\u00e2\u0080\u0099s top trust and safety experts and members from our site integrity
column22: legal
column23: data science investigation
column24: and public policy teams. This blend of perspectives
column25: expertise
column26: and backgrounds is a critical component of maintaining the health of the conversation on our service.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nFostering civic engagement and the election conversation\nTwitter is the place where people go to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening during an election
column27: participate in the conversation
column28:
and join the online campaign trail.

And to enjoy the lighter side of the election:

column3: "title": "Additional steps we're taking ahead of the 2020 US Election"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Additional steps we're taking ahead of the 2020 US Election
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 9 October 2020\nLink copied successfully\nThis blog has been updated November 2
column10: to reflect updated information on labeling election results.\nTwitter plays a critical role around the globe by empowering democratic conversation
column11: driving civic participation
column12: facilitating meaningful political debate
column13: and enabling people to hold those in power accountable. But we know that this cannot be achieved unless the integrity of this critical dialogue on Twitter is protected from attempts \u00e2\u0080\u0094 both foreign and domestic \u00e2\u0080\u0094 to undermine it.\nToday
column14: we're announcing additional
column15:
significant product and enforcement updates that will increase context and encourage more thoughtful consideration before Tweets are amplified.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
How our Civic Integrity Policy applies on and around Election night
We do not allow anyone to use Twitter to manipulate or interfere in elections or other civic processes
column16: and recently expanded our civic integrity policy to address how we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll handle misleading information surrounding these events. Under this policy
column17: we will label Tweets that falsely claim a win for any candidate and will remove Tweets that encourage violence or call for people to interfere with election results or the smooth operation of polling places. More specifically:\nPeople on Twitter
column18: including candidates for office
column19: may not claim an election win before it is authoritatively called. To determine the results of an election in the US
column20: we require either an announcement from state election officials
column21: or a public projection from at least two authoritative
column22: national news outlets that make independent election calls. Tweets which include premature claims will be labeled and direct people to our official US election page.\nTweets meant to incite interference with the election process or with the implementation of election results
column23: such as through violent action
column24: will be subject to removal. This covers all Congressional races and the Presidential Election.\n New prompts and more warnings on misleading Tweets\nWe currently may label Tweets that violate our policies against misleading information about civic integrity
column25: COVID-19
column26: and synthetic and manipulated media. Starting next week
column27: when people attempt to Retweet one of these Tweets with a misleading information label
column28:
they will see a prompt pointing them to credible information about the topic before they are able to amplify it.
Tweets with labels are already de-amplified through our own recommendation systems and these new prompts will give individuals more context on labeled Tweets so they can make more informed decisions on whether or not they want to amplify them to their followers.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In addition to these prompts
column29: we will now add additional warnings and restrictions on Tweets with a misleading information label from US political figures (including candidates and campaign accounts)
column30: US-based accounts with more than 100
column31: 000 followers
column32: or that obtain significant engagement. People must tap through a warning to see these Tweets
column33: and then will only be able to Quote Tweet; likes
column34: Retweets and replies will be turned off
column35: and these Tweets won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t be algorithmically recommended by Twitter. We expect this will further reduce the visibility of misleading information
column36:
and will encourage people to reconsider if they want to amplify these Tweets.
This Tweet is unavailable

            This label is for illustrative purposes only. 
          
          
        
Encouraging more considerationÂ 
Beginning October 20 through at least the end of Election week in the US
column37: when we will assess their continued necessity
column38: we will also introduce the following changes globally to Twitter:\nFirst
column39: we will encourage people to add their own commentary prior to amplifying content by prompting them to Quote Tweet instead of Retweet. People who go to Retweet will be brought to the Quote Tweet composer where they\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be encouraged to comment before sending their Tweet. Though this adds some extra friction for those who simply want to Retweet
column40: we hope it will encourage everyone to not only consider why they are amplifying a Tweet
column41: but also increase the likelihood that people add their own thoughts
column42: reactions and perspectives to the conversation. If people don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t add anything on the Quote Tweet composer
column43:
it will still appear as a Retweet. We will begin testing this change on Twitter.com for some people beginning today.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Second
column44: we will prevent \u00e2\u0080\u009cliked by\u00e2\u0080\u009d and \u00e2\u0080\u009cfollowed by\u00e2\u0080\u009d recommendations from people you don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t follow from showing up in your timeline and won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t send notifications for these Tweets. These recommendations can be a helpful way for people to see relevant conversations from outside of their network
column45: but we are removing them because we don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t believe the \u00e2\u0080\u009cLike\u00e2\u0080\u009d button provides sufficient
column46: thoughtful consideration prior to amplifying Tweets to people who don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t follow the author of the Tweet
column47: or the relevant topic that the Tweet is about. This will likely slow down how quickly Tweets from accounts and topics you don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t follow can reach you
column48: which we believe is a worthwhile sacrifice to encourage more thoughtful and explicit amplification.\nFinally
column49: we will only surface Trends in the \u00e2\u0080\u009cFor You\u00e2\u0080\u009d tab in the United States that include additional context. That means there will be a description Tweet or article that represents or summarizes why that term is trending. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been adding more context to Trends during the last few months
column50: but this change will ensure that only Trends with added context show up in the \u00e2\u0080\u009cFor You\u00e2\u0080\u009d tab in the United States
column51:
which is where the vast majority of people discover whatâs trending. This will help people more quickly gain an informed understanding of the high volume public conversation in the US and also help reduce the potential for misleading information to spread.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Constantly working to protect elections
The improvements weâre announcing today are the latest in our comprehensive effort to apply the lessons of 2016
column52: and from elections that have happened around the world since
column53:
to the 2020 US Election. This is exemplified in our efforts surrounding the last US Midterm Election through this month:
9/2018 - Encouraged voter registration for all Americans during the 2018 midterm elections
10/2018 - Tightened our policies and zero-tolerance approach to hacked materials
10/2018 - Produced
column54: and continue to update
column55:

1/2019 - Issued a comprehensive review of our efforts to protect the 2018 U.S. midterms
6/2019 - Launched public interest notice and defined our approach on public interest
10/2019 - Banned all political ads on Twitter
column56:
including ads from state-controlled media
12/2019 - Added Election Labels to candidatesâ accounts
2/2020 - Introduced our rules on and labels for synthetic and manipulated media
3/2020 - Held planning exercises to prepare for a variety of Election Day scenarios
5/2020 - Added labels and warnings to potentially harmful misleading informationÂ 
8/2020 - Deployed labels on government and state-affiliated media accounts
9/2020 - Implemented account security requirements for high-profile political accounts
9/2020 - Built a U.S. Election hub containing credible news and voting resources
9/2020 - Encouraged voter registration and emphasizing safe voting options
9/2020 - Expanded our civic integrity policy to include specifics around pre and post election day
Twitter has a critical role to play in protecting the integrity of the election conversation
column57: and we encourage candidates
column58: campaigns
column59: news outlets and voters to use Twitter respectfully and to recognize our collective responsibility to the electorate to guarantee a safe
column60: fair and legitimate democratic process this November. As with any other product change
column61: we will learn
column62: observe

column64: to inform both our strategy around future global elections and Twitter's overall product experience.\nIn addition to these changes
column65: as we have throughout the election period
column66: we will have teams around the world working to monitor the integrity of the conversation and take action when needed. We have already increased the size and capacity of our teams focused on the US Election and will have the necessary staffing to respond rapidly to issues that may arise on Twitter on Election night and in the days that follow.\u00c2\u00a0\nFor more updates as the election continues
column67:
please follow @TwitterGov.
###

State election officials (as determined by the National Association of Secretaries of State and the National Association of State Election Directors)
National news outlets that have dedicated

column3: "title": "Disclosing networks to our state-linked information operations archive"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nDisclosing networks to our state-linked information operations archive\nThursday
column8: 8 October 2020\nLink copied successfully\nToday we are disclosing five distinct networks of accounts to our archive of state-linked information operations. The accounts that we have published in our archive today - the only archive of its kind in the industry - include independent information operations that we have attributed to Iran
column9: Saudi Arabia
column10: Cuba
column11: Thailand and Russia.\u00c2\u00a0\nPost-investigation
column12: we permanently suspended all 1
column13: 594 accounts associated with the five networks
column14: for various violations of our platform manipulation policies. Along with our enforcement
column15: we shared early access to the data we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re releasing today with the Stanford Internet Observatory\u00c2\u00a0(SIO) for independent investigation and analysis.\nIran\nBased on information shared by industry peers
column16: we identified a network of primarily compromised accounts on Twitter operating from Iran
column17: which artificially amplified conversations on politically sensitive topics
column18: including Black Lives Matter (BLM)
column19: the murder of George Floyd
column20: and other issues of racial and social justice in the United States.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn cases where we identify that an account has been compromised for the purposes of engaging in violative behavior
column21: we aim to restore the account to the original account holder. We were able to do so successfully in most cases here. In all
column22: we suspended a total of 104 accounts connected with this campaign.\u00c2\u00a0\nTo protect the privacy of people whose accounts were used without permission for this campaign
column23: we are hashing all user-identifiable information connected with this set across all the data we are releasing.\nSaudi Arabia\u00c2\u00a0\nWe investigated and removed 33 accounts originating in Saudi Arabia
column24: with ties to the Saudi government. These accounts were created to impersonate key Qatari political figures and to advance narratives about Qatari politics which are geostrategically favorable to the Saudi authorities.\u00c2\u00a0 \nCuba\u00c2\u00a0\nWe have permanently suspended 526 fake accounts run by youth organizations with ties to the Cuban government
column25: including Uni\u00c3\u00b3n de J\u00c3\u00b3venes Comunistas (UJC) and\u00c2\u00a0Federaci\u00c3\u00b3n Estudiantil Universitaria (FEU).\nThailand\nOur investigation uncovered a network of accounts partaking in information operations that we can reliably link to the Royal Thai Army (RTA). These accounts were engaging in amplifying pro-RTA and pro-government content
column26: as well as engaging in behavior targeting prominent political opposition figures.\nWe are disclosing 926 accounts today and continue to enforce against small-scale activity associated with this network
column27: as we identify it.\u00c2\u00a0\nRussia\u00c2\u00a0\nWe communicated proactively about this set of five accounts at the beginning of September 2020. Today
column28:
weâre adding them to the archive.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Working collaboratively with industry peers and the FBI
column29:
we were made aware of a number of accounts that had potential links to a fake news agency called PeaceData. They were immediately removed from the service and weâve marked all links to the site as unsafe across the service.Â 
Our work in this areaÂ 
Our goal with these disclosures is to continue to build public understanding around the ways in which state actors try to abuse and undermine open democratic conversation. To build on this mission we hosted an online conference this summer with Carnegie that brought together industry experts to discuss further collaboration and ways to empower deeper research of these critical issues. We will continue to facilitate these forums in 2021.Â 
We believe we have a responsibility to protect the integrity of the public conversation and hold state power to account. We will continue to keep our archive updated so the public
column30: journalists
column31:
and the research community can access and analyze these networks.Â 
Keep on top of regular updates from us over at @TwitterSafety.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Transparency around image cropping and changes to come "
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Transparency around image cropping and changes to come 
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 1 October 2020\nLink copied successfully\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re always striving to work in a way that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s transparent and easy to understand
column9: but we don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t always get this right. Recent conversation around our photo cropping methods brought this to the forefront
column10: and over the past week
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been reviewing the way we test for bias in our systems and discussing ways we can improve how we display images on Twitter. So
column12: while there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a lot still to do
column13: today we want to share how we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re developing a solution for each of these areas.\u00c2\u00a0\nHow We Tested Our System\nWe tested the existing machine learning (ML) system that decides how to crop images before bringing it to Twitter
column14: but we should\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve published how we did it at the same time so the analysis could be externally reproducible. This was an oversight.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nThe image cropping system relies on saliency
column15: which predicts where people might look first. For our initial bias analysis
column16: we tested pairwise preference between two demographic groups (White-Black
column17: White-Indian
column18: White-Asian and male-female). In each trial
column19: we combined two faces into the same image
column20: with their order randomized
column21: then computed the saliency map over the combined image. Then
column22: we located the maximum of the saliency map
column23: and recorded which demographic category it landed on. We repeated this 200 times for each pair of demographic categories and evaluated the frequency of preferring one over the other.\nWhile our analyses to date haven\u00e2\u0080\u0099t shown racial or gender bias
column24: we recognize that the way we automatically crop photos means there is a potential for harm. We should\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve done a better job of anticipating this possibility when we were first designing and building this product. We are currently conducting additional analysis to add further rigor to our testing
column25: are committed to sharing our findings
column26:
and are exploring ways to open-source our analysis so that others can help keep us accountable.
Changes to Come
We are prioritizing work to decrease our reliance on ML-based image cropping by giving people more visibility and control over what their images will look like in a Tweet. Weâve started exploring different options to see what will work best across the wide range of images people Tweet every day. We hope that giving people more choices for image cropping and previewing what theyâll look like in the Tweet composer may help reduce the risk of harm.Â Â 
Going forward
column27: we are committed to following the \u00e2\u0080\u009cwhat you see is what you get\u00e2\u0080\u009d principles of design
column28: meaning quite simply: the photo you see in the Tweet composer is what it will look like in the Tweet. There may be some exceptions to this
column29: such as photos that aren\u00e2\u0080\u0099t a standard size or are really long or wide. In those cases
column30: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll need to experiment with how we present the photo in a way that doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t lose the creator\u00e2\u0080\u0099s intended focal point or take away from the integrity of the photo.\u00c2\u00a0\nBias in ML systems is an industry-wide issue
column31: and one we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to improving on Twitter. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re aware of our responsibility
column32: and want to work towards making it easier for everyone to understand how our systems work. While no system can be completely free of bias
column33: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to minimize bias through deliberate and thorough analysis
column34: and share updates as we progress in this space.\nThere\u00e2\u0080\u0099s lots of work to do
column35:
but weâre grateful for everyone who spoke up and shared feedback on this. Weâre eager to improve and will share additional updates as we have them.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
