column3: "title": "Inclusion & Diversity Report September 2020: #BlackLivesMatter"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nInclusion & Diversity Report September 2020: #BlackLivesMatter\nWednesday
column8: 30 September 2020\nLink copied successfully\nIn our Q2 Report
column9: we explored the company\u00e2\u0080\u0099s response to the global COVID pandemic. This quarter
column10:
we take a closer look at the impact of #BlackLivesMatter for Tweeps in the US and around the world.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Just when 2020 had done the most â it did more. Itâs been a long overdue summer of racial reckoning in the United States and around the world
column11: as advocates and allies raise their voices and demand an end to systemic racism
column12: white supremacy
column13: police brutality
column14: and anti-Blackness.\u00c2\u00a0\n#BlackLivesMatter is a movement that transcends political parties or nation-states; it's grounded in a struggle for fundamental human rights\u00c2\u00a0\u00e2\u0080\u0094 and the hashtag first appeared in 2013 right on Twitter. So not only does that mean it hits especially close to home for all of us at Twitter
column15: but also
column16: as a Black woman raising three Black children
column17: this work is deeply personal.\nThe road to racial equality is long
column18: but I\u00e2\u0080\u0099m proud of the steps we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve taken to lay the foundation for us to continue to drive progress. While this blog post is mostly focused on the urgent call for change within the Black community in the US
column19:
we know that this echoes throughout our work with underrepresented groups around the world.
Letâs start with representation within our US workforce*:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâve set an ambitious goal for 2025 of having at least 25% of our overall US workforce be underrepresented minoritiesÂ â at least 10% of which will be Black Tweeps. These numbers arenât nearly big enough
column20: especially in technical and leadership roles
column21: but they do show that Twitter strives to be a leader of our industry when it comes to representation of Black employees. Check out our latest workforce representation data in our Inclusion & Diversity Report.\nSo once Tweeps walk through our (now virtual) doors
column22:
what do we do to make sure they #LoveWhereYouWork?Â  Short answer: A lotâ¦
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
First
column23: we want every Tweep regardless of location or job to understand their role in creating a culture where everyone is empowered to bring their full authentic selves to work
column24: experience belonging
column25: and do the best work of their career. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s one of the first messages we deliver to all new Tweeps on Day One in #FlightSchool
column26: our new hire orientation. This vision takes ongoing work
column27: so we also empower Tweeps with courses like \u00e2\u0080\u009cHealthy Conversations\u00e2\u0080\u009d (how to respectfully navigate tough topics in the workplace)
column28: \u00e2\u0080\u009cWords Matter\u00e2\u0080\u009d (how to spot and interrupt microaggressions)
column29: and \u00e2\u0080\u009cAllyship @ Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u009d (how to be an ally to underrepresented people). We recently made these courses mandatory for all Tweeps around the world to ensure everyone is operating with the same understanding of what is expected from them.\nOur Business Resource Groups (BRGs) are the lifeblood of inclusion efforts at Twitter and Blackbirds is one of our oldest
column30: largest
column31: and most well known. Founded in 2012
column32: Blackbirds membership spans across our global offices. In the past year alone
column33: membership has grown by more than 100% \u00e2\u0080\u0094 a testament to the strength of our Blackbirds community and their allies. I want to take a moment to personally acknowledge the global leadership team of Blackbirds whose passionate commitment to this work makes us all better. Thank you
column34: Keyaira Lock
column35: Jade Williams
column36: Marvin Williams
column37: Sioban Massiah
column38: Ola Idowu
column39: Sheldon Louis
column40:
and Royce Haynes.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
These Tweeps âÂ and all our BRG chairs around the worldÂ Â â empower our next generation of leaders
column41: foster a culture of inclusivity and belonging
column42: and give back to the greater community. In addition to performing their core job function
column43: they navigate the complexities
column44: nuances
column45: and emotional labor of sometimes being the only person who looks
column46: loves
column47: worships
column48: or has lived like them. They do this work to empower our next generation of leaders
column49: so that one day
column50: they will no longer be the only. This work is essential to Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s success \u00e2\u0080\u0094 it is not a \u00e2\u0080\u009cside hustle\u00e2\u0080\u009d or \u00e2\u0080\u009cvolunteer activity.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\u00c2\u00a0That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we recently introduced a new compensation program to formally recognize the global leadership team of all of our BRGs.\u00c2\u00a0\nDespite longstanding ongoing investments in this work
column51: like many of you
column52: this summer we were called to do even more.\u00c2\u00a0\nFirst
column53: we hosted a series of #FlockTalks on racial justice and anti-Blackness in the US
column54: EMEA
column55: and JAPAC. #FlockTalks are Tweep-only sessions
column56: designed to hold space for those who\u00e2\u0080\u0099d like to come together in community to share how they're feeling with one another. We believe there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a direct correlation between conversations like this
column57: the health of our workplace
column58: and the health of our service.\u00c2\u00a0\nThe #FlockTalks revealed that many of our Tweeps were struggling with emotions highly associated with trauma \u00e2\u0080\u0094 anger
column59: anxiety
column60: sadness
column61: depression
column62: and numbness. So we created #TakeCare
column63: a one-hour
column64: virtual discussion featuring therapists and wellness experts specializing in racism and trauma
column65: providing tools and guidance to help Tweeps unpack and process everything happening in the world. We also expanded our mental health benefits to increase ongoing access to Black therapists with expertise in anti-Blackness
column66: systemic racism
column67:
and race-related trauma.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Racism impacts communities around the world. Thatâs why nearly all of our global BRGs delivered programs that empowered Tweeps to reflect on
column68:
and take a deeper look at anti-Blackness across their respective communities:Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitter Alas hosted a four-part workshop series dismantling anti-Blackness within the Latinx community
column69: featuring a wide array of global speakers across the Latinx diaspora
column70: including Rosa Clemente (@rosaClemente)
column71: Zahira Kelly-Cabrera (@bad_dominicana)
column72:
and Luana Genot (@luanagenot).
Monique Melton (@MoeMotivate) joined Twitter Parents to discuss raising antiracist kids
Twitter Open kicked off global Pride Month by unpacking the intersectionality of the Black and Queer communities with DeRay Mckesson (@deray).Â 
Twitter Stripes hosted a powerful conversation about #BlackLivesMatter and combating racial bias in the military
column73: which featured veteran Tweeps as well as external speakers
column74: Richard Brookshire
column75: co-founder of the Black Veterans Project (@BlackVetProject)
column76: and Tonya Oxendine of Merging Vets and Players (@VetsandPlayers).\u00c2\u00a0\nTwitter Faith co-hosted a #PraiseBreak with Blackbirds for a moment of reflection
column77: gratitude
column78: and faith
column79:
with special guest DJ Diamond Kuts (@djdiamondkuts).
Twitter Women facilitated a hands-on workshop called #CallYourGirlfriend on the historical context and understanding privilege and oppression with Melanie Brazzell of What Really Makes Us Safe (@WhatMakesUsSafe).
Twitter Able hosted a global all-hands discussing allyship and solidarity with the black community.Â 
And Twitter Asians is planning an Anti-Racism series with the goal of providing participants with the knowledge and tools to become active in dismantling racism and prejudice in the Asian community.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
All summer
column80: we demonstrated our solidarity and allyship on @TwitterTogether
column81: and across other Twitter owned and operated accounts. We proudly joined the push for\u00c2\u00a0#PoliceReformNow
column82: #JusticeForBreonnaTaylor
column83: and our leadership and policy teams have been meeting with advocates and elected officials to help drive progress. We made sure Black mental health resources were front and center for anyone who needed them in this curated Moment. We published \u00e2\u0080\u009cHow to be an ally right now: #BlackLivesMatter
column84: \u00e2\u0080\u009d shared it with the world in a thread and blog
column85: and helped everyone Diversify Your Feed.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nLast week
column86: the verdict in Breonna Taylor's case once again showed us how much work we have to do. The system isn't broken
column87: it's functioning exactly as it was intended to. And for those wanting to practice allyship
column88: wanting to dismantle systems of oppression and change the status quo
column89: we launched a new series of workshops for Tweeps with new content to reflect current events based on our four principles of allyship: Learn
column90: Ask
column92: and Speak Up.\u00c2\u00a0Learn about approach in the Twitter Blog
column93:
âAllyship Right Now.â
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We also launched #TwitterTogetherTalks
column94: a new series exploring racial equity
column95: inclusion
column96: and diversity. We started with best-selling author and scholar Dr. Ibram X. Kendi (@DrIbram) for a conversation with Tweeps about dismantling systemic racism and how to be an antiracist. Next up was award-winning writer
column97: director
column98: and advocate Janet Mock (@janetmock) to explore the intersectionality of movements and the importance of #BlackTransLivesMatter. Most recently
column99: we hosted Anthony Ray Hinton (@eji_org) in conversation with @jack to explore racial injustice and brutality in policing and the impact of mass incarceration on Black communities.\nA common theme we heard was that between the pandemic and a summer of racial reckoning
column100: Tweeps were tired. So we introduced a day of global rest for the company. It was so popular
column101: we introduced four more. We also led our industry by announcing that Juneteenth would be a US holiday forevermore. For Tweeps outside the US
column102: we identified regional emancipation dates to ensure everyone can observe this important day of reflection.\nOn Juneteenth
column103: we elevated Black voices and their Tweets to educate and celebrate Black joy. Across the nation
column104: our Community and Culture team demanded racial equity and justice with powerful statements
column105: reflected on billboards throughout cities at the center of the #BlackLivesMatter movement. Our Social team partnered with Blackbirds to dedicate an entire day to a never-ending parade of creativity and a true love for life with #BlackJoy. We also commemorated with a @Twitter Voice Tweet from Opal Tometi (co-founder of #BlackLivesMatter)
column106: published a @TwitterTogether thread educating on what Juneteenth represents
column107:
and commissioned Black artists to update headers of Twitter owned and operated accounts.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We also deepened our investments in the advocacy organizations on the front lines driving change
column108: and empowered Tweeps to do the same by lifting our matching gifts cap. We made a $250
column109: 000 grant split evenly between the Equal Justice Initiative (@eji_org) and the National Association of Black Journalists (@NABJ). We dedicated #AdsForGood grants for nonprofit organizations to amplify #BlackLivesMatter voices on Twitter. As we did with COVID-19
column110: we are offering free premium ad services for credible resources and voices from the movement on Twitter
column111: such as the Spotlight and Promoted sections in the Trends/Explore tab and First View on the Home timeline for all users to see
column113:
weâre introducing a more globally inclusive approach to our Corporate Social Responsibility strategy.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
One of the most powerful things we can do is promote healthy conversation on our service. Weâll continue to iterate on our policies and roll out new product features to do this. This is a part of ongoing work to expand our hateful conduct policy that started in 2018. As a part of this work
column114: we quickly realized we don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t have all the answers
column115: which is why we have developed a global working group of outside experts to help us think about how we should address dehumanizing speech around more complex categories like race
column117: and national origin. This group will help us understand the nuances
column119: and ultimately help us answer questions like how we address power and privilege on the service.\u00c2\u00a0\nMost importantly
column120:
weâll continue to serve the public conversation and fight for racial justice and inclusionÂ â and we wonât stop #UntilWeAllBelong.

column3: "title": "Our continued work to keep Twitter secure "
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Our continued work to keep Twitter secure 
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 24 September 2020\nLink copied successfully\nAt Twitter
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re acutely aware of the role we play in society and we take that responsibility seriously. We have been
column10: and will continue to be
column11: focused on empowering the public conversation. To do this
column12: we must protect the security and privacy of the people who use our service. You can see some of this work on Twitter
column13: such as in the privacy and account security settings and controls we offer you
column14: but a lot of it happens behind the scenes. We want to share more on the work we're doing to protect your account and keep Twitter secure.\n1. Improving our access management processes and authentication systems.\nAs we shared in July
column15: we have teams around the world that need to access customer data to provide account services and keep Twitter running. For example
column16: engineering team members have access to build and operate the features that people rely on every day. Other teams use proprietary tools to help with a variety of support issues including to review content for potential violations of the Twitter Rules and respond to user reports. We are constantly working to balance how we build products and provide support to people who use Twitter while ensuring the security and privacy of people who use our service. That means access is limited and is only granted for valid business reasons (i.e.
column17: ensuring an account holder can get support if they are locked out of their account).\nTo further secure our internal tools from potential misuse
column18: we have been strengthening the rigorous checks that team members with access must undergo. This also helps reduce the potential for an unauthorized person to get access to our systems. We have strict principles around who is allowed access to which tools and at what time
column19: and require specific justifications for customer data to be accessed.\n2. Improving our detection and monitoring capabilities.\nSimilar to how we proactively detect and alert you of suspicious behavior on your account to help you keep it secure
column20: we have internal detection and monitoring tools that help alert us of unusual behavior or possible unauthorized attempts to access our internal tools. These tools are constantly being improved
column21: even since the July incident
column22: to include things like expanding our detection and response efforts to include suspicious authentication and access activity.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn addition to the improvements we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made on the backend
column23: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important for you to have meaningful controls over your account security and privacy on Twitter. We recently implemented some of these security measures for a designated group of high-profile
column24: election-related Twitter accounts in the US
column25: and we encourage everyone on Twitter to enable security controls such as two-factor authentication and password reset protection.\n3. Investing in tools and training for our employees and contractors.\nIn addition to requiring Security and Privacy & Data Protection training for all newly hired Twitter employees
column26: we introduced new courses and increased the frequency and availability of existing courses for all employees. For example
column27: we introduced two new mandatory training sessions for people who have access to non-public information. These trainings make clear the dos and don'ts when accessing this information and ensure employees understand how to protect themselves when they are online so they can better avoid becoming phishing targets for attackers. In addition to existing security training courses
column28: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also enhanced training content on secure coding
column29: threat modeling
column30: privacy impact assessments
column31: and privacy by design so privacy is integrated into everything we design and build by default.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur teams have also been investing in additional penetration testing and scenario planning to help secure Twitter from a range of possible threats
column32: including in the context of the upcoming 2020 US elections. Specifically
column33: over a five month period from March 1 to August 1
column34: Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s cross-functional elections team conducted tabletop exercises internally on specific election scenarios. Some of the topics included: hacks and other security incidents
column35: leaks of hacked materials
column36: platform manipulation activity
column37: foreign interference
column38: coordinated online voter suppression campaigns
column39: and the post election day period.\nInternally
column40: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re rolling out phishing-resistant security keys and requiring our team to use them when authenticating to systems around the world. This is work we had already begun but have accelerated in recent weeks. This will help reduce the risk of an unauthorized third-party gaining access to our internal systems using compromised employee credentials.\u00c2\u00a0\nFinally
column41: we continue to invest in and scale the processes in place to review products for security and privacy concerns before they launch. If a project could have significant privacy impacts
column42: we conduct a detailed impact assessment to make sure we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re taking appropriate measures before we launch it. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve significantly increased the number of privacy reviews and impact assessments the past few years. Specifically
column44: we did about 100 privacy reviews; in 2019
column45: we did almost 500 privacy reviews; and in the first 6 months of 2020
column46: we have completed more than 300 privacy reviews. \nSo what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next? \nWe are continuing to invest more in the teams
column47: technology
column48: and resources to support this critical work. We also know that we can do more to make it easier for you to find and use the settings and controls we offer
column49: so we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re working on rolling out improvements to the design and navigation of our privacy settings. You\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll see these improvements in Twitter soon.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe want you to have peace of mind when you come to Twitter that the data you share with us is secure
column50: and that you understand and feel empowered to use the controls we offer you to keep your account secure. This will always be ongoing work for us
column51: but trust that we are committed to acting in the interest of the people who use our service. Where we discover an issue
column52: we will work quickly to fix it
column53: learn from it
column54:
and hold ourselves accountable by keeping you informed.Â

column3: "title": "Celebrating the power of young people through #YouthLead"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nCelebrating the power of young people through #YouthLead\nThursday
column8: 24 September 2020\nLink copied successfully\nYoung people make up more than half of the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s population and they are the largest group of Internet users. On the 24th of September 2018
column9: the UN launched Youth2030: The United Nations Youth Strategy. By partnering with young people
column10: the UN Youth Strategy aims to recognise the resilience of young people around the world
column11: address their needs and empower them to achieve their full potential.\u00c2\u00a0\nTwo years on from the launch
column12: through Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s open and conversational nature
column13:
weâve seen countless examples on Twitter of young people leading impactful movements around the world on issues like climate change and social justice - empowering them to have a voice on issues that matter most to them.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Throughout August - #YouthMonth2020 - Twitter collaborated with the Office of the Secretary Generalâs Envoy on Youth to raise awareness of the work being done by the youth of today. We collaborated on #YouthDay through an on-service conversation with @UNYouthEnvoy
column14: this activation highlighted the challenges faced by youth of today
column15: as we navigate the global COVID-19 pandemic.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn the spirit of marking the two year anniversary of the UN\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Youth 2030 Strategy
column16: we also worked together on the first ever Twitter emoji designed by young people
column17: for young people
column18:
across the globe.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Through a series of engaging Twitter polls and threads from @UNYouthEnvoy
column19: young people had their voices heard on the creation of an emoji that would represent them and the work they do; from deciding on the hashtag #YouthLead
column20: to determining what design elements the emoji should include
column21: to voting on the final emoji design.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nThis emoji and hashtag aims to unify and drive an inclusive conversation on Twitter about the work young people are leading on in our local and global communities.\u00c2\u00a0 To support this diverse and inclusive dialogue
column22: the\u00c2\u00a0#YouthLead\u00c2\u00a0hashtag
column23: \u00c2\u00a0is available in 20 different languages including Spanish
column24:
Korean and Thai.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Today
column25: on the two year anniversary of the Youth 2030 Strategy
column26: we are happy to launch the chosen emoji
column27: activated on Twitter through the hashtag #YouthLead. Through this emoji
column28: we are inviting young people from all around the world to share their perspectives on what youth leadership looks like to them \u00e2\u0080\u0094 highlighting the many innovations
column29:
challenges and successes that youth continue to experience everyday.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Jayathma Wickramanayake
column30: the UN Secretary-General\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Envoy on Youth
column31: notes; ''Young people are disproportionately affected by the COVID-19 pandemic \u00e2\u0080\u0094 from its immediate challenges like disruption to education
column32: loss of employment
column33: increased mental health challenges
column34: and increased gender-based violence both online and offline
column35: to its long-term socio economic impacts
column36: young people have undoubtedly been hit the hardest. But they rose up to the challenge. As they always are during times of crisis
column37: young people were resilient and resourceful
column38: and they stepped up to protect and support their communities regardless of the challenges they were facing.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe are pleased to collaborate with Twitter to celebrate the resiliency and leadership that young people show every day on the streets
column39: in the classrooms and in the frontlines by creating the #YouthLead emoji by young people
column40:
for young people to celebrate their contributions to build a more sustainable and peaceful word.â
These ideas for the #YouthLead emoji were brought to life through the artwork of young artistÂ Seqininnguaq Qitura Poulsen. Seqininnguaq is an emerging young Inuk/Kalaaleq leader from Kalaallit Nunaat (Greenland) where she works on indigenous and LGBTQ+ rights as well as education and mental health. Seqininnguaq is also part of the Global Indigenous Youth Caucus where she is leading as their Arctic Focal Point.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
When Seqininnguaq was bringing young peoplesâ ideas to life with the emoji
column41: it was important for her to highlight that young people can and should be empowered to have a powerful voice in important decisions being made
column42: around the world.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nTo mark the launch
column43: Seqininnguaq had a special message to young people around the world:\u00c2\u00a0 \u00e2\u0080\u009cI know you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re struggling and no matter how much you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re struggling and what it is you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re struggling with
column44: there is always support and help. You will find your people
column45: you will find a place where you feel safe
column46: accepted and loved
column47: I promise'' \nCelebrating the power of youth is something that we continue to prioritise at Twitter. Throughout the year
column48: we have partnered with youth organisations across the globe to support them
column49: as they make use of Twitter to engage in conversations leading to change.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur partnerships with organisations like the Office of the Secretary General\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Envoy on Youth
column50:
are key for us to stay engaged and educated on the needs and wants of the youth of today - we appreciate these collaborations and look forward to what partnerships like this can create in the future.Â 
To see how young voices are empowered on Twitter followÂ @TwitterForGoodÂ and join the conversation -Â #YouthLead.Â 
Â 
** Source: Twitter/Ipsos US national study
column51:
Sept. 2020; Young people = 18-34 year olds in the US; Young Twitter users refers to those 18-34 who report using Twitter at least once a month in the US.

column3: "title": "Empowering US voters on National Voter Registration Day"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Empowering US voters on National Voter Registration Day
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 22 September 2020\nLink copied successfully\nAs the 2020 US Election approaches
column9: Twitter is taking steps to empower more people to join in the conversation
column10: participate confidently
column11: and make their voices heard.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn recent weeks
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve launched a new US election hub that makes it easy to find reliable news and information
column13: expanded our policies around election misinformation
column14: and required high profile election-related accounts to increase their security.\u00c2\u00a0\nNow
column15: in partnership with National Voter Registration Day
column16: Twitter is making its biggest push ever to encourage people to register to vote and confirm their registration status. Today
column17:
weâre rolling out new tools and in-app experiences that will put voter registration resources at the public's fingertips and support the essential voter registration efforts happening across the country.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Today
column18: every person with a Twitter account located within the United States will see:\nA home timeline prompt encouraging them to register to vote or confirm their registration via TurboVote
column19: a tool from the nonpartisan
column20: nonprofit organization Democracy Works
column21: and to Tweet out these resources.\nA push alert that directs them to a landing page with additional voter registration information.\nA promoted campaign from @TwitterGov
column22: which includes a takeover of today\u00e2\u0080\u0099s US Promoted Trend Spotlight with registration resources from TurboVote.\nTwitter hashtag emoji with #NationalVoterRegistrationDay and #VoteReady to empower civic conversation across the country.\nThe prompt and push alert is available in over 40 languages
column23: depending on each person\u00e2\u0080\u0099s individual app settings.\nDuring the 2018 US midterm elections
column24: 68% of people who used TurboVote resources via Twitter turned out to vote. While nine in ten people who use Twitter daily say they plan to vote in the upcoming US elections
column25: over half say they still need more information about the candidates on their ballot and how to vote in 2020.*\nThese new activations go hand in hand with ongoing Twitter efforts to empower greater civic engagement this election season. In August
column26: we launched our first ever voter registration search prompt in partnership with Vote.Gov. When people search for key terms related to voter registration on Twitter
column27: they see a prompt in English or Spanish pointing them to official sources. Last week
column28: celebrities and influencers Tweeted with #YourVoiceYourVote
column29: sharing important voter registration PSAs using Voice Tweets that linked to voter registration and absentee ballot information. Plus
column30: people on Twitter will continue to have access to a range of fun
column31: election-themed emojis through the debates
column32: early voting
column33: and election day.\u00c2\u00a0\nPeople should expect additional voting-related notices as we get closer to election day
column34: and stay tuned for more from us here and from @TwitterGov.\n*Twitter/Ipsos national study

column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Celebrating 10 years of #KpopTwitter
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 21 September 2020\nLink copied successfully\nOver the past 10 years
column9: @Twitter and K-pop have become a true dream team. There\u00e2\u0080\u0099s so much energy on the timeline
column10: from both the artists and the fans.\nWhen K-pop artists want to reach a global audience
column11: they go on Twitter to connect with their passionate fans who want to be the first to see and talk about what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening. These fans -- many who are young and based all over the world -- are flocking to Twitter to join these fun #KpopTwitter conversations to feel connected to a global fan community.\nAll we can say is thank you -- it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s been a pleasure to watch and participate in the growth of K-pop over the past 10 years. Through your passion
column12: #KpopTwitter is one of the largest global conversations on Twitter today. K-pop and Twitter have grown side by side over the past decade
column13: and despite the global COVID outbreak
column14: there were 6.1 billion K-pop related Tweets in the past 12 months worldwide. Now with over 300 K-pop Topics (by artists names) that can be followed on Twitter
column15:
fans around the world can immediately see the best Tweets and easily join the global conversation about their favorite artists.

To celebrate 10 years of #KpopTwitter success

column17: we are organizing an exclusive \u00e2\u0080\u009cDecade of #KpopTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u009d global live party at the #TwitterBlueroom

2020.

Twitter continues to be the best way for music fans to see and talk about whatâs happening. Thatâs especially true in the K-pop world

dancing and âHallyu (Korean Wave)â culture that has taken the world by storm.

#KpopTwitter is truly a global community as the top 20 markets with the most Kpop-related conversations (from July 1

2020) cover every region in the world today:

2020):

column3: "title": "Improved account security during the 2020 US election"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nImproved account security during the 2020 US election\nThursday
column8: 17 September 2020\nLink copied successfully\nVoters
column9: political candidates
column10: elected officials and journalists rely on Twitter every day to share and find reliable news and information about the election
column11: and we take our responsibility to them seriously. As we learn from the experience of past security incidents and implement changes
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also focused on keeping high-profile accounts on Twitter safe and secure during the 2020 US election.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re taking the additional step of proactively implementing account security measures for a designated group of high-profile
column13: election-related Twitter accounts in the US. Starting today
column14: these accounts will be informed via an in-app notification from Twitter of some of the initial account security measures we will be requiring or strongly recommending going forward.\u00c2\u00a0 \nWhile we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re requiring some accounts do this given the unique sensitivities of the election period
column15: everyone on Twitter can take advantage of these security measures
column16:
(and we encourage them to do so!) 
What types of accounts are in this designated group? 
US Executive Branch and Congress 
US Governors and Secretaries of State 
Presidential campaigns
column17: political parties and candidates with Twitter Election Labels running for US House
column18: US Senate
column19:
or Governor 
Major US news outlets and political journalists 
What account security requirements and recommendations will be communicated today? 
Accounts will be required to use a strong password. Accounts with a weak password will be required to update and use a stronger password the next time they log in. 
Twitter will enable Password reset protection for accounts by default. This is a setting that helps prevent unauthorized password changes by requiring an account to confirm its email address or phone number to initiate a password reset. 
Accounts will be strongly encouraged to enable Two-factor authentication (2FA). 2FA provides an additional layer of security to protect accounts from unauthorized logins. 
Here is what the first notification will look like:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In the coming weeks
column20: Twitter will also implement additional proactive internal security safeguards for these accounts
column21: including:\nMore sophisticated detections and alerts to help us
column22: and account holders
column23:
respond rapidly to suspicious activity
Increased login defenses to prevent malicious account takeover attempts
Expedited account recovery support to ensure account security issues are resolved quickly
Implementing these security measures is a critical preventative step
column24:
and you will continue to see us introduce new protections and features to help safeguard accounts on Twitter.

column3: "title": "Helping you find accurate US Election News and Information"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Helping you find accurate US Election News and Information
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 15 September 2020\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter wants to empower every eligible person to vote in the 2020 US election
column9: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re focused on helping people register
column10: better understand the voting process during COVID-19 including early voting options
column11: and feel informed about the choices on their ballot. While nine in ten daily Twitter users say they plan to vote in the upcoming US elections
column12: over half say they still need more information about the candidates on their ballot and how to vote in 2020.*\nAs elections occur around the world
column13: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen Twitter serve as the centralized hub for real-time political conversation
column14: resources and breaking news. But we also know that at times it can be hard to quickly find the reliable news and accurate information people need in order to meet registration deadlines and participate confidently.\nThat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve banned political ads
column15: expanded our policies around election misinformation
column16: and are adding context to Tweets with labels for candidates
column17: government and state-affiliated media accounts
column18: and notices on Tweets with manipulated media. Trends now include additional context
column19: Search results about voter registration lead with official sources
column20: and people can report Tweets with deliberately misleading election information.\u00c2\u00a0\nWith just under 50 days to go until election day and when many Americans are already facing registration deadlines and preparing for early voting
column21:
weâre launching our 2020 US election hub to make it simpler for people to find accurate information and resources on Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
People in the United States will see the hub at the top of their Explore tab which will include:
News in both English and Spanish in the form of Twitter Moments created by reputable news outlets themselves
column22: or by Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Curation team.\nLive streams of major election events like debates.\nA tool that shows candidates for US House
column23: US Senate
column24: and governor with an Election Label in your state.\nLocalized news and resources by state.\nAnd in a first for Twitter
column25: the hub will also include a series of voter education public service announcements (PSAs) created using information from nonpartisan government and voting advocacy organizations. The PSAs will run on Twitter all the way to election day
column26: providing factual information on topics like voter registration
column27: how to request an absentee ballot
column28: and tips on staying healthy while voting during the pandemic.\nThe first PSA is already live here in English and Spanish
column29: and if people want to subscribe to this series
column30: they can Like or Retweet this Tweet in order to receive them via in-app notifications.\nThere\u00e2\u0080\u0099s more work to be done on voter empowerment during this election
column31: so stay tuned for more from us here and from @TwitterGov.\n*Twitter/Ipsos national study

column3: "title": "Expanding our policies to further protect the civic conversation"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nExpanding our policies to further protect the civic conversation\nThursday
column8: 10 September 2020\nLink copied successfully\nThe conversation happening on Twitter is never more important than during elections. Twitter is where people come to hear directly from elected officials and candidates for office
column9: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s where they come to find breaking news
column10: and increasingly
column11: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s an integral source for information on when and how to vote in elections. As more people seek ways to vote and express their fundamental civil rights safely during the COVID-19 pandemic
column12: the need for this type of information has only grown.\nUpdating our policies\nOur existing Civic Integrity Policy targets the most directly harmful types of content
column13:
namely those related toÂ 
Information or false claims on how to participate in civic processes
Content that could intimidate or suppress participation
False affiliation
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In recognition of the changing circumstances of how people will vote in 2020
column14: and in line with our commitment to protecting the integrity of the election conversation
column15: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re expanding this existing framework. The goal is to further protect against content that could suppress the vote and help stop the spread of harmful misinformation that could compromise the integrity of an election or other civic process.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s changing?\u00c2\u00a0\nPeople who use our service have told us that non-specific
column16:
disputed information that could cause confusion about an election should be presented with more context.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Starting next week
column17: we will label or remove false or misleading information intended to undermine public confidence in an election or other civic process. This includes but is not limited to:\nFalse or misleading information that causes confusion about the laws and regulations of a civic process
column18: or officials and institutions executing those civic processes.\nDisputed claims that could undermine faith in the process itself
column19: e.g. unverified information about election rigging
column20: ballot tampering
column21: vote tallying
column22: or certification of election results.\nMisleading claims about the results or outcome of a civic process which calls for or could lead to interference with the implementation of the results of the process
column23: e.g. claiming victory before election results have been certified
column24:
inciting unlawful conduct to prevent a peaceful transfer of power or orderly succession.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In line with our existing enforcement approach
column25: Tweets that are labeled under this expanded policy will have reduced visibility across the service. Reducing the visibility of Tweets means that we will not amplify the Tweets on a number of surfaces across Twitter. However
column26: anyone following the account will still be able to see the Tweet and Retweet.\nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next?\nThis policy will take effect in one week on Thursday
column27: September 17
column28: 2020. We will not permit our service to be abused around civic processes
column29: most importantly elections. Any attempt to do so \u00e2\u0080\u0094 both foreign and domestic \u00e2\u0080\u0094 will be met with strict enforcement of our rules
column30:
which are applied equally and judiciously for everyone.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet

column3: "title": "Amplifying #SuicidePrevention resources on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Amplifying #SuicidePrevention resources on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8:
9 September 2020
Link copied successfully
Protecting the health of the public conversation is a top priority for our company.
Many people use Twitter to express unique points of view and talk openly about concerns. As we grapple with the weight and reality of an unprecedented public health crisis
column9: it is our job to ensure that Twitter remains a safe space for anyone interested in mental health tips and resources or opening up about their individual mental health concerns. \nSuicide prevention in extraordinary times \nAccording to the World Health Organization
column10: almost 800
column11: 000 people die due to suicide every year. Further
column12: suicide rates can increase in prolonged crises and experts note that the COVID-19 global pandemic will cause distress and leave many people vulnerable to mental health problems and suicidal behavior. The US Center for Disease Control reports that younger adults
column13: racial/ethnic minorities and essential workers are disproportionately faced with these mental health challenges.\u00c2\u00a0\nThese statistics emphasize the urgency and importance of elevating the global conversation on suicide prevention and self harm
column14: and we recognize that we have a role and responsibility to help improve access to and raise awareness of suicide prevention and self harm information and services.\u00c2\u00a0\nRaising awareness and elevating the public conversation\nEarlier this summer
column15: we worked with various mental health partners across the globe to raise awareness and encourage honest conversation around the emotional challenges we are experiencing together
column16: amid the unprecedented COVID-19 crisis. Since then
column17: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve expanded our work with NGOs to identify
column18: connect
column19: and engage vulnerable people across the world. In particular
column20: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve continued to engage suicide prevention organizations and counseling services to ensure that people on Twitter feel safe and have access to support when they need it most.\nWorld Suicide Prevention Day\u00c2\u00a0\nWorld Suicide Prevention Day on September 10
column21: 2020 welcomes another opportunity to continue our momentum in spreading awareness and encouraging action to prevent suicide and self harm.\u00c2\u00a0\nTwitter is grateful to continue our global World Suicide Prevention Day partnership with the International Association for Suicide Prevention (IASP). Together
column22: for the third year
column23: we are launching a custom emoji in the shape of an orange ribbon - the international symbol for World Suicide Prevention Day. The emoji will appear when people Tweet with the hashtags #WorldSuicidePreventionDay
column24: #WSPD
column25: #WSPD2020 and #SuicidePrevention through September 25 and is activated in 23 languages.\nWe are working with over 20 nonprofit partners worldwide to offer Ads for Good grants and amplify their local campaigns on Twitter. These partners are leading suicide prevention and mental health awareness in markets across the Asia Pacific
column26: US
column27: Canada
column28: Latin America
column29: Europe
column30: and Africa.\nWe are also amplifying the creative activations of our Trust & Safety Council Suicide Prevention & Mental Health advisory group partners around World Suicide Prevention Day across the globe
column31: including:\n#ICANHELP: Using Twitter to amplify ideas from student leaders on tackling suicide in local communities across the US.\n#MentalHealthPH: Starting a hashtag campaign
column32: #MayKaramayKa
column33: to encourage people in the Philippines to thank those who helped them in times of need. They\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also hosting a Q&A on September 10th for mental health professionals and psychologists to answer questions in real-time.\nMentally Aware Nigeria: Launching an animated video series covering a range of topics from identifying suicidal behaviors to supporting those in need.\u00c2\u00a0\nTELL: Launching #StepUp
column34: a virtual step challenge encouraging everyone to take one step for each life lost daily from suicide in Japan - between WSPD and World Mental Health Day.\u00c2\u00a0\nBeyond Blue: Showcasing stories of 8 individuals who experienced suicidal ideation in Australia
column35:
empowering individuals in crisis to know that support is available.Â 
#ThereIsHelp
Weâve partnered with local mental health authorities and nonprofits in each market to offer #ThereIsHelp - a notification service that provides valuable mental health information and resources via Twitter and email. 
When someone searches for terms associated with suicide or self harm
column36: the top search result is a notification encouraging them to reach out for help. This year we expanded the prompts to several new markets in consultation with local mental health partners to ensure that we are sharing the latest and most helpful resources in our #ThereisHelp prompts across the globe.\n#ThereIsHelp is available for people in the US

column64: Thailand and the UK.\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s active commitment to improving mental health plays an important role in addressing suicide and self harm
column65:
and we look forward to continued collaboration with suicide prevention organizations across the world.

column3: "title": "Making Twitter more accessible"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Making Twitter more accessible
          
          
            and
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8:
2 September 2020
Link copied successfully
Serving the public conversation means continuously taking steps to make Twitter more accessible â from what we build to the internal programs and policies we implement globally â and this must include people with disabilities.Â 
Testing voice Tweets earlier this summer made us realize how much work we still need to do as a company
column9: and we made a commitment to make Twitter more inclusive for the disabled community \u00e2\u0080\u0093 creating a dedicated team to focus on greater accessibility
column10: tooling
column11: and advocacy across all of our products.\u00c2\u00a0\nSo what are we doing to accelerate this necessary change? \nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re introducing two new teams we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re building to focus on this work: 1) the Accessibility Center of Excellence and 2) the Experience Accessibility Team
column12: which will focus specifically on the features and products on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nThe Accessibility Center for Excellence will set goals
column13: drive progress
column14: consult and partner with groups across our core business functions to help make aspects of Twitter more accessible. This includes everything from accessibility in our office spaces to our marketing and communications strategies
column15: to legal and policy standards
column16: and more.\u00c2\u00a0 \nThe Experience Accessibility Team will work within our product org on new and existing features and products
column17: providing resources and tools that promote greater accessibility on the service. They\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll work in tandem with the Accessibility Center for Excellence to ensure we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re held accountable in identifying and filling accessibility gaps throughout the product development lifecycle. \nBeyond staffing our teams
column18: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re already working to add automated captions to audio and video by early 2021. This lays the foundation for a longer-term roadmap that invests broadly in media accessibility throughout our service. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve partnered with external groups and over the coming months we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be gathering feedback from people with disabilities via interviews
column19: surveys
column20: and doing remote usability studies of new prototypes. While this is underway
column21: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to test related media features. We know we need to do more to make our service accessible and we will \u00e2\u0080\u0093 you can follow along on all of our accessibility product updates at\u00c2\u00a0@TwitterA11y.\nWhile we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve outlined new initiatives happening across Accessibility @Twitter
column22: we are continuing to engage with our Tweeps
column23: partners
column24: and people on this important topic. Our business resource groups
column25: like @TwitterAble
column26: remain key voices in our cultural accessibility and product efforts
column27: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll keep hosting public forums like our \u00e2\u0080\u009cDisability in UX\u00e2\u0080\u009d event led by @TwitterA11y.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re proud of the progress we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made to make Twitter more accessible \u00e2\u0080\u0093 both as a company and as a service \u00e2\u0080\u0093 but we know there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a lot more work ahead to ensure we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re truly inclusive for people with disabilities. Follow @TwitterAble
column28: @TwitterTogether
column29:
andÂ @TwitterA11y for the latest updates to our progress. Weâll keep going #UntilWeAllBelong.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Building a real-time golf leaderboard"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Building a real-time golf leaderboard
                By
                
  
  
              
                and
                
  
  
Tuesday
column8:
1 September 2020
Link copied successfully
Insights
Building a real-time golf leaderboard
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Tuesday
column9: 1 September 2020\nLink copied successfully\nAs more and more people are enjoying opened golf courses right now
column10: we want to share some learnings from the Twitter Data Partner Cup that we hosted last fall. The format was a 'shotgun scramble' golf tournament in Los Angeles
column11: CA meant to celebrate a few of\u00c2\u00a0Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Data partners\u00c2\u00a0and their customers for a day of fun on the links. If you are unfamiliar with the scramble format
column12: each member of a four-person team tees off and the team repeatedly picks the best shot until the hole is completed. With a 'shotgun' start
column13: there are 18 teams that begin play simultaneously \u00e2\u0080\u0093 each starting on a different hole. For example
column14: team 8 starts on hole 8.\nWith most non-professional golf tournaments
column15: the team scores are typically not known until the very end when the scorecards are turned in. How cool would it be to get real-time score updates during the game? We saw this as an opportunity to create a tool that would allow for a live scoring system. This system could enable teams to submit their scores from the course as holes are completed
column16: and the compiled scores could be shared via a live leaderboard
column17:
helping to fuel the competition.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As members of the Twitter Developer Relations team
column18: we felt up for the challenge to build such a scoring system with the Twitter platform. We began prototyping a solution during a company hackweek. We first sketched out a technical design for a system where: \nTeam scores are submitted via Direct Messages.\nWhen a score arrives
column19: the score is stored
column20: a new leaderboard is generated
column21: and that leaderboard is immediately sent back to the scorer via a Direct Message.\nWhen a score arrives that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s under par
column22: a congratulatory Tweet is posted.\nEvent \"marshals\" are enabled to post leaderboard Tweets as the event unfolded.\nIt became clear that we'd be building a\u00c2\u00a0Twitter chatbot
column23: \u00c2\u00a0where private messages (Direct Messages) provide the main communication channel
column24: while also having the ability to communicate with public Tweets.\nDesign and Twitter building blocks\nWhen we thought about the features we'd want for such an app
column25: these surfaced as the main features:\nScores are submitted via Direct Messages using a simple format that encodes the team number
column26: the number of the hole just completed
column27: along with the score. Each team has a score keeper
column28: and this player is taught how to submit scores.\nWhen a player submits a score
column29: they should receive an updated leaderboard via Direct Message. This serves as confirmation that the score was received and accepted.\nThe system needed the ability to support updating an incorrect score. Mistakes will happen.\nIf the score is below par
column30: a Tweet is automatically posted to publicly congratulate the team. #BirdieAlert\nThe app should support a set of admin-level commands that only event marshals have access to. For example
column31: these marshals decide when to publicly Tweet the leaderboard
column32:
typically every 20-30 minutes. We did not want to Tweet a leaderboard every time a score is submitted since a total of 324 scores are expected.
The leaderboard should look good and be easy to understand. Building a leaderboard graphic took considerably more effort than expected. See below for the final output.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
With these design goals in mind
column33: we began to build with the following Twitter API endpoints
column34: which provide the foundation for any Twitter chatbot: \u00c2\u00a0\nAccount Activity API\u00c2\u00a0- We knew we were building a 'listening' application
column35: and we needed to listen for incoming Direct Messages with scores. The webhook-based Account Activity API (AAA) provides these real-time listening skills. The AAA provides the bridge between your web app and Twitter. We created the @HackerScorer account to host the chatbot and subscribed that account to the AAA service.\nDirect Message API\u00c2\u00a0- When a score was received
column36: the chatbot was designed to immediately respond to the scorer with an updated leaderboard in a Direct Messages. So
column37:
we knew the Direct Messages API would provide the fundamental 'submit score' communication channel.
POST statuses/updateÂ - TheÂ @HackerScorerÂ account needed to Tweet when the event marshals triggered a leaderboard update. The system was also designed to send a congratulatory Tweet automatically when a score arrived that was under par.
Learnings and next steps
Even though we were testing and debugging up until the night before the event (like any hackweek project)
column38: we are happy to report the leaderboard app worked nearly flawlessly. The ability to see how other teams were scoring added to the excitement as the event progressed. Seeing notifications of other team's subpar holes added to the \"what's happening now?\" experience.\nThe main day-of-show challenge was spotty cell coverage out on the course. It's definitely recommended to test coverage at the event location beforehand. Also
column39: in some cases
column40: there clearly was not enough training on how to submit scores correctly the first time (we will not name names). Finally
column41: we built the app to Tweet only when teams scored a Birdie (one under par). While Eagles (two under par) were not expected
column42: they happened several times and were not Tweeted about. More sadly
column43: there was a hole-in-one that went completely unacknowledged in real-time. Next time
column44:
weâll be sure to account for these rare events and notify the audience!
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Not into golf? That's OK. Keep in mind that the framework used here to support a live golf scoring system is general enough for other use cases. This design could be used for a variety of other scenarios like scavenger hunts and other sports tournaments
column45: such as soccer and bowling. Beyond shared sporting events
column46: these patterns can support private polls by receiving private votes and rankings and publicly sharing compiled results at their completion. \nThe next time you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re planning a tournament or friendly game
column47:
think of Twitter.
Want to learn more about building Twitter chatbots?
The @HackerScorer chatbot was developed in Python using Flask. See theÂ project's GitHub repositoryÂ for more details.
If you want to learn more about how this live scoring app was developed and deployed
column48: see our code-driven blog post about this prototype. This blog post is split into four parts
column49: focusing on getting started with Twitter chatbots
column50: designing the chatbot experience
column51: developing the database-driven scoring system
column52:
and generating leaderboard graphics in real-time.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet

column3: "title": "Adding more context to Trends"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Adding more context to Trends
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 1 September 2020\nLink copied successfully\nTrends show what everyone is talking about right now. But too often
column9: we look at one word or phrase trending on Twitter and ask
column10: \u00e2\u0080\u009cwhy is this trending?\u00e2\u0080\u009d That question was actually Tweeted over half a million times over the last year! It should be easier to understand what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s being said immediately. Throughout Twitter
column11: we've been working to bring people more context on what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening with labels on Tweets and accounts as well as curated pages (aka Moments) and related articles on trends. To help with this
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re adding pinned Tweets and descriptions on trends to help explain why something is trending.\u00c2\u00a0\nSometimes the right Tweet can help make sense of a trend. Starting today
column13: some trends will have a representative Tweet pinned to them to give you more insight about a trend right away. A combination of algorithms and our curation team determine if a Tweet represents a trend by evaluating if the Tweet is very reflective of the trend and popular. Our algorithms are designed to identify representative Tweets that aren\u00e2\u0080\u0099t potentially abusive
column14: spam
column15: or posted by accounts trying to take advantage of our system. Representative Tweets on trends can be found on Twitter for iOS and Android now. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re working to bring them to twitter.com soon too.\nIn the coming weeks
column16: you should see brief descriptions added to some trends as well to help add context to the trend. Descriptions will provide straightforward
column17:
clearly sourced context around why something is trending. Descriptions are developed by our curation team and follow their guidelines. Descriptions on trends will be found on twitter.com and Twitter for iOS and Android.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Representative Tweets and descriptions on trends will be available in Argentina

column31: the United Kingdom

column33: and the United States. To bring more clarity to the conversation
column34: we hope to add more context to more trends over time.\u00c2\u00a0\nTo be clear
column35:
we know there is more work to do to improve trends and the context updates weâre announcing today are just a small step in the right direction. There is more we can do to help people understand why something is trending and to provide transparency around how something trends. We need to make trends better and we will.

column3: "title": "How LikeFolio Gains Financial Insights for Investors with Twitter Data"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
How LikeFolio Gains Financial Insights for Investors with Twitter Data
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 31 August 2020\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter has long been the place where people discuss what matters to them
column9: including their opinions on brands
column10: products
column11: and lifestyle changes. But what some might not know is that companies are able to tap this massive amount of data to develop consumer behavior insights.\nWant to know how? Just ask Andy and Landon Swan-- they created\u00c2\u00a0LikeFolio
column12: a company that analyzes social media data to identify early shifts\u00c2\u00a0in consumer behavior that could help guide investment decisions for companies like TD Ameritrade and their clients.\u00c2\u00a0LikeFolio\u00c2\u00a0used Twitter as their data source due to easy-to-use APIs and for the natural way Twitter content was suited for mass consumption\u00c2\u00a0and analysis.\nSurfacing Consumer Behavior Insights\nWhen covid-19 pandemic shutdowns occurred in March 2020
column13: \u00c2\u00a0LikeFolio\u00c2\u00a0identified that mentions of dog and cat adoptions rose significantly on Twitter
column14:
surging over 68% in one month.Â LikeFolioâsÂ analysis revealed two trends:
Â Â Â Â 1.Â More pet adoptions meant consumers were buying more pet supplies.
Â Â Â Â 2.Â Consumers were likely to value home delivery during the pandemic shutdown.
Chewy
column15: an e-commerce pet supply company
column16: became a stock to monitor. As CHWY stock sold off with the broader market to under $23/share
column17: \u00c2\u00a0LikeFolio\u00e2\u0080\u0099s\u00c2\u00a0data revealed a massive increase in consumer spending with Chewy.\u00c2\u00a0LikeFolio\u00c2\u00a0clients were made aware of this potential trade idea through\u00c2\u00a0LikeFolio\u00e2\u0080\u0099s\u00c2\u00a0data insights. One month after the\u00c2\u00a0LikeFolio\u00c2\u00a0analysis
column18: \u00c2\u00a0CHWY stock doubled.\nLikeFolio\u00c2\u00a0is just one example of how companies can use Twitter data to provide a robust data set for analysis
column19: product innovation
column20: and
column21: as\u00c2\u00a0LikeFolio\u00c2\u00a0has discerned
column22:
opportunities to provide unique insights to inform better decision making.
ReadÂ LikeFolioâsÂ case studyÂ here.
And learn more about how you canÂ use Twitter Data.
