column3: "title": "Introducing the new Twitter Transparency Center"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Introducing the new Twitter Transparency Center
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8:
19 August 2020
Link copied successfully
Transparency is core to the work we do at Twitter. 
The open nature of our service has led to unprecedented challenges around protecting freedom of expression and privacy rights as governments around the world increasingly attempt to intervene in this open exchange of information. We believe that transparency is a key principle in our mission to protect the Open Internet
column9:
and advancing the Internet as a global force for good.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The fundamental belief in the power of open
column10: public conversation inspired Twitter to launch one of the industry's first transparency reports back in 2012. At that time
column11: our goal was to provide the public with regular insights into government pressure that impacted the public
column12: whether through overt attempts at political censorship or by way of soliciting account data through information requests.\nThe world has changed significantly since 2012. In 2020
column13: it is more important than ever that we shine a light on our own practices
column14: including how we enforce the Twitter Rules
column15: our ongoing work to disrupt global state-backed information operations
column16:
and the increased attempts by governments to request information about account holders. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Our new Twitter Transparency Center
We have reimagined and rebuilt our biannual Twitter Transparency Report site to become a comprehensive Twitter Transparency Center. Our goal with this evolution is make our transparency reporting more easily understood and accessible to the general public.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Whatâs new?Â 
Brand new website that includes all our disclosed data in one placeÂ 
Data visualizations making it easier to compare trends over timeÂ 
Country comparison module
Tooltips to help explain key terms and provide more insights on the terms we use
History of transparency milestones and updates
New metrics and methodology on the enforcement of the Twitter Rules (from July 2018 through December 2019)
New policy categories to better align with the Twitter Rules
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Reports will be published in Arabic
column17: Turkish
column18: Spanish
column19: German
column20: French
column21: Japanese
column22: and Portuguese very soon too
column23: and we are continuing to iterate on the process to further contextualize the data. \nOur work to increase transparency efforts across the company is tireless and constant. We will continue to work on increasing awareness and understanding about how our policies work and our practices around content moderation
column24: data disclosures and other critical areas. In addition
column25: we will take every opportunity to highlight the actions of law enforcement
column26: governments
column27:
and other organizations that impact Twitter and the people who use our service across the world.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The data
The latest data reflects the period July 1 to December 31
column28: 2019. We endeavour to release this material as soon as possible every six months but due to a number of factors
column29: including the COVID-19 pandemic and getting the new Twitter Transparency Center up and running
column30: we have faced delays. The next update to the data will cover the period of January - June 2020.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur work on information operations:\nOur archive of state-backed information operations is updated on a rolling basis after we identify and remove them from Twitter. We have also increased our cadence of disclosures
column31: recently sharing our largest disclosure to date with 32
column32: 242 accounts added to the archive.\nThis archive
column33: used by researchers
column34: journalists and experts around the world
column35: now spans more than 9 terabytes of media
column36: includes over 83
column37: 000 accounts
column38: and over 200 million Tweets and is an industry-first resource. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve now released datasets of information operations originating in more than 15 countries
column39: offering researchers unique insight into how information operations unfold on the service.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also expanding how we work with partners in the research community to improve understanding of information operations and disinformation. Earlier this year we strengthened our partnership with two leading research institutions \u00e2\u0080\u0094 the Australian Strategic Policy Institute (ASPI) and the Stanford Internet Observatory \u00e2\u0080\u0094 to enable their analysis and review of data related to our disclosures.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe also hosted our first ever #InfoOps2020 conference in partnership with Carnegie's Partnership for Countering Influence Operations. The event brought together academic experts
column40: industry
column41:
and government to discuss opportunities for collaboration and research on IO and support an open exchange of ideas between Twitter and the research community.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Platform Manipulation:
Our blog from earlier this year gives a thorough explanation about our proactive work to counter platform manipulation across the service and the common misconceptions around so-called âbotsâ on Twitter. Our policies in this area focus on behaviour
column42: not content
column43: and are written in a way that targets the spammy tactics different people or groups could use to try to manipulate the public conversation on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nContinuing a year-on-year trend
column44: our proactive detection of this behavior has resulted in an almost 10% reduction in anti-spam challenges
column45: e.g. when we ask people to provide a phone number or email address or fill in a ReCAPTCHA code to verify there is a human behind an account.\u00c2\u00a0\nTerrorism & violent extremism:\nThe Twitter Rules prohibit the promotion of terrorism and violent extremism. Action was taken on 86
column46: 799 unique accounts under this policy during this reporting period. 74% of the unique accounts were proactively suspended using our internal
column47: proprietary tools. We continue our close partnership with our peers as part of the Christchurch Call to Action and are committed to eradicating the presence of violent extremist content across our respective services.\u00c2\u00a0\nChild sexual exploitation:\nWe do not tolerate child sexual exploitation on Twitter. Child sexual exploitation (CSE) including links to images of or content promoting child exploitation
column48: is removed from the site without further notice and reported to The National Center for Missing & Exploited Children (NCMEC). People can report content that appears to violate the Twitter Rules regarding Child Sexual Exploitation via our web form and we also investigate other reports via various reporting flows in-app for CSE too. There were 257
column49: 768 unique accounts suspended during this reporting period for violating Twitter policies prohibiting child sexual exploitation. 84% of those unique accounts were proactively suspended using a combination of technologies (including PhotoDNA and internal
column50: proprietary tools).\nTwitter Rules enforcement:\nFor the first time
column51: we are expanding the scope of this section to better align with the Twitter Rules
column52: and sharing more granular data on violated policies. This is in line with best practices under the Santa Clara Principles on Transparency and Accountability in Content Moderation.\u00c2\u00a0\nDue to our increased focus on proactively surfacing violative content for human review
column53: more granular policies
column54: better reporting tools
column55: and also the introduction of more data across twelve distinct policy areas
column56: we have seen a 47% increase in accounts locked or suspended for violating the Twitter Rules. This work will never be stagnant and these stats should fluctuate as we improve and the challenge evolves. The increase is also reflective of a trend we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve observed across our recent Twitter Transparency Reports
column57:
as we step up the level of proactive enforcement across the service and invest in technological solutions to respond to the changing characteristics of bad-faith activity on our service.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Abuse/harassment As we tightened our rules and increased our use of technology and human review working in concern
column58: there was a 95% increase in the number of accounts actioned for violations of our abuse policy during this reporting period. This reporting period saw the largest increase in the number of accounts actioned under these policies.\nHateful conduct Hateful conduct expanded to include a new dehumanization policy on July 9
column59: 2019. There was a 54% increase in the number of accounts actioned for violations of our hateful conduct policy during this reporting period.\nSensitive media
column60: including graphic violence and adult content There was a 39% increase in the number of accounts actioned for violations of our sensitive media policy during this reporting period.\nPromoting suicide & self-harm We do not permit people to promote
column61: advocate
column62: and persuade another individual to engage in self-harm or suicide. There was a 29% increase in the number of accounts actioned for violations for this type of behavior. This is the first time we disclosed this data as we reprioritized how this type of egregious content can be reported to Twitter expeditiously.\nIllegal or certain regulated goods or services A new addition to our data disclosures
column63: there were 60
column64: 807 unique accounts actioned for violations of our illegal or certain regulated goods or services policy during this reporting period.\u00c2\u00a0\nPrivate information Sharing an individual\u00e2\u0080\u0099s private information \u00e2\u0080\u0094 or so-called doxxing \u00e2\u0080\u0094 without their express consent is a violation of the Twitter Rules. Internal tooling improvements allowed us to increase enforcement of this policy
column65: and there was a 41% increase in the number of accounts actioned for violations of our private information policy during this reporting period.\nNon-consensual nudity Due to internal improvements and extensive retraining specific to this enforcement area
column66: this reporting period saw a 109% increase in the number of accounts actioned for violations of our non-consensual nudity policy
column67: the largest increase in the number of accounts actioned under this policy.\nViolent threats During this reporting period
column68:
we saw a 5% decrease in the number of accounts actioned for violations of our violence policies (Violent Threats and Glorification of Violence).
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Legal requests:
In addition to enforcing the Twitter Rules
column69: we also may take action in response to legal requests.\nInformation requests (legal requests for account information):\u00c2\u00a0\nGovernments and law enforcement agencies around the world submitted approximately 21% more information requests compared to the previous reporting period. Notably
column70: the aggregate number of accounts specified in these requests increased by nearly 63%. The total volume of requests and specified accounts are respectively the largest we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen to date since our transparency reporting began in 2012. We received government information requests from 91 different countries since 2012.\nInformation requests from the United States continue to make up the highest percentage of legal requests for account information. During this reporting period
column71: 26% of all global requests for account information originated within the United States. The second highest volume of requests originate from Japan
column72: comprising 22% of global information requests.\nAnonymous and pseudonymous speech is important to Twitter and is central to our commitment to defend and protect the voices of the public. We often receive non-government information requests to disclose account information of anonymous or pseudonymous Twitter accounts (i.e.
column73: requests to \u00e2\u0080\u009cunmask\u00e2\u0080\u009d the identity of the individual)
column74: which we frequently object to. Twitter objected to 23 US civil requests for account information that sought to unmask the identities of anonymous speakers on first amendment grounds during this reporting period. We ended up litigating six of these requests. Twitter prevailed in four cases
column75: lost one
column76:
and one is still pending. No information was produced in response to the other 17 requests.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Removal requests (legal requests for content removal)*:
In this reporting period
column77: Twitter received 27
column78: 538 legal demands to remove content specifying 98
column79: 595 accounts. This is the largest number of requests and specified accounts that we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve received since releasing our first Transparency Report in 2012.\u00c2\u00a0\nThis record number of legal demands originated from 51 different countries. 86% of the total global volume of legal demands originated from only three countries: Japan
column80: Russia
column81: and Turkey.\u00c2\u00a0\nLegal demands from Japan increased by 143% this reporting period
column82: accounting for 45% of global requests received. The 12
column83: 496 requests from Japan are primarily related to laws regarding narcotics and psychotropics
column84: obscenity
column85:
or money lending.
Copyright & trademark actions:Â 
Copyright violations: We received a 13% increase in DMCA takedown notices affecting 163% more accounts during this reporting period.
Trademark notices: We saw a 7% increase in the total number of trademark notices received since our last report.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
This report reflects not only the evolution of the public conversation on our service but the work we do every day to protect and support the people who use Twitter.Â 
Follow @Policy and @TwitterSafety for continued updates on the changes we make across the company to drive meaningful and intuitive transparency.Â 
*Unless prohibited from doing so
column86: we continue to publish legal requests when we take action directly to the Lumen Database
column87:
a partnership with Harvardâs Berkman Klein Center for Internet & Society.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet

transparency

column3: "title": "Supporting policy change and service reform through Twitter data"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Supporting policy change and service reform through Twitter data
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 19 August 2020\nLink copied successfully\nThe UK\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) supports families and children in the UK through its Child Maintenance Service which helps parents who are separating to calculate financial support and in some cases even collect those payments. In 2019 the\u00c2\u00a0service enabled \u00c2\u00a31 billion to be paid to over 1 million children
column9: playing a critical role in alleviating child poverty in the UK.\nThe DWP depends on annual surveys and 1:1 user interviews to measure client satisfaction and garner feedback on their service. While the interviews in particular yield valuable insights
column10: they do have some limitations. \u00e2\u0080\u009cInterviews are great for informing future initiatives but not particularly helpful for an iterative approach where we have to move fast and get a pulse on the situation
column11: \u00e2\u0080\u009d said Fay Cooper
column12: Lead Product Manager at DWP's Children and Families division. \u00e2\u0080\u009cI needed a way to unlock the voice of the customer at scale and shift the conversation with internal stakeholders from
column13: \u00e2\u0080\u009cI think and I feel\u00e2\u0080\u009d to \u00e2\u0080\u009cI know because the data shows us.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nSpecifically
column14: Cooper and her team were looking for evidence to support their hypothesis that many applicants were finding the DWP\u00e2\u0080\u0099s telephone-based application process stressful and inconvenient. With the help of\u00c2\u00a0Wordnerds
column15: a UK based software company with pioneering text analysis technology
column16: DWP examined data from the conversation on Twitter to identify the key themes associated with the child support discussion as well as associated emotions and sentiment. The resulting insights confirmed their suspicion about the telephone application\u00c2\u00a0process. Clients were expressing frustration with lack of access outside of DWP\u00e2\u0080\u0099s business hours and in some cases
column17: this access limitation even appeared to be exacerbating domestic violence situations. Interestingly
column18: they were also able to capture a better understanding of the male perspective from what has typically been a female-focused process.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nThanks to these insights
column19: DWP was able to secure investment for a new digital application service that addressed many of their customers\u00e2\u0080\u0099 concerns around ease of access. Within the first three months of the launch
column20: the service moved from 100% telephony to 80% digital
column21: freeing clients from a 45-minute phone application process to just 15 minutes online. And as a result
column22: completion rates are now averaging 95%. This has also allowed DWP to free up resources to focus on other areas of need.\nAnd then COVID\nIn late March amid a global pandemic
column23: the UK government issued a stay at home order beginning what would be three months of lockdown for the country. Agencies and departments across the UK Government were forced to adapt to the new measures while continuing to deliver vital services. For the DWP this drove a critical need to understand how the lockdown was impacting its customers and the crucial payments they rely on to support their children.\nThe DWP again looked to the conversation on Twitter for a real-time pulse of the situation. Unsurprisingly
column24: they found concerns around missed payments due to parents losing jobs
column25: the reassessing of income and general anxiety about increases in child poverty and suffering.\nThe DWP used this information to quickly prioritize service changes
column26: including developing recovery plans to chase missed payments as well as new proactive notifications and faster payment methods. It also inspired the idea of partnering with charities and other volunteer organisations to support single parents in need.\nWhere to next?\nReflecting on the results
column27: Cooper commented
column28: \u00e2\u0080\u009cThe real-time nature of Twitter was a game-changer for us. We update our services every two weeks and in order to understand the impact of these new features it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s crucial to\u00c2\u00a0get real-time feedback
column29: especially in challenging times such as the lockdown period.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nLooking forward
column30: Cooper says they will continue listening to the conversation on Twitter. \u00e2\u0080\u009cI am really passionate about designing services which make a difference. In child maintenance
column31: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s powerful to see the difference our products make to children and their parents. Our new insight platform
column32: blending traditional user research with Twitter data
column33:
will be an important driver towards our objective of delivering a betterÂ user experience while supporting policy change.â
Interested in learning more about the power of social listening? Get inspired atÂ data.twitter.com.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Embracing modern customer care without upsetting your CFO"
column7:
"post_text": "highTint
Embracing modern customer care without upsetting your CFO
                By
                
  
  
Thursday
column8:
13 August 2020
Link copied successfully
Embracing modern customer care without upsetting your CFO
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
How do you deliver great
column9: modern customer care while maintaining operational efficiency? How do social listening tools help you deliver more human
column10:
empathetic care? Whatâs the biggest mistake organizations are making when it comes to leveraging data that can improve customer experience?Â 
 Twitter Official Data Partner Sprinklr and Twitter hosted experts in CX and customer service to discuss these questions and explore topics such as:
Why going off script is necessary to deliver truly human care
How AI and automation can scale customer care (without bots taking the âhumanâ out of it)
What role social listening tools can play in modern customer care
Practical next steps to get started on improving your CX
View the webinar for a rich discussion with Maureen Blandford
column11: Tech Marketing & Transformation Leader; Tracey Finlay
column12: Leadership
column13: Tech Marketing & Transformation Leader; Joe Rice
column14: Data & Enterprise Solutions at Twitter; and Jen Brown
column15: Director of Marketing
column16:
Sprinklr.
Here are some highlights:
What factors are causing brands issues with CX?
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We are all tired of the word âtransformation
column17: \u00e2\u0080\u0099 but it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s still the reality. I talk about legacy mountains in organizations; it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s still a huge obstacle. Legacy structures
column18: processes
column19: and mindsets
column20:
itâs very difficult for a functional leader to overcome those without the C-suite on board. We still have moats and drawbridges with how functions are communicating with each other; weâre not communicating very well.
Maureen Blandford
What hinders companies from leveraging the knowledge customer care has?
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Too often people see the contact center as the lowest of the low. When I talk to agents
column21: they know more about what the customers want than the customers do. They have the answers. But organizations don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t trust their agents to intuitively know what is right for the customer. Yet
column22: 99 percent of the time
column23: they do. They just need to be trusted. Get a big bunch of customer-facing people in a room for three hours and ask them: What do customers do that is really annoying? They will list off everything and give you an amazing
column24:
low-cost roadmap of stuff you can fix right away. And it makes your customer-facing teams feel listened to.
Tracey Finlay
How do you leverage social insights to make better CX decisions?
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Organizations have focused too much on quantitative social insights (impressions
column25: engagement
column26: reach) which aren\u00e2\u0080\u0099t business outcomes
column27: and have underutilized and probably underappreciated the qualitative nature of Twitter data. This is in my opinion more insightful and more powerful as it's feedback that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s emotive
column28: unprompted
column29: and in the moment. Twitter is now 14 years old and I\u00e2\u0080\u0099m still surprised by the number of organizations that don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t have any processes or tools like Sprinklr to engage and manage their social engagement and therefore lots of Tweets and DMs go unanswered. Twitter is public by nature and so presents a great opportunity to humanize your brand and show you care.\nJoe Rice\nView the webinar for the full discussion
column30:
including more tips on how to improve CX in your customer service today.

column3: "title": "New conversation settings
column4: coming to a Tweet near you"
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/product/2020/new-conversation-settings-coming-to-a-tweet-near-you"
column8: "post_text": "Product\nNew conversation settings
column9:
coming to a Tweet near you
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column10: 11 August 2020\nLink copied successfully\nSince your Tweet = your space
column11: we've been testing new settings to give people more control over the conversations they start. Sometimes people are more comfortable talking about what's happening when they can choose who can reply. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen people use these settings to have conversations that weren't really possible before. Starting today
column12: everyone will be able to use these settings so unwanted replies don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t get in the way of meaningful conversations.\nHere\u00e2\u0080\u0099s how it works. Before you Tweet
column13: choose who can reply with three options: 1) everyone (standard Twitter
column14: and the default setting)
column15: 2) only people you follow
column16: or 3) only people you mention. Tweets with the latter two settings will be labeled and the reply icon will be grayed out for people who can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t reply. People who can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t reply will still be able to view
column17: Retweet
column18: Retweet with Comment
column19: share
column20:
and like these Tweets.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Since we started testing this in May
column21: people have used it to host interviews and panels
column22: share what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s on their mind
column23: and make announcements. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve learned a lot from usage
column24: feedback interviews
column25: and surveys. These settings help some people feel safer and could lead to more meaningful conversations
column26:
while still allowing people to see different points of view. Hereâs more on what people shared with us. â¬ï¸
These settings help some people feel safer.
People tell us they feel more comfortable Tweeting and more protected from spam and abuse.
Problematic repliers aren't finding another way â these settings prevented an average of three potentially abusive replies while only adding one potentially abusive Retweet with Comment. And
column27:
we didnât see any uptick in unwanted Direct Messages.
People who face abuse find these settings helpful â those who have submitted abuse reports are 3x more likely to use these settings.
Itâs a new method to block out noise â 60% of people who used this during the test didnât use Mute or Block.
The change could lead to more meaningful conversations on Twitter.
People are sharing more of their thoughts âÂ Tweets using these settings about topics like Black Lives Matter and COVID-19 are on average longer than those that donât use these settings.
Some people use these settings to have more sensitive conversations about politics and social issues. Those with a lot of followers use these settings to share more feelings
column28: opinions
column29:
and personal news.
People still can see various points of view.
Research shows people understand replies are limited on these Tweets.
People more frequently look for additional commentary when replies are limited âÂ  the new Retweets with Comments timeline is visited 4x more often on Tweets using these settings.
Differing views can still be shared with Retweets with Comments
column30: which sometimes reach a larger audience than the original Tweet. Several times
column31: we saw more Likes and views on a Retweet with Comment than on the original Tweet
column32: even though the original Tweet author had more followers.\nTwitter serves the public conversation
column33: so it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important for people to be able to see different perspectives. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll keep working on making it easier for people to find the entire discussion through Retweets with Comments. Also
column34:
weâre trying out a new label to make it more obvious when these conversation settings are used.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâll continue to update these Tweet settings based on your feedback. In the next few months weâre planning to add an option to invite more people to the conversation after it starts
column35: clear notifications for when you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re invited to join a conversation using these settings
column36:
and more ways to see the entire discussion.Â 
Everyone can now use these settings on Twitter for iOS and Android as well as twitter.com. You know what to do â @ me with what you think!

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "New labels for government and state-affiliated media accounts"
column7: "post_text": "Product\nNew labels for government and state-affiliated media accounts\nThursday
column8:
6 August 2020
Link copied successfully
Our mission is to serve the public conversation and an important part of that work is providing people with context so they can make informed decisions about what they see and how they engage on Twitter.
Twitter provides an unmatched way to connect with
column9: and directly speak to public officials and representatives. This direct line of communication with leaders and officials has helped to democratize political discourse and increase transparency and accountability. We also took steps to protect that discourse because we believe political reach should be earned not bought. In 2019
column10: we banned all state-backed media advertising and political advertising from Twitter. Today we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re expanding the types of political accounts we label.\u00c2\u00a0 \nWe will add new labels to the following categories of Twitter accounts:\nAccounts of key government officials
column11: including foreign ministers
column12: institutional entities
column13: ambassadors
column14: official spokespeople
column15: and key diplomatic leaders. At this time
column16: our focus is on senior officials and entities who are the official voice of the state abroad \nAccounts belonging to state-affiliated media entities
column17: their editors-in-chief
column18:
and/or their senior staffÂ  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
How do we define government accounts for these new labels?
Our focus is on senior officials and entities that are the voice of the nation state abroad
column19: specifically the account categories listed above. Labels will only be applied to accounts from the countries represented in the five permanent members of the UN Security Council: China
column20: France
column21: Russian Federation
column22: the United Kingdom
column23: and the United States. For transparency and practicality
column24: we are starting with a limited and clearly-defined group of countries before expanding to a wider range of countries in the future. We believe this is an important step so that when people see an account discussing geopolitical issues from another country
column25: they have context on its national affiliation and are better informed about who they represent. At this time
column26: we're not labeling the personal accounts of heads of state
column27: as these accounts enjoy widespread name recognition
column28: media attention
column29: and public awareness. Institutional accounts associated with their offices that changeover depending on election results will be labeled
column30: however.\u00c2\u00a0 \nIn general
column31: we're focused on those within the respective administrations underneath the head of state that offer its policy perspective abroad. \nHow do we define state-affiliated media accounts for these new labels?\u00c2\u00a0\nState-affiliated media is defined as outlets where the state exercises control over editorial content through financial resources
column32: direct or indirect political pressures
column33: and/or control over production and distribution. Unlike independent media
column34: state-affiliated media frequently use their news coverage as a means to advance a political agenda. We believe that people have the right to know when a media account is affiliated directly or indirectly with a state actor. State-financed media organizations with editorial independence
column35: like the BBC in the UK or NPR in the US for example
column36: will not be labeled. As part of the development of this process
column37: we consulted with a number of expert groups
column38: including members of the Digital and Human Rights Advisory group in Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Trust & Safety Council.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0 \nWe will also no longer amplify state-affiliated media accounts or their Tweets through our recommendation systems including on the home timeline
column39: notifications
column40: and search. Government accounts listed in category one are not affected by this change.\u00c2\u00a0\nTo offer even more context to the public
column41:
clicking the labels on both categories of accounts directs people to an article explaining the policy and referring them to the Twitter Transparency Report for additional information.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Notification and appeals processÂ  
Weâll notify any account thatâs labeled and if the account owner believes weâve made a mistake
column42:
they can reach out to us directly.Â  
Next steps
We plan to continue expanding this approach to additional countries over time and look forward to providing additional updates as those plans take shape.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "An update on our security incident"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
An update on our security incident
            By
            
  
  
Saturday
column8: 18 July 2020\nLink copied successfully\nLast updated on July 30
column11: 2020\nAs our investigation continues
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sharing an update to answer some of the remaining questions based on what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve discovered to date. We will provide a more detailed technical report on what occurred at a later date given the ongoing law enforcement investigation and after we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve completed work to further safeguard our service.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhat we know now\nThe social engineering that occurred on July 15
column14: targeted a small number of employees through a phone spear phishing attack. A successful attack required the attackers to obtain access to both our internal network as well as\u00c2\u00a0 specific employee credentials that granted them access to our internal support tools. Not all of the employees that were initially targeted had permissions to use account management tools
column15: but the attackers used their credentials to access our internal systems and gain information about our processes. This knowledge then enabled them to target additional employees who did have access to our account support tools. Using the credentials of employees with access to these tools
column16: the attackers targeted 130 Twitter accounts
column17: ultimately Tweeting from 45
column18: accessing the DM inbox of 36
column19: and downloading the Twitter Data of 7.\u00c2\u00a0\nThere has been concern following this incident around our tools and levels of employee access. To run our business
column20: we have teams around the world that help with account support. Our teams use proprietary tools to help with a variety of support issues as well as to review content in line with The Twitter Rules and respond to reports. Access to these tools is strictly limited and is only granted for valid business reasons. We have zero tolerance for misuse of credentials or tools
column21: actively monitor for misuse
column22: regularly audit permissions
column23: and take immediate action if anyone accesses account information without a valid business reason. While these tools
column24: controls
column25: and processes are constantly being updated and improved
column26: we are taking a hard look at how we can make them even more sophisticated.\nThis attack relied on a significant and concerted attempt to mislead certain employees and exploit human vulnerabilities to gain access to our internal systems. This was a striking reminder of how important each person on our team is in protecting our service. We take that responsibility seriously and everyone at Twitter is committed to keeping your information safe.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve communicated directly with the impacted account owners and worked to restore access to any accounts who may have been temporarily locked out during our remediation efforts. Our investigation is ongoing
column27: and we are working with the appropriate authorities to ensure that the people responsible for this attack are identified.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhat we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re doing to protect our service\nSince the attack
column28: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve significantly limited access to our internal tools and systems to ensure ongoing account security while we complete our investigation. As a result
column29: some features (namely
column30: accessing the Your Twitter Data download feature) and processes have been impacted. We will be slower to respond to account support needs
column31: reported Tweets
column32: and applications to our developer platform. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sorry for any delays this causes
column33: but we believe it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a necessary precaution as we make durable changes to our processes and tooling as a result\u00c2\u00a0 of this incident. We will gradually resume our normal response times when we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re confident it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s safe to do so. Thank you for your patience as we work through this.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re always investing in increased security protocols
column34: techniques and mechanisms \u00e2\u0080\u0093 it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s how we work to stay ahead of threats as they evolve. Going forward
column35: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re accelerating several of our pre-existing security workstreams and improvements to our tools. We are also improving our methods for detecting and preventing inappropriate access to our internal systems and prioritizing security work across many of our teams. We will continue to organize ongoing company-wide phishing exercises throughout the year.\nWe will continue to share updates and precautionary steps we take so that others can learn from this
column36: too. We recognize the trust you place in us
column37: and are committing to earning it by continued open
column39: 2020\nAs we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been informing via the @TwitterSupport account
column40: on Wednesday
column41: July 15
column43: we detected a security incident at Twitter and took immediate action. As we head into the weekend
column44: we want to provide an overview of where we are.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn this post we summarize the situation as of July 17 at 8:35p Pacific Time. The following information is what we know as of today and may change as our investigation and outside investigations continue. Additionally
column45: as the investigation of this incident is unfolding
column46: there are some details \u00e2\u0080\u0094 particularly around remediation \u00e2\u0080\u0094 that we are not providing right now to protect the security of the effort. We will provide more details
column47: where possible in the future
column48: so that the community and our peers may learn and benefit from what happened.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhat happened\u00c2\u00a0\nAt this time
column49: we believe attackers targeted certain Twitter employees through a social engineering scheme. What does this mean? In this context
column50: social engineering is the intentional manipulation of people into performing certain actions and divulging confidential information.\u00c2\u00a0\nThe attackers successfully manipulated a small number of employees and used their credentials to access Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s internal systems
column51: including getting through our two-factor protections. As of now
column52: we know that they accessed tools only available to our internal support teams to target 130 Twitter accounts. For 45 of those accounts
column53: the attackers were able to initiate a password reset
column54: login to the account
column55: and send Tweets. We are continuing our forensic review of all of the accounts to confirm all actions that may have been taken. In addition
column56: we believe they may have attempted to sell some of the usernames.\nFor up to eight of the Twitter accounts involved
column57: the attackers took the additional step of downloading the account\u00e2\u0080\u0099s information through our \u00e2\u0080\u009cYour Twitter Data\u00e2\u0080\u009d tool. This is a tool that is meant to provide an account owner with a summary of their Twitter account details and activity. We are reaching out directly to any account owner where we know this to be true.\u00c2\u00a0None of the eight were verified accounts.\nOur actions\u00c2\u00a0\nWe became aware of the attackers\u00e2\u0080\u0099 action on Wednesday
column58: and moved quickly to lock down and regain control of the compromised accounts. Our incident response team secured and revoked access to internal systems to prevent the attackers from further accessing our systems or the individual accounts. As mentioned above
column59: we are deliberately limiting the detail we share on our remediation steps at this time to protect their effectiveness and will provide more technical details
column60: where possible
column61: in the future.\nIn addition to our efforts behind the scenes
column62: shortly after we became aware of the ongoing situation
column63: we took preemptive measures to restrict functionality for many accounts on Twitter - this included things like preventing them from Tweeting or changing passwords. We did this to prevent the attackers from further spreading their scam as well as to prevent them from being able to take control of any additional accounts while we were investigating. We also locked accounts where a password had been recently changed out of an abundance of caution. Late on Wednesday
column64: we were able to return Tweeting functionality to many accounts
column65: and as of today
column66: have restored most of the accounts that were locked pending password changes for their owners.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe are continuing our investigation of this incident
column67: working with law enforcement
column68: and determining longer-term actions we should take to improve the security of our systems. We have multiple teams working around the clock focused on this and on keeping the people who use Twitter safe and informed.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhat the attackers accessed\u00c2\u00a0\nThe most important question for people who use Twitter is likely \u00e2\u0080\u0094 did the attackers see any of my private information? For the vast majority of people
column69: we believe the answer is
column70: no. For the 130 accounts that were targeted
column71: here is what we know as of today.\nAttackers were not able to view previous account passwords
column72: as those are not stored in plain text or available through the tools used in the attack. \nAttackers were able to view personal information including email addresses and phone numbers
column73: which are displayed to some users of our internal support tools. \nIn cases where an account was taken over by the attacker
column74: they may have been able to view additional information. Our forensic investigation of these activities is still ongoing. \nWe believe that for up to 36 of the 130 targeted accounts
column75: the attackers accessed the DM inbox
column76: including 1 elected official in the Netherlands. To date
column77: we have no indication that any other former or current elected official had their DMs accessed.\u00c2\u00a0[Added on July 22
column78:
2020] 
We are actively working on communicating directly with the account-holders that were impacted.
Our next steps 
As we head into the weekend and next week
column79:
we are focused on these core objectives:
Restoring access for all account owners who may still be locked out as a result of our remediation efforts. 
Continuing our investigation of the incident and our cooperation with law enforcement.Â  
Further securing our systems to prevent future attacks. 
Rolling out additional company-wide training to guard against social engineering tactics to supplement the training employees receive during onboarding and ongoing phishing exercises throughout the year. 
Through all of this
column80: we also begin the long work of rebuilding trust with the people who use and depend on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re acutely aware of our responsibilities to the people who use our service and to society more generally. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re embarrassed
column81: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re disappointed
column82: and more than anything
column83: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sorry. We know that we must work to regain your trust
column84: and we will support all efforts to bring the perpetrators to justice. We hope that our openness and transparency throughout this process
column85: and the steps and work we will take to safeguard against other attacks in the future
column86:
will be the start of making this right.
More to come via @TwitterSupport as our investigation continues.Â

column3: "title": "Using data from the conversation on Twitter to help detect wildfires"
column7:
"post_text": "Using data from the conversation on Twitter to help detect wildfires
                By
                
  
  
Wednesday
column8:
24 June 2020
Link copied successfully
Using data from the conversation on Twitter to help detect wildfires
Mayday.ai combines data from the conversation on Twitter with satellite imagery
column9: cameras
column10: and IP911 to help provide real-time or near real-time wildfire disaster and incident management services.\nIn 2019
column11: in California alone
column13: 872 fire incidents burned more than 253
column14: 321 acres
column15: damaged or destroyed 732 structures
column16: and killed three people. When it comes to wildfires
column17: early detection can buy authorities time to warn impacted communities and get the right resources in the right place quickly. Up until now
column18: first responders and disaster response coordinators have lacked easy access to real-time
column19: on-the-ground data. Kian Mirshahi
column20: founder of Mayday.ai
column21: is passionate about democratizing access to disaster information and is working to build a community-level ecosystem for proactive disaster management and resiliency.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhen major events happen
column22: people turn to Twitter to share what they\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve witnessed
column23: document what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in real-time
column24: and to get key information. This wildfire season
column25: Mayday.ai is set to combine data from the unfolding conversation on Twitter with its proprietary incident detection system
column26: which is based on satellite sensors
column27: \u00c2\u00a0 an array of 35
column28: 000 traffic cameras
column29:
and IP911 to power a comprehensive detection and a highly targeted notification tracker. Mayday.ai has developed a comprehensive dispatch platform and a mobile app which will provide first responders and civilians unprecedented access to real-time incident information -- and has so far had much success in detecting wildfires using its proprietary platform and is being used as a template for other disasters in Maydayâs roadmap.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Wildfires are one disaster that humans can prevent with a culture shift in disaster management policies and practices
column30:
Kian Mirshahi
founder of Mayday.ai
âThe opportunity costs of our current reactive and disconnected practices are tremendous and continue to increase. Maydayâs proactive and integrated approach uses satellite imaging
column31: multiple data sources
column32: and machine learning capabilities to identify fires faster than anything else can.\u00e2\u0080\u009d So far this year
column33: Mayday has detected almost all reported wildfires in the Americas ahead of 911 reports
column34: with some as early as four hours.\u00c2\u00a0\nMayday uses data from the conversation on Twitter to analyze social media sentiment and gain critical information from people at the scene. They track keywords and event-centric groupings with hashtags
column35: for example
column36: #Easyfire. Once a fire is named
column37: that hashtag is used to track all data on Twitter and filter critical information to responders and continuously refined via natural language processing. Mayday is also providing visual data through geotagged images and videos shared on Twitter. These event-centric innovations with social sentiment analysis
column38: combined with a multitude of sensors from 22
column39: 000 miles above sea all the way to ground-level
column40: give Mayday.ai an incredible and highly disruptive edge in real-time disaster services.\u00c2\u00a0 \n\u00e2\u0080\u009cWe see Twitter as a source of critical information from citizen journalists and witnesses. We want people to Tweet when a disaster or incident strikes so this information can be used reliably to help inform authorities faster as the event unfolds. This is a best practice that we are building in our communities as we onboard them\u00e2\u0080\u009d said Mirshahi.\u00c2\u00a0 \nMayday is launching its platform this season in the Western States and will be fully available in the United Stated in early 2021. Mayday is also working with various global partners and expects to have its platform globally available by the end of 2021. To learn more
column41: follow\u00c2\u00a0Mayday.ai and their great progress on Twitter: @mayday_ai
column42: \u00c2\u00a0or reach out to us directly.\nTwitter does not own
column43: operate or manage any third party services mentioned above
column44: including Mayday.ai
column45:
and businesses should conduct their own due diligence of the companies they choose to work with.

column3: "title": "Lockdown 2020 - what social data can tell us about what\u2019s next"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Lockdown 2020 - what social data can tell us about whatâs next
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 23 June 2020\nLink copied successfully\nAs the world emerges from lockdown
column9: the big question on most of our minds is \u00e2\u0080\u009cwhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next?\". Will work from home
column10: learn from home and exercise from home be the new norm? Will bikes and walking begin to displace cars and crowded transit? Is business travel as we knew it finished? These questions and more are being asked by organizations trying to make sense of the past three months and the long term implications. Many will look to market research to try and understand what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening and predict the future. But after such an unprecedented event
column11: can people clearly articulate how it has impacted their lives?\u00c2\u00a0 This question hits at a much bigger challenge of market research and traditional methods such as surveys and focus groups: people aren\u00e2\u0080\u0099t very good at articulating what they think about certain topics or what they may do in the future.\u00c2\u00a0\nTraditional market research often asks consumers to share their feelings about products
column12: services and experiences
column13: but this approach is inevitably biased by virtue of the very questions presented and the specific words used. For example
column14: 'How did you find your stay?' will elicit a different response than
column15: 'Did you enjoy your stay?' This framing
column16: as it is known
column17: guides participants down specific paths
column18: encouraging filtered
column19: rational and retrospective responses. But
column20: unfortunately
column21: that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not how we as humans make decisions.\nPreviously
column22: I wrote about how our emotions extend to decision-making and how numerous studies reveal that our behaviours are often guided by non-conscious drivers. Put another way
column23: we are often unreliable witnesses to our own actions and beliefs. So how do we infer what people really feel on a subject? The key is to capture unprompted reactions in the moment when they are actually happening. These \u00e2\u0080\u0098non-framed\u00e2\u0080\u0099 thoughts tend to be more accurate and more authentic because they represent true emotion and are without bias.\nOne place you can find a vast amount of unprompted reactions on a host of topics is social data. Twitter
column24: in particular
column25: sees hundreds of millions of thoughts
column26: experiences and opinions shared on the platform every day. These tweets provide unique qualitative insights
column27: shedding light on underlying motivations
column28: emerging behaviours and new norms.\u00c2\u00a0\nTwitter has always been a great place to see these trends emerge
column29: allowing you to develop hypotheses which can then be tested and further refined with qualitative and quantitative research methods. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s this combining of stated preferences with revealed behaviours that provides a more complete
column30: nuanced perspective on a given topic. Twitter is also proving a useful proxy for brand tracking and benchmarking studies. These well-established longitudinal studies typically rely on surveys and are generally performed only once a year. However
column31: leveraging consumer feedback from Twitter makes continuous brand tracking possible and cost-effective. \nAs to \u00e2\u0080\u009cwhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next?\u00e2\u0080\u009d
column32: a YouGov poll from mid-April found that only 9% of Britons want life to return to 'normal' once lockdown is over. But can they be believed? To quote the American poet Ralph Waldo Emerson
column33: \u00e2\u0080\u009cWhat you do speaks so loudly that I cannot hear what you say.\u00e2\u0080\u009d \nInterested in obtaining better insights on topics important to you? Watch this\u00c2\u00a0episode of #TwitterTalk:\u00c2\u00a0Attitudes
column34:
emotions and behaviours: using social data to drive qualitative insight.
You can also get inspired at data.twitter.com with case studies that illustrate the value of Twitter data. 
Â 
Â

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Your Tweet
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/product/2020/your-tweet-your-voice"
column8: "post_text": "Product\nYour Tweet
column9:
your voice 
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Wednesday
column10: 17 June 2020\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter is where you go to talk about what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening. Over the years
column11: photos
column12: videos
column13: gifs
column14: and extra characters have allowed you to add your own flair and personality to your conversations. But sometimes 280 characters aren\u00e2\u0080\u0099t enough and some conversational nuances are lost in translation. So starting today
column15: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re testing a new feature that will add a more human touch to the way we use Twitter \u00e2\u0080\u0093 your very own voice.\nTweeting with your voice is not too different from Tweeting with text. To start
column16:
open the Tweet composer and tap the new icon with wavelengths. Youâll see your profile photo with the record button at the bottom â tap this to record your voice.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Composing a Tweet  
          
          
        
          
            Recording a voice Tweet 
          
          
        
Each voice Tweet captures up to 140 seconds of audio. Have more to say? Keep talking. Once you reach the time limit for a Tweet
column17: a new voice Tweet starts automatically to create a thread. Once you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re done
column18: tap the Done button to end your recording and go back to the composer screen to Tweet.\nPeople will see your voice Tweet appear on their timeline alongside other Tweets. To listen
column19: tap the image. On iOS only
column20:
playback will start in a new window docked at the bottom of your timeline and you can listen as you scroll. You can also keep listening while doing other things on your phone or on the go.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Voice Tweet playing in the timeline  
          
          
        
Creating voice Tweets will be available to a limited group of people on Twitter for iOS to start but in the coming weeks everyone on iOS should be able to Tweet with their voice. Everyone will be able to see (hear) them and reply. Learn more in our help center.
Thereâs a lot that can be left unsaid or uninterpreted using text
column21: so we hope voice Tweeting will create a more human experience for listeners and storytellers alike. Whether it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s #storytime about your encounter with wild geese in your neighborhood
column22: a journalist sharing breaking news
column23: or a first-hand account from a protest
column24:
we hope voice Tweeting gives you the ability to share your perspectives quickly and easily with your voice. We canât wait to see how people will use this to make their voices heard and add to the public conversation.

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Talking #MentalHealthAwareness on Twitter with our global partners "
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Talking #MentalHealthAwareness on Twitter with our global partners 
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 15 June 2020\nLink copied successfully\nThe open nature of Twitter can spark conversations among people facing similar struggles worldwide. As we experience the unprecedented COVID-19 pandemic
column9: talking openly about our mental health concerns can build empathy and respect.\u00c2\u00a0 \nThroughout the month of May
column10: we worked with over 60 of our mental health partners around the world to raise awareness and help break the stigma associated with mental health.\nUtilizing the hashtags\u00c2\u00a0#LetsTalk\u00c2\u00a0and #TogetherWeCan
column11: our partners inspired a series of honest
column12: global mental health conversations around the anxiety and stress that we \u00e2\u0080\u0094 our families
column13: peers
column14: educators
column15: students
column16:
and vulnerable groups â are experiencing together.Â 
The hashtags and bespoke emoji was translated into over 30 languages and activated in over 30 different countries during the month of May.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We saw countless creative uses of Twitter for #MentalHealthAwarenessWeek and #MentalHealthAwarenessMonth including live Twitter Q+As with mental health organizations
column17: people sharing mental health tips and resources and people opening up about their individual mental health concerns.\u00c2\u00a0\nThrough these trusted partnerships
column18: we encouraged people to see Twitter as a place to talk about their mental health \u00e2\u0080\u0094 sharing their experiences and helping others understand how different cultures and communities respond to these challenges.\u00c2\u00a0\nBringing the conversation together\u00c2\u00a0 \nOur mental health emoji and hashtags were utilized throughout the month of May to integrate and amplify the global conversation. They were shared almost 170
column19: 000 times on the service \u00e2\u0080\u0094 promoting access to mental health resources from over 70 global mental health organizations.\nThe hashtags #MentalHealth; #MentalHealthMonth; #LetsTalk and #TogetherWeCan combined to reach over half a million uses throughout the month
column20: bringing the global conversation together to raise awareness and normalize discussion around mental health.\nAlong with these important and real on-service mental health conversations with our partners and the bespoke emoji launches across the world
column21: we donated Ads for Good grants for mental health partners to amplify their messages and campaigns over the month of May.\u00c2\u00a0\nAPAC \nOn May 4th
column22: our partners Samaritans of Thailand (@Samaritans_Thai) launched an Ask Me Anything on-service Q+A
column23: where people on Twitter had the opportunity to ask questions about their mental health stresses and have them answered and supported by @Samaritans_Thai experts. The Q+A was brought together on the service using the hashtag #AskSamaritansTH and the bespoke mental health hashtags #UsapTayo and #\u00e0\u00b8\u0084\u00e0\u00b8\u00b8\u00e0\u00b8\u00a2\u00e0\u00b8\u0081\u00e0\u00b8\u00b1\u00e0\u00b8\u0099\u00e0\u00b9\u0084\u00e0\u00b8\u0094\u00e0\u00b9\u0089\u00e0\u00b8\u0097\u00e0\u00b8\u00b8\u00e0\u00b8\u0081\u00e0\u00b9\u0080\u00e0\u00b8\u00a3\u00e0\u00b8\u00b7\u00e0\u00b9\u0088\u00e0\u00b8\u00ad\u00e0\u00b8\u0087\u00c2\u00a0\u00e2\u0080\u0094 all amplified through Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s @NonProfits account to further promote the insights and resources published throughout the on-service Q+A.\u00c2\u00a0\nKey themes discussed throughout included how to deal with feelings of guilt
column24: how to manage social anxieties
column25:
and where to go to for support:Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
North America
On May 5th
column26: our Mental Health America partners took to Twitter to answer frequently asked questions related to COVID-19 mental health challenges and ways to cope - bringing the conversation together on the service through the hashtags #LetsTalk\u00c2\u00a0and #TogetherWeCan. This activation was amplified live via a thread through Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s @NonProfits account.\u00c2\u00a0\nThis thread shows the many resources and support available for people who are feeling anxious and unnerved through stressful times in their lives. This conversation on Twitter also breaks down stigmas associated with speaking about mental health areas like mindfulness and meditation
column27: mental health tools
column28: finding gratitude and joy in daily routines
column29:
as well as where to find credible information regarding COVID-19.
On May 7th â Child Youth & Mental Health Day â our partners in Canada @KidsHelpPhone promoted their key resources on how to support young people throughout the COVID-19 pandemic.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
LATAM
Our partner Centro de ValorizaÃ§Ã£o da Vida (@CVVoficial) shared mental health resources and encouraged people on Twitter to have honest conversations about the mental health stresses caused by the global pandemic. Using the hashtags #JuntosPodemosÂ and #VamosConversarÂ they invited people to connect with their services and break the stigma around mental health. Their tweets were amplified through Twitterâs @NonProfits account.
Our partner in Colombia
column30: @MutanteOrg also shared some key mental health resources and encouraged people to engage in open conversations about their mental health.\u00c2\u00a0 With the hashtag #HablemosDeSaludMental
column31:
@MutanteOrg also invited psychologists to engage in and promote deep thinking around the importance of good mental health.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
EMEA
Our partner Mental Health Europe (@MHESME) launched their on-service Q+A on the 6th of May
column32: and this @MHESME thread was also amplified via Twitter @NonProfits.Topics discussed included: utilizing social media in positive ways
column33: supporting healthcare workers
column34: being there for family and friends during COVID-19
column35:
and managing mental health triggers:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Resources
Mental health awareness and treatment is a critical global issue
column36: and it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important to capture tools that we can turn to over time. Via our Twitter @NonProfits account
column37: we developed a Twitter List of our mental health partner profiles and resources for people to access as needed on the service.\u00c2\u00a0\nThrough our @Policy account
column38: we created a #LetsTalk Moment to showcase the reach and engagement that on-service conversations can enable through global partners
column39: which inspire us to express our real and unique challenges and address mental health together.\nWHO\nAs #MentalHealthAwareness month came to a close
column40: the WHO answered some frequently asked questions and shared toolkits through their @WHO Twitter profile to address the stresses and anxieties that people continue to face through the COVID-19 pandemic. We amplified this important resource via our @Policy handle.\u00c2\u00a0\nSome key areas of focus in this FAQ conversation were: techniques in managing stress
column41: how to manage the stress associated with seeing constant COVID-19 media reports
column42:
and advice for parents and children who are spending much more time at home due to the pandemic.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
By sparking conversations with local organizations and showcasing innovative ways partners utilize the service
column43: our goal was to provide an interconnected space to raise diverse perspectives and resources to confront the mental health effects of COVID-19. We continue to work in collaboration with our mental health partners around the world
column44:
in keeping the #MentalHeath conversation alive and engaged on Twitter.Â

column3: "title": "Disclosing networks of state-linked information operations we\u2019ve removed"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nDisclosing networks of state-linked information operations we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve removed\nFriday
column8: 12 June 2020\nLink copied successfully\nToday we are disclosing 32
column9: 242 accounts to our archive of state-linked information operations \u00e2\u0080\u0094 the only one of its kind in the industry. The account sets we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re publishing to the archive today include three distinct operations that we have attributed to the People's Republic of China (PRC)
column10: Russia
column11: and Turkey respectively. Every account and piece of content associated with these operations has been permanently removed from the service. In addition
column12: we have shared relevant data from this disclosure with two leading research partners: Australian Strategic Policy Institute (ASPI) and Stanford Internet Observatory (SIO).\nIn all instances
column13: accounts were suspended for various violations of our platform manipulation policies.\u00c2\u00a0\nPeople\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Republic of China (PRC)\nWhile this network is new
column14: the technical links we used to identify the activity and attribute it to the PRC remain consistent with activity we initially identified and disclosed in August 2019. Our proactive removal of this network from Twitter is a direct result of the technical efforts we instituted after thoroughly studying and investigating past coordinated information operations from the PRC.\nToday\u00e2\u0080\u0099s PRC disclosure relates to two interconnected sets of accounts:\n23
column15: 750 accounts that comprise the core of the network
column16: e.g. the highly engaged core network.\nApproximately 150
column17: 000 accounts that were designed to boost this content
column18: e.g. the amplifiers. Based on feedback from researchers on our prior disclosures that we need to better refine the disclosure process to enable efficient investigation of the core activity
column19: we have not included the 150
column20: 000 amplifier accounts in the public archive.\nDespite the volume
column21: the core 23
column22: 750 accounts we are publishing to the archive were largely caught early and failed to achieve considerable traction on the service
column23: typically holding low follower accounts and low engagement. Of the approximately 150
column24: 000 amplifier accounts
column25: the majority had little to no follower counts either and were strategically designed to artificially inflate impression metrics and engage with the core accounts.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn general
column26: this entire network was involved in a range of manipulative and coordinated activities. They were Tweeting predominantly in Chinese languages and spreading geopolitical narratives favorable to the Communist Party of China (CCP)
column27: while continuing to push deceptive narratives about the political dynamics in Hong Kong.\u00c2\u00a0\nRussia\u00c2\u00a0\nAided in part by useful information sharing from external researchers and our peer companies
column28: we investigated accounts associated with Current Policy
column29: a media website engaging in state-backed political propaganda within Russia. A network of accounts related to this media operation was suspended for violations of our platform manipulation policy
column30: specifically cross-posting and amplifying content in an inauthentic
column31: coordinated manner for political ends. Activities included promoting the United Russia party and attacking political dissidents. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re disclosing all 1
column32: 152 accounts and associated media to our public archive today.\u00c2\u00a0\nTurkey\nDetected in early 2020
column33: this network of accounts was employing coordinated inauthentic activity
column34: which was primarily targeted at domestic audiences within Turkey. Based on our analysis of the network\u00e2\u0080\u0099s technical indicators and account behaviors
column35: the collection of fake and compromised accounts was being used to amplify political narratives favorable to the AK Parti
column36: and demonstrated strong support for President Erdogan. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re disclosing 7
column37: 340 accounts to the archive today.\nTechnical signals point to the network being associated with the youth wing of the party and a centralized network that maintained a significant number of compromised accounts. As a result
column38: the network we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re disclosing today includes several compromised accounts associated with organizations critical of President Erdogan and the Turkish Government. These compromised accounts have been repeated targets of account hacking and takeover efforts by the state actors identified above. The broader network was also used for commercial activities
column39: such as cryptocurrency-related spam.\u00c2\u00a0\nNext steps for this work\nUltimately our goal is to serve the public conversation
column40: remove bad faith actors
column41:
and to advance public understanding of these critical topics. In the future weâre going to:
Offer more clarity in the public archive around impression counts and attempt to further measure the tangible impact of information operations on the public conversation.
Continue to formalize our academic partnerships to ensure theyâre globally diverse and advancing public understanding of these issues.
Host an online conference later in the summer to bring experts
column42: industry
column43: and government together to discuss opportunities for further collaboration.\nOur Site Integrity efforts represent some of the most critical work we do at Twitter to protect the public conversation. For a detailed breakdown of how we conduct these investigations
column44: the operational principles that inform them
column45: and our approach to transparency
column46:
see here.
Keep on top of regular updates from us over at @TwitterSafety.

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Allyship right now: #BlackLivesMatter"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Allyship right now: #BlackLivesMatter
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 4 June 2020\nLink copied successfully\nCOVID-19 may not discriminate
column9: but systemic inequalities have exacerbated its disproportionate impact on Black and Brown communities. Amid the already growing fear and uncertainty around the pandemic
column10: last week again brought attention to something perhaps more pervasive: the long-standing racism and injustices faced by Black and Brown people on a daily basis.\nThe recent killings of Ahmaud Arbery
column11: Breonna Taylor
column12: Tony McDade and George Floyd
column13: and the victimization of Christian Cooper have left many of us angry
column14: and with a deep sense of grief. But that grief doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t compare to what Black people face every day. #SayTheirNames\nNow is a time to take care \u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00e2\u0080\u0093 and take action. Now is a time for #Allyship. At Twitter
column15: our principles of allyship are simple: Learn
column16: Ask
column17: Show up
column18:
and Speak up.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Learn 
Do your own research. To practice allyship
column19: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important to first understand the historical and structural contexts that have led to racism and discrimination that are so ingrained in society.\u00c2\u00a0\nHere is recommended reading to get started on your journey
column20: \u00c2\u00a0 Lies My Teacher Told Me: Everything Your American History Textbook Got Wrong
column21: How to be an Anti-Racist
column22:
and âWho gets to be afraid in America?â Also check out this Anti-Racism Resource Guide.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Ask
Understand that answering questions takes emotional labor â be mindful of safe spaces and make sure youâve done your personal learning before you ask a Black person to share with you.
Approach questions with empathy and in a way to understand peopleâs lived experiences. Do not approach asking questions from a place of disbelief. Some questions you could ask include:Â 
âIf you have the time/energy
column23: do you feel comfortable sharing your experience with me?\u00e2\u0080\u009d\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cThis week is heavy. How are you feeling/coping?\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nNote: When someone\u00e2\u0080\u0099s sharing their experience with you
column24: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s enough to simply say
column25: \u00e2\u0080\u009cI hear you.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t feel like you need to respond
column26: or provide your own story. Instead
column27:
center them and what theyâre sharing with you.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Show up 
People are dealing with a lot right now. But especially for Black people
column28: this is an incredibly difficult time. Be mindful of that in emails
column29: on social media
column30:
and in communications. Offer to reschedule meetings and be as flexible as possible with any deadlines.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
From donating to organizations fighting for racial justice and police reform
column31: to supporting Black-owned businesses and signing petitions
column32: check out this list of 75 ways you can do something for racial justice and leverage your area of influence to create change.\u00c2\u00a0\nConduct a self-audit. Who\u00e2\u0080\u0099s in your circle? Who do you turn to for advice? Who do you follow and engage with on social media?\nDo not re-share pictures and videos of violence perpetrated against Black people. While we may want to increase awareness
column33: such media can be triggering and retraumatizing. \nWhile social distancing
column34: it may seem difficult to show up physically for your colleagues or the Black community. Do it virtually \u00e2\u0080\u0094 but without expectations. This is about them
column35:
not you.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Speak up
In meetings
column36: on social media
column37: in conference calls
column38: in chats with friends and family. In your circle
column39:
create more allies. Address anti-Black sentiments when you see them and discuss the violence and injustice that Black communities face.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Continuously leverage your voice and privilege to amplify Black and Brown communities. Violence
column40: police brutality
column41: racism
column42:
and discrimination arenât isolated incidents. Theyâre happening everywhere everyday. Hereâs an example of how you can use your voice:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Allyship is not about who you are
column43: but what you do consistently and authentically. Do the work. Everyone is dealing with a lot these days
column44: but be especially mindful of Black and Brown communities who regularly face threats to their wellbeing
column45: violence
column46:
and hate because of their identity.Â 
There is no better time to stand up for whatâs right. #UntilWeAllBelong #BlackLivesMatter 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
