column3: "title": "Inclusion & Diversity Report May 2020: Principles during a pandemic"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nInclusion & Diversity Report May 2020: Principles during a pandemic\nWednesday
column8: 27 May 2020\nLink copied successfully\nAlthough the world doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t look the same since our last post
column9: our commitment to Inclusion & Diversity at Twitter has never been stronger. Since our last update
column10: we transitioned more than 5
column11: 000 Tweeps to a fully virtual workforce
column12: introduced new programs and benefits
column13:
and doubled down on inclusion in the age of COVID-19. Weâve accomplished a lot ââ and learned some important lessons along the way.Â 
Here are the four key principles that have guided our Inclusion & Diversity response at Twitter:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Put people first ââ and really listen
Our priority has always been our Tweeps
column14: their safety
column15: well-being
column16: and security. In February
column17:
we were one of the first companies to announce a global WFH policy ââ for us it was an easy decision. But it still required a massive amount of work to operationalize.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We created Slack channels specifically to answer questions related to COVID-19
column18: launched a COVID-19 focused global survey to take the pulse of our Tweeps
column19: hosted more global all hands meetings to check in on everyone
column20: and increased opportunities to connect virtually across teams \u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00e2\u0080\u0093 especially our Business Resource Groups (BRGs).\nWorking from home
column21: and trying to work at home during a global pandemic are different. So we re-evaluated our global benefits to identify opportunities for enhancements. In addition to reimbursing expenses associated with Tweeps\u00e2\u0080\u0099 WFH setup
column22: we also increased our investments in mental and physical health benefits
column23:
and explored ways to better support caregivers learning to navigate our new reality.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Lead with empathy and flexibility
Our deep listening produced some common themes. People were having difficulty focusing
column24: and productivity was being impacted by the pandemic. This was especially true for Tweeps from communities of color
column25: caregivers and/or those at higher risk of infection. So we introduced resources to help managers prioritize their own well being while managing a team
column26: foster deeper empathy between managers and their direct reports
column27: paused 2020 performance ratings
column28: and made room for Tweeps to operate at reduced capacity when needed.\nIn partnership with @TwitterParents
column29: we launched a special listening session for parents. What we heard was that our recently-introduced supplemental child care benefit wasn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t having the impact that we hoped because of shelter in place orders. What parents \u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00e2\u0080\u0093 and everyone \u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00e2\u0080\u0093 needed was more flexibility to manage through the pandemic in a way that worked for them. So we introduced flexible work schedules for Tweeps who needed extra time to take care of themselves and their families
column30: and coached managers on how to lean in to asynchronous work
column31: allowing Tweeps to get their work done how and when it suits them. And since there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s no keeping the kids out of the home office
column32:
we launched a weekly storytime with Twitter leadership to give everyone a break.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We emphasized decentralization and supporting a distributed workforce
column33: even before the pandemic started
column34: which allowed us to quickly transition our Tweeps to being fully virtual. The past few months have proven this works for us and we made working from home an option for everyone whose roles allow it
column35: permanently \u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00e2\u0080\u0093 even after the pandemic ends. This decision will help drive workforce diversity by ensuring anyone
column36: anywhere
column37:
can work for Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Cultivate allyship
The virus doesnât discriminate. Unfortunately
column38:
some people do. So we teamed up with @TwitterAsians to host Flock Talks for the entire company about COVID-19 and racism. We know thereâs a direct correlation between conversations like these and the health of our workplace and our service. Tweeps from across the globe came together to share personal stories about the impact of COVID-19 and how people can be allies during the pandemic.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We didnât stop there. Via #TwitterTeamUp
column39: we brought together a cross-functional group of leaders from BRGs
column40: Product
column41: Policy
column42: and Trust & Safety to discuss the work being done to prevent misinformation around COVID-19 and anti-Asian rhetoric on the platform. We also launched a campaign focused on #AllyshipRightNow to address hate speech
column43: encourage allyship
column44:
and create a space where personal stories from the Asian community could be shared.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Conversation about COVID-19 in the US must include its disproportionate impact on diverse communities. Via #DiversityPartnerships
column45: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve hosted a weekly series focusing on underrepresented communities to call attention to the unique challenges they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re each facing during this crisis. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve had 8 sessions featuring 26 speakers including: Marc Morial (@NatUrbanLeague)
column46: Sindy M Benavides (@LULAC)
column47: KD Chavez (@acluhawaii)
column48: Pamela Prince-Eason (@WBENCLive)
column49: John C. Yang (@AAAJ_AAJC)
column50: Fatima Goss Graves (@nwlc)
column51: Alphonso David (@HRC)
column52:
and Jill Houghton (@DisabilityIN).
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Double down on BRGs
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Global workforce? No problem! Check out our dual timezone virtual BRG Leadership Roundtable. 
          
          
        
We have seen record growth in membership and participation across our BRGs ââ more than 30% increase since the beginning of the year. Weâre using this as an opportunity to enhance new member onboarding
column53: invest more in virtual events
column54:
and accelerate expansion to ensure representation across our global locations.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
ð£ @TwitterWomen
Unfortunately
column55: the arrival of COVID-19 in the US shuttered plans for Women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s History Month
column56: so instead we hosted a virtual launch party featuring the stories of women from intersectional backgrounds worldwide. Flexibility was key
column57: and our @TwitterWomen leaders rose to the challenge without missing a beat. The session was extraordinary and emotional
column58:
reaching more than 400 Tweeps across the globe.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
ð£ @TwitterFaith
We committed to adding even more BRGs in 2020
column59: and this January we were excited to introduce our newest BRG:\u00c2\u00a0@TwitterFaith. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s time to move beyond merely \u00e2\u0080\u009caccommodating\u00e2\u0080\u009d faith
column60: and instead
column61: grow towards building a culture where faith
column62: as part of someone\u00e2\u0080\u0099s identity
column63: is welcomed
column64: acknowledged
column65:
and celebrated.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Spring
column66: for so many people across the globe
column67: marks holy months centered around faith
column68: fellowship
column69: family \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and food. And so
column70: @TwitterFaith launched #FaithFoodies. In the spirit of social distancing
column71: Tweeps opened their homes to host cooking demos for traditional dishes
column72:
sharing stories of their familyâs holiday traditions.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
@TwitterFaith also hosted its first ever Ramadan 101 workshop
column73: giving Muslim employees the opportunity to build community
column74: but also giving their colleagues
column75: team members
column76:
and leaders a way to learn and practice allyship. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Representation matters
It might look a little different
column77: but we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re still hiring! We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve recently evaluated all of our open roles on our Careers site to ensure those listed align to our most urgent business priorities. During these uncertain times
column78: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re being even more deliberate about hiring
column79: development
column80:
and promotions throughout the business to ensure weâre still advancing our workplace representation goals. Check out the latest numbers here.
Our teams have been working hard to ensure that we can continue to bring the best and brightest talent to fill essential roles at Twitter. We know that times are tough right now so we want to make it easier than ever to connect with us because we want you to #JoinTheFlock.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Now is the time to remain steadfast in our commitment to become the most inclusive tech company in the world. Now is the time to be consciously inclusive. Now is the time to come together. #UntilWeAllBelong
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@TwitterTogether
#UntilWeAllBelong

column3: "title": "#KeepItOn: Making your voice heard to end Internet shutdowns "
column7:
"post_text": "Company
#KeepItOn: Making your voice heard to end Internet shutdowns 
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 26 May 2020\nLink copied successfully\nAs we continue to face the global coronavirus pandemic
column9: one truth that has come to bear over recent weeks and months is that what we are experiencing knows no borders. \nOne of the elemental things powering our shared resolve at this unprecedented moment is the connected nature of our world
column10: connectivity that is driven by the Internet. But
column11: what if the ability to gather and share critical information
column12: access essential products and services
column13: learn and work from home effectively
column14: connect with our loved ones
column15: and speak truth to power
column16: was taken away from us? Unfortunately
column17: this is the reality for many people around the world.\u00c2\u00a0\nA recent report from Access Now shows an increase in Internet shutdowns globally
column18: with 213 documented shutdowns in 2019 and a concerning trend toward more targeted and prolonged shutdowns. Sometimes known as (Internet) \u00e2\u0080\u0098blackouts\u00e2\u0080\u0099 or \u00e2\u0080\u0098kill switches\u00e2\u0080\u0099
column19: shutdowns can be highly targeted
column20: focused on specific groups of individuals for the purposes of repressing dissent
column21: to larger shutdowns which can deprive entire communities of essential information and isolate people from their support networks. The deliberate throttling of Internet speeds \u00e2\u0080\u0094 increasingly a tool of repression \u00e2\u0080\u0094 creates friction and barriers to entry for those who need it most.\nTo help raise awareness of this important issue
column22: Twitter is pleased to support the #KeepItOn campaign
column23: with the launch of a special emoji. #KeepItOn is a coalition of more than 200 organisations \u00e2\u0080\u0094 ranging from research centers to rights and local advocacy groups
column24: detection networks
column25: and media organizations \u00e2\u0080\u0094 located within 75 countries around the world
column26: fighting to end Internet shutdowns globally.\u00c2\u00a0\nTwitter's mission is to serve the public conversation. We are committed to protecting freedom of expression
column27: while encouraging healthy and productive public conversations. Having access to the free and open Internet is a right that many have come to see as essential. It is a right that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s increasingly inseparable from free expression
column28: self-determination
column29: and self-actualization.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur right to access news
column30: connection
column31: and medical information on the open Internet is more vital than ever during this pandemic. For some
column32: it may be existential. It acts as a distribution channel for the most up-to-date information on how to prevent the spread of the virus; a directory that points us to the services we need to stay healthy; and a place where we can gather with friends and family. And with our economies reliant on digital technologies and connectivity
column33: an open Internet is a foundational pillar on which recovery must be built.\u00c2\u00a0\nShutdowns can only impede this progress
column34: unnecessarily walling off targeted communities and entire populations. We have also seen a worrying trend towards regulatory action that could see instances of shutdowns increase further. Some of this is motivated by an urgent need to tackle COVID-19 in any way possible \u00e2\u0080\u0094 some isn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t \u00e2\u0080\u0094 but the long-term result could be an Internet that is less open
column35: less free
column36: and less empowering for all.\u00c2\u00a0\nThroughout the past weeks and months
column37: we have seen first-hand that the principles of net neutrality and how the open
column38: borderless nature of the Internet has allowed us to stay connected. As we face this pandemic
column39: Twitter is helping people find reliable information
column40: connect with others
column41: and follow what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in real time. In March
column42: we announced that we were contributing to two organizations working tirelessly to uphold the fundamental values of a free press during the pandemic. Additionally
column43: a critical function of our service is providing a place where people can openly and publicly respond to their leaders and hold them accountable.\nWorking with our partners across the globe
column44: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve facilitated conversations and the sharing of authoritative and credible information through our #KnowTheFacts prompt
column45: now available in approximately 80 countries
column46: hosting Q&As with the World Health Organization on @Twitter
column47:
and launching a global campaign to support the #SafeHands campaign.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We have seen a huge surge in sharing gratitude
column48: with more than 250 million Tweets shared worldwide expressing appreciation since March 15
column49:
and celebrating those who are on the frontlines protecting us all.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
These campaigns and global initiatives would not have been possible without the global
column50: open
column51: and interconnected Internet. Today
column52: to support this critical movement
column53: we're encouraging people around the world to make their voices heard by using #KeepItOn.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cAccess to information and freedom of expression are the foundations of our democracy. During a global health crisis
column54: we all should be working to facilitate people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s access to credible and timely information. Any attempt to throttle
column55: stifle
column56: and shut down the internet including social media during this pandemic and beyond will have a detrimental effect on our collective health and well-being.\u00e2\u0080\u009d says Berhan Taye
column57:
Senior Policy Analyst and Global Internet Shutdowns Lead at Access Now.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter

column3: "title": "Testing
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/product/2020/testing-new-conversation-settings"
column8: "post_text": "Product\nTesting
column9:
testing ... new conversation settings
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column10: 20 May 2020\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter is where you go to see and talk about what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening. But sometimes
column11: unwanted replies make it hard to have meaningful conversations. (Ahem
column12: reply guys.) Since last year
column13: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been working to give people more control over their conversations starting with the ability to hide replies. We also began trying out new ways to start conversations with casual
column14: fleeting thoughts. And now
column15:
weâre testing new settings that let you choose who can reply to your Tweet and join your conversation.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Before you Tweet
column16: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be able to choose who can reply with three options: everyone (standard Twitter
column17: and the default setting)
column18: only people you follow
column19: or only people you mention. Tweets with the latter two settings will be labeled and the reply icon will be grayed out so that it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s clear for people if they can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t reply. People who can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t reply will still be able to view
column20: Retweet
column21: Retweet with Comment
column22:
and like these Tweets.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
For now
column23: only a limited group of people globally on Twitter for iOS
column24: Android
column25: and twitter.com can Tweet with these settings
column26: but everyone can see these conversations. Learn more in our help center.\nBeing able to participate and understand what's happening is key for useful public conversation. So
column27: we're exploring how we can improve these settings to give people more opportunities to weigh in while still giving people control over the conversations they start. In addition to this
column28: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re making it easier to read all conversations around a Tweet with a new layout for replies and more accessible Retweets with comments.\u00c2\u00a0\nOne thing we know for sure is that you'll be creative with this update. Maybe you'll host a debate on the benefits of pineapple on pizza (#TeamPineapple) with fellow pizza pals or invite a panel of distinguished guests for a fireside chat. You could even play a game of tic-tac-toe for people to follow along without messing up your moves. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to see what you do!\nAnd as always
column29:
@ me with what you think.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Bot or not? The facts about platform manipulation on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Bot or not? The facts about platform manipulation on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 18 May 2020\nLink copied successfully\nGoing back a few years
column9: there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s been a lot of discussion of \u00e2\u0080\u009cbots\u00e2\u0080\u009d online. Over time
column10: however
column11: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s become a loaded and often misunderstood term.\u00c2\u00a0\nPeople often refer to bots when describing everything from automated account activity to individuals who would prefer to be anonymous for personal or safety reasons
column12: or avoid a photo because they\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve got strong privacy concerns. The term is used to mischaracterize accounts with numerical usernames that are auto-generated when your preference is taken
column13: and more worryingly
column14: as a tool by those in positions of political power to tarnish the views of people who may disagree with them or online public opinion that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not favorable.\u00c2\u00a0\nThere are also many commercial services that purport to offer insights on bots and their activity online
column15: and frequently their focus is entirely on Twitter due to the free data we provide through our public APIs. Unfortunately
column16: this research is rarely peer-reviewed and often does not hold up to scrutiny
column17:
further confusing the public's understanding of whatâs really happening.
Letâs break it down and explain the facts.Â 
Whatâs a bot?Â 
Based on what weâve described above
column18: there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a lot of understandable confusion and we need to do a better job of explaining ourselves. In sum
column19: a bot is an automated account \u00e2\u0080\u0094 nothing more or less.\nGoing back a few years
column20: automated accounts were a problem for us. We focused on it
column21: made the investments
column22:
and have seen significant gains in tackling them across all surfaces of Twitter. That doesnât mean our work is done.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Whatâs more important to focus on in 2020 is the holistic behavior of an account
column23:
not just whether itâs automated or not. Thatâs why calls for bot labeling donât capture the problem weâre trying to solve and the errors we could make to real people that need our service to make their voice heard. Itâs not just a binary question of bot or not â the gradients in between are what matter. 
Thatâs why we focus our attention on where the most critical work is. We call it platform manipulation.Â  
Whatâs platform manipulation?
Our proactive work is focused on manipulation in many forms and that includes the malicious use of automation. As discussed
column24: our policies in this area focus on behavior
column25: not content
column26: and are written in a way that targets the spammy tactics different people or groups could use to try to manipulate conversations on Twitter (rather than on what they're specifically saying).\u00c2\u00a0\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important to note
column27: not all forms of automation are necessarily violations of the Twitter Rules. We've seen innovative and creative uses of automation to enrich the Twitter experience \u00e2\u0080\u0094 for example
column28: accounts like @pentametron and @tinycarebot.\u00c2\u00a0\nAutomation can also be a powerful tool in customer service interactions
column29: where a conversational bot can help find information about orders or travel reservations automatically. This is incredibly useful and efficient for small businesses
column30: especially at a time of social distancing.\u00c2\u00a0\nSo what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s prohibited?\nMalicious use of automation to undermine and disrupt the public conversation
column31: like trying to get something to trend\nArtificial amplification of conversations on Twitter
column32: including through creating multiple or overlapping accounts\nGenerating
column33: soliciting
column34: or purchasing fake engagements\nEngaging in bulk or aggressive tweeting
column35: engaging
column36: or following\nUsing hashtags in a spammy way
column37: including using unrelated hashtags in a tweet (aka \"hashtag cramming\")\nOur technological power to proactively identify and remove these behaviors across our service is more sophisticated than ever. We permanently suspend millions of accounts every month that are automated or spammy
column38:
and we do this before they ever reach an eyeball in a Twitter Timeline or Search.Â 
We also publish data on our removals every six months in theÂ Twitter Transparency Report.Â 
What about tools like Botometer & Bot Sentinel?
These tools start with a human looking at an account â often using the same public account information you can see on Twitter â and identifying characteristics that make it a bot. So in essence
column39: the account name
column40: the level of Tweeting
column41: the location in the bio
column42: the hashtags used etc.\u00c2\u00a0\nThis is an extremely limited approach.\nAs mentioned
column43: an account with a strange handle is often someone who was automatically recommended that username because their real-name was taken at sign-up. An account with no photo or location may be someone who has personal feelings on online privacy or whose use of Twitter may expose them to risk
column44: like an activist or dissident. Don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t like to add much of a bio or your location to your account? Some of us at Twitter don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t either. Even if all of these public details are put into a machine learning model to try to probabilistically predict if an account is a bot
column45: when they rely on human analysis of public account information
column46: that process contains biases \u00e2\u0080\u0094 from the start.\nLet\u00e2\u0080\u0099s take some other everyday examples for clarity. Someone who Tweets 100 times a day with #SuperBowl could just be an extremely engaged individual who loves football (or hates it if their team is bad). If you care deeply about the environment and Tweet about it at a certain political moment when you and your friends want to make an impact
column47: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re not \u00e2\u0080\u009cpolitical bots\u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\u0094 you're active citizens organizing an organic online campaign to drive change in your community.\u00c2\u00a0\nThese tools do not account for these common Twitter use cases
column48: how far we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve come
column49: and how things have evolved. As a result nuance can be lost. The outcome? Binary judgments of who\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a \u00e2\u0080\u009cbot or not\u00e2\u0080\u009d
column50: which have real potential to poison our public discourse \u00e2\u0080\u0094 particularly when they are pushed out through the media.\u00c2\u00a0\nThat doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t mean we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re perfect. Of course not. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s just that the threat has evolved and the narrative on what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s actually going on is increasingly behind the curve.\nIf I see suspicious activity
column51: can I report it?\u00c2\u00a0\nYes. If you see\u00c2\u00a0suspicious activity
column52: report it to us. We add your signal to the hundreds of others we use to inform our technical approach.\nIf we want to create a healthy information ecosystem
column53: we all have a part to play. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve reinforced these points many times and we will get stronger and more direct in our public efforts at this critical moment in the global public conversation. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re keenly aware of our responsibility in this space. That includes protecting the integrity of our service
column54: continuing to keep platform manipulation off of Twitter
column55:
and leading with transparency by sharing regular updates on our progress and learnings.Â

column3: "title": "Why social data is key for brands in COVID-19"
column7:
"post_text": "highTint
Why social data is key for brands in COVID-19
                By
                
  
  
Thursday
column8: 14 May 2020\nLink copied successfully\nWith social data
column9:
brands have a clearer picture of what customers expect and need in the time of COVID-19.
Listening to and understanding the conversations on Twitter can provide brands insights into how to communicate with customers during these times.Â 
We spoke with three Twitter data partners to get their thoughts on how much the conversation has changed and what this means for marketers.Â  
Brandwatch 
As people took to their homes to practice social distancing
column10: the conversation changed literally overnight
column11: to stockpiling and toilet paper shortages
column12: their jobs
column13: their loved ones and their own personal health.\u00c2\u00a0\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s interesting about the conversation we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re seeing on Twitter is that it gives us insight into how people are feeling and what they are doing to cope
column14: \u00e2\u0080\u009d says Victoria Miller
column15: VP of Global Communications at Brandwatch
column16: a digital consumer intelligence company that specializes in social media monitoring
column17: social listening
column18: consumer
column19: and market insights.\u00c2\u00a0\nConversation around good deeds increased 170% from March 1 to May 14
column20: up from January and February. People in America donated food (18k mentions)
column21: made masks for medical personnel (12k mentions)
column22: and promoted the message of shopping local (8.1k mentions.) In Canada
column23: volunteering to help the vulnerable and elderly was the most popular act
column24: followed by donations of money
column25: food
column26: blood and PPE. India (English mentions) was also a huge driver of conversation. Their donations were also the most popular charitable act
column27: with 78k mentions.\u00c2\u00a0\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cPeople are dealing with a high level of change and\u00c2\u00a0 they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re adapting to new circumstances and taking on new activities. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s been incredible to watch this evolve through social listening
column28: \u00e2\u0080\u009d says Miller.\u00c2\u00a0\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cThese insights and the ever changing conversation has helped our customers rethink how they engage and support consumers\u00e2\u0080\u009d
column29: says Miller.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cA lot of our clients are really keen to broadly understand how people are feeling
column30: because striking the right tone with their content
column31: the campaigns and products is so key at the moment
column32: \u00e2\u0080\u009d says Miller. \u00e2\u0080\u009cI suspect that a lot of brands are making changes now that they\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll keep in place permanently.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\u00c2\u00a0\nSprinklr \nBy March
column33: when COVID-19 was declared a global pandemic
column34: Sprinklr
column35: the NYC-based Customer Experience Management (CXM) platform for large organizations
column36: used its AI capabilities to analyze over 600 million Tweets to learn more about the conversation on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0 \n\u00e2\u0080\u009cTwitter gives organizations the opportunity to understand the past context of the conversation and insights to help them anticipate how it might evolve
column37: \u00e2\u0080\u009d says Paul Herman
column38: Sprinklr VP of Product Marketing.\u00c2\u00a0 \nSprinklr discovered that many of the new and unreported symptoms of COVID-19
column39: like the loss of taste and smell
column40: were initially popping up on Twitter. Many healthcare workers were taking to Twitter to share their frustrations on the lack of PPE
column41: which for government officials
column42: helps them identify which areas are in need of essential resources.\u00c2\u00a0 \n\u00e2\u0080\u009cIt highlighted for companies an urgency to move towards a more holistic approach to customer experience management
column43: \u00e2\u0080\u009d says Herman. \u00e2\u0080\u009cResearch is one thing
column44: but research combined with customer care combined with marketing as a holistic function is another.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\u00c2\u00a0 \nPeople now expect brands and government agencies to be there for them when the situation improves. To Herman
column45: this means brands and governments need to be where these people are
column46: they have to speak to them in a human way and they have to build trust with them.\u00c2\u00a0 \nSprout Social \nTo Patrick Cuttica
column47: the sheer volume of the COVID-19 conversation and the data it generates represents an incredible moment in the history of social listening.\u00c2\u00a0 \n\u00e2\u0080\u009cVery few events impact every single industry
column48: every single country and every person on this planet
column49: and so I think what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s really unique is the scale of what these conversations look like and the far-reaching impact it has
column50: \u00e2\u0080\u009d says Patrick Cuttica
column51: Director of Product Marketing at Sprout Social
column52: a company that specializes in deep social media listening and analytics for more than 20
column53: 000 brands and agencies.\u00c2\u00a0 \nWhile the pandemic has put a pause on live events like golf tournaments and basketball playoffs
column54: networks are filling the sports void with other types of entertainment.\u00c2\u00a0 \nFor instance
column55: Netflix and ESPN\u00e2\u0080\u0099s \u00e2\u0080\u009cThe Last Dance
column56: \u00e2\u0080\u009d the documentary series on Michael Jordan and the Chicago Bulls
column57: was the most eagerly awaited cultural moment of the summer. But with the NBA season put on hold
column58: basketball fans went on Twitter to plead with ESPN for an earlier release date. It worked
column59: thanks in part to the conversation on social media. \u00e2\u0080\u009cThe Last Dance\u00e2\u0080\u009d has now become a cultural event in its own right. \n\u00e2\u0080\u009cIn the absence of live sports
column60: professional sports teams and events have had to completely shift their overall content strategies on social and beyond during this time. Twitter has played a significant role in that shift
column61: both in the way Twitter data can help inform new strategies and in the way content is distributed and discussed on Twitter
column62: \u00e2\u0080\u009d said Cuttica.\u00c2\u00a0 \nThese current times have also changed how healthcare companies engage with patient communities on Twitter. Sprout Social recently introduced a new product offering within their social listening suite
column63: the \u00e2\u0080\u009cCOVID-19 Featured Topic\u00e2\u0080\u009d. This tool gives Sprout customers the ability to \u00e2\u0080\u009cdimension the overall social conversation data set around COVID-19 to understand how it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s impacting their brand
column64: \u00e2\u0080\u009d said Cuttica. For instance
column65: by using this tool
column66: healthcare customers can define potential trends in the use of associated words and phrases like \u00e2\u0080\u009celective surgery
column67: \u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\u009chospital access\u00e2\u0080\u009d or \u00e2\u0080\u009cpregnancy.\u00e2\u0080\u009d \n\u00e2\u0080\u009cThis would indicate that there was growing uncertainty or concern among patients around the topics
column68: \u00e2\u0080\u009d says Cuttica
column69: \u00e2\u0080\u009cand hospital systems could get ahead of this uncertainty by proactively clarifying via social content.\u00e2\u0080\u009d \nLooking ahead
column70: brands should use their Twitter data to help shape their marketing content and stay up to date on the pulse of the conversation.\u00c2\u00a0 \n\u00e2\u0080\u009cTwitter is an amazing platform for showcasing these stories and driving the global conversation
column71: \u00e2\u0080\u009d says Cuttica. \u00e2\u0080\u009cIt could be political moments
column72: cultural events
column73: or it could be something like the COVID-19 pandemic where the entire world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s online behavior changes almost overnight. People come to Twitter to find information
column74: share opinions and create connections during these times
column75:
and this makes Twitter data invaluable for brands.â
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
#DataPartners
#SocialListening
#COVID-19

COVID-19

column3: "title": "Keeping our employees and partners safe during #coronavirus"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Keeping our employees and partners safe during #coronavirus
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 12 May 2020\nLink copied successfully\nTo see all of the latest steps Twitter is taking in response to COVID-19
column9:
visitÂ covid19.twitter.com.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
May 12
column10: 2020 \n#LoveWhereverYouWork\nTwitter was one of the first companies to go to a work from home model in the face of COVID-19
column11: but we don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t anticipate being one of the first to return to offices.\u00c2\u00a0 \nWe were uniquely positioned to respond quickly and allow folks to work from home given our emphasis on decentralization and supporting a distributed workforce capable of working from anywhere. The past few months have proven we can make that work. So if our employees are in a role and situation that enables them to work from home and they want to continue to do so forever
column12: we will make that happen. If not
column13: our offices will be their warm and welcoming selves
column14: with some additional precautions
column15: when we feel it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s safe to return.\u00c2\u00a0\nHere\u00e2\u0080\u0099s how we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re thinking about the next few months:\nOpening offices will be our decision
column16: when and if our employees come back
column17: will be theirs.\u00c2\u00a0\nWith very few exceptions
column18: offices won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t open before September. When we do decide to open offices
column19: it also won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t be a snap back to the way it was before. It will be careful
column20: intentional
column21: office by office and gradual.\u00c2\u00a0\nThere will also be no business travel before September
column22: with very few exceptions
column23:
and no in-person company events for the rest of 2020. We will assess 2021 events later this year.
Weâre proud of the early action we took to protect the health of our employees and our communities. That will remain our top priority as we work through the unknowns of the coming months.
#LoveWhereverYouWork
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
 March 11
column24: 2020\nMoving to mandatory work from home globally + supporting our employees\u00c2\u00a0 \nOur top priority remains the health and safety of our Tweeps
column25: and we also have a responsibility to support our communities
column26: those who are vulnerable
column27: and the healthcare providers who are on the front lines of this pandemic.\u00c2\u00a0To continue this push
column28: we are moving beyond our earlier guidance of \u00e2\u0080\u009cstrongly encouraging work from home\u00e2\u0080\u009d provided on March 2 and have now informed all employees globally they must work from home.\nWe understand this is an unprecedented step
column29: but these are unprecedented times. And we will continue to do all that we can to support our Tweeps
column30: including:\u00c2\u00a0\nPaying our contractors
column31: vendors and hourly workers For contractors and hourly workers who are not able to perform their responsibilities from home
column32: Twitter will continue to pay their labor costs to cover standard working hours while Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s work-from-home guidance and/or travel restrictions related to their assigned office are in effect.\u00c2\u00a0\nAdditional resources to support parents As part of our ongoing global benefits support
column33: Twitter is stepping in to ease additional expenses parents may be experiencing when their normal daycare closes due to COVID-19 by providing reimbursement for the additional daycare expenses incurred.\u00c2\u00a0\nHelping Tweeps set up their at-home offices All employees
column34: including hourly workers
column35: will receive reimbursement toward their home office set up expenses
column36: and we are working with our vendors to ensure our contractors' work-from-home needs are met as well. We listened to employee feedback and expanded our policy to include home office equipment
column37: such as desks
column38: desk chairs
column39: and ergonomic chair cushions. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also allowing Tweeps to expense online fees while working from home.\n#FlockTalk Last year
column40: we introduced #FlockTalk
column41: a program activated when Tweeps want to come together during difficult times to share what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s going on with them
column42: find community
column43: and be heard by our leaders. News around COVID-19 is impacting people in a number of different ways -- from schools and offices being closed
column44: to serious health concerns
column45: to racism towards communities
column46: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re all dealing with a lot. The Twitter Inclusion & Diversity team (@TwitterTogether) in partnership with @TwitterAsians will host a virtual #FlockTalk that acknowledges there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a direct correlation between conversations between us
column47: the health of our workplace
column48: and the health of our service.\u00c2\u00a0\nResource guides to make the work-from-home transition easier Working from home can be a challenging transition
column49: so we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve provided a variety of resource guides to help our employees continue to get the job done. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re listing them here as well because at times like this
column50: sharing insights and learning is so important. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re all in this together and we want to help others outside of Twitter make their transitions to working outside of their offices easier.\nWorking From Home Best Practices: We have shared the factors to consider to make sure Tweeps are ready to be productive and healthy. Some factors include workspace
column51: communication
column52: self-care
column53: and logging hours. Overall
column54: working from home doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t change your day-to-day work
column55: it just means you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be doing it from a different environment.\nManaging a Distributed Team: Being a People manager means providing a consistent and positive employee experience for everyone on your team
column56: regardless of location. This manager resource guide highlights the three key pillars of management: Strategy
column57: Growth and Care. So what changes when your team is fully distributed? The good news\u00e2\u0080\u0094not much! These pillars still apply whether you manage a distributed or co-located team.\u00c2\u00a0\nVirtual Interview Guide: All interviews at Twitter will be done via video conferencing. A completely virtual interview has its benefits. It is ideal for introducing candidates to remote work cultures
column58: and it is a great opportunity for candidates who will work remotely to get a sense for the experience of interacting with other team members remotely.\u00c2\u00a0 While this Virtual Interview Guide is not a holistic Interview Guide
column59: it instead focuses on the aspects of interviewing candidates remotely that differ from interviewing candidates in-person.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe have also shared guides for working across time zones
column60: utilizing collaboration tools to stay connected
column61:
and ergonomic tips for working from home and on-the-go.
Weâll continue sharing information as we navigate these changes. Itâs all in dedication to keeping our Tweeps and everyone around us healthy. Weâre all in this together!
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
March 2
column62: 2020\nEncouraging employees to work from home  In addition to the travel
column63: event and visitor restrictions that we previously shared
column64: today we provided additional guidance as we look to protect the health and safety of our workforce. Beginning today
column65: we are strongly encouraging all employees globally to work from home if they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re able. Our goal is to lower the probability of the spread of the COVID-19 for us - and the world around us. We are operating out of an abundance of caution and the utmost dedication to keeping our Tweeps healthy.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe are working to make sure internal meetings
column66: all hands
column67: and other important tasks are optimized for remote participation. We recognize that working from home is not ideal for some job functions. For those employees who prefer or need to come into the offices
column68: they will remain open for business. Our Real Estate & Workplace team is increasing deep cleaning and sanitizing in all spaces
column69: as well as more visual reminders for personal hygiene best practices and pre-packaged
column70: pre-composed
column71: and pre-plated food options. \nWorking from home will be mandatory for employees based in our Hong Kong
column72: Japan
column73: and South Korea offices due in part to government restrictions. Our criteria will evolve over time as we get more information
column74: and we will communicate to affected Tweeps as appropriate. \nWhile this is a big change for us
column75: we have already been moving towards a more distributed workforce that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s increasingly remote. We're a global service and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to enabling anyone
column76:
anywhere to work at Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
March 1
column77: 2020\nSuspending non-critical business travel and events  We recently shared information about the work we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re doing to surface the right information
column78: to promote constructive engagement
column79: and to highlight credible information around the spread of #coronavirus COVID-19. We will continue to update the public on these efforts this week.\nWe also have the responsibility of ensuring that the health and safety of our employees and partners is not compromised. We have continued to monitor the situation closely and are adjusting our internal policies to respond to this rapidly-evolving situation. On February 29
column80:
we informed our people and started notifying partners that we are suspending all non-critical business travel and events.Â Â 
This policy is effective immediately and will continue until the World Health Organization or Centers for Disease Control deem it appropriate to step back from pandemic precautionary measures or when a vaccine becomes available.Â  
Our goal is to reduce the risk that anyone at Twitter might contract or inadvertently spread the virus. It is important that we take these proactive steps to protect ourselves and others and minimize the spread of COVID-19.Â  
There are enormous transnational efforts underway to tackle this virus. As a global company with a global workforce
column81: we want to do what we can to help the success of these multi-stakeholder containment efforts. Temporarily suspending travel is an immediate and important step. \nWe want to thank our people
column82:
partners and customers for their patience and understanding.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "#TwitterForGood Day goes remote"
column7: "post_text": "Company\n#TwitterForGood Day goes remote\nMonday
column8: 11 May 2020\nLink copied successfully\nOur goal with Twitter for Good is to bring our company together to be a force for positive change in the communities we serve. While this happens in myriad ways every day at Twitter
column9: we focus on two global days of service annually to harness this energy at scale for maximum impact.\u00c2\u00a0\nOn May 8
column10: we launched our first-ever fully remote Twitter for Good Day. It was fun
column11: it was meaningful
column12:
and it required a complete shift in thinking as we all continue to battle #COVID19.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
It became clear in late February that this year would look very different. Our plan to revitalize parks
column13: visit classrooms
column14: and prepare and serve meals in local communities around the world ground to a halt. We faced a decision to cancel the day outright or to reimagine what it might look like for Tweeps to give back from their homesinstead at physical locations within the community.\u00c2\u00a0\nAs it turns out
column15: the decision was easy: The need in communities around the world had never been greater
column16: and our employees were eager \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and yearned \u00e2\u0080\u0094 to give back.\u00c2\u00a0\nQ&A sessions with Jack\nIn line with our global approach to Twitter for Good
column17:
Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey kicked off the first ever remote day of service by hosting Periscope Q&A sessions live on Twitter with nonprofit leaders in every corner of the world.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
More than 130
column18: 000 people tuned in to hear these conversations with Project RockIt in Australia
column19: SpunOut in Ireland
column20: Voz de Comunidades in Brazil
column21: the Houston Food Bank
column22: and Code Tenderloin in San Francisco. These participating organizations \u00e2\u0080\u0094 diverse in location
column23: mission
column24: and purpose \u00e2\u0080\u0094 are all longstanding Twitter partners. As the world has shifted to care for their communities amid COVID-19
column25: these conversations reflected the work of nonprofit partners and their agile response tomeet the needs of the people they serve.\u00c2\u00a0\nActivations and outcomes\nIn total
column26: we organized 52 projects
column27: contributed more than 1
column28: 500 hours of service
column29: and donated $165
column30: 000 (and counting) through our Employee Matching program in the month of May alone.\u00c2\u00a0\nTweeps baked cakes in France for frontline workers
column31: joined a conversation about the risks of domestic violence during COVID in Singapore
column32: prepared food provisions for high-risk populations in Mexico
column33: and faced the daunting challenge of trying to prove they are smarter than a 5th grader in a high-stakes trivia match with students at DeMarillac Academy in San Francisco.\nWhile Twitter provided a set of opportunities for every employee to volunteer
column34: give
column35: or learn
column36: we know that many employees pursued a cause of their own. One example was the ingenuity of a Tweep who used a 3D printer to make mask straps for frontline workers. Through it all
column37: the love
column38: care
column39: and compassion Tweeps felt for our community partners was alive and kicking; a testament to the power of service regardless of the events taking place outside Twitter.\nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next?\nOur first global remote day of service made this abundantly clear: Our community partners are struggling to meet the exponentially increased demand for their services
column40: and we need to embrace our charitable giving
column41: nonprofit partnerships and on-service support for these organizations now more than ever.\nThis Twitter for Good Day showed us yet again that our community partners and our employees are extraordinarily creative
column42: adaptable
column43: and ready to meet the challenges of our communities. The strength of a virtual day of service is that it allows each of us to approach today\u00e2\u0080\u0099s pressing issues in our own unique way \u00e2\u0080\u0094 empowered to innovate
column44: adapt
column45: and give back.\nTwitter for Good Day may occur only twice a year
column46: but we know that the real work happens in between
column47: every day and every week. The spirit of giving continues to take flight at Twitter
column48: and we are committed to staying the course as long as it is needed
column49:
for our communities and all those in need.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Updating our approach to misleading information"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Updating our approach to misleading information
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 11 May 2020\nLink copied successfully\nEffective November 23
column10:
Twitter is no longer enforcing the COVID-19 misleading information policy.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In serving the public conversation
column11: our goal is to make it easy to find credible information on Twitter and to limit the spread of potentially harmful and misleading content. Starting today
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re introducing new labels and warning messages that will provide additional context and information on some Tweets containing disputed or misleading information related to COVID-19.\nIn March
column13: we broadened our policy guidance to address content that goes directly against guidance on COVID-19 from authoritative sources of global and local public health information. Moving forward
column14: we may use these labels and warning messages to provide additional explanations or clarifications in situations where the risks of harm associated with a Tweet are less severe but where people may still be confused or misled by the content. This will make it easier to find facts and make informed decisions about what people see on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nNew labels and warnings\nDuring active conversations about disputed issues
column15: it can be helpful to see additional context from trusted sources. Earlier this year
column16: we introduced a new label for Tweets containing synthetic and manipulated media. Similar labels will now appear on Tweets containing potentially harmful
column17:
misleading information related to COVID-19. This will also apply to Tweets sent before today.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
These labels will link to a Twitter-curated page or external trusted source containing additional information on the claims made within the Tweet.Â 
Depending on the propensity for harm and type of misleading information
column18:
warnings may also be applied to a Tweet. These warnings will inform people that the information in the Tweet conflicts with public health expertsâ guidance before they view it.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
While false or misleading content can take many different forms
column19: we will take action based on three broad categories:\nMisleading information \u00e2\u0080\u0094 statements or assertions that have been confirmed to be false or misleading by subject-matter experts
column20: such as public health authorities. \nDisputed claims \u00e2\u0080\u0094 statements or assertions in which the accuracy
column21: truthfulness
column22:
or credibility of the claim is contested or unknown. 
Unverified claims â information (which could be true or false) that is unconfirmed at the time it is shared.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
*We will continue to introduce new labels to provide context around different types of unverified claims and rumors as needed.
How will we identify these Tweets?
Our teams are using and improving on internal systems to proactively monitor content related to COVID-19. These systems help ensure weâre not amplifying Tweets with these warnings or labels and detecting the high-visibility content quickly. Additionally
column23: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to rely on trusted partners to identify content that is likely to result in offline harm. Given the dynamic situation
column24: we will prioritize review and labeling of content that could lead to increased exposure or transmission.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll learn a lot as we use these new labels
column25: and are open to adjusting as we explore labeling different types of misleading information. This process is ongoing and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll work to make sure these and other labels and warnings show up across Twitter. Embedded Tweets and Tweets viewed by people not logged into Twitter may still appear without a label.\nServing the public conversation remains our overarching mission
column26:
and weâll keep working to build tools and offer context so that people can find credible and authentic information on Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet
Twitter logo icon

product

column3: "title": "Serving the public conversation during #KoreanElection2020 amid COVID-19"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Serving the public conversation during #KoreanElection2020 amid COVID-19
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 27 April 2020\nLink copied successfully\nSouth Korea held a nation-wide election amidst this COVID-19 global pandemic on April 15
column9: 2020. Despite the challenges
column10: the election recorded a historic 66.2% voter turnout
column11: the highest in three decades for a parliamentary election. Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s role was even more critical as campaigns went virtual and people relied more than ever on online information. As such
column12: Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s mission of serving the public conversation remained core
column13: and we ensured Twitter supported the participatory discussion every step of this election cycle.\u00c2\u00a0\nProtecting the integrity of the #KoreanElection2020 conversation on Twitter\nIn preparation
column14: Twitter verified the accounts of 10 different regional election commissions
column15: five political parties
column16: and 94 candidates so that people could check the authenticity of information on the service. Two days prior to the election
column17: @TwitterKorea also announced the official Twitter accounts of 140 candidates from eleven political parties and also the nine political party accounts that had also joined the live national conversation. By following these accounts
column18: people were able to receive the latest updates including candidates\u00e2\u0080\u0099 pledges and campaign schedules
column19:
or to send a Twitter mention or direct message (DM) to ask questions.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Fighting platform manipulation and spam was a high priority. In the service ofÂ  protecting the integrity of the election conversation
column20: Twitter partnered with the Korean National Election Commission (@necmedia2017) to tackle issues such as deliberate election disinformation and clear violations of the Twitter Rules. Throughout the cycle we took enforcement\u00c2\u00a0 action against bad-faith accounts who tried to manipulate the service and spread misinformation around the election.\u00c2\u00a0 \nEmpowering and amplifying the election conversation\nTo help support and drive the public's interest in the election on Twitter
column21: we launched a custom emoji 20 days prior to the election day in partnership with the National Election Commission. The emoji symbolized the voting stamp and was automatically generated by hashtags #KoreanElection
column22: #KoreanElection2020
column23: #\u00ed\u0088\u00ac\u00ed\u0091\u009c(Voting)
column24: #\u00ed\u0088\u00ac\u00ed\u0091\u009c\u00ec\u009d\u00b8\u00ec\u00a6\u009d(ProofOfVoting)
column27: #21\u00eb\u008c\u0080\u00ea\u00b5\u00ad\u00ed\u009a\u008c\u00ec\u009d\u0098\u00ec\u009b\u0090\u00ec\u0084\u00a0\u00ea\u00b1\u00b0(21stLegislativeElection)
column28: and #415\u00ec\u00b4\u009d\u00ec\u0084\u00a0(April15Election). From March 25 through April 25
column29: a total of 90
column30:
109 conversations were recorded using the emoji.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Government agencies also made important election announcements on Twitter as the election was held during the unprecedented COVID-19 pandemic. The National Election Commission and the Ministry of the Interior and Safety (@withyou3542) both shared the code of conduct for safe voting and received positive feedback from citizens.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
During the month in the lead up to the election
column31: a total of 3.8 million Tweets related to the election were generated from candidate campaigns to \u00e2\u0080\u009c#IVoted\u00e2\u0080\u009d selfies.\u00c2\u00a0 On the weekend prior to the election
column32: which was reserved for early voting
column33: we saw 380
column34: 000 election-related Tweets and a record high voter turnout of 26.69%
column35: the highest since the advance voting system was adopted for nationwide elections in 2014.\u00c2\u00a0\nThe electoral reform in December 2019 lowered the legal voting age from 19 to 18 years old. 18-year-old voters shared the excitement of voting for the first time on Twitter. Civil society groups
column36: especially youth organizations
column37:
drove conversations around this milestone and encouraged voting for all age groups and even ran a straw vote project for those aged below 18 to encourage participation in the civic engagement.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
On election day
column38: more than 1.1 million related keywords were mentioned on Twitter with election-related terms dominating Trends.\u00c2\u00a0 The most mentioned keyword in Korea was \u00e2\u0080\u009c\u00ea\u00b0\u009c\u00ed\u0091\u009c\u00eb\u00b0\u00a9\u00ec\u0086\u00a1(Ballot Counting Broadcast)\u00e2\u0080\u009d -- the country\u00e2\u0080\u0099s reputation for high-quality CGI graphics during vote counting proved true once again in this election where candidates were depicted as characters on a competitive duck boat ride
column39: or even on a boxing match.\u00c2\u00a0\nThe second most Tweeted keyword was \u00e2\u0080\u009c\u00ed\u0088\u00ac\u00ed\u0091\u009c\u00ec\u0099\u0084\u00eb\u00a3\u008c(Voting Complete)\u00e2\u0080\u009d
column40: followed by \u00e2\u0080\u009c#Korea_wants_justice\u00e2\u0080\u009d
column42:
and âë¹ëì¥ê°(Plastic Gloves)â. âë¹ëì¥ê°(Plastic Gloves)â trended because voters were asked to put on disposable plastic gloves as a precautionary measure against viruses upon arriving at polling stations around the country.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The live vote counting on Twitter by MBC News (@mbcnews) and Arirang TV (@arirangworld
column43:
@ArirangTVnews) also received much attention among global audiences and garnered over 1.1 million cumulative views in total. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
To highlight interesting global content about the election that received global attention
column44: TwitterMoments (@TwitterMoments) curated six Moments in English
column45:
Japanese and Portuguese.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Celebritiesâ voting Tweets also drew attention from all over the world
column46: particularly the millenial and Gen-Z dominated #Kpop fan base. BTS again proved its popularity when member 'Suga' Tweeted about his vote with a photo on the official BTS Twitter account (@BTS_twt). This Tweet alone was retweeted 490
column47: 000 times
column48: got 1.64 million likes
column49:
and then became the 'Most Retweeted I Voted Selfie Tweet' during this election.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Given the role and importance in popular culture #Kpop plays
column50: its noteworthy that so many celebrities also joined the election conversation and showed their civic support; Sandara Park (@krungy21)
column51: Golden Child (@Hi_Goldenness)
column52: NCT DREAM (@NCTsmtown_DREAM)
column53: Rocket Punch (@RCPC_members)
column54:
and Gong Minji (@mingkki21) also shared their âProof of Votingâ Tweets.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The voting public also Tweeted their proof-of-voting photos. In the past people would receive a stamp on their hands
column55: this time they shared their photos wearing masks and plastic gloves
column56: or observing the strict social distancing protocols of 1-meter (3-feet) apart while at the polls.\u00c2\u00a0\nProtecting the public conversation continues to be Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s top priority. We will continue to work to protect conversations on the service
column57: particularly around election cycles
column58: by investing in technology
column59: developing new policies
column60:
and building meaningful partnerships to further our understanding of the political and social context within which Twitter operates.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet

elections
policy

column3: "title": "Commemorating the 50th Earth Day"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nCommemorating the 50th Earth Day\nWednesday
column8: 22 April 2020\nLink copied successfully\nLeading up to this 50th anniversary of Earth Day
column9: Twitter has been working closely with the Earth Day Network to help elevate the efforts and conversation around this global initiative.\nEarth Day Network\u00e2\u0080\u0099s mission is to build the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s largest environmental movement to drive transformative change for people and the planet. They seek to diversify
column10: educate and activate environmentally-conscious people worldwide. At Twitter
column11:
weâre dedicated to supporting their work by democratizing access to information on why the environmental movement is critical to the health of our planet and its people.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The 50th anniversary of Earth Day is a historic milestone. Amid two global threats
column12: climate change and the pandemic
column13: we must stand united as never before. As coronavirus drives us online
column14: social media is more important than ever in connecting people and driving change. With Earth Day Network and Twitter working together
column15: we will use our voices to create the largest
column16:
most diverse online mobilization.
Kathleen Rogers
Earth Day Network CEO
â@KathleenEDNâ
Despite the uniquely challenging circumstances presented by the COVID-19 pandemic
column17: virtual commitments and activations will still be happening to work toward slowing the effects of climate change. Building on our work from last year
column18: the #EarthDay emoji is active to celebrate the work of individuals around the globe who are committed to the cause. We also donated advertising credits again this year through our #AdsForGood program to help amplify the message.\nIn addition to our partnership with the Earth Day Network
column19: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve supported other organizations working to promote environmental conservation and sustainability. Through numerous engagements including events
column20: #AdsForGood grants
column21: on-service support
column22: and trainings
column23: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve helped them use the power of Twitter to amplify their work and raise awareness. These have included the global and/or local chapters of: United Nations (UN) Environment Programme
column24: UN Framework Convention on Climate Change
column25: UN Development Programme
column26: Greenpeace
column27: Voice for the Planet
column28: Let Me Breathe
column29: WWF
column30: 350.org
column31: FridaysForFuture
column32: We Don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t Have Time
column33:
among others.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The fight for the future of our planet has never been more important. On the 50th anniversary of Earth Day
column34: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re thrilled to partner with the Earth Day Network and numerous nonprofit organizations around the globe to elevate the conversation around protecting our planet. At Twitter
column35: we recognize how far we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve come and acknowledge the critical work ahead of us. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to playing our part.\nMonique Meche\nTwitter Vice President
column36: Global Public Policy and Philanthropy\n\u00e2\u0080\u008e@MoniqueMeche\u00e2\u0080\u008e\nAs we mentioned in 2019
column37: our data centers represent an area of opportunity for us to think of our business through the lens of sustainability and to put our dedication into practice. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re continuing to work toward our goal of achieving 100% carbon-neutral power sourcing in our current data centers by the end of 2022. While we work to reach that target
column38: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also offsetting our current carbon emissions through the climate change and environmental nonprofit Cool Effect. Tweeps from around the globe voted last year and we selected three distinct projects as the financial beneficiaries of our offsetting initiatives:\n\u00e2\u0098\u009d\u00ef\u00b8\u008fProtecting Brazil\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Jacund\u00c3\u00a1 Forest Reserve \u00e2\u0080\u0094 This reserve strives to improve conservation of the rainforest while working to protect the livelihoods of those who live and work there.\n\u00e2\u009c\u008c\u00ef\u00b8\u008fTree planting initiatives in India
column39: Kenya
column40: and Uganda \u00e2\u0080\u0094 This project helps small communities replant trees so they can counter the effects of poverty
column41: deforestation
column42: and harmful carbon emissions.\n\u00f0\u009f\u00a4\u009fA biodiversity protection project in Indonesia \u00e2\u0080\u0094 Indonesia is losing forests at the rate of half a million hectares a year
column43: which is one of the highest rates in the world. The Rimba Raya Biodiversity Reserve
column44: the largest REDD+ project in the world
column45: works to preserve these forests and stop development and deforestation.\nOnce again this year
column46: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be building on these partnerships and continuing to support the areas where we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re making the largest sustainability impact.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe made a decision early on for our employees globally to work from home to support efforts to slow the spread of COVID-19. Over the past year
column47: we've also celebrated significant achievements in our Twitter offices and maintained momentum while working remotely.\u00c2\u00a0\nHighlights from our work leading up to the 50th anniversary include:\nOffice Build-Outs: We will continue to work closely with our Real Estate and Workplace team to ensure that we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re retrofitting and installing environmentally-friendly water faucets and achieving at least 95% \u00e2\u0080\u009cGreen Certified\u00e2\u0080\u009d status and using 100% Carbon Neutral Energy in our directly-leased buildings by 2025. To date
column48: 92% of our global office space is Green Building Certified Spaces.\nEnergy: In 2019
column49: Twitter converted 300
column50: 000+ square feet of office space
column51: or roughly 300kWh/mo of standard grid electricity to 100% renewable energy through PG&E\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Solar Choice Program in our San Francisco office.\nSustainability Team: In 2019
column52: Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Real Estate & Workplace team formally developed a Workplace Sustainability Team focusing on implementing sustainability standards and reducing our impact on the environment. This team also created resources for employees to encourage environmentally healthy habits
column53: even as we work from home.\u00c2\u00a0\nPlastic Use: By reducing our single-use plastic consumption
column54: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve effectively removed more than 100
column55: 000+ plastic straws
column57: 000+ plastic toothbrushes
column58: and 35
column59: 000+ single-use plastic beverage bottles from our offices per year.\nRecycled Products: We continue to strive to introduce and increase pre- and post-consumer recycled content in our office supply. In 2019
column60: we introduced 100% recycled content mailer packages in our San Francisco mailroom and are still working toward our goal of utilizing 100% recycled paper products by the end of 2020. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also partnered with TerraCycle in several offices to recycle products that otherwise would not be recyclable through existing municipal systems (i.e.
column61: plastic bags
column62: plastic shipping material
column63: pens
column64: and other writing utensils).\nComposting: We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re actively composting in more than a third of our offices around the world to divert organic waste away from landfills \u00e2\u0080\u0094 we will meet a 50% target in 2021. For example
column65: after introducing this in our Atlanta office in 2019
column66: we were able to divert 244 pounds of organic waste from landfills in less than six months.\u00c2\u00a0\nHow Twitter employees are getting involved We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve created an internal programming to encourage Tweeps to learn
column67: participate in the conversation
column68: and engage in remote volunteer activities to celebrate the day. We also set up a dedicated internal #EarthDay2020 campaign page through our employee donation matching program to support organizations working on environmental conservation and sustainability. Any Twitter employee can donate to relevant nonprofit organizations and Twitter will match donations up to a maximum amount per employee.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhat can you do? From charitable contributions
column69: watching documentaries
column70: and reading scientific material to DIY projects in your community or volunteering your time and talents \u00e2\u0080\u0094 there are a number of ways for people to get involved in Earth Day
column71:
even while we #StayHome.Â 
We encourage you to Tweet using the hashtag #EarthDay to help spread awareness about the 50th-anniversary celebration and let the world know what youâre committed to doing this year to increase environmental sustainability. Itâs on all of us.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

#OnlyOnTwitter

column3: "title": "Protecting and supporting journalists during COVID-19"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Protecting and supporting journalists during COVID-19
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 24 March 2020\nLink copied successfully\nTo see all of the latest steps Twitter is taking in response to COVID-19
column9: visit covid19.twitter.com.\nAll around the world
column10: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen our service connecting people with the authoritative health information they need to protect themselves and their loved ones. That work can only be successful if people have access to the news and information they need.\u00c2\u00a0\nRight now
column11: every journalist is a COVID-19 journalist. From the stories of healthcare workers on the frontlines
column12: to analysis of the real human and economic cost of the pandemic
column13: reporters around the world are still writing
column14: still exposing themselves to harm
column15: still giving us the facts. Journalism is core to our service and we have a deep and enduring responsibility to protect that work. This week we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re contributing to two critical organizations that are working tirelessly to uphold the fundamental values of a free press during this pandemic.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re donating one\u00c2\u00a0million dollars\u00c2\u00a0evenly distributed between the Committee to Protect Journalists and the International Women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Media Foundation. These funds will be used to ensure these organizations can continue their work in the face of new economic strains and to directly support journalists. Their shared efforts to advocate for the rights of vulnerable reporters and to guarantee an equal share of voice for women in the industry has never been more relevant or important.\u00c2\u00a0\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cWe are grateful for Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s generous support. Our efforts at CPJ are focused on ensuring that journalists around the world have the information and resources they need to cover the COVID-19 pandemic safely. And we are pushing back against governments that are censoring the news
column16: and restricting the work of the press. We need timely
column17: accurate information flowing within countries and across borders so that political leaders
column18: health policy experts
column19: and the public at large can make informed decisions at this critical moment.\u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\u0094 Joel Simon
column20: Executive Director
column21: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ).\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cRight now
column22: there is a great need to support our community of journalists covering
column23: and dealing with
column24: this global pandemic. Based on our decades of work with journalists who operate in dangerous and difficult environments
column25: the IWMF understands the critical role that safety and security plays in the industry. Thanks to the incredible support of Twitter
column26: the IWMF will be able to address the needs of our community of journalists more deeply and robustly. By supporting journalists from diverse communities
column27: together we can support the most representative news possible in this evolving time.\u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\u0094 Elisa Lees Mu\u00c3\u00b1oz
column28: Executive Director
column29: International Women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Media Foundation (IWMF).\nCOVID-19 has been with us for months but the power of the virus is now being felt on all corners of the globe. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re witnessing real-time public conversation on an issue that connects us all on a core human level and our purpose has never been stronger. We will continue to work with our partners as the crisis evolves and are grateful for their journalistic leadership and commitment to the power of the pen.\u00c2\u00a0\nFor more
column30: please follow @TwitterForGood
column31: @pressfreedom
column32:
and @IWMF.

          This Tweet is unavailable.
