column3: "title": "The journey to social intelligence"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
The journey to social intelligence
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8:
18 March 2020
Link copied successfully
The journey to social Intelligence
14 years ago (March 21
column9: 2006) Jack Dorsey sent the first Tweet signalling the beginning of a public conversation that has grown to encompass hundreds of millions of people around the world who share their thoughts
column10: experiences and opinions as they happen. Not too long after that first Tweet our first API was launched
column11: giving developers the ability to access and analyze data created from that public conversation. Like Twitter
column12: the impact of social media data analysis has evolved considerably over the years. Today
column13: people are tapping into Twitter data to support a broad array of information needs including measuring content and campaign performance
column14: trend detection
column15: influencer discovery and market research.\nBased on my experience and personal observations working with hundreds of organizations over the years
column16: when it comes to putting this unique data source to work to support better decision-making
column17:
most organizations can be categorized within three stages of social intelligence maturity.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Stage 1 - Emerging (Brand monitoring)
In the first stage of maturity
column18: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s likely to be the marketing and communications teams engaging with social data -\u00c2\u00a0 primarily using social media monitoring tools to track social media content performance and brand mentions for public relations and crisis alerting purposes. In fact
column19: according to Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Social Data Insights Report (based on data from a study commissioned with the Harris Poll)
column20: 9 out of 10 companies use social data for marketing purposes. Metrics such as likes and follows as well as the volume of mentions and associated sentiment are front and center. At this stage
column21: organizations tend to view social data analysis purely through an isolated lens of optimizing their social media campaigns and monitoring brand health. What\u00e2\u0080\u0099s missing is a broader awareness of the value that social data can provide across their organization.\nCompanies at this emerging stage of maturity would benefit from a few simple efforts that could expose the wider business to the value of social insights. \"Oftentimes people have to experience social data for themselves before they really get it
column22: so starting small with a defined project
column23: and sharing relevant insights is key to growing adoption
column24: \" says Jillian Ney
column25:
Founder of The Social Intelligence Lab.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Stage 2 - Established (Social listening)
At the established stage
column26: social media data analysis branches out from the marketing communications function and starts to be viewed as a useful source of consumer insights. It
column27: however
column28: tends to be leveraged in an ad hoc
column29: reactive manner with requests bubbling up from different parts of the business to whoever has access and training on the organization's social listening tool. And due to this lack of clear ownership
column30: organizations are slow to develop competencies in this area and tend to have multiple social media listening and analytics tools which are underutilized or not fit for purpose. And while organizations at this stage are starting to get clear value from social media data
column31:
for the most part it remains a siloed data source not used in conjunction with other research methodologies and/or data sources.
Many organizations at this stage feel they have checked the box of social listening and yet are vastly underutilizing its potential. They would do well to clearly define their social listening objectives and align those with the key questions the business needs answering.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Stage 3 - Innovator (Social intelligence)
An organization becomes an innovator when social media data is viewed as an important and unique source of consumer intelligence
column32: helping to make more informed decisions across their business. As a result
column33: it is embedded into their market research and customer feedback management efforts. In these organizations
column34: you typically find a central analytics or consumer insights team driving cross-functional data analysis efforts that encompass social media data
column35: integrating it with other data sources such as their own 1st party data. These organizations are not only advanced users of their social media listening and analytics tools but are also comfortable working with raw social media data and connecting directly to the social media platforms\u00e2\u0080\u0099 APIs. This allows them to pull social media data into their business intelligence tools to look for patterns and relationships between various data sets. Some may even employ their own approaches to NLP(natural language processing) for topic modelling and sentiment analysis.\nOrganizations at this stage have gone beyond the simple volumetric analysis common of stage two behaviours and strive to understand the context behind social media conversations. Crucially
column36: they understand social media data\u00e2\u0080\u0099s strengths
column37: the questions it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s good at answering and when it should be utilized. Generally speaking
column38:
they excel at social media data analysis because they excel at data analysis and see it as a competitive advantage.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The social intelligence journey
In the fourteen years since Jackâs first tweet
column39: social media data analysis has become an accepted part of consumer research. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not without its challenges and detractors
column40: but remains an incredible realtime source of insight into our moods and mindsets as well as our views on anything and everything from the trendy to the mundane. It is the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s largest focus group
column41: unique in its ability to provide answers to questions we didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t think to ask.\n So regardless of which stage of maturity you currently find yourself
column42: if leveraging this giant focus group called Twitter is important to you
column43: we are here to help. Visit data.twitter.com for social listening case studies
column44: a list of Twitter Official Partners or to get in touch with our team. And if you are interested in social customer care
column45:
check out our maturity model on that specific topic.

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "An update on our continuity strategy during COVID-19"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
An update on our continuity strategy during COVID-19
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 16 March 2020\nLink copied successfully\nEffective November 23
column10:
Twitter is no longer enforcing the COVID-19 misleading information policy.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
To see all of the latest steps Twitter is taking in response to COVID-19
column11: visit covid19.twitter.com.\nUpdated April 1
column12: 2020\nAs the entire world faces an unprecedented public health emergency
column13: we want to be open about the challenges we are facing and the contingency measures we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re putting in place to serve the public conversation at this critical time.\u00c2\u00a0We are regularly working with and looking to trusted partners
column14: including public health authorities
column15: organizations
column16:
and governments to inform our approach.
We will keep three blog posts updated on a rolling basis and encourage everyone to consult with them regularly for updates:Â 
Our contingency strategy to protect the conversation (here)
Our working guidance to our employees and partners to keep them safeÂ 
Our partnerships and public engagement strategies
Steps weâre taking
As we continue to provide guidance to our employees that they must work from home to support self-distancing efforts to slow the spread of COVID-19
column17: we also need to operationally pivot our core efforts to keep people safe on Twitter.\nIncreasing our use of machine learning and automation to take a wide range of actions on potentially abusive and manipulative content. We want to be clear: while we work to ensure our systems are consistent
column18: they can sometimes lack the context that our teams bring
column19: and this may result in us making mistakes. As a result
column20: we will not permanently suspend any accounts based solely on our automated enforcement systems. Instead
column21:
we will continue to look for opportunities to build in human review checks where they will be most impactful. We appreciate your patience as we work to get it right â this is a necessary step to scale our work to protect the conversation on Twitter. 
How are we using automated technology during this time?
To help us review reports more efficiently by surfacing content that's most likely to cause harm and should be reviewed first.
To help us proactively identify rule-breaking content before it's reported. Our systems learn from past decisions by our review teams
column22: so over time
column23: the technology is able to help us rank content or challenge accounts automatically.\nFor content that requires additional context
column24: such as misleading information around COVID-19
column25: our teams will continue to review those reports manually.\nWhat you can expect if you file a report during this time:\nIf you've reported an account or Tweet to us
column26: it will take longer than normal for us to get back to you. We appreciate your patience as we continue to make adjustments.\nBecause these automated systems don't have all of the context and insight our team has
column27: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll make mistakes. If you think we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made a mistake
column28: you can let us know and appeal here.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe appreciate your patience as we work to keep our teams safe
column29: while also making sure we're protecting everyone on Twitter. You can always continue to use hide replies
column30: mute
column31: block
column32: reply filters
column33: and the other tools we offer you to control conversations on the service.\n\u00c2\u00a0\nKeeping the service running and the Tweets flowing is one of our top priorities in these difficult times. Our work has never been more critical and our service has never been in higher demand. In the past few weeks
column34: we have seen more and more people turn to Twitter to participate in the public conversation and follow what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in real time.\nThe global conversation about COVID-19 and ongoing product improvements are driving up total monetizable DAU (mDAU)
column35: with quarter-to-date average total mDAU reaching approximately 164 million
column36: up 23% from 134 million in Q1 2019 and up 8% from 152 million in Q4 2019.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also seen a 45% increase in our curated events page usage and a 30% increase in Direct Message (DM) usage since March 6.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhile many of our teams are transitioning to working from home
column37: some of our infrastructure teams have physical responsibilities that are critical to keeping our data centers
column38: and Twitter
column39: up and running. These teams are operating under the \u00e2\u0080\u009cessential services\u00e2\u0080\u009d provisions dedicated in City
column40: County and State orders to ensure business continuity. We couldn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t keep the Tweets flowing without their daily dedication and hard work.\nThe combination of the new work environment and the increased load on our platform has placed unique stresses on our operations
column41: requiring our engineering teams to work more closely together than ever to respond to new demands
column42: and to plan for the future. From our IT
column43: Network and Product Engineering teams to our infrastructure and data center teams
column44: we have collectively mobilized to ensure we are able to stay safe and productive under the stress of the new levels of traffic we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re seeing on our service.\u00c2\u00a0\nThe effects of COVID-19 on Twitter have already surpassed any event we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen
column45: and it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s possible that as the pandemic continues
column46: we will see additional stress on our service. Beyond Twitter
column47: COVID-19 has also had a far-sweeping impact on our supply chain partners. Whereas normally we'd have months of lead time to add hardware capacity for expected growth
column48: in this case
column49: manufacturing delays in China have compromised the supply chain
column50: resulting in delays in deliveries to our data centers. Our Data Center
column51: SiteOps
column52: Supply Chain
column53: Hardware Engineering and Mission Critical teams continue to manage the physical infrastructure that underlies the service -- expertly innovating to unlock additional capacity in existing supply.\nOur teams are actively addressing areas where we need to add capacity to critical services
column54: looking at how we can optimize existing technology to be more performant
column55: and planning for how we might adjust to the way people are using Twitter during this time.\u00c2\u00a0 \nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s critical for Twitter to stay up and running through this global crisis. Our teams are focused
column56: and as we make changes to our systems to meet these new demands
column57: we will communicate openly. We will share what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve done
column58: what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve learned
column59: and if we see incidents
column60: what we will do to recover as quickly as possible. Follow @TwitterEng to stay up to date.\u00c2\u00a0 \n\u00c2\u00a0\nBroadening our definition of harm to address content that goes directly against guidance from authoritative sources of global and local public health information. Rather than reports
column61: we will enforce this in close coordination with trusted partners
column62: including public health authorities and governments
column63: and continue to use and consult with information from those sources when reviewing content.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to prioritize removing content when it has a clear call to action that could directly pose a risk to people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s health or well-being
column64: but we want to make it clear that we will not be able to take enforcement action on every Tweet that contains incomplete or disputed information about COVID-19. This is not meant to limit good faith discussion or expressing hope about ongoing studies related to potential medical interventions that show promise.\nSince introducing these policies on March 18
column65: we have removed more than 1
column66: 100 tweets containing misleading and potentially harmful content from Twitter. Additionally
column67: our automated systems have challenged more than 1.5 million accounts which were targeting discussions around COVID-19 with spammy or manipulative behaviors. We will continue to use both technology and our teams to help us identify and stop spammy behavior and accounts.\nWe may also apply the public interest notice in cases where world leaders violate the COVID-19 guidelines.\nUnder this guidance
column68: we will require people to remove tweets that include: \nDenial of global or local health authority recommendations to decrease someone\u00e2\u0080\u0099s likelihood of exposure to COVID-19 with the intent to influence people into acting against recommended guidance
column69: such as: \u00e2\u0080\u009csocial distancing is not effective\u00e2\u0080\u009d
column70: or actively encouraging people to not socially distance themselves in areas known to be impacted by COVID-19 where such measures have been recommended by the relevant authorities.\nDescription of alleged cures for. COVID-19
column71: which are not immediately harmful but are known to be ineffective
column72: are not applicable to the COVID-19 context
column73: or are being shared with the intent to mislead others
column74: even if made in jest
column75: such as \u00e2\u0080\u009ccoronavirus is not heat-resistant - walking outside is enough to disinfect you\u00e2\u0080\u009d or \u00e2\u0080\u009cuse aromatherapy and essential oils to cure COVID-19.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nDescription of harmful treatments or protection measures which are known to be ineffective
column76: do not apply to COVID-19
column77: or are being shared out of context to mislead people
column78: even if made in jest
column79: such as \u00e2\u0080\u009cdrinking bleach and ingesting colloidal silver will cure COVID-19.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nDenial of established scientific facts about transmission during the incubation period or transmission guidance from global and local health authorities
column80: such as \u00e2\u0080\u009cCOVID-19 does not infect children because we haven\u00e2\u0080\u0099t seen any cases of children being sick.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nSpecific claims around COVID-19 information that intends to manipulate people into certain behavior for the gain of a third party with a call to action within the claim
column81: such as \u00e2\u0080\u009ccoronavirus is a fraud and not real - go out and patronize your local bar!!\u00e2\u0080\u009d or \u00e2\u0080\u009cthe news about washing your hands is propaganda for soap companies
column82: stop washing your hands\u00e2\u0080\u009d.\nSpecific and unverified claims that incite people to action and cause widespread panic
column84: such as \u00e2\u0080\u009cThe National Guard just announced that no more shipments of food will be arriving for 2 months - run to the grocery store ASAP and buy everything!\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nSpecific and unverified claims made by people impersonating a government or health official or organization such as a parody account of an Italian health official stating that the country\u00e2\u0080\u0099s quarantine is over.\nPropagating false or misleading information around COVID-19 diagnostic criteria or procedures such as \u00e2\u0080\u009cif you can hold your breath for 10 seconds
column85: you do not have coronavirus.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nFalse or misleading claims on how to differentiate between COVID-19 and a different disease
column86: and if that information attempts to definitively diagnose someone
column87: such as \u00e2\u0080\u009cif you have a wet cough
column88: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not coronavirus - but a dry cough is\u00e2\u0080\u009d or \u00e2\u0080\u009cyou\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll feel like you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re drowning in snot if you have coronavirus - it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not a normal runny nose.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nClaims that specific groups
column89: nationalities are never susceptible to COVID-19
column90: such as \u00e2\u0080\u009cpeople with dark skin are immune to COVID-19 due to melanin production\u00e2\u0080\u009d or \u00e2\u0080\u009creading the Quran will make an individual immune to COVID-19.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nClaims that specific groups
column91: nationalities are more susceptible to COVID-19
column92: such as \u00e2\u0080\u009cavoid businesses owned by Chinese people as they are more likely to have COVID-19.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\n\u00c2\u00a0\nBuilding systems that enable our team to continue to enforce our rules remotely around the world. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also increasing our employee assistance and wellness support for everyone involved in this critical work
column93: and ensuring people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s privacy and security stay a top priority.\u00c2\u00a0\nInstituting a global content severity triage system so we are prioritizing the potential rule violations that present the biggest risk of harm and reducing the burden on people to report them.\nExecuting daily quality assurance checks on our content enforcement processes to ensure we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re agile in responding to this rapidly evolving
column94:
global disease outbreak.
Engaging with our partners around the world to ensure escalation paths remain open and urgent cases can be brought to our attention.
Continuing to reviewÂ the Twitter Rules in the context of COVID-19 and considering ways in which they may need to evolve to account for new behaviors.
As weâve said on many occasions
column95: our approach to protecting the public conversation is never static. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s particularly relevant in these unprecedented times. We intend to review our thinking daily and will ensure we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sharing updates here on any new clarifications to our rules or major changes to how we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re enforcing them.\u00c2\u00a0\nFinally
column96: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re encouraged that our service is being used around the world to provide free
column97: authoritative health information
column98: and to ensure that everyone has access to the conversations they need to protect themselves and their families. For more
column99: our dedicated COVID-19 Event\u00c2\u00a0page has the latest facts right at the top of your timeline
column100:
and weâll continue to share updates @TwitterSafety and @TwitterSupport.

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Brand communications in time of crisis"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Brand communications in time of crisis
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 11 March 2020\nLink copied successfully\nUpdated April 2
column9: 2020\nTo see all of the latest steps Twitter is taking in response to COVID-19
column10: visit covid19.twitter.com.\nSince the emergence and subsequent outbreak of COVID-19
column11: there have been millions of Tweets and Retweets about the virus around the globe. We are seeing a COVID-19 related Tweet every 45 milliseconds and #Coronavirus is now the second most used hashtag of 2020. These volumes reflect the huge appetite for seeing and sharing news and information related to this virus as it unfolds.\u00c2\u00a0\nThere\u00e2\u0080\u0099s no doubt about it
column12: what we are facing is unprecedented. This is global
column13: this is open-ended
column14: and this could affect every brand
column15: every business
column16: and every individual. In times of crisis
column17: people look to leaders and institutions for guidance
column18: reassurance and information. Increasingly
column19: they also look to businesses.\nLet\u00e2\u0080\u0099s be clear. This is not a \"marketing opportunity\" to capitalise on
column20: and we do not recommend brands opportunistically linking themselves to a health scare. However
column21: we want to recognise that this is a new reality and requires thoughtful navigation
column22: from all of us.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe also know that Twitter is a platform that plays a significant role in crisis communications
column23: and can be a powerful tool for you to communicate with your customers
column24: employees
column25: and the broader ecosystem at times like this. So while this is not a typical crisis
column26:
weâd like to share the advice we give in difficult circumstances.
Whatâs appropriate for my brand right now?
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Know your brand.Â 
This is not about looking at what others are doing and copying. Itâs about understanding the unique role your brand plays in peopleâs lives
column27: how that has changed
column28: and how your brand can help or be useful during this crisis. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s also about looking for opportunities to lead by example
column29: and do the right thing
column30:
where it makes sense for your business.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Keep up to date with whatâs happening.Â 
Things are changing fast
column31: what might have felt like a good message yesterday might not be the right thing today. Keep a close eye on the news and conversation
column32: and be sure to consider the context before replying or broadcasting. And note
column33: sometimes it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s better not to say anything at all. \nWhen using Twitter
column34:
youâll notice we have a prompt in place which directs people searching for Coronavirus content to accurate information from the relevant local bodies (e.g. CDC ). This is running in 64 countries and in 20 languages. We are also pushing the most important content to the top of our search results and in your home timelines.Â  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Be thoughtful about tone of voice.Â 
Just like people
column35: brands should evolve their tone depending on the context. Right now might not be the best time to be snarky or sarcastic
column36: while empathy
column37: understanding and even certain types of humour may go a long way.\nOne of the most shared COVID-19 related Tweets
column38: speaks well to the importance of tone
column39: as Kumail Nanjiani reminds people to think of others who may be more vulnerable to this virus. How do you get this right? The best way is by listening to what people
column40: and your customers
column41: are saying \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and reflecting that in your copy and tone appropriately. \nAnticipate changes in your customer\u00e2\u0080\u0099s behaviour.\nAs people are potentially asked to self-isolate
column42: or stay home
column43: there will be a number of behaviour changes that might impact their needs as well as how they interact with your business.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve already seen the release of James Bond pushed back from April to November
column44: in an effort to avoid a major global release when people are social distancing. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also seen airlines offer flexible tickets
column45: at no added cost
column46:
to reflect the realities of travel right now.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
There are other consumer behaviour changes we can anticipate from China:
Increased shift to e-commerce. For retail brands
column47: get ahead of this by ensuring you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re prepared to support the changing customer needs and connection points.\nSignificant boom in live-streaming. As events were cancelled and retail stores were closed in China
column48: people and businesses took to live-streaming. Knowing this may happen elsewhere
column49: think about how going live could help you extend planned live events (without attendees present)
column50:
or connect with your customers.Â Check out Twitter Media to learn more about how our live brand studio can help.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
What might people need right now?
Below are the types of things we see people seek out in times of crisis
column51: and might be especially relevant right now. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re not saying you should do any or all of this
column52: but these are some need states that you might want to think about. \nAccurate & Reliable Information.\nIn times of crises
column53: people want credible information. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen that verified people on Twitter are about 2.4x more likely to participate in COVID-19 conversation than non-verified people
column54: and 75% of COVID-19 related Tweets are actually Retweets. In other words
column55: the primary method of sharing information during a time of crisis is through Retweeting.\nIf you have useful and reliable information that might help people navigate the uncertainty
column56: or keep people calm
column57: you should share it. For example
column58: retail/e-commerce brands can keep the public updated on stock to help mitigate panic buying. If you have important information that affects your company
column59: or your employees (e.g. around transmission of the virus)
column60:
you may want to consider sharing that publicly.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
When it comes to setting policies and supporting your employees through this uncertain period
column61:
there is truly an opportunity to lead by example and get others to follow in your steps.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Customer Service & Support.
Inevitably
column62: some brands are immediately more impacted by COVID-19
column63: due to the nature of their business. Travel (Airline/Cruises/Hospitality/Tourism) and Finance Institutions are seeing the strongest associations with COVID-19 so far.  \nIf COVID-19 is directly affecting your business and your customers
column64: use Twitter to interact 1:1 with your customers and support them
column65:
and to broadcast any initiatives youâre launching that widely address the issue.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Itâs important to listen and understand the concerns your customers have and to address them
column66: as best you can. Demonstrating you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re doing your best in uncertain times
column67: can go a long way. If you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re not directly affected
column68: but have something meaningful to offer (that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s true to your brand)
column69: consider sharing. For example
column70: health/wellbeing tips
column71:
meditation/calming content.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Distraction & Levity.Â 
In times like this
column72: when the newscycle can be overwhelming
column73:
a bit of light distraction and entertainment can go a long way.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Â The reality is that the average Twitter timeline is a mix of news
column74: information and interests. In fact
column75: since January 1st
column76: COVID-19 related Tweets only represent 1% of total Tweets that have been sent on Twitter. \nIn other words
column77: people on Twitter are switching between updates on COVID-19
column78: while following elections
column79: news
column80: sports
column81: TV & entertainment
column82: and everyday lols. So long as you are thoughtful with copy and tone
column84: and remember it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s better to stay in your lane and be true to your brand than to associate with the virus. \nCommunity & Positivity.\nAs humans
column85: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re programmed to seek out connection. While social distancing measures offer protection and security
column86: they come with significant impact on individuals
column87: communities and the world at large. In the face of home quarantining
column88: we witnessed beautiful moments of connection emerge from China
column89: showing the importance of positivity and connection right now. \nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also seen non-COVID-19 related positive stories capture people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s attention
column90: because good things continue to happen
column91: despite the context right now. Brands should continue to connect with and celebrate these moments
column92: as and when appropriate. This could apply to events
column93: trends and occasions from #IWD2020 to sports
column94:
TV premieres and culture.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
What is Twitter's policy for ad campaigns related to COVID-19?
Twitter permits explicit or implicit reference to COVID-19 only if the campaign is related to adjustments to business practices
column95: and/or support for their customers and employees in the wake of COVID-19. Note that this policy only applies to managed advertisers; self serve advertisers are still prohibited from including any references to COVID-19. Twitter also prohibits the targeting of keywords related to COVID-19
column96: with no exceptions.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nTwitter permits Public Service Announcements (PSA\u00e2\u0080\u0099s) from government and supranational entities
column97: news outlets that currently hold a political content exemption certification
column98: and some vetted organizations who have a current partnership with the Twitter Policy team.\u00c2\u00a0\nIf you are thinking of running a campaign prompted by
column99: or related to COVID-19
column100: we recommend you read Twitter Ads policies
column101: specifically the Inappropriate Content Policy
column102:
before building any advertising campaigns.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
To get you started on how to communicate during this time
column103: here are a few questions to ask yourself:\u00c2\u00a0Can you share positive stories that might uplift the people who connect with your brand on Twitter? Do you have positive initiatives that you can talk about? Can you bring your community on Twitter together
column104:
in a positive way?

column3: "title": "Inclusion & Diversity Report March 2020"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nInclusion & Diversity Report March 2020\nWednesday
column8: 11 March 2020\nLink copied successfully\nAt Twitter
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re using the new decade as an opportunity to refresh our approach to our public conversation around inclusion and diversity.\nBut first
column10: let\u00e2\u0080\u0099s take a look at highlights from 2019:*\nTotal representation of women
column11:
Black and Latinx Tweeps increased
47.1% of new hires were women; up 1.4 percentage points from last year
15.7% of US new hires were Black or Latinx; up 3.4 percentage points from last year
1 in 3 Tweeps participate in at least one Business Resource Group
All of these gains were made during a time of rapid global expansion at Twitter
column12: making progress especially meaningful.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur sights on the horizon We kicked off 2020 in Houston at #OneTeam
column13: where we brought our entire company together in one place
column14: with the goal of continuing to build a diverse and global team with a shared vision of serving the public conversation.\nWe make this investment in our Tweeps because they are the most important stakeholders in our work. Without Tweeps
column15: there is no Twitter. Like many company all-hands
column16: #OneTeam was an opportunity to come together
column17: connect
column18: and align around our strategic priorities. Because we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re Twitter
column19: it was so much more. But don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t take our word for it
column20:
check out this thread from a Tweep who was there:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Why Houston? We saw an opportunity to have a real-world connection with a city that has been at the center of some incredible conversations on our service â like during #HurricaneHarvey. Twitter empowered first responders and community volunteers to come to the aid of stranded residents as flood waters rose. #OneTeam enabled us to make even deeper investments in the Houston community.
Our central organizing principle: âpurpose before profit
column21: \u00e2\u0080\u009d an acknowledgement that by focusing on our mission and our customers
column22: we will unlock long-term durable impact and opportunity. Over the course of three days
column23: we deeply explored what it means to truly serve the public conversation and directly heard from our global customers about the role our service plays in their lives\u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00e2\u0080\u0093and the world.\nWe also meditated
column24: volunteered across 49 local nonprofits
column25:
and shared an inspirational new vision for the future of diversity and inclusion at Twitter.Â 
Our vision for the future Weâre on a journey to be the worldâs most diverse and inclusive tech company. We used the start of a new decade to lay down a roadmap of what it will take to get there.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Our efforts were informed by the appreciation that there is no other company whose product plays the role in the world that ours does. That means the stakes are incredibly high and we donât have the luxury of time or incrementalism. We have a unique responsibility to be bold
column26: move fast\u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00e2\u0080\u0093and get this right.\nWe started with two questions: 1) What would it take to realize this vision? and 2) How long would it take to get there? We studied our peers in tech
column27: evaluated industry benchmarks
column28: and took a close look within the company. Here\u00e2\u0080\u0099s where our work led us:\nWhile women currently make up 42.5% of our workforce
column29: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committing that by 2025
column30: at least half of our global workforce will be women. We want women to be represented across our global business
column31: so we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also set targets for representation across technical roles (42%) and leadership (41%).\nThis is an ambitious goal and timeline
column32:
but one we can and must achieve together.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâre also setting bold new targets for the United States
column33: where the federal government allows for more categorization of our workforce. By 2025
column34: our commitment is that at least a quarter of our US workforce to be under-represented minorities; specifically Black
column35: Latinx
column36: Native American
column37: Alaskan or Hawaiian/Pacific Islander
column38: or Multiracial. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re currently at 14.8%. And
column39: for the first time later this year
column40: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll publicly report our progress on workforce representation of military veterans
column41: LGBTQ people
column42:
and people with disabilities. These efforts reflect the more inclusive approach weâre taking in cultivating a truly diverse US workforce.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Why set targets? We set goals for things that are importantââand diversity and inclusion has never been more important at Twitter. While goal setting has been a point of controversy in diversity and inclusion
column43: we know representation targets work
column44: because we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen it in action.\nThe introduction of workforce representation targets were a catalyst to increased investment
column45: organizational alignment
column46: transparency and accountability. Most importantly
column47: they helped drive progress: Since workforce representation targets were introduced in 2018
column48: our global representation of women has increased 4.1 percentage points
column49: and in the United States representation of Black and Latinx Tweeps has increased by 2.4 percentage points and 1.5 percentage points
column50: respectively. During the same period
column51: Twitter was expanding rapidly
column52: making this growth especially meaningful.\nOur journey together The path forward involves everyone. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re doubling down on investments that reach Tweeps around the world. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re launching an Inclusive Hiring Program to drive global progress in workforce representation. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re leveraging the momentum from investments in our global Business Resource Groups to introduce an Allyship Program with the goal of bringing our BRGs closer to the business and drive belonging. And
column53: our Supplier Inclusion Program is expanding its focus to include more communities and regions.\u00c2\u00a0\nOver the next three quarters
column54: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll use this forum to share insights and take a closer look at specific initiatives that are helping us break new ground
column55: while providing quarterly updates on our numbers here. At year end
column56: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll share a comprehensive report on all the activities that contributed to our progress in 2020.\u00c2\u00a0\nRadical transparency drives accountability\u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00e2\u0080\u0093to each other and all of you. We encourage you to follow our progress and let us know what you think. What do you want to hear from us in the year ahead?\nWe look forward to the ongoing conversation
column57:
because weâre all in this together #UntilWeAllBelong.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
*Data Notes: All data is based on employee self-identification. Gender is global. Race / Ethnicity is US-based. Workforce data includes regular full-time employees. New hire data includes regular
column58: full-time employees who started within 12 months of the data effective date. Leadership includes Directors and above. Technical is our functional designation and omits G&A and sales designations. Data effective dates: comparison of 2018 (Dec 31
column60: 2018) for new hires in the beginning summary
column61: current standing for women
column62: US Black
column63: and US Latinx (as of Jan 31
column65: and growth metrics since 2018 (Dec 31
column66: 2017) compared to current standing (as of Jan 31
column67:
2020).

column3: "title": "Our #DataForGood partnership with New Zealand's NCPACS"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Our #DataForGood partnership with New Zealand's NCPACS
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 11 March 2020\nLink copied successfully\nAt Twitter
column9: our purpose is to serve public conversation around the world. With world leaders
column10: advocates
column11: journalists
column12: academics
column13: and nonprofits on the service
column14: we seek to empower conversations that are influential and leave a lasting impact on society. It is a company priority to increase the health
column15: openness
column16: and civility of this uniquely open conversation.\nIn a New Zealand first through our #DataforGood program
column17: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re announcing a partnership with the University of Otago\u00e2\u0080\u0099s National Centre for Peace and Conflict Studies (@NCPACS). Our shared goal is to use Twitter data to study the ways online conversations can be used to promote tolerance and inclusion instead of division and exclusion. The initiative will be led by Emeritus Professor Kevin Clements (@kpclements) and lead researcher Sanjana Hattotuwa (@sanjanah).\nNCPACS was established in 2009 as New Zealand\u00e2\u0080\u0099s first Centre to combine global interdisciplinary expertise on the issues of development
column18: peace-building
column19: and conflict transformation. Located within the University of Otago\u00e2\u0080\u0099s (@otago) Division of Humanities
column20: it has since made significant contributions to emergent research areas and holds regular conferences promoting research and intercommunity dialogue.\nIn the aftermath of the horrific Christchurch terror attacks on 15 March 2019
column21: Twitter and NCPACS embarked on a joint research project aimed at analysing the ways in which Twitter and social media more broadly was used for both positive and negative purposes.\u00c2\u00a0\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cThe project is a wonderful example of the way in which Twitter is working with governments
column22: other companies and organisations
column23: to ensure that its service is not abused by those promoting polarisation
column24: hate language
column25: and violence
column26: \u00e2\u0080\u009d said Emeritus Professor Kevin Clements
column27: former Foundation Chair of Peace and Conflict Studies
column28: Founding Director of the NCPACS
column29: and Secretary General of the International Peace Research Association.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cWhile the initial prompt for this joint research project came from the 15 March 2019 Christchurch massacre
column30: there have been numerous examples of digitally amplified polarisation around the world. The challenge is how to understand the ways in which social media can be used to promote tolerance and inclusion instead of division and exclusion.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cUnder the aegis of Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s global #DataforGood initiative
column31: NCPACS received a data grant that enables our Centre and our dedicated researchers to explore in depth the events
column32: conversations
column33: and topics on Twitter with the hope and expectation that our work may inform strong policy outcomes
column34: inspire others who are tackling similar issues around the world
column35: and promote the place and role for new partnerships as we work together to solve the rapidly evolving challenges of polarised communities and identities offline and online.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nLead researcher and Ph.D. candidate at the NCPACS
column36: Sanjana Hattotuwa
column37: has extensive experience living in and responding to violent conflict and has made\u00c2\u00a0 significant studies of social media to determine how online communications activate positive and negative responses from a wider public. He has done this work in Sri Lanka
column38: Myanmar
column39: and after the Christchurch massacre in 2019
column40: in New Zealand.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cThis research is extremely important in helping us understand the ways in which narratives are produced
column41: promoted and engaged with to generate or stymie altruistic behaviour
column42: \u00e2\u0080\u009d Mr Hattotuwa explained.\u00c2\u00a0\nMr. Hattotuwa conducted preliminary research just a week after the Christchurch massacre. By using data generated from tens of thousands of public Tweets anchored to the violence
column43: he discovered a local and global outpouring of support for victims
column44: solidarity with the citizens of New Zealand
column45: the affirmation of democratic ideals
column46: pushback against terrorism
column47: and unequivocal condemnation of the perpetrator.\u00c2\u00a0\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cI was surprised by the volume of Tweets with just five hashtags (#christchurchmosqueshooting
column48: #christchurchshooting
column49: #christchurchterroristattack
column50: #newzealandterroristattack and #christchurch) generating around 85
column51: 000 Tweets in the immediate 24-hour period after the attack.\u00c2\u00a0 Another two hashtags pegged to the number of victims at the time (#49lives) and a message of solidarity (#theyareus) emerged the day after
column52: generating 37
column53: 000 more Tweets.\u00c2\u00a0\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cIn Urdu and Hindi
column54: from Pakistan to India
column55: as well as the New Zealand Prime Minister\u00e2\u0080\u0099s own responses on Twitter in English
column56: the most viral Tweets at the time featured content and conversations condemning the massacre\u00e2\u0080\u009d noted Mr. Hattotuwa. \u00e2\u0080\u009cA Tweet by Prime Minister Jacinda Arden (@jacindaardern) was liked over 135
column57: 000 times and Retweeted over 38
column58:
000 times just five days after the massacre.â
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We are optimistic the research will not only demonstrate key dynamics of different communication patterns prior to the Christchurch massacre
column59: but will also enable us to better understand ways in which differences get turned into polarised
column60: and ultimately
column61: toxic divisions. This will be helpful for all those involved in the Christchurch Call
column62: as well as other forums studying these topics.\nWe believe in the power of the public conversation to heal wounds and to build enduring
column63: peaceful communities.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn tandem with our multilateral efforts with industry and as signatories to the Christchurch Call to Action
column64: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been resolutely focused on the ways Twitter can tackle extremism while promoting dialogue and inter-community understanding. Our goal is to harness the unique power of our service by providing data that empowers research
column65: and hopefully gain a better understanding of the risks and the opportunities available through fostering an open
column66: public conversation. Under the academic leadership of the University of Otago
column67: Emeritus Professor Kevin Clements
column68: and Sanjana Hattotuwa
column69: we want to listen
column70: learn
column71: and put their insights into action.\nFor more updates
column72: follow @Policy
column73:
the global voice of Twitterâs Public Policy team. 
Â

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Stepping up our work to protect the public conversation around Covid-19"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Stepping up our work to protect the public conversation around Covid-19
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 4 March 2020\nLink copied successfully\nWe recently revised our travel policy to ensure we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re playing our part in the global containment efforts relating to coronavirus (Covid-19). In tandem
column9: our entire company is stepping up its internal and external efforts to build partnerships
column10: protect the public conversation
column11: help people find authoritative health information
column12: raise relief funds
column13: and contribute pro bono advertising support to ensure people are getting the right message
column14: from the right source.\u00c2\u00a0\nWith a critical mass of expert organizations
column15: official government accounts
column16: health professionals
column17: and epidemiologists on our service
column18: our goal is to elevate and amplify authoritative health information as far as possible.\nGlobal expansion of the Covid-19 search prompt\u00c2\u00a0 Launched six days before the official designation of the virus in January
column19: we continue to expand our dedicated search prompt feature to ensure that when you come to the service for information about Covid-19
column20: you are met with credible
column21: authoritative content at the top of your search experience. We have been consistently monitoring the conversation on the service to make sure keywords \u00e2\u0080\u0094 including common misspellings \u00e2\u0080\u0094 also generate the search prompt.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn each country where we have launched the initiative
column22: we have partnered with the national public health agency or the World Health Organization (@WHO) directly. The proactive search prompt is in place with official local partnerships in over 70 countries around the world.\nThey include:\u00c2\u00a0Australia
column23: Austria
column24: Belgium
column25: Brazil
column26: Brunei
column27: Cambodia
column28: Canada
column29: Cyprus
column30: Denmark
column31: Egypt
column32: Estonia
column33: Finland
column34: France
column35: Germany
column36: Hong Kong
column37: Iceland
column38: India
column39: Indonesia
column40: Ireland
column41: Italy
column42: Japan
column43: Jordan
column44: Korea
column45: Laos
column46: Latvia
column47: Lebanon
column48: Malaysia
column49: Mongolia
column50: Myanmar
column51: Netherlands
column52: New Zealand
column53: Norway
column54: Paraguay
column55: Philippines
column56: Poland
column57: Singapore
column58: Spain
column59: Sri Lanka
column60: Sudan
column61: Sweden
column62: Switzerland
column63: Taiwan
column64: Thailand
column65: Turkey
column66: United Kingdom
column67: United States
column68: Uruguay
column69: Vietnam
column70: and Yemen.\nProtecting the conversation The power of a uniquely open service during a public health emergency is clear. The speed and borderless nature of Twitter presents an extraordinary opportunity to get the word out and ensure people have access to the latest information from expert sources around the world.\nTo support that mission
column71: our global Trust & Safety team is continuing its zero-tolerance approach to platform manipulation and any other attempts to abuse our service at this critical juncture. At present
column72: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re not seeing significant coordinated platform manipulation efforts around these issues. However
column73: we will remain vigilant and have invested substantially in our proactive abilities to ensure trends
column74: search
column75: and other common areas of the service are protected from malicious behaviors. As ever
column76: we also welcome constructive and open information sharing from governments and academics to further our work in these areas \u00e2\u0080\u0094 we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re in this together.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe have also ensured the Events feature contains credible information about Covid-19 and is available at the top of the home timeline for everyone in Japan
column77: South Korea
column78: Australia
column79: Argentina
column80: Brazil
column81: Canada
column82: Colombia
column84: \u00c2\u00a0France
column86: India
column87: Ireland
column88: \u00c2\u00a0Italy
column89: Mexico
column90: New Zealand
column92: Spain
column93: the UAE
column94: the UK and the US.\n#AdsForGood support & additional protections Based on our Inappropriate Content Policy
column95: we will halt any attempt by advertisers to opportunistically use the Covid-19 outbreak to target inappropriate ads. Government entities that want to disseminate public health information will be permitted to promote ads on Covid-19. In the case of Covid-19
column96: we have put additional safeguards into place in order to facilitate the sharing of trusted public health information and to reduce potential harm to users. We are currently prohibiting the promotion of all medical masks\u00c2\u00a0and alcohol hand sanitizers due to strong correlation to Covid-19 and instances of inflated prices globally.\nIn addition
column97: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committing Ads for Good credits to nonprofit organizations to ensure they can build campaigns to fact-check and get reputable health information to the widest possible audiences. For example
column98: as part of the International Fact-Checking Network (IFCN/@factchecknet)
column99: we have supported the Spanish organization @maldita_es and @malditobulo
column100: which focuses on mitigating the impact of disinformation on public discourse through fact-checking and data journalism techniques. In Asia
column101: we have partnered with the Taiwan Fact Checking Center (@taiwantfc)
column102: which has been using Twitter to connect with IFCN fact checkers around the world via #CoronavirusFacts. They are working in real-time to find credible information and debunk rumors in Chinese.\nFurthering our partnerships\u00c2\u00a0 Our Global Public Policy team has open lines of communication with relevant multinational stakeholders
column103: including the World Health Organization
column104: numerous global government and public health organizations
column105: and officials around the world
column106: to ensure they can troubleshoot account issues
column107: get their experts verified
column108: and seek strategic counsel as they use the power of Twitter to mitigate harm.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also in close contact with our industry peers and will attend all relevant cross-functional meetings. As a uniquely open service
column109: our data is being used in research every day and our researchers hub is publicly available. We welcome applications for the use of Twitter data to support research on Covid-19. We will also explore further #DataForGood partnerships to assess how our data products can enhance academic and NGO understanding of public health emergencies now and into the future.\u00c2\u00a0\nPlaying our part through donation matching\u00c2\u00a0 We've set up a dedicated internal Covid-19 campaign page through our employee donation matching program to support humanitarian response and relief efforts around the world. Any Twitter employee can donate to relevant nonprofit organizations
column110: and Twitter will match donations up to $2
column111: 000 per employee.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhat can you do?\u00c2\u00a0 Looking for advice on how best to use Twitter in a time like this? Follow @WHO and your local health ministry \u00e2\u0080\u0094 seek out the authoritative health information and ignore the noise. See something suspicious or abusive
column112: report it to us immediately. Most importantly
column113: think before you Tweet. Through Twitter Moments
column114: we have curated longer-form content that helps tell the full story of what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening around Covid-19 globally. For educators and parents
column116: which was built in partnership with @UNESCO
column117: here.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re absolutely committed to playing our part and will continue to provide substantive updates as this situation evolves. For more
column118:
follow @TwitterSafety and @Policy.

column3: "title": "Why business IQ is not enough in the era of the relationship economy"
column7:
"post_text": "highTint
Insights
Why business IQ is not enough in the era of the relationship economy
                By
                
  
  
Friday
column8:
14 February 2020
Link copied successfully
Why business IQ is not enough in the era of the relationship economy
Originally coined in the 1960âs
column9: the term \u00e2\u0080\u009cemotional intelligence\u00e2\u0080\u009d (EQ) hit the mainstream when it became the topic (and title) of a 1995 best selling book by author and science journalist David Goleman. Goleman\u00e2\u0080\u0099s in-depth review of research on the human brain and human behavior led him to the conclusion that cognitive intelligence alone is not a reliable predictor of future success in life and business. Rather it is emotional intelligence that plays a major role in determining success in life.1 This (at the time) relatively new way of looking at people and success has since gained wide acceptance and EQ has become highly valued within the workplace and beyond.\nTwenty-five years later
column10: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s hard not to draw parallels with a shift happening in the business world. Thanks to technology and global connectivity
column11: cultural
column12: language and geographic barriers to information flow and communication have all but disappeared. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s great news for consumers as it means more choice than ever before. But for businesses it means competition is at an all-time high and relying on status quo business IQ \u00e2\u0080\u0093 price
column13: product and distribution - is no longer enough.\u00c2\u00a0\nWelcome to the Relationship Economy\nWelcome to the relationship economy - where customer experiences and brand loyalty (business EQ) reign supreme. As Forrester puts it
column14: \u00e2\u0080\u009cCompetitive strategy can no longer rely on strength of manufacturing
column15: distribution
column16: or information. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s the Age of Customer and Forrester\u00e2\u0080\u0099s data proves that the right Customer Experience is the only way to significantly differentiate\u00e2\u0080\u009d.2\nEmotional Intelligence and Business\nSo
column17: what does EQ mean when it comes to business? Much like the original ideas espoused by Goleman
column18: businesses would do well to better understand the feelings
column19: motivations and emotions of their customers and then use that insight to guide their actions.\u00c2\u00a0\nFor their part
column20: customers want more than a transaction. They are looking for everything you would expect from a relationship - alignment of values
column21: trust
column22: personalization
column23: exceptional service and open dialogue. And
column24: for better or worse
column25: consumers today are less loyal and quick to switch should the relationship sour. According to the American Express 2017 Customer Service Barometer
column26: more than half of Americans have scrapped a planned purchase or transaction because of bad service
column27: and 33 percent say they\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll consider switching companies after just a single instance of poor service.\nIf business EQ is the secret ingredient of meaningful
column28: lasting and mutually beneficial relationships
column29: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s critical that businesses be attuned to their customers by gathering emotional intelligence in real-time
column30: continuously. They need to be able to pick up signals before things turn bad or identify things that work well and do more of them. There is one place where consumers are freely sharing their emotions
column31: unprompted
column32: in the moment. Every minute of every day
column33: people around the world are sharing their thoughts
column34: experiences and opinions as they happen on Twitter. Social listening helps tap into these insights
column35: allowing businesses to sharpen their customer EQ and act in the best interest of the relationship.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nReady to improve your business\u00e2\u0080\u0099s emotional intelligence? Get inspired at data.twitter.com.\n1 Daniel Goleman
column36: Emotional Intelligence: Why it can matter more than IQ
column38:
Bantam Books 2 Forrester. (2017). Why and how to lead a CX transformation. Available at: https://www.forrester.com/report/Why+And+How+To+Lead+A+CX+Transformation/-/E-RES137883

column3: "title": "US Census search prompt launch & efforts to support Census conversations"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
US Census search prompt launch & efforts to support Census conversations
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 11 February 2020\nLink copied successfully\nEnsuring the public can find information from authoritative sources is a key aspect of our commitment to serve the public conversation on Twitter. This year
column9: the United States Census Bureau will conduct its decennial Census
column10: deploying resources across the country to ensure an accurate count of people living in the US. Statistics gathered by the Census are used to determine the number of seats each state holds in the U.S. House of Representatives and inform how state
column11: local
column12:
and federal lawmakers will allocate billions of dollars in funds to local communities each year for the next decade.
Direct engagement with the Census Bureau and key stakeholders Our outreach and close partnership with Census officials has driven our approach to keeping the conversation healthy. We partnered with the US Census Bureau in November 2019 to host a training at TwitterDC with more than 30 civil society partners in attendance that learned about Twitter's civic integrity policies and best practice content tactics. Weâve hosted a multitude of similar trainings and educational sessions for nonprofit organizations that will deploy resources to support the Census.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The Census Bureau is glad to have the help of our 2020 Census partners and technology platforms in the fight against misinformation and disinformation. There's still work to be done and we need everyone's help in reporting content intended to affect the accuracy and completeness of the count.
Ron Jarmin
US Census Bureau Deputy Director and COO
â@uscensusbureauâ
Twitter is also a founding member of the Civic Alliance
column13: a nonpartisan group of businesses working together to increase civic involvement. The coalition will specifically focus on supporting participation in the Census.\nHere\u00e2\u0080\u0099s what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re doing to protect the Twitter conversation related to the #2020Census:\u00c2\u00a0\nDedicated Census search prompt We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve partnered with the US Census Bureau to launch a new tool so when someone searches for certain keywords associated with the Census
column14: a prompt will direct individuals to the official Census site: https://2020Census.gov. This website provides clear information on the 2020 Census
column15: how to participate
column16:
and how the Census process will safeguard individual privacy and security.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
This search prompt is available on iOS
column17: Android
column18: and mobile.twitter.com in the United States. This is an expansion of our #KnowTheFacts prompt
column19: which we specifically put in place for the public to find clear
column20: credible information on critical issues.\nAs of March 19
column21: the search prompt is available in English
column22: Spanish
column23: and 11 additional languages including: Chinese (simplified)
column24: Vietnamese
column25: Korean
column26: Russian
column27: Arabic
column28: Tagalog
column29: Polish
column30: French
column31: Haitian Creole
column32: Portuguese
column33: and Japanese.\u00c2\u00a0\nExpanding policy enforcement to protect the Census conversation Additionally
column34: as part of our company-wide efforts to fight misinformation regarding participation in civic events
column35: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re applying our existing election integrity policy to Census-related content to make certain the Census conversation on Twitter remains healthy.\nAhead of key moments in the 2020 US election
column36: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve turned on a tool that enables people to report misleading information about how to participate in an election or other civic event. It is against the Twitter Rules to share false or misleading information about how to participate in an election or other civic event. This tool helps us identify and remove misinformation that could suppress turnout for events such as the US Census and elections around the globe.\u00c2\u00a0\nFor updates on this work
column37: follow @TwitterGov and @Policy.\nUpdated on March 19
column38: 2020 \u00e2\u0080\u0094 The search prompt expanded from English and Spanish to also include the following languages: Chinese (simplified)

column40: Korean

column3: "title": "#SaferInternetDay 2020: Creating a better internet for all"
column7:
"post_text": "Events
#SaferInternetDay 2020: Creating a better internet for all
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 11 February 2020\nLink copied successfully\nThe first Safer Internet Day was held in 2004 \u00e2\u0080\u0094 2 years before Twitter was born. Now
column9: 16 years on
column10: we are delighted to be working with partners all over the world to mark #SaferInternetDay2020 and play our part in shaping a better internet for all.\nOver the past 12 months
column11: we have made substantial strides in tackling abusive content on our service globally. There will always be more to do
column12: but we have made meaningful progress. Key highlights include:\nMore than 1 in 2 of Tweets we take action on for abuse are now proactively surfaced using technology
column13: rather than relying on reports to Twitter - this compares to 1 in 5 tweets in 2018;\nWe have seen a 105% increase in accounts actioned by Twitter (locked or suspended for violating the Twitter Rules);\nIn November 2019
column14: we launched the option globally for users to hide replies to their Tweets \u00e2\u0080\u0094 now anyone can choose to hide replies to their Tweets;\nIn December 2019
column15: we expanded and diversified our Trust and Safety Council
column16: which brings together experts and organizations from around the world to help advise us as we develop our products
column17: programs and the Twitter Rules;\nLast Tuesday
column18: we announced a new rule to address synthetic & manipulated media. From 5 March
column19:
we will start labeling Tweets if we believe that media shared within them have been significantly and deceptively altered or fabricated. Labels will link to a Twitter moment to provide additional context from reputable sources on the content in question.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Making Twitter safer is not a job we can do alone â which is why itâs so important to us
column20: to participate in #SaferInternetDay2020. Across the world today and throughout February
column21: we are working with our network of safety partners to amplify their guidance
column22: provide Ads for Good grants to support their campaigns
column23: and collaborating on what we can all do create a better Internet. We are running safety training and delivering presentations on our work across 4 continents
column24: and participating in events globally to commemorate the day.\nIn Mexico City
column25: we will be delivering a safety training for the Mechanism for the Protection of Human Rights Defenders and Journalists. In India
column26: we will be addressing e-Raksha: Cybercrime Against Children with the CyberPeace Foundation & UNICEF.\nAt our HQ in San Francisco
column27: we will be conducting a safety workshop for high school students from #ICANHELP (@icanhelp)
column28: and partnering with Common Sense (@commonsense) to deliver digital citizenship training to various nonprofits serving youth and families. We will also be opening our event space to 50 Digital Learning facilitators from San Francisco Unified School District (@SFUSDdot)
column29: and sharing Twitter educator and safety best practices.\u00c2\u00a0\nHere in Europe
column30: we will be running a training at the Helsinki Central Library Oodi; participating in Better Internet for Kids meeting organised by the European Commission in Brussels
column31: and running an event to promote a safer internet for all citizens
column32: especially young people
column33: with our partners Webwise at our international HQ in Dublin.\nIn the UK - working with @ArtHouse
column34: we created four short videos about the range of safety tools available on Twitter
column35: with 4 online leaders; Habiba da Silva
column36: \u00c2\u00a0Dina Tokio
column37: \u00c2\u00a0Hannah Witton
column38: \u00c2\u00a0Alexander Leon. Our aim is to reach a wider audience with engaging content about these individuals\u00e2\u0080\u0099 own experiences on the service
column39: and the safety tools they use.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe are encouraging conversations with a special emoji for the hashtags #SaferInternetDay and #SID2020
column40: available in eighteen languages to encourage conversations around a safer internet.\nThroughout 2020
column41: we will continue to support our safety partners
column42: and work to ensure the public conversation on Twitter is healthy
column43: open
column44:
and safe.

column3: "title": "Looking ahead in 2020: Twitter Data Partners weigh in"
column7: "post_text": "Insights\nLooking ahead in 2020: Twitter Data Partners weigh in\nMonday
column8:
10 February 2020
Link copied successfully
What will social listening and customer care look like this year?
2019 was a big year for social media with trends shifting from social management and towards social intelligence as discussed in our recent blog. As we now find ourselves at the start of a whole new year (and a new decade!) who better to set the stage for what's to come than the Twitter Official Data Partners?
From social listening to customer care
column9: we asked senior thought leaders to share what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s in store for the industry in 2020. In response
column10: this group shared their vision on trends
column11: themes
column12:
and goals to come for this year.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
"While social listening tools will continue to evolve
column13: we predict that in 2020
column14: we'll see the greatest advances in marketers' own sophistication and use of insights to influence and inform the rest of their organizations.\"\nJamie Gilpin CMO
column15:
Sprout Social @jamiewo
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
"2020 is a special year in Japan and we believe trend detection is a key to success. We believe it is necessary not only to extract and visualize Tweet-related information from keywords but also to capture what trends are occurring from communication and engagement on Twitter."
Takumi Ryujin Executive Manager
column16:
Â NTT Data @nttdata_nazuki
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
"Brands are beginning to use Twitter to gain product insights and location insights; and use that data to modify their products and improve retail experiences. The value of this unstructured feedback on Twitter makes it the modern focus group for customer-centric brands."
Grad Conn Chief Experience and Marketing Officer
column17:
Sprinklr @gradconnâ
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
"Advances in AI will enable companies to be far more real-time in social listening and more proactive in their responses. Leading enterprises will focus on detecting emerging events and nascent trends
column18: enabling faster response and more effective risk mitigation and management.\"\nTed Bailey CEO and Chairman
column19:
Dataminr @TedBailey
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
"In 2020 and throughout the next decade we predict a need not only to collect and analyze ever-growing unprompted conversations from consumers
column20: but also to collect prompted views and opinions from billions of consumers across the globe.\"\nPhill Agnew Director of Product Marketing
column21:
Brandwatch @p_agnewâ
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
One thing we know for sure is that in 2020
column22: people will continue to come to Twitter to see and talk about what's happening in the world as it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening. And
column23: the data and insights generated from that conversation have the potential to transform and deepen our understanding of the people and topics important to us.\nTo learn more about the Twitter Official Data Partners
column24:
head to partners.twitter.com.
