column3: "title": "Building rules in public: Our approach to synthetic & manipulated media"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Building rules in public: Our approach to synthetic & manipulated media
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 4 February 2020\nLink copied successfully\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s our responsibility to create rules on Twitter that are fair and set clear expectations for everyone on our service. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we announced our plan last fall to once again seek input from around the globe on how we will address synthetic and manipulated media. Today
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sharing what we learned and how it shaped the update to The Twitter Rules
column10: how we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll treat this content when we identify it
column11: as well as something new you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll see in Twitter as part of this change.\nWhat did we learn? Through a survey on our initial draft of this rule
column12: as well as Tweets that included the hashtag #TwitterPolicyFeedback
column13: we gathered more than 6
column14: 500 responses from people around the world. We also consulted with a diverse
column15: global group of civil society and academic experts on our draft approach. Overall
column16: people recognize the threat that misleading altered media poses and want Twitter to do something about it. Here are some of the top-line findings:\nTwitter should give me more information: Globally
column17: more than 70 percent of people who use Twitter said \u00e2\u0080\u009ctaking no action\u00e2\u0080\u009d on misleading altered media would be unacceptable. Respondents were nearly unanimous in their support for Twitter providing additional information or context on Tweets that have this type of media.\nThis type of content should be labeled: Nearly 9 out of 10 individuals said placing warning labels next to significantly altered content would be acceptable. That is about as many who said it would be acceptable to alert people before they Tweet misleading altered media.  Compared to placing warning labels
column18: respondents were somewhat less supportive of removing or hiding Tweets that contained misleading altered media. For example
column19: 55 percent of those surveyed in the US said it would be acceptable to remove all of such media. When asked to give their open-ended thoughts about the proposed rule
column20: people who opposed removal of all altered media talked about the impact on free expression and censorship.\nIf it is likely to cause harm
column21:
it should be removed: More than 90 percent of people who shared feedback support Twitter removing this content when itâs clear that it is intended to cause certain types of harm.
There should be enforcement action when sharing this content: More than 75 percent of people believe accounts that share misleading altered media should face enforcement action. Enforcement actions could include people on Twitter having to delete their Tweet or having their account suspended.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Whatâs the new rule? You may not deceptively share synthetic or manipulated media that are likely to cause harm. In addition
column22: we may label Tweets containing synthetic and manipulated media to help people understand the media\u00e2\u0080\u0099s authenticity and to provide additional context.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll use the following criteria to consider Tweets and media for labeling or removal under this rule:\nAre the media synthetic or manipulated?  In determining whether media have been significantly and deceptively altered or fabricated
column23: some factors we consider include:\u00c2\u00a0  \u00e2\u0080\u0094Whether the content has been substantially edited in a manner that fundamentally alters its composition
column24: sequence
column25: timing
column26: or framing; \u00e2\u0080\u0094Any visual or auditory information (such as new video frames
column27: overdubbed audio
column28: or modified subtitles) that has been added or removed; and \u00e2\u0080\u0094Whether media depicting a real person has been fabricated or simulated. \nAre the media shared in a deceptive manner?   We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll also consider whether the context in which media are shared could result in confusion or misunderstanding or suggests a deliberate intent to deceive people about the nature or origin of the content
column29: for example by falsely claiming that it depicts reality.  We also assess the context provided alongside media
column30: for example:  \u00e2\u0080\u0094The text of the Tweet accompanying or within the media \u00e2\u0080\u0094Metadata associated with the media\u00c2\u00a0 \u00e2\u0080\u0094Information on the profile of the person sharing the media \u00e2\u0080\u0094Websites linked in the profile of the person sharing the media
column31: or in the Tweet sharing the media\nIs the content likely to impact public safety or cause serious harm?   Tweets that share synthetic and manipulated media are subject to removal under this policy if they are likely to cause harm. Some specific harms we consider include:  \u00e2\u0080\u0094Threats to the physical safety of a person or group \u00e2\u0080\u0094Risk of mass violence or widespread civil unrest \u00e2\u0080\u0094Threats to the privacy or ability of a person or group to freely express themselves or participate in civic events
column32: such as: stalking or unwanted and obsessive attention;targeted content that includes tropes
column33: epithets
column34:
or material that aims to silence someone; voter suppression or intimidation
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
What will this look like on Twitter? If we believe that media shared in a Tweet have been significantly and deceptively altered or fabricated
column36: as available
column37: such as a landing page with more context.\nIn most cases
column38:
we will take all of the above actions on Tweets we label.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Our teams will start labeling Tweets with this type of media on March 5
column39: 2020.\nThis will be a challenge and we will make errors along the way \u00e2\u0080\u0094 we appreciate the patience. However
column40: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to doing this right. Updating our rules in public and with democratic participation will continue to be core to our approach. \nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re working to serve the public conversation
column41:
and doing our work openly and with the people who use our service.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@TwitterSafety
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet

How the @Chiefs #SuperBowl victory played out on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 3 February 2020\nLink copied successfully\n#SuperBowlLIV was one for the ages. The conversation amongst football fans
column9: analysts

column14:
and more around the @Chiefs Super Bowl victory over the @49ers unfolded on Twitter.Â

The @Chiefs immediately Tweeted to celebrate their Super Bowl title.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

Twitter data

column15: the conversation around #SuperBowlLIV lit up Twitter around the world.\nHere are the top three moments of Super Bowl 54.\nDamien Williams seals the game with a long touchdown run

column3: "title": "Topics: Behind the Tweets "
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Topics: Behind the Tweets 
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 30 January 2020\nLink copied successfully\nThree months ago
column9: we launched Topics to make it easier to find the most interesting conversations happening on Twitter about the things you love.\u00c2\u00a0\nSince then
column10: people have asked to learn more about how Topics work. So
column11: we want to provide some background on how specific Topics are selected
column12: the process to find the best Tweets for you about these Topics
column13: and how we seek to highlight healthy conversations.\u00c2\u00a0\nHow Topics are chosen\nRight now
column14: there are roughly 1
column15: 000 Topics you can follow via the Topic browser
column16:
which will then show you Tweets about those Topics in your Home timeline. And weâre adding new Topics almost every week. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Prompt within Twitter showing you how to follow Topics.  
          
          
        
          
            Some Topics you can follow. 
          
          
        
We add new Topics based on the volume and health of conversations happening on Twitter. We start by looking at the volume of conversation on Twitter: how much people are Tweeting
column17: Retweeting
column18: replying
column19: and liking Tweets about that Topic. The more conversation
column20: the more likely it will be evaluated for inclusion in our next batch of available Topics. Topics reflect the broader
column21: lasting conversations people have about the events
column22: people
column23: and things they discuss. Once we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve identified a new Topic
column24: we then shift our focus to identifying the most relevant Tweets.\u00c2\u00a0\nFinding the most relevant Tweets on a Topic\nTo find the full set of Tweets about a Topic
column25: we use a combination of methods including looking at the text of Tweets as well as signals generated by machine learning solutions highlighting what Tweets might be about. At times
column26: our teams and external partners may also help source accounts to be included in certain Topics.\nTo find the most relevant Tweets
column27: we start by identifying the people on Twitter who are most interested in a given Topic using using a combination of machine learning
column28: curation
column29: and keywords.* This could mean they Tweet a lot about the Topic or interact a lot with Tweets about the Topic. From there
column30: we find the Tweets that are most interesting to those people
column31: using additional algorithms that look at many signals from those fan accounts including what types of content they engage with or specific accounts that are most relevant. Our systems check to confirm these Tweets are relevant to the Topic by looking at a series of related keywords.\nKeeping Topics healthy\nA healthy conversation about Topics is one where you want and feel safe to participate. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve implemented a number of protections so that the conversations included in a Topic should be healthy and free from abuse. This includes working to not recommend Tweets for a Topic if the engagement is manipulated or spammy. We look at a number of underlying signals
column32: including how others interact with both the Tweet and the author \u00e2\u0080\u0094 things like reports
column33: blocks
column34: and whether people have dismissed similar recommendations by clicking \u00e2\u0080\u009cshow less often\u00e2\u0080\u009d or muting closely-related keywords. These are just some of the signals we use when ranking and filtering the group of Tweets until we have a set we are confident recommending for that Topic. And
column35: to be clear: Tweets that criticize
column36: satirize
column37: or disagree within a Topic are a natural part of a healthy conversation and are eligible for inclusion. These protections are on top of all of the health protections we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve already put in place for other parts of Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn addition to the processes described above
column38: there are quality assurance checks with a globally distributed team of people to confirm Topics are accurately highlighting relevant and healthy conversations. If Topics are unfollowed frequently or Tweets within Topics are reported often
column39: these could be signals that those Topic Tweets might not be pertinent and healthy. If this is happening
column40: we may pause the Topic temporarily.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe know people are trusting us by following Topics and that Topics offer additional amplification to Tweets
column41: so we want to make sure we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re amplifying relevant
column42: healthy conversations.\u00c2\u00a0\nPersonalizing the Topic for you\u00c2\u00a0\nWhen you follow a Topic
column43: the Tweets you see about that Topic in your timeline are personalized. Your past activity \u00e2\u0080\u0094 like your Tweets and Tweets you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve liked
column44: replied to
column45: or Retweeted \u00e2\u0080\u0094 are used to identify the Tweets you'll find most interesting. Also
column46: if you engage more with one Topic
column47: like Dogs
column48: versus another Topic
column49: like cats
column50: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll show you more of the Dog Topic. (Sorry cat lovers!)\u00c2\u00a0\nTo wrap it up
column51: let\u00e2\u0080\u0099s use one of my favorite Topics
column52: BLACKPINK
column53: as an example. For the BLACKPINK Topic
column54: accounts regularly Tweeting about and engaging with the KPOP band generally or a specific band member
column55: like a fan account
column56: are found. From there
column57: Tweets that would be interesting to those fan accounts are gathered using the method described above. Throughout this process
column58: our systems are at work ensuring we are surfacing the conversations you want to see.\nFrom that narrowed pool
column59: depending on what might be most interesting to you
column60: say which band member you Tweet about or reply to Tweets about the most
column61: you may see a Tweet about Lisa or Jennie.\nAfter all that
column62: the best BLACKPINK Topic Tweet for you is ready to be shown in your Home timeline!\nThis is just the start
column63:
weâll keep working to improve Topics. We hope you like it. ð
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
If you donât see a Topic you want to follow yet
column64: don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t worry. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re adding new Topics almost every week. Topics are available in English
column65: Japanese
column66: Spanish
column67: Portuguese
column68: Arabic
column69: and Korean.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099d love to hear how you are liking Topics. Do the Topics you follow show interesting Tweets? When you follow a Topic
column70: do you see too many or too few related Tweets? We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll keep tweaking our systems to make Topics better. You can give feedback on Topic Tweets by tapping the down arrow on the Tweet and choosing \u00e2\u0080\u009cShow less often.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\u00c2\u00a0\n*Updated July 2
column71: 2020 to elaborate on how Tweets about a Topic are discovered and clarify that for certain Topics
column72:
our teams and external partners may help source accounts to be included. 
Â

column3: "title": "Helping the world find credible information about novel #coronavirus"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Helping the world find credible information about novel #coronavirus
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 29 January 2020\nLink copied successfully\nAs the global conversation continues around the spread of novel #coronavirus
column9: we want to share the work we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re doing to surface the right information
column10: to promote constructive engagement
column11: and to highlight credible information on this emerging issue. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen over 15 million Tweets on this topic in the past four weeks and that trend looks set to continue.\u00c2\u00a0 \nPreventing platform manipulation\nAt present
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re not seeing significant coordinated attempts to spread disinformation at scale about this issue. However
column13: we will remain vigilant and have invested significantly in our proactive abilities to ensure trends
column14: search
column15: and other common areas of the service are protected from malicious behaviors. As ever
column16: those who engage in these practices will be removed from our service. We do not permit platform manipulation and we encourage people to think before sharing or engaging in deliberate attempts to undermine the public conversation.\u00c2\u00a0\nExpanding search prompt\nGiven the rapidly evolving nature of the issue and the growing international response
column17: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve launched a new dedicated search prompt to ensure that when you come to the service for information about the #coronavirus
column18: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re met with credible
column19: authoritative information first. In addition
column20: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re halting any auto-suggest results that are likely to direct individuals to non-credible content on Twitter. This is an expansion of our #KnowTheFacts prompt
column21: which we specifically put in place for the public to find clear
column22: credible information on immunization and vaccination health.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nOur official #coronavirus partnerships are now in place in\u00c2\u00a0Australia

column75: official content across the globe.\u00c2\u00a0\nFor more
column76: please follow @TwitterGov and @Policy

where we will provide updates as appropriate.

#KpopTwitter rises to the top with 6.1 billion global Tweets in 2019
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 17 January 2020\nLink copied successfully\n2019 was a huge year for #KpopTwitter
column9: as Kpop remains an undisputable force that continues to make waves across the world. With an amazing record of 6.1 billion Tweets in 2019
column10: which was 15% higher than 2018; Twitter shows that it is the best place to find out what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening with all things Kpop
column11: and to join in the conversations with like-minded Kpop fans around the world!\nWhile Kpop gained popularity in South Korea 25 years ago
column12:
it is only in recent times through the power of millennial fans worldwide that Kpop-related conversations have gained traction across the world on Twitter. Here are the top 10 countries that Tweeted the most about Kpop in 2019: 
This Tweet is unavailable

Additionally
column13: countries such as Canada
column14: France

This Tweet is unavailable

column17:
the BTS Army demonstrated their power by propelling BTS (@bts_twt) member Jungkookâs video Tweet of him dancing to Billie Eilishâs (@billieeilish) âBad Guyâ to become the most Retweeted Tweet (aka the Golden Tweet) worldwide in 2019.

but we also saw a trend of individual team member accounts rising above the crowd such as Baekhyun (@B_hundred_Hyun) and BamBam (@BamBam1a).

Fastest Growing Kpop Groups in 2019 With new Kpop groups joining Twitter in 2019
column20: and some having a surge of Tweet volumes in comparison to the year before

we took a look at the 10 fastest rising Kpop accounts worldwide.
This Tweet is unavailable

#TwitterBlueroom LIVE Q&A Sessions In 2019
column22: Twitter hosted a total of 67 #TwitterBlueroom sessions with various Kpop bands and artists
column23: connecting fans globally to their favorite Kpop stars by bringing exclusive interviews and Q&A sessions for them to get closer to their idols. Kpop stars that joined us in the Blueroom this year included ASTRO (@offclASTRO)
column24: Eric Nam (@ericnamofficial)
column25: IZONE (@official_izone)
column26: ONEUS (@official_ONEUS)
column27: just to name a few. Fans could participate by Tweeting their questions to their idols
column28: and using the hashtag #WhosNext4TwitterBlueroom to nominate who they would like to see in the next #TwitterBlueroom.\u00c2\u00a0\nAmongst the #TwitterBlueroom sessions that took place last year; SuperM (@SuperM)
column29: the super group that consists of representative Kpop idol members
column30:
broke the record for the most watched #KpopTwitter blueroom with over two million total viewers.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Co-founders of Twitter
column31: Jack Dorsey (@Jack) and Biz Stone (@biz)
column32: made a stop in South Korea to join globally acclaimed Kpop band GOT7 (@GOT7Official) for a #TwitterBlueroom session
column33: recording over 1.1 million views! During the live broadcast
column34: which lasted approximately 30 minutes
column35: Jack
column36: Biz and GOT7 members answered fan questions posted through the hashtag #JACKmeetsGOT7 \u00e2\u0080\u0093 their discussion included Jack and Biz\u00e2\u0080\u0099s experiences in Korea
column37: how Twitter is a great platform for GOT7 to engage their fans on a more personal level
column38:
and what would each one of them do if they had two weeks to do anything they want.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Beyond music
column39:
fashion also plays an instrumental role in Kpop and Kpop stars have been stealing the spotlight at major fashion events globally. Kpop idols Sandara Park (@krungy21) and ITZY (@ITZYofficial) have partnered with Twitter to bring exclusive content for their fans by hosting live #KpopTwitter Blueroom and Q&A sessions direct from Paris Fashion Week (#PFW).

          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Connecting fans to the biggest Kpop award shows and events worldwide  With Twitter
column40: Kpop fans worldwide can now join in the conversations around the biggest Kpop award shows and events worldwide
column41: such as KCON 2019 (@KCON_Global)
column42: and the 2019 Mnet Asian Music Awards (#2019MAMA).\u00c2\u00a0During KCON 2019 held across four cities
column43:
40 million related Tweets along with 28 million views on KCON-related videos were generated. GOT7âs (@GOT7Official) Tweet shared by KCON Thailand (@KCONThailand) emerged as the most retweeted Tweet from KCON 2019.
This Tweet is unavailable

          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
#2019MAMA
column44: the most important Kpop awards ceremony that wraps up the year
column45: was one of the #KpopTwitter moments that fans across the world did not want to miss. From October 24
column46: the date which the\u00c2\u00a0#2019MAMA vote was started
column47: to December 4
column48: the day of the event
column49: the fans from around the world generated around an astounding 102 million Tweets on Twitter. Moreover
column50:
BTSâ Red Carpet 360 Camera video that was posted on MAMAâs official Twitter account was the Most Retweeted Tweet from the event.Â

At all three events
column51: we saw spikes in conversations as Kpop fans kept themselves updated through a flurry of Tweets expressing their love for their favorite artists and idols. Exclusive content is shared through the respective Twitter official handles such as Red Carpet Live Streaming and \u00e2\u0080\u009cTwitter Mirror
column52: \u00e2\u0080\u009d a special video format where Kpop idols\u00e2\u0080\u0099 autographs were created
column53: receiving fervent love and response from their fans. From the East to West
column54: fans can now get easy

is already drawing Kpop fans around the world to Twitter.
Come and join the #KpopTwitter conversation today to see and talk about your favourite Kpop idols and stay updated everyday with other Kpop fans around the world!

column3: "title": "Is 2020 the year of prediction?"
column7:
"post_text": "highTint
Insights
Is 2020 the year of prediction?
                By
                
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 8 January 2020\nLink copied successfully\nPrediction as a practice may have famously got its start in the 7th Century BC
column9: when the oracle of Delphi
column10: in consultation with the Greek god Apollo
column11: would look to the future to provide guidance ranging from when to plant crops to whether or not to wage war.\nToday
column12: the practice of predicting the future has come a long way from ancient Greece. Magic and spiritual consultation has been replaced with statistical models and data. Mathematicians and data experts are applying methods such as regression analysis
column13: decision trees and neural networks to calculate probable future events and behaviour across consumer
column14: social and scientific spheres. Given the amount of interest and investment being put into prediction
column15: our hunger to know the future clearly hasn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t waned.\nUsing Social Prediction for Consumer Trend Forecasting\u00c2\u00a0\nWith respect to business
column16: our obsession with prediction makes sense. In today\u00e2\u0080\u0099s constantly accelerating hyper-competitive environment it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s never been more crucial to be the first mover. Consider the competitive world of consumer products. Between 2013 and 2018
column17: $20B in sales was lost by large and midsize U.S. CPGs to small and private-label brands. These small
column18: nimble challengers proved adept at identifying and capitalizing on new and emerging consumer trends and being first to market with innovative new products.\nPut simply
column19: in the business world those who can best predict the future will win. But where to start? Social data and social prediction may hold the key.\nPredicting Trends Using Twitter Data\nTwitter is often thought of as the place where news breaks first
column20: where the news gets its news. And while that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s absolutely correct
column21: what is less appreciated about Twitter is that it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s also the place to see and understand the trends that are shaping society. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve always thought of it as the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s largest focus group
column22: where people share their experiences on anything and everything. And while some of these insights might be quite mundane
column23: in the aggregate they allow us to understand human behaviours
column24: moods and mindsets. They reveal taste preferences
column25: friction and frustration with products or services and desires for unarticulated needs.\nAnd when you combine 14 years of these insights (Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s age) with predictive modelling techniques
column26: you can turn trendspotting from an ad-hoc and subjective art form into a more systematic
column27: data-driven capability. Used and applied correctly it changes your company\u00e2\u0080\u0099s consumer intelligence competency from a focus on what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happened
column28: to what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s going to happen and how do we take advantage?\nPredictive Social Analytics Reveals Consumer Food Trends\nThis is an emerging space to be sure
column29: but we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re already seeing some impressive results.\u00c2\u00a0 Take Black Swan
column30: for example
column31: a data science and technology company specializing in social prediction. Using Natural Language Processing technology
column32: they\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve built data sets based on social media conversations surrounding specific product categories. These datasets allow them to identify
column33: size and forecast the future importance of every topic of conversation that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s being talked about by consumers; from macro-level drivers like sustainability to specific trend manifestations like a trending ingredient.\u00c2\u00a0 For example
column34: Black Swan says they can predict how popular Bakuchiol \u00e2\u0080\u0093 the plant-based vegan alternative to retinol \u00e2\u0080\u0093 will be in 6
column36: or 18 months\u00e2\u0080\u0099 time versus other trendy ingredients in the skincare category.\nAccording to Black Swan
column37: their clients such as PepsiCo and other global brands are using these trend predictions to improve the velocity and throughput of their innovation programs
column38: accelerating time to market while also helping to prioritize their corporate development and acquisition efforts. A great example is PepsiCo\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Global Insights team
column39: who have been using Black Swan\u00e2\u0080\u0099s social prediction software to fast-track their new product ideation process. As new concepts and ideas are conceived in a workshop environment they are instantly validated against the latest trend data and predictions in an iterative process. The result: several new product concepts for their snacking portfolio were optimised and validated in just four hours
column40: a process that traditionally took them at least four weeks!\nWhen it comes to tapping into emerging trends and accelerating innovation
column41:
itâs easy to see how prediction can be a game-changer.Â 
Need a resolution for 2020? Why not put aside oracles and crystal balls for good and look to Twitter for inspiration? I predict it will be the best decision you make all year.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
@TwitterBusiness
@TwitterSafety
Tweet

social listening

prediction

column7:
"post_text": "Product
Twitter announces Promoted Trend Spotlight goes global
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Monday
column8:
6 January 2020
Link copied successfully
Put your brand at the center of conversation where the power of video meets the premium real estate of the Explore tab: Introducing Promoted Trend Spotlight
Today
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re announcing the launch of the newest takeover ad product on Twitter
column10: Promoted Trend Spotlight. This takeover ad placement pairs the undeniable stopping power of video with the premium real estate of Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Explore tab. The Explore tab
column11: Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s collection of trending topics and hashtags
column12: is where people go to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening
column13:
making it a prime location for advertisers to connect with people and conversation.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Launching a new streaming service â even when itâs called Disney+ â requires breaking through and becoming a part of the cultural conversation. We knew social platforms
column14: including Twitter
column15: would be playing a key role. We leveraged the Promoted Trend Spotlight throughout our campaign as it was important for us to truly capture people's attention at scale.\nTrevor Kelley\nVice President
column16: Digital Marketing
column17: Disney+ \nWe are now making Promoted Trend Spotlight generally available in the United States
column18: the United Kingdom
column19: and Japan
column20: and expanding the product to 12 additional markets: Australia
column21: Brazil
column22: Canada
column23: France
column24: Germany
column25: India
column26: Indonesia
column27: Mexico
column28: Saudi Arabia
column29: South Korea
column30: Spain
column31: and Thailand.\u00c2\u00a0\nHow it works:\nAs a complement to Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Promoted Trend takeover product
column32: Promoted Trend Spotlight supports 6-second videos and GIFs
column33: as well as static images. Creative displays on mobile and desktop
column34: with the ad running edge-to-edge on mobile.\nYour ad will appear at the top of the Explore tab for the first two visits per person
column35: per day.\nAfter the initial two visits
column36: the placement moves to the standard Promoted Trend placement and organic editorial content resurfaces in the Spotlight placement.Â  This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. Your browser does not support the video element. Play Play Pause Seek 0% buffered 00:00 Current time 00:00 Duration 00:00 Toggle Mute Volume In an eye-tracking study conducted by EyeSee
column37: a global behavioral research company
column38: people spent 26% more time looking at the Promoted Trend Spotlight as compared to the standard Promoted Trend unit. These longer dwell times generated impact throughout the funnel: from +113% higher ad recall and +18% higher brand consideration to +67% lift in stated likelihood to use a brand in the future. In addition
column39: according to internal Twitter data
column40: people were three times more likely to click through an ad in the Spotlight unit than the standard Promoted Trend.\nKey features:\nCaptures attention: With immersive
column41: full-width creative
column42: Promoted Trend Spotlight captures attention and reinforces your message.\nDifferentiates your brand: Sitting atop the Explore tab
column43: Promoted Trend Spotlight differentiates your brand from other placements on Twitter by appearing next to highly curated editorial content.\nSurfaces conversation: Tying together the prominent placement and expansive coverage atop Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Explore tab
column44:
brands have the opportunity to generate conversation and invite discussion.

please contact your Twitter Client Partner.

column3: "title": "An update of our work around #Taiwan2020"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
An update of our work around #Taiwan2020
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 6 January 2020\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter serves the global
column9: public conversation
column10: and protecting the integrity of the conversation around elections is an essential part of our mission.\u00c2\u00a0\nAs we lead into the #TaiwanElection
column11:
we'd like to take this opportunity to share some updates on the work we've been doing to protect and enhance the health of the public conversation at this pivotal cultural and political moment. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Protecting the integrity of the #TaiwanElection conversation on TwitterÂ 
Updating the Twitter Rules The Twitter Rules are a living document meaning that our policies and enforcement options evolve continuously to address emerging behaviors online. 
Our Election Integrity Policy prohibits any attempt to interfere with the electoral process by undermining the physical act of voting
column12: or registering to vote. This applies to the distribution of false or misleading information about the electoral process or when or how to vote. We also have policies to address other behaviours that can appear during elections such as platform manipulation and spam (including fake accounts)
column13: and the distribution of hacked materials. \nOur policies prohibit news media entities controlled by state authorities from purchasing advertisements on Twitter. We also recently announced a ban on all political advertising globally on Twitter. We made this decision based on our belief that political message reach should be earned
column14:
not bought.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Training political partners on using Twitter and our reporting channels During elections
column15: we work closely with political parties from across the political spectrum to train them on using Twitter to best engage with their constituents. In preparation for the #TaiwanElection
column16: we onboarded and held trainings for both the\u00c2\u00a0Democratic Progressive Party\u00c2\u00a0and the Kuomintang.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe launched a dedicated
column17: elections-specific support portal for election partners to provide feedback directly to us about issues and concerns that could arise during the 2020 #TaiwanElection. This process is designed to ensure we receive and review critical feedback about emerging issues as quickly as possible. We have trained the Central Election Commission of Taiwan and law enforcement agencies on using these channels to report suspicious
column18: abusive
column19:
and rule-violating activity to Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Fighting platform manipulation and spam  Platform manipulation and spam are clearÂ violations of the Twitter Rules and we continue to invest intensively to identify and combat bad-faith actors who try to manipulate the service - particularly around the time of elections.
We use technology to fight platform manipulation strategically and at scale. This lets us tackle attempts to manipulate conversations rapidly
column20: across languages and time zones
column21: without relying on reactive reports - often before accounts have even issued their first Tweet.\nWe continue to make strong progress and in the first half of 2019
column22: challenged almost 100 million accounts. As part of our efforts in this space
column23:
we willÂ disclose datasets associated with coordinated malicious activity that we are able to reliably associate with state-affiliated actors on our Data Disclosure Hub.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Sharing our approach to election-related misinformation We spoke at the first APAC Fact Checking Forum hosted by theÂ Taiwan Fact Checking Center in October
column24: alongside industry peers
column25: on Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s approach to election-related dis- and misinformation. We shared details on our proactive technological approach
column26: leveraging machine learning and human review to tackle spammy
column27:
inauthentic behaviour proactively.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Empowering the public conversation During any election
column28: Twitter is the place where people go to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening
column29: participate in the conversation
column30:
and virtually join the campaign trail.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Launching a custom #TaiwanElection emoji To unite people around the election conversation on Twitter
column31: we launched a custom election emoji that will run for the duration of the campaign. The emoji incorporates a common voting symbol in Taiwan and will be activated by bilingual hashtags #TaiwanElection
column32: #TaiwanVotes
column33: #Taiwan2020
column35:
and #å°ç£æç¥¨. We hope the emoji will be a valuable visual link to help promote the discoverability of the election conversation.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Engaging with partners We onboarded
column36: trained
column37: and gave #AdsForGoods grants to civil society groups including the Taiwan Fact Checking Center
column38: the Taiwan Alliance for the Advancement of Youth Rights and Welfare
column39: and Taiwan Citizen Congress Watch.\nThe public conversation on Twitter is never more important than during elections
column40: the cornerstone of any democracy. Twitter shows the world what is happening
column41: democratises access to information and\u00e2\u0080\u0094at its best\u00e2\u0080\u0094provides insights into a diversity of perspectives on critical issues in real-time.\nWe deeply respect the integrity of the election conversation
column42:
and are committed to providing a service that fosters and facilitates free and open democratic debate.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet

column3: "title": " New disclosures to our archive of state-backed information operations"
column7: "post_text": "Company\n New disclosures to our archive of state-backed information operations\nFriday
column8:
20 December 2019
Link copied successfully
Transparency is at the heart of everything we do at Twitter. Thatâs why we routinely disclose datasets of information operations we can reliably link to state actors.Â  
These datasets live in our public archive of state-backed information operations â the largest of its kind in the industry. First launched in October 2018
column9: the archive has been accessed by thousands of researchers from around the world
column10: who in turn have conducted independent
column11: third-party investigations of their own.\nState-backed information operations originating in Saudi Arabia\nToday
column12: we are sharing comprehensive data about 5
column13: 929 accounts which we have removed for violating our platform manipulation policies. Rigorous investigations by our Site Integrity team have allowed us to attribute these accounts to a significant state-backed information operation on Twitter originating in Saudi Arabia.\u00c2\u00a0\nThese accounts represent the core portion of a larger network of more than 88
column14: 000 accounts engaged in spammy behaviour across a wide range of topics. We have permanently suspended all of these accounts from the service. In order to protect the privacy of potentially compromised accounts repurposed to engage in platform manipulation
column15: and in response to researcher feedback requesting that we pre-filter unrelated spam
column16: we have not disclosed data for all 88
column17: 000 accounts. In the interest of offering meaningful transparency
column18: the dataset we are disclosing includes a representative
column19: random sample of the fake and spammy accounts associated with this broader network.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe have also shared information about this activity with our peer companies to enable investigations of related activity on their services
column20: and the relevant law enforcement entities.\u00c2\u00a0\nHere are some additional distinct features of the accounts we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re disclosing today:\nOur internal analysis shows the network was involved in various forms of platform manipulation
column21: targeting discussions related to Saudi Arabia and advancing their geopolitical interests on the world stage. Primarily
column22: accounts were amplifying messages favourable to Saudi authorities
column23: mainly through inauthentic engagement tactics such as aggressive liking
column24: Retweeting and replying. While the majority of the content from this network was in Arabic
column25: a portion of it related to events relevant to Western audiences
column26: including amplification of discussion around sanctions in Iran and appearances by Saudi government officials in Western media.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nOur investigations have traced the source of the coordinated activity to Smaat
column27: a social media marketing and management company based in Saudi Arabia. Our in-house technical indicators show that Smaat appears to have created
column28: purchased
column29: and/or managed these accounts on behalf of \u00e2\u0080\u0094 but not necessarily with the knowledge of \u00e2\u0080\u0094 their clients. We have permanently suspended Smaat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s access to our service as a result
column30: as well as the Twitter accounts of Smaat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s senior executives. Smaat managed a range of Twitter accounts for high-profile individuals
column31: as well as many government departments in Saudi Arabia.\u00c2\u00a0\nMany of the accounts involved in the overall network employed third-party automated tools in order to amplify non-political content at high volumes. As a general matter
column32: the use of automation to Tweet helpful content \u00e2\u0080\u0094 like crisis response info or weather updates \u00e2\u0080\u0094 is not a violation of our rules. However
column33: this behaviour was
column34: in part
column35: strategically employed in an attempt to mask the overall platform manipulation originating from these accounts. These tactics made it more difficult for observers to identify political Tweets in the timelines of accounts
column36: which mostly shared automated
column37: non-political content.\u00c2\u00a0\n What\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next \nWe exist to serve the public conversation around the world. To this end
column38: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to take strong enforcement action against any state-backed information campaigns which undermine our company\u00e2\u0080\u0099s mission
column39: principles
column40: and policies.\u00c2\u00a0\nFor more information on the processes and principles behind this work
column41:
see here.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet

column3: "title": "The state of social intelligence: 2019 year in review"
column7:
"post_text": "highTint
The state of social intelligence: 2019 year in review
                By
                
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 17 December 2019\nLink copied successfully\nChances are
column9: your company or organization is already successfully tapping into social media to monitor your brand
column10: run marketing campaigns and even manage customer service. But it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s when you start putting that social data to work to make better decisions
column11: that you know that you have moved from social media management to social intelligence. That transition has been the focus of many conversations I\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve had with businesses during the past year
column12:
including a couple of social listening roundtables weâve hosted here at Twitter. Hereâs my summary of what those businesses are telling me:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Social intelligence is on the rise
As previously mentioned
column13: more companies are seeing Twitter and other social data as a valuable source of insight into the people and topics important to them. Businesses are realizing the uniqueness of social media in providing real-time
column14:
unprompted and authentic feedback and are starting to overlay this âvoice of the customerâ data with other data sources to find correlation and causation.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Insight is being âdemocratizedâ
Companies are in the midst of massive rollouts of dashboards and alerting capabilities to support the specific needs of various departments and regions. At the same time
column15:
analysis capabilities are being more centralized to support specialization and reduce duplication of effort. Social listening and analytics tools are supporting the former while business intelligence tools the latter. And to that pointâ¦
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
DIY is happening
Some innovative organizations are applying their own models for text analysis to more accurately understand all this unstructured data. For this reason
column16: they are either connecting directly to social APIs themselves or are using their social listening provider\u00e2\u0080\u0099s APIs to get social data into their business intelligence tools for further
column17:
deeper data analysis.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Small is big
When taken as a whole
column18: the sheer quantity of social data points can be impressive but quantity is not necessarily a requirement for success. Many companies are deriving immense value in surfacing small numbers (hundreds or even dozens) of highly relevant data points on very specific topics. For example
column19: an analyst researching a topic such as yogurt might only find a couple of hundred mentions in a given month
column20: but within that data set are valuable insights around flavor preferences
column21:
health benefits or usage trends.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Itâs not if
column22: but when\nMost organizations aren\u00e2\u0080\u0099t asking if social data like that from Twitter has value but when they should be utilizing it. Put another way
column23: what questions is Twitter good at answering? How does social media data complement other data sources and/or research techniques? The answers might vary depending on industry
column24: audience
column25: and/or geography
column26: but many organizations I\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve spoken with are getting immense value from social data at the beginning of their research
column27:
using it to understand market context and quickly (and cheaply) test assumptions.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
New innovators are emerging
Innovation has primarily been driven by social listening vendors over the past decade
column28: however
column29: we are starting to see some really interesting and innovative work coming from smaller digital agencies and data science shops connecting the social dots with other data sources. As mentioned
column30:
itâs this blending of data sources which will prove the value of social data for new use cases.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As 2019 draws to a close and we look toward a new decade
column31: what is the current state of social intelligence? To paraphrase Churchill
column32: this is certainly not the beginning of the end
column33: but it is
column34: perhaps
column35: the end of the beginning. And this stage should excite us. If you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re ready to start your move to social intelligence
column36:
get inspired at data.twitter.com. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
@TwitterBusiness
@TwitterSafety
Tweet
Twitter logo icon

social intelligence

column3: "title": "Inclusion & Diversity Report December 2019"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nInclusion & Diversity Report December 2019\nTuesday
column8: 17 December 2019\nLink copied successfully\nAs 2019 winds down
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re providing an end-of-year update on our journey to build a more diverse and inclusive Twitter:\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made good progress in the past two years. We exceeded some targets for workforce representation
column10: but fell short of others and need to do better. \nThe momentum we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve gained recruiting diverse technical talent is encouraging \u00e2\u0080\u0094 we must now extend that progress to senior roles
column11: where more focus is needed.\nAs we approach a new decade
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to take a new approach to how we measure the diversity of our global workforce
column13: set bold targets
column14: and share our progress.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn the meantime
column15: we presented this report to our Board on December 12
column17: and because we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to working in the open
column18:
weâre sharing it with you here. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The Data
In 2017
column19: we set two-year diversity targets for women
column20: Black
column21:
and Latinx representation at Twitter.Â  
So where are we today?
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâre on a journey with no finish line and progress can never be fast enough. Over the last two years weâve made progress â exceeding representation targets in some areas (Black) and falling short in others (women and Latinx).Â Â 
Next year
column22: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re introducing a new vision for what we want our workforce to look like in five years
column23: and a career pathways program that will help increase representation of women
column24: Black
column25: and Latinx Tweeps across all levels
column26: roles
column27: and office locations. \nHiring is a critical driver of our progress. In the most recent quarter
column28: we hired more women
column29: Black
column30: and Latinx talent compared to the previous quarter. However
column31: we need to double down here to keep pace with overall hiring at the company
column32:
which has accelerated. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Below are the attrition rates for women
column33: Black
column34: and Latinx talent
column35: which continue to be at or below the company-wide attrition rate. While this is encouraging data
column36: we are determined to lower attrition across these groups even further
column37:
and will be investing heavily in 2020.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Beyond these three demographics
column38:
we continue to track and support deeper representation across our workforce. Here are the broader breakdowns:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The true measure of diversity is more complex than what can be gathered from formal People systems. Thatâs why weâve launched an anonymous internal Global Inclusion Survey to collect more robust information about our Tweepsâ lived experiences. The survey explores important topics across gender
column39: sexual orientation
column40: race/ethnicity and immigration
column41: socio-economic status
column42:
and religion â to name a few. This data will guide our future I&D investments and we look forward to sharing the results in a future report.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Hiring
Weâve doubled down on our presence at industry conferences popular with talent from diverse communities. This fall
column43: we had our strongest presence yet at AdWeek
column44: Women Impact Tech
column45: AdColor
column46: National Black MBA
column47: Grace Hopper Conference
column48: Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers Conference
column49: AfroTech
column50: and Women in Product. Our Talent Acquisition teams continue to cultivate leads from these events with a focus on hiring interns
column51: new grads
column52:

We also made two critical hires to continue growing our I&D team.Â Preet GrewalÂ (@preet_oG) is the new Head of Inclusion & Diversity for Asia Pacific who will share responsibility for Europe and Latin America and help ensure that our work maintains a truly global perspective as we scale. Donna Wright (@DJtheHRLady) is our new Head of Diversity Talent Acquisition and will lead our work to embed inclusive hiring principles throughout the hiring progress.

column57: we launched mandatory unconscious bias training for all Tweeps. These trainings equip learners to recognize and address the effects of unconscious bias by challenging assumptions; encouraging diversity of experience

and expression; and supporting a workplace culture that actively and intentionally strives to be more inclusive.

and giving back with San Francisco AIDS Foundation (@SFAIDSFound) and #TwitterForGood.Â

We also recognized International Day of People with Disabilities by featuring guest chefs with disabilities.

Product & Partnerships
#TwitterTeamUp 
In October
column102: we launched a new internal effort to identify opportunities to better protect and promote diverse voices across our company and service. #TwitterTeamUp is a cross-functional effort led by our Inclusion & Diversity team in partnership with our Business Resource Groups
column103: User Services
column104: Health
column105: and Trust & Safety. The collaboration has opened new lines of communication across leaders who play an important role in shaping how the company thinks about these issues. We look forward to sharing progress in a future update.\u00c2\u00a0 \n#TwitterVoices \nIn October
column106: we hosted 30 Latinx and Afro-Latinx #TwitterVoices in New York to discuss their experience on the platform
column107: Latinidad in the spectrum of society
column108: trust and safety
column109: and more. In November
column110: we convened over 40 Black power voices in S\u00c3\u00a3o Paulo for a #TwitterVoices \u00e2\u0080\u009cConversation Sessions\u00e2\u0080\u009d event
column111: as well as hosted a #SheInspiresMe \u00e2\u0080\u009cEla Me Inspira\u00e2\u0080\u009d dinner to surface issues of Black identity
column112: gender equality and obstacles for Black creators ensuring that our work always maintains a global lens. Insights generated from these conversations are shared cross-functionally across the organization to inform future product and policy considerations.\nGlobal Paternity Leave Task Force \nWhen all parents have equal access to and take their full family leave
column113: everyone wins. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re proud to be part of the Global Paternity Leave Task Force. The effort focuses on changing caregiving norms and driving gender equality by empowering men to take their full paternity leave so the benefits are felt at home
column115: and in society more widely. \n@TechWomen 2019 \nTwitter is a proud partner of @TechWomen
column116: which focuses on creating the next generation of women STEM leaders from Africa
column118: and the Middle East. As part of a five-week program
column119: we recently hosted five emerging leaders
column121: and sent a delegation to DC who spoke at the World Bank and met with Embassy officials to raise awareness of the importance of investing in STEM education for women and girls around the world. \nBuilding a Diverse Supply Chain \nIn collaboration with Twitter Women
column122: we hosted an event to bring women entrepreneurs
column126:
and two virtual workshops for diverse suppliers to empower them to do business with us. We also had a presence across a number of events for diverse suppliers including:
Women's Business Enterprise National Council 2019 Conference
National Minority Supplier Development Council 2019 Conference
Accenture Diverse Supplier Development Program
Western Regional Minority Supplier Development Council 2019 Multi Industry Expo
Western Regional Minority Supplier Development Council - Builders & Tradespeople Construction Day
Women's Business Enterprise Council - Pacific - Bold Success
Women's Business Enterprise Council - Pacific - EmpowHer
Diversity Partnerships
In October we hosted New York Times' 1619 Project as part of our Join The Conversation Series to empower more businesses to navigate complex discussions around topics like race in the workplace. We also deepened our work with the National Pan-Hellenic Council to empower more diverse voices across the platform.
#TwitterforGood
Giving back to our communities is part of our DNA. This quarter we conducted 90+ volunteer projects across 22 offices
column127: spanning the globe on #TwitterforGood Day. We worked with 1
column129: 750 hours of service in close partnership with 80 community-based organizations.\nIn San Francisco
column130: we rolled out our final quarter of cash grants in 2019 totaling $1
column132: 000 for the year; an 80% increase from 2018. We also invested in a suite of in-kind donations and on-platform ad grants to provide holistic support to our key partners. We partnered with organizations that comprise a comprehensive workforce development pipeline for underrepresented minorities in tech. This work culminated in opening doors to employment at Twitter with the launch of our new Data Science/Engineering apprentice program. \nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Next? \nAs the year winds down
column133: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve got our sights set on 2025 and are asking ourselves
column134: what will it take to become the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s most inclusive and diverse tech company? We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to share our vision with you in our next report. In the meantime
column135:
we want to hear from you! What would you like to see from us? Looking forward to the conversation â see you on @Twitter!

column3: "title": "The top 10 brands that make people happier on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
The top 10 brands that make people happier on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 13 December 2019\nLink copied successfully\nWhat makes a memorable marketing campaign? Often
column9: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a superstar or a jingle that catches your attention. But this year
column10: the brands who are breaking through the noise are communicating heartfelt messages. Sprinklr analyzed brands who received a significant amount of buzz for their marketing this year to find the top 10 campaigns with the happiest reactions on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhy is this study important? Because emotions drive sales. Research shows that positive emotions toward a brand have a far greater influence on consumer loyalty than trust and other judgments
column11: which are based on a brand\u00e2\u0080\u0099s attributes. The most successful brands listen to their customers on Twitter
column12:
learn from them and take these insights to create successful marketing campaigns that elicit a positive emotional response.Â  
Sprinklrâs Twitter insights from the top 10 brands that make people happier:Â  
1. Disney - #GalaxysEdge 
The massive anticipation for Star Wars: Galaxyâs Edge themed lands at Disneyland Park and Disney World created positive online buzz with Star Wars fans discussing what to expect when exploring the new galaxy far
column13: far away. So far
column14: mentions of #GalaxysEdge on Twitter are eighty-eight percent positive.\u00c2\u00a0\nThe biggest spike in conversation on Twitter happened on May 31st
column15: 2019 with more than 60 thousand people discussing opening day of the Galaxy\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Edge at Disneyland in Anaheim. The next biggest spike was on August 29th with more than 19 thousand people talking about opening day at Disney World on Twitter. The most prevalent positive emotion is celebration - with 34 percent of people posting about celebrating the launch of the #GalaxysEdge.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0 \n2. NASA - 50th anniversary of the Apollo 11 Moon landing \nNASA celebrated the 50th anniversary of the historic Apollo 11 Moon mission in July with a live television and Twitter broadcast
column16: events and a major digital campaign. They also launched 3 crew members to the International Space Station on the same day as the anniversary. On Twitter
column17: more than 123
column18: 000\u00c2\u00a0 people have mentioned #Apollo50th and NASA 50th anniversary of the Apollo 11
column19: and 93 percent of these mentions are positive. NASA\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Twitter account posted one of the most popular tweets on July 17th for world emoji day
column20: which received an overwhelmingly positive response at 78
column21:
000Â  likes.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
3. Microsoft - We All Win
Microsoft highlighted its commitment to accessible technology that levels the playing field during the Super Bowl with its commercial
column22: \u00e2\u0080\u009cWe All Win.\u00e2\u0080\u009d The commercial showed young gamers using the Xbox Adaptive Controller. It was a huge hit on Twitter
column23: receiving a 95 percent positive sentiment
column24: was one of the top 5 most talked about purpose-driven superbowl ads
column25: and was a winner of the #BrandBowl53 for tech.\nTop positive themes in the discussion around the campaign include love
column26: accessibility
column27:
and inclusion. Microsoftâs Tweet launching the campaign on January 31st was one of the most popular Tweets.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
4. Nike - Dream Crazier
In February
column28: Nike launched a hugely popular commercial called
column29: \u00e2\u0080\u009cDream Crazier.\u00e2\u0080\u009d According to Nike
column30: the video \u00e2\u0080\u009cshines a spotlight on female athletes who have broken barriers
column31:
brought people together through their performance and inspired generations of athletes to chase after their dreams.âÂ 
Tennis star Serena Williams narrates the ad. Her words generated a powerful reaction â over 85 percent of mentions of âDream Crazierâ on Twitter are positive.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
5. McDonaldâs - #BeaBrewGooder SweepstakesÂ 
This August
column32: McDonald\u00e2\u0080\u0099s launched McCaf\u00c3\u00a9 It Forward
column33: a three-day
column34: pay-it-forward program designed to spread goodness across the U.S. one cup of coffee at a time. They also announced the McCaf\u00c3\u00a9 Be A Brew-Gooder Sweepstakes encouraging coffee lovers to recognize those who they think have done good in their world.\nThe campaign has received a 99 percent positive reaction on Twitter so far
column35: with thousands of\u00c2\u00a0 mentions from McDonald\u00e2\u0080\u0099s fans nominating a friend or family member who has done something good. The major conversation themes about\u00c2\u00a0 #BeaBrewGooder include love
column36: life
column37:
good and friend. 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
6. adidas - #SheBreaksBarriers
In honor of International Womenâs Day
column38: adidas launched the \u00e2\u0080\u009cShe Breaks Barriers\u00e2\u0080\u009d campaign to push for women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s equality and visibility in sports beyond one day. As part of this campaign
column39: adidas announced its partnership with Twitter on March 7th
column40: 2019 to livestream female high school sports
column41: saying
column42: \u00e2\u0080\u009cbecause when she is seen
column43: she breaks barriers.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\u00c2\u00a0\nThe campaign has received a 94 percent positive reaction. Out of the mentions with an identifiable gender
column44: 47 percent are male. Of course
column45: the biggest burst of mentions was on International Women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Day on March 8th
column46:
2019.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
7. Bosch - #LikeABosch
Founded in 1886
column47: Bosch is the perfect example of a company who knows how to continuously reinvent its image \u00e2\u0080\u0093 and use humor successfully \u00e2\u0080\u0093 for modern times. In January at the tech event CES
column48: Bosch launched their #LikeABosch video
column49:
a parody of "Like a Boss" by the comedy group The Lonely Island. The video highlights a savvy Internet of Things (IoT) user and is meant to highlight Boschâs connected products.Â 
The campaign has thousands of mentions and 96 percent of them are positive.Â 
8. Dove - #ShowUs
Dove partnered with Girlgaze and Getty Images for Project #ShowUs
column50: building the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s largest stock photo library created by women and non-binary individuals to shatter beauty stereotypes. With these images
column51: Dove hopes to create an inclusive vision of beauty in media and advertising.\u00c2\u00a0\nThe campaign has 3
column52: 756 Twitter mentions with a more than 90 percent positive reaction. One of the most liked and shared posts is from Shondaland\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Twitter account
column53: the media company behind Grey's Anatomy
column54:
Scandal and How to Get Away with Murder.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
9. Gillette - #TheBestMenCanBe
In January
column55: Gillette launched \"The Best Men Can Be
column56: \u00e2\u0080\u009d a social responsibility advertising campaign to address toxic masculinity and promote organizations that help men achieve their personal best. This was a divisive campaign
column57: yet the majority of mentions were fiercely positive.\u00c2\u00a0\nTop themes and phrases of discussion associated with the campaign included \u00e2\u0080\u009cwell done Gillette\u00e2\u0080\u009d and \u00e2\u0080\u009ctoxic masculinity.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Gillette\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Tweet from January 14th is one of the most popular Tweets in this campaign. Many celebrities drove a spike in mentions
column58:
including actress Melissa Fumero who had a strong positive reaction on Twitter.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
10. Coca-Cola - #OrangeVanilla In February
column59: Coca-Cola unveiled its first new flavor of Coke in over a decade: Coca-Cola Orange Vanilla. The summer-themed flavor contributed to over a billion reactions on social media and stronger than expected sales.\u00c2\u00a0\nMore than 21
column60: 000\u00c2\u00a0 people on Twitter mentioned #OrangeVanilla. While a good amount of people weren\u00e2\u0080\u0099t huge fans of the flavor choice
column61: the majority still reacted with happiness.\u00c2\u00a0\nSprinklr\u00e2\u0080\u0099s data analysis also showed that Atlanta loves Orange Vanilla Coke. Out of every public post that had an identifiable location
column62: the top five cities where people mentioned Orange Vanilla Coke with the most positive sentiment on Twitter include: Atlanta
column63: Chicago
column64: Los Angeles
column65: Houston
column66:
and Dallas.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Another example of Coke making a connection with their fans was on World Kindness Day.Â  Coke reached out on Twitter to find out what #KindnessStartsWith. Twenty Coca-Cola markets activated across the globe around World Kindness Day on Twitter with 6 languages in the creative. Their goal was to spread optimism and joy to others by continuing their work from WKD 2018 to make the internet a kinder
column67: more optimistic place. In 2019
column68: Coca-Cola expanded their message to energize people globally by listening and starting a conversation with consumers about what kindness means to them. \nCare More\u00c2\u00a0 Brands like these make their customers happy by listening to them and showing them love. Using customer insights to create memorable campaigns that evoke a strong emotional reaction is the key to a winning strategy.\nSprinklr\u00e2\u0080\u0099s analysis of brand campaigns includes Tweets from January 1st 2019 to September 1st
column69: 2019 in 93 languages. The ranking analyzed Fortune 500 companies and government agencies to pull out the top 10 brands
column70: and takes into account the amount of mentions a brand received\u00c2\u00a0 around its campaign
column71: and how many of those mentions are positive. To learn more about Sprinklr
column72:
head to partners.twitter.com
Â

column3: "title": "Strengthening our Trust and Safety Council"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nStrengthening our Trust and Safety Council\nFriday
column8: 13 December 2019\nLink copied successfully\nIn 2016
column9: we established the Twitter Trust and Safety Council
column10: which brings together more than 40 experts and organizations to help advise us as we develop our products
column11: programs and the Twitter Rules. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been discussing internally and with the current members how we can make sure the Council best serves the people who use Twitter
column12: and heard feedback that we needed to broaden membership to include a more diverse range of voices and organize members to have deeper conversations.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nGoing forward
column13: the Council will be made up of several groups
column14: each focused on advising us on important issues that contribute to real-world harm. These are difficult areas to discuss
column15: so it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s even more important to ensure these topics have dedicated time and are understood as unique challenges in their own right. In 2020
column16:
we will initially set up groups focused on:
Safety and online harassment
Human and digital rights
Child sexual exploitation
Suicide prevention and mental health
These four groups cover topics that are critical to ensuring people feel safe
column17: and will be a crucial part in helping us learn how we can move faster to address emerging trends and risks. Focusing on these issues will help us more quickly adapt and address new trends and risks to consider. By bringing together a wider and more diverse range of perspectives
column18: we hope to engage in more substantial discussion of these issues.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll also set up temporary working groups on other topics that will be better addressed in conversation with organisations that have related expertise
column19: including those who may not already be members of the Council. One such group will work on the issues we face as we broaden our interpretation of dehumanization.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Coming Next\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll share more on how we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll expand the Council to include experts from more countries and perspectives not yet represented as well as other ways we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll gather feedback from people
column20: including details of which groups will be participating in the working groups. We are currently talking to existing members and potential new members about this.\u00c2\u00a0\nA lot of what we currently do
column21: such as ongoing meetings with NGOs
column22: activists and other organizations is always part of our process
column23:
but we havenât done enough to share that externally. The feedback and advice we receive from them makes Twitter better and safer. Expect us to communicate more of our thinking moving forward.Â 
Weâre grateful for the continued support and engagement from our partners around the world and look forward to collaborating with even more groups in the future.Â 
Â

column3: "title": "Helping identify 2020 US election candidates on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Helping identify 2020 US election candidates on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 12 December 2019\nLink copied successfully\nWhen voters look for the latest breaking news and political commentary during an election
column9: they turn to Twitter to find it directly from the source. That can range from a journalist reporting from the campaign trail
column10: a government office providing voting resources
column11: or a politician sharing their stance on an issue.\nWith just under a year until US Election Day and two months until the first votes are cast in the Iowa caucus
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re launching two initiatives that will help people find original sources of information on Twitter by clearly identifying political candidates.\nFirst
column13: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re bringing back Election Labels
column14: which we first launched during the 2018 US midterm election. These labels received overwhelmingly positive feedback from voters and candidates
column15: and they played a prominent role in election conversation: In the week before Election Day
column16: people on Twitter saw Labeled accounts approximately 100 million times each day
column17: and 13% of US election conversation on Twitter included a Tweet with an Election Label.\u00c2\u00a0\nSecond
column18: starting this week
column19: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll start identifying candidates who qualify for the primary ballot for US House
column20: US Senate
column21: and Gubernatorial races with a verified badge.\nFor both primary candidate verification and Election Labels
column22: we are partnering with Ballotpedia
column23: as we did in 2018
column24: to utilize their expertise in identifying the official campaign Twitter accounts of candidates.\nWhat are Election Labels?\nElection Labels provide information about political candidates
column25: like the office they are running for
column26: their state and district number
column27: and contain a small ballot box icon. The Label will appear on the profile page of a candidate\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Twitter account and on every Tweet sent and Retweeted by the candidate\u00e2\u0080\u0099s account
column28:
even when embedded on sites off of Twitter. See below how the labels will look:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Which candidates will qualify for election labels?
Labels will appear on the Twitter accounts of candidates running for US House of Representatives
column29: US Senate
column30: or Governor in the 2020 US election who have qualified for the general election ballot.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhen will election labels appear?\nYou\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll start seeing Labels appear on applicable candidates\u00e2\u0080\u0099 Twitter accounts once the candidate has qualified for the general election ballot. This will happen on a rolling basis as states have different caucus and election dates
column31: with the first occurring on March 3rd.\nWhich candidates will be verified and when?\nStarting today
column32: Twitter will begin verifying the campaign Twitter accounts of candidates who have qualified for primary elections for the US House of Representatives
column33: US Senate
column34: and Governor
column35: and have been identified by our research partners at Ballotpedia. Again
column36: this will happen on a rolling basis as states have different filing deadlines.\nWhat is Ballotpedia?\nTwitter is partnering with Ballotpedia
column37: a civic nonprofit organization that publishes nonpartisan information on federal
column38: state
column39: and local politics
column40:
to help identify the campaign Twitter accounts of candidates once they qualify for the general election ballot for an applicable office.
Whatâs Next?
Stay tuned as we continue to focus on building tools that better enable people to find quality news and have informative conversations on Twitter.
