column3: "title": "Giving a helping hand to communities on #TwitterForGood Day - Fall 2019"
column7:
"post_text": "Events
Giving a helping hand to communities on #TwitterForGood Day - Fall 2019
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 5 December 2019\nLink copied successfully\nAt Twitter
column9: we care deeply about improving the communities we work and live in. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why twice a year
column10: thousands of our employees participate in various charity
column11: philanthropic
column12: and community-based projects as part of our #TwitterForGood global initiatives.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur latest #TwitterForGood Day took place in November and saw 1
column13: 600 Twitter employees commit more than 4
column14: 740 hours of service in 22 cities around the world. From Dubai to Dublin and Sydney to Sao Paulo
column15: volunteers served meals
column16: taught STEM skills to school children
column17: cleaned parks
column18:
and much more!
Check out how Twitter employees around the world spent the day by scrolling down for updates!
APAC
Sydney
Twitter Australia (@TwitterAU) prepared meals in partnership with Our Big Kitchen (@OurBigKitchen)
column19: a community-run
column20: industrial kitchen in the heart of Sydney. Through food rescue programs like SecondBite and Foodbank
column21: OBK minimises food waste by turning fresh produce into a home cooked meal. By providing a place where people from all walks of life can connect through doing good
column22: volunteers spent the afternoon with the OBK team to prepare and cook meals for distribution to shelters across the state
column23:
which support families in need.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Jakarta
Twitter employees in Jakarta partnered with Girls in Tech Indonesia (@girlsintechID) to share best practices and provide practical workshops on how to âlisten
column24: inspire
column25: find
column26: and engage\u00e2\u0080\u009d on Twitter and connect with various online communities; including sharing insights and tips about content creation to increase presence on the platform.\u00c2\u00a0\nPhilippines\nTwitter Philippines (@TwitterPH) partnered with Mental Health Philippines (@mentalhealthph) and Dr. Gia Sison (@giasison) in Manila to host an event to create awareness about mental health. The conversation took place on Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Q&A VIT app
column27: where questions were asked and discussed both offline and online. The hashtag #AskDocG was used to drive conversation around this important discussion.\nThere were approximately 50 people in attendance for #TwitterForGood day
column28: including NGO partners
column29: the public
column30: and Twitter employees. This event was a great opportunity to highlight the launch of #ThereIsHelp
column31: a notification service on Twitter which provides valuable mental health resources to vulnerable people
column32:
and encourages them to reach out and get help when they need it.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Seoul
Twitter Korea (@TwitterKorea) partnered with the Hansol Social Welfare Center (@hansolwf) to provide meal services to senior citizens
column33: embodying the #TwitterForGood spirit in the holiday season. At the onset of the day
column34: the Center\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Head
column35: buddhist monk Kasup (@kasupmaha)
column36:
highlighted how the Center is actively leveraging the power of Twitter in sharing and promoting the philanthropic efforts at the local district level in the city of Seongnam. Team Korea delivered a total of 100 lunch boxes and served 200 special meals to the elderly. Major shout out to the dishwasher team of five Twitter volunteers that spared no effort in ensuring the smooth running of the kitchen!Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Singapore
Twitter Singapore (@TwitterSG) kick started #TwitterforGood Day at Food Bank Singaporeâs warehouse. Twitter employees helped with stocktaking
column37:
packing and storing of food donations received by Food Bank Singapore. Food Bank Singaporeâs mission is to bridge the gap in the market by collecting surplus food in the market and providing it to people and organizations in need of food.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitter Singapore also partnered with Roses of Peace (@rosesofpeace)
column38: a youth-driven organization that fosters a culture of interfaith appreciation in Singapore by building bridges between diverse communities. Twitter Singapore hosted underprivileged youth for an afternoon
column39: many of whom had never visited a tech company. Volunteers teamed up to teach youth how to code. We also conducted a digital literacy session
column40:
teaching these youth how to be safe on Twitter.Â 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tokyo
A range of #TwitterForGood initiatives took place at TwitterJapan (@TwitterJapan) in the lead up to #TwitterForGood Day. Employees partnered with Doctors without Borders (@MSFJapan) and visited elementary schools to teach a class on the value of onesâ lives and the significance of the work of the international NGO.
Some employees played futsal with teenagers who are part of Tracos (@NPO_TRACOS). Tracos is a long-term partner of ours and provides futsal trainings for those who have disabilities. Twitter volunteers visited the office of Rebit (@Re_Bit) and helped assemble their teaching materialsâ kit on diversity focusing on LGBTQ issues for elementary school pupils and junior high school students on 22 November. While volunteering
column41: Twitter volunteers were also able to learn about LGBTQ issues
column42: which was certainly a valuable experience for them.\nAdditionally
column43: on December 6th
column44:
approximately a third of Japanese employees participated in the most popular community clean-up activity with Chuo Ward (@chuo_city).Â  Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
India 
@TwitterIndiaÂ partnered with LetMeBreathe (@LetMeBreathe_In) to build floating wetlands
column45: an eco-friendly and cost-effective method to clean one of the oldest bodies of water
column46: Hauz Khas Lake in Delhi that dates back to the 14th century. India Tweeps came together to create two wetlands or islands from scratch using recycled bottles and coir that are designed to function as a self-sustaining ecosystem and clean the lake by soaking-up all the pollutants. Named as Tweet and Retweet
column47:
the islands will not only support revival of the lake but also function as a habitat for migratory birds.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Europe
Twitter Dublin (@TwitterDublin) employees put their pedals to the metal on #TwitterForGood Day as they kicked off a 600km #CycleForGood
column48: travelling the equivalent of the distance from Malin Head to Mizen Head (the length of Ireland)
column49: to raise funds for the housing and homelessness charity Peter McVerry Trust (@PMVTrust). Employees in Dublin set a fundraising target of \u00e2\u0082\u00ac10
column50: 000 for the #HomesForGood campaign by the end of 2019
column51: with the funds going towards support services for those who have recently been housed by theTrust. They raised a whopping \u00e2\u0082\u00ac11
column52: 181 in total so far. The office activities were included in radio broadcasts around the country spreading the #TwitterForGood message.\u00c2\u00a0 \nOther #TwitterForGood initiatives which took place throughout the day
column53: included welcoming a group of school children who learned about careers and digital literacy skills. Delegates from a number of Irish charities and NGOs also joined employees for training and to learn more about Twitter best practices. Employees also hosted a #WelcomeHomeStarterKits making session
column54: filling kits with donated items like
column55: washing powder
column56: cleaning products as well as coffee mugs & coffee
column57: to get those moving into their new homes with Peter McVerry Trust off to a great start. Other fundraising activities including Christmas wreath making
column58: a \u00e2\u0080\u0098Twizzle\u00e2\u0080\u0099 table quiz
column59:
and a leadership auction.

London
Twitter UK (@TwitterUK) hosted a range of #TwitterForGood activities throughout the month of November. These included a charity bake sale for Housing for Women
column60: and a gift drive for AgeUK (@ageukwest) Westminster\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Christmas dinner. Some employees also spent a day with Dogs Trust (@dogstrust)
column61: the UK\u00e2\u0080\u0099s largest dog welfare charity
column62: where they assisted by spending time with the dogs)
column63: making snuffle mats
column64: filling kongs
column65: and sorting donations.\u00c2\u00a0\nLater in the month
column66: employees volunteered with Haven House
column67: a childrens\u00e2\u0080\u0099 hospice
column68: where they helped the hospice prepare for its Christmas Craft Day by making and hanging decorations
column69: sorting Santa\u00e2\u0080\u0099s grotto and decorating communal areas of the hospice. Going forward
column70: Twitter UK will build on this partnership further by enabling staff to volunteer in Haven House stores
column71:
which help raise funds for the childrensâ hospice.

Twitter Deutschland (@TwitterDE) joined Volunteer Boerse Hamburg to help build a garden for people with dementia. They cleaned paths
column72: planted flowers
column73: cut hedges and disposed of leaves. Thanks to the teams\u00e2\u0080\u0099 work
column74:
the residents can relax in a new pavilion and enjoy the impressions of the garden next spring!
This Tweet is unavailable

          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Spain
Twitter Espana (@TwitterEspana) volunteered at the logistics center of the Red Cross and Red Half Moon (@RSCruzRojaMad) in the city. The team heard from passionate volunteers who provided a wide overview of the Red Cross
column75: and how the logistic center gives support to people all around the world. Volunteers spent the rest of the morning selecting
column76:
categorizing and organizing the textile material to be offered to people in need.Â

Twitter Paris (@TwitterParis) went to Samusocial de Paris (@SamuSocialParis) headquarters where volunteers helped sort and wrap clothes and toys for youth in local shelters at Christmas. Samusocial de Paris runs a variety of activities including social service assistance
column77: shelter
column78:
and clothing and household donations for people living in shelters.Â

Twitter celebrated its first ever #TwitterForGood day in Belgium this year. On this occasion
column79: the team joined forces with Serve the City Brussels (@stcbrussels)
column80: part of the global movement of volunteers Serve the City
column81:
to prepare and serve breakfast to approximately 250 refugees and homeless.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable

US & Canada
BostonÂ 
Partnering with the Greater Boston Food Bank
column82: 25 employees sorted and packed 8
column83: 248 lbs of food which translated into making 6
column84:
873 meals possible for families across Eastern Massachusetts. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.

San Francisco
Twitter San Francisco (@TwitterSF) was out in full force on #TwitterForGood Day â 550 employees volunteered for 2382 hours at 35 projects across the city! Volunteers removed invasive plants from a quarter-mile stretch along the shore of Ocean Beach with the SF Parks Alliance (@SFParksAlliance);explored innovative ways to teach digital citizenship with Common Sense Media (@CommonSense); taught STEM skills to an emerging generation of school-aged children with Catholic Charities (@CatholicCSF)
column86: and Play-Well Tek (@PlayWell_TEK); explored career options with job seekers from dev/mission (@devmissionorg) and JVS (@JVSBayArea);\u00c2\u00a0 got their hands dirty in the community garden at the Tenderloin Neighborhood Community Development (@TNDC);\u00c2\u00a0 taught yoga to kids from West Bay Pilipino Community Center (@WestBayCenterSF); and much more! Thanks to all of our volunteers and partners
column87:
we had an amazing experience bringing together our company and community â all in a dayâs work for #TwitterForGood.

Toronto
@TwitterCanada came out in full force for #TwitterForGood this fall
column88: participating in a series of events that allowed employees to apply their skills and develop some new ones.\u00c2\u00a0\nInitiatives included building wheelchair ramps for local accessibility organization
column89: StopGap Foundation (@StopGapRamp)

where local businesses and partner learned how they can be part of a homeless solution for Toronto.Â

Supporting its local community

column105: while some cleaned and re-designed the youth room at Watts Empowerment Center and built new computer chairs for the media center.\nWith Safe Place for Youth

clothing and all basic necessities.Â

Seattle
Forty-three Twitter volunteers from our Seattle office partnered with Food Lifeline (@FoodLifeLine) and Maryâs Place (@MarysPlaceWA) as part of our #TwitterForGood activity this year.Â 
Food Lifelineâs mission is to feed people experiencing hunger today and work to end hunger for tomorrow
column110: so volunteers from Twitter joined a Volunteer Group onsite at the organisation.\u00c2\u00a0\nSix volunteers from the Seattle office traveled to the Food Lifeline facility and helped sort
column112: and package food products to be distributed to various food banks in the Greater Seattle Area
column113: while 30 employees based at the Twitter Seattle office
column114: helped package meal kits to be donated to Food Lifeline that will be distributed among local food banks to families in need.\nThe mission for Mary\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Place is to provide safe
column115: inclusive shelter and services that support women
column116: children & families on their journey out of homelessness.\nKeeping that in mind
column117: four Seattle volunteers undertook an online monetary fundraiser to supply the new Marketplace & Family Diversion Center created by Mary\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Place. Donations were needed to help supply shelves
column119: and hooks to set up the facility.\nFour other volunteers then set up an off-site volunteer group to help set up the new Marketplace & Family Diversion Center created by Mary\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Place

where families in need can get all of their essentials like clothing and home items.

Boulder 
Boulder employees spent this #TwitterForGood day volunteering with a number of local organizations to support our community. This included Boulder Community Cycles (@CommunityCycles)

where Tweeps helped repair donated kids bikes to regift this holiday season; @YWCABoulder where Tweeps read to kids and helped clean up the playground; Boulder Bridge House (@bobridgehouse); a local transitional housing provider where tweeps helped clean the transitional housing facility; and Douglas Land Conservancy (@DLConservancy) where Tweeps helped set up a new filing system and update a website.

and organize books in the library. Employees enjoyed and learned from the kids as much as they did from them!Â

and gardening.Â

Upcoming #TwitterForGood activity - December
Hong Kong 
On December 16

The initiative invited youth based in the UAE to use the power of Twitter by creating an account that would fuel philanthropic efforts in their community.\nThe winning account

column3: "title": "The path to innovation starts with the customer"
column7:
"post_text": "lowTint
The path to innovation starts with the customer
                By
                
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 4 December 2019\nLink copied successfully\nAccording to McKinsey
column9: 80% of executives think their current business models are at risk to be disrupted in the near future. In addition
column10: 84% of executives say that innovation is important to their growth strategy. In a one week period
column11: Twitter logged over 100K appearances of #innovation. It feels like literally EVERYONE is talking about innovation. Electronics companies
column12: fast food chains
column13: insurance providers
column14: airlines - I could go on - they all see innovation as a path forward into the future - whether that future be one of improved customer experiences
column15: greater efficiency
column16: increased profits
column17: continuing relevance or all four.\u00c2\u00a0\nYet
column18: according to Harvard professor and best-selling author Clayton Christensen
column19: 95% of all product innovations fail. Those are daunting odds.\u00c2\u00a0\nSo
column20: what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a business to do? Many experts assert that the answer partially lies with the customer. Specifically
column21: businesses need to identify the \u00e2\u0080\u009cwhy\u00e2\u0080\u009d behind customer actions and choices - what need are they trying to meet when they purchase a product or service?\u00c2\u00a0 What is the context surrounding that decision? That deeper understanding of the customer will surface opportunities to innovate.\nIf you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re a customer experience (CX) professional
column22: this should be great news. Isn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t your whole \u00e2\u0080\u009craison d\u00e2\u0080\u0099\u00c3\u00a8tre\u00e2\u0080\u009d all about understanding the customer? The question is
column23: how well do you really know your customers? And
column24: to build on that
column25: is your current customer program generating the types of insights that uncover the context critical to discovering opportunities to innovate?\nUsing social media data with traditional survey data for deeper consumer insights\nUncovering context is tough. Certainly
column26: traditional voice of the customer (VoC) surveys have served CX professionals well by providing a high-level measurement of their customer\u00e2\u0080\u0099s overall satisfaction as well as identifying ongoing concerns and/or gaps in customer experience. But
column27: because surveys are by their very nature directive
column28: i.e. the company determines the questions and the timing
column29: not to mention they are usually completed after the customer experience in a sterile format
column30: they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re unlikely to be very good at revealing the circumstances and emotions surrounding a customer interaction.\nOn Twitter
column31: people share hundreds of millions of Tweets every day. And
column32: at every stage of the customer journey
column33: through their Tweets
column34: they are signalling satisfaction
column35: concerns
column36: frictions
column37: and yes
column38: context. They are not only expressing how they feel but why they feel that way. And
column39: thanks to\u00c2\u00a0social listening tools
column40: \u00c2\u00a0you can easily tap into these conversations
column41: \u00c2\u00a0uncovering insights in real-time\u00c2\u00a0as well as historical patterns. When combined with other more traditional data from sources like surveys or focus groups
column42: that additional context provides a fuller picture of your customers
column43: allowing your business to know them on a deeper level
column44: uncovering hidden opportunities to innovate.\nOf the six key success factors identified in PWC\u00e2\u0080\u0099s\u00c2\u00a02018 Global Innovation 1000\u00c2\u00a0study
column45: coming in at number four is \u00e2\u0080\u009cbase innovation on direct insights from end-users\u00e2\u0080\u009d. Of course
column46: there are many factors that feed into innovation success
column47: but identifying innovation opportunities that will resonate with your customers is a critical first step.\nYour customers are talking right now
column48:
providing you with the clues and context to identify your next big innovation. Are you ready to start listening? Get inspired atÂ data.twitter.comÂ with case studies that illustrate the power of social listening.

column8: 3 December 2019\nLink copied successfully\nUpdated May 13th
column9: 2020\nWhether you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re launching a new campaign or a new product
column10: or want to build cultural relevance among your audience
column11: chances are you are looking to drive marketing objectives such as brand lift. In some instances
column12: marketers may not be able to measure their campaigns\u00e2\u0080\u0099 branding impact as they are bounded by survey study minimums -- but what good is a campaign if we don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t understand how it moves awareness
column13: consideration
column14: intent
column15: or other key branding goals?\u00c2\u00a0 \nTo help marketers measure how their campaigns are driving brand lift
column16: we are making Twitter Brand Surveys available for managed accounts in North America
column17: South America
column18: Asia Pacific
column19: Europe and Middle East. We developed Twitter Brand Surveys while keeping accessibility and actionability in mind -- we wanted campaigns
column20: big or small
column21: to have access to survey studies and for brands to understand which specific Tweets drove the highest lift. This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. Your browser does not support the video element. Play Play Pause Seek 0% buffered 00:00 Current time 00:00 Duration 00:00 Toggle Mute Volume Low minimum media spend Twitter Brand Surveys is a 1st party solution
column22: allowing us to offer a low minimum media spend requirement while still delivering statistically significant results. This gives marketers the opportunity to scale survey studies beyond large campaigns. Contact your Twitter account rep to learn more about the minimum spend in your region.\u00c2\u00a0\nActionable insights through Creative Attribution\nTwitter Brand Survey reports provide insights beyond topline results -- they deliver insights into how certain elements of your campaign and creatives are driving brand lift. We developed a proprietary Creative Attribution model to identify the Promoted Tweet or In-Stream Video Ad responsible for high and low brand lift
column23: which helps marketers hone their creative strategy for the future.\u00c2\u00a0\nAdditionally
column24: marketers can learn how the frequency of their ad exposure affects brand metrics or understand the lift in message association for their brand and its competitors (hint: if there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a lift for your competitor
column25: perhaps the creative and messaging is not differentiated enough).\nQuick reporting turnaround\nTo help marketers fine-tune campaign and creative strategy for future campaigns in a timely manner
column26: Twitter strives to deliver reports to clients within 10 business days after the campaign ends.\u00c2\u00a0\nMany brands have already started using Twitter Brand Surveys to understand how their campaigns are driving brand lift.\u00c2\u00a0\nFor the launch of its new Pandora Reflexions\u00e2\u0084\u00a2 collection
column27: Pandora (\u00e2\u0080\u008e@PANDORA_NA) partnered with Mindshare and Twitter to drive awareness of their new line and used Twitter Brand Survey to measure results. The insights from Twitter Brand Surveys quantified Pandora\u00e2\u0080\u0099s success
column28: revealing statistically significant increases in campaign awareness
column29: consideration
column30:
and Tweet recall. It also helped Pandora reinforce its current campaign and creative strategy for the future. You can find more info on the success story here.

column31: shared

column34: Pandora Jewelry\n\u00e2\u0080\u008e@charissekay\u00e2\u0080\u008e\nIf you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re interested in running brand survey studies on your campaigns and want to learn more about which countries it is available in

column3: "title": "What we have been doing to protect your privacy and data"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
What we have been doing to protect your privacy and data
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 2 December 2019\nLink copied successfully\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s so common to hear tech companies say: \u00e2\u0080\u009cPrivacy is not a privilege; it is a fundamental right\u00e2\u0080\u009d that those words have become a cliche. People have become desensitized to hearing companies say
column9: \u00e2\u0080\u009cwe value your privacy
column10: \u00e2\u0080\u009d and are worn out from being asked to accept privacy policies that they rarely
column11: if ever
column12: even read. Many companies make these declarations without even showing people what actions they are taking to protect their privacy. And let's be honest
column13: we have room for improvement too.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe believe companies should be accountable to the people that trust them with their personal information
column14: and responsible not only to protect that information but to explain how they do it.\u00c2\u00a0\nThat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re launching the Twitter Privacy Center to provide more clarity around what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re doing to protect the information people share with us. It is the central place that host\u00e2\u0080\u0099s everything that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s part of our privacy and data protection work: related initiatives
column15: announcements
column16: new privacy products
column17: and communication about security incidents. It should be easier to find and learn more about the work we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re doing to keep your data secure
column18: including what data we collect
column19: how we use it
column20: and the controls you have.\nHow we think about Privacy and Data Protection at Twitter\nPeople\u00e2\u0080\u0099s right to privacy and data protection is something we have fought to protect since Twitter was created in 2006. From the beginning
column21: we have offered a range of ways for people to be part of the conversation on Twitter on their terms \u00e2\u0080\u0093 from creating pseudonymous accounts to protect their identity to letting people control who sees their Tweets. But what people see externally is not the sum of our work. Behind the scenes
column22: teams across the company are constantly working to protect your privacy and data. This work has three areas of focus:\nFix technical debt. Twitter has changed a lot since the first Tweet was sent almost 14 years ago. As was
column23: and still is
column24: common in fast-growing tech companies
column25: we built new features and services on top of older systems. In some cases
column26: the older systems were never made to support their current uses \u00e2\u0080\u0094 that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s technical debt. Tackling technical debt is an ongoing challenge for every company
column27: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been doing it for years. This work isn't just good for the privacy and safety of people who use Twitter
column28: it's also good for business. It will help us get better products and services to you faster. Also
column29: you may have noticed that we have been communicating more data and security related disclosures over the last two years. Many of those are the direct result of these efforts. We have been working to make sure our systems meet your expectations
column30: and when they don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t or when we have found issues that may require your attention to keep you safe and secure
column31: we have told you about them. We'll continue to do this when something requires your attention.\u00c2\u00a0\nBuild privacy into the products we launch. Privacy by design is a priority with every product we build. To achieve this
column32: we continue to build out our processes to review the products we launch. This process involves our Information Security
column33: Product and Privacy Counsel teams
column34: and our independent Office of Data Protection. This is critical work that we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re continuing to invest in. Every new employee goes through data privacy
column35: security
column36: and management training. We launched an internal group called Twitter Doves
column37: which is designed to cultivate the best data privacy
column38: security and management practices for everyone at the company. The Doves\u00e2\u0080\u0099 motto
column39: \"trust is earned
column40: not given
column41: \" guides best practices we adhere to across Twitter. Finally
column42: we're speaking with people around the world to better understand how different cultures and groups think about privacy and what they expect when they share their information with a company like ours. For example
column43: through the initial findings from this research
column44: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve learned that \u00e2\u0080\u009cmeaningful controls\u00e2\u0080\u009d have different connotations depending on where you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re from. This kind of feedback is critical to us as we build the privacy and data controls people want when they use Twitter.\nKeep ourselves accountable to the people that trust us with their data. We know that there is no silver bullet that will make people trust us with their data. However
column45: we also know that to keep your trust we have to show you we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re accountable. We have already taken a variety of steps to weave accountability into how we operate. Our Data Protection Officer
column46: Damien Kieran
column47: provides an independent assessment of all privacy and data protection-related work to our board of directors on a quarterly basis to make sure we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re appropriately discussing any issues and concerns we have and to drive alignment on what matters from a data protection perspective. We are continuing to invest in our Data Management Organization so that we can always account for the data we have
column48: how it is used
column49: and when it is shared. To make sure everyone at Twitter is accountable
column50: privacy and data protection is the heart of our 2020 company-wide priority to build products that earn the trust of people who use them. Also
column51:
launching the Twitter Privacy Center provides a central place to keep you updated on our privacy and data protection work and aid us in being accountable to you through transparency.Â 
Twitter is not perfect at privacy and data protection. But we want you to know our statements are not a cliche but backed by an evolving privacy and data protection program intended to keep your data secure and us accountable.Â 
Â

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "More control over your conversations: now available globally"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
More control over your conversations: now available globally
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 21 November 2019\nLink copied successfully\nEveryone should feel safe and comfortable while talking on Twitter. To make this happen
column9: we need to change how conversations work on our service. Currently
column10: repliers can shift the topic or tone of a discussion and derail what you and your audience want to talk about. To give you more control over the conversations you start
column11: we tested the option for you to hide replies to your Tweets. We learned that the feature is a useful new way to manage your conversations. Today
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re making this available to everyone globally.\u00c2\u00a0\nHere\u00e2\u0080\u0099s how it works. Anyone can choose to hide replies to their Tweets. Everyone can see and engage with hidden replies by tapping the grey icon that will appear on the Tweets. This way
column13: you have more control over the conversations you start
column14:
but people can still see the entire conversation.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Hereâs what we learned during our tests:
People mostly hide replies they think are irrelevant
column15: off-topic
column16: or annoying. \nThe option is a new way to shut out noise; 85% of the people who hide replies are not using block or mute. \nPeople were curious to see how public figures like those in politics and journalism would use this update. So far
column17: they aren't hiding replies very often.\nIn Canada
column18: 27% of people who had their Tweets hidden said they would reconsider how they interact with others in the future. Also
column19: they thought it was a helpful way to manage what they saw
column20: similar to muted keywords.\nWe learned that you may want to take further action after you hide a reply
column21:
so now weâll check to see if you want to also block the replier.
Some people mentioned that they didnât want to hide replies due to fear of retaliation as the icon remains visible. Weâll continue to get feedback on this.
These are early findings and we look forward to continued learning as the feature is used by more people. 
Looking ahead
column22: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re working on new controls and more clarity around the rules of conversation spaces. Soon
column23: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be launching a new hide replies endpoint so developers can build additional conversation management tools. We're exploring more options around who can reply to or see specific conversations
column24: and are testing engagement changes to see if these lead to healthier discussions. We're committed to making sure people feel safe and comfortable talking on Twitter.\nThe option to hide replies is rolling out globally on iOS
column25: Android
column26: Twitter Lite
column27:
and twitter.com. Let us know what you think!Â 
Â

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Help us shape our approach to synthetic and manipulated media"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nHelp us shape our approach to synthetic and manipulated media\nMonday
column8: 11 November 2019\nLink copied successfully\nWhen you come to Twitter to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in the world
column9: we want you to have context about the content you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re seeing and engaging with. Deliberate attempts to mislead or confuse people through manipulated media undermine the integrity of the conversation.  That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we recently announced our plan to seek public input on a new rule to address synthetic and manipulated media. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve called for public feedback previously because we want to ensure that \u00e2\u0080\u0094 as an open service\u00c2\u00a0\u00e2\u0080\u0094 our rules reflect the voice of the people who use Twitter. We think it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s critical to consider global perspectives
column10: as well as make our content moderation decisions easier to understand.  What is synthetic and manipulated media?  The Twitter Rules
column11: the service
column12: and its features are always evolving
column13: based on new behavior we see online. We routinely consult with experts and researchers to help us understand new issues like synthetic and manipulated media. Based on these conversations
column14: we propose defining synthetic and manipulated media as any photo
column15: audio
column16:
or video that has been significantly altered or fabricated in a way that intends to mislead people or changes its original meaning. These are sometimes referred to as deepfakes or shallowfakes.  Hereâs a draft of what weâll do when we see synthetic and manipulated media that purposely tries to mislead or confuse people:  Twitter may:
place a notice next to Tweets that share synthetic or manipulated media;
warn people before they share or like Tweets with synthetic or manipulated media; or
add a link â for example
column17: to a news article or Twitter Moment \u00e2\u0080\u0093 so that people can read more about why various sources believe the media is synthetic or manipulated.\nIn addition
column18: if a Tweet including synthetic or manipulated media is misleading and could threaten someone's physical safety or lead to other serious harm
column19: we may remove it.  We want to hear from you You\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll find here a brief survey
column20: which is available in English
column21: Hindi
column22: Arabic
column23: Spanish
column24: Portuguese
column25: and Japanese. For languages not represented here
column26: our team is working closely with local non-governmental organizations and policymakers to ensure their perspectives are represented.  If you prefer to Tweet your feedback
column27: we'll be listening there
column28: too. Use the hashtag #TwitterPolicyFeedback.  Additionally
column29: if you\u00e2\u0080\u0099d like to partner with us to develop solutions to detect synthetic and manipulated media
column30: fill out this form.  The feedback period will close on Wednesday
column31: Nov. 27 at 11:59 p.m. GMT. At that point
column32: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll review the input we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve received
column33: make adjustments
column34: and begin the process of incorporating the policy into the Twitter Rules
column35:
as well as train our enforcement teams on how to handle this content. We will make another announcement at least 30 days before the policy goes into effect.  Weâre committed to serving the public conversation on Twitter and doing our work in an open and transparent manner. Thank you for taking the time to be part of this process â we look forward to hearing what you think.

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "But
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/insights/2019/but-how-do-you-really-feel"
column8: "post_text": "Insights\nBut
column9:
how do you really feel?
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column10:
6 November 2019
Link copied successfully
Emotion - the holy grail of customer insight
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Consumer research has come a long way. From focus groups to behavioral analytics to neuroscience techniques â todayâs research professionals wield a wide array of techniques and tools - from the simple to the more sophisticated - all to better understand people and their behaviour as consumers. Couple this with the power of big data analytics
column11: and you might think the picture of today\u00e2\u0080\u0099s consumer is all but complete. And yet
column12: is there a single business who can confidently say that they really know their customers on an emotional level?\nIt turns out that we humans are emotional beings and
column13: not surprisingly
column14: that emotionality extends to consumer decision-making. As author and Harvard scholar Gerald Zaltman asserts
column15: 95% of decisions are made in the emotional domain1. Taken one step further
column16: consider the System 1 and System 2 theory posited by noted psychologists Kahneman and Tversky which echoes Zaltman \u00e2\u0080\u0093 the first impulse is always emotional and comes from our reptile brain
column17: which then gets processed (or not) by the rational neocortex. What that means for our understanding of the customer is that without intercepting that first impulse
column18: we can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t be sure we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re capturing the real intent; that raw
column19: unfiltered
column20: unprocessed response.\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not that we haven\u00e2\u0080\u0099t tried.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhether through focus groups or surveys
column21: we ask customers to share their feelings and motivations about our products and services
column22: as well as their purchase and post-purchase experience. But this approach to analyzing customer experience is limited. Because it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s done in a way that encourages filtered
column23: rationally processed and controlled retrospective responses
column24: the moment is lost and with it the emotion.\nSo
column25: how best to fulfil your quest for the holy grail of emotion?\nThe key is to capture unprompted reactions in the moment. While tapping directly into a consumer\u00e2\u0080\u0099s brain is unrealistic
column26: not to mention unethical
column27: there is one place where consumers are freely sharing their emotions
column28: unprompted
column29: in the moment. Every minute of every day
column30: people around the world are sharing their thoughts
column31: experiences and opinions as they happen on Twitter. More often than not
column32: emotion is part of the mix. When they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re feeling something about your brand or product
column33: those emotions often convert into action. Eileen had the best stay at your resort? Her friends take note and may visit. Kenny\u00e2\u0080\u0099s child wasn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t treated well at a drama camp? Other parents are now on alert. Diana found the interviewing experience at your company odd? Other potential recruits may opt to give it a pass.\nBy listening to those voices we not only have an unprecedented opportunity to engage directly with our customers and react quickly
column34: we can take it a step further by identifying insights that bring us closer than ever to understanding them on an emotional level. This deeper understanding can be put to work shaping better customer experiences my making emotional connections and ultimately driving greater customer satisfaction and brand affinity.\u00c2\u00a0\nWith traditional research
column35: it may take some time and effort to understand how your customers really feel. With Twitter
column36: you don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t need to ask the question \u00e2\u0080\u0093 you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll know before your surveys
column37: focus groups or sales data tell you.\nYour customers are talking. Are you ready to start listening? Get inspired at data.twitter.com with case studies that illustrate the power of social listening.\n1 How Customers Think: Essential Insights into the Mind of the Market
column38:

column3: "title": "18 trends that highlight fundamental shifts in culture"
column7: "post_text": "Insights\n18 trends that highlight fundamental shifts in culture\nMonday
column8: 4 November 2019\nLink copied successfully\nFrom \u00e2\u0080\u009cEthical Self\u00e2\u0080\u009d to \u00e2\u0080\u009cDIY Spirituality
column9: \u00e2\u0080\u009d Twitter reveals the fastest-growing conversations going into 2020\nKnowing that consumers expect brands to be culturally relevant
column10: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve always encouraged marketers to find authentic ways to connect with culture.\u00c2\u00a0\nToday
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re releasing hundreds of cultural insights from the conversation on Twitter
column12: to inspire and empower brands to develop campaigns on the leading edge of shifts in consumer behavior and beliefs.\nWe tapped into the largest catalog of human thought and conversation \u00e2\u0080\u0093 Twitter \u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00c2\u00a0 to analyze billions of Tweets over the past three years. Using machine learning to remove commonplace topics and fads
column13: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve uncovered hundreds of insights
column14: 18 of the fastest-evolving trends and 6 overarching themes. These reflect fundamental shifts in U.S. culture and provide a window into what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s starting to matter more and more to consumers as we enter a new decade.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve packaged all of these cultural insights into an immersive website
column15: which we are unveiling today
column16: and created a dedicated \u00e2\u0080\u009cTrend Pack\u00e2\u0080\u009d for each of the 18 trends that dives deep into conversation growth
column17: key drivers
column18: related hashtags
column19: emoji sentiment...and of course
column20:
Tweets.
And this is only the beginning: Weâll refresh these insights annually and will expand to additional markets in 2020.
The Big 6
Well-being: The human desire to live a happy
column21: healthy life continues to be a cultural priority
column22: but the focus has shifted from the outside in. Where body image
column23: diet
column24: and physical appearance once dominated the conversation
column25:
a healthy mind and whole-body wellness are starting to take center stage. Trends in this theme: Data-Driven Bodies | Holistic Health | Being Well Together
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Everyday Wonder:Â 
The more people learn about the universe
column26: the more in awe of it they become. They\u00e2\u0080\u0099re fascinated by the cosmos and everything it contains
column27: from the planets themselves
column28: to climate change and extreme weather
column29: to spiritual energy and healing. Trends in this theme: DIY Spirituality | In Awe of Nature | Cosmic Fascination\n\u00f0\u009f\u0093\u00a3Standout stat: Conversation around spiritual practices that were once considered \u00e2\u0080\u009cNew Age\u00e2\u0080\u009d in the US \u00e2\u0080\u0093 like yoga
column30: chakras
column31: Zen
column32: and mindfulness \u00e2\u0080\u0093 declined 45%. Meanwhile conversation around alternative spirituality \u00e2\u0080\u0093 like healing
column33: energy
column34: and astrology in relation to spiritual practices \u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00c2\u00a0 jumped 168%.\u00c2\u00a0\nCreator Culture:\u00c2\u00a0\nMakers
column35: builders
column36: and entrepreneurs have joined artists
column37: writers
column38: and musicians in the creative arena. They\u00e2\u0080\u0099re actively blurring the lines between work and personal passions
column39: reimagining the day job
column40:
and pushing creativity into mainstream culture. Trends in this theme: Creative Currency | Hustle Life | Connecting Through Video
ð£Standout stat: Unsigned musician hashtags have increased 113% as unsigned artists use Twitter to get buzz around their talents.
My Identity:
The concept of identity is broader than ever
column41: and people have never felt more empowered to be their true selves and make their own rules. They\u00e2\u0080\u0099re living out loud
column42: sharing their passions
column43: breaking stereotypes
column44:
and demanding more from society on issues of gender and diversity. Trends in this theme: Fandom | Gender Redefined | Represent Me
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
One Planet: 
More and more people are holding themselves
column45: their communities
column46: and businesses to higher standards when it comes to respecting the planet. As people take a hard look at the environmental costs of everyday life
column47:
theyâre becoming increasingly focused on taking action and finding innovative solutions to create a more sustainable culture. Trends in this theme: Ethical Self | Sustainable Steps | Clean Corporations
ð£Standout stat: The conversation around environmental veganism has lifted 235% as people discuss veganism as a means to safeguard the future of the planet.
Tech Life:Â 
Technology is continuing to change how people learn
column48: how they create
column49: and how they work. People are excited
column50: even if a bit uncertain at times
column51: about having a front-row seat to fundamental change
column52: and they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re imagining the possibilities of a more connected
column53: more efficient
column54: more expansive future. Trends in this theme: Blended Realities | Future Tech | Tech Angst\n\u00f0\u009f\u0093\u00a3Standout stat: Conversation about a fourth industrial revolution has grown 340% as people discuss their unpreparedness for change
column55: especially when it comes to the effects of AI and blockchain on the workforce.\nHow marketers can use these insights to connect to culture\nHaving this level of insight into the topics that are of growing importance to consumers is incredibly valuable in the creative development
column56: and even product development
column57: phases of marketing
column58: as well as participating in the conversation with consumers.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sharing these insights to help marketers stay on the leading edge of culture
column59:
and get a deeper understanding of whatâs starting to matter more to consumers. Our goal is to inspire powerful and award-winning campaigns in 2020.
Dive into all of our insights at: https://marketing.twitter.com/na/en/culture-and-conversations#/ 
Â 
Methodology:Â From January 1
column60: 2016 through June 30
column62: billions of Tweets were analyzed to uncover the most-used hashtags
column63: then mapped to cluster themes of conversation. Through both human coding and machine learning
column64: commonplace topics like politics and sports were removed
column65: and significant growth areas and contextual shifts in conversation identified. With the help of cultural insights experts at CrowdDNA
column66: 18 emerging trends were uncovered. Tools used: Twitter Internal
column67: Crimson Hexagon
column68: and Talkwalker. Tweet volumes at monthly increments
column69: geo-filtered for US market
column70:
growth stats compare Q2/2019 vs. Q1/2016.

column3: "title": "15th Transparency Report: Increase in proactive enforcement\u00a0on accounts "
column7:
"post_text": "Company
15th Transparency Report: Increase in proactive enforcementÂ on accounts 
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 31 October 2019\nLink copied successfully\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re continually striving to be more proactive and open in the work we do to serve the public conversation on Twitter. Part of that effort is our biannual Twitter Transparency Report
column9: which we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve produced since July 2012 to share global trends across a number of areas of our enforcement on Twitter
column10: including the Twitter Rules and legal requests we receive.\u00c2\u00a0\nThe report is ever-evolving. For the first time
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re incorporating data and insights regarding impersonation policy enforcement
column12: as well as state-backed information operations datasets that were previously released to the public to empower research and awareness of these campaigns.\u00c2\u00a0\nSince the last Twitter Transparency Report
column13: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve continued to further invest in proactive technology to positively and directly impact people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s conversations on the service.\u00c2\u00a0\nHere are key highlights from that work
column14: which relate to the latest reporting period (January 1 to June 30
column15: 2019)*:\nMore than 50% of Tweets we take action on for abuse are now proactively surfaced using technology
column16: rather than relying on reports to Twitter;\n105% increase in accounts actioned by Twitter (locked or suspended for violating the Twitter Rules);\nContinuing a year-on-year trend
column17: a 30% decrease in accounts suspended for the promotion of terrorism; and\n67% more global legal demands
column18:
originating from 49 different countries.Â 
*All figures compared to the last reporting period.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitter Rules enforcement Our continued investment in proprietary technology is steadily reducing the burden on people to report to us. For example
column19: more than 50% of Tweets we take action on for abuse are now being surfaced using technology. This compares to just 20% a year ago.\u00c2\u00a0\nAdditionally
column20: due to a combination of our increased focus on proactively surfacing potentially violative content for human review and the inclusion of impersonation data for the first time
column21: we saw a 105% increase in accounts locked or suspended for violating the Twitter Rules. \nSpecific policy content areas:\nPrivate information: We saw a 48% increase in accounts reported for potential violations of our private information policies. We suspended 119% more accounts than the previous reporting period. This increase may be attributed to the launch of improvements to our reporting flow that make it easier to report private information
column22:
as well as changes to our internal enforcement processes which permit bystanders to report potential private information violations for review.
Sensitive media: We saw a 37% increase in accounts reported for potential violations of our sensitive media policies. We actioned 41% more accounts.
Hateful conduct: There was a 48% increase in accounts reported for potential violations of our hateful conduct policies. We actioned 133% more accounts compared to the last reporting period.
Abuse: We saw a 22% increase in accounts reported for potential violations of our abuse policies. We took action on 68% more accounts compared to the last reporting period.
Impersonation: Impersonation is when an account poses as another person
column23: brand
column24: or organization in a confusing or deceptive manner and is prohibited by the Twitter Rules. During this reporting period
column25: we took enforcement action on 124
column26:
339 accounts for violating our impersonation policy.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Platform manipulation We also continue to focus on deterring potentially spammy accounts at the time of account creation; often before their first Tweet. However
column27: our enforcement actions tend to fluctuate for a variety of reasons
column28: often due to the type of spam.\nThis reporting period
column29: our anti-spam challenges \u00e2\u0080\u0094 where we ask people to provide a phone number or email address or fill in a ReCAPTCHA code to verify there is a human behind an account \u00e2\u0080\u0094 fell by nearly 50%.\u00c2\u00a0\nRemoval of terrorist content A total of 115
column30: 861 accounts were suspended for violations related to the promotion of terrorism this reporting period
column31: down 30% from the previous reporting period. This continues a year-on-year decrease in the number of accounts promoting terrorist content on Twitter as we take more comprehensive enforcement action using our technology and strengthen partnerships with our peers. Of those suspensions
column32: 87% consisted of accounts we proactively flagged using internal
column33: proprietary removal tools.\nRemoval of child sexual exploitation content During this reporting period
column34: we suspended a total of 244
column35: 188 accounts for violations related to child sexual exploitation. Of the unique accounts suspended
column36: 91% were surfaced by a combination of technology solutions (including PhotoDNA and internal
column37: proprietary tools).\nLegal requests In addition to enforcing the Twitter Rules
column38: we also may take action in response to legal requests.\nCopyright violations:\nWe received a 101% increase in DMCA takedown notices since our last report. However
column39: many were incomplete or not actionable. We continue to see a high volume of fraudulent DMCA reports from Turkey and Japan
column40:
while fraudulent reports from Brazil also continue to increase.
Trademark notices:
We saw a 39% increase in the total number of trademark notices received since our last report. The increase is likely due to an influx of reports that failed to provide sufficient information to take any action on our part.
Information requests (legal requests for account information):
Information requests from the United States continue to make up the highest percentage of legal requests for account information. During this reporting period
column41:
29% of all global requests for account information originated within the United States.
National security requests:
At this time we are only able to share information about the number of National Security Letters (NSLs) received which are no longer subject to non-disclosure orders. We believe it is much more meaningful to publish these actual numbers than reporting in the bands authorized per the USA Freedom Act. Our litigation in the case Twitter v. Barr continues.
During this reporting period
column42: we notified people affected by three additional NSLs after the gag orders were lifted. As reflected in the report
column43: non-disclosure orders for 17 total NSLs have been lifted to date. Twitter is committed to continuing to use the legal mechanism available to us to request a judicial review of these gag orders.\nRemoval requests (legal requests for content removal)*:\nCompared to the previous reporting period
column44: we received roughly 67% more legal requests to remove content
column45: originating from 49 different countries. Of the requests received
column46: 80% of the volume originated from Japan
column47: Russia
column48: and Turkey. We withheld content in a country 2
column49: 457 times
column50: at either an account or Tweet level.\n*We continue to publish these legal requests when we take action directly to the Lumen Database
column51: a partnership with Harvard\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Berkman Klein Center for Internet & Society.\nWe remain deeply committed to transparency at Twitter \u00e2\u0080\u0094 it continues to be one of our key guiding principles. This commitment is reflected in the evolution and expansion of the report in recent years: It now includes dedicated sections on platform manipulation and spam
column52: our Twitter Rules enforcement
column53: and state-backed information operations we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve previously removed from the service.\u00c2\u00a0\nThis report reflects not only the evolution of the public conversation on our service but the work we do every day to protect and support the people who use Twitter. Follow @Policy and @TwitterSafety for relevant updates
column54:
initiatives or announcements regarding our efforts.Â

column3: "title": "Social customer service: the three stages of maturity"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Social customer service: the three stages of maturity
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 30 October 2019\nLink copied successfully\nOn April 6
column10: when Twitter was barely 2 years old
column11: Frank Eliasin
column12: a manager with Comcast\u00e2\u0080\u0099s customer support team launched Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s first-ever dedicated customer support handle
column13: @ComcastCares. A somewhat radical strategy at the time
column14: Comcast\u00e2\u0080\u0099s move to social proved to be the first step in a journey towards embedding social into their customer experience.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nToday
column15: millions of people come to Twitter to express their thoughts
column16: experiences and opinions -\u00c2\u00a0 making Twitter one of the top channels where customers engage with brands
column17: including airing their customer service woes. Offering some level of social customer service just makes good business sense.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn my work
column18: I spend a lot of time talking to and educating companies on the potential of Twitter data. When it comes to social customer service I\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve observed that most companies fall into three stages of maturity.\nStage 1 - Emerging\nMany companies begin providing social customer service almost accidentally
column19: as a result of their social media marketing efforts. Customers find their social marketing channels and concerns flow in. Conscientious marketers do their best to direct these incoming service issues to the right people so they can close the loop with a response. But a lack of clear ownership means messages occasionally fall through the cracks
column20: and there is very little performance tracking on customer service interactions let alone service-level agreements (SLAs). The focus tends to be on \u00e2\u0080\u009cbest-effort\u00e2\u0080\u009d and it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s common practice to deflect the incoming customer service enquiries to other support channels such as phone or email.\u00c2\u00a0\nCompanies at this emerging stage of maturity would benefit most from clear guidelines accompanied by staff training for interacting with customers on social media. In addition
column21: a good social media management tool would go a long way in preventing things from falling through the cracks; improving social media response times while also facilitating better cross-team collaboration.\nStage 2 - Established\nAt this stage of their social care journey
column22: businesses have fully adopted social customer service as an equal to established channels such as phone
column23: email or chat. With clear guidelines in place
column24: one or more trained agents are dedicated to resolving social enquiries on the originating platform (versus diverting to phone or email). SLAs such as First Response Time and Time to Resolution are in place and monitored. A social care tool is in use and with it
column25: defined routing and approval workflows.\nMany businesses stay at this stage and feel satisfied that they are getting the job of social customer care done. They are responsive and their customers are appreciative. Why change anything? But
column26: by not looking to further innovate and mature their program
column27: they may be missing out on an opportunity to create deeper value for both their customers and their business.\u00c2\u00a0\nStage 3 - Innovator\nIn the third and most advanced stage of social care maturity
column28: businesses shift from social adoption to social innovation. They are proactively promoting social (including messaging) as a channel where customers can receive expedited customer service. Customer experience delivery is driven by \u00e2\u0080\u0098social engagement centers\u00e2\u0080\u0099. Part marketing and part care
column29: these \u00e2\u0080\u009ccenters\u00e2\u0080\u009d are designed to not only resolve customer issues but to also proactively engage with the public on topics and events of relevance to the business. They blend human interaction and automation (such as bots) into a unified service experience and are able to collect real-time Net Promoter Score (NPS) and Customer Satisfaction (CSAT) feedback. Their social media suite is integrated with other critical systems allowing for more holistic customer visibility to enable personalization. They know who their customers are
column30: the issues they\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve had in the past and how they\u00e2\u0080\u0099d like to be treated.\nBusinesses in this stage see their approach to social as a true differentiator and source of competitive differentiation. They have adopted an innovation mindset and are quick to adopt best practices and benchmark themselves against their peers. Crucially
column31: they have senior leadership buy-in who practice what they preach
column32:
actively engaging with customers.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The social customer care journey
Over ten years have passed since @ComcastCares went live. Their social care experiment has grown from handling a few thousand conversations a year to well over 50k a month
column33: and social customer service has become an integral part of the company\u00e2\u0080\u0099s customer experience. Quite a journey!\nRegardless of which stage of maturity you currently find yourself
column34: if delivering customer service via Twitter is important to you
column35: we are here to help. Visit data.twitter.com for social customer service case studies
column36:
a list of Twitter Official Partners or to get in touch with our team.Â

column3: "title": "Twitter builds partnership with UNESCO on media and information literacy"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Twitter builds partnership with UNESCO on media and information literacy
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 24 October 2019\nLink copied successfully\nAt Twitter
column9: we have always championed the free flow of information and people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s right to free expression online. These complementary commitments intersect when we discuss media and information literacy.\nWe want to empower the people who use our service to critically engage with the content they see. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why today
column10: to mark the beginning of @UNESCO\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Global Media and Information Literacy Week 2019
column11: we are launching a new handbook for educators
column12:
entitled Teaching and Learning with Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Easy-to-read
column13: informative and fun
column14: the handbook primarily aims to help educators equip younger generations with media literacy skills
column15: in turn enabling them to ask the right questions about content they engage with online
column16: and critically analyse news and information they engage with on the service.\u00c2\u00a0\nThe resource contains best practice guidelines on media literacy from UNESCO
column17: and also a reading list curated by UNESCO\u00e2\u0080\u0099s program specialists
column18: which is intended to guide educators through current teaching literature on this topic.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nTo ensure it has a wide global reach
column19: it will be initially translated into 9 different languages
column20: including English
column21: French
column22: Spanish
column23: German
column24: Portuguese
column25: Arabic
column26: Japanese
column27: Swedish
column28: Hindi
column29: with future plans to translate it for other countries.\u00c2\u00a0 \u00c2\u00a0 \u00c2\u00a0\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll also be distributing the resource to schools by leveraging our many partnerships across the world
column30: for example through UNESCO\u00e2\u0080\u0099s network of relevant NGOs
column31: state education agencies
column32: and the European network of Safer Internet Centres.\u00c2\u00a0\nThese efforts directly complement our policy development process on misinformation
column33:
specifically a new public comment period where you can provide feedback on upcoming policies we will be enacting to combat synthetic and manipulated media on our service.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The digital classroom
The Handbook also contains tips for educators and parents who want to unlock the benefits of Twitter as a learning tool in the classroom or at home
column34: offering a helpful blend of theory
column35: lesson plans
column36: and case studies.\u00c2\u00a0\nTaking a holistic view of what it means to be able to be a good digital citizen
column37: the handbook also contains sections which cover online safety
column38: dealing with cyberbullying as an educator
column39: and learning how to control your digital footprint. You can read it in more detail here.\nUNESCO and Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s partnership\nThe resource is a product of Twitter and UNESCO\u00e2\u0080\u0099s ongoing 18 month global partnership in this area
column40: during which time we supported NGOs working on media and information literacy through our Ads For Good programme and supported their #MILClicks programme with a range of on-service activity
column41:
such as the serialisation of content from @MILClicks.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Some of Twitterâs other activities include:Â 
Launching a dedicated emoji with accompanying hashtags #GlobalMILWeek
column42: #ThinkBeforeSharing
column43:
and #ThinkBeforeClicking.
Partnering with the National Association for Media Literacy Education (NAMLE) to support Media Literacy Week in the United States using the hashtag #MediaLitWk.Â 
Offering Ads For Good grants to NGOs in @UNESCOâs network to help raise awareness for their work.
VP of Public Policy
column44: Government and Corporate Philanthropy at Twitter
column45: Colin Crowell
column46: states: \u00e2\u0080\u009cAt Twitter
column47: we are hopeful that this Handbook will have a tangible
column48: beneficial impact on students across the world by helping educators impart critical information and skills to younger generations about how to navigate an increasingly complicated media environment. We deeply treasure our global partnership with UNESCO on media and information literacy and this project strongly benefits\u00c2\u00a0 from UNESCO\u00e2\u0080\u0099s expertise in this area. We look forward to continued discussion and collaboration with UNESCO on how media and information literacy can be a defence \u00e2\u0080\u0094 particularly in our young people \u00e2\u0080\u0094 against disinformation and political propaganda around the world.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nMoez Chakchouk
column49: Assistant Director-General of UNESCO says: \u00e2\u0080\u009cPolarized information is driving a rise in hate and discrimination and is often amplified by inauthentic and malicious activity
column50: while disinformation is compromising democracy and development. Promoting media and information literacy learning through social media platforms
column51: such as this Twitter and UNESCO collaboration
column52: could be far-reaching if systematically implemented and sustained.\u00e2\u0080\u009d He continues
column53: \u00e2\u0080\u009cThis is only the start of Twitter and UNESCO working together
column54:
we can expand our cooperation to give more impetus to promoting media and information literate citizenry in online spaces.â
Â

column3: "title": "When it comes to digital transformation
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/insights/2019/when-it-comes-to-digital-transformation-start-with-the-customer"
column8: "post_text": "When it comes to digital transformation
column9:
start with the customer
                By
                
  
  
Wednesday
column10: 23 October 2019\nLink copied successfully\nIf it seems like everyone is talking about digital transformation these days
column11: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s with good reason. We are smack in the middle of an era like no other
column12: characterized by exciting emerging and evolving technologies like cloud computing
column13: mobile devices
column14: artificial intelligence and the internet of things
column15: all fueled by accelerating connectivity speeds. And
column16: by taking advantage of technology to transform your business
column17: you are motivated by outcomes like increased efficiency
column18: greater profits and in some cases
column19: new market opportunities.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn parallel with this is another emerging phenomenon - the empowered consumer.\u00c2\u00a0 People\u00e2\u0080\u0099s expectations for companies they do business with have changed. Concerns around issues like security
column20: privacy
column21: transparency
column22: corporate social responsibility
column23: immediacy
column24: and personalization are finding a voice and informing people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s decisions about whether or not to do business with a company. And what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s more
column25: they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sharing those opinions well beyond their traditional social circles at home and at the office.\nEmpowered and influential consumers can make or break your business. With the stakes so high
column26: doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t it make sense that you put the customer at the center of your digital transformation strategy?\u00c2\u00a0\nRead your customers\u00e2\u0080\u0099 minds with social listening\nFortunately
column27: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not that hard to find out what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s on customers\u00e2\u0080\u0099 minds. Technology and tools have empowered customers to communicate more easily and frequently than ever before. Well over half of the world is online where they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re spending an average of almost 7 hours every day. A portion of that time is spent communicating feedback (both prompted and unprompted) on the brands they encounter and care about
column28: whether through writing reviews
column29: completing surveys
column30: or sharing opinions and experiences on social media platforms like Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nOn Twitter
column31: people share hundreds of millions of Tweets every day. And
column32: at every stage of the customer journey
column33: they are signalling satisfaction
column34: concerns
column35: frictions
column36: and conflicts through their posts. They are not only expressing how they feel but why they feel that way. And
column37: thanks to social listening tools
column38: you can easily tap into these conversations
column39: uncovering insights in real-time as well as historical patterns. When combined with other more traditional data from sources like surveys
column40: focus groups or research
column41: you can come closer than ever to knowing your customers on a deeper level and understanding their wants
column42: needs and concerns.\u00c2\u00a0\nExamples of digital transformation with unintended consequences\nConsider some of the unintended consequences of digital transformation. In the case of US restaurant chain Shake Shack
column43: they piloted a cashier-less
column44: cash-free location. The self-serve kiosks promised to streamline customer service while reducing operating expenses. Unfortunately
column45: the initiative was abandoned after 6 months. Why? It turns out Shake Shack customers like to customize their orders and the new human-free system didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t permit this flexibility. And
column46: believe it or not
column47: many people still want to pay with cash. Could a deeper understanding of their customers have better set up this digital transformation initiative for success?\u00c2\u00a0\nDigital transformation in banking is another interesting example. Most of us have embraced the flexibility of online banking yet this transformation is still fraught with challenges. According to recent research from J.D. Power
column48: 28% of US retail bank customers are now digital-only
column49: but they are the least satisfied among all customer segments examined in the study. Digital-only experiences are not living up to customer expectations in the areas of communication and advice; products and fees; and new account opening. Could banks be better equipped to tackle these challenges with a deeper understanding of their digital customers?\nDigital transformation strategy development: customers are key\nWhether it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s introducing automation or AI
column50: shifting from bricks and mortar to digital
column51: moving to the cloud or changing backend infrastructure
column52: companies need to put customers at the center of their digital transformation strategy. Get it right and you will be the beneficiary of everything promised by digital transformation
column53:
including happier customers and lasting brand loyalty. Get it wrong and you risk the wrath of the empowered customer.
Your customers are talking. Are you ready to start listening? Get inspired at data.twitter.com with case studies that illustrate the power of social media listening and check out a list of Twitter Official Partners.
