column3: "title": "Guest post: Five ways brands build connections on social"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Guest post: Five ways brands build connections on social
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 18 October 2019\nLink copied successfully\nPeople today crave connection
column9: especially in our digital world. Brands have long been household names
column10: but with a strong social media presence
column11: they can now occupy an even more personal place in our lives.\u00c2\u00a0\nWith so much noise it can be difficult for brands to build genuine relationships with their target audiences. For the brands that clear this hurdle
column12: the payoff is real. When those connections are established
column13: brands are rewarded with a boost in customer loyalty and spending and word-of-mouth recommendations\u00e2\u0080\u0094all direct contributions to their bottom line.\u00c2\u00a0 \nSprout Social data shows that 57% of people will increase their spend with a brand when they feel connected to it. To narrow in on that perspective
column14:
62% of the people on Twitter donât hesitate to spend more money for the products or services of a brand they like (compared to 51% of the general online population). 
Putting customers and their wants at the center of your digital strategy is vital if you want to foster long-lasting relationships. Weâve highlighted five things brands must do to better connect with their audiences and turn casual followers into engaged brand advocates.
1. Treat Twitter as the core customer experience element it is.
In an environment with so much potential for meaningful relationships
column15: there are big expectations: 78% of consumers want brands to use social to help people connect with each other. \nBusinesses can no longer ignore the value of digital. Outdated excuses (i.e. that it is too difficult to quantify success and that it does not affect the bottom line) are no longer valid today. Twitter is transforming how customers and brands talk to one another
column16: making it an integral part of the consumer experience. Companies like Apple
column17: for example
column18: have their own support handles specifically for handling customer service requests and answering product questions.\u00c2\u00a0\n2. Use a mix of entertaining and educational content to attract followers.\nWhile many want the content they come across to entertain
column19: your content strategy has to strike a balance between showing what your brand offers and what your brand represents. 57% of people on Twitter will favor brands that share their values
column20: compared to just 45% of the general online population.\u00c2\u00a0\nWell-executed educational content can make people feel good about your product and confident about choosing you over competitors. Half of consumers follow a brand on social to learn about new products and services.\nThat said
column21: people still want to be engaged and entertained before they buy. 50% of social marketers say entertaining and inspirational posts are the most effective in helping them reach their goals.\u00c2\u00a0\n3. Utilize formats like live video to engage with your audience.\nVideo has reigned as the digital content king over the past few years. But despite the push for video
column22: marketers are still behind when it comes to nurturing their video presence
column23: resulting in missed opportunities to connect with consumers. With 45% of consumers wanting to see more live video from brands
column24: marketers should invest in video for sustained future growth.\u00c2\u00a0\nCultivating communities also offers brands a unique opportunity to connect directly with their audiences. More than two-thirds of consumers will join a private group because they want to connect with people who are similar to them
column25: while almost half (46%) join to communicate directly with a brand or business. The larger the landscape becomes
column26: the more private communities can help brands stay in close contact with their customers.\n4. Create posts offering trials or discounts to convert followers into customers.\nA good deal never gets old. Of consumers that follow brands on social but don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t buy from them
column27: 61% said posts offering discounts or free trials encourage them to make their first purchase. Promotional content is one of the few cut-and-dried ways businesses quantify social performance as it relates to sales goals and ensure a boost in customer loyalty. Brands can take advantage of holidays like Black Friday or Cyber Monday to offer exclusive discounts that get buyers excited. Space Camp USA
column28: for example
column29: created Tweets highlighting a limited-time promotion for Black Friday shoppers.\u00c2\u00a0\n5. Leverage authentic advocacy to grab your audience\u00e2\u0080\u0099s attention.\nWhen marketers take the time to build authentic consumer relationships
column30: they are rewarded with an increase in web traffic
column31: a boost in sales and\u00e2\u0080\u0094one of a brand\u00e2\u0080\u0099s greatest organic marketing tools\u00e2\u0080\u0094word-of-mouth advocacy.\u00c2\u00a0\nOne way to move consumers to action is to leverage employee advocacy
column32: a strategy currently employed by 72% of all social marketers. When brands encourage employees to share content to their own networks
column33: 45% of consumers say they are more likely to research that product or service. Starbucks
column34: for example
column35:
has a unique employee advocacy program that encourages staff members to share brand updates and news on Twitter.
These advantages make it easy to see why more brands are embracing the employee advocacy as a business priority.Â 
Moving toward a social-first customer experience
In an era where consumers seek meaningful experiences with brands and are drawn to authentic conversations
column36: a business with no social presence is one with no future. People crave connection with their favorite brands
column37: and Twitter provide consumers with a direct line of communication.\nSocial is the perfect place to start meaningful relationships with customers. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s an environment that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s intimate
column38: where we celebrate the ability to share and connect with one another. As a brand
column39: make everything you deliver there count.\nTo learn more about Sprout Social
column40:
check out their profile on partners.twitter.com.

column3: "title": "World Leaders on Twitter: principles & approach"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
World Leaders on Twitter: principles & approach
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8:
15 October 2019
Link copied successfully
There continues to be meaningful public conversation about how we think about Tweets from world leaders on our service. We welcome the conversation and want to share more context on our principles and process for reviewing reported Tweets from these accounts.Â 
ContextÂ 
When it comes to the actions of world leaders on Twitter
column9: we recognize that this is largely new ground and unprecedented. We understand the desire for our decisions to be \u00e2\u0080\u009cyes/no\u00e2\u0080\u009d binaries
column10: but it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not that simple. The actions we take and policies we develop will set precedent around online speech and we owe it to the people we serve to be deliberate and considered in what we do.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur mission is to provide a forum that enables people to be informed and to engage their leaders directly. We also have a responsibility to the people who use Twitter to better explain why we make the decisions we make
column11:
which we will do here.Â 
Our approach
Everything we do starts with an understanding of our purpose and of the service we provide: a place where people can participate in public conversation and get informed about the world around them.Â 
We assess reported Tweets from world leaders against the Twitter Rules
column12: which are designed to ensure people can participate in the public conversation freely and safely.\nWe focus on the language of reported Tweets and do not attempt to determine all potential interpretations of the content or its intent.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nPresently
column13: direct interactions with fellow public figures
column14: comments on political issues of the day
column15: or foreign policy saber-rattling on economic or military issues are generally not in violation of the Twitter Rules.\u00c2\u00a0\nHowever
column16: if a Tweet from a world leader does violate the Twitter Rules but there is a clear public interest value to keeping the Tweet on the service
column17:
we may place it behind a notice that provides context about the violation and allows people to click through should they wish to see the content. We announced this in June.Â 
Enforcement scenariosÂ 
We want to make it clear today that the accounts of world leaders are not above our policies entirely. The below areas will result in enforcement action for any account on our service (without consideration of the potential public interest value in allowing the Tweet to remain visible behind a notice):
Promotion of terrorism;Â 
Clear and direct threats of violence against an individual (context matters: as noted above
column18: direct interactions with fellow public figures and/or commentary on political and foreign policy issues would likely not result in enforcement);\u00c2\u00a0\nPosting private information
column20: we will err on the side of leaving the content up if there is a clear public interest in doing so.\u00c2\u00a0\nWith critical elections and shifting political dynamics around the world
column21: we recognize that we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re operating in an increasingly complex and polarized political culture. These are constantly evolving challenges and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll keep our policies and approach under advisement
column22: particularly as we learn more about the relationship between Tweets from world leaders and the potential for offline harm.\u00c2\u00a0\nThis post seeks to provide clear insight into how we address content from world leaders on Twitter today
column23: and will serve as our statement on the decisions we make
column24: rather than our teams providing feedback on individual Tweets and decisions. We've also updated our dedicated Help Center page to provide a significantly more detailed breakdown of how we make decisions regarding the use of the public interest notice.\nOur goal is to enforce our rules judiciously and impartially. In doing so
column25: we aim to provide direct insight into our enforcement decision-making
column26: to serve public conversation
column27:
and protect the publicâs right to hear from their leaders and to hold them to account.

column3: "title": "Return of the (Twitter for) Mac"
column7: "post_text": "Product\nReturn of the (Twitter for) Mac\nFriday
column8: 11 October 2019\nLink copied successfully\nYou might remember we gave you a sneak peek at Twitter for Mac back in June
column9: and shared a lot of insight on why we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re bringing it back. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been working hard to make sure that the new Twitter for Mac has the same features
column10: look and feel as Twitter for iOS where you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll get new features just as quick.\nNow
column11: Twitter for Mac is here and available to use on Mac OS 10.15 Catalina \u00e2\u0080\u0093 it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s the same Twitter you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve always known but with new bells and whistles just for Mac
column12: which will include:\nMulti-Task with Multiple Windows: No need to pause anything while you browse and Tweet. Look at multiple memes and photos alike all at once
column13: and compose Tweets in as many windows as you need.\nMore of Your Favorite Features: From Dark Mode to multi-account
column14: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll get all of your favorite features from Twitter for iOS in Twitter for Mac.\nDrag and Drop It: Want to quickly include a funny photo or a link to a story you can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t stop reading in your Tweet? Now
column15: you can drag and drop 4k images (JPEG
column16: PNG
column17: TIFF
column18: HEIC and WebP)
column19: text and links directly into your Tweet composer.\nTwitter should always be consistent and connect you to the conversations and interests you care about most across all the ways you use it. The new Twitter for Mac is the latest example of our commitment to this goal
column20:
and weâll continue to build off of this work as we bring new Twitter features and improvements to you.
What do you think about the new Twitter for Mac? Visit the App Store to download and let us know what you think.Â 
Any questions? Visit our Help Center article here.

column3: "title": "What marketing gets that Customer Experience (CX) doesn\u2019t"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
What marketing gets that Customer Experience (CX) doesnât
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 9 October 2019\nLink copied successfully\nBoth the Marketing and Customer Experience teams care deeply about the customer and the brand.\u00c2\u00a0 They are driven by data
column9: surfacing insights and measuring but very rarely are they integrated or even sharing with one another.\u00c2\u00a0\nOdds are good that your Marketing department is already using tools to listen
column10: analyze and measure social data. This is backed up by results from a recent Harris Poll* sponsored by Twitter. Marketing leaders polled revealed that 93% of them are using social media in their programs- from tracking their campaigns to measuring brand equity. 74% also reported using social platforms to perform some customer care \nOver on the CX team
column11: for the most part
column12: if anyone is thinking about social
column13: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s an afterthought. According to a recent report from Forrester**
column14:
most voice of the customer (VoC) programs are still heavily focused on traditional data sources like surveys and missing out on unstructured and unsolicited data like that from social media platforms. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Does marketing know something that CX doesnât?
Here are 3 big things marketers know about social media data that they need to share with their CX colleagues:
1. Social is whatâs happening right now
While surveys continue to be the bread and butter of CX programs
column15: by their very nature they are limited because they only measure a moment in time. What marketers understand is that customers are also providing a steady stream of feedback in real-time
column16: and in the case of Twitter
column17: that feedback is intentionally public.\u00c2\u00a0 Throughout the customer journey - people are signalling satisfaction
column18: concerns
column19: frictions
column20: and conflicts through their social posts. They are not only expressing how they feel but why they feel that way.\u00c2\u00a0\n2. Social data is authentic (mostly)\u00c2\u00a0\nWhile not to suggest the CX programs aren\u00e2\u0080\u0099t collecting authentic feedback
column21: solicited feedback like that from surveys and focus groups is limited and directed by the questions and topics. Marketers who employ social listening strategies are rich in unsolicited feedback. And
column22: sophisticated marketers understand the nuances between the individual social platforms.\u00c2\u00a0For example
column23: Instagram users may post inspirational content and strive to depict their best selves
column24: while over on Twitter
column25: customers are likely to share their unfiltered views on any and every topic - from the mundane to the controversial.\n3. Social is great at surfacing unknowns\nHave you ever been blindsided by unintended consequences from the introduction of a new product or service? Or been surprised when a competitor seemed to predict the future and capitalize on a new trend before anyone else? Marketers know that news often breaks first on social platforms and social data is often the bellwether of emerging trends and issues. By listening
column26: they can insert their voice into breaking topics and identify and mitigate issues before they become a crisis.\u00c2\u00a0 \u00c2\u00a0\nBy tapping into social data and combining it with traditional data sources
column27: CX practitioners will find themselves one step closer to a true 360 view of the customer. These real-time and authentic reactions to and experiences with your brand - good
column28: bad and neutral
column29: will empower you to shape experiences for the better and win approval and loyalty of your customers.\nAre you ready to integrate social data into your CX program? First step - talk to your marketing team. Chances are
column30: they\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been waiting for your call.\u00c2\u00a0 Need more support? Visit data.twitter.com for case studies
column31: a list of Twitter Official Partners or to get in touch with our team.\u00c2\u00a0\n*The Harris Poll
column32: Social Media 2.0 How Social Data Informs Business Decision Making\n**Forrester - The Top Trends Among VoC Leaders

column3: "title": "Your customers are talking. Are you listening?"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Your customers are talking. Are you listening?
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 25 September 2019\nLink copied successfully\nI think we can all agree
column9: the digital revolution is over. By that I mean the shift from analog to digital is fully underway and there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s no way to unring the technology bell. Think about it. More than half the world is online with more people connecting every day. People everywhere are online
column10: blending their work and personal lives while searching
column11: reading
column12: watching
column13: playing
column14: listening and connecting to share experiences
column15:
opinions and information - every minute of every day. Consider these numbers published by TNW earlier this year:
57% of the world is online where on average they spend almost 7 hours of the day 
45% of the world are social media users 
2.8B people are shopping online
column16: spending almost $3B/year ($634 each) \nOver 95% of consumers say they are at least somewhat influenced by what other people say about brands on social media \nIf you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re a customer experience (CX) expert
column17: take note - these are your customers. And
column18: their move online has fundamentally changed how they interact with your brand - sharing their thoughts
column19: preferences and experiences at every stage of the customer journey - and you may be missing all of it. Status quo customer experience and Voice of the Customer programs chug along - trying to integrate new data sources while relying on tried and true traditional research methods - surveys
column20: focus groups and interviews. By overlooking a wealth of untapped social data
column21: your picture of your customer only grows murkier.\nBut it doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t have to be that way.\u00c2\u00a0\nImagine getting an unprecedented view of your customer through realtime
column22: unprompted and authentic reactions to your brand
column23: surfacing what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important now as well as who and what is influencing them.\u00c2\u00a0 And
column24: imagine putting those insights to work to respond to your customers\u00e2\u0080\u0099 needs and shape their experience for the better
column25: winning their approval and loyalty.\nPeople around the world are sharing hundreds of millions of Tweets every day
column26: making Twitter the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s largest publicly available searchable archive of consumer thoughts
column27: experiences and opinions. You can tap into and harness those conversations through social listening and monitoring. Combined with your other data sources
column28: those tweets paint a more accurate picture of your customers. Not only can this newfound understanding catch an issue before it becomes a crisis
column29: but it can also lead to new products and services
column30: customer retention insights
column31: process improvements and more. All ultimately driving towards the holy grail of CX
column32: increased customer satisfaction scores.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been thinking a lot about how Twitter data can contribute to CX programs and I\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be sharing some of those thoughts in upcoming posts. In the meantime
column33: if you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re looking for inspiration
column34: check out data.twitter.com for case studies that illustrate the power of social listening. When you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re ready
column35:
Â  talk to your customer experience service provider about incorporating Twitter data into your program.Â 
Your customers are talking. Are you ready to listen?
Â

column3: "title": "Your social customer service vendor checklist"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Your social customer service vendor checklist
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 23 September 2019\nLink copied successfully\nPeople share hundreds of millions of Tweets every day - expressing their thoughts
column9: experiences and opinions - making Twitter one of the top channels where customers engage with brands
column10:
including airing their customer service woes.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
82% of people on Twitter actively engage with brands1 
80% of social care requests sent via social platforms also happen on Twitter2 
74% of social media professionals also reported using social platforms to perform some customer care3Â  
The average cost of a social interaction is only $1 compared to $6 for a call center interaction4
Adding social interaction to your customer service offering makes good business sense. Doing it right
column11: means considering a range of administrative
column12:
technical and cultural factors. The following checklist can help guide you to the best solution for your business.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The Social Customer Service Checklist
Customer Service Analytics  Key care-focused metrics should include First Response Time
column13: Average Handling Time and Time to Resolution. What metrics are available and will you be able to create custom metrics to align with your specific business needs?\nApproval Workflows  Will you be able to create permission-based custom workflows for the purposes of agent collaboration
column14:
content approval and quality control?
Customer Experience Auditing  The ability to access and export the full conversation history and call agent actions is especially critical in highly regulated industries such as financial services.
Case Management and Ticketing  Can you create cases or tickets for follow-up and/or escalation? What about connectors or integrations to commonly used case management platforms?
Customer Service Chatbots  Can you integrate chatbots? Twitter has deployed a number of features to improve customer experiences such as welcome messages and quick replies. Will you have access to these features?
Compliance and Information Security  Whether itâs SOC2 accreditation or other certifications important in your industry and/or country.
Conversation history  Threading public tweets and private Direct Messages together into a conversation view provides valuable context should an issue need to be escalated or passed to another agent. Twitter has made it easy for brands to move a customer from a Tweet into a private message with the launch of Direct Message deep links.
Credibility  Specific industries tend to have their own needs when it comes to customer care. Does the vendor understand and have experience in your industry? Ask for case studies and customer references.
CRM & ID Matching  Can you add tags and notes to social profiles? How are these additions added to your CRM? Twitter allows brands to match user IDs to customer records under specific circumstances - if the user has expressly consented or the matching is being done based on publicly available data and/or data provided directly by the applicable Twitter user that an individual would reasonably expect to be used for that purpose.
Data Access  What are the relationships with the social networks being featured? Enterprise level? Whitelisted access to API feeds? These relationships matter
column15: when it comes to your mission-critical customer care operation. Certified Twitter Official Partners can be found here https://partners.twitter.com/en.\nCustomer Care Feedback  Can you deploy CSAT and NPS surveys as well as track sentiment conversion? Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Customer Feedback feature enables people to privately share their opinions with a business after a service interaction. Will you have the option to access this feature?\nIntegrations & pre-built Connectors  Which third-party software integrations are important to you? If you can access them
column16: how? Are they uni-directional
column17: bi-directional or an iframe? What about custom integrations?\nCustomer Knowledge Base  Is there a built-in knowledge base for care agents with suggested answers based on the context of the message? What about connectors to your existing knowledge base or content management system?\nOnboarding  What will the onboarding process look like
column18: both for product training and the softer side of social care such as establishing an appropriate tone of voice?\nRouting & Prioritization  How will social messages be routed and prioritized to appropriate care agents? There are many options including routing based on keywords
column19:
influencer score and CRM history. Donât forget language-specific routing for localization and global coverage.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Your customers are waiting for you on Twitter. Are you ready to join them? Get started at data.twitter.com where youâll find case studies and a list of Twitter Official Partners or to get in touch with our team.Â 
12017 Twitter User Survey
2 2016 Twitter Advertising Survey
3 The Harris Poll
column20:
Social Media 2.0 How Social Data Informs Business Decision Making
4 Forrester Report 2015: Contact Centers Must Go Digital or Die
Â

column4: driving brands to create ideas worth talking about"
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/product/2019/Twitter-next"
column8: "post_text": "Product\nTwitter Next
column9:
driving brands to create ideas worth talking about
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column10: 23 September 2019\nLink copied successfully\nAs the industry has shifted
column11: so have the needs of marketers who want to break through the clutter and drive conversations about their campaigns
column12: products and messages. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why today
column13: we are evolving Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s brand strategy team and re-orienting our offerings around a single mission: to create human-centric ideas worth talking about.\nIntroducing Twitter Next
column14: which includes campaign and content strategy services
column15: brand voice consultations
column16: and a newly formed lab of technologists
column17: program managers
column18:
and designers. The expanded team - now in 20+ markets worldwide - also includes specialists in engineering and data science.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
At Twitter Next
column19: we partner with the industry\u00e2\u0080\u0099s largest advertisers and leverage cutting edge tech to power Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s most innovative brand activations. Studying hundreds of millions of Tweets per day
column20: we listen to our audience to understand not just what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening today
column21: but what will happen tomorrow.\nExperimentation with the lab\nThrough data-driven experimentation
column22: Twitter Next\u00e2\u0080\u0099s new lab has already stewarded more than 200 custom programs in 2019
column23: with advertisers across all industries globally. From Twitter-powered knitting machines
column24: to vast experiments with Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s API to produce new and engaging experiences
column25: this team focuses on re-imagining the technological possibilities of Twitter.\nFor instance
column26: the team has been working with top brands
column27: including KFC
column28:
to push the boundaries of Twitter threads.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As this was a first for us
column29: we really appreciated the strategic and technical support from the Twitter Next Team. They helped us plan all of the content and walked us through the set-up
column30: ensuring the campaign ran as smoothly as possible at launch. We're very appreciative for the expertise and support the team gave us.\nJosh Benge\nBrand Engagement Manager
column31: KFC\nTwitter Next also recently unlocked a beta-trial of its new Brand Reminders platform
column32: which enables advertisers set up auto-reply campaigns to notify fans about new content. The team has already piloted with over 70 advertisers for sales promotions
column33: movie trailer drops
column34: TV tune-in announcements
column35:
and more. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The tool made it amazingly easy to set up a Brand Reminder campaign for the BET Awards. The results â tens of thousands of people who opted in to receive a reminder the day of the event â exceeded our expectations. Weâre excited to use this again for future launches and events.
Ken Gibbs
VP
column36: Digital Video & Social Content
column37:
BET
Campaign & Content Strategy
Recent research published by Twitter and IPG reveals that a brandâs cultural involvement makes up a full 23% of a consumerâs purchase decision**. Twitter Next is constantly analyzing audience behavior and conversational patterns on Twitter to inform campaign and product launch strategies for brands.
Recently
column38: Samsung Spain wanted to leverage their Game of Thrones partnership to market a line of QLED television sets. After observing the massive debates over who would win the \u00e2\u0080\u009cIron Throne
column39: \u00e2\u0080\u009d Twitter Next and Samsung co-created an experience where fans Tweeted-to-vote for their favorite characters in a tournament-style format. During the five-day campaign period
column40:
Samsungâs hashtag #BatallaQLED saw 4x more mentions than the official #GameOfThrones hashtag in Spain.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
âI'm not sure we've ever seen one of our campaign messages - in this case #BatallaQLED - more talked about on Twitter. I think of Twitter as more than just a media platform; the team at Twitter Next are truly creative partners for us.
Alfonso Fernandez
CMO
column41: Samsung Spain\nBrand Voice Consultation\nThe underpinning of any talkable campaign on Twitter relies on an authentic and engaging brand voice
column42: which is why Twitter Next offers marketers a menu of brand voice consultations and workshops
column43: designed to hone their company\u00e2\u0080\u0099s personas in a relatable manner.\nFor example
column44: Canada\u00e2\u0080\u0099s No Name Brands launched their presence on Twitter in 2019 for the first time ever
column45: quickly reaching popular culture status among users. Their launch generated 23
column46:
000 new followers in the first two months and doubled mentions of Canadian icon Celine Dion during the same time period.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Our new @nonamebrands Twitter account is bringing the no name brand to life in a fresh way. This brand is rooted in simple and direct communication with our customers and we felt that Twitter was the perfect avenue to expand this conversation.
Uwe Stueckmann
SVP Marketing
column47: Loblaw Companies Limited\nStart the conversation\nAt Twitter Next
column48: we learn from the past
column49: live in the moment and focus on what can be. Interested collaborating on your next product launch or campaign? Contact your local Twitter representative or DM @ajos on Twitter.\n  \n*MAGNA & Twitter
column50: \"The Impact of Culture\" research
column51:
2019

column3: "title": "Disclosing new data to our archive of information operations"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nDisclosing new data to our archive of information operations\nFriday
column8: 20 September 2019\nLink copied successfully\nIn October 2018
column9: we disclosed the first comprehensive archive of state-backed information operations on Twitter. We launched this initiative to empower academic and public understanding of these coordinated campaigns around the world
column10: and to empower independent
column11: third-party scrutiny of these tactics on our platform.\u00c2\u00a0\nAs our investigations of platform manipulation around the world have continued
column12: we subsequently added new datasets in January
column13: June and August
column14: while also sharing insights on Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s internal investigative approach and how these complex
column15: sometimes cross-jurisdictional operations are identified.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nNearly one year on
column16: the archive is now the largest of its kind in the industry. Thousands of researchers have made use of these datasets that contain millions of individual Tweets and more than one terabyte of media. Using our archive
column17: these researchers have conducted their own investigations and shared their insights and independent analyses with the world.\u00c2\u00a0\nTransparency and openness are deep-seated values at the heart of Twitter which define and guide our methodology around these disclosures. Today
column18: we are disclosing six additional datasets covering five separate jurisdictions. Per our policies on platform manipulation
column19: we have permanently suspended all the below accounts from the service.\nUnited Arab Emirates & Egypt\u00c2\u00a0 \nWe have removed a network of 271 accounts originating in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and Egypt. These accounts were interconnected in their goals and tactics: a multi-faceted information operation primarily targeting Qatar
column20: and other countries such as Iran. It also amplified messaging supportive of the Saudi government.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe also found evidence that these accounts were created and managed by DotDev
column21: a private technology company operating in the UAE and Egypt. We have permanently suspended DotDev
column22: and all accounts associated with them
column23: from our service.\nAdditionally
column24: we suspended a separate group of 4
column25: 248 accounts operating uniquely from the UAE
column26: mainly directed at Qatar and Yemen. These accounts were often employing false personae and tweeting about regional issues
column27: such as the Yemeni Civil War and the Houthi Movement.\u00c2\u00a0\nSaudi Arabia\nOur investigations also detected a small group of six accounts linked to Saudi Arabia\u00e2\u0080\u0099s state-run media apparatus which were engaged in coordinated efforts to amplify messaging that was beneficial to the Saudi government. While active
column28: the accounts in this set presented themselves as independent journalistic outlets while tweeting narratives favourable to the Saudi government.\u00c2\u00a0\nSeparately
column29: we have also permanently suspended the Twitter account of Saud al-Qahtani for violations of our platform manipulation policies. This account is not included in the archives disclosed today.\nWe continue to suspend a range of accounts for other types of political spam violations in Saudi Arabia. As ever
column30: we will disclose any attribution we can reliably make to state actors if and when we learn them.\nSpain\nWe have removed 259 accounts we identified as falsely boosting public sentiment online in Spain. Operated by Partido Popular
column31: these accounts were active for a relatively short period
column32: and consisted primarily of fake accounts engaging in spamming or retweet behaviour to increase engagement.\u00c2\u00a0\nEcuador\nEarlier in the summer
column33: we removed a network of 1
column34: 019 accounts in Ecuador tied to the PAIS Alliance political party. The network
column35: composed largely of fake accounts
column36: was primarily engaged in spreading content about President Moreno\u00e2\u0080\u0099s administration
column37: focusing on issues concerning Ecuadorian laws on freedom of speech
column38: government censorship
column39: and technology. Tactics most commonly used were hashtag manipulation and retweet spam.\u00c2\u00a0\nChina (PRC)/Hong Kong \nIn August
column40: we disclosed that we had identified a network of more than 200
column41: 000 fake accounts based in the PRC which were attempting to sow discord about the protest movement in Hong Kong. Today
column42: we are publishing additional datasets relating to 4
column43: 301 accounts which were most active in this information operation to further public awareness and understanding.\u00c2\u00a0\nNext steps\u00c2\u00a0\nGoing forward
column44: we will continue to enhance and refine our approach to disclosing state-affiliated information operations on our service. For example
column45: we intend to more routinely disclose data relating to state-backed information operations on the service using our @TwitterSafety handle and in future iterations of the Twitter Transparency Report. We will share more on these plans soon.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nWe see this as a necessary and vital step to regularize our transparency work in this area
column46:
and to encourage more third-party investigation of these behaviors online.
You can access relevant information on these account sets below.
September 2019
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

Twitter Partner Marketing Manager Kim Wu sat down with the #PanteneOppa hair icon to share some of the best Tweets about Steve Aoki that received little to no engagement.
âThere are a lot of Tweets happening on Twitter about you
column13: but a lot of times

column15: \u00e2\u0080\u0099\u00e2\u0080\u009d she told Aoki.\nThe Twitter Lost Tweets series uncovers those hard-to-find conversations

thereâs a lot of Tweets about his hairÂ  â and cake.Â

column3: "title": "More control over your conversations: now available in Japan and the US!"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
More control over your conversations: now available in Japan and the US!
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 19 September 2019\nLink copied successfully\nTo give people more control over their Twitter experience we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve developed different features over the years \u00e2\u0080\u0093 from block
column9: muting keywords and accounts
column10: to notifications filters \u00e2\u0080\u0093 so that everyone can tailor their experience to make Twitter work best for them. Earlier this year we started testing a way to give people more control over the conversations they start. Today
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re expanding this test to Japan and the United States!\nWith this test
column12: we want to understand how conversations on Twitter change if the person who starts a conversation can hide replies. Based on our research and surveys we conducted
column13: we saw a lot of positive trends during our initial test in Canada
column14: including:\nPeople mostly hide replies that they think are irrelevant
column15: abusive or unintelligible. Those who used the tool thought it was a helpful way to control what they saw
column16: similar to when keywords are muted.\nWe saw that people were more likely to reconsider their interactions when their tweet was hidden: 27% of people who had their tweets hidden said they would reconsider how they interact with others in the future.\nPeople were concerned hiding someone\u00e2\u0080\u0099s reply could be misunderstood and potentially lead to confusion or frustration. As a result
column17: now if you tap to hide a Tweet
column18: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll check in with you to see if you want to also block that account.\nThese are positive and heartening results: the feature helped people have better conversations
column19: and was a useful tool against replies that deterred from the person\u00e2\u0080\u0099s original intent.\nWe're interested to see if these trends continue
column20: and if new ones emerge
column21: as we expand our test to Japan and the US. People in these markets use Twitter in many unique ways
column22:
and weâre excited to see how they might use this new tool.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            What it looks like when you hide a Tweet  
          
          
        
          
            What it looks like to view a conversation with hidden replies

column3: "title": "UNICEF and BTS work to #ENDviolence on UN International #FriendshipDay"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
UNICEF and BTS work to #ENDviolence on UN International #FriendshipDay
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 18 September 2019\nLink copied successfully\nUsing the power of conversation
column9: Twitter works with organizations around the world to drive meaningful impact in communities. International organizations like @UNICEF are using Twitter to connect with their communities
column10: build relationships
column11: spark conversation and drive actions.\nTo mark UN International Day of Friendship on July 30
column12: UNICEF challenged the younger members of its community to celebrate friendship through acts of kindness both on Twitter and in real life. This effort was part of UNICEF\u00e2\u0080\u0099s #ENDviolence campaign. In December last year
column13: young people from around the world drafted the #ENDviolence Youth Manifesto. In it
column14: they shared what they want from their parents
column15: teachers
column16:
policymakers and each other to feel safe and supported in and around school â and kindness stood out as one of the most powerful means to prevent bullying.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
To help get the word out
column17: UNICEF partnered with high-profile supporters and K-pop sensation @BTS_twt. The Korean pop group invited their more than 21 million followers to get in on the kindness action by leaving a kind note for someone online or in person.\u00c2\u00a0\nFor UNICEF
column18: partnering with BTS was a perfect fit
column19: \u00e2\u0080\u009cThey are a powerful driving force for positive change and credible young advocates for our work
column20: \u00e2\u0080\u009d\u00c2\u00a0 says Paloma Escudero
column21: Director of Global Communication at UNICEF. \u00e2\u0080\u009cBTS\u00e2\u0080\u0099 passion
column22: authenticity
column23: and personal stories have inspired young people around the world to take action and recognize their own power to end violence in and around schools. Through our #ENDviolence LOVE MYSELF partnership
column24: BTS has galvanized young people to spread love and kindness
column25:
â says Escudero.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
UNICEF used two hashtags as a part of their call to action. #ENDviolence and #FriendshipDay collectively generated almost 1.5M mentions over seven days according to Twitter Official data partner Brandwatch.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The conversation was overwhelmingly positive. Ending violence and âfriendshipâ were widely supported and recognized on Twitter. The table below shows the overwhelming positive conversation that resulting from this campaign. To calculate sentiment
column26:
Brandwatch employs a rules-based process around context and keywords to train their software.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Brandwatch identified the top 100 emojis used from the dayâs conversation. One emoji
column27: in particular
column28: is an important symbol to BTS ARMY fans. The purple heart was the most used in the conversation at more than 700
column29: 000 times. For BTS fans
column30: this emoji aptly symbolizes love
column31: trust
column32:
and being there for one another as explained by BTS member Kim Taehyung.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            The 100 most-used emojis in the #FriendshipDay conversation  
          
          
        
UNICEFâs message of kindness and friendship was amplified by their partner accounts @bts_love_myself and @bts_bighit. The activation resonated strongly with the values of their audience on Twitter. UNICEFâs approach aligned with Gen Z users who respond positively to calls to action and who care for social justice. More broadly
column33: we know that people on Twitter care about what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in the world and they want brands to stand for something.\nUNICEF took a conversational approach and encouraged dialogue on Twitter. They empowered their followers with assets to create their own content so that allies and influencers could participate and amplify the message on #FriendshipDay. \nEscudero explains
column34: \u00e2\u0080\u009cEach and every part of the activation was driven by young people. It was important for us to continue following their lead and create a call-to-action and creative that was simple
column35:
accessible and most importantly tapped into their existing online behaviours. The series of âkind noteâ templates did just that and were based on a format that is popular amongst this demographic on social media.â
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitter helps individuals and organizations connect with each other in real-time. That interaction is made even more impactful when it is positive and driving action towards a common goal.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

#OnlyOnTwitter

column3: "title": "Inclusion & Diversity Report September 2019"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nInclusion & Diversity Report September 2019\nWednesday
column8: 18 September 2019\nLink copied successfully\nThis quarterly report highlights areas where we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re making progress in building a more diverse and inclusive Twitter
column9: and where more focus is needed:\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made progress increasing representation of women
column10: black
column11: and Latinx talent. This work is always ongoing and as we increase I&D investments we will be particularly focused on retention.\nOur approach to recruiting diverse technical talent is showing early signs of impact. Moving forward
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll double down on these programs and extend them to other parts of the business.\nDiversity in our leadership ranks remains a gap
column13: and while that gap is getting smaller
column14: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s critical to make progress here. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re implementing new initiatives focused on senior roles and expect to have more to report at year\u00e2\u0080\u0099s end.\nWe presented this report to our Board on September 12
column16: and because we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to working in the open
column17:
weâre sharing it with you here. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The Data
In 2017
column18: we set two-year diversity targets for women
column19: black
column20:
and Latinx representation at Twitter. 
Hereâs how weâre doing:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâve increased representation of women
column21: black
column22: and Latinx Tweeps
column23:
having already met our two-year goal for black representation. We will continue to invest in recruitment programs and increase our focus on retention across all three groups.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
At the macro level weâre trending in the right direction
column24: increasing Latinx and black leadership representation. Since our May report
column25: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen decreases in representation of women and black leaders
column26:
driven primarily by attrition. This is an important focus area for us and we will formalize targets for diverse representation in leadership and technical roles (below) in 2020.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâve slightly increased representation of women
column27: black
column28: and Latinx employees in technical roles
column29: driven by increased diversity recruitment efforts.\u00c2\u00a0\nRecently
column30: we also launched a hiring tour to bring even more diverse talent into technical roles. We look forward to sharing the results in Q4.\nHiring is a critical driver of our progress. In the most recent quarter
column31: our hiring of women slowed slightly
column32:
while it increased among black and Latinx employees.
New hire results below are expressed as a percentage of total new hires between August 2018 and August 2019. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Attrition data tells us how weâre doing retaining employees
column33: including diverse talent. Below are the attrition rates for women
column34: black
column35: and Latinx talent
column36: which are similar or below the company-wide attrition rate. While a good sign
column37:
we will continue to monitor and focus on retention.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
An updated snapshot of race and ethnicity in the US is below:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In our May I&D report
column38: we provided an overview of our internal diversity dashboards. We recently expanded the functionality so that Tweeps can drill down further into orgs
column39: see trends in representation across the business
column40:
and filter by leader and office location. We are committed to sharing diversity data with our people because we know deep transparency builds trust and drives change.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
AccountabilityÂ 
We recently rolled out a new I&D Health Check-Up program
column41: a monthly customized report for each member of our leadership team
column42: or \u00e2\u0080\u009cStaff.\u00e2\u0080\u009d These check-ups help keep I&D top of mind by giving leaders a more detailed view on hiring
column43: attrition
column44: and promotions for women
column45: black
column46: and Latinx employees across their org. They also provide a tool for business support functions (e.g.
column47: recruiters
column48:
HRBPs) to tailor efforts for each org and accelerate progress. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Hiring & Promos
Diversifying Leadership We want our Tweeps to see themselves reflected in our leadership. Thatâs why in Q3
column49: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re launching an initiative to require diverse candidate slates for all senior roles (L8 and above). The program requires that at least one female (worldwide) and one black or Latinx (US) qualified candidate be considered by the interview panel. We will share results from this initiative in Q2 of next year.\nRecruiting Diverse Technical Talent We play an important role in growing the pipeline of diverse technical talent. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re investing in next-generation technical leaders from nontraditional backgrounds (coding bootcamps
column50: self-taught coders
column51: veterans
column52: caregivers returning to the workforce
column53: etc.) and those underrepresented in tech (women
column54: black
column55: Latinx
column56: Native American).\u00c2\u00a0\nIn July
column57: we launched our first Engineering Apprenticeship Program
column58: a one-year rotation initially focused on people from nontraditional computer science backgrounds. Upon completion of the program
column59: graduates will transition into one of our engineering teams. Our first cohort arrives in Q4. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to working out the kinks as we learn and grow so the program may reach its full potential in 2020. \nWe are also pursuing a decentralized workforce strategy as a way of expanding our reach to tap into more diverse talent pools. So we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve launched a hiring tour for technical roles
column60: currently focused on six cities outside of San Francisco. Interviewing is hard enough
column61: so we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re offering qualified applicants airfare
column62: hotel stays \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and even onsite childcare \u00e2\u0080\u0094 for those who need it. This initial effort is focused on three skill sets (Backend/Systems
column63: Full Stack
column64: and Mobile) but we may expand to more roles and cities if it proves successful. \nPromotions We review promotions annually. In our most recent analysis
column65:
we found that the makeup of employees promoted from January 2018 to December 2018 generally tracked to our demographic population during that time frame.
Female employees (global): 40.9% of promotions*
Black employees (US): 3.3% of promotions
Latinx employees (US): 3.7% of promotions
*Promotions are defined by moving from one grade level to the next.
Based on these results
column66: we know we can do better. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re focused on addressing promotion of black and Latinx employees
column67: particularly in entry-level technical roles where we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re launching an onboarding program for new grads. We are also evaluating opportunities to formally integrate I&D into the promotion decision-making process.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nScaling a Global I&D Team We are scaling our I&D team! In July
column68: we hired a new global leader
column69: James Loduca (@JamesLoduca)
column70:
Â who is building a team with an eye to all of the ways we want to embed I&D across core business functions. We are also hiring a leader based in Asia Pacific to ensure that our I&D function has a truly global perspective as we scale.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Learning & Development
Our goal is to embed I&D throughout our learning and development programs. 
This summer
column71:
we conducted âWords Matterâ workshops at offices around the globe to empower our Tweeps with inclusive language skills to guide their daily interactions with each other. 
Here are a few things happening in Q4: 
We are launching weekly workshops as part of an expansion of our Q2 global pilot focused on Healthy Conversations. We are focused on empowering our Tweeps to have healthy conversations around the tough issues that can surface everyday and put health at the center of our culture.Â  
We are also hosting our fourth cohort of WELead
column72: our leadership program for emerging female talent
column73: and launching our first Global Female Leaders Program in partnership with Stanford University. \nMoving forward
column74: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re building out a portfolio of learning and development that we can deploy at scale on topics like Unconscious Bias
column75: Inclusive Hiring
column76:
and Inclusive Leadership. We hope to have these programs in place by the first half of next year. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Connecting with our Tweeps
Tweeps play a critical and active role in building an inclusive and diverse Twitter. Here are some Q2 highlights. 
Flock Talk The health of our employees is our top priority. Thatâs why in August we launched Flock Talk
column77: a program that builds on past efforts for Tweeps to come together during difficult times to share what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s going on with them
column78: find community
column79: and be heard by our leaders. This session was focused on hearing from Latinx Tweeps and allies in the wake of a series of events targeting Latinx people in the United States. More than 150 Tweeps from across the US and Mexico participated in the first session. The program coincides with the formation of an internal working group to meet regularly and review opportunities to better protect and promote diverse voices across our company and service.\n#TweepTour  Our leaders were on the road this summer visiting Twitter offices in Atlanta
column80: Madrid
column81: Paris
column82: London
column84: Dublin
column86: Bangalore
column87: and New York to hear directly from our Tweeps. Their feedback revealed opportunities to better resource our BRGs and make them truly global
column88: empower all Tweeps with tools to be allies
column89:
and create inspirational moments for Tweeps to create a more diverse and inclusive Twitter around the world. Weâre already working to address what we heard!
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Business Resource Groups Our BRGs are the foundation of our inclusion efforts at Twitter. To ensure they have the resources and support they need to be successful on a global scale
column90:
we are implementing these enhancements:
Expanded global leadership structure implemented across all BRGs
New strategic planning and budgeting process aligned with companyâs annual planning
Dedicated resources throughout the business to support BRG efforts
Annual strategic leadership summit to meet with leadership
column92: and celebrate success\nIn September
column93: we celebrate Latinx voices around the world (corresponding with Hispanic Heritage Month in the US). We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also excited to launch our latest BRG
column94: Twitter Able (@TwitterAble)
column95: for Tweeps with disabilities and their allies.\u00c2\u00a0 \nHere are some of the amazing things that our BRGs made possible in Q2: \nTwitter Alas\u00c2\u00a0(@TwitterAlas) deepened its partnership with Techqueria
column96: a nonprofit serving the largest community of Latinx people in tech. Together
column97: we hosted events in New York and San Francisco to learn from Latinx leaders
column98: network with peers
column99:
and deepen the connection between great Latinx talent and our company.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitter AsiansÂ (@TwitterAsians) hosted an event bringing the Asian tech community together in Cambridge and celebrated the release of âBlinded by the Lightâ with a cast Q&A and advanced screenings for members in New York and San Francisco.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
BlackbirdsÂ (@Blackbirds) launched the Blackbirds Ambassador program to expand Blackbirds leadership and support to more Twitter offices around the world. This program empowers ambassadors to locally grow Blackbirds with a dedicated budget
column100: resources
column101: and communication channels.\nTwitter Open\u00c2\u00a0(@TwitterOpen) conducted 40+ global events
column103: and digital campaigns for Pride. To highlight the diversity and intersectionality of its community
column104: Twitter Open co-hosted events around the world with Blackbirds
column105: Twitter Alas
column106: Twitter Asians
column107: and Twitter Women
column108:
and marched in the Dublin and London Pride parades. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In honor of the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall Riots (#Stonewall50)
column109:
Twitter Open produced a campaign spotlighting powerful voices in the LGBTQ+ community to emphasize the power of being seen and heard. It culminated in a large-scale digital out-of-home activation in Times Square for World Pride in NYC and in San Francisco during its Pride parade. #SeeUsHearUs
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitter StripesÂ (@TwitterStripes) is growing a partnership with Merging Vets and Players
column110: an organization that supports former combat veterans and professional athletes \u00e2\u0080\u009cafter the uniform comes off.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Stripes is also partnering with Student Vets of America in an effort to align veteran talent on college campuses with our University Recruiting efforts.\nTwitter Women\u00c2\u00a0(@TwitterWomen) hosted seven events with 200+ attendees. Highlights include an \u00e2\u0080\u009cOwn Your Own Story\u00e2\u0080\u009d workshop with Olivia Christian on crafting an authentic and compelling personal brand story
column111: and fireside chats in New York and Dublin with authors Lydia Fenet and Jean Case
column114:
respectively.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Product & Partnerships
Building a Diverse Supply Chain As we launched this program
column115: much of our work has focused on understanding our current spend with diverse suppliers
column116: the resources that buyers need to be successful
column117:
and the unique value Twitter can bring to diverse suppliers and our community partners.Â 
We developed program objectives for 2019 and beyond focused on: 
Connecting qualified diverse-owned businesses with Twitter
Establishing strategies that help suppliers better compete for Twitter businessÂ 
Setting near and long-term diverse supplier spend goalsÂ 
Developing accurate and timely diverse spend reportingÂ 
Promoting Twitterâs commitment to Supplier Inclusion
In Q4
column118: we are launching a Supplier Development virtual workshop for diverse suppliers entitled \u00e2\u0080\u009cHow to Do Business With Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u009d and hosting \u00e2\u0080\u009cA Night of Networking\u00e2\u0080\u009d event in collaboration with Twitter Women
column119: bringing together women-owned businesses and Twitter. \nInvesting in Communities Our I&D efforts extend beyond our workforce to include underrepresented voices on our service
column120: and the communities where our Tweeps work and live.\nThis quarter we hosted a new event series of #TwitterVoices to build trust and elevate diverse voices on the platform. Some highlights include: \nIn Cannes
column121: we celebrated black and brown creators with a cameo by The McKinley Clover Steppers
column122: a group of young black women from the South Bronx who use traditional step dance to advance equality.\nIn Detroit
column123: 40 powerful voices came together to discuss investment in the city
column125: and explore opportunities for partnership.\nWe also launched 10 days of virtual #TweetUps in 40 locations around the world to connect people across difference and distance. As part of the activation
column126: we hosted #TweetUps for black #TwitterVoices in Detroit to share a meal with Afro-Brazilians in Sao Paulo. Black voices in Harlem dined with Nigerians in Lagos
column127:
and Latinx voices in LA convened across the table with Afro-Latino people in Honduras. These powerful connections and conversations enabled underrepresented communities to share what's happening in their world and discover what's happening in someone else's. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
On the five-year anniversary of the Ferguson tragedy
column128: we met with activists who were active on the platform during the protests after the death of Michael Brown. This gave the activists a moment to sit down with Jack Dorsey (@Jack) and Twitter leadership to talk about activism on the platform moving forward
column129:
and ways to invest in the greater community.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
#TwitterforGood It is important to us to help people with barriers to employment find work thatâs meaningful to them and open pathways to careers in tech for underrepresented minorities.Â Â 
In San Francisco
column130: this year we have invested $1.6 million in local partners
column131: donated 340+ computers to groups like Dev/Mission
column132: Code Tenderloin and Hack the Hood
column135: a center that lets homeless or low-income residents access technology
column137: and training. \nWe also conducted 85+ volunteer projects across 26 offices
column138: spanning the entire globe on #TwitterforGood Day. We worked with 1
column140:
800 hours of service in close partnership with 80 community-based organizations. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Whatâs Next?
Phew! That was a lot ââÂ and weâre just getting warmed up. Thanks to all of our Tweeps who helped drive progress this quarter
column141: and to all of you for coming along for the ride and sharing your feedback. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited for all the opportunities ahead. See you back here for our year-end report
column142:
and until then â see you on Twitter!

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "3 things to consider when vetting social listening tools"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
3 things to consider when vetting social listening tools
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8:
10 September 2019
Link copied successfully
Ready to take your market insights to the next level?
3 important factors to consider when choosing a social listening tool
Whatâs happening in the world? What are people talking about? How do they feel about certain topics
column9: brands or products? Organizations have tried for a long time to uncover these types of insights through traditional research methods like surveys
column10: focus groups and interviews.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nWhat if you could take your research to the next level and uncover even deeper insights in real time? Today
column11: an unprecedented number of people - including your customers
column12: prospects
column13: competitors and other stakeholders - are freely sharing their experiences
column14: interests and opinions publicly
column15: in real time
column16: on Twitter. Twitter is the largest
column17: publicly available
column18:
searchable archive of human-generated thought ever. Itâs the worldâs largest focus group. Are you ready to start listening?
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Social Listening: start with why (and what)
Tapping into the worldâs largest focus group might seem daunting. The good news is that social listening platforms have the expertise
column19: technology and tools to make it easier to get started. But
column20: before choosing a vendor
column21: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll need to get clear on your objectives. Are you seeking brand or industry insights? Customer feedback? Crisis monitoring? Something else? And
column22: once you have the data
column23: what type of analysis do you need to perform? Do you want to know how your audience is feeling about a product
column24: service
column25: experience or issue? What about searching images for your brand or your competitor\u00e2\u0080\u0099s logos?\u00c2\u00a0\nKnowing what you want will form the foundation for finding a social listening tool that best meets your needs. When you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re ready to start evaluating vendors
column26:
keep the following three factors in mind:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
1. Data
Access to the relevant data can be a key differentiator among social listening platforms. Itâs critical that you understand how they are procuring their social data and from which sources. Areas to probe:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Data sources - From social channels to blogs
column27: reviews
column28: forums
column29: print & TV
column30: there are many sources of data. Which data sources does the vendor support and
column31: of those
column32: which ones will help you achieve your listening goals? Be ready with your own list of sources
column33: geographic focus and topics you want to analyze.\nData providers - Is the platform accessing data via third party brokers
column34: direct from the social networks themselves or by \u00e2\u0080\u0099scraping\u00e2\u0080\u0099 the web? If they are accessing the data directly from the source
column35: inquire if it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s via publicly available APIs
column36: elevated access or a paid licensing agreement. This is important as changes to APIs and/or commercial agreements could impact your data access. Another important and related question is whether the data provided is being sampled or is full fidelity. Is metadata included?\u00c2\u00a0\nHistorical data - Looking for insights from the past? If yes
column37: make sure your vendor has that capability. Does the social listening tool provide access to historical data from its various sources? If so
column38: how far back in time
column39:
and is this full fidelity or sampled? How long does it take the vendor to access and showcase insights from historical data?
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
2. Text analysis (Natural Language Processing)
At the heart of any social listening social listening tool is text analysis: the techniques used to understand
column40: organize
column41:
and apply sentiment and emotion to text. Some things to consider:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
How is the platform performing text analysis? This is really about a vendorâs accuracy when it comes to annotating your data. Social listening tools have a variety of approaches to this
column42: so spend some time discussing how their approach differs from others. You likely will hear acronyms like NLP
column43: ML and AI - make sure your vendor can break these down in an understandable way.\nWhat level of detail is the text analyzed: paragraph
column44: sentence or phrase? At what level is sentiment and emotion applied? Does the vendor guarantee a minimum accuracy
column45: and if so
column46: how is it measured? How is the sentiment scored
column47:
and can you override it?
What languages are supported? Can they deliver the same accuracy for each language?
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
3. Customer experience
When it comes to social listening platforms
column48: your experience matters. To choose a vendor who can act as a true partner
column49: helping you to improve your social listening maturity
column50:
consider:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Industry expertise - Specific industries tend to have their own needs when it comes to social listening. Does the vendor understand and have experience in your industry? Ask for case studies and customer references.
Onboarding & customer support - How will they support you to get up and running? Do they provide services to help you build advanced queries and/or validate findings? What SLAs do they offer for customer support?
Alerting
column51: reporting & visualizations - Does the social listening tool offer real-time alerts? Do they allow you to create customized alerts and thresholds? When it comes to reporting
column52:
does the vendor allow you to easily export charts and graphs? And do they provide display technology for offices and war rooms or command centres?
User experience - Can the user interface be navigated by a casual user allowing them to build queries and analyze results? Is a query builder available for those who canât use boolean logic? 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
When it comes to social listening
column53: you have choices. Get clear on your needs and then carefully evaluate each of the vendors. Need more support? Visit data.twitter.com for social listening case studies
column54:
a list of Twitter Official Partners or to get in touch with our team. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Updating our advertising policies on state media"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Updating our advertising policies on state media
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 19 August 2019\nLink copied successfully\nOur singular mission is to serve the public conversation. This mission applies to every part of our service
column9: including our advertising and promotional products.  Today
column10: we are updating our advertising policies with respect to state media. Going forward
column11: we will not accept advertising from state-controlled news media entities. Any affected accounts will be free to continue to use Twitter to engage in public conversation
column12: just not our advertising products.  This is a global approach and will be enforced across our entire business.  Why are we doing this?  We want to protect healthy discourse and open conversation. To that end
column13: we believe that there is a difference between engaging in conversation with accounts you choose to follow and the content you see from advertisers in your Twitter experience which may be from accounts you're not currently following. We have policies for both but we have higher standards for our advertisers.  This policy will not apply to taxpayer-funded entities
column14: including independent public broadcasters.  How will we define state-controlled media in this context? This policy will apply to news media entities that are either financially or editorially controlled by the state. It has been informed by established academic and civil society leaders in this space. Sources include Reporters Without Borders Press Freedom Index
column15: Freedom House
column16: the Economist Intelligence Unit Democracy Index
column17: the European Journalism Centre\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Media Landscapes Report
column18: the Committee to Protect Journalists
column19: and UNESCO's framework to assess media development and independence.  We will be making policy determinations on the basis of critical issues of media freedom and independence
column20: such as control of editorial content
column21: financial ownership
column22: influence or interference over broadcasters
column23: editors
column24: and journalists
column25: direct and indirect exertion of political pressure
column26: and/or control over the production and distribution process.  This policy will not apply to entities that are solely dedicated to entertainment
column27: sports
column28: and travel content. However
column29: if the content is mixed with news
column30: it will be prohibited.  Next steps We will be notifying directly affected entities in the coming days. They will have 30 days to offboard from our advertising products
column31: after which we will stringently enforce these policies. In the meantime
column32: no new campaigns will be allowed and we will enforce our policies rigorously. Affected media entities are free to continue to use their Twitter account(s) to organically participate in public conversation
column33:
as long as they are in compliance with the Twitter Rules.  We are exploring transparency approaches to keep the public updated on these types of actions going forward.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet

column3: "title": "Long story
column4: short: 6-second video bidding is now available"
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/product/2019/Long-story-short-6-second-video-bidding-is-now-available"
column8: "post_text": "Product\nLong story
column9: short: 6-second video bidding is now available\nMonday
column10: 19 August 2019\nLink copied successfully\nWith mobile video consumption at an all time high
column11: studies show brand impact happens almost instantaneously (within seconds) with video ads. A recent Twitter-sponsored study by EyeSee determined short-form (under six seconds)
column12: sound-off videos with clear branding drive significantly better ad recall and message association on mobile than linear TVC style videos. Optimal video creative and viewing experiences drive brand lift and sales. After all
column13: when was the last time you enjoyed sitting through a minute-long ad on your phone? Never? Us
column14: too.\u00c2\u00a0\nTo help advertisers get their video stories in front of the most valuable audience in the moments they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re most receptive
column15: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to announce the availability of a 6-second video bid unit to advertisers globally. With this
column16: advertisers have the security of transacting on a longer view
column17: while still providing the optimal experience of a short-form
column18: mobile video to their audience. Advertisers will be charged only once their ad is viewed for 6 seconds
column19: with pixels at 50% in view (6s/50%). This bid unit is globally available on Promoted Video
column20: In-stream Video Sponsorships
column21: and In-stream Video Ads for assets 15 seconds or less in length.\nUnlike other channels
column22: Twitter is not a forced-view environment\u00e2\u0080\u0094 our platform\u00e2\u0080\u0099s native video consumption tends to be shorter and more serendipitous as people discover fresh
column23: relevant content by scrolling through their feed. Whether launching a new product or connecting a brand message with audiences across the world
column24: you can maximize your impact with our valuable audience by running optimal creative. Today we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to provide a flexible option for advertisers who care about the completed view metric
column25:
but are ready to lean into the mobile-first paradigm and develop short-form assets optimized for in-feed viewing.
Advertisers across the world are embracing this new format.Â
