column3: "title": "Information operations directed at Hong Kong"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nInformation operations directed at Hong Kong\nMonday
column8: 19 August 2019\nLink copied successfully\nWe are disclosing a significant state-backed information operation focused on the situation in Hong Kong
column9: specifically the protest movement and their calls for political change.  What we are disclosing This disclosure consists of 936 accounts originating from within the People\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Republic of China (PRC). Overall
column10: these accounts were deliberately and specifically attempting to sow political discord in Hong Kong
column11: including undermining the legitimacy and political positions of the protest movement on the ground. Based on our intensive investigations
column12: we have reliable evidence to support that this is a coordinated state-backed operation. Specifically
column13: we identified large clusters of accounts behaving in a coordinated manner to amplify messages related to the Hong Kong protests.\nAs Twitter is blocked in PRC
column14: many of these accounts accessed Twitter using VPNs. However
column15: some accounts accessed Twitter from specific unblocked IP addresses originating in mainland China. The accounts we are sharing today represent the most active portions of this campaign; a larger
column16: spammy network of approximately 200
column17: 000 accounts \u00e2\u0080\u0094 many created following our initial suspensions \u00e2\u0080\u0094 were proactively suspended before they were substantially active on the service.\nAll the accounts have been suspended for a range of violations of our platform manipulation policies
column18:
which we define as:Â 
Spam
Coordinated activity
Fake accounts
Attributed activity
Ban evasion
Examples of violative content
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Next steps Covert
column19: manipulative behaviors have no place on our service \u00e2\u0080\u0094 they violate the fundamental principles on which our company is built. As we have said before
column20: it is clear that information operations and coordinated inauthentic behavior will not cease. These deceptive strategies have been around for far longer than Twitter has existed. They adapt and change as the geopolitical terrain evolves worldwide and as new technologies emerge. For our part
column21: we are committed to understanding and combating how bad-faith actors use our services.  Today we are adding archives containing complete Tweet and user information for the 936 accounts we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve disclosed to our archive of information operations \u00e2\u0080\u0094 the largest of its kind in the industry.  We will continue to be vigilant
column22:
learning from this network and proactively enforcing our policies to serve the public conversation. We hope that by being transparent and open we will empower further learning and public understanding of these nefarious tactics. You can access relevant account and Tweet information on our dedicatedÂ Election Integrity Hub.
Note: We have divided these archives into two parts to better enable review of the intersecting networks of accounts which comprise this campaign. We have evidence to indicate that both sets are associated with the same entity.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Guest Post: Emily Drewry discusses Forbes\u2019 data-driven Twitter strategy"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Guest Post: Emily Drewry discusses Forbesâ data-driven Twitter strategy
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 5 August 2019\nLink copied successfully\nForbes
column9: a global publisher with a focus on business news
column10: is constantly reinventing itself to meet the demands of modern media. Amid talks of declining news readership
column11: Forbes had its most profitable year in 2018 since it became Forbes Media in 2006. Playing a major role in Forbes\u00e2\u0080\u0099 success story is their focus on social-first content and personalized engagements with millions of followers across its social channels \u00e2\u0080\u0093 particularly on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nI spoke with Emily Drewry
column12: Senior Manager of Social Content at Forbes
column13: for an inside look at Forbes\u00e2\u0080\u0099 approach to creating engaging content and developing a global Twitter strategy. According to Emily
column14: \u00e2\u0080\u009cTwitter for us is like nowhere else.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Check out the full interview below to learn more about how Forbes is creating relevant content for its Twitter audience.\nRachel: How many handles does Forbes have
column15: and how do you manage them?\nEmily: Forbes has more than 30 social media accounts so we really use the calendar in Sprinklr to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s coming up and this enables the social team across the world to stay on the same page. The calendar has turned into a communication tool for us
column16: to help us collaborate.\u00c2\u00a0\nMy team spends an average of 6 hours per day using Sprinklr
column17: and we estimate our jobs would take an average 5 hours additional per day without the platform.\nRachel: What\u00e2\u0080\u0099s your Twitter strategy?\u00c2\u00a0\nEmily: Forbes has many different types of coverage. We are known for longer
column18: in-depth features but we also have a trending news initiative. For breaking news reporters
column19: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s essential we get their stories out on Twitter as soon as possible. That allows them to be part of the real-time news conversation and reach a crucial
column20: broad audience. Twitter for us is like nowhere else. If you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re not on Twitter when a conversation is happening
column21: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a huge opportunity missed.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur editor is scheduling posts throughout the day
column22: 24 hours a day
column23: 7 days a week. We post probably 100 posts a day on Twitter
column24: focusing on the most timely content that comes from Forbes.com.\u00c2\u00a0\nWith Sprinklr publishing
column25: we schedule content on Twitter ahead of time for nights and weekends so we can still go home and be normal people. If we need to quickly change the time of the scheduled post or edit the text within it
column26: we don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t have to redo the post in Sprinklr which is a productivity savings\u00e2\u0080\u0094 we can just drag and drop the post to the new time and make edits within the platform. News stories are coming in quickly all the time so we often have to reschedule things
column27: and I can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t imagine what it would be like to manually change scheduled Twitter posts every time we wanted to make an edit. Definitely saves us a number of hours a week.\nRachel: Can you talk about your video series the #ForbesFlash?\u00c2\u00a0\nEmily: #ForbesFlash started in July 2017
column28: and it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a regular recap of the biggest stories of the week. What\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important and valuable about it is that I\u00e2\u0080\u0099m not reiterating the stories that everyone has already read. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re focused on the quality journalism that our reporters have put out for the week.\u00c2\u00a0\nTwitter was the home initially for the #ForbesFlash because I found that our audience didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t have a visual opportunity to catch up on the most important news of the week. Because of Sprinklr reporting
column29: I know which stories were the most popular for the week so it helps me curate the script for these videos.\u00c2\u00a0\nRachel: How have you increased the engagement of the content you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re putting out for Forbes across social?\u00c2\u00a0\nEmily: Based on the ability to look at all of our social content comprehensively in Sprinklr
column30: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been able to optimize our social content across platforms for specifically what our audience is interested in seeing. I can use Sprinklr to filter by channels and easily understand that the content that performs best on Twitter might not be what performs best on Facebook or LinkedIn. So we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re using the real-time engagement metrics and click-through rates to help us continuously improve the effectiveness of our content.\u00c2\u00a0\nRachel: Final thoughts?\u00c2\u00a0\nEmily: Twitter is the platform we publish on the most because it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s great for real-time
column31: breaking news and it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s where our audience spends their time. Twitter is a news aggregator for many people
column32: so it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important for us to join in as a voice for our readers.\nTo learn more about Sprinklr
column33:
head to partners.twitter.com.
Â

column3: "title": "Are marketers missing customer signals on social?"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Are marketers missing customer signals on social?
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 19 July 2019\nLink copied successfully\nIn our data-driven world
column9: marketers need to think more about the nature of social conversations and not just look at raw social data. You would probably agree: It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a lot harder to get value from social insights if you don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t have a clear sense of the conversations your customers are having with each other
column10: as well as with you and other brands on social.\nWe live in a time where people are generating and accessing an extraordinary amount of data
column11: both real-time and historical. What makes Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s social data so unique is that it reflects the public conversations happening in real-time. And what makes Twitter audiences so unique is that they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re made up of influencers who drive public conversation. They are receptive
column12: relevant and looking for new experiences with a discovery mindset\u00e2\u0080\u0094not just a lean-back-and-entertain-me mindset. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why Twitter is investing in new ways of understanding behind conversations and delivering meaningful data about the hundreds of millions of Tweets shared on Twitter every day.\nWhen you think about the size and breadth of the conversation on Twitter
column13: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s essentially the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s largest focus group-- of present and historical data. Research shows 79% of Twitter users follow brands and 53% recommend products and services to friends and family. Listening to what consumers are saying can surface unique opportunities that extend beyond marketing
column14: into customer service
column15: sales and even product innovation. And for a brand
column16: this allows them to provide a better customer experience
column17: avert issues that could have a negative impact
column18: and get valuable insights to help deliver products and services that better meet consumer needs.\nDiana Helander
column19: head of marketing for the Twitter Developer Platform
column20: chatted with Marketing Disrupted podcast hosts Brent Chaters and Amber Mac about the importance of social listening
column21: and the role of Twitter Data in helping marketers solve problems.\u00c2\u00a0\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important for brands to start listening
column22: \u00e2\u0080\u009d Helander says in the Marketing Disrupted podcast episode Brands On-Line: Marketing
column23: Tech and Social Media. \u00e2\u0080\u009cBrands can help identify something newsworthy
column24: or if needed
column25: remediate an issue. But that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s just a first step. Following on from that is active engagement with those audiences
column26: whether it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s for brand voice
column27: marketing campaigns or customer service\u00e2\u0080\u0094engaging in that conversation and doing so in an authentic way.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nBy listening first
column28: brands can then analyze conversations and social mentions. This can provide a better understanding of what consumers are talking about
column29: doing or buying
column30: which is where solutions like trend analysis come into play.\nIn the podcast
column31: Helander shares some case-study examples of how Twitter Official Partners have used social listening to drive big results and how they\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve used social insights to find fun ways to engage their audiences. For example
column32: she discusses how Sprinklr
column33: a Twitter Official Partner
column34: helped Chick-fil-A use artificial intelligence to spot signs of food-borne illness from social media posts with 78% accuracy
column35: and how social listening helped NASA spot a gap in its content strategy and successfully engage new audiences.\nCheck out Diana Helander\u00e2\u0080\u0099s full interview about Twitter Data\u00e2\u0080\u0099s role in marketing on the Marketing Disrupted podcast
column36: episode 3: \"Brands On-Line: Marketing
column37: Tech and Social Media.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Helander\u00e2\u0080\u0099s portion starts at the 29:09 mark
column38:
just after McDonald's Canada VP and CTO Lara Skripitsky.

column3: "title": "Introducing a new Twitter.com"
column7: "post_text": "Product\nIntroducing a new Twitter.com\nMonday
column8: 15 July 2019\nLink copied successfully\nToday
column9: we are starting to roll out a new Twitter.com \u00e2\u0080\u0093 a refreshed and updated website that is faster
column10: easier to navigate and more personalized. The site has an updated look and feel that is more consistent with the Twitter you see on other devices
column11: making it easier to access some of your favorite features
column12:
and with more options to make it your own.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâve been testing aspects of this for a while so we could make sure the new site reflected how you use Twitter. Thanks to hundreds of thousands of responses we received during those tests
column13: Twitter.com\u00e2\u0080\u0099s features make conversations easier to find and follow \u00e2\u0080\u0093 and just a bit more fun: \nMore of What\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Happening: We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve brought over Explore to bring you the same great content found in our apps; expect more live video and local moments personalized for wherever you are in the world. Get context with profile information within conversations and check out your Top Trends in any view so you never miss what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening.\nEasy Access to Your Favorite Features: Bookmarks
column14: Lists
column15: and your Profile are right up front and have their own spot on the side navigation
column16: making it easier and faster to jump between different tabs.\nDirect Messages All in One Place: Direct Messages have been expanded so you can see your conversations and send messages all from the same view. Now there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s less hassle switching between screens to send a message.\nLogin
column17: Logout Struggle No More: Whether you have one profile or a few
column18: now you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also able to switch between accounts faster
column19: directly from the side navigation; your stan
column20: foodie and cat meme accounts thank you.\nMake Twitter Yours: The love is real for dark mode themes Dim and Lights Out. You\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve asked for even more ways to personalize Twitter so we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re bringing you different themes and color options
column21:
along with two options for dark mode.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

Want to hear more from our team on how they redesigned and built Twitter.com? Check out our engineering blog series âNew Nest: Building the New Twitter.comâ which shares more on how we rebuilt the website from the ground up.
Weâre looking forward to hearing what you think about our new site

column7:
"post_text": "Product
Giving you more control over your conversations
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 11 July 2019\nLink copied successfully\nEveryday
column9: people start important conversations on Twitter
column10: from #MeToo and #BlackLivesMatter
column11: to discussions around #NBAFinals or their favorite television shows. These conversations bring people together to debate
column12: learn
column13: and laugh. That said we know that distracting
column14: irrelevant
column15: and offensive replies can derail the discussions that people want to have. We believe people should have some control over the conversations they start. So we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re going to test a new feature that gives people the option to hide replies to their Tweets.\u00c2\u00a0\nStarting next week
column16: people in Canada will have the option to hide replies to their Tweets. Anyone around the world will be able to see and engage with hidden replies by tapping the grey icon that will appear. We want to be clear and transparent when someone has made the decision to hide a reply
column17:
and will be looking at how this feature gives more control to authors while not compromising the transparency and openness that is central to what makes Twitter so powerful.Â 
By testing in one country we want to get feedback and better understand how this tool can improve before itâs available globally.Â 
Hereâs what it will look like:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            What it looks like when you hide a Tweet 
          
          
        
          
            What it looks like to view a conversation with hidden replies 
          
          
        
Weâll be testing this for the next few weeks. So if you can use this or happen to see it on Twitter
column18:
let us know what you think!

column3: "title": "Guest post: Taking the high road: The power of purpose-driven stances "
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Guest post: Taking the high road: The power of purpose-driven stances 
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 10 July 2019\nLink copied successfully\nThe age of the purpose-driven brand has arrived
column9: for (mostly) better and (a little) worse. Marketing blogs are packed to the gills with stories of high-profile brands taking stands on controversial social and cultural issues. While some brands come out on the other side triumphant
column10: with elevated sales and glorious brand alignment
column11: others hope the world will soon forget how they offended the masses with distasteful missteps. The few that succeed can likely thank a healthy mix of luck and calculated risk.\nTrying to insert your brand into a culture moment while being sensitive to polarizing points of view is no easy task. But by taking purpose-driven stances
column12: brands can offer strength and steadiness during tumultuous times.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cIn a time of immense turmoil
column13: people are turning to brands as islands of stability.\u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\u0093 Richard Edelman
column14: Chairman
column15: Edelman\nConsumers want brands that stand for something by taking a position on an issue and having a strong point of view
column16: but that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not all. Today\u00e2\u0080\u0099s consumers also expect brands to contribute to their quality of life. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why successful
column17: purpose-driven brand platforms require more than just good timing. To stand out
column18: brands must identify a purpose and turn to data
column19: insights and social listening to engage in relevant
column20: genuine
column21: open and empathetic conversations.\nAccording to a 2019 Sprout Social report
column22: 72% of consumers expect brands to be positive contributors to society and almost half expect brands to act as leaders. An additional 45% of consumers say brands can strengthen their connection with customers by supporting a cause that is personally relevant to them.\u00c2\u00a0\nMajor brands like Patagonia
column23: Nike
column24: and Axe have all taken purpose driven stances on widespread cultural concerns
column25: and the role that they play is unique and powerful. Because they each prioritized brand authenticity in the cultural moments they chose to enter
column26:
that elusive balance of luck and calculated risk has allowed them to operate as the beacons of strength and steadiness consumers say they want in the brands they trust.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Movements Start on Twitter
When something happens in the world around us
column27: for many of us
column28: \u00c2\u00a0 our instinct is to pull out our phones and share it with others. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s the moment when \u00e2\u0080\u009clook at me
column29: \u00e2\u0080\u009d becomes the infinitely more powerful \u00e2\u0080\u009clook at this.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\u00c2\u00a0\nTwitter represents the daily pulse of global conversations and provides the ultimate context for brands to connect with people. People on Twitter\u00c2\u00a0 are active and driving the conversations that shape culture. It is the largest searchable collection of human thought
column30:
and longest-running focus group thatâs ever been created. Movements start on Twitter because the community is active and engaged.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Patagoniaâs Dedication to the PlanetÂ 
Outdoor retailer Patagonia set the standard for aligning a values-driven corporate mission with its audiencesâ personal values
column31: as evidenced by a decades-long history of supporting environmental causes. When the White House announced a reduction in the size of two national parks in 2017
column32: Patagonia responded almost immediately by turning their website into a call to action. Visitors to the site were greeted with following the message:\n\u00c2\u00a0\u00e2\u0080\u009cThe President Stole Your Land. In an illegal move
column33: the president just reduced the size of Bears Ears and Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monuments. This is the largest elimination of protected land in American history. Patagonia won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t step down.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nDays later
column34: Patagonia took its defiance of the current administration one step further and filed a lawsuit seeking to clarify the Antiquities Act of 1906
column35: which states a sitting president has the power to create national monuments but not reduce them. The brand also put its money where\u00c2\u00a0 its values are by donating a $10 million tax break it received as a result of policy changes by the current administration to environmental causes.\nThough there were some calls of \u00e2\u0080\u009cnewsjacking\u00e2\u0080\u009d on Twitter in the days after Patagonia\u00e2\u0080\u0099s public opposition
column36: the majority of the response was overwhelmingly positive because the brand was using its considerable platform to raise awareness about an issue its customers were passionate about. And that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s good for business as well as perception: Patagonia\u00e2\u0080\u0094a company with $1 billion in profits in 2018\u00e2\u0080\u0094 saw a 7 percent increase in sales the week after their statement. In Patagonia\u00e2\u0080\u0099s case
column37:
success came when their actions were deeply grounded in fulfilling their mission statement and lived up to consumer expectations.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Nike Supports Kaepernick
In 2016
column38: N.F.L. quarterback Colin Kaepernick sat during the national anthem at a pre-season game in order to raise awareness about racism
column39: police brutality and the oppression of people of color. The next year Kaepernick left the San Francisco 49ers and became a free agent but wasn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t signed by another team. In 2018
column40: Nike made the bold move of partnering with Kaepernick on a campaign about standing up for beliefs
column41:
featuring a black-and-white photo of Kaepernick and the powerful message âBelieve in something even if it means sacrificing everything. #Justdoit.â
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In 24 hours
column42: the post garnered more Twitter \u00e2\u0080\u009clikes\u00e2\u0080\u009d than former U.S. President Obama\u00e2\u0080\u0099s announcement of his second term
column43: and twice as many views on Twitter than any other platform. Nike won the \u00e2\u0080\u009cMarketer of the Year\u00e2\u0080\u009d title by Ad Age in 2018 for this collaboration.\nThe campaign however
column44: was met with mixed reactions
column45:
with some Tweeting pictures of Nike purchases to show their support and others taking to Twitter to share their outrage. It even led to a trend of people setting their shoes on fire and cutting the Nike logo off of their socks. A video of flaming sneakers was viewed 11 million times on Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
But despite the polarizing nature of the campaign
column46: Nike\u00e2\u0080\u0099s sales increased by 30 percent and their market-cap grew by nearly $6 billion in just a couple of weeks. Nike was able to take a calculated risk in part because the message aligned with the shared values of the brand and their audience
column47:
and it paid off.
Axe Redefines What it Means to be Masculine
Patagonia and Nike are both examples of brands with long histories of championing a specific set of values. But what about when a brand that realizes its values are suddenly out of sync with its audience?
Axe
column48: maker of men\u00e2\u0080\u0099s grooming products
column49: built its brand based on traditional views of masculinity--namely that one\u00e2\u0080\u0099s value as a man is rooted in your ability to attract women. But by the mid 2010s
column50: public opinion of how masculinity is defined and portrayed had clearly evolved.\nIn 2016
column51: Axe took a pulse check of what was important to its audience of young men and found that perceptions of what it meant to \u00e2\u0080\u009cbe a man\u00e2\u0080\u009d were more complex than they may have seemed in the past. Rather than rehashing its \u00e2\u0080\u009csex sells\u00e2\u0080\u009d-based advertising of old
column52: Axe responded to the cultural evolution with a campaign that put the definition of masculinity squarely in the hands of its audience. The tagline
column53: \u00e2\u0080\u009cFind your magic
column54: \u00e2\u0080\u009d encouraged guys to embrace what made them each unique.\nThis new campaign bucked traditional views of what it means to be a man and instead embraced a wide range of definitions
column55: ultimately encouraging guys to be themselves in order to unlock what is memorable and special about them. In the end
column56: the campaign had 70 percent positive sentiments across Twitter
column57: and resulted in a 15 percent increase in purchase intent.\nAxe\u00e2\u0080\u0099s campaign worked because it didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t ask anything of the audience
column58:
but rather reflected the audienceâs own positive qualities back to them. It was tested and rooted in real cultural shifts and behavior.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
How brands can create a framework for purpose
According to Sprout Social
column59: four out of five consumers believe society is more divided than ever before and they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re looking to brands to reignite connection. Sixty-four percent of consumers want brands to connect with them and just under half (49%) expect brands to bring people together towards a common goal.\u00c2\u00a0\nAfter years of observing brands who \u00e2\u0080\u009cdo purpose well\u00e2\u0080\u009d on Twitter
column60:
weâve discovered this formula as a framework for arriving at a unique brand purpose.
Â Brands should ask:
What fuels your business? 
What values guide your company?
How are you showing your commitment in a way that invites others to rally with you?
Does your brand have a right or role to be here? Does your company have a history to values that align with this topic?
Will this stand up 10 years from now?
Are you doing or just saying? Is your brand making a commitment that supports the purpose? Are you showing
column61: not just telling? [SM2]\u00c2\u00a0\nBy answering these questions and drilling down to your brand\u00e2\u0080\u0099s true purpose
column62: you can feel confident that your audiences will respond with passion.\nPatagonia
column63: Nike and Axe all took calculated risks and landed big results. Each clarified its company\u00e2\u0080\u0099s values
column64: understood where those values intersected with what their audience cared about and built experiences that supported those shared touchpoints. The result? Real
column65: deep
column66: authentic connections with customers.\n\u00c2\u00a0To learn more about Sprout Social
column67:
check out their profile on partners.twitter.com.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter

column3: "title": "Introducing the Twitter Engineering Apprenticeship Program"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nIntroducing the Twitter Engineering Apprenticeship Program\nWednesday
column8: 10 July 2019\nLink copied successfully\nIn our Inclusion & Diversity quarterly report
column9: we announced that we were looking to generate a stronger pipeline for diverse talent. As we look to make our company reflect the diverse voices that come to Twitter every day
column10: we are excited to announce the launch of the Twitter Engineering Apprenticeship Program.\u00c2\u00a0\nThrough this program
column11: we hope to grow our technical workforce of next-generation leaders from nontraditional backgrounds (coding bootcamps
column12: self-taught coders
column13: veterans
column14: caregivers returning to the workforce
column15: etc.) and those underrepresented in tech (women
column16: black
column17: Latinx
column18: Native American). Through our new apprenticeship program
column19: participants will go through a one-year rotation program with full-time employment benefits. Upon completion of the program
column20: they will graduate and join one of our engineering teams.\nWe are working to significantly grow our company and our technical workforce in the next year. This program will help us bring up-and-coming talent into our engineering and data science teams across our San Francisco
column21: Boulder
column22: and New York offices.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe know that great talent exists outside the traditional sourcing structures
column23: and we need to do a better job of creating and fostering a sustainable pipeline of diverse talent. This is one step we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re taking to do our part.\u00c2\u00a0\nDo you see yourself in this program? Come help us build the best Twitter for people around the world. Over the course of 12 months
column24: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll participate in a rotation program within Twitter Engineering
column25: helping build Twitter for Android
column26: iOS
column27: or web
column28: working on our backend systems
column29: or on our Data Science team. The program is designed for applicants with at least two years of any work experience and will provide hands-on experience
column30: while pairing applicants with dedicated coaches and mentors to set you up for a successful career in engineering.\u00c2\u00a0\nApplications are now open
column31: and will close on July 31
column32:
2019. You can apply here. We canât wait to have you join the flock!

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column4: helping brands create and optimize content"
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/product/2019/Introducing-Twitter-ArtHouse"
column8: "post_text": "Product\nIntroducing Twitter ArtHouse
column9:
helping brands create and optimize content
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column10: 10 July 2019\nLink copied successfully\nAccording to Nielsen
column11: advertising creative is the top factor in driving sales*
column12: so brands need to create content that drives brand love and business impact. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why today
column13: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re bringing together the combined power of our Creator management
column14: video editing
column15: and live broadcasting offerings under one roof: Twitter ArtHouse.\nTwitter ArtHouse connects brands with the creative capital and talent of Influencers
column16: Artists and Editors who can add a new dimension of relevance to their content. The global team brings together content strategists
column17:
digital producers and influencer marketing specialists to help brands launch new products and connect to whatâs happening in culture.
Our mission is simple: to help brands design Twitter first content that moves people.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Creator Influence and ArtistryÂ 
At Twitter ArtHouse
column18: we help curate best-in-class Creators to develop ideas and assets on behalf of brands. We look at Creators through two lenses: Influencers with broader reach and Artists with creative craft. Influencers offer brands the ability to tap into unique voices and built-in fan bases
column19: while Artists represent the slate of illustrators
column20: animators
column21: and videographers who bring craft to content and start with the mobile canvas.\u00c2\u00a0\nIn terms of creative performance
column22: we partnered with Magna and IPG Media Lab on a Twitter-sponsored study that showed that Twitter users spend 24% more time with ads** that come from Creators
column23: as opposed to those posted directly by brands. Recall of branded creator posts also leads to 41% increased purchase intent** reinforcing the value of audience-first content.\u00c2\u00a0\nOn the Influencer front
column24:
Wendyâs leverages Influential Creators to launch new products and connect with cultural moments. To launch their new SâAwesome menu items they partnered with comedic Creator Demetrius Harmon to take fans into a test kitchen where he created fan-fueled suggestions:Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
On the Artistic front
column25:
Google Brazil decided to fight bias with knowledge by inviting five artists to illustrate LGBTQ milestones in the fight for equality. Google also used a Twitter thread to amplify their support for Pride. Influencers in the LGBT community helped boost awareness of the thread:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In the past six months
column26: we have doubled our efforts in Artistic Creators and have seen a 3x increase in visual campaigns in partnership with brands.\nVideo Editing and Optimization\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nAs part of the Twitter ArtHouse offering
column27: our video editors help brands optimize creative assets for the Twitter feed using data driven best practices. In partnership with GroupM***
column28: we learned that compared to TV commercials
column29: optimized videos achieve +19% in unaided recall and +6% in message association. We also found that video optimized for Twitter drives an increase of 33% (vs. non-optimized TVCs) in emotional engagement.***\u00c2\u00a0 Video editing is a quick turn solution - we can help brands turn around feed friendly assets in just a few days.\u00c2\u00a0\nFor Stitch Fix\u00e2\u0080\u0099s \u00e2\u0080\u0098Personal Styling\u00e2\u0080\u0099 campaign
column30: we helped optimize their existing asset to run as short form video in front of publisher content about awards season. Optimization included a :06 edit with the addition of branding and captions.Â  This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. Your browser does not support the video element. Play Play Pause Seek 0% buffered 00:00 Current time 00:00 Duration 00:00 Toggle Mute Volume To support Dunkin's launch of their Power Breakfast sandwich and Dunkin' Bowl
column31:
we helped create feed-stopping assets from their highly visual TV commercial: 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Live Brand StudioÂ 
On Twitter
column32: brands can be Creators. Whether they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re producing their own content or extending their sponsorships
column33: brands are using Twitter to take center stage. Twitter Live Brand Studio is a service designed to help brands go live and maximize their own events and drive conversation on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nSince 2018
column34: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve streamed over 100 brand-led live events and have helped marketers like AT&T and Samsung launch something new and connect with culture. For their \u00e2\u0080\u0098Dive Bar Tour
column35: â Bud Light live-streamed their Post Malone concert from an intimate venue in Nashville.Â  This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. Your browser does not support the video element. Play Play Pause Seek 0% buffered 00:00 Current time 00:00 Duration 00:00 Toggle Mute Volume Brands are continually looking for smarter ways to develop feed-first content that brings something unique to the Twitter platform. When content connects with Twitterâs influential
column36: receptive audience it can make a product launch land
column37:
and even become a part of the cultural zeitgeist.Â Â  
For more information please contact your Twitter representative. Follow @ArtHouse on Twitter.

column3: "title": "Guest post: #panteneOppa: Learning from Steve Aoki's viral moment "
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Guest post: #panteneOppa: Learning from Steve Aoki's viral moment 
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 9 July 2019\nLink copied successfully\nCulture is happening on Twitter. With hundreds of millions of global users
column9: Twitter is the perfect place for brands to listen to their customers
column10: learn from them and show them some love. As a recent Vulture article says
column11: \u00e2\u0080\u009cAdvertising has always been integrated with culture \u00e2\u0080\u0094 mascots brought brands to life
column12: influencers became human billboards \u00e2\u0080\u0094 but Twitter has facilitated a new sort of intimacy for brands
column13: one in which they can blend in with people and develop their own personas.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nHashtags are one of the main ways that brands use Twitter to connect with customers. But
column14: how do hashtags become popular? And
column15: how do brands take advantage of viral hashtags?\u00c2\u00a0\nThis is the story of #PanteneOppa \u00e2\u0080\u0093 a random hashtag from a local radio station that turned Steve Aoki into a brand ambassador for Pantene. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a great example of a brand seizing an opportunity to launch an organic marketing campaign
column16: created and driven by the conversation on Twitter.\nHow #PanteneOppa Went Viral\u00c2\u00a0\nOn October 25th 2018
column17: DJ Steve Aoki released \u00e2\u0080\u009cWaste it on Me
column18: \u00e2\u0080\u009d a song featuring the world renowned South Korean boy band BTS. In addition to holding records for best-selling albums
column19: BTS also holds a host of social media records such as most Twitter engagements (average retweets) for a music group
column20: thanks to their huge fan base the BTS Army. In 2018
column21: BTS was ranked as the #1 most Tweeted about account for 2018 worldwide.\nOnly three days later on October 29th
column22: #PanteneOPPA hashtag was born. A local radio station in Tennessee
column23: 103.7 KISS FM
column24: tagged Pantene in a Tweet with a gif of Steve Aoki jumping
column25: saying \u00e2\u0080\u009cHey @Pantene we have your new spokesperson! Look at that hair bounce \u00f0\u009f\u0091\u008f\u00f0\u009f\u008f\u00be #PanteneOppa.\u00e2\u0080\u009d In Korean
column26: oppa literally means \u00e2\u0080\u009colder brother of a female person
column27:
â but the meaning of oppa has changed over time and now commonly refers to a close friend or romantic interest.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
On October 30th
column28: Pantene responded to launch a new campaign that connected it to a global audience organically. Pantene\u00e2\u0080\u0099s simple Tweet -- \u00e2\u0080\u009cCan we join this party?\u00e2\u0080\u009d received\u00c2\u00a0 a response from 103.7 KISS FM who mentioned BTS in their Tweet
column29:
urging Pantene to collaborate with Steve Aoki and BTS on a commercial.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
On October 30th
column30: Steve Aoki jumped into the conversation. Steve Aoki\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Tweet accepting the new nickname has more than 45K likes and 20.5K retweets.\u00c2\u00a0\nAccording to Steve Aoki
column31: who spoke with Sprinklr and Pantene on a panel at the 2019 Twitter Beach
column32: Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity
column33: BTS fans are uniquely powerful on Twitter. \u00e2\u0080\u009cThey\u00e2\u0080\u0099re definitely young
column34: but they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re incredibly organized and intelligent. If they love you
column35: the power they have is exponential
column36: \u00e2\u0080\u009d said Aoki.\u00c2\u00a0\nOn October 31st
column37: Pantene ensured BTS fans stayed involved in the Twitter conversation . The company responded to Steve Aoki\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Tweet with lyrics from the BTS and Steve Aoki new song
column38: \u00e2\u0080\u009cWaste It On Me\u00e2\u0080\u009d with a request for the BTS Army to comment with\u00c2\u00a0 #PanteneOppa commercial ideas. They also didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t forget to mention 103.7 KISS FM in their Tweet \u00e2\u0080\u0093 a nice call out to the radio station that started this conversation. In response
column39: 103.7 KISS FM encouraged BTS fans to give Pantene some #PanteneOppa ideas. From there
column40: #PanteneOppa was officially a viral hashtag.\u00c2\u00a0\nSprinklr\u00e2\u0080\u0099s social listening found that Pantene and 103.7 KISS FM Tweets mentioning the BTS Army and Steve Aoki drove the most engagement
column41: leading to a huge spike in #PanteneOppa mentions on October 31st. Thousands of BTS fans responded on Twitter
column42:
creating viral #PanteneOppa memes.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Throughout the month of November
column43: Pantene strategically kept the #PanteneOPPA conversation going with an engaging poll
column44:
hilarious Tweets (one has 16.9K likes so far) and  1-1 Tweets to fans.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Pantene didnât miss out on the opportunity to thank 103.7 KISS FM either and on November 12th the radio station Tweeted a picture of the care package â with a handwritten note
column45:
personalized T-shirt and products â that Pantene sent to them for all the positive buzz they created for the brand.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
This engagement resulted in a spike in Twitter conversations mentioning #PanteneOPPA thatâs lasted through 2019.
What Brands Can Learn From #PanteneOppaÂ 
1. Be Natural on Twitter & Donât Force Engagement. Throughout Panteneâs entire engagement on Twitter with #PanteneOppa
column46: the company never forced the conversation. Sprinklr\u00e2\u0080\u0099s platform found that only two of the four spikes in hashtag mentions were driven by Tweets from Pantene
column47: meaning that the majority of the brand love was organically created by customers.\nThis is a great example of how to create meaningful connections with customers through a social media campaign inspired by an earned engagement. As with all conversations
column48: over time they die down and the Twitter universe moves to the next hot topic. Pantene allowed the conversation to die down just like it started \u00e2\u0080\u0093 naturally. But the connections they made and the brand voice they built remain.\n2. Tap into the fandom on Twitter. Pantene knows that the conversation about their brand is happening on Twitter. The company paid attention to the Tweets about Steve Aoki and BTS
column49: and used this moment to effectively participate with those fans with relevant and fun content \u00e2\u0080\u0093 like incorporating BTS song lyrics into their Tweets. The tone of their Tweets were like any other fan
column50: excited and wanting to be in on the joke. The @Pantene handle had character and was funny. In only one month \u00e2\u0080\u0093 from October 28th to November 28th 2018 \u00e2\u0080\u0093 Sprinklr found that more than 20
column51: 000 individual BTS fans on Twitter mentioned #PanteneOppa and generated 29
column52:
943 mentions of the hashtag #PanteneOppa. Sprinklrâs listening capabilities also found that the sentiment on Twitter around Pantene grew significantly in October 2018 when the #PanteneOppa hashtag went viral. This increase in sentiment can be attributed to the effective Twitter content Pantene published as a result of its deep knowledge of consumers and BTS fans.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
3. Listen to Your Customers on Twitter
column53: Learn from Them and Show Them Love. Pantene
column54: Steve Aoki
column55: BTS and 103.7 KISS FM all succeeded in driving engagement around #PanteneOppa because they listened to their customers
column56: quickly engaged with them and also created personalized engagements to one another. 51% of marketers say that access to social data (listening in real-time to conversations your brand otherwise wouldn't be privy to) is very important to overall business decision making. From listening on Twitter
column57: they learned what would make their customers happy. They quickly turned this insight into action and showed their customers and fans some love with personalized Tweets
column58: polls and creative images. They also knew that measurement should be more sophisticated than just looking at\u00c2\u00a0 \u00e2\u0080\u009clikes\u00e2\u0080\u009d in order to understand the full story.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nWith the right technology like Sprinklr in place
column59: brands can listen and authentically connect with audiences on Twitter to drive deep levels of engagement and make their customers happier.\nWant even more? Watch Steve Aoki
column60: VP of Hair Care at Pantene Ilaria Resta
column61: and VP of Sprinklr Marketing Yoli Chisholm on a panel at Twitter Beach at Cannes Lions. The Secret Language of Fans: How Brands Tap #Fandom Culture on Twitter.\nTo learn more about Sprinklr
column62:
head to partners.twitter.com.

column3: "title": "Updating our rules against hateful conduct"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Updating our rules against hateful conduct
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 9 July 2019\nLink copied successfully\nEditorial note: This blog was first posted on July 9
column10: and last updated December 13
column12: to reflect additional changes made to our rules against hateful conduct.\nWe create our rules to keep people safe on Twitter
column13: and they continuously evolve to reflect the realities of the world we operate within. Our primary focus is on addressing the risks of offline harm
column14: and research* shows that dehumanizing language increases that risk.\nAs we develop the Twitter Rules in response to changing behaviors and challenges with serving the public conversation
column15: we understand the importance of considering a global perspective and thinking about how policies may impact different communities and cultures. Since 2019
column16: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve prioritized feedback from the public
column17: external experts
column18: and our own teams to inform the continued development of our hateful conduct policy.\nExpanding our hateful conduct policy\u00c2\u00a0\nWhile we encourage people to express themselves freely on Twitter
column19: abuse
column20: harassment and hateful conduct continue to have no place on our service.\u00c2\u00a0As part of our work to make Twitter safe
column21: our hateful conduct policy covers all protected categories. This means that we prohibit language that dehumanizes others on the basis of religion
column22: caste
column23: age
column24: disability
column25: disease
column26: race
column27: ethnicity
column28: national origin
column29: gender
column30: gender identity
column31: or sexual orientation.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe will require Tweets like those below to be removed from Twitter when they are reported to us. We will also continue to surface potentially violative content through proactive detection and automation. If an account repeatedly breaks the Twitter Rules
column32:
we may temporarily lock or suspend the account; more on our range of enforcement optionsÂ here.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
 Our approach to addressing hateful conduct on TwitterÂ 
The Twitter Rules help set expectations for everyone on the service and are updated to keep up with evolving online behaviors
column33: speech
column34: and experiences we observe. In addition to applying our iterative and research-driven approach to the expansion of the Twitter Rules
column35: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve reviewed and incorporated public feedback to ensure we consider a wide range of perspectives.\u00c2\u00a0 \u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nWith each update to this policy
column36: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve sought to expand our understanding of cultural nuances and ensure we are able to enforce our rules consistently. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve benefited from\u00c2\u00a0feedback from various communities and cultures who use Twitter around the globe. Consistent feedback we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve received includes:\u00c2\u00a0\nClearer language \u00e2\u0080\u0094 Across languages
column37: people believed the proposed change could be improved by providing more details
column38: examples of violations
column39: and explanations for when and how context is considered. We incorporated this feedback when refining this rule
column40: and also made sure that we provided additional detail and clarity across all our rules.\u00c2\u00a0\nNarrow down what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s considered \u00e2\u0080\u0094 Respondents said that \u00e2\u0080\u009cidentifiable groups\u00e2\u0080\u009d was too broad
column41: and they should be allowed to engage with political groups
column42: hate groups
column43: and other non-marginalized groups with this type of language. Many people wanted to \u00e2\u0080\u009ccall out hate groups in any way
column44: any time
column45: without fear.\u00e2\u0080\u009d In other instances
column46: people wanted to be able to refer to fans
column47: friends
column48: and followers in endearing terms
column49: such as \u00e2\u0080\u009ckittens\u00e2\u0080\u009d and \u00e2\u0080\u009cmonsters.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\u00c2\u00a0\nConsistent enforcement \u00e2\u0080\u0094 Many people raised concerns about our ability to enforce our rules fairly and consistently
column50: so we developed a longer
column51: more in-depth training process with our teams to make sure they were better prepared when reviewing a report.\nThat said
column52: even with these improvements
column53: we recognize we will still make mistakes. We are committed to further strengthening both our enforcement processes and our appeals processes to correct our mistakes and prevent similar ones moving forward.\nOur trusted partners\u00c2\u00a0\nWe realize that we don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t have all the answers
column54: so in addition to public feedback
column55: we work in partnership with our Trust & Safety Council as well as other organizations around the world\u00c2\u00a0with deep subject matter expertise in this area. \u00c2\u00a0\nAs we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve expanded this policy
column56: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve collaborated with civil society
column57: academics and third-party experts to help us think about how we could appropriately address dehumanizing speech around these complex categories. For example
column58: we've worked with partners to help us better understand the challenges we would face and to ultimately answer questions like:\u00c2\u00a0\nHow do we protect conversations people have within marginalized groups
column59: including those using reclaimed terminology?\u00c2\u00a0\nHow do we ensure that our range of enforcement actions take context fully into account
column60: reflect the severity of violations
column61:
and are necessary and proportionate?
How can â or should â we factor in considerations as to whether a given protected group has been historically marginalized and/or is currently being targeted into our evaluation of severity of harm?
How do we account for âpower dynamicsâ that can come into play across different groups?Â 
"Our work in local communities helps us think critically about ways to ensure social cohesion between the diverse communities we serve
column62: institutions
column63: and policymakers. As a trusted partner
column64: we worked with Twitter to ensure that cultural and regional nuances relevant to migrant groups were accounted for in their hateful conduct policy update.\" \u00e2\u0080\u0094 Roses of Peace
column65: an interfaith organization that aims to build a cohesive and resilient Singapore\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to build Twitter for the global community it serves and ensure your voices help shape our rules and how we work. As we continue to look for opportunities to evolve and expand our policies to better handle the challenges we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re currently facing
column66: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll update you on what we learn and how we plan to address it. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll also continue to provide regular updates on all of the other work we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re doing to make Twitter a safer place for everyone via\u00c2\u00a0@TwitterSafety.\n*Examples of research on the link between dehumanizing language and offline harm:\nDr. Susan Benesch
column67: \u00e2\u0080\u009cWhat is Dangerous Speech?\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nNick Haslam and Michelle Stratemeyer
column68:
âRecent research on dehumanizationâÂ

column3: "title": "How Twitter bridges the gap between brands and their audiences"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
How Twitter bridges the gap between brands and their audiences
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 8 July 2019\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s communities don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t just reflect the most important topics of the day
column9: they shape the global discourse through real-time conversations and debates. People on Twitter aren\u00e2\u0080\u0099t observing passively; \u00c2\u00a0they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re generating significant cultural movements in real-time.\nThis is why it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s so important for brands to listen to what people are talking about on the platform. Now
column10: more than ever
column11: businesses must track relevant conversations
column12: influencers
column13: competitors
column14: customer feedback
column15: social engagement
column16: and crisis management.\nTwo brands at the forefront of building relationships on Twitter are NASA and Nationwide. They use Twitter in unique ways to better understand what their fans are interested in
column17: and use that information to generate tailored content that strengthens their brand voice. Through Twitter
column18: the two organizations talking directly to passionate fans \u00e2\u0080\u0093 and build authentic connections in the process.\nNASA\u00e2\u0080\u0099s mission to go above and beyond\n@NASA has over 30 million followers on Twitter
column19: but the organization has also galvanized its audience by sharing content across 500 social accounts aimed at niche communities
column20: including the @NASA_Astronauts handle which accounts for individual astronauts
column21: space stations
column22:
and missions.
These niche accounts offer behind-the-scenes looks at agency initiatives and streamline content to the followers who are most receptive to it.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Engaging different audiences across multiple accounts requires a serious listening strategy. And while tapping into Twitter insights and actively listening to different audiences can uncover positive feedback and praise
column23: it can also expose areas where people feel underserved.\nAfter auditing its Twitter audience using insights from Sprinklr
column24: a comprehensive social suite
column25: NASA realized that while its fans enjoyed stunning photos of space and behind-the-scenes looks into missions
column26: there was a group of people who wanted to know what space sounded like
column27: too. The organization\u00e2\u0080\u0099s in-depth Twitter listening sparked an idea about
column28: well
column29: listening.\nTo meet the demand
column30: NASA incorporated space audio clips into its social media content strategy
column31: highlighting the ominous galactic soundscapes in Tweets and giving certain followers the experiences they were missing. The sounds topped the intergalactic charts
column32: with promotional tweets drawing up to 6
column33:
000 likes and many of the recordings themselves receiving well over a million plays on SoundCloud.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
âEverybody has that little bit of childlike wonderment in them
column34: \u00e2\u0080\u009d says Jason Townsend
column35: NASA\u00e2\u0080\u0099s deputy social media manager. \u00e2\u0080\u009cIf we can find that curiosity in every person out there and pull it out of them
column36: then we can really engage with an audience that is interested in what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re talking about.\u00e2\u0080\u009d \nNASA\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Twitter presence exemplifies social media engagement at its best. People follow the accounts to learn
column37: share their own expertise
column38: and interact with other space enthusiasts. NASA uses insights and data to find fun ways to engage its existing audience and reach new frontiers of fans.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cAt the end of the day
column39: if you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re not measuring what you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re doing
column40: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re not succeeding at being able to improve
column41: learn from what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s going on
column42: and roll that up into your next actions
column43: \u00e2\u0080\u009d Townsend says. \nHow Nationwide uses Twitter data to get personal\nNationwide is on its customers\u00e2\u0080\u0099 side with an authentic
column44: relatable brand voice that extends to Twitter. Through its Twitter content
column45: the brand is able to convey trust
column46: an especially important priority when interacting with customers who have important questions about their coverage.\nTo show its human side
column47: Nationwide uses Twitter to showcase how it engages with the community beyond insurance
column48: through initiatives like the Nationwide Children\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Hospital network
column49: among others.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cA lot of people hear Nationwide and think of insurance\u00e2\u0080\u00a6we want to be known for so much more
column50: \u00e2\u0080\u009d says Dace de la Foret
column51: Nationwide\u00e2\u0080\u0099s director of social media. \u00e2\u0080\u009cWe want people to know about what we do for the communities where we live and work
column52: and specifically our Foundation\u00e2\u0080\u0099s relationship and support of Nationwide Children\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Hospital.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cMuch of the engagement we have with our followers is focused on showing them the connection between Nationwide \u00e2\u0080\u0098the business\u00e2\u0080\u0099 and Nationwide \u00e2\u0080\u0098the company that is making a difference in people's\u00e2\u0080\u0099 lives
column53: \u00e2\u0080\u0099\u00e2\u0080\u009d he added. \u00e2\u0080\u009cIt comes down to a simple question: Who is the audience and what is the best way these messages will resonate with them?\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nBy harnessing Twitter data to drive its philanthropic efforts and listen at scale
column54: Nationwide can create personalized content for its Twitter followers with support from Sprinklr.\nThese social insights also allow Nationwide to look at its diverse audience to identify the micro-influencers
column55: brand ambassadors and patient champions who take to social media to praise the brands\u00e2\u0080\u0099 initiatives. By learning from its Twitter audience
column56:
the brand can engage them in conversation or share their Tweets and stories with the rest of the Nationwide community.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
âSocial listening is not just about seeing what people are saying
column57: but seeing what people are asking of you
column58: \u00e2\u0080\u009d says de la Foret.\nThe most valuable audiences are on Twitter\nTwitter serves brands invaluable feedback and the opportunity to hear from a range of people and perspectives that inform important business decisions
column59: from what to stand for to when to launch.\nTo make the most of these real-time connections
column60: brands can \u00c2\u00a0#startwiththem and include Twitter as a core part of their business model
column61: not just as an ad hoc addition. By listening to what their audiences are saying
column62: brands can build meaningful connections with their customers
column63: and take the right steps to make new ones.\nTo learn more about Sprinklr
column64:
check out their profile on partners.twitter.com.

column3: "title": "Insights into the 2019 #FIFAWWC conversation on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Events
Insights into the 2019 #FIFAWWC conversation on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8:
8 July 2019
Link copied successfully
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
This summerâs FIFA Womenâs World Cup captured the hearts and attention of the globe
column9: and as ever the conversation flowed on Twitter throughout.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhether it was VAR
column10: goal celebrations or notable omissions from the line-up
column11: Twitter was the place where football fans came together to follow the agony
column12: ecstasy and heartbreak of the tournament.\nAfter 52 matches that got the planet\u00e2\u0080\u0099s pulses racing
column13: including the epic FIFA Women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s World Cup Final between USA (@USWNT) and The Netherlands (@oranjevrouwen) we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve compiled the moments that illustrate the massive role Twitter played for fans since the event began on June 7.\nWonderstrikes
column14: two-footed tackles
column15:
or the managersâ tactical acumen all drove Twitter to discuss all things related to the #FIFAWWC.
Â 
Fans Tweeted the most during the USA v Netherlands final
We saw the bulk of the conversation during the live matches
column16:
including the final match between the USA and The Netherlands which was the most tweeted about game of the #FIFAWWC.Â 
Here are the five most-Tweeted matches:
Final: USA vs NED
England vs USA
France vs USA
France vs Brazil
USA vs Thailand
Â 
Fans sent more Tweets when USA won the World Cup than at any other point during the tournament.
Here are the top five moments that generated the biggest peaks of Twitter conversation
column17: measured in Tweets per minute (TPM)
column18: during the entire tournament:\nJuly 7th
column19: Final: USA wins World Cup over NED\nJuly 7th

column3: "title": "Our partnership with UNHCR to launch #KnitForRefugees"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Our partnership with UNHCR to launch #KnitForRefugees
          
          
            and
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 1 July 2019\nLink copied successfully\nWe partnered with UNHCR
column9: The UN Refugee Agency and Kniterate to launch a global campaign to proactively and collectively shed light on an important issue facing Syrian and Iraqi internally displaced persons (IDPs) and refugees in the Middle East North Africa region as winter approaches.\u00c2\u00a0\nCurrently around 14 million Syrians and Iraqis are displaced in the region: The needs in the region remain significant. Last year
column10: UNHCR was able to reach 3.6 million Syrian and Iraqi IDPs and refugees with winterization assistance. But urgent funding is needed to ensure that life-saving winterization assistance is in place before freezing temperatures grip the region
column11: exposing tens of thousands of families. For many
column12: this will be the ninth consecutive winter in displacement.\nUNHCR\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Twitter campaign aims to generate awareness through the power of the service and share a strong call to action by encouraging people to act and make a difference through donations in advance of the winter season. Through a partnership with London-based Kniterate (@Kniterate) the innovative campaign will demonstrate the power of Tweets
column13:
as a compact digital knitting machine begins to knit a scarf featuring participating Twitter accounts.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The campaign will be rolled out across multiple regions
column14: kicking off in the UAE. UNHCR\u00e2\u0080\u0099s official global account on Twitter\u00c2\u00a0@Refugees
column15:
Tweeted a video around the cause calling on people to Retweet the Tweet in order to knit the first part of the scarf live on Twitter. The same campaign will be rolled out in several countries in the coming months until winter starts. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
This partnership with Twitter is really significant for UNHCR. Funds raised through this campaign will support our efforts to provide life-saving interventions to the most vulnerable refugees this winter. Every year we see firsthand the desperation faced by refugees in the region during the winter season. We hope that through this initiative
column16:
we will not only raise awareness of the plight of refugees but also raise the necessary funds to ensure that no refugee is left out in the cold.
Ayat El-Dewary
UNHCR Officer in Charge in the UAE
â@ayateldewaryâ
Concluding on 30 November 2019
column17:
the results of the campaign will be shared during the Global Summit of Refugees in Geneva.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Defining public interest on Twitter"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nDefining public interest on Twitter\nThursday
column8: 27 June 2019\nLink copied successfully\nOur highest priority is to protect the health of the public conversation on Twitter
column9: and an important part of that is ensuring our rules and how we enforce them are easy to understand. In the past
column10: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve allowed certain Tweets that violated our rules to remain on Twitter because they were in the public\u00e2\u0080\u0099s interest
column11: but it wasn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t clear when and how we made those determinations. To fix that
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re introducing a new notice that will provide additional clarity in these situations
column13: and sharing more on when and why we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll use it.\nServing the public conversation includes providing the ability for anyone to talk about what matters to them; this can be especially important when engaging with government officials and political figures. By nature of their positions these leaders have outsized influence and sometimes say things that could be considered controversial or invite debate and discussion. A critical function of our service is providing a place where people can openly and publicly respond to their leaders and hold them accountable.\nWith this in mind
column14: there are certain cases where it may be in the public\u00e2\u0080\u0099s interest to have access to certain Tweets
column15: even if they would otherwise be in violation of our rules. On the rare occasions when this happens
column16: we'll place a notice \u00e2\u0080\u0093 a screen you have to click or tap through before you see the Tweet \u00e2\u0080\u0093 to provide additional context and clarity. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll also take steps to make sure the Tweet is not algorithmically elevated on our service
column17: to strike the right balance between enabling free expression
column18: fostering accountability
column19:
and reducing the potential harm caused by these Tweets.Â 
Who does this apply to?
We will only consider applying this notice on Tweets from accounts that meet the following criteria. The account must:
Be or represent a government/elected official
column20: be running for public office
column21: or be considered for a government position (i.e.
column22: next in line
column23: awaiting confirmation
column24: named successor to an appointed position);\nHave more than 100
column25: 000 followers; and\nBe verified.\nThat said
column26: there are cases
column27: such as direct threats of violence or calls to commit violence against an individual
column28:
that are unlikely to be considered in the public interest.
What will the notice look like?Â 
The notice will be immediately visible in your home timeline and across other areas like search.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
How will we decide when to use this notice?Â 
A cross-functional team including Trust and Safety
column29: Legal
column30: Public Policy and regional teams will determine if the Tweets are a matter of public interest based on the criteria listed above and the following considerations:\nThe immediacy and severity of potential harm from the rule violation
column31: with an emphasis on ensuring physical safety;\nWhether preserving a Tweet will allow others to hold the government official
column32: candidate for public office
column33:
or appointee accountable for their statements;Â 
Whether there are other sources of information about this statement available for the public to stay informed;
If removal would inadvertently hide context or prevent people from understanding an issue of public concern; and
If the Tweet provides a unique context or perspective not available elsewhere that is necessary to a broader discussion.
You can learn more about our decision making principles here
In instances where a Tweet violates our rules and our review doesnât find that it would be in the public interest to leave it up
column34: we will require the account owner to remove the Tweet. Either way
column35: this notice will make our decision-making clearer.\u00c2\u00a0\nWhat happens to the Tweet that gets this notice placed on it?\u00c2\u00a0\nWhen a Tweet has this notice placed on it
column36: it will feature less prominently on Twitter
column37:
and not appear in:
Safe search
Timeline when switched to Top Tweets
Live events pages
Recommended Tweet push notificationsÂ 
Notifications tab
Explore
Limited engagements â Likes
column38: Replies and Retweets will be disabled to reduce the reach of Tweets that violate our rules. Retweeting with comment (Quote Tweeting) will remain so people can share the Tweet with additional context. \nThis notice won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t be applied to any Tweets sent before today and
column39: given the conditions outlined above
column40: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s unlikely you'll encounter it often. We cannot predict the first time it will be used
column41: but we wanted to give you more information about this new notice before you come across it on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nOver time
column42: public interest and how it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s defined on Twitter may change as we observe different types of behavior. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to evaluate how our rules and enforcement actions can be clearer and keep working to make our decision-making easier to understand.\n*Updated on October 15
column43:
2019: This post was updated to include additional product updates.
Â 
Â

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "What to expect from Twitter ahead of the first #DemDebate"
column7:
"post_text": "Events
What to expect from Twitter ahead of the first #DemDebate
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 26 June 2019\nLink copied successfully\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s always an election year on Twitter. In fact
column9: this year alone
column10: voters have taken part in the global Twitter conversation about elections in the European Union
column11: Australia
column12: India
column13: and Indonesia. We take the learnings from every election \u00e2\u0080\u0094 including the 2018 US Midterms \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and use them to improve the experience of people who use Twitter and enhance our election integrity safeguards.\u00c2\u00a0\nAs the US Democratic presidential primary debates kick off this week
column14: here\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a rundown of how you can take part in the Twitter conversation and the steps we are taking to ensure you can trust the information you see.\nHow do I watch the #DemDebate on Twitter? On Wednesday and Thursday
column15: June 24-25
column16: starting at 9 p.m. ET
column17: the debates will be broadcast live on Twitter in English and Spanish via @NBCNews and @TelemundoNews.\n#DemDebate is the official hashtag for the debates \u00e2\u0080\u0094 you can search for it or tap it anywhere on Twitter to find the live broadcast.\nCheck the top of your home timeline on mobile: If you follow @NBCNews or @TelemundoNews or are interested in politics
column18: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll see the live broadcast there.\nPlus
column19: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll include a \u00e2\u0080\u0098set reminder\u00e2\u0080\u0099 button before each debate on the #DemDebate event page
column20: which you can select to receive an alert when it starts.\nHow is Twitter prioritizing a healthy election conversation? We have a cross-functional team focused on election integrity efforts that aims to foster an environment conducive to healthy
column21: meaningful conversation on Twitter and address threats posed by hostile foreign and domestic actors.\nNew rules Ahead of the US midterms last fall
column22: we updated the Twitter Rules around several key issues impacting the integrity of elections across the globe. The rules address: (1) fake accounts engaged in a variety of malicious behaviors
column23: (2) removing accounts that deliberately mimic or are intended to replace accounts we have previously suspended for violating our rules
column24: and (3) the distribution of hacked material that contains private information or trade secrets
column25: or could put people in harm\u00e2\u0080\u0099s way.\nAdditionally
column26: earlier this year
column27: we strengthened our rules against deliberate attempts to mislead voters to now explicitly prohibit manipulating or interfering in the election process. This includes posting or sharing content that may suppress voter turnout or mislead people about when
column28: where
column29: or how to vote.\u00c2\u00a0\nFighting spam and manipulation Communal spaces on Twitter (like search
column30: hashtags
column31: and trends) are the most common areas where people go to find the latest information about ongoing events and conversation outside of their home timeline and existing follower network. This is especially true during live events with a high volume of Tweets
column32: like presidential debates.\nWe know bad-faith actors can attempt to manipulate the content in these spaces
column33: and our existing rules and algorithms are built to stay ahead of these attempts. Our policies ban misleading
column34: deceptive
column35: and spammy behavior and prohibit attempts to game trends or cause unrelated Tweets to appear in search results. In addition to these existing preventative systems
column36: we will be protecting the integrity of the conversation around key topics and trends.\u00c2\u00a0\nCampaign outreach and partnerships To date
column37: our public policy team has met and facilitated trainings with 20 presidential campaign teams and the Democratic National Committee
column38: Republican National Committee
column39: Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee
column40: and National Republican Senatorial Committee to share information on account security
column41: content best practices
column42: our advertising policies
column43: and Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s reporting procedures.\nWe have existing
column44: open lines of communication with the US Department of Homeland Security
column45: state elections directors
column46: and the FBI's Foreign Influence Task Force.\nPublic archive of information operations Last October
column47: we launched the first archive of potential state-backed information operations we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen on Twitter. It is our fundamental belief that these accounts should be made public and searchable so members of the public
column48: governments
column49: and researchers can investigate
column50: learn
column51: and build media literacy capacities for the future. We updated this public archive in January
column52: as recently as a few weeks ago
column53: and will continue to do so if we identify state-backed activity targeting conversations on Twitter.\nWe also produced an in-depth review of our efforts to protect the public conversation around the 2018 US Midterm Elections
column54: which notes that what we saw was more domestic than foreign in nature.\nWhere can I find debate insights and data? Around the debates
column55: @TwitterGov will share insights and information about how the conversation is unfolding on Twitter. This will include data after each debate night like the most Tweeted about moments
column56: on-stage candidates
column57: and US politicians.\nHow do I identify and learn about ads? It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s very likely that you will see Promoted Tweets containing political or election-related content on Twitter during debates. Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s policies require that accounts running these kind of advertisements become certified as political campaigning or issue advertisers
column58: which requires that their Promoted Tweets contain more explicit identification
column59: and that they consent to increased transparency on their advertising campaigns\u00e2\u0080\u0099 targeting and spend data. We believe this transparency is vital
column60:
and we continue to support the Honest Ads Act.Â 
All of the data on political campaigning and issue advertising is publicly available in Twitterâs Ads Transparency Center.
Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â  Â Â ***
Twitter exists to serve the public conversation
column61: and people must have confidence in the integrity of the information found on the service
column62: especially information relevant to elections and the democratic process.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur efforts to foster healthy
column63: meaningful conversations on Twitter during the entirety of the US presidential election are ongoing
column64: and we will continue to update the public via @Policy
column65: @TwitterSafety
column66:
and @TwitterGov.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
