column3: "title": "Guest Post: Q&A on social listening with Sprout Social CMO
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/insights/2019/sproutsocial"
column8: "post_text": "Insights\nGuest Post: Q&A on social listening with Sprout Social CMO
column9:
Jamie Gilpin
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column10:
14 June 2019
Link copied successfully
A version of this article was previously published on Adapt by Sprout Social.
Social media: For the average consumer
column11: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s the go-to platform for opinions
column12: the occasional rant and off-the-cuff observations about the world today. For businesses
column13: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a powerful medium to dig deeper into what makes their audience tick and how to keep their brands top of mind for future customers. \nMost brands are already monitoring the conversation on social platforms. A retailer
column14: for example
column15: might use monitoring to immediately respond to customer inquiries or to like and share positive user-generated content. The ability to track direct mentions is great for any business\u00e2\u0080\u0099 engagement strategy\u00e2\u0080\u0094but there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s more opportunity to tap into on social than meets the eye.\nWhere companies stand to benefit the most is when they learn to listen to the conversations on social media at scale. Unlike monitoring
column16: social listening incorporates a lot more data\u00e2\u0080\u0094it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not only analyzing what people are saying about your brand
column17: but also exploring what they say about your competitors and your industry at large. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s being able to take a look at the big picture trends that shape conversations and extracting insights to apply to your social strategy and beyond.\nTo learn more about the applications of social listening and why businesses can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t afford to ignore insights drawn from social data
column18: we talked to Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Head of Marketing for Data and Enterprise Solutions
column19: Diana Helander.\nWhy do businesses today need listening to compete?\nDH: In this day and age
column20: with more consumers using social media than ever
column21: social listening is no longer a competitive differentiator\u00e2\u0080\u0094it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a must-have. Consumers are more empowered than ever before and have higher expectations of positive experiences with brands. Through listening
column22: brands can uncover insights about their products
column23: business
column24: employees
column25: competitors
column26: industry\u00e2\u0080\u0094and more importantly
column27: they can use social listening to learn from and connect with their customers. Ignoring social listening is
column28: in turn
column29: ignoring your customers.\nPeople often think the advantages of social listening are limited to fine-tuning your social strategy. How can these insights help businesses grow beyond social?\nDH: While listening is often associated with informing social strategies
column30: the applications of listening insights don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t end there. Social listening offers something other business data does not: real-time
column31: unsolicited customer or audience feedback. This information drives innovation and allows businesses to learn more about their audience as well as their competitors.\nWhy should leaders care about listening? Do you have any tips for team members looking to secure buy-in from leadership?\nDH: Today\u00e2\u0080\u0099s executives need to be plugged into the fastest moving news cycle we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve ever seen\u00e2\u0080\u0094and Twitter is the only way to do that. Whether it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s brand reputation
column32: customer experience
column33: competitive advantage or crisis management
column34: Twitter is what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening around the world and is the best way to get a pulse of what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening with your customers. Leaders of customer-focused businesses need to empower their teams with social listening tools and strategies if they want to be at the forefront of their industries and make truly data-driven decisions.\nWhat are the most influential uses for social listening you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re seeing brands implement today? Are there any brands doing particularly exciting things with listening insights?\nDH: Because social listening is a way to capture unsolicited customer feedback or audience engagement
column35: its value is broadly applicable. We see brand leaders using listening to not only uncover deep market insights and identify trends
column36: but also perform real-time campaign optimization
column37: make critical decisions regarding product development and new product introductions
column38: as well as identify influencers. Leading companies who invest in social listening can do so much more than simply respond to customer issues.\nVTWO
column39: a boutique consultancy based in Australia
column40: used social listening to help clients learn more about their target audience and to identify what types of social content sparked the most engagement among consumers. Thanks to listening
column41: VTWO grew one of its client\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Twitter following by 229% and increased the number of Twitter messages received by 356%.\nFor brands that don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t regularly use Twitter
column42: there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a misconception that Twitter listening insights won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t be relevant for their brand. What would you say is the missed opportunity in these instances?\nDH: There are a couple of reasons why Twitter audiences are so valuable. Twitter reaches hundreds of millions of users around the world and contains insights on specific people
column43: businesses
column44: industries
column45: trends and more. People are on Twitter to discover what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s new
column46: and over two-thirds of Twitter users influence the purchasing decisions of their friends and family.\nWhile skeptics might think social applies only to B2C businesses
column47: social data is increasingly being used by B2B companies
column48: particularly when it comes to financial investments. Bloomberg
column49: for example
column50: leverages Twitter social data to help its subscribers identify meaningful and relevant news so they can make better informed investment decisions.\nWhat are some examples of interesting or surprising insights we can glean from Twitter listening data?\nDH: While many companies monitor Twitter conversations to identify a problem (like an airline responding to customer complaints about a delayed flight)
column51: innovative companies are identifying trends and insights that drive new product development. A packaged goods company
column52: for example
column53: can use Twitter data to reveal changing consumer tastes for new flavors
column54:
informing the development and marketing of new beverage offerings.
Listening is also about communicating. Companies should be thinking not only about how theyâre listening to the conversation but also how they can engage with those conversations on Twitter and through which content formats. A Kantar/Millward Brown study found the Twitter environment was shown to be a strong platform for video retention; a higher proportion of consumers watch video straight through to the end on Twitter than on Facebook or Instagram.
What is the biggest mistake you see social and digital teams making when it comes to incorporating listening into their strategies?
DH: There are two big pitfalls weâve seen far too often. The first is keeping social data siloed
column55: or limiting its application and the opportunity to use that data to support a more holistic view of audiences and customers. A recent Forrester report on social media maturity points to the need for marketers to leverage this data beyond just outbound marketing and consider how it can be used across other parts of their organizations.\nThe second is listening for the sake of listening instead of listening to support existing business goals. Many brands we talk to know they have to \u00e2\u0080\u0098listen to social media\u00e2\u0080\u0099 but they fail to set goals beyond just \u00e2\u0080\u0098listen\u00e2\u0080\u0099. Successful listening starts with existing business initiatives
column56: like improving customer feedback or managing a PR crisis
column57:
and incorporating social insights to support those goals and processes.
Â 
 Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Listening today pays dividends tomorrow
Helander said it best when describing the significance of listening: âIgnoring social listening is
column58: in turn
column59: ignoring your customers.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Without social listening
column60: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s difficult (and pretty expensive) for businesses to know how people truly feel about their brand and in turn
column61: they miss out on valuable customer insights that can serve as a competitive advantage.\nWhen brands begin to listen\u00e2\u0080\u0094and not just for the sake of listening\u00e2\u0080\u0094they have an opportunity to analyze honest customer feedback and get a real-time pulse on the state of the industry. With the right tools and a little bit of patience
column62: businesses can turn social chit chat into powerful insights to fuel long-term strategies.\nTo learn more about Sprout Social
column63:
check out their profile on partners.twitter.com.

column3: "title": "Information operations on Twitter: principles
column7: "author": "Yoel Roth"
column8: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/company/2019/information-ops-on-twitter"
column9: "post_text": "Company\nInformation operations on Twitter: principles
column10: process
column11:
and disclosure
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column12: 13 June 2019\nLink copied successfully\nIn October 2018
column13: we published the first comprehensive archive of Tweets and media associated with known state-backed information operations on Twitter. Since its launch
column14: thousands of researchers from across the globe have downloaded datasets
column15: which contain more than 30 million Tweets and over 1 terabyte of media
column16: using our archive to conduct their own investigations and to share their insights and independent analysis with the world. Today
column17: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re adding six additional datasets to our archive
column18: covering coordinated
column19: state-backed activities originating from four jurisdictions. All accounts have been removed from Twitter.\nWe believe that people and organizations with the advantages of institutional power and which consciously abuse our service are not advancing healthy discourse but are actively working to undermine it. By making this data open and accessible
column20: we seek to empower researchers
column21: journalists
column22: governments
column23: and members of the public to deepen their understanding of critical issues impacting the integrity of public conversation online
column24: particularly around elections. This transparency is core to our mission.\nToday\u00e2\u0080\u0099s disclosures\nIran (4
column25: 779 accounts) The below account sets all originated in Iran
column26: and we believe all are associated with \u00e2\u0080\u0094 or directly backed by \u00e2\u0080\u0094 the Iranian government. However
column27: the signals and behaviors of each set were individually different. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve broken them down accordingly:\nSet one (1
column28: 666 accounts): We removed more than 1
column29: 600 accounts originating in Iran. Cumulatively
column30: these accounts Tweeted nearly 2 million times. They Tweeted global news content
column31: often with an angle that benefited the diplomatic and geostrategic views of the Iranian state. Platform manipulation is a violation of the Twitter Rules.\nSet two (248 accounts): In addition to the 1
column32: 600 accounts listed above
column33: we took action on a second set of more than 200 accounts originating in Iran which were more directly engaged with discussions related to Israel specifically.\nSet three (2
column34: 865 accounts): Recently
column35: we discussed an action to remove more than 2
column36: 800 accounts originating in Iran. These accounts employed a range of false personas to target conversations about political and social issues in Iran and globally.\nRussia (4 accounts) As part of our ongoing investigations into activity connected with the Russian Internet Research Agency (IRA)
column37: we removed four accounts which we believe are associated with the IRA. These removals are the result of increased information sharing between industry peers and law enforcement. For more on our removal of IRA-specific accounts around the 2016 US Presidential Election
column38: see here.\nSpain (130 accounts) Earlier this year
column39: we suspended 130 fake accounts originating in Spain. These accounts were directly associated with the Catalan independence movement
column40: specifically Esquerra Republicana de Catalunya. They were primarily engaged in spreading content about the Catalan Referendum. The network includes fake accounts which appear to have been created with the intent to inorganically influence the conversation in politically advantageous ways. Setting up fake accounts is a violation of the Twitter Rules
column41: \u00c2\u00a0full stop.\nVenezuela (33 accounts) In addition to a previously disclosed domestically-focused set
column42: this is the second time we identified accounts originating within Venezuela that were engaging in platform manipulation targeted outside of the country. Today\u00e2\u0080\u0099s disclosure is comprised of 33 additional accounts directly connected with the previous group of 764 accounts (published to the archive in January). While there were initial indications that these accounts were associated with the Russian Internet Research Agency
column43:
our further analysis suggests that they were operated by a commercial entity originating in Venezuela. We are sharing further data on this group to update the public on our attribution efforts.
We also want to take this opportunity to comprehensively share our principles and process for future disclosures. Below are answers to some of the most common questions we receive regarding our handling of information operations on Twitter.
What are our guiding principles in this work? We believe Twitter has a responsibility to protect the integrity of the public conversation â including through the timely disclosure of information about attempts to manipulate Twitter to influence elections and other civic conversations by foreign or domestic state-backed entities. We believe the public and research community are better informed by transparency.
How do we do it? Our Site Integrity team is dedicated to identifying and investigating suspected platform manipulation on Twitter
column44: including potential state-backed activity. In partnership with teams across the company
column45: we employ a range of open-source and proprietary signals and tools to identify when attempted coordinated manipulation may be taking place
column46: as well as the actors responsible for it. We also partner closely with governments
column47: law enforcement
column48: and our peer companies to improve our understanding of the actors involved in information operations and develop a holistic strategy for addressing them.\nHow do I access the full archive of content and Tweets? The complete public archive of content and Tweets are available on our dedicated Election Integrity Hub.\nWhat is the makeup of the team at Twitter working on these issues? Teams across the company contribute to our research
column49: analysis
column50: and investigation efforts related to information operations. These teams include data scientists
column51: linguists
column52: policy analysts
column53: political scientists
column54: and technical experts in abuse and anti-spam issues.\nWhat policies do you enforce and how do you mitigate the risk of suppressing legitimate speech from political parties? Our policies are focused on misleading
column55: deceptive
column56: and spammy behavior
column57:
and are specifically intended to differentiate between coordinated manipulative behavior and legitimate speech from individuals and political parties. The policies we enforce most frequently in this context include:
Platform manipulation and spam
Coordinated activity
Fake accounts
Attributed activity
Distribution of hacked materials
Ban evasion
We enforce these policies without regard for the specific entities involved. However
column58: as we discuss below
column59: our decision to disclose datasets related to these activities are impacted by our ability to definitively attribute.\nWhat are your standards for disclosure? First
column60: as noted above
column61: we only disclose datasets associated with coordinated malicious activity that we are able to reliably associate with state-affiliated actors. For privacy and safety reasons
column62: we do not disclose information about individuals or accounts not affiliated with a state actor.\nSecond
column63: given the challenges of attribution
column64: we require clear
column65: verifiable associations between accounts we identify and state-affiliated actors. While we enforce our rules proactively and at scale
column66: disclosure of datasets requires additional evidence of coordinated
column67: state-backed activity.\nFinally
column68: we rigorously quality-check the resulting datasets in an attempt to eliminate potential false positives caused by account compromises or analytical error. Mistakes can happen
column69: and we do our best to avoid this at every stage of our investigations. This process takes time.\nHow does Twitter decide when to disclose datasets? Timing varies. If and when we identify malicious activity on Twitter
column70: our first priority is to enforce our rules and remove accounts engaged in attempts to manipulate the public conversation. Following these enforcements
column71: we carry out thorough investigations of the accounts and individuals involved. This analysis can take anywhere from several days to many months \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and in some instances
column72: subsequent enforcement actions may allow us to retrospectively attribute activity we enforced against in the past. We only disclose datasets once we have determined attribution
column73: and once all applicable investigations have concluded. We also proactively notify law enforcement
column74: our peers
column75: and other relevant state agencies.\nWhy the focus only on state-affiliated actors? When we have significant evidence to indicate that state-affiliated entities are knowingly trying to manipulate and distort the public conversation
column76: we believe it should be disclosed as a matter of public interest. People and organizations with the advantages of institutional power and which consciously abuse our service are not advancing healthy discourse but are actively working to undermine it. This is a violation of our company principles
column77: policies
column78: and overarching mission to serve the public discourse.\nYou\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve said that you challenge millions of accounts per week for engaging in platform manipulation. Why not disclose information about those? We do. Twice a year
column79: we share information about our actions to detect and prevent platform manipulation and spam in the Twitter Transparency Report. Our goal in disclosing additional datasets related to malicious state-backed activity on Twitter specifically is to enable research that improves the public understanding of information operations. While other forms of platform manipulation and spam may at times be involved in these operations
column80: we do not disclose specific
column81: Tweet-level data about these activities unless they are directly associated by clear
column82: technical indicators to a specific
column83: attributed campaign by a state-actor. We do
column84: however
column85: have a public API that allows researchers to investigate a small subset of Tweets to further public awareness of the conversation on Twitter.\nWhat about research I see on Twitter and \u00e2\u0080\u0098bots\u00e2\u0080\u0099? Non-peer reviewed research using our public API can often be deeply flawed. We see a lot of commercially-driven and non-peer reviewed research that make sweeping assessments of account behaviors only using public signals
column86: such as location (if cited)
column87: account content
column88: how often an account Tweets
column89: and the accounts it follows. To be clear: none of these indicators are sufficient to determine attribution to a state entity definitively. Looking for accounts that look similar to those disclosed as part of our archives is an equally flawed approach
column90: given many of the bad actors mimic legitimate accounts to appear credible. This approach also often wrongly captures legitimate voices who share a particular political viewpoint that one disagrees with.\nWe work with thousands of signals and behaviors to inform our analysis and investigation. Furthermore
column91: none of our preemptive work to challenge accounts for platform manipulation (up to 8-10 million accounts per week) are visible in the small sample available in our public API. Before engaging in this type of research and making these claims
column92: ethical norms should be considered. To do otherwise does not further public knowledge but rather risks deeply undermining trust in public debate and conversation.\nFor more on our archive of information operations
column93:
please visit our dedicated site and follow the conversation at @Policy and @TwitterSafety.

column3: "title": "The Twitter NeighborNest turns four"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nThe Twitter NeighborNest turns four\nFriday
column8: 7 June 2019\nLink copied successfully\nFour years ago
column9: we opened the NeighborNest
column10: Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s family-friendly community learning center. With a mission of creating new possibilities through technology literacy and a love of learning
column11: the NeighborNest provides San Francisco residents and partner organizations access to technology and critical life skills. Programs such as our Digital literacy courses
column12: Affordable Housing workshops
column13: Coding for Kids classes and Twitter for nonprofits allow us to work with and for the community to bridge the digital divide.\nCheck out this moment to see highlights from the last four years!\nPowered by community partners and Twitter volunteers
column14: the NeighborNest\u00e2\u0080\u0099s family-friendly environment helps to foster bright and hopeful futures for all. Since opening our doors in 2015
column15: we've had the pleasure of hosting more than 17
column16: 000 visits from residents and community members
column17: and conducting 4
column18: 700 hours of programming. This wouldn't have been possible without the commitment and support of over 15 partner organizations and 1
column19: 600 hours of service from Twitter volunteers.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cI personally am so proud of the facility and program that we have created and thrilled that this resource is available and welcoming for the homeless and at-risk families we serve
column20: helping them to bridge the very real digital divide in a supportive and encouraging environment.\u00e2\u0080\u009d -- Erica Kisch
column21: Executive Director
column22: Compass Family Services\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cThe NeighborNest is such a well-conceived and executed contribution to helping families move out of poverty and homelessness. This place and program has many threads of meaningful impact. We are proud to be a part of it!\u00e2\u0080\u009d -- Laurie Sanchez
column23: Program Director
column24: Community Technology Network\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cEvery other month
column25: the Nest has hosted our cohorts in an on-site tech visit. These visits create hope and support increased self-esteem because they are engaged with dignity and respect\u00e2\u0080\u009d -- Program Director
column26: Code Tenderloin\nOur work at the Nest is centered around three core values: learn
column27: connect
column28: and grow. Whether connecting individuals with services at the Nest or learning directly from them through their life experiences
column29: the relationships we foster every day allow us to grow in ways we could only imagine.\nThe NeighborNest provides some of our most vulnerable community members access to technology and critical life skills:\nDigital Access & Literacy: Digital Literacy
column30: Affordable Housing
column31: Open Computer Lab Time\nOnline Safety & Education: Digital Citizenship for Youth & Adults\nEquality & Workforce Development: Career Exposure
column32: Coding for Kids\nFamily-Friendly programs: Family Movie Night
column33: Music and Movement
column34: Story Hour and Arts & Crafts
column35: Childcare\nCapacity-Building for NGOs: Twitter for Nonprofits
column36: Hosting Meeting & Event Space\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cStarting out as a homeless family with an infant son
column37: I have used the Nest to become stable in my housing
column38: parenting and so many other parts of my life. I value the Nest in my life.\u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\u0093 Mother
column39: Compass Family Services Client\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cMy eldest son Nico is so enthusiastic about the Twitter coding workshop he attends through Catholic Charities Maureen & Craig Sullivan Youth Services
column40: that his younger brother can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t wait to join when he\u00e2\u0080\u0099s old enough to be a part of the lucky crowd! Nico is learning about coding \u00e2\u0080\u0093 and working as part of a group. These are valuable lessons he will use throughout his life! We are very thankful!\u00e2\u0080\u009d -- Mother of Nico
column41:
Catholic Charities Client

The NeighborNest gives Twitter volunteers the opportunity to experience the Tenderloin
column42: Mid-Market and South of Market Area from the perspective of our neighbors. While it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s incredibly important to understand the community\u00e2\u0080\u0099s history
column43: the strength of its residents and the everyday struggles

column51: more intuitive engineer. It reminds me that I am blessed and helping others if a gift I give myself.\u00e2\u0080\u009d -- Greg Wright

column55: and caretakers. As a mom

column57: and the Nest provides that welcoming

we are thrilled to continue expanding our impact in the community with the renewal of our five-year lease. Hereâs to continued partnerships and creating new possibilities through technology literacy and a love of learning!

column3: "title": "Making our rules easier to understand"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Making our rules easier to understand
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 7 June 2019\nLink copied successfully\nOur rules exist to help keep everyone using Twitter safe and ensure they can participate freely in the public conversation. Over time
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve added new rules and updated existing ones
column10: but these changes eventually made our rules confusing and difficult to understand.\nSo today
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re refreshing our rules with simple
column12: clear language and reorganizing them into high-level categories: safety
column13: privacy and authenticity. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also added detail around other policies
column14: including election integrity
column15: platform manipulation and spam.\n What\u00e2\u0080\u0099s new? \nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve gone from about 2
column16: 500 words to under 600. In 280 characters or less
column17: each rule clearly describes exactly what is not allowed on Twitter.\nNew categories \u00e2\u0080\u0094 safety
column18: privacy
column19: and authenticity \u00e2\u0080\u0094 mean our rules are organized thematically
column20: so you can find the information you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re looking for more quickly.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re refreshing rule pages to have more information
column21: including examples
column22: step-by-step instructions about how to report
column23: and details on what happens when we take action. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to make updates
column24:
but you can see some of the new pages here:
Â  Â  Private Information
Â  Â  Sensitive Media
Â Â Â Â Terrorism & violent extremism
What comes next?
Everyone who uses Twitter should be able to easily understand what is and is not allowed on the service. As part of our continued push towards more transparency across every aspect of Twitter
column25: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re working to make sure every rule has its own help page with more detailed information and relevant resources
column26: with abuse and harassment
column27: hateful conduct
column28: suicide or self-harm
column29:
and copyright being next on our list to update. Our focus remains on keeping everyone safe and supporting a healthier public conversation on Twitter. You can read our rules at twitter.com/rules.

column3: "title": "Introducing the #GoldenTweet Awards & the ways to follow the #FIFAWWC"
column7:
"post_text": "Events
Introducing the #GoldenTweet Awards & the ways to follow the #FIFAWWC
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 5 June 2019\nLink copied successfully\nIn just two days
column9: the FIFA Women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s World Cup is kicking off in Paris
column10: with the finest footballing talent around on display to a global audience.\n#GoldenTweet Awards\nAs nations across the world battle it out to become world champions
column11: Twitter will be on the lookout to find the top Tweeters of #FIFAWWC. Throughout the tournament
column12: Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s analytics team will be working to identify the best Tweets from Argentina
column13: Australia
column14: Brazil
column15: Canada
column16: Chile
column17: France
column18: Germany
column19: Japan
column20: Mexico
column21: Spain
column22: South Korea
column23: US
column24: and UK. Following the final
column25: the most popular Tweets across multiple categories will be crowned #GoldenTweet winners.\nThe Tweets that reign supreme will be presented with an iconic
column26:
limited-edition trophy featuring the Twitter bird.

column3: "title": "Inclusion & Diversity Report May 2019"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nInclusion & Diversity Report May 2019\nTuesday
column8: 4 June 2019\nLink copied successfully\nWe want our company to reflect our service
column9: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re continuing our journey to bring inclusion and diversity to how we work and who we are. We are making steady progress while we learn the right approach for Twitter.\nIn our Annual Inclusion & Diversity report published in March
column10: we committed to greater transparency around our work
column11: and more frequent updates. We wanted to show work in progress so we shifted our annual cadence of reporting to quarterly. This is our first quarterly Inclusion & Diversity (I&D) report which we presented to our Board on May 30
column12: 2019. Instead of creating a different report to publish publicly
column13: we are sharing with you what we shared with them.\nThis report is broken down across six key areas: data
column14: accountability
column15: hiring
column16: training
column17: product and partnerships
column18: and Tweeps. Included within each are areas we progressed
column19: areas we are falling short
column20: what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve learned
column21: and where we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll focus.\nOur goal is to do our work at Twitter out in the open and this is a step toward that vision. Through increased openness
column22: we believe we can learn together
column23: discuss together
column24:
and make greater strides together.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The Data
Where we are In 2018
column25: we set two-year diversity targets for women
column26: black
column27:
and Latinx total representation. We earlier reported our numbers as of Dec 2018. Here are our numbers as of May 2019.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâre on track to meet our targets for women and black employees. For Latinx
column28: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re behind and are prioritizing Latinx hiring
column29: inclusion
column30: and retention efforts.\n[Gender data is global
column31: 99.1% of Tweeps have self-identified. Race and ethnicity data is US only
column32: of which 80.8% of Tweeps self-identified.] \nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen increases across women
column33: black
column34:
and Latinx leadership representation. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Women representation in technical roles increased slightly
column35:
while black and Latinx remained steady.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We anticipate a spike in the hiring of technical roles in Q3. This will unlock a significant opportunity to increase women
column36: black
column37:
and Latinx representation. 
Hiring is a critical indicator of future trends. New hire results below are expressed as a percentage of total new hires in May 2019. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Attrition data informs where we prioritize our retention efforts. The data here is shown as a percentage of total company attrition. For example
column38:
38.7% of total attrition were women.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Here are the broader race and ethnicity breakdowns for the US.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
New diversity dashboards In March of this year
column39: we launched a new internal dashboard that gives all Tweeps access to org-level demographic data (gender
column40: race
column41: leadership
column42: and tech representation stats) at the management level. All data is based on voluntary self-ID.\nThere are drop-downs to view gender and race/ethnicity data at the Twitter level
column43: and also at the team level (Engineering
column44: Product
column45: Marketing
column46: Legal
column47: etc). \nBy hovering over any of the columns
column48: leadership and tech vs. non-tech representation is provided. For instance
column49: a Tweep can select a leader\u00e2\u0080\u0099s name in the drop-down
column50: select race/ethnicity
column51:
and hover over the column on the right to learn how many black employees are within that leaderâs team. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Pay equity  In Q1 we finished an analysis of pay after our comp planning cycle.Â  We found that all of our people are paid equitably across genders
column52: races
column53: and ethnicities.\nOur analysis compared pay across all US-based employees
column54: as well as pay for employees in our global offices
column55: and included base salary
column56: incentive compensation (where applicable)
column57: performance bonus
column58: and equity compensation. We looked at the data across gender (globally) and race/ethnicity (US only) based on employee self-ID.\nPromotions Recently
column59:
the People team began a review of our promotion data. We are currently analyzing the results and once complete we plan on sharing our findings in Q3. We will prioritize any next steps that might be needed to ensure equity.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Our data: what we learned After analyzing our data and gathering feedback from Tweeps and people on Twitter
column60: we identified three key issues to address:\nWe have significant gaps in self-ID. We don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t have a fully accurate capture of our people and our work can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t be maximized without that foundation.\nWe have been too limited in the definitions of diversity we have used. We need to expand from the\u00c2\u00a0US government definition\u00c2\u00a0of diversity and create something broader to reflect diversity of backgrounds
column61: geography
column62: cultures
column63:
and perspectives.
Our data and insights are too US-centric. Weâre a global company and every local market has diversity priorities and challenges. We have not done enough to dive into the racial diversity in offices around the world. There are legal restrictions around what data can be captured but we believe through prioritization we can find time and resources against this.
Our data: what weâre doing about it
Self-identification (self-ID) refresh  We are doing a full refresh of our self-ID process
column64: expanding the scope of what we collect to include sexual orientation
column65: gender identity
column66: disabilities
column67: and military status. We will also communicate internally to raise the visibility of its importance. We plan to update the process for our US market in June and address non-US markets in the latter half of 2019.\nNew anonymous surveys with definitions  Secondly
column68: in Q3 we will launch an anonymous survey to all Tweeps around the world. It is an opportunity to collect even more self-ID information via survey questions.  Some categories we are considering either expanding or which will be new include: Gender; Race/Ethnicity; Sexual Orientation; Gender Identity; Military Status; Disability Status; Nationality; Family/Caregiver Status.  The self-ID refresh coupled with the anonymous survey will help us arrive at our most accurate composite of employee representation to date. We will report our findings in a future quarterly report. \nHire international-focused diversity lead  Finally
column69: we will add an international diversity lead to our I&D team. We have begun scoping the needs of our global offices
column70: and this role will be fully-dedicated to inclusion and diversity
column71:
market to market.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Accountability
New Leadership team goals and targets While we have company-level diversity targets
column72: we are now committing to individual Leadership (\u00e2\u0080\u009cStaff\u00e2\u0080\u009d) level goals.\nIn Q3
column73: we will set targets for women
column74: black
column75: and Latinx for each executive team leader and their orgs. We believe this direct accountability will help drive progress in mindset and outcomes. We will also be refreshing the org-specific A.I.R. plans (attract
column76: include
column77: retain) to be customized to each team\u00e2\u0080\u0099s new targets for Women
column78: Black
column79: and Latinx populations. These are to be completed in Q3. \nNew company performance goals for 2020 and beyond Also in the latter half of 2019
column80: we will review how we reward our leaders that make I&D a priority within their own teams.\nDiversifying supplier base We will also be incorporating accountability into how we drive towards a more diverse set of suppliers.\nIn April
column81: we hired our first Supplier Inclusion & Diversity Manager within the Finance team
column82: Kristen Hickey.\nA first area of focus is women-owned businesses
column83: and we will look to intersect with other certified diverse businesses. We recently joined the Women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Business Enterprise National Council (WBENC)
column84: the largest certifier of women-owned businesses in the US and a leading advocate for women business owners and entrepreneurs.\nIn the latter half of 2019
column85:
the Supplier I&D team will be incorporating supplier inclusion efforts into how we buy at Twitter. We expect to define longer term objectives and key results in Q3.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Hiring
The recruiting team has been partnering with I&D and the business on ways to generate a more diverse pipeline
column86: while still keeping a focus on the foundational systems and process work that needs to get addressed. \u00c2\u00a0We are installing new tools and systems that will allow us to build and track talent pipelines and referrals more effectively and providing improved candidate experiences. We also expect our decentralization work will support diversity hiring efforts over time
column87: particularly by opening up candidate pools in locations with a more diverse population. \nWe have recently hired a new head of eng recruiting with a strong background in technical and diversity recruiting and we are recruiting for a Director of Diversity Recruiting to drive efforts across all parts of the recruitment org. \u00c2\u00a0Efforts currently underway include internal batch hiring days
column88: fast follow up on candidates from Industry/BRG events and sourcing/referral jams
column89: pilot hiring efforts for nontraditional hires (e.g.
column90: Associate SWE program)
column91: and competitive/SWAT efforts on opportunistic hires (e.g.
column92: diverse candidates
column93: mass layoffs in a skillset
column94: etc.).\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0 \nThis year
column95:
we will also provide more training for hiring managers and recruiters on effective diversity sourcing and eliminating bias from the process. We are also partnering closely with the People Analytics team to arrive at ways to measure diversity within our funnels. This will allow us to understand where drop-off is occurring and identify where we need to make improvements. 
We are also moving toward implementing policies that would require hiring managers to be presented with a diverse slate of candidates for certain roles moving forward. We expect to land on any changes in Q3 and will share those details in a future report. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Training
Our goal is to ensure our company reflects our service by building the processes
column96: training
column97: and tools that underpin a healthy workplace and help Tweeps grow: \nUpcoming new programs include:\nNEW healthy conversations training: global workshops in Q2 to arm all Tweeps with the skills and tools to have authentic
column98: respectful conversations\nNEW updated bias training: Twitter bias training in Q3 based on completion of an in-depth needs analysis to understand how to identify bias
column99: how to reduce it
column100:
and what to do if we see it
EXPANDED investment in female leaders: a WELead program aimed at mid-level female leaders (Level 6-7) and a new Stanford Women's Executive program aimed at senior leaders (Level 8+)
TEST AND LEARN mentor program: Finance is piloting a new system to scale mentoring across the company so we can access and share critical skills and expertise. We will assess ability to scale this across the company for 2020.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Product and Partnerships
Inclusion and diversity must be reflected in the products we build
column101: and the partnerships we forge: \nMachine Learning Ethics
column103: and Accountability (META) Earlier this year we created the META (Machine Learning Ethics
column104: Transparency
column105: and Accountability) team. Their focus includes:\nDefining and measuring fairness in our algorithmic decisions by building the necessary tooling\nEstablishing best practices for algorithmic transparency and accountability. Promoting the adoption of fairness by design
column106: i.e.
column107:
a set of fairness concerns injected at every stage of ML driven software development
Providing the framework to understand bias in our systems and drive its adoption across Twitter
Communicating the latest research and Twitter specific cases of biases to our ML practitioners and the company at large
Maintaining a healthy relationship with the research community. This includes sponsoring conferences
column108: hosting researchers (fellowships)
column109: and more\nMETA is supported by our academic partners Professor Moritz Hardt and Professor Ben Recht (who have been retained as part-time consultants) and was funded as a strategic investment by Engineering. \nAccessibility Last year
column110: several Tweeps formed a group called Accessibility Shepherds to help drive awareness of accessibility issues faced by those that use Twitter
column111: as well as those that work at Twitter.\nIn recent months
column112: the Accessibility Shepherds have taught internal classes and engaged with product teams to raise awareness and answer questions on the topic of accessibility. Our Engineering and Product teams have been working on improvements for client accessibility (iOS
column115: the Accessibility Shepherds will be formalizing as a Business Resource Group (BRG)
column116: developing training materials for our engineering teams
column117: and also exploring early conversations around product enhancements that benefit this space. \nDiversity Partnerships In March
column118: Candi Castleberry Singleton took on the new role of overseeing our Diversity Partnership Strategy & Engagement. \u00c2\u00a0The Diversity Partnership Strategy (DPS) is focused on building trust
column120:
and diverse communities. Introductory meetings with partners have been underway. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweeps
Tweeps play a critical and active role in building an inclusive and diverse Twitter. Here are some Q1 highlights. 
#TweepTour Throughout March
column122: and May our leaders have been connecting with local Tweeps and their communities on the #TweepTour. So far they have visited Singapore
column134: with many more stops planned in June.\nThe tour has been well received and a source of great learning and insights for our leaders with common themes emerging
column136: how we can build greater global mindset
column137: and key insights on culture. \nBusiness Resource Groups In February
column138: @Blackbirds executed an end-to-end plan for Black History Month which included hosting fireside chats with black leaders and creatives
column139: welcoming guest chefs specializing in the flavors and traditions of African Diaspora
column140: and celebrating black women throughout history via the #WallForACause event with NY-based artist Keebs. In London
column141:
Blackbirds partnered with Black Girls Book Club on a #DopeDiscussion chat and also hosted a screening with The Mother Drum about their diaspora film series.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
 @TwitterWomen hosted 60+ events across 23 offices during the month of March in celebration of International Womenâs Day (March 8) and Womenâs History Month (March in the US). Highlights included a #SheInspiresMe wall in all offices and a VIT visit from @ChelseaClinton. On our platform
column142: there were 11.9M Tweets with the hashtag #SheInspiresMe
column143:
which activated the womenâs symbol emoji with translations in 19 languages.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
@TwitterALAS recently participated in the #TweepTour in Mexico and Brazil where there is much excitement in activating events and experiences in both countries. ALAS also hosted a three-day immersive tech experience for young women (in partnership with MindGirl by Mindot) and inked a deal to partner with Recruiting & Women of ALPFA (Association of Latino Professionals for America).
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In 2019
column144: @TwitterAsians is focused on going global. \u00c2\u00a0Growing beyond the community which began in our North American offices
column145: we are extremely proud to now have @TwitterAsians Leads in 12 offices worldwide including Singapore
column150: and Mumbai. \u00c2\u00a0Q1 kicked off with 15+ Lunar New Year celebrations and a march in the Chinese New Year Parade.\n@TwitterOpen co-hosted two intersectional events. The first was a Lunch & Learn co-hosted by @TwitterParents with Dr. Guy Ringler
column152: surrogacy and other family-building options for the LGBTQ community. The second event was a fireside chat co-hosted by @TwitterAsians with California State Assemblymember Evan Low
column153: who made history by being the youngest openly LGBT mayor in the United States at the age of 26. The team is gearing up for an amazing Pride Month this June
column154: complete with events and experiences across our global offices.\n@TwitterStripes participated in a number of intersections events with other BRGs including Blackbirds and Twitter Women during their affinity months. Additionally
column155:
Stripes worked closely with Twitter For Good to host various events for veterans and tech industry partners.
BRG action plans We asked our BRGs to prioritize the problems they are facing at Twitter. We are underway with follow-up sessions and aligning on plans that address each BRGs unique needs and asks. Elements of those plans include:
Recognizing value: ensuring the positive impact delivered each day by the BRGs is recognized and rewarded as part of our performance review process
#notapipelineproblem: building a process through which the amazing people introduced to Twitter via BRG channels do not get âlost in the shuffleâ; we commit to proactively follow through and leverage this talent pool when sourcing for future roles
Event support: developing end-to-end playbooks and providing resources to support the BRGs with large cross-functional efforts such as Black History Month and International Womenâs Day
As a further step
column156: the People leadership team has set up a recurring weekly sync with the objective of deep diving into attract and retain efforts for our women
column158:
and Latinx communities. This level of focus and attention is expected to set the tone and pace needed to make a real change. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Whatâs Next?
Weâve got a lot of work ahead of us and will be listening to our Tweeps
column159:
and your feedback. We believe these quarterly updates will spark conversations and actions needed for changeÂ â at Twitter and beyond. Weâll be back in three months!

Our spring 2019 Twitter For Good Day
            By

Monday
column8: 3 June 2019\nLink copied successfully\nTwice a year
column9: Tweeps around the world take some time away from their desks to give back to their communities \u00e2\u0080\u0093 #TwitterForGood Day. More than 1
column10: 330 Twitter employees around the world committed more than 3
column11: 350 hours of service to projects such as cleaning up neighborhoods San Francisco
column12: hosting Iftar dinners for young people in Jakarta
column13: revamping a community center in Dublin
column14: and organizing a dance for children with disabilities in Sao Paulo. This day reminds us of the impact service
column15:
community and partnership can have.
Want to see how Tweeps spent the day? Check out this moment and continue scrolling for a snapshot!
APAC
Sydney
As part of the annual Australiaâs Biggest Morning Tea
column16: @TwitterAU hosted a morning tea stall to raise money for Cancer Council Australia (@CancerCouncilOz). The idea behind Australia\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Biggest Morning Tea is simple \u00e2\u0080\u0094 bring your friends
column17: colleagues
column18: and community together over some tea and treats to help fund Cancer Council\u00e2\u0080\u0099s life-saving research
column19: prevention
column20: programs
column21:
and help support people impacted by cancer.

India

we are continuing to monitor the aftermath of Cyclone Fani and are trying to work with our NGO partners in supporting restoration work in Orissa and other impacted areas.

@TwitterIndia celebrated #TwitterForGood Day with a range of activities focused around environmental protection
column26: social awareness and public health
column27: kicking things off with a #TwitterForGood with a \u00e2\u0080\u0098City Session on the State of Varanasi Pollution\u00e2\u0080\u0099 in partnership with #LetMeBreathe (@LetMeBreathe_In). Varanasi continues to be one of the most polluted cities in the world. The session looked at multiple approaches that could be adopted in order to \u00c2\u00a0deal with the menace of air pollution including reforestation
column28: minimising pollution of the Ganga River

among others.

Seoul
Under the theme "Everyday is #EarthDay
column32: \" @TwitterKorea partnered with the Gangnam District Volunteer Center of Seoul City to conduct activities around the Yangjae Stream that runs through Southern Seoul. After learning about the ecosystem around the Yangjae Stream from local activists
column33:
the team spent a day making Effective micro-organism mudballs which provide a good microbial diversity in pond water and belong to the biological water improvement agents (EM Mudballs) Volunteers then threw 500 EM balls into the stream to help clean the water. This was the first time Team Korea participated in an environmental volunteer activity. It was a meaningful opportunity to demonstrate Twitter's commitment to the environment and interact with community leaders at the district level.

          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Singapore
@TwitterSG spent the month of May hosting #TwitterForGood activities. This kicked off with the Earth Observatory of Singapore (@EOS_SG)

column35: as well as measuring their impact with the use of Twitter data. Tweeps also visited Project X (@ProjectX)

where the Executive Director of Project X spoke about the landscape and legal provisions surrounding the issue of sex work and human rights in Singapore.

The team in Singapore also hosted a panel on parental benefits and the âMotherhood biasâ together with the Association of Women for Action and Research (@awarenews)

column39: and a Book Drop with WomenTalk (@WOMENTALKTVASIA)

an online video and podcast interview series featuring unsung heroines in Asia.

Tokyo
@TwitterJP volunteered at the neighbourhood community clean-up for Chuo-city Â (@Chuo_city)

animal loving Tweeps visited Peace Wanko @peaceWankoJapan to look after dogs living in shelters. This nonprofit also trains abundant dogs as rescue dogs to work at disaster sites.

@TwitterMENA organized the #TweetRight initiative at the American University of Cairo where students attended digital literacy workshops and created accounts that aim to combat misinformation on the platform. The competition encouraged students to be active and creative while engaging in a powerful dialogue on promoting the health of the public conversation. The winning team received a Twitter Ads For Good reward that will help them continue to develop the knowledge and skill-set needed to fight misinformation and #TweetRight.

The idea behind the initiative is for Tweeps to be exposed to Emirati local culture and values by attending a family-hosted Ramadan Iftar at an Emirati home in Dubai and to participate in local Ramadan traditions

reflecting tolerance and engagement with the community.

Europe
Dublin
As a part of its annual volunteer efforts
column47: @TwitterDublin voted to partner with The Peter McVerry Trust (@PMVTrust) for a second year. The Irish Tweeps set a fundraising target of \u00e2\u0082\u00ac10
column48: 000 by the end of 2019
column49: with the funds going towards support services for those who have recently been re-housed by the Trust. For #TwitterForGood Day
column50: the team kicked off the day by calling over 60 businesses on behalf of PMVT to enable the building of their database. Tweeps hit the streets of Dublin selling badges on behalf of PMVT which were created by our very own #CreativeNest committee. Tweeps also prepared 1

000 care kits to donate to PMVT to aid those experiencing homelessness. column3: "title": "Twitter acquires Fabula AI to strengthen its machine learning expertise "
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Twitter acquires Fabula AI to strengthen its machine learning expertise 
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 3 June 2019\nLink copied successfully\nMachine learning plays a key role in powering Twitter and our purpose of serving the public conversation. From onboarding people on the platform to connecting them with relevant conversations
column9: we leverage machine learning (ML) across a multitude of our product surface areas.\nTo continually advance the state of machine learning
column10: inside and outside Twitter
column11: we are building out a research group at Twitter
column12: led by Sandeep Pandey
column13: to focus on a few key strategic areas such as natural language processing
column14: reinforcement learning
column15: ML ethics
column16: recommendation systems
column17: and graph deep learning. \nWe are excited to announce that
column18: to help us get there
column19: we have acquired Fabula AI (Fabula)
column20: a London-based start-up
column21: with a world-class team of machine learning researchers who employ graph deep learning to detect network manipulation. Graph deep learning is a novel method for applying powerful ML techniques to network-structured data. The result is the ability to analyze very large and complex datasets describing relations and interactions
column22: and to extract signals in ways that traditional ML techniques are not capable of doing. \nThis strategic investment in graph deep learning research
column23: technology and talent will be a key driver as we work to help people feel safe on Twitter and help them see relevant information. Specifically
column24: by studying and understanding the Twitter graph
column25: comprised of the millions of Tweets
column26: Retweets and Likes shared on Twitter every day
column27: we will be able to improve the health of the conversation
column28: as well as products including the timeline
column29: recommendations
column30: the explore tab and the onboarding experience. \nFabula was founded by Michael Bronstein
column31: Damon Mannion
column32: Federico Monti
column33: and Ernesto Schmitt. It is led today by co-founder and chief scientist Michael Bronstein and chief technologist Federico Monti
column34: who began their collaboration together while at the University of Lugano
column35: Switzerland. Bronstein is one of the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s leading researchers in graph deep learning
column36: and has pioneered its application in the realm of Internet companies. \n\u00e2\u0080\u009cWe are really excited to join the ML research team at Twitter
column37: and work together to grow their team and capabilities. Specifically
column38: we are looking forward to applying our graph deep learning techniques to improving the health of the conversation across the service
column39: \u00e2\u0080\u009d said Michael Bronstein.\nOur initial focus when Fabula joins the Twitter team will be to improve the health of the conversation
column40: with expanding applications to stop spam and abuse and other strategic priorities in the future.\nBronstein is currently the Chair in Machine Learning & Pattern Recognition at Imperial College
column41: and will remain in that position while leading graph deep learning research at Twitter. Bronstein will be joined by long-time collaborators from academia (many current or former students) who have spent years researching advances in geometric deep learning. \nOur acquisition of Fabula builds on other investments we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made in machine learning
column42: for example
column43: Madbits in 2014
column44: Whetlab in 2015 and Magic Pony in 2016. Fabula's team will be joining the Twitter Cortex team of ML engineers
column45: data scientists
column46:
and researchers. Cortex is the central ML org at Twitter with the goal to advance machine learning inside & outside Twitter. 
We are excited to welcome the Fabula team to Twitter! 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
@TwitterEng
Tweet
Twitter logo icon
Tags:
machine learning

column3: "title": "6.2m Tweets on EU elections as voters turn to Twitter for conversation"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
6.2m Tweets on EU elections as voters turn to Twitter for conversation
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 31 May 2019\nLink copied successfully\nAs the dust finally settles on the EU elections
column9: let\u00e2\u0080\u0099s reflect on the Tweets
column10: topics
column11: themes
column12: and trends that got people talking on Twitter over the campaign. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s been an exciting
column13: loud and engaging few weeks
column14: where Europeans not only came out in force at polling stations
column15: but also on Twitter.  To drive engagement across all official EU languages
column16: we launched two special emojis for the occasion - #EP2019 and #EUelections2019. From Thursday to Sunday \u00e2\u0080\u0094 when voters from 28 Member States went to the polls \u00e2\u0080\u0094 EU election-related conversations amassed an incredible 2.1 million Tweets collectively
column17: including those using #EP2019
column18: #EUelections2019 and #ThisTimeImVoting. Relatedly
column19: voter turnout was way up.  Overall
column20: since the campaign began in February
column21: there was 6.2 million election-related Tweets
column22:
marking aÂ  273% increase in Tweet volume on the previous EU elections. Twitter was the conversational platform of choice for those who wanted to engage on the issue for the 2019 EU elections. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Unsurprisingly
column23: Brexit-related issues attracted a huge level of conversation and engagement with over 1.5 million Tweets posted on the topic over the election weekend alone
column24: with 221k of those using #Brexit.\u00c2\u00a0 \u00c2\u00a0  In terms of candidates who are front-runners for the next President of the EU Commission
column25: most mentioned during the election weekend were @TimmermansEU
column26: @ManfredWeber and @SkaKeller with the most frequently mentioned political parties being; European Green Party; European People's Party and the Party of European Socialists. The rise in Twitter conversation involving the European Green Party is one that is certainly reflective of the #GreenWave across Europe in terms of voting patterns.  Engagement was also extremely high for the #TellEurope Eurovision debate
column27:
with 2.5m views on Twitterâs livestream of the event from the Parliamentâs @Europarl_EN account. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The much-loved #DogsAtPollingStations also proved popular
column28: with almost 22
column29:
000 Tweets between Thursday and Friday. Hereâs a snippet of what was shared: 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
On Sunday
column30: when 21 countries went to the polling stations
column31: Europe was alight with election 2019 conversation as demonstrated by our Tweet velocity heatmap. The map shows the geographical distribution of conversation across the region
column32:
including spikes as people expressed their democratic participation in every individual Member State.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As the figures show
column33: the depth of conversation around the #EUelections was significantly higher (273%) than the previous election cycle
column34: highlighting how Twitter is increasingly utilized by citizens to express themselves on the issues that matter to their everyday lives. To help protect these critical online conversations
column35: we took a number of proactive steps specific to these elections. These included establishing an elections integrity team to monitor trends and behaviours; rolling out a new tool to allow people to report deliberately misleading election-related content; and launching a political campaign ads policy to provide more insight into electioneering ads.\nIn February
column36: we said Twitter would work diligently to ensure it would be the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s window into the EU election conversation. Between selfies at count centres
column37: breaking news alerts and the intense back-and-forth of the Brexit debate
column38: the conversation was dynamic
column39: extraordinarily varied and most importantly
column40: created an online town square to unite voters around key issues relevant to them. \u00c2\u00a0 \nServing and protecting the health of the public conversation continues to be Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s key priority. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue working to protect conversations on the service
column41: particularly around election cycles
column42: by investing in technology
column43: developing new policies
column44:
and building meaningful partnerships to further our understanding of the political and social context within which Twitter operates.
Â

column3: "title": "Addressing the abuse of tech to spread terrorist and extremist content"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nAddressing the abuse of tech to spread terrorist and extremist content\nWednesday
column8: 15 May 2019\nLink copied successfully\nIn addition to our commitment to the Christchurch Call
column9: Twitter
column10: Facebook
column11: Microsoft
column12: Google
column13: and Amazon\u00c2\u00a0commit to the following:\nFive Individual Actions:\n1. Terms of Use.\u00c2\u00a0We commit to updating our terms of use
column14: community standards
column15: codes of conduct
column16: and acceptable use policies to expressly prohibit the distribution of terrorist and violent extremist content. We believe this is important to establish baseline expectations for users and to articulate a clear basis for removal of this content from our platforms and services and suspension or closure of accounts distributing such content.\u00c2\u00a0\n2. User Reporting of Terrorist and Violent Extremist Content.\u00c2\u00a0We commit to establishing one or more methods within our online platforms and services for users to report or flag inappropriate content
column17: including terrorist and violent extremist content. We will ensure that the reporting mechanisms are clear
column18: conspicuous
column19: and easy to use
column20: and provide enough categorical granularity to allow the company to prioritize and act promptly upon notification of terrorist or violent extremist content.\n3. Enhancing Technology.\u00c2\u00a0We commit to continuing to invest in technology that improves our capability to detect and remove terrorist and violent extremist content online
column21: including the extension or development of digital fingerprinting and AI based technology solutions.\n4. Livestreaming.\u00c2\u00a0We commit to identifying appropriate checks on livestreaming
column22: aimed at reducing the risk of disseminating terrorist and violent extremist content online. These may include enhanced vetting measures (such as streamer ratings or scores
column23: account activity
column24: or validation processes) and moderation of certain livestreaming events where appropriate. Checks on livestreaming necessarily will be tailored to the context of specific livestreaming services
column25: including the type of audience
column26: the nature or character of the livestreaming service
column27:
and the likelihood of exploitation.Â 
5. Transparency Reports.Â We commit to publishing on a regular basis transparency reports regarding detection and removal of terrorist or violent extremist content on our online platforms and services and ensuring that the data is supported by a reasonable and explainable methodology.
Four Collaborative Actions:
1. Share Technology Development.Â We commit working collaboratively across industry
column28: governments
column29: educational institutions
column30:
and NGOs to develop a shared understanding of the contexts in which terrorist and violent extremist content is published and to improve technology to detect and remove terrorist and violent extremist content more effectively and efficiently. This will include:
Work to create robust shared data sets to accelerate machine learning and AI and sharing insights and learnings from the data.
Development of open source or other shared tools to detect and remove terrorist or violent extremist content.
Enablement of all companies
column31: large and small
column32: to contribute to the collective effort and to better address detection and removal of this content on their platforms and services.\n2. Crisis Protocols.\u00c2\u00a0We commit to working collaboratively across industry
column33: governments
column34: and NGOs to create a protocol for responding to emerging or active events
column35: on an urgent basis
column36: so relevant information can be quickly and efficiently shared
column37: processed
column38: and acted upon by all stakeholders with minimal delay. This includes the establishment of incident management teams that coordinate actions and broadly distribute information that is in the public interest.\n3. Education.\u00c2\u00a0We commit to working collaboratively across industry governments
column39: educational institutions
column40:
and NGOs to help understand and educate the public about terrorist and extremist violent content online. This educating and reminding users about how to report or otherwise not contribute to the spread of this content online.
4. Combatting Hate and Bigotry. We commit to working collaboratively across industry to attack the root causes of extremism and hate online. This includes providing greater support for relevant research â with an emphasis on the impact of online hate on offline discrimination and violence â and supporting capacity and capability of NGOs working to challenge hate and promote pluralism and respect online.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet

column3: "title": "Helping you find reliable public health information on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Helping you find reliable public health information on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8:
10 May 2019
Link copied successfully
Weâre committed to protecting the health of the public conversation on Twitter â ensuring individuals can find information from authoritative sources is a key part of that mission.
We recently launched a new tool so when someone searches for certain keywords associated with vaccines
column9: a prompt will direct individuals to a credible public health resource. In the United States
column10: we partnered with the US Department of Health & Human Services and point people to vaccines.gov.\u00c2\u00a0The new search prompt is available on iOS
column11: Android
column12: and\u00c2\u00a0mobile.twitter.com\u00c2\u00a0in the United States (in English and Spanish)
column13: Canada (in English and French)
column14: UK
column15: Brazil
column16: Korea
column17: Japan
column18: Indonesia
column19: Singapore
column20: and in Spanish-speaking Latin American countries. If you search on\u00c2\u00a0twitter.com
column21:
thereâs a pinned Tweet with information from trusted partners.*Â 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We already do this when individuals search for terms associated with suicide or self-harm as part of our #ThereIsHelpÂ initiative and hope to expand it to other important public health issues in the coming months. Additionally
column22: we will not auto-suggest\u00c2\u00a0queries that are likely to direct individuals to non-credible commentary and information about vaccines.\nThis new investment builds on our existing work to guard against the artificial amplification of non-credible content about the safety and effectiveness of vaccines. We already ensure that advertising content does not contain misleading claims about the cure
column23: treatment
column24: diagnosis or prevention of certain diseases and conditions
column25: including vaccines.\nAt Twitter
column26:
we understand the importance of vaccines in preventing illness and disease and recognize the role that Twitter plays in disseminating important public health information. We think it's important to help people find reliable information that enhances their health and well-being.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
*only in US
column27: Canada
column28: UK
column29: Brazil
column30: and Korea.\n\u00c2\u00a0\nCorrection 5/14/19 at 4:30pm PT: An earlier version of the blog stated that this \"the new search prompt is available on iOS
column31: Android
column32: and\u00c2\u00a0mobile.twitter.com\u00c2\u00a0in the United States (in English and Spanish)
column33: Canada
column34: the UK
