column3: "title": "Key data and insights from our 14th Twitter Transparency Report"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Key data and insights from our 14th Twitter Transparency Report
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 9 May 2019\nLink copied successfully\nTransparency is a key guiding principle in our mission to serve the public conversation. For the past seven years
column9: our biannual Twitter Transparency Report has highlighted trends in requests made to Twitter from around the globe. Over time
column10: we have significantly expanded the information we disclose adding metrics on platform manipulation
column11: Twitter Rules enforcement
column12: and our proactive efforts to eradicate terrorist content
column13: violent extremism
column14: and child sexual exploitation from our service.\nWe strongly believe in providing data and information that is straightforward and provides insights into the types of requests we receive from governments and others around the world. This is why we also upload legal requests directly into Lumen database
column15: a long-term partnership with the Berkman Klein Center at Harvard. We encourage the public to explore this site to get a sense of the day-to-day queries we receive from governments and other entities around the world.\nFreedom of expression is the cornerstone of why we exist
column16: and we hope that the larger and more granular datasets published in our Transparency Report provide you with information that can help you understand the political and social contours of how nation-states and their institutions interact with our company. We believe it is vital that the public see the demands we receive
column17: and how we work to strike a balance between respecting local law
column18: letting the Tweets flow
column19: and protecting people from harm. We will continue to update our report with new data and evolve our commitment in this space
column20:
particularly around the Twitter Rules and our own enforcement.
The below data points highlight some of the most important and interesting trends weâve observed during this reporting period (July-December 2018).
Global information requests (legal requests for account information):
We received broadly the same number of information requests (combined emergency disclosure requests and non-emergency requests for account information) compared to the previous reporting period.
The US submitted 6% fewer information requests than the last reporting period
column21: with 58% fewer accounts specified. This contributed to the lower volume of accounts specified globally. Notably
column22: the number of accounts specified worldwide decreased by 34%.\nWe have received government information requests from 86 different countries. The United States now comprises only 30% of global government information requests and 35% of all global accounts specified in the same category.\nThe second highest volume of information requests were submitted by Japan (24% of global information requests
column23: comprising 20% of global accounts specified). Requests from the United Kingdom (13%)
column24: India (6%)
column25: Germany (6%)
column26: and France (5%) together account for 30% of all global information requests
column27: and 29% of all global accounts specified.\nThe volume of global emergency disclosure requests (EDRs) decreased by 2% since the last reporting period. For the first time since we began reporting
column28: the United Kingdom submitted the greatest percentage of global EDRs (33%)
column29: followed by the United States (30%).\nGlobal removal requests (legal requests for content removal):\nWe received roughly 8% fewer global legal requests to remove content
column30: impacting approximately 2% fewer accounts
column31: compared to the previous reporting period. However
column32: there was an 84% increase year-over-year between 2017 and 2018.\nWe received legal requests specifying 27
column33: 283 accounts from 48 different countries
column34: including Bulgaria
column35: Kyrgyzstan
column36: \u00c2\u00a0Republic of North Macedonia
column37: and Slovenia for the first time.\n74% of the total global volume of legal requests to remove content originated from only two countries: Russia and Turkey.\nRemoval of terrorist content  During this reporting period
column38: a total of 166
column39: 513 accounts were suspended for violations related to promotion of terrorism
column40: which is a reduction of 19% from the volume shared in the previous reporting period. Of those suspensions
column41: 91% consisted of accounts flagged by internal
column42: purpose-built technological tools. The trend we are observing year-on-year is a steady decrease in terrorist organizations attempting to use our service. This is due to zero-tolerance policy enforcement that has allowed us to take swift action on ban evaders and other identified forms of behavior used by terrorist entities and their affiliates. In the majority of cases
column43: we take action at the account setup stage \u00e2\u0080\u0094 before the account even Tweets. We are encouraged by these metrics but will remain vigilant. Our goal is to stay one step ahead of emergent behaviors and new attempts to circumvent our robust approach.\nRemoval of child sexual exploitation  During this reporting period
column44: we suspended a total of 456
column45: 989 unique accounts for violations related to child sexual exploitation
column46: which is down 6% from the volume disclosed in the previous reporting period. Of those unique accounts suspended
column47: 96% were surfaced by a combination of technology solutions
column48: including PhotoDNA and internal proprietary tools. As standard and required by law
column49: we continue to report to the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children (NCMEC). Alongside our other safety partners worldwide
column50: NCMEC continue to play a critical role and we deeply value and appreciate the partnership.\nPlatform manipulation*  Proactive challenges of accounts for spammy behavior and platform manipulation have decreased by 17% in the second half of 2018 versus the first half
column51: totalling 194 million challenges in the second half of 2018. Approximately 75% were subsequently automatically removed after failing our account challenge process. This is due to a range of factors
column52: including our increased emphasis on detection of malicious activity at signup \u00e2\u0080\u0094 stopping bad actors from ever getting to the stage of Tweeting \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and positive external trends affecting the volume of this activity targeting Twitter. Aggregate reports of these types of behavior have also decreased in the second half of 2018
column53: suggesting that people continue to experience fewer spammy interactions on Twitter.\nNational security requests  As in past reports
column54: Twitter is only able to publish very limited information about national security requests due to legal prohibitions that we continue to challenge in court (see here for a full update on Twitter v. Barr
column55: our ongoing transparency litigation). At this time we are able to share information about the number of National Security Letters (NSLs) received which are no longer subject to non-disclosure orders. We believe it is much more meaningful to publish these actual numbers than reporting in the bands authorized per the USA Freedom Act.\nDuring this reporting period we notified users affected by two additional NSLs after the gag orders were lifted. As reflected in the report
column56: non-disclosure orders for 14 total NSLs have been lifted to date. Twitter is committed to continuing to use the legal mechanism available to us to request judicial review of these gag orders. More broadly
column57: we are also committed to arguing that indefinite non-disclosure orders are unconstitutional in both the criminal and national security contexts. We view each request for judicial review as an opportunity to strengthen the legal precedent protecting our First Amendment rights. \nTwitter Rules enforcement  Across the six Twitter Rules policy categories included in this report
column59: 388 accounts were reported by known government entities compared to 5
column60: 461 reported during the last reported period
column61: an increase of 17%. We have a global team that manages enforcement of our Rules with 24/7 coverage
column62: in every supported language on the service. It is worth noting that the raw number of reported accounts is not a consistent indicator of the validity of the reports we receive. During our review process
column63: we may consider whether reported content violates aspects of the Twitter Rules beyond what was initially reported. For example
column64: content reported as a violation of our private information policy may also be a violation of our policies for hateful conduct. If the content is determined to violate any Twitter Rule
column65: it is actioned accordingly. Not all reported accounts are found to violate the Twitter Rules
column66: and reported accounts may be found to violate a different rule than was initially reported. We may also determine that reported content does not violate the rules at all. The volumes often fluctuate significantly based on world events
column67: including elections
column68: national and international media stories
column69: and large conversational moments in social and political culture.\nLegislative changes  We produce the Twitter Transparency Report to inform the public about the actions we take and the requests we receive from governments around the world. As the public discussion about regulation increases
column70: we believe transparency is an essential part of ensuring you \u00e2\u0080\u0094 the public \u00e2\u0080\u0094 are able to see how these laws operate. Transparency is not just the responsibility of tech companies. Governments and regulators should be transparent about their own actions
column71: enabling people to know if content has been removed because of a decision Twitter made
column72: or because of a government request. This transparency is essential if we are to foster an informed debate and mitigate the risk of inappropriate use of state power.\nWe encourage you to review our latest Twitter Transparency Report in depth and to follow the conversation over at @Policy.\n*A note about our previous report: We regularly review
column73: refine
column74: and iterate upon the data we collect and evaluate for the Twitter Transparency Report. Since we published our last report
column75: we have moved to a different data source for tracking the number of spam and platform manipulation reports we receive from people who use Twitter. In our last report (covering January-June 2018)
column76: we shared that we received 4
column78: 893 spam reports. Based on our updated data source
column79: we now believe that 3
column81:
533 reports the accurate number. Today we reflect these corrections as a revision to our previous reportâs data.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet

transparency

column3: "title": "Strengthening our approach to deliberate attempts to mislead voters"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nStrengthening our approach to deliberate attempts to mislead voters\nWednesday
column8:
24 April 2019
Link copied successfully
Voting is a fundamental human right and the public conversation occurring on Twitter is never more important than during elections. Any attempts to undermine the process of registering to vote or engaging in the electoral process is contrary to our company's core values.
Today
column9:
we are further expanding our enforcement capabilities in this area by creating a dedicated reporting feature within the product to allow users to more easily report this content to us. This is in addition to our existing proactive approach to tackling malicious automation and other forms of platform manipulation on the service. We will start with 2019 Lok Sabha in India and the EU elections and then roll out to other elections globally throughout the rest of the year.
What types of content are in violation?
You may not use Twitterâs services for the purpose of manipulating or interfering in elections. This includes but is not limited to:
Misleading information about how to vote or register to vote (for example
column10: that you can vote by Tweet
column11: text message
column12: email
column13: or phone call);\nMisleading information about requirements for voting
column14: including identification requirements; and\nMisleading statements or information about the official
column15:
announced date or time of an election.
How do I report? 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In-app
You can report this content for review in-app as follows:
Select report Tweet from drop down menu
Select âitâs misleading about votingâ
Select the option that best tells us how the Tweet is misleading about voting
Submit your report.
Desktop
You can report this content for review on desktop as follows:
Select report Tweet from drop down menu
Select âitâs misleading about votingâ
Select the option that best tells us how the Tweet is misleading about voting
Submit your report.
This feature is only available in the EU and India for now. Our teams have been trained and we recently enhanced our appeals process in the event that we make the wrong call.
Next steps
This strengthened approach will be fully operational in India beginning April 25 and the EU on from April 29. For more on the specifics of the policy
column16: the types of content we will be taking action on
column17: and our enforcement approach
column18:
visit the Twitter Help Center here. Our efforts to protect the public conversation around elections are ongoing and are guided by our core company principles.
Catch up with the latest over at @TwitterSafety.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter

column3: "title": "Leveraging the power of Twitter to combat the opioid crisis"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Leveraging the power of Twitter to combat the opioid crisis
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 23 April 2019\nLink copied successfully\nAt Twitter
column9: we put the people who use our service first in every step we take. The safety and security of the people who use Twitter is our top priority. Over the past year
column10: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve utilized the power of our service to help prevent drug misuse
column11: curb illegal online drug sales
column12: and promote public health information. Most importantly
column13: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been working to champion those who use Twitter to build a thriving #RecoveryMovement.  In 2017 alone
column15: 237 people in the United States died from drug overdoses. Nearly 70 percent of those deaths involved opioids
column16: surpassing the number of deaths resulting from traffic accidents. Last year
column17: US government leaders invited Twitter to collaborate on efforts to help combat the #OpioidCrisis. Twitter is committed to leveraging our resources and tools to help meet this important challenge.  DEA #TakeBackDay Twitter is once again partnering with the Drug Enforcement Administration\u00e2\u0080\u0099s (DEA) for its Take Back Day
column18: a biannual campaign that encourages Americans to dispose of their prescription drugs at a local drop-off site in order to prevent drug misuse. The next #TakeBackDay in the United States is on April 27.\nTwitter has re-launched a custom emoji for #TakeBackDay and is coordinating with congressional leaders and Administration officials to raise awareness for this event on the platform. Last year
column19: launching the custom #TakeBackDay emoji and the corresponding hashtags helped to elevate the conversation with 50x the engagement compared to previous years. In fall 2018
column20: #TakeBackDay Tweets garnered more than 1 million impressions with the help of high-profile Tweets
column21:
including one from the First Lady of the United States.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Working to prevent drug sales online We remove any Tweets offering to sell opioids and regulated drugs. Weâve ramped up the use of our anti-spam tools
column22: deployed new
column23: targeted technologies around this issue
column24: and implemented additional internal processes to enforce the Twitter Rules regarding drug-related content.  To inform our efforts
column25: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve consulted expert researchers from leading institutions
column26: government officials
column27: and law enforcement entities. This work has resulted in the removal of more than 17
column28: 000 Tweets globally since mid-2018 for violating our rules related to illegal and regulated drug sales \u00e2\u0080\u0094 included in that figure is attempted credit card scams and diet pill sales
column29: as well as related spammy behaviors.  In the next few weeks
column30: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be updating our rules so they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re shorter
column31: simpler
column32: and easier to understand. Included in that effort will be additional clarity regarding how we treat the sale of illegal and regulated drugs on Twitter.  #RecoveryMovement According to a recent study conducted by researchers at Johns Hopkins and Harvard
column33: 2.5 million US adults in recovery report recovery-related use of online technology and that interventions leveraging online technologies have enhanced outcomes for these individuals.  We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve developed strong partnerships with recovery researchers from leading academic institutions and advocates to shape our product and policy work. To support the people who are active in the #RecoveryMovement online
column34: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve held events and supported on-platform engagement
column35: including donating pro bono advertising awards through our #AdsForGood program. We invite government leaders
column36: NGOs
column37: advocates
column38: and people in recovery to join us in celebrating #RecoveryMonth in September on Twitter.  Collaboration to promote public health We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve hosted events at Twitter's DC office with guests including the US Surgeon General
column39: members of Congress
column40: Young People in Recovery President and CEO Justin Luke Riley
column41:
and Substance Use Disorders Institute Recovery Scientist Robert Ashford to discuss the opioid crisis and #RecoveryMovement.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Last year
column42: Twitter participated in the US Food and Drug Administration\u00e2\u0080\u0099s (FDA) Online Opioid Summit in which we committed to taking stronger action against the availability of illegal online drug sales. We provided an update on our progress at a follow-up event at the FDA earlier this month.  Nonprofits help to share public health information
column43: conduct important research and create communities of support
column44: oftentimes through online services. To support their efforts
column45: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve conducted best practices training with organizations like Lily\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Place and The Partnership for Drug-Free Kids to enhance their effectiveness on Twitter.  In November 2018
column46:
Twitter co-hosted an event with industry peers and The Center for Safe Internet Pharmacies featuring Dopesick author Beth Macy and representatives from the National Institutes of Health. We also participated in a panel discussing how the tech industry can continue to combat the opioid crisis.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In San Francisco
column47: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re teaming up with the Saint Francis Foundation
column48: the Harm Reduction Coalition
column49: GLIDE
column50: the Tenderloin Community Benefit District
column51: and Gubbio Project \u00e2\u0080\u0094 organizations that are all working toward a multifaceted approach to address the crisis. This year
column52: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also keynoting Young People in Recovery\u00e2\u0080\u0099s 2019 conference and will provide training for the organization\u00e2\u0080\u0099s chapter leaders across the country.  Our commitment continues We will continue to invest in tools and technology to improve the health of the conversation on Twitter
column53:
as well as build on our efforts with outside partners to ensure Twitter doing its part to help those with substance use disorders connect to recovery communities.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Taking steps toward sustainability this Earth Day"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Taking steps toward sustainability this Earth Day
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 22 April 2019\nLink copied successfully\nEarth Day is an important day of action in the world on the issue of climate change. At Twitter
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re delighted to partner with the Earth Day Network
column10: as well as share new commitments that our company is making to help address this pressing issue.\nFrom the first Earth Day in 1970
column11: the annual event has grown from 20 million to more than 1 billion people participating in activities around the globe. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re helping to promote a variety of campaigns on Twitter focused on increasing environmental awareness and education
column12: as well as working to mobilize citizens around the movement.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve built and launched an emoji in celebration of #EarthDay\u00c2\u00a0that highlights key campaigns people are driving on Twitter including #ClimateAction
column13: #EarthRise
column14:
and #VoteEarth. Weâve also donated pro bono advertising credits under our #AdsForGood program to help promote efforts leading up to Earth Dayâs 50th Anniversary.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As part of our commitment to making San Francisco â where our company is headquartered â a greener place
column15: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve partnered with the San Francisco Parks Alliance. Today
column16: Tweeps are volunteering to clean up and restore the habitat at Cayuga Park. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll also be bringing Tweeps together for volunteer initiatives in our offices around the globe as part of the \u00e2\u0080\u009cGreat Global Clean Up\u00e2\u0080\u009d in May and #FridayForGood.  Leading up to the 50th anniversary of Earth Day in 2020
column17: Twitter is also making new commitments
column18: including:\nTravel: We will begin to offset our carbon emissions for regular employee travel
column19: as well as large-scale events like #OneTeam2020 and the #TweepTour. This program works by funding green energy projects around the world
column20: managed through Cool Effect
column21: a climate change nonprofit.\nData Centers: Our data centers represent a significant piece of our carbon footprint. Our goal is to achieve 100% carbon-neutral power sourcing in our current data centers by the end of 2022. While we work to bring that online
column22: we will also offset our current carbon emissions through Cool Effect.\nPlastic Use: We will minimize our use of plastic at Twitter events
column23: as well as end the use of single-use bottles
column24: utensils
column25: and plates by 2020.\nRecycled Products: By year\u00e2\u0080\u0099s end
column26: all Twitter offices will use 100% recycled paper products in the United States and globally by 2020.\nComposting: We will implement a new composting program in our US offices by the end of 2020
column27: building on the leadership of the green initiatives already underway in many of our offices worldwide.\nOffice Build-Outs: We will continue to work closely with our Real Estate and Workplace team to ensure that we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re retrofitting and installing environmentally-friendly water faucets and achieving at least 95% \u00e2\u0080\u009cGreen Certified\u00e2\u0080\u009d status and 100% Carbon Neutral Energy in our directly-leased buildings by 2025. Our EMEA HQ in Dublin office is already powered entirely by renewable energy. To achieve this
column28: building aspects including water consumption
column29: energy efficiency
column30: indoor air quality
column31: and material selection were designed and installed in line with LEED\u00e2\u0080\u0099s guidelines and metrics. The team received an award for its leadership in the city.\nHow can you participate? Start by joining the conversation using the dedicated hashtags
column32: following the accounts mentioned here
column33:
and thinking of ways you can reduce your own carbon footprint at home and at work.
We believe taking these steps are important but know we have more to do to. This is a global issue with global ramifications. We are committed to playing our part.
Â

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "A healthier Twitter: Progress and more to do"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
A healthier Twitter: Progress and more to do
          
          
            and
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 16 April 2019\nLink copied successfully\nWe want people to feel safe on Twitter. Last year
column9: we shared that building a Twitter free of abuse
column10: spam and other things that distract from the public conversation is our top priority. Since then
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made strides in creating a healthier service. Today
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sharing an update on our progress and previewing some changes you can expect to see in the next few months. There will always be more to do
column13: but we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made meaningful progress that is important to share.\nHere is a summary of progress we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made
column14:
with more detail on our proactive work below:
38% of abusive content thatâs enforced is surfaced proactively to our teams for review instead of relying on reports from people on Twitter.
16% fewer abuse reports after an interaction from an account the reporter doesnât follow.
100
column15:
000 accounts suspended for creating new accounts after a suspension during January-March 2019 ââ a 45% increase from the same time last year.
60% faster response to appeals requests with our new in-app appeal process.
3 times more abusive accounts suspended within 24 hours after a report compared to the same time last year.
2.5 times more private information removed with a new
column16: easier reporting process.\nTaking Action Without Reports\nPeople who don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t feel safe on Twitter shouldn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t be burdened to report abuse to us. Previously
column17: we only reviewed potentially abusive Tweets if they were reported to us. We know that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not acceptable
column18: so earlier this year we made it a priority to take a proactive approach to abuse in addition to relying on people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s reports.\nThis time last year
column19: 20% of potentially abusive content was flagged to our teams for review proactively. Today
column20: by using technology
column21: 38% of abusive content that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s enforced is surfaced proactively for human review instead of relying on reports from people using Twitter. This encompasses a number of policies
column22: such as abusive behavior
column23: hateful conduct
column24: encouraging self-harm
column25: and threats
column26: including those that may be violent.\nThe same technology we use to track spam
column27: platform manipulation and other rule violations is helping us flag abusive Tweets to our team for review. With our focus on reviewing this type of content
column28: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also expanded our teams in key areas and geographies so we can stay ahead and work quickly to keep people safe. Reports give us valuable context and a strong signal that we should review content
column29: but we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve needed to do more and though still early on
column30: this work is showing promise.\nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s to Come\nKeeping people safe on Twitter remains our top priority
column31: and we have more changes coming to help us work toward that goal. Here\u00e2\u0080\u0099s some of what to expect in the coming months:\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to improve our technology to help us review content that breaks our rules faster and before it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s reported
column32: specifically those who Tweet private information
column33: threats
column34: and other types of abuse.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll make it easier for people who use Twitter to share specifics when reporting so we can take action faster
column35: especially when it comes to protecting people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s physical safety.\nContext on Tweets and our enforcement is important in understanding our rules
column36: so we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll add more notices within Twitter for clarity
column37: such as if a Tweet breaks our rules but remains on the service because the content is in the public interest.\nWe are updating our rules in the next few weeks so they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re shorter
column38: simpler and easier to understand.\nStarting in June
column39: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be experimenting with ways to give people more control over their conversations by giving them an option to hide replies to their Tweets.\n We have more to do to ensure everyone feels safe on Twitter
column40:
and will keep sharing progress on @TwitterSafety.

column3: "title": "A Healthier Twitter: One Year In"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
A Healthier Twitter: One Year In
          
          
            and
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 15 April 2019\nLink copied successfully\nWe want people to feel safe on Twitter. Last year
column9: we shared that building a Twitter free of abuse
column10: spam and other things that distract from the public conversation is our top priority. Since then
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made strides in creating a healthier service. Today
column12:
weâre sharing an update on our progress and previewing changes you can expect to see in the next few months.
Here is a summary of progress weâve made with more detail below:
38% of abusive content thatâs enforced is surfaced proactively instead of relying on reports
16% less abuse reports after an interaction from an account the reporter doesnât follow
100
column13:
000 accounts suspended for creating new accounts after a suspension during January-March 2019 â a 45% increase from the same time last year
60% faster response to appeals requests with our new in-app appeal processÂ 
3 times more abusive accounts suspended that are reported to us within 24 hours compared to the same time last year
2.5 times more private information removed with a new
column14: easier reporting process\nTaking Action Without Reports People who don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t feel safe on Twitter shouldn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t be burdened to report abuse to us. By using technology
column15: 38% of abusive content that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s enforced is surfaced proactively instead of relying on reports. This encompasses a number of policies
column16: such as abusive behavior
column17: hateful conduct
column18: encouraging self-harm
column19: and threats
column20: including those that may be violent.\nThe same technology we use to track spam and other rule violations is helping us flag abusive Tweets to our team for review. With this focus on reviewing this type of content
column21: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also expanded our teams in key areas and geographies so we can stay ahead and work quickly to keep people safe. Reports give us valuable context and strong signal that we should review content
column22: but we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve needed to do more and this work is showing promise.\nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s to Come Keeping people safe on Twitter remains our top priority
column23: and we have more changes coming to help us keep working towards that goal. Here\u00e2\u0080\u0099s some of what to expect in the coming months:\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to make changes that will allow us to remove content that breaks our rules faster and before it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s reported
column24: specifically those who tweet private information
column25: threats and other types of abuse.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll make it easier to share specifics when reporting so we can take action faster
column26: especially when it comes to protecting peoples\u00e2\u0080\u0099 physical safety.\nContext on tweets and our enforcement is important in understanding our rules
column27: so we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll add more notices within Twitter for clarity
column28: such as if a Tweet breaks our rules but remains since the content is in the public interest.\u00c2\u00a0\nWe are updating our rules in the next few weeks so they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re shorter
column29: simpler and easier to understand.\u00c2\u00a0\nStarting in June
column30: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be experimenting with ways to give people more control over their conversation by giving them an option to hide replies to their Tweets.\nWe have more to do to ensure everyone feels safe on Twitter
column31:
and will keep sharing progress on @Twittersafety. Â

column7:
"post_text": "                    Partners

            Guest post: The 5-minute guide to mastering audiences on Twitter
          
Nick Taylor (@najttaylor)
Senior Product Marketing Manager
column8:
Brandwatch
Publication date: 4/10/19
    Website
    
    
    
    
  
    View profile
    
    
    
    
  
    @Twitter
    
    
    
    
  
Twitter users love the platform because itâs the best place to find people with common interests from all over the world. This makes it a great place to build and foster a community.
Twitter is also âwhatâs happeningâ. Itâs where people go to follow the latest stories and events.Â This makes it a great place to engage your audience when theyâre most receptive.
But as well as offering marketers a great platform on which to reach consumers
column9: Twitter has data that can inform marketing strategies on the platform itself and beyond.\nBecause Twitter data is detailed and public it is invaluable to our customers who need to build a better understanding of their consumers using tools like\u00c2\u00a0Brandwatch Audiences. Even those in industries that might not expect a lot of direct engagement there can use insights from Twitter to better reach their target audiences online and offline.\nBuilding a meaningful marketing persona is hard work. Focus groups and market research are expensive undertakings
column10: and often they take so long they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re out of date by the time anyone gets to look at them.\nTwitter data is a fantastic
column11: real-time source of public opinion on pretty much anything
column12: but there are millions of tweets sent every day. How do you know where to start looking?\nHere\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a simple five-minute guide for which audiences you should be identifying
column13: how to define them
column14: what you can discover from them
column15:
and what to do next.
Brandwatch Audiences
Brandwatch AudiencesÂ is an influencer and audience analytics platform that helps marketers identify and reach the right people.
Powered by the full fidelity Twitter API
column16: it allows users to study all the public tweets of any group of people in real-time.\nWhat makes Brandwatch Audiences especially useful for building meaningful personas and marketing strategies is that it can benchmark any insights against the whole of Twitter. This is critical when trying to cut through the noise to see not only what your target audience is talking about the most but also what they talk about more than anyone else.\nTo learn more about Brandwatch
column17:
check out theirÂ profile.
          Ready to get started?
        
    Contact

column3: "title": "Take the field with @MLB on Twitter in 2019"
column7: "post_text": "Events\nTake the field with @MLB on Twitter in 2019\nWednesday
column8: 27 March 2019\nLink copied successfully\nThe Major League Baseball season is around the corner and with engaging new content this year
column9: Twitter is the place where fans can come to view live video and near-real time highlights
column10: and join the MLB conversation.  Live on Twitter\nThis season @MLB will be giving fans a unique opportunity to vote for which players\u00e2\u0080\u0099 at-bats they want to watch live on Twitter \u00e2\u0080\u0093 every day.  Each morning
column11: @MLB will Tweet out a call for fans to choose which player will be the featured hitter that day. @MLB will then livestream every one of that player\u00e2\u0080\u0099s at-bats on Twitter for fans in the United States. This is scheduled to debut on Opening Day - Thursday
column12: March 28 - and continue throughout the regular season.  In addition
column13: @MLB will broadcast live shows on Twitter around key tentpole events on the Major League Baseball calendar
column14: including the London Series
column15: Home Run Derby
column16: All-Star Game from Cleveland
column17: trade deadline
column18: and the Postseason.  Highlights of every home run  For the first time this year
column19: @MLB will post highlights of each and every home run hit during the season on Twitter
column20: including capturing some of those in a specially-curated nightly video montage.  MLB also will once again make near real-time game video highlights available for fans moments after they happen on the field from @MLB on Twitter
column21: offering additional ways to follow all of the baseball action at home or on the go. Spanish-language highlights also will be available from @LasMayores
column22: MLB\u00e2\u0080\u0099s official Spanish-language account
column23: throughout 2019.  Team emoji\nTo help fans bring their baseball Tweets to life
column24:
special hashtag-triggered emojis for all 30 MLB teams will be back come Opening Day. Fans can join the conversation by Tweeting about their favorite MLB teams with a unique hashtag-triggered emoji all season long. Here are the team hashtags that will add color to your Tweets!

column3: "title": "Celebrating #EUMediaLiteracyWeek"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Celebrating #EUMediaLiteracyWeek
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 20 March 2019\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter has transformed the way information is reported on and engaged with around the world. It has contributed to the democratisation of access to news and events in innovative and dynamic ways. Every single person has the potential to tell the world what's happening in their village
column9: their town
column10: their city
column11: and their community. There are fewer barriers to full participation in the global conversation.\nWhile we firmly believe in the power of open
column12: public conversation
column13: the speed of the Internet presents unique challenges around media literacy and information quality. Building public capacities to analyse and discern what is and is not quality material is vital. As the European Commission says
column14: a high level of media literacy is a key factor to enable citizens to make informed decisions in the digital age.\nThis week marks the first ever #EUMediaLiteracyWeek
column15: a new initiative driven by the Commission to promote skills required to navigate an increasingly complex information environment. Twitter is pleased to play its part in supporting and celebrating this important event.\nWhat we're doing across the EU\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s open and real-time nature is a powerful antidote to the spreading of all types of false information. Journalists
column16: experts and engaged citizens tweet side-by-side correcting and challenging public discourse in seconds. However
column17: we do not rely on user interaction alone.\nAs part of our work improving the health of the public conversation
column18: we are focusing on product
column19: policy and enforcement innovations to address the behaviours which detract from that conversation. We\u00c2\u00a0have updated and expanded our Rules to better reflect how we identify fake accounts
column20: and continue to aggressively address malicious automation and other forms of platform manipulation. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also signed the EU Code of Conduct on Disinformation with industry partners
column21: and we are sponsoring and contributing to media literacy initiatives in many countries around the world
column22: including in Europe. Here are some examples:\nIreland (EMEA HQ)\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re supporting the #BeMediaSmart campaign run by the Media Literacy Network
column23: an initiative of the Broadcasting Authority of Ireland. This campaign plays on how conscious we are of where our food comes from and asks that we give the same consideration to the sources of media we consume. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be amplifying the reach of this campaign by supporting nonprofit partners with Ads for Good grants. Partners include the National Youth Council of Ireland
column24: the National Adult Literacy Agency
column25:
and Webwise. Check out some Twitter resources on the campaign website at bemediasmart.ie/resources
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We are continuing our engagement with young people. Last week
column26: we hosted secondary school students from across Dublin who participated in the School Digital Champions programme
column27: an initiative of the Department of Communications
column28: Climate Action
column29:
and Environment. WeÂ talkedÂ to them about digital citizenship and the increasing importance of media literacy skills.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
France
We are partnering with CLEMI (@LeCLEMI) - the Liaison Center for News Media and Education. We will be highlighting their studentsâ work from @TwitterFrance and
column30: later this month
column31: we will host 60 students in the Paris office to discuss the representation of women in sport by analysing Tweets from various sources. At the event
column32: we will be joined by a sports journalist
column33: a teacher
column34: and an Olympic basketball player.\nBrussels\nLast week
column35: we participated in an event for platforms to highlight media literacy initiatives
column36: as well as the implementation of the AVMSD and how it can have a positive impact on media literacy capacities.\nUK\nWe have awarded Ads for Good grants to some of our closest nonprofit partners. Shout Out UK runs political and media literacy programmes in schools and colleges and will amplify their Media Minded content with this Twitter campaign. Bite the Ballot will reach out to young people on the service and survey them on their civic literacy. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll also be running a Tea
column37: Toast and Tweeting session to support senior citizens in their use of Twitter.\nGlobal UNESCO partnership\nTwitter is delighted to have a fruitful partnership with UNESCO
column38: which includes media and information literacy. Later this year
column39: we will publish a co-branded educational resource
column40: Teaching and Learning with Twitter
column41: which includes expert guidance from UNESCO on media and information literacy best practices for educators of all kinds.\nIn the meantime
column42:
UNESCO publishes a great range of helpful information on media and information literacy on their MILClicks account. This includes: 13 points to help detect disinformation online; how misinformation can be spread through the use of âfalse expertsâ; why âdisinformationâ is preferable to âfake newsâ; the common traits of propaganda; and some helpful tips on phishing and monitoring your cookie trail.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
No single actor
column43: organisation or institution has the capacity to enhance media literacy skills across Europe. For our part
column44: we look forward to developing our collaborative partnership with UNESCO and other relevant partners
column45:
while continuing to raise awareness of media literacy and give prominence to credible information across our service.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter

column3: "title": "Our 2018 Inclusion and Diversity Report"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Our 2018 Inclusion and Diversity Report
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8:
14 March 2019
Link copied successfully
People around the world come to Twitter to share ideas and have conversations. Our company must reflect the people we serve â every community and all voices.
Last year
column9: we set two year diversity targets
column10: prioritizing the populations that have historically been underrepresented in tech and at Twitter: Women (globally)
column11: Black and Latinx (US).\nSo where are we today?\nWhen we say we want our company to reflect our service
column12: we've got a long way to go
column13:
but we've made solid progress towards our goals.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Â 
Increasing workforce representation is only part of the story. In order to move the needle on diversity
column14: we need to measure and understand our workforce holistically including hiring
column15: attrition and retention. \nNew hire results below are expressed as a percentage of total new hires in 2018. For example
column16:
45.7% of all new hires in 2018 were Women. Hereâs how weâre doing: 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Â 
On attrition
column17: these results are expressed as a percentage of total attrition in 2018. For example
column18:
39.6% of total attrition were Women.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Each member of the leadership team has new A.I.R. (attract
column19: retain
column20: include) plans tailored to their orgs against these targets. With overall Women and Black representation up 1.8 and 1.1 percentage points respectively in 2018
column21: and positive hiring and retention trends
column22: we believe we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re on track to achieve our 2019 targets for both of these demographics.\nWe have a lot of work to do with our overall Latinx representation
column23: with improvement in 2018 at just 0.5 of a percentage point. We need to retain the amazing Tweeps we have
column24: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll focus on attracting new people. We will work closely with Twitter Alas
column25: our Business Resource Group for Latinx employees and allies
column26: the People team and external partners to help us close this gap with urgency.\nBeyond these three demographics
column27:
we continue to actively track and support representation across our workforce. Here are the broader breakdowns.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Â 
Missing from this chart is sexual orientiation and gender identity because we had lower participation in our self-ID survey for this category. We believe a refresh of our self-identification efforts and a new anonymous survey will allow us to better understand and share a more accurate representation of our company moving forward. This will also put us in a position to report on representation for employees with disabilities and with military status.
Our Business Resource Groups (Blackbirds
column28: Twitter Alas
column29: Twitter Asians
column30: Twitter Open
column31: Twitter Stripes
column32: Twitter Women) are a critical force within the company. They tell our story through events and experiences
column33: support our recruitment strategy
column34: drive an inclusive culture
column35: and ensure diversity is front and center in everything we do. This year
column36: a new group is being formed to represent Tweeps with disabilities
column37:
as well as intersection groups to give Tweeps a safe space to discuss issues that matter to them.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
What comes next?
When sharing details of future plans
column38: we always want to get feedback and drive conversation. The below is a thread from Leslie Berland
column39: our Head of People and Chief Marketing Officer. It focuses on transparency
column40:
accountability and organizational changes that we believe will set us up for a more inclusive and diverse Twitter in 2019 and beyond.
Â

column3: "title": "Expanding transparency around political ads on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Expanding transparency around political ads on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 19 February 2019\nLink copied successfully\nWe continue to be committed to enforcing stricter policies for political advertisers and providing clear
column9: transparent disclosure for ads on Twitter. This is part of our overall goal to protect the health of the public conversation on our service and to provide meaningful context around all political entities who use our advertising products.  Last May
column10: we launched our Political Campaigning Policy in the United States to provide clear insight into how we define political content and who is advertising political content on Twitter. In conjunction
column11: we launched the Ads Transparency Center (ATC). The ATC allows anyone across the globe to view ads that have been served on Twitter
column12: with even more details on political campaigning ads
column13: including ad spend and targeting demographics.  Today
column14: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re expanding our political ads policy and transparency approach to include all European Union member states
column15: India
column16: and Australia.  When will enforcement begin? Enforcement of this policy will begin the week commencing March 11th in these countries
column17: after which only certified advertisers will be allowed to run political campaigning ads on our service. Political advertisers must apply now for certification and go through the every step of the process.  What\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next? Our teams will continue to build the operational and tooling support to expand our political advertising policies to other key markets throughout 2019. We strongly believe that meaningful transparency is the best path forward for all advertising products we offer
column18:
particularly those that are utilized in a political context.

column3: "title": "The world\u2019s window into the European election conversation"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nThe world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s window into the European election conversation\nTuesday
column8: 19 February 2019\nLink copied successfully\nThis May
column9: millions of citizens from across the European Union\u00e2\u0080\u0099s (EU) 27 Member States will have their say on the future political complexion of the European Parliament. The second largest democratic exercise of its kind in the world in 2019
column10: the European elections will have a major impact on the region\u00e2\u0080\u0099s geopolitical outlook and priorities for the next five years.  Twitter is committed to serving the public conversation around this major global event. As a real-time
column11: live service
column12: we seek to be the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s window into the critical conversations happening right across Twitter between candidates
column13: voters
column14: journalists
column15: political parties and groups
column16: civil society
column17: and electoral commissions. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re already working proactively to support and protect these conversations
column18: and today we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re detailing some of the additional steps we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re taking ahead of #EUElections2019.  Expanding our political campaigning ads policy across all Member States Our political campaigning ads policy is being expanded to cover #EUElections2019
column19: providing the general public with an additional layer of insight into who is running a political campaign ad on Twitter. The policy
column20: which is also being expanded into India and Australia today
column21: means that an ad endorsing a party or a candidate will be viewable in our Ads Transparency Center
column22: where you will be able to see details such as billing information
column23: ad spend
column24: and impressions data per Tweet. Additionally
column25: we will be showing demographic targeting data for the ads being served. The ads will exist indefinitely within the Transparency Center
column26: where they are viewable by anyone in the world
column27:
regardless of whether or not they own a Twitter account.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In addition to the information being shared within the Ads Transparency Center itself
column28:
we are making it clearer who is advertising European political campaign content on Twitter by including a visual label and disclaimer information on promoted content from certified accounts. This will allow users to easily identify political campaign ads and to know who paid for them. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
To qualify for the policy
column29: candidates
column30: organisations
column31: and individuals seeking to advertise political campaigning content must now undergo a thorough certification process. Once proof of identity is verified
column32: and advertisers meet our eligibility requirements
column33: a letter with an access code will be posted to their address to confirm they are located within the EU. This will ensure that only EU-based individuals can advertise political campaign content on the service.  Enforcement of this policy will begin on 11 March
column34: after which only certified advertisers will be allowed to run political campaigning ads on our service. Political advertisers must apply now for certification and go through every step of the process. Guidelines for political advertisers can be found here.  We will expand this policy to country-level elections in the future
column35: as our teams continue to develop their operational and tooling support.  Cross-functional European elections team In addition to increased transparency around political ads
column36: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also formed a high-level internal elections group to lead our electoral integrity work in the region from now until polling day. Using our proprietary-built internal tools
column37: the team will proactively protect the integrity of regional trends
column38: support partner escalations
column39: and identify potential threats from malicious actors.  Cross-functional by design
column40: the team consists of several of the company\u00e2\u0080\u0099s top trust and safety experts
column41: as well as members of our site integrity
column42: legal
column43: engineering
column44: data science investigations
column45: and our public policy teams in Europe. This blend of perspectives
column46: expertise and backgrounds is absolutely critical.  It also mirrors the model we put in place for the internal teams who directed our proactive efforts during recent elections in Germany
column47: Sweden
column48: Mexico
column49: the US
column50: and Brazil. As we move forward
column51: we will continue with this model of bringing in additional expertise and personnel who can augment our approach
column52: growing the experience level from one critical election to the next.  Promoting media literacy and healthy campaigning on Twitter In the coming weeks and months
column53: our public policy team across Europe will ramp up their engagement with political parties and the EU\u00e2\u0080\u0099s local Member State offices to arrange Twitter trainings
column54: distribute media literacy resources
column55: and to promote healthy
column56: constructive participation in the democratic process.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to identify candidates for verification
column57: amplify campaigns that encourage voter participation and launch a special election emoji to encourage engagement and conversation. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll provide updates on this work when we have more information.\nFurther recent election integrity efforts by Twitter include:\nSigning up to the EU Code of Conduct on Disinformation
column58: and forming a global partnership with @UNESCO to promote better media literacy among citizens.\nIntroducing new policies on fake accounts and hacked materials
column59: and updating our spam reporting flow to enable the public to provide more granular information when reporting to us.\nDonating to the @DisinfoEU
column60: @AtlanticCouncil and @NDI
column61: all of which are doing meaningful work on #EUElections2019.\nEmpowering independent research of foreign influence campaigns\u00c2\u00a0in places like Russia
column62: Iran
column63: and Venezuela to develop a shared understanding of these threats and tactics.\nAs the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s window into the public conversation around #EUElections2019
column64:
Twitter is prepared to play its part in enhancing access to healthy democratic discourse.

column3: "title": "Working together for a safer Internet"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Working together for a safer Internet
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 5 February 2019\nLink copied successfully\nThe first Safer Internet Day took place in 2004
column9: a full two years before the first Tweet was sent. And just as Twitter has become a global platform
column10:
Safer Internet Day has grown from being a European event to one thatâs celebrated in over 140 countries. Today we join withÂ safety partnersÂ across the world to mark #SaferInternetDay2019 and to encourage conversations around a better internet. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The theme of this yearâs Safer Internet Day â âTogether for a better internetâ â reflects a set of beliefs we share: that the internet can always be better
column11: that it remains a force for good
column12: and that it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s all of our jobs to make it safe and healthy. \nThe safety of Twitter has been our highest priority for over two years. In the last year
column13: we have made more than 70 policy
column14: product
column15: and process updates to build a healthier Twitter. We also took a number of steps to help people see high-quality information
column16: strengthening our sign-up processes
column17: account verification and the ways our data can be accessed. Some of these changes included:\nTackling issues of behaviors that detract from the public conversation on Twitter and introducing new signals
column18: which has led to fewer abuse reports.\nIntroducing new policies to address fake accounts
column19: attributed activity and the distribution of hacked material.\nGathering public feedback as we developed new policies. \nExpanding our team and focusing more resources on our health work
column20: including the acquisition of Smyte.\nRolling out new notices so it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s easier to see when a Tweet was removed for breaking our rules. \nMaking Twitter safer is a job that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s never complete. Nor is it a job we can do alone. On Safer Internet Day
column21: we support our global network of safety partners by amplifying their campaigns
column22: awarding Ads for Good grants
column23: and hosting them in our offices for frank and robust conversations. To serve that conversation on the platform
column24: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve launched a special emoji for the hashtags #SaferInternetDay and #SID2019
column25:
available in twelve languages to encourage conversations around a safer internet.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As we look to 2019
column26: we know that there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a lot of work to do. While we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made progress and learned a lot
column27: the job isn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t done. We are committed to improving the quality of information you see on Twitter
column28: and to ensuring that content does not lead to offline harm. We will continue to make it more difficult for bad actors to create spammy or fake accounts that manipulate our platform. And we want to do all of this as transparently as possible. We won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t stop working to build a healthier Twitter
column29:
so people feel safe and are able to find high-quality information on our service.
Â

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "2018 US midterm elections review"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
2018 US midterm elections review
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 31 January 2019\nLink copied successfully\nToday
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sharing a comprehensive review of our efforts to protect the integrity of the public conversation on Twitter regarding the 2018 US midterm elections.  The public conversation occuring on Twitter is never more important than during elections. Our service shows the world what is happening
column10: democratizes access to information and \u00e2\u0080\u0094 at its best \u00e2\u0080\u0094 provides people around the globe with insights into a diversity of perspectives on critical election issues. Any attempts to undermine the integrity of our service erode the core tenets of freedom of expression online
column11: the value upon which our company is based. This issue affects all of us and is one that we care deeply about as individuals
column12: both inside and outside the company.  What we learned  Partnerships matter As the internet evolves
column13: so too do the challenges and opportunities society faces. Collaborative partnerships with peer companies
column14: federal agencies
column15: law enforcement
column16: state governments
column17: and civil society organizations make us better. Our greatest partner in making the service healthier continues to be the public who challenge us
column18: hold us accountable
column19: and bring potentially problematic content to our attention.  Threats change Although we identified voter suppressive content of primarily domestic origin on Election Day
column20: we cannot assume that this will be the dominant threat going forward. Elections are coming up around the world
column21: and our goal is to protect their integrity to the best of our ability and to take the learnings from each with us. Our role
column22: as ever
column23: is to do our best to stay one step ahead while remaining humble in the face of potential new challenges.\nCross-functional is key The teams that work on these issues at Twitter are truly cross-functional by design. This blend of perspectives and backgrounds is absolutely critical. We all care deeply about elections and work passionately to protect the service. From engineering to data science to legal
column24: these enforcements and disclosures touch upon many core areas of our company. As we move forward
column25: we will continue with this model of bringing in additional expertise and personnel who can augment our approach
column26: growing the level of experience from one critical election to the next.  What we saw in 2018  Major voter registration drive The 2018 US midterm elections were the most Tweeted-about midterm election in history. More than 99 million Tweets were sent from the first primaries in March through Election Day. The overwhelming majority of the Tweets relating to the midterms were individuals expressing their views on issues and candidates they care about
column27: and encouraging others to vote. Americans Tweeted to encourage neighbors
column28: friends
column29: family
column30: and complete strangers to register to vote. In addition to the strong discussion we hosted on Twitter
column31: we also collaborated with a number of non-governmental organizations to promote voter registration
column32: civic engagement
column33: and media literacy
column34: including RockTheVote
column35: Democracy Works
column36: TurboVote Challenge
column37: HeadCount
column38: DoSomething
column39: and Ballotpedia.  Domestic attempts at voter suppression In order to protect this positive conversation
column40: we took several proactive measures to remove malicious content posted by bad-faith actors
column41: like building new policies
column42: having a dedicated partner escalation path
column43: and training our teams on how to be most effective in the face of new threats. In this context
column44: we removed content that attempted to influence an election by deterring groups of eligible voters
column45: particularly through voter intimidation or providing false information about voting or registering to vote. The number of problematic examples was relatively small. We took action on nearly 6
column46: 000 Tweets we identified as attempted voter suppression
column47: much of which originated here in the United States. As we prepare for elections worldwide
column48: we remain vigilant and continue to build external partnerships
column49: while focusing internally on effectively deploying our resources to protect election-related conversations.  Foreign information operations In contrast to 2016
column50: we identified much less platform manipulation from bad-faith actors located abroad. That said
column51: as part of our ongoing review we found limited operations that have the potential to be connected to sources within Iran
column52: Venezuela
column53: and Russia. The majority of these accounts were proactively suspended in advance of Election Day due to the increasingly robust nature of our technology and internal tooling for identifying platform manipulation. As ever
column54: attribution is difficult and takes time and significant resourcing to properly investigate. These datasets are analyzed in the full retrospective review and we have added them all to our archive to empower further research by experts in the field.  Our commitment continues The core mission of Twitter is to serve the public conversation. It is why we exist. We must promote and maintain the health of that conversation. The people who use our service must have confidence in the integrity of the information found on the platform
column55: especially with respect to information relevant to elections and the democratic process. We continue our efforts to address the threats posed by hostile domestic and foreign actors
column56: and work to foster an environment conducive to healthy
column57:
meaningful conversations on our service.  The full 2018 US midterm elections report can viewed and downloaded below.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Empowering further research of potential information operations"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Empowering further research of potential information operations
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 31 January 2019\nLink copied successfully\nIn October last year
column9: we launched the first archive of all potential foreign information operations we have seen on Twitter. It is our fundamental belief that these accounts should be made public and searchable so members of the public
column10: governments
column11: and researchers can investigate
column12: learn
column13: and build media literacy capacities for the future.  So far
column14: this archive of accounts and content has been accessed by thousands of researchers
column15: governments
column16: and people interested in learning more about foreign information operations. We have already seen valuable reporting and research produced on the basis of these datasets
column17: including by major universities and think tanks in the United States and around the world.  Today
column18: we are adding to this archive five new account sets we found based on continued contextual and semantic analysis from our investigations teams
column19: one of the core components in our effort to protect the integrity of our service.  Bangladesh As noted last December
column20:
working with our industry peers we identified and suspended a very small number of accounts originating from Bangladesh for engaging in coordinated platform manipulation. The Tweets were entirely in Bengali and focused on regional political themes. All of these accounts and content are now part of the archive and can be investigated and reviewed by interested parties.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Iran In August 2018
column21: we were notified by an industry peer about possible malicious activity on their service about an attempted influence campaign we identified as potentially located within Iran. After receiving information from them
column22: we began an investigation on our service to build our understanding of these networks. As soon as we discovered malicious activity
column23:
we immediately notified law enforcement and updated the public.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Since that time
column24: through ongoing data science analysis
column25: we have identified and suspended 2
column26: 617 additional malicious accounts that we believe may have origins in Iran. Twitter has been in close contact with our industry peers on this matter and shared detailed information with them about the malicious accounts. This multilateral process of information-sharing will continue
column27: enabling us and our industry peers to work together to better understand and identify malicious activity.  Russia In September 2018
column28: Jack Dorsey testified on Capitol Hill on recent activities affiliated with the Russian Internet Research Agency (IRA)
column29: disclosing that Twitter had suspended a total of 3
column30: 841 accounts. Through ongoing analyses and investigations
column31: we continue to build on our contextual understanding of these networks of accounts to improve our ability to find and suspend this activity as quickly as possible in the future. This is particularly vital as groups such as the IRA evolve their practices in response to industry-wide suspension efforts.  Our ongoing efforts have uncovered an additional 418 accounts. We cannot render definitive attribution to the IRA for these accounts
column32: although most appear to originate in Russia
column33: and much of the behavior mimics the activity of prior accounts tied to the IRA. We encourage researchers and other experts to study them and to contribute to general public awareness of these activities online.  Venezuela Twitter has removed 764 accounts located in Venezuela. We are unable to definitively tie the accounts located in Venezuela to information operations of a foreign government against another country. However
column34: these accounts are another example of a foreign campaign of spammy content focused on divisive political themes
column35: and the behavior we uncovered is similar to that utilized by potential Russian IRA accounts. We are disclosing them out of an abundance of caution and welcome the feedback of researchers.  Additionally
column36: we have removed 1
column37: 196 accounts located in Venezuela which appear to be engaged in a state-backed influence campaign targeting domestic audiences. We have shared information on these accounts with our industry peers
column38: and continue to investigate malicious activity originating in Venezuela
column39: both targeting audiences with in Venezuela and abroad.  What\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next? As we have said
column40: these issues are not new. Manipulation of information for national or geopolitical ends is part of human history and transcends ideological viewpoints. The medium of communication is what has changed. The behavior is against our values as a company. For our part
column41: we are learning
column42: evolving
column43: and building a technological and personnel-driven approach to combating it. We hope that holistic
column44:
transparent disclosures such as this can help us all learn and build the necessary societal defenses and capacities to protect public conversation.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Partnering with researchers at UC Berkeley to improve the use of ML"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Partnering with researchers at UC Berkeley to improve the use of ML
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 29 January 2019\nLink copied successfully\nAt Twitter
column9: our purpose is to serve public conversation around the world. With world leaders
column10: journalists
column11: celebrities on the platform
column12: we serve conversations that are influential and leave a lasting impact on society. It is important to us to help increase the collective health
column13: openness
column14: and civility of public conversation.\nMachine Learning plays a key role in powering Twitter. From onboarding users on the platform to preparing their timeline and everything in between
column15: a multitude of ML models help power the experience. Thus
column16: making Twitter more healthy requires making the way we practice ML more fair
column17:
accountable and transparent.
Studying the societal impact of machine learning is a growing area of research in which Twitter has been participating. We are a proud sponsor of the ACM FAT* 2019 conference. But we feel that this is just a start and and there is a lot more work ahead of us from both a research and a practical standpoint. We owe it to our users and society at large to improve in this area.
Today we are proud to share a significant step in this direction -- we are partnering with researchers at UC Berkeley to establish a new research initiative focused on studying and improving the performance of ML in social systems (such as Twitter). The initiative will be lead by Professor Moritz Hardt and Professor Ben Recht.
The team at UC Berkeley will closely collaborate with a corresponding team inside Twitter. As a company
column18: Twitter is able to bring data and real-world insights to the table
column19: but by partnering with UC Berkeley we can create a research program that has the right mix of fundamental and applied research components to make a real practical impact across industry.\nToday
column20: the consequences of exposing algorithmic decisions and machine learning models to hundreds of millions of people are poorly understood. Even less is known about how these algorithms might interact with social dynamics: people might change their behaviour in response to what the algorithms recommend to them
column21: and as a result of this shift in behaviour the algorithm itself might change
column22: creating a potentially self-reinforcing feedback loop. We also know that individuals or groups will seek to game or exploit our algorithms and safeguarding against this is essential.\nBy bringing together the academic expertise of UC Berkeley with our industry perspective
column23:
we are looking to do fundamental work in this nascent space and apply it to improve Twitter.
Â
