column3: "title": "Guest post: Why we must remember the Holocaust"
column7: "post_text": "Events\nGuest post: Why we must remember the Holocaust\nThursday
column8: 24 January 2019\nLink copied successfully\nWith each passing year
column9: the number of Holocaust survivors left to tell their story diminishes. It is likely that within 25 years
column10: none will remain. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s up to us all to preserve their memory; to ensure that the horrors of the past will never be repeated.  In 2017
column11: we initiated the first ever global #WeRemember campaign for International Holocaust Remembrance Day. It asks people around the world to complete an easy
column12: yet meaningful
column13: task. Write the words \u00e2\u0080\u009cWe Remember\u00e2\u0080\u009d on a sheet of paper; take a picture of yourself holding the sign; and post it to social media with the hashtag #WeRemember. We hoped that \u00e2\u0080\u0093 even if just for just a moment \u00e2\u0080\u0093 this would encourage people stop and reflect.\nOur initial goal was to reach a symbolic 16 million people \u00e2\u0080\u0093 the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Jewish population before the Holocaust. But
column14: to our surprise
column15: over the past two years
column16: we have touched nearly 1 billion people in more than 100 countries. Using social media
column17: we have fostered a community of people who have a common goal: stand up to hate.\nSocial media platforms like Twitter have succeeded in bringing the world together in ways previous generations could never have imagined. Advances in technology have fundamentally altered the way that we consume information. Moreover
column18: the Internet has lent a voice to those who were once voiceless. Having been born in the former Soviet Union
column19: it astonishes me that the average citizen can now respond to a Tweet from his or her country\u00e2\u0080\u0099s leader knowing that there is a real chance it will be seen.\nThe Internet is vast
column20: and while it has connected the world and enhances our lives in so many ways
column21: it has also exposed some dark realities. White supremacists and antisemites are now afforded access to the same platforms as the influencers that billions of young people look to for the latest in fashion and pop culture trends.\nAlthough these are serious online threats
column22: they pale in comparison to the threats that Jewish communities around the world face to their physical security from ideological extremists. In the past few years alone
column23: there have been violent attacks against Jews in France
column24: Bulgaria
column25: Belgium
column26: Denmark
column27: and the United States
column28: to name just a few. The recent attack at the Tree of Life Synagogue in Pittsburgh
column29: which claimed the lives of 11 people
column30: is just the latest example of how radicalism and ignorance can have a tragic impact.\nMuch of this rise in antisemitism can be attributed to a decline in or complete lack of Holocaust education in schools. We must find new ways to reach young people so they will be able to learn the lessons of history\u00e2\u0080\u0099s greatest tragedy. Educational seminars and remembrance events are no longer enough. Shockingly
column31: nearly a third of all Americans and more than 4-in-10 Millennials believe that substantially less than 6 million Jews were killed (two million or fewer) during the Holocaust. Even more troubling
column32: there were more than 40
column33:
000 concentration camps and ghettos during the Holocaust and almost half of Americans (45 percent) cannot name a single one. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Through our #WeRemember campaign and www.AboutHolocaust.org
column34: created in partnership with UNESCO
column35: we are taking steps toward filling the glaring hole in Holocaust education around the world.\nA key component of the campaign is the sharing of personal stories of Holocaust survivors. Today
column36: thanks to Twitter
column37: we will be holding an event @TwitterNYC to commemorate Holocaust Remembrance Day. We will hear from Toby Levy
column38: a courageous woman who survived the Holocaust in hiding thanks to the kindness of an average citizen who stood up to the Nazis\u00e2\u0080\u0099 hate. We are committed to ensuring that lessons of Toby\u00e2\u0080\u0099s story are not lost to history.\nTwitter Director of Policy & Philanthropy in the US and Canada Carlos Monje highlighted Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s commitment to commemorating this important partnership
column39: \u00e2\u0080\u009cPartnering with World Jewish Congress on the #WeRemember campaign helps us to underscore the power of Twitter in sharing the lessons of the Holocaust to fight xenophobia
column40: genocide
column41:
and all forms of discrimination. We have an important role to amplify counternarratives to hate.â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The World Jewish Congress believes it is up to social media users around the globe to set the tone. As a society
column42: we emphasize that there must be a zero-tolerance policy against hate speech. Like the countries we live in
column43: the Internet is a democracy. If we speak out together
column44:
we canât be ignored. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Evolving our Twitter Transparency Report: expanded data and insights"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nEvolving our Twitter Transparency Report: expanded data and insights\nWednesday
column8:
12 December 2018
Link copied successfully
Twitterâs 13th biannual Transparency Report represents our ongoing commitment to increasing the availability of critical information and data on how we handle legal requests and other content issues.
While originally focused on requests submitted to Twitter by government actors
column9: like court orders for information or content removal
column10: over the years we have been working to expand the report to also include more detail about the actions we take when enforcing the Twitter Rules.\nIn this latest report
column11: we have continued this evolution and are now including details about the enforcement of a number of key content policies. We have also added a new section covering platform manipulation
column12:
which you can read more about below and in the report itself.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Internet freedom and online expression
Internet freedom and online expression remain under significant pressure and constraint
column13: a trend we have observed across recent reports. The latest Twitter Transparency Report shows that Twitter received approximately 80% more global legal demands
column14: impacting more than twice as many accounts compared to the previous reporting period. Similar to the last reporting period
column15: roughly 87% of the total global volume originated from only two countries: Russia and Turkey.\nTwitter also received 10% more government information requests (combined emergency disclosure requests and non-emergency requests)
column16: which is the largest percentage increase since our July-December 2015 report.\nThe new Twitter Rules enforcement\nThe new Twitter Rules enforcement section within the Transparency Report is a significant milestone on our transparency journey. It provides data and insights into the following areas of our enforcement approach: abuse
column17: hateful conduct
column18: private information
column19: child sexual exploitation
column20: sensitive media
column21: and violent threats.\nThese categories represent some of the most common reports that Twitter receives
column22: and our intention is to include more categories in future reports.\nThis data does not take into account content that has been actioned using technological tools
column23: the goal of which is to limit the reach and spread of potentially abusive content. In addition
column24: not every report we receive is actionable. For example
column25: we receive a large volume of false reports that bad actors have submitted in a coordinated effort to detract from our enforcement capabilities. Furthermore
column26: many of the reports that did not fall into these core categories were actioned under other policies
column27: such as impersonation
column28: unlawful use
column29: evasion of suspension
column30: etc.\nWith each successive report
column31: we are committed to evolving our approach to make it more comprehensive.\nProviding actionable data and insights takes time to aggregate and to make clear for the widest possible audience \u00e2\u0080\u0094 our goal with every report. As such
column32: we are continuously working to ensure the material we provide is clear
column33: contextual
column34: and meaningful. We strive to improve how we accurately measure and report
column35:
and we look forward to expanding our transparency in this area as we work to improve the health of the public conversation.
Platform manipulation
This also marks the first Twitter Transparency Report in which we are publishing metrics pertaining to our actions to fight spam and other malicious forms of automation. This builds on our recent work to disclose a full database of previously removed content and accounts that had potential links to state-backed information operations.
As we discussed in our June 2018 blog post
column36: we are making strong progress in this area. We challenge millions of potentially spammy accounts every month
column37: requesting additional details
column38: like email address and phone numbers to authenticate them. From January to June
column40: approximately 75% of accounts challenged ultimately did not pass those challenges and were suspended.\nAt the same time
column41: the average number of reports we received through our reporting flow continued to drop \u00e2\u0080\u0094 from an average of approximately 868
column42: 349 in January to approximately 504
column43: 259 in June. These report decreases indicate the effectiveness of our proprietary built technology in proactively identifying and challenging accounts at source and at scale. We have also built a new and refined reporting flow so account holders can give us more signals to augment our proactive enforcement strategies.\nEfforts to eradicate child sexual exploitation\nTwitter does not tolerate any material that features or promotes child sexual exploitation \u00e2\u0080\u0094 whether in Direct Message or elsewhere throughout the service. This includes media
column44: text
column45: illustrations
column46: or computer-generated images. When we remove content
column47: we immediately report it to the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children (NCMEC). NCMEC makes reports available to the appropriate law enforcement agencies around the world to facilitate investigations and prosecutions.\nIn the reporting period of January 1
column49: to June 30
column51: we suspended a total of 487
column52: 363 accounts for violations related to child sexual exploitation. 97% of those accounts were proactively flagged by a combination of technology
column53: including PhotoDNA
column54: and other purpose-built internal proprietary tools.\nWe will continue to aggressively fight online child sexual abuse
column55: as well as invest in the technology and tools that are essential to our zero tolerance enforcement policy. We continue to welcome partnerships around the world with law enforcement to continue our rigorous and significantly scaled operations on these types of egregious content.\nRemoving terrorist content\nWe continue our efforts to eradicate content from our platform that violates the Twitter rule prohibiting the promotion of terrorism. We suspended a total of 205
column56: 156 accounts under this policy in the period of January 1
column58: through June 30
column59: 2018. Of those suspensions
column60: 91% consisted of accounts that were proactively flagged by internal
column61: proprietary tools. Continuing the trend we have seen for some time
column62: the number of reports we received from governments of terrorist content decreased by 77% compared to the previous reporting period. Government reports now constitute less than 0.1% of all suspensions in the reported time period as a result of the scale of our technological approach.\nThe full Twitter Transparency Report with updated details and data covering January through June 2018 can be found here. As part of our longstanding commitment to #transparency
column63: we will continue to evolve and expand this report
column64:
and we look forward to sharing these updates in the future.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet
Twitter logo icon
Tags:
government
policy
transparency

column3: "title": "#TwitterForGood Day
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/events/2018/tfgdayfall2018"
column8: "post_text": "Events\n#TwitterForGood Day
column9:
Fall 2018
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column10: 12 December 2018\nLink copied successfully\nEarlier this fall
column11: Twitter employees around the world participated in #TwitterForGood Day \u00e2\u0080\u0094 our biannual day of service where employees step away from their day-to-day jobs to partner with community-based organizations
column12: working to improve the neighborhoods where we live and work.\nTwitter employees have always given back. While we support programs throughout the year

column3: "title": "Defining what makes Twitter\u2019s audience unique"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Defining what makes Twitterâs audience unique
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 8 November 2018\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter is \u00e2\u0080\u0098what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening.\u00e2\u0080\u0099 It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s the place where people go to see and participate in the conversation about nearly everything that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s going on in the world. This behavior has prompted us to look deeply at the Twitter audience -- to understand what are the unique
column9:
defining characteristics of this audience given their on-platform behavior.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
So we conducted a holistic
column10: multicountry study in 2017 to unify what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve come to know about Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s audience from various studies over the\u00c2\u00a0years.\u00c2\u00b9 \nThe results were fascinating
column11: as they were largely consistent across the globe: Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s audience operates in a receptive mindset when using the platform
column12: and the audience is also highly influential across a vast array of topic categories.\nHowever
column13: this blog post will largely focus on the findings from the US portion of the study.\n1. An audience at its most receptive on Twitter\nConsumer attention is perhaps one of the most scarce resources facing advertisers today. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s no longer sufficient to simply try and reach the right audience; that audience must also be receptive for ads to be effective. For example
column15: we conducted research to understand what Twitter and other platforms uniquely offer their users in the UK.\u00c2\u00b2 Unsurprisingly
column16:
we found that Twitter uniquely provides its users the opportunity to discover whatâs happening in the world. That functional purpose translates into Twitter users operating in a different mindset when theyâre on the platform compared to other online environments.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In particular
column17: the act of discovery
column18: the predominant way in which the audience uses the platform
column19: puts them in a receptive mindset
column20: meaning that information is stored in their long-term memory more effectively. This is particularly important for advertisers
column21:
as academic literature shows that long-term memory encoding relates closely to purchase intent.
Our most recent audience study delved into discovery and found that Twitter users are natural explorers. Compared to the general online population:
They are more likely to discover new things (82% vs. 71% for the online pop.)
They are more open-minded (81% vs. 74%)
They also like to be the firstÂ to try new things (59% vs. 41%).
2. Twitterâs audience is valuable for its influence
Twitter users are hugely influential. A previously Twitter-commissioned study in the UKÂ³ interviewed friends of Twitter users (without them knowing why their friend had been selected for the research). We found that 3 in 4 of them said that a Twitter user is the first person they look to for advice when they want to learn more about a topic
column22: and 9 in 10 of them said they had changed their opinion on a purchase based on advice from their Twitter-using friend. Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s audience is influential far beyond Twitter
column23: which is of great value to brands.\nIn this study
column24: we went one step further. We wanted to understand how universal the Twitter audience influence was
column25: beyond what we observed in the UK. More specifically
column26: we wanted to find out whether Twitter users were influential
column27: regardless of geography
column28: age
column29: gender
column30:
or topic.
What we found was that Twitter users in the US (and across the globe) are also influential across the vast majority of demographics and topic category.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Furthermore
column31: we found that Twitter users love to share content they see on Twitter
column32:
on and off the service. In fact:
 
78% of US Twitter users like to give their opinion about things theyâre knowledgeable about or interested in (vs 66% US online population)
55% of US Twitter users share things theyâve seen on Twitter with others offline (by showing them their phone screens)
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
3. Twitterâs users and brands
When it comes to brands
column33: Twitter users are demanding consumers
column34: who want quality and responsiveness
column35: and they strongly reward brands that make the effort.\nThe study found that Twitter users are willing to pay more for quality products (66% vs. 58% for online pop.) and to save time (54% vs. 42% for online pop.).\nThey are also more brand conscious
column36:
choosing brands that fit the best with their values.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
4. So what does this all mean?
This study demonstrates how the Twitter audience is curious
column37: leaned in and ultimately receptive. Combined with their influence
column38: proclivity to share what they know
column39: and loyalty to brands offering quality products in a way that align with their values
column40:
they are the perfect catalyst for any marketers campaign messaging.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Footnotes: Â¹Methodology: Research done in partnership with Kantar Media. Fieldwork done in December 2017. 1503 USA Internet users
column41: 787 Twitter USA users \u00c2\u00b2Tapestry & Twitter
column42: UK
column43: 2016 \u00c2\u00b3Starcom & Twitter
column44:
2016

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Five days until #ElectionDay 2018"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Five days until #ElectionDay 2018
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 1 November 2018\nLink copied successfully\nWith five days left until Election Day in the US
column9: we want to share an update on our efforts to ensure that Twitter provides a healthy space for public conversation that voters can rely on for accurate election news and information.\nThis has already been the most Tweeted-about US midterm election ever. Since October 1
column10: people have sent more than 10 million Tweets about voting and early voting (15
column11: 000 US users even have \u00e2\u0080\u0098vote\u00e2\u0080\u0099 in their display name!)\nOver the last several months
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve taken significant steps to safeguard the integrity of conversations surrounding the US elections by reducing the spread of disinformation
column13: strengthening outreach to government stakeholders
column14: and streamlining our enforcement processes.\u00c2\u00a0We are committed to serving the public conversation about elections on our platform. Examples of this include our ongoing health initiatives
column15: political party and state election official education and dedicated reporting routes
column16: and empowering further research of our information operations.\nWe launched our #BeAVoter campaign in September to promote increased
column17: informed participation in the 2018 US midterms. To date
column18: Twitter has added nearly 1
column19: 000 election labels to candidates\u00e2\u0080\u0099 profiles and partnered with local television stations across the country to livestream 32 House
column20: Senate and gubernatorial debates on Twitter. In comparison to 2016
column21: the number of people who Tweeted about #NationalVoterRegistrationDay has also doubled.\nStarting today
column22: Twitter is launching a wave of new #BeAVoter campaign initiatives to build on those efforts and encourage eligible voters to participate in next week\u00e2\u0080\u0099s elections.\nPeople on Twitter in the US will see an Election Day countdown in their home timeline with information on how to find their polling place and who is on their ballot via GetToThePolls.com
column23:
an initiative of the Voting Information Project (VIP).
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We are also launching a #BeAVoter video campaign with influential young voices on Twitter to leverage their reach and encourage young people to educate themselves about which candidates will appear on their ballot
column24:
as well as show up to the polls on Election Day.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Additionally
column25: Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s official election hashtags and emojis are now live: #Midterms2018
column26: #BeAVoter
column27: #iVoted
column28: #yoVot\u00c3\u00a9
column29:
and #ElectionDay.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We want every eligible person to #BeAVoter in this election
column30: and believe these initiatives will provide a safe
column31:
healthy platform for everyone to join the #ElectionDay conversation on November 6.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Improving health during Global Media and Information Literacy Week 2018"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Improving health during Global Media and Information Literacy Week 2018
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 24 October 2018\nLink copied successfully\nOur singular goal as a company is to serve
column9: protect
column10: and enhance the health of the public conversation. \nWe believe we have a responsibility to deliver a place where freedom of expression is valued
column11: where individual voices can speak truth to power
column12: and where millions of people from across the world come together to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening.\u00c2\u00a0\nThe open Internet connects us
column13: educates us
column14: and entertains us. But its primary strength is the manner in which it has democratised information for citizens
column15: affording them opportunities to be part of real-time conversations around major global and domestic events.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s true that the increasing frequency
column16: speed
column17: and velocity of online information being presented to users is a remarkable technological advance
column18:
but at times it can be difficult to separate the signal from the noise.
Building media literacy skills
We believe citizens should be empowered to develop the skills that help them critically analyse material for credibility and to ask the right questions of the information they are engaging with and sharing online.
For our part
column19: we have already taken steps to help empower citizens become more media literate.\nThere\u00e2\u0080\u0099s our dedicated educational resource
column20: the Educator\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Guide to Twitter
column21: which raises awareness of media and information literacy among parents
column22: educators
column23: and academics.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also supported the efforts of many non-profits across the world who work to promote media and information literacy.\nMore recently
column24: we reinforced our commitment to enhancing media literacy levels of people who use our platform when we signed up to the EU\u00e2\u0080\u0099s new Code of Conduct on Disinformation
column25: along with various online platforms
column26: social media networks
column27:
advertisers and the advertising industry.
The Code encourages signatories to enhance media literacy levels to better help Europeans identify online disinformation and approach online content with a critical eye.
The Commission will in turn encourage fact-checkers and civil society organisations to provide educational material to schools and educators and organise a European Week of Media Literacy.
Global Media and Information Literacy Week 2018
As part of our ongoing efforts
column28: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also very proud to partner with UNESCO to promote Global Media and Information Literacy Week 2018
column29: which begins today and runs until October 31.\nTwitter has a long-standing
column30: fruitful relationship with UNESCO
column31: and this year
column32: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re particularly excited by their focus on developing a network of Media and Information Literate Cities.\nTheir vision is to nurture cities which help their citizens improve quality of life by making the most of media
column33: information and digital tools available to them.\nMr Moez Chakchouk
column34: UNESCO\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Assistant Director-General for Communication and Information
column35:
said: "UNESCO is pleased to be partnering with Twitter to promote media and information literacy (MIL) among people in cities and communities around the world.
"Media and Information Literacy is key to empowering citizens with the critical thinking essential to building sustainable and smart cities. Social media platforms like Twitter have the potential to facilitate debate and foster inclusive knowledge societies."
Some of Twitterâs activities as part of the Global MIL Week 2018 include:
Launching a new hashtag #ThinkBeforeSharing with an accompanying emoji as part of a global call to action which encourages people to pause and to be mindful of the content they choose to share online
Publishing a co-branded educational resource entitled Teaching and Learning with Twitter
column36: an easy-to-read manual for educators of all stripes who want to unlock the benefits of Twitter as a learning tool in the classroom and at home
column37: while receiving guidance directly from UNESCO on media and information literacy best practices.\nDistributing Ads for Good grants to 10 separate NGOs in UNESCO\u00e2\u0080\u0099s media and literacy network
column38: to help raise awareness of their work.\nDelivering a speech at MIL Week\u00e2\u0080\u0099s feature conference at the Vytautas Magnus University in Kaunas
column39: Lithuania
column40: along with speakers from the Council of Europe
column41: the European Commission
column42: Harvard University
column43: the London School of Economics
column44: the Communications University of China
column45: the Centre for Media and Information Literacy in Kenya
column46: and the Brazilian Institute of Information in Science and Technology
column47: amongst a truly global gathering of expert participants.\nPartnering with the National Association for Media Literacy Education (NAMLE) to support Media Literacy Week in the United States using the hashtag #MediaLitWk. US Media Literacy week will be held from November 5th until 9th and Twitter is proud to again partner with NAMLE to support media literacy education programs in the United States.\nImportant elections coming up in 2019 for the European Union
column48: Africa
column49: and India mean that now more than ever
column50: citizens are turning to platforms like Twitter for information and context to inform their decision.\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s for this reason we are investing more heavily in resources and tools to help surface more credible content with behaviour-based signals
column51: and tackle problematic content like spam and automation.\nOur continued and committed focus to media literacy will help supplement these efforts.\nWe cannot do this alone and it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s beyond one internet service. Collaboration is vital. That is why we are partnering with industry partners
column52: regulators
column53: educators
column54:
and parents to help build a new generation of empowered and media literate citizens.
Â

column3: "title": "More clarity on reported Tweets and enforcement"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
More clarity on reported Tweets and enforcement
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 17 October 2018\nLink copied successfully\nWhen we determine that a Tweet violates the Twitter Rules
column9: we require the violator to delete it before they can Tweet again. One piece of feedback we've heard regularly is that it's not always clear to people when we took enforcement action or if someone deleted a Tweet on their own. Starting today
column10: we're adding new notices to make it easier to see when we've taken enforcement action on a Tweet.\n Now
column11: once we've required a Tweet to be deleted
column12:
we will display a notice stating that the Tweet is unavailable because it violated the Twitter Rules along with a link to the Rules and an article that provides more detail on how we enforce our rules. This notice will be displayed on both the accountâs profile and the specific Tweet for 14 days after the Tweet is deleted. You'll see this change rolling out to both the app and on Twitter.com in the coming weeks. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We've also gotten feedback that you don't want to continue seeing Tweets you've reported. Starting today
column13: once you've reported a Tweet
column14: it will be hidden behind a notice like the one below. If there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a need to see the Tweet you reported
column15:
you can tap the notice to view it.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Since early 2017
column16: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve shipped more than 100 changes or experiments
column17: made more than a dozen policy updates
column18: expanded our teams and enforcement \u00e2\u0080\u0093 all to continue building a safer Twitter. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve updated our rules with more details and examples to make them easier to understand
column19: improved communication to people who break our rules so they know which Tweet caused the issue and which rule it broke
column20:
and notify people with our apps about the reports they file.
Improving our communication around steps weâre taking to keep you safe remains one of our top priorities. We hope these changes bring more clarity on how and when we our enforce our rules.
Â

column3: "title": "Enabling further research of information operations on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Enabling further research of information operations on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 17 October 2018\nLink copied successfully\nToday we are releasing all the accounts and related content associated with potential information operations that we have found on our service since 2016. We had previously disclosed these activities
column9:
but are now releasing substantially more information about them to enable independent academic research and investigation.
This is the continuation of our overarching mission to serve the public conversation.
Why are we doing this?
Earlier this year
column10: we committed to the United States Congress and the public to provide regular updates and information regarding our investigation into foreign interference in political conversations on Twitter. Since that time
column11: we have shared examples of these types of content posted on Twitter by the Internet Research Agency (IRA) and provided the public with a direct notice if they interacted with these accounts. In August
column12: we also disclosed details of another attempted influence campaign we identified as potentially located within Iran.\nIn line with our strong principles of transparency and with the goal of improving understanding of foreign influence and information campaigns
column13: we are releasing the full
column14: comprehensive archives of the Tweets and media that are connected with these two previously disclosed and potentially state-backed operations on our service. We are making this data available with the goal of encouraging open research and investigation of these behaviors from researchers and academics around the world.\nThese large datasets comprise 3
column15: 841* accounts affiliated with the IRA
column16: originating in Russia
column17: and 770 other accounts
column18: potentially originating in Iran. They include more than 10 million Tweets and more than 2 million images
column19: GIFs
column20: videos
column21: and Periscope broadcasts
column22: including the earliest on-Twitter activity from accounts connected with these campaigns
column23: dating back to 2009.\nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next?\nIt is clear that information operations and coordinated inauthentic behavior will not cease. These types of tactics have been around for far longer than Twitter has existed \u00e2\u0080\u0094 they will adapt and change as the geopolitical terrain evolves worldwide and as new technologies emerge. For our part
column24: we are committed to understanding how bad-faith actors use our services. We will continue to proactively combat nefarious attempts to undermine the integrity of Twitter
column25: while partnering with civil society
column26: government
column27: our industry peers
column28: and researchers to improve our collective understanding of coordinated attempts to interfere in the public conversation. Our dedicated site integrity team
column29: in partnership with a diverse range of committed organizations and personnel across the company
column30: continue to invest heavily in this area. We are constantly seeking to improve our own ability to detect
column31: understand
column32: and neutralize these campaigns as quickly and robustly as technically possible.\nIndependent analysis of this activity by researchers is a key step toward promoting shared understanding of these threats. To support this effort
column33: we have provided early access to a small group of researchers with specific expertise in these issues. Working with law enforcement and the authorities will always be our first priority
column34: but we strongly believe that this level of transparency can enhance the health of the public conversation on the internet. This is our singular mission.\nTo learn more about what is included and how researchers can download the datasets
column35: visit our dedicated Elections Integrity Hub. \u00c2\u00a0\n*In this case
column36: we initially misidentified 228 accounts as connected to Russia. As our investigations into their activity continued
column37:
we uncovered additional information allowing us to more confidently associate them with Venezuela.Â More here.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet
Twitter logo icon
Tags:
government
elections
policy
Twitter for Good
research

And thatâs a wrap! The 2018 #Promote Innovation Challenge has come to an end. 000 in Twitter media.

Unlocking global revenue through In-Stream Video Ads
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 1 October 2018\nLink copied successfully\nIn-Stream Video Ads were designed to unlock incremental revenue for top publishers who want to monetize their videos on Twitter
column9: while making it easier for advertisers to reach influential audiences and align with great content. Over the past year
column10: we have expanded this capability to nearly 20 global markets
column11: including Australia
column12: Brazil
column13: and Spain.\nToday
column14: we are pleased to announce that publishers can now monetize their entire global video audience on Twitter through In-Stream Video Ads. Previously
column15: In-Stream Video Ads were limited to the markets in which publishers are based
column16: but in many cases
column17: publishers have a global following. We heard feedback that they want to monetize their organic following
column18: outside of their home country.\nWe expect this opportunity can build on the momentum publishers across the world are seeing on Twitter: Over the first half of 2018
column19:
publisher earnings for this product have more than doubled relative to the same period in 2017.
This new feature is garnering excitement from publishers around the globe looking to increase reach and revenue:
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
All of our brands have seen exceptional growth this year on Twitter and built massive audiences of highly-engaged fans from around the world on the platform. Twitter has always been a great partner to Group Nine and has shown a true understanding of the value of great content. We are excited about the new opportunities to connect advertising partners with our audience and bring them into the amazing stories we tell
column20:
on a global scale.
Christa Carone
President of Group Nine Media
â@ChristaCaroneâ
In-Stream Video Ads has changed how we work on Twitter daily
column21: and now we are creating much more native video on the platform. Apart from monetizing our content
column22: it's enabling us to reach new audiences that aren't connected with our Club. In-Stream Video Ads allows us to generate revenue
column23: gain impact in new markets and increase our number of followers. It is also very significant that the monetized videos have a completion rate beyond the organic average.\nDidac Lee\nFC Barcelona Board Member
column24:
Digital
â@DidacLeeâ
This is a big win for monetization against the way BuzzFeed creates global content. We typically see our content travel beyond the local handle it was created in and extend to many other markets. Often times the most viral content reaches global audiences and this update helps advertisers align with that content.
Ken Blom
SVP of Branded Content Distribution & Ad Operation at BuzzFeed
â@KenBlomâ
In-Stream Video ads are available in markets across the world.
Â

publishers can reach out to their partner manager.

column3: "title": "An update on our elections integrity work"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
An update on our elections integrity work
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Monday
column8:
1 October 2018
Link copied successfully
We are committed to improving the health of the public conversation on Twitter and protecting the integrity of elections is an essential part of that mission.
Ahead of upcoming elections
column9:
today we are sharing updates across three critical areas of our election integrity efforts: (1) Updates to the Twitter Rules (2) Detection and Enforcement; and (3) Product Improvements. 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Updates to the Twitter Rules
We have updated the Twitter Rules to provide clearer guidance around several key issues: 
Fake accounts: We have heard feedback that people think our rules about spam and fake accounts only cover common spam tactics like selling fake goods. As platform manipulation tactics continue to evolve
column10: we are updating and expanding our rules to better reflect how we identify fake accounts
column11: and what types of inauthentic activity violate our guidelines. We now may remove fake accounts engaged in a variety of emergent
column12:
malicious behaviors. Some of the factors that we will take into account when determining whether an account is fake include:
Â  Â  Â  Â  -Use of stock or stolen avatar photos
Â  Â  Â  Â  -Use of stolen or copied profile bios
Â  Â  Â  Â  -Use of intentionally misleading profile information
column13: including profile location\nAttributed activity: As per the Twitter Rules
column14: if we are able to reliably attribute an account on Twitter to an entity known to violate the Twitter Rules
column15: we will take action on additional accounts associated with that entity. We are expanding our enforcement approach to include accounts that deliberately mimic or are intended to replace accounts we have previously suspended for violating our rules.\nDistribution of hacked materials: Our rules prohibit the distribution of hacked material that contains private information or trade secrets
column16: or could put people in harm\u00e2\u0080\u0099s way. We are also expanding the criteria for when we will take action on accounts which claim responsibility for a hack
column17: which includes threats and public incentives to hack specific people and accounts. Commentary about a hack or hacked materials
column18: such as news articles discussing a hack
column19:
are generally not considered a violation of this policy.
Detection and enforcement
We have seen positive results from our investments in conversational health and information integrity:
We continue to enforce our rules against intentionally misleading election-related content. In August
column20: we removed approximately 50 accounts misrepresenting themselves as members of various state Republican parties. We have also taken action on Tweets sharing media regarding elections and political issues with misleading or incorrect party affiliation information. We continue to partner closely with the RNC
column21: DNC
column22: and state election institutions to improve how we handle these issues.\nIn August
column23: we removed 770 accounts engaging in coordinated behavior which appeared to originate in Iran. Our investigation into this activity continues
column24: and we will share further updates on our findings with law enforcement
column25: our industry peers
column26:
and the public.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Our automated detections continue to identify and challenge millions of potentially spammy and automated accounts per week. In the first half of September
column27: we challenged an average of 9.4 million accounts each week. \nAs a result of our proactive detections and enforcements
column28: we have continued to see a decline in the average number of spam-related reports we receive from users each day \u00e2\u0080\u0094 from an average of approximately 17
column29: 000 per day in May
column30: to approximately 16
column31: 000 per day in September.\nIn July
column32: we introduced a new registration process for developers requesting access to our APIs
column33: intended to prevent the registration of spammy and low quality apps. While we continue to proactively identify and remove malicious applications \u00e2\u0080\u0094 suspending
column34: on average
column35: approximately 30
column36: 000 applications each month as a result of these efforts \u00e2\u0080\u0094 we continue to make it more difficult for these apps to operate in the first place.\nWe are continuing to roll out improvements to our proactive enforcements against common policy violations
column37:
including building new proprietary systems to identify and remove ban evaders at speed and scale.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Product developments
Finally
column38: we continue to make improvements to the Twitter product to help people stay informed and to see the best content first:\nWe heard feedback that people want an easy way to see the most recent Tweets in their home timeline. We recently updated the timeline personalization setting to allow people to select a strictly reverse-chronological experience
column39:
without recommended content and recaps. This ensures you have more control of how you experience whatâs happening on our service.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Â 
We are continuing to roll out new features to show people context about accounts on Twitter. In May
column40: we launched an election labels beta for candidates in the 2018 US midterm elections. We are also going to send candidates a message prompt to ensure they have two-factor authentication enabled on their account so it is safe and secure. \nWe are offering electoral institutions increased support via an elections-specific support portal
column41: which is designed to ensure we receive and review critical feedback about emerging issues as quickly as possible. We will continue to expand this program ahead of the elections and will provide information about the feedback we receive in the near future.\nAs part of our civic engagement efforts
column42: we are building conversation around the hashtag #BeAVoter with a custom emoji
column43: sending US-based users a prompt in their home timeline with information on how to register to vote
column44: and drawing attention to these conversations and resources through the top US trend. This trend is being promoted by @TwitterGov
column45: which will create even more access to voter registration information
column46:
including election reminders and an absentee ballot FAQ.

column3: "title": "Creating new policies together"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Creating new policies together
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 25 September 2018\nLink copied successfully\nThe Twitter Rules apply to everyone who uses Twitter. In the past
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve created our rules with a rigorous policy development process; it involves in-depth research and partnership with the members of our Trust and Safety Council and other experts to ensure these policies best serve every person on the service. Now
column10: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re trying something new by asking everyone for feedback on a policy before it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s part of the Twitter Rules.\nFor the last three months
column11: we have been developing a new policy to address dehumanizing language on Twitter. Language that makes someone less than human can have repercussions off the service
column12: including normalizing serious violence. Some of this content falls within our hateful conduct policy (which prohibits the promotion of violence against or direct attacks or threats against other people on the basis of race
column13: ethnicity
column14: national origin
column15: sexual orientation
column16: gender
column17: gender identity
column18: religious affiliation
column19: age
column20: disability
column21: or serious disease)
column22: but there are still Tweets many people consider to be abusive
column23: even when they do not break our rules. Better addressing this gap is part of our work to serve a healthy public conversation.\nWith this change
column24: we want to expand our hateful conduct policy to include content that dehumanizes others based on their membership in an identifiable group
column25: even when the material does not include a direct target. Many scholars have examined the relationship between dehumanization and violence. For example
column26: Susan Benesch has described dehumanizing language as a hallmark of dangerous speech
column27: because it can make violence seem acceptable
column28: and Herbert Kelman has posited that dehumanization can reduce the strength of restraining forces against violence.\nWe want your feedback to ensure we consider global perspectives and how this policy may impact different communities and cultures. For languages not represented here
column29: our policy team is working closely with local non-governmental organizations and policy makers to ensure their perspectives are captured.\nBelow you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll find a quick survey
column30: which will be available until Tuesday
column31: October 9
column32: at 6:00am PST. Once the feedback form has closed
column33: we will continue with our regular process
column34: which passes through a cross-functional working group
column35: including members of our policy development
column36: user research
column37: engineering
column38: and enforcement teams. We will share some of what we learn when we update the Twitter Rules later this year.\nThis is part of our singular effort to increase the health of the public conversation on our service and we hope this gives you a better understanding of how new rules are created. We want you to be part of this process
column39: let us know what you think in the form below.\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Dehumanization Policy\nYou may not dehumanize anyone based on membership in an identifiable group
column40: as this speech can lead to offline harm.\nDefinitions:\nDehumanization: Language that treats others as less than human. Dehumanization can occur when others are denied of human qualities (animalistic dehumanization) or when others are denied of their human nature (mechanistic dehumanization). Examples can include comparing groups to animals and viruses (animalistic)
column41: or reducing groups to a tool for some other purpose (mechanistic).\nIdentifiable group: Any group of people that can be distinguished by their shared characteristics such as their race
column42: ethnicity
column43: national origin
column44: sexual orientation
column45: gender
column46: gender identity
column47: religious affiliation
column48: age
column49: disability
column50: serious disease
column51: occupation
column52: political beliefs
column53: location
column54:
or social practices.
Examples of dehumanization:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Thank you for submitting your feedback. The submission form is now closed.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet

column3: "title": "#BeAVoter this US election"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
#BeAVoter this US election
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 24 September 2018\nLink copied successfully\nToday
column9: Twitter is launching our #BeAVoter campaign to promote increased
column10: informed participation in the 2018 US election on Tuesday
column11: November 6.\nEvery day
column12: people across the country use Twitter to hear directly from political candidates and journalists
column13: organize and talk with their community on issues they are passionate about
column14: and learn about ways that they can get involved in the democratic process by volunteering
column15: donating
column16: and even running for office.\nBut the first and most important step to participate in the election is registering to vote - and we want every eligible person to #BeAVoter in this election.\nBeginning on Monday
column17: September 24
column18: people on Twitter in the US will see:\nA prompt in their home timeline with information on how to register to vote. Already registered? Great - people will be able to Tweet at their followers to encourage them to register.\n#BeAVoter as the top US trend promoted by @TwitterGov
column19: which will create even more access to voter registration information
column20: including election reminders and an absentee ballot FAQ.\nA new emoji connected to #BeAVoter that will help unify the conversation around this important
column21:
national call to action.
Check out how they look below:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
All of these prompts will link people to TurboVote
column22: a non-profit
column23: non-partisan organization
column24: which we have partnered with to launch this campaign ahead of National Voter Registration Day on Tuesday
column25: September 25.\nTwitter is where people go to for news and information about elections
column26: and it is our obligation to ensure that we meet this expectation and provide a platform that promotes healthy
column27: public conversation and surfaces reliable information for voters.\nThat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why ahead of the 2018 election we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve created new labels to identify candidates
column28: launched stricter rules and transparency tools for political advertising
column29: and have committed to strengthen our platform against attempted manipulation.\nOur #BeAVoter campaign is an extension of this work to advocate for increased
column30:
informed participation in elections.
Stay tuned between now and election day on November 6th for more updates on this campaign.

column3: "title": "Working together to prevent suicide"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nWorking together to prevent suicide\nMonday
column8: 10 September 2018\nLink copied successfully\nSeptember 10
column10: is World Suicide Prevention Day
column11: and the theme for this year is \"Working Together to Prevent Suicide.\"\nIn recognition of this important global event
column12: Twitter
column13: in partnership with the International Association for Suicide Prevention (IASP)
column14: is launching a special emoji in the shape of an orange and yellow ribbon \u00e2\u0080\u0094 the international symbol for World Suicide Prevention Day. The emoji will appear when people Tweet with the hashtags #WorldSuicidePreventionDay
column15: #SuicidePrevention
column16: #WSPD2018
column17: and #WSPD from September 7-16 in 15 different languages.\nAt Twitter
column18: we believe that addressing mental health requires collaboration between all stakeholders \u00e2\u0080\u0094 public
column19: private
column20: and not-for-profit \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and we recognize that we have a role and responsibility to help ensure that people can access and receive support when they need it most.\nOne of the key ways that we do this is via a range of valued partnerships with suicide prevention and counselling services in various countries. This includes our marquee \"There is Help\" partnerships with the Suicide Prevention Lifeline in the US
column21: the Tokyo Suicide Prevention Center in Japan
column22: and Lifeline Korea. Today we are expanding our services to bring relevant resources to additional countries through formalized partnerships in Brazil
column23: Australia
column24: Hong Kong
column25: Spain
column26: Ireland
column27: Germany
column28: and the UK.\nThis service offers a prompt on Twitter
column29: which links the user directly to valuable mental health resources to vulnerable people and encourages them to reach out and get help when they need it.\nWhen someone searches for terms associated with suicide or self-harm
column30: the top search result is a prompt encouraging them to reach out for help. This valuable notification provides the contact details of the partner organization in their country when certain keywords are used. It is available on mobile devices and desktop in the US
column31: Japan and Korea
column32: and now offered on mobile in Brazil
column33: Australia
column34: Hong Kong
column35: Spain
column36: Ireland
column37: Germany
column38: and the UK.\nSuicide prevention remains a complex challenge but at Twitter we believe it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important that people who are struggling are seen and heard so that they can get the help they need.\nThe various communities on Twitter are a source of positive support
column39: encouraging users who may be struggling not to self-harm to reach out for professional help. We also have a list of international resources on our website where people can go to find more information and the details of relevant organizations within their respective countries. Increasingly
column40: we see mental health organizations offering critical services via digital channels and social media platforms that are relevant
column41: widely used and reflective of the way society communicates today.\nWe have a reporting form for people threatening suicide or self-harm and a dedicated team who review these reports. When we receive reports that a person is threatening suicide or self-harm
column42: we will contact the reported user and let him or her know that someone who cares about them identified that they might be at risk. We will provide the reported user with available online and hotline resources and encourage them to seek help.\nWe also provide information in our Help Center
column43: both for people who may be experiencing thoughts of suicide and self-harm
column44:
and for people who are concerned about another Twitter user.
We believe "There is Help" and Twitterâs other partnerships and initiatives in this space will make a valuable contribution to the ongoing and larger efforts required to address this serious issue.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

#OnlyOnTwitter

column3: "title": "Announcing new US issue ads policy"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Announcing new US issue ads policy
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 30 August 2018\nLink copied successfully\nToday we are announcing the next phase of our efforts to provide increased transparency for advertising on Twitter
column9: with the launch of a new US-specific Issue Ads Policy and certification process.\nThis new policy will impact the following:\nAds that refer to an election or a clearly identified candidate
column10: or\nAds that advocate for legislative issues of national importance\nExamples of legislative issues of national importance include topics such as abortion
column11: civil rights
column12: climate change
column13: guns
column14: healthcare
column15: immigration
column16: national security
column17: social security
column18: taxes
column19: and trade. These are the top-level issues we are considering under this policy
column20: and we expect this list to evolve over time.\nGetting certified\nTo provide people with additional information about individuals or organizations promoting issue ads
column21:
weâve established a certification process that verifies an advertiserâs identity and location within the US.
Advertisers that promote ads that fall under this policy must apply for certification and meet specific eligibility requirements. Advertisers can apply for certification here.
Exemption for news organizations
The intention of this policy is to provide the public with greater transparency into ads that seek to influence peopleâs stance on issues that may influence election outcomes. We donât believe that news organizations running ads on Twitter that report on these issues
column22: rather than advocate for or against them
column23:
should be subject to this policy.
News publishers that meet specific criteria will be able to apply for exemption from this policy. Learn more here and submit your application here. 
Increased transparency
Similar to political campaigning ads
column24:
issue ads will be specifically labeled as such within the timeline so that people will be able to clearly see who is promoting the ads and easily access more information. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We will also include issue ads within the Ads Transparency Center
column25: which will provide the same level of detail as political campaigning ads
column26: including billing information
column27: ad spend
column28:
and targeting information.  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Enforcement
Enforcement of this new issue ads policy will begin September 30th
column30: in the US only
column31:
after which ads from advertisers that have not been properly certified will be halted and the advertiser will be prompted to become certified.
Whatâs next?
We are continuing our efforts to expand our political content policies globally and will continue to work towards providing increased transparency for all advertising on Twitter.
For what this means for brands
column32: visit the Twitter Marketing Blog. For any additional questions
column33:
visit the FAQs.

column3: "title": "Investing in the best Twitter experience for you"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Investing in the best Twitter experience for you
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 16 August 2018\nLink copied successfully\nOur goal is to deliver the best Twitter for you. This year
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re moving faster towards this goal by focusing on improving Twitter for iOS
column10: Android
column11: and twitter.com. As part of this
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve chosen to stop supporting some other experiences. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve removed support for Twitter for Apple Watch and Twitter for Mac
column13: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve replaced our previous Twitter for Windows app with our Progressive Web App
column14: and today we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re removing support for some outdated developer tools.\nWe feel the best Twitter experience we can provide today is through our owned and operated Twitter for iOS and Android apps
column15:
as well as desktop and mobile twitter.com. Weâve long believed this âÂ weâve focused on delivering the best experience for our apps and sites for years. Recent feature and settings improvements (many of which are only possible in a Twitter-owned app) include:
Better organization of Tweets to mitigate troll-like behavior
More aggressive enforcement of our guidelines during live videos
Faster ways to find relevant Tweets and videos
Consistent app navigation and real-time Tweet engagement counts
Control over your Twitter data
Improved accessibility support
Notifications and Direct Message controls
In addition to these recent changes
column16:
Twitter-owned apps and websites have always been the only way to experience features like:
Explore (including Moments)
Periscopes
Polls
Bookmarks
Tweet-level controls for feedback
In order to prioritize making these experiences great
column17: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve chosen to stop investing in other products \u00e2\u0080\u0094 including two legacy developer tools used by about 1% of third-party developers. This means that some Twitter-like apps will not be able to function the exact same way as before. For example
column18: instead of Tweets automatically streaming in like they once did in some third-party apps
column19: you might need to pull to refresh like you do in Twitter-owned apps and sites. Several of the most popular apps have already made updates so that you can continue using them with minimal disruption.\nWe know some of you don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t like this more focused approach. There are good reasons you love the various Twitter apps you have used over the years
column20: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re grateful for the developers who build them.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re still strongly committed to ongoing investment in our developer ecosystem. Our investments are focused on helping developers create fundamentally new and innovative ways to use Twitter. Also
column21: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re continuing to invest in TweetDeck
column22: our desktop web client for professionals who need more advanced tools.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re grateful for your trust as we continue to improve. We also appreciate your feedback \u00e2\u0080\u0094 it helps us know what is important for you
column23:
which helps us build a better Twitter experience.
Â

column3: "title": "Twitter Lite in the Google Play Store: now available in 45+ countries"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Twitter Lite in the Google Play Store: now available in 45+ countries
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 13 August 2018\nLink copied successfully\nEvery day
column9: millions of people around the world use Twitter to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening. However
column10: there are several barriers to using Twitter
column11: including slow mobile networks
column12: expensive data plans
column13: or lack of space on mobile devices. When building new products
column14: we want to make sure what we create allows people to have the best possible experience
column15: no matter where they are.\nAs a result of this
column16: last year
column17: we released Twitter Lite as an app in the Google Play Store
column18: which minimizes data usage
column19: loads quickly on slower networks and takes up less space on your device. Today we are excited to announce we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re expanding to 21 more countries including Argentina
column20: Belarus
column21: Dominican Republic
column22: Ghana
column23: Guatemala
column24: Honduras
column25: India
column26: Indonesia
column27: Jordan
column28: Kenya
column29: Lebanon
column30: Morocco
column31: Nicaragua
column32: Paraguay
column33: Romania
column34: Turkey
column35: Uganda
column36: Ukraine
column37: Uruguay
column38: Yemen
column39: and Zimbabwe. Now
column40: Twitter Lite will be available in the Google Play Store in more than 45 countries.\nHere are a few ways Twitter Lite makes Twitter more accessible
column41: fast
column42: and data-friendly for you:\nData saver: We want to make sure that Twitter Lite is accessible to people with data
column43: bandwidth
column44: and device constraints. By enabling Data saver
column45: you can control which images and videos load on your phone. You can still load all this content at any time by hitting \u00e2\u0080\u009cLoad image\u00e2\u0080\u009d or \u00e2\u0080\u009cLoad video\u00e2\u0080\u009d
column46: helping you save money and data in real time.\nBuilt for 2G and 3G networks: At an install size of 3MB
column47: Twitter Lite saves data and space
column48: and loads quickly on unreliable networks. While using the app on 2G or 3G
column49: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll notice that content will load quickly on Twitter Lite. We want to make sure you can see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening no matter what network you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re on!\nBookmarks: Running low on data? Want to save a Tweet for later? Bookmarks is an easy-to-use feature that allows you to save important Tweets for later
column50: for when you have more data or a better internet connection.\nPush notifications: Starting today
column51: Twitter Lite supports push notifications
column52: allowing you to keep up with what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening around the world.\nNight mode: Night mode gives your timeline a darker theme
column53: which is easier on your eyes and easier to read \u00e2\u0080\u0094 even during the day.\nThreads: Following our announcement last year
column54: threaded Tweets are now available on Twitter Lite! We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made it easy to create a thread by adding a plus button in the composer
column55: so you can connect your thoughts and publish your threaded Tweets all at the same time.\n\u00c2\u00a0\nAs mobile-first users continue to change how we use the internet
column56: we want to make sure that Twitter is relevant
column57: useful
column58: and dependable. Wherever you are
column59: we want to make Twitter your go-to place to find out what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening. While we continue working to make this app available in more countries
column60: you can always access Twitter through your smartphone or tablet browser
column61: by visiting mobile.twitter.com. With Twitter Lite
column62: you can get real-time updates on news
column63: sports
column64: entertainment
column65: politics
column66: and other topics that matter most to you
column67: without having to sacrifice on data or storage.\nDownload Twitter Lite from the Google Play Store today!\nTwitter Lite Google Play app is now available in all of the following countries: Algeria

column3: "title": "The Twitter Rules: a living document"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
The Twitter Rules: a living document
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 7 August 2018\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter is reflective of real conversations happening in the world and that sometimes includes perspectives that may be offensive
column9: controversial
column10: and/or bigoted. While we welcome everyone to express themselves on our service
column11: we prohibit targeted behavior that harasses
column12: threatens
column13: or uses fear to silence the voices of others. We have the Twitter Rules in place to help ensure everyone feels safe expressing their beliefs and we strive to enforce them with uniform consistency.\nOur policies and enforcement options evolve continuously to address emerging behaviors online and we sometimes come across instances where someone is reported for an incident that took place prior to that behavior being prohibited. In those instances
column14: we will generally require the individual to delete the Tweet that violates the new rules but we won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t generally take other enforcement action against them (e.g. suspension). This is reflective of the fact that the Twitter Rules are a living document. \u00c2\u00a0We continue to expand and update both them and our enforcement options to respond to the changing contours of online conversation. This is how we make Twitter better for everyone.\nWe are continually working to update
column15: refine
column16: and improve both our enforcement and our policies
column17: informed by in-depth research around trends in online behavior both on and off Twitter
column18: feedback from the people who use Twitter
column19: and input from a number of external entities
column20:
including members of our Trust & Safety Council. Â 
Â 
A few examples of how our rules have changed*:
In August 2013
column21: we added a section explicitly prohibiting \u00e2\u0080\u009ctargeted harassment\u00e2\u0080\u009d to the Twitter Rules under the \u00e2\u0080\u009cAbuse and Spam\u00e2\u0080\u009d category.\nIn December 2015
column22: we added a separate \u00e2\u0080\u009cAbusive Behavior\u00e2\u0080\u009d section to the Twitter Rules.\nIn November 2016
column23: we shared more details around hateful conduct and how we enforce policy violations.\nSince then
column24: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve updated the list of abusive behaviors we prohibit to include unwanted sexual advances
column25: posting or sharing intimate photos or videos of someone that were produced or distributed without their consent
column26: wishes or hopes of harm
column27:
and threats to expose or hack someone.
Last year we expanded hateful conduct and media policies to include abusive usernames and hateful imagery. We also updated rules around violence and physical harm to include the glorification of violence and violent extremist groups.
Â 
Similarly
column28: our enforcement options have expanded significantly over the years. We originally had only one enforcement option: account suspension. Since then
column29: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve added a range of enforcement actions and now have the ability to take action at the Tweet
column30: Direct Message
column31: and account levels. Additionally
column32: we take measures to educate individuals that have violated our rules about the specific tweet(s) in violation and which policy has been violated. We also continue to improve the technology we use to prioritise reports that are most likely to violate our rules and last year we introduced smarter
column33: more aggressive witness reporting to augment our approach.\nGiven the scale of Twitter
column34:
we will not always get it right. We believe we have to rely on a straight-forward principled approach and focus on the long term goal of understanding - not just in terms of the service itself - but in terms of the role we play in society and our wider responsibility to foster and better serve a healthy public conversation.
----
Reference:
Twitter Help Center â Our approach to policy development and enforcement philosophy
Twitter blog â Serving the Public Conversation During Breaking Events
July 2013 â Twitter Rules
August 2013 â Twitter Rules (addition of âTargeted Harassmentâ)
April 2016 â Twitter Rules (addition of âAbusive Behaviorâ section)
Â
