column3: "title": "Measuring healthy conversation"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Measuring healthy conversation
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 30 July 2018\nLink copied successfully\nEarlier this year
column9: as part of our global health initiative
column10: we committed to serving the public conversation and working to increase the collective health
column11: openness
column12: and civility of the dialogue on our service. We want everyone\u00e2\u0080\u0099s experience on Twitter to be free of abuse
column13: harassment
column14: and other types of behaviors that can detract or distort from the public conversation. Work has been underway for months to make progress in these areas
column15: such as making changes so you can be confident in your follower counts
column16: introducing new signals into how we present and organize Tweets
column17: sharing more on our expanded efforts to fight malicious automation
column18: and acquiring Smyte to address safety
column19: spam
column20: and security challenges more quickly and effectively.\nIf you want to improve something
column21: you must be able to measure it. Inspired by our friends at Cortico
column22: a nonprofit research organization that has taken the time to more deeply understand the concept of measuring conversational health
column23: we wanted to examine what this would look like for Twitter. However
column24: we knew this was not something we should address alone
column25: and put out a request for proposals to help us develop a measurement framework. Partnering with outside experts who can provide thoughtful analysis
column26: external perspective
column27: and rigorous review is the best way to measure our work and stay accountable to those who use Twitter. Since March
column28: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve reviewed more than 230 proposals from around the world that challenged us to think critically about how we can define and measure the health of public conversation on Twitter.\nOur teams reviewed each proposal in depth. To start
column29: we organized a review committee with representatives from diverse groups across Twitter
column30: including Engineering
column31: Product
column32: Machine Learning
column33: Data Science
column34: Trust & Safety
column35: Legal
column36: and Research. In the first round
column37: each proposal was reviewed and scored by two different people. The 50 proposals that made it to the next round were each reviewed by a total of four different people
column38: and then the 16 semifinalists were further evaluated by a small committee of subject-matter experts. Finally
column39: we interviewed a handful of finalists by video conference before making the final selection. By the end
column40: we had written more than 350 reviews in total and examined the finalists in depth; as a result
column41: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re confident in the process that led us to the two extraordinary partners we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve selected.\nExamining echo chambers and uncivil discourse\nLed by Dr. Rebekah Tromble
column42: assistant professor of political science at Leiden University
column43: along with Dr. Michael Meffert at Leiden
column44: Dr. Patricia Rossini and Dr. Jennifer Stromer-Galley at Syracuse University
column45: Dr. Nava Tintarev at Delft University of Technology
column46: and Dr. Dirk Hovy at Bocconi University
column47: this project will develop two sets of metrics: how communities form around political discussions on Twitter
column48: and the challenges that may arise as those discussions develop.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cIn the context of growing political polarization
column49: the spread of misinformation
column50: and increases in incivility and intolerance
column51: it is clear that if we are going to effectively evaluate and address some of the most difficult challenges arising on social media
column52: academic researchers and tech companies will need to work together much more closely. This initiative presents an important and promising opportunity for Twitter and our team of researchers to share expertise and work on solutions together
column53: \u00e2\u0080\u009d Tromble said.\nThe Leiden-led project will primarily focus on two key challenges: echo chambers and uncivil discourse. Based on their past findings
column54: echo chambers
column55: which form when discussions involve only like-minded people and perspectives
column56: can increase hostility and promote resentment toward those not having the same conversation. The project\u00e2\u0080\u0099s first set of metrics will assess the extent to which people acknowledge and engage with diverse viewpoints on Twitter.\nThe second set of metrics will focus on incivility and intolerance in Twitter conversations. The group has found that while incivility
column57: which breaks norms of politeness
column58: can be problematic
column59: it can also serve important functions in political dialog. In contrast
column60: intolerant discourse \u00e2\u0080\u0094 such as hate speech
column61: racism
column62: and xenophobia \u00e2\u0080\u0094 is inherently threatening to democracy. The team will therefore work on developing algorithms that distinguish between these two behaviors.\nThe project brings together scholars with different backgrounds and expertise
column63: bridging political science
column64: communication
column65: and computer science. The six scholars working together across four universities will combine deep social scientific subject expertise with strong technical expertise to develop and adapt measures of healthy conversations on Twitter.\nBridging gaps between communities on Twitter\nProfessor Miles Hewstone and John Gallacher at\u00c2\u00a0the University of Oxford
column66: in partnership with Dr. Marc Heerdink at the University of Amsterdam
column67: will be studying how people use Twitter
column68: and how exposure to a variety of perspectives and backgrounds can decrease prejudice and discrimination.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re very excited about the opportunity to work with Twitter on investigating the important social challenges of a digitally connected world
column69: \u00e2\u0080\u009d said Miles Hewstone
column70: Ph.D.
column71: professor of social psychology at Oxford University. \u00e2\u0080\u009cEvidence from social psychology has shown how communication between people from different backgrounds is one of the best ways to decrease prejudice and discrimination. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re aiming to investigate how this understanding can be used to measure the health of conversations on Twitter
column72: and whether the effects of positive online interaction carry across to the offline world.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nThe project builds on Professor Hewstone\u00e2\u0080\u0099s longstanding work to study intergroup conflict. When the communication between groups contains more positive sentiments
column73: cooperative emotions
column74: and more complex thinking and reasoning from multiple perspectives
column75: prejudice is reduced and relations can improve. This was previously demonstrated in a variety of contexts
column76: including in post-conflict community building efforts in Northern Ireland as well as in online communities. As part of the project
column77: text classifiers for language commonly associated with positive sentiment
column78: cooperative emotionality
column79: and integrative complexity will be adapted to the structure of communication on Twitter.\nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next?\nEnsuring we have thoughtful
column80: comprehensive metrics to measure the health of public conversation on Twitter is crucial to guiding our work and making progress
column81: and both of our partners will help us continue to think critically and inclusively so we can get this right. We know this is a very ambitious task
column82: and look forward to working with these two teams
column83: challenging ourselves to better support a thriving
column84: healthy public conversation.\nThank you to everyone who submitted an application \u00e2\u0080\u0094 we are grateful to all who took the time and initiative to help shape this critical work. We look forward to working with these two organizations
column85:
and the broader academic community to counsel and support our teams to create healthier experiences on Twitter.

column3: "title": "Safer conversation for live video "
column7: "post_text": "Company\nSafer conversation for live video \nFriday
column8: 27 July 2018\nLink copied successfully\nChatting on live video should be safe for both broadcasters and viewers
column9: so that everyone is empowered to join the conversation without fear of abuse. The Periscope Community Guidelines apply to live video on both Twitter and Periscope. As part of our ongoing effort to build a safer service
column10: we are launching more aggressive enforcement of the guidelines related to chats sent during live broadcasts.\nOur community can\u00c2\u00a0report and vote on chats they consider to be abusive
column11: and group moderation determines if someone can continue chatting. Starting on August 10
column12: we will also review and suspend accounts for repeatedly sending chats that violate the guidelines. If you are in a broadcast and see a chat that may violate our guidelines
column13: please report it.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to making sure everyone feels safe
column14: whether you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re broadcasting or just tuning in. Look out for more changes across policies
column15: product
column16:
and enforcement as we continue to make both Twitter and Periscope safer.
Â

column3: "title": " Setting the record straight on shadow banning"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
 Setting the record straight on shadow banning
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 26 July 2018\nLink copied successfully\nPeople are asking us if we shadow ban. We do not. But let\u00e2\u0080\u0099s start with
column9: \u00e2\u0080\u009cwhat is shadow banning?\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nThe best definition we found is this: deliberately making someone\u00e2\u0080\u0099s content undiscoverable to everyone except the person who posted it
column10: unbeknownst to the original poster.\nWe do not shadow ban. You are always able to see the tweets from accounts you follow (although you may have to do more work to find them
column11: like go directly to their profile). And we certainly don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t shadow ban based on political viewpoints or ideology.\nWe do rank tweets and search results. We do this because Twitter is most useful when it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s immediately relevant. These ranking models take many signals into consideration to best organize tweets for timely relevance. We must also address bad-faith actors who intend to manipulate or detract from healthy conversation.\nAs a specific example
column12: if a search result has 30
column13: 000 tweets
column14:
hereâs what we take into consideration when ranking:
Tweets from people youâre interested in should be ranked highly
Tweets that are popular are likely to be interesting and should be higher ranked
Tweets from bad-faith actors who intend to manipulate or divide the conversation should be ranked lower
This last bullet is the basis of our work around serving healthy public conversation. Here are some of the signals we use to determine bad-faith actors:
Specific account properties that indicate authenticity (e.g. whether you have a confirmed email address
column15: how recently your account was created
column16: whether you uploaded a profile image
column17: etc)\nWhat actions you take on Twitter (e.g. who you follow
column18: who you retweet
column19: etc)\nHow other accounts interact with you (e.g. who mutes you
column20: who follows you
column21: who retweets you
column22: who blocks you
column23:
etc)
We know this approach is working because we see fewer abuse reports and spam reports.
What Happened This Week
Yesterday
column24: we identified an issue where some accounts weren\u00e2\u0080\u0099t auto-suggested in search even when people were searching for their specific name. To be clear
column25: this only impacted our search auto-suggestions. The accounts
column26: their tweets and surrounding conversation about those accounts were showing up in search results. As of yesterday afternoon
column27: this issue was resolved.\nThere were a number of follow up questions relating to our thread yesterday that we wanted to address:\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cHow many people were impacted by the search auto-suggest issue?\u00e2\u0080\u009d Hundreds of thousands of accounts were impacted by this issue. This impact was not limited to a certain political affiliation or geography. And
column28: to be clear
column29: these accounts were only impacted within search auto-suggestions-- they still appeared in search results. This issue has now been resolved.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cIt looks like this only affected Republican politicians. Were Democratic politicians also impacted?\u00e2\u0080\u009d Yes
column30: some Democratic politicians were not properly showing up within search auto-suggestions as result of this issue. As mentioned above
column31: the issue was broad-ranging and not limited to political accounts or specific geographies. And most accounts affected had nothing to do with politics at all.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cOK
column32: so there was a search auto-suggest issue. But what caused these Republican representatives to be impacted?\u00e2\u0080\u009d For the most part
column33: we believe the issue had more to do with how other people were interacting with these representatives\u00e2\u0080\u0099 accounts than the accounts themselves (see bullet #3 above). There are communities that try to boost each other\u00e2\u0080\u0099s presence on the platform through coordinated engagement. We believe these types of actors engaged with the representatives\u00e2\u0080\u0099 accounts-- the impact of this coordinated behavior
column34: in combination with our implementation of search auto-suggestions
column35: caused the representatives\u00e2\u0080\u0099 accounts to not show up in auto-suggestions. In addition to fixing search yesterday
column36:
weâre continuing to improve our system so it can better detect these situations and correct for them.
Weâre focused on making these systems better and smarter over time and sharing our work and progress with all of you. We think itâs critical to promoting healthy public conversation on Twitter and earning trust.

column3: "title": "Putting people first on data portability"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Putting people first on data portability
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 20 July 2018\nLink copied successfully\nAt Twitter we believe in providing you with the tools you need to control your data and with the means to know exactly how it is used and for what purpose. We also believe that you should have control over how you transfer information between the online products and services that you use. That is why we
column9: alongside our peers at Google
column10: Microsoft
column11: and Facebook
column12: are formally launching the Data Transfer Project (DTP).\nThe opportunity\nRight now
column13: much of the online products and services we use do not interact with each other in a coherent and intuitive fashion. Information that is housed on one platform can not be easily and securely transferred to other services. This is not a positive collective experience for the people who use our services and we are keen to work through some of the challenges as an industry. The Data Transfer Project is an open source initiative aiming to empower any company to create tools that enable people to freely move their information across the web - without barriers. To start
column14: our companies want to share experiences and knowledge to carve out a positive path forward.\nAt Twitter
column15: we feel strongly that portability and interoperability are central to innovation on the internet. We believe that a more frictionless
column16: individually-driven forms of data transfer between online platforms and services will result in an innovative
column17: creative
column18: and people-first online experience for all. Making it easier for users to choose among services also facilitates competition
column19: empowering everyone to try new services and choose the offering that best suits their individual needs. This facilitative and collaborative spirit of openness is the principled bedrock of our free and open internet. It is a principle we at Twitter are dedicated to furthering.\nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next?\nAlongside Google
column20: Microsoft
column21: and Facebook
column22: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve produced a white paper that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s designed to set the course we want to chart as this project evolves. In keeping with our overarching principles around transparency and accountability
column23: this process of information sharing between our companies and the related work streams will be open for all to scrutinise
column24: critique
column25: and to build off. To find out more and to help us along our way
column26: please visit the dedicated GitHub Data Transfer Project site.\nAs always
column27:
we will keep you updated on our progress. This will take time but we are very excited to work with innovators and passionate people from other companies to ensure we are putting you first. Fundamentally this about pushing towards a more open and dynamic internet for you to engage with and one that places the control and the power in your hands.
Follow @Policy for more updates.

column3: "title": "Announcing the 2018 #Promote Innovation Challenge"
column7:
"post_text": "Announcing the 2018 #Promote Innovation Challenge
                By
                
  
  
              
                and
                
  
  
Thursday
column8:
19 July 2018
Link copied successfully
Weâre pleased to announce that entries are now being accepted for the 2018 #Promote Innovation Challenge!
Twitter collaborates with a diverse ecosystem of businesses to serve our global marketers. #Promote is our way of recognizing some of the most exciting marketing technology and service solutions in the industry.
Walk the walk
For our third annual event
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re focusing on impact. Not only will we be highlighting some of the most exciting technology in the industry
column10: but we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be giving six finalists the chance to showcase their performance in a $50
column11: 000 Twitter ad campaign. Finalists will then have the opportunity to present their solution and case study before a judging panel of Twitter executives. The grand prize winner will be rewarded $100
column12: 000 in media credit
column13: co-marketing opportunities
column14:
and recognition within the Twitter Official Partner program.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Looking back
Last year
column15: we ran our most successful #Promote to date with entries from industry leaders in video solutions
column16: content marketing
column17:
and advertising technology around the globe. The competition was incredibly strong but we managed to select nine businesses to present their solutions before a live audience at Twitter NYC.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Moving forward
For 2018
column18: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re casting a wide net. If your solution enhances advertising on Twitter
column19: we want to know about it. This may include solutions specialized in campaign optimization
column20: creative
column21: audience insights
column22: measurement

column8: 17 July 2018\nLink copied successfully\nThe #WorldCup drama unfolded on the pitch in Russia

column11: or to show sportsmanship despite tough defeats
column12: football fans across the globe came to Twitter to experience every exhilarating and emotional moment as it happened.\nAfter 64 thrilling matches
column13: including the dramatic World Cup Final between France (@equipedefrance) and Croatia (@HNS_CFF)
column14:
weâve compiled the numbers and their visualizations that illustrate the massive role Twitter played for fans since the event began on June 14.

column3: "title": "Confidence in follower counts"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Confidence in follower counts
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 11 July 2018\nLink copied successfully\nAs part of our ongoing and global effort to build trust and encourage healthy conversation on Twitter
column9: every part of the service matters. Follower counts are a visible feature
column10: and we want everyone to have confidence that the numbers are meaningful and accurate.\nOver the years
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve locked accounts when we detected sudden changes in account behavior. In these situations
column12: we reach out to the owners of the accounts and unless they validate the account and reset their passwords
column13: we keep them locked with no ability to log in. This week
column14: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be removing these locked accounts from follower counts across profiles globally. As a result
column15: the number of followers displayed on many profiles may go down.\nMost people will see a change of four followers or fewer; others with larger follower counts will experience a more significant drop. We understand this may be hard for some
column16: but we believe accuracy and transparency make Twitter a more trusted service for public conversation.\nThough the most significant changes are happening in the next few days
column17: follower counts may continue to change more regularly as part of our ongoing work to proactively identify and challenge problematic accounts.\nWhy does an account get locked?\nIf we detect sudden changes in account behavior
column18: we may lock the account and contact the owner to confirm they still have control of it. These sudden changes in account behavior could include Tweeting a large volume of unsolicited replies or mentions
column19: Tweeting misleading links
column20: or if a large number of accounts block the account after mentioning them. We sometimes lock an account if we see email and password combinations from other services posted online and believe that information could put the security of an account at risk \u00e2\u0080\u0094 so we require accounts to change of their passwords for protection. Until we confirm that everything is ok with the account
column21: we lock it
column22: which makes them unable to Tweet or see ads.\nHow are these accounts different from spam or bots?\nIn most cases
column23: these accounts were created by real people but we cannot confirm that the original person who opened the account still has control and access to it.\nSpam accounts (sometimes referred to as bots) typically exhibit spammy behavior from the beginning
column24: are increasingly predictable by our systems
column25: and can be automatically shut down with our technology.\u00c2\u00a0You can learn more about our ongoing work to prevent spam on Twitter here.\nWhy just followers? Will this expand to Tweets
column26: Likes
column27: and Retweets?\nOur ongoing work to improve the health of conversations on Twitter encompasses all aspects of our service. This specific update is focused on followers because it is one of the most visible features on our service and often associated with account credibility. Once an account is locked
column28: it cannot Tweet
column29: like or Retweet and it is not served ads.\nWill this change affect your Monthly Active User (MAU) or Daily Active User (DAU) metrics?\nNo
column30: it will not. Removing locked accounts from followers doesn't impact MAU or DAU. Locked accounts that have not reset their password in more than one month are not included in MAU or DAU. While today\u00e2\u0080\u0099s change doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t affect MAU or DAU
column31:
some accounts we remove from the service as part of our ongoing commitment to a healthy public conversation have the potential to impact publicly reported metrics.
Continuing to Communicate with You
This is another step to improve Twitter and ensure everyone can have confidence in their followers. Follow @Twitter and @TwitterSafety for the latest updates as we continue our commitment to serve the public conversation.
Â

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Providing more transparency around advertising on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Providing more transparency around advertising on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 28 June 2018\nLink copied successfully\nUpdated January 25
column9: 2021:\nAs of January 25
column11: the Ads Transparency Center is no longer available. Please visit Business.Twitter.com to learn more and download a historical archive of all political and issue ads prior to the prohibition of both Political and Issue Ads on Twitter.\nLast year
column12: we announced our intention to provide transparency for all ads running on Twitter
column13: with a specific emphasis on political advertising. Our first step towards this was releasing a new Political Campaigning Ads Policy for US federal elections and candidates.\nToday we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re pleased to share the second part of our efforts
column14: the Ads Transparency Center
column15: which allows anyone across the globe to view ads that have been served on Twitter
column16: with even more transparency around US federal election campaigning ads.\nWhat does it look like?\nSimilar to the search experience on Twitter
column17: to view ads from any advertiser you will be able to simply search for a specific handle and see the creative for all ad campaigns that have run within the last 7 days from that handle.\u00c2\u00a0If an ad is reported and taken down from Twitter
column18: it will be tombstoned in the Ads Transparency Center within approximately 24 hours. If the account was suspended
column19:
Tweets will not be shown in the ATC. The same applies to deleted users and Tweets. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
For US political advertisers that fall under our new Political Campaigning Policy
column20: you will be able to see further details
column21: including billing information
column22: ad spend
column23: and impression data per Tweet. Additionally
column24:
we will be showing demographic targeting data for the ads being served.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As previously announced
column25: in addition to the information being shared within the Ads Transparency Center itself
column26: we are making it clearer than ever who is advertising US federal political campaign content on Twitter by including a visual badge and disclaimer information on promoted content from certified accounts. This will allow users to easily identify political campaign ads
column27: know who paid for them
column28:
and whether it was authorized by a candidate.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Who has access to the Ads Transparency Center?
Everyone around the world will have access to the Ads Transparency Center. No login or Twitter account will be required
column29: making it very simple for people to have clear insight and details on who is advertising on Twitter. The Ads Transparency Center will include all advertisers on Twitter globally
column30: but only US federal election campaigning ads that fall under our new policy will be shown at this stage.\nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next?\nWe will be launching a specific issue ads policy in the future
column31: as well as enhancements to the Ads Transparency Center itself. In addition
column32: we are examining how to adapt and internationalize both political campaigning and issue ads policies. We are doing our due diligence to get this right and will have more updates to come. We stay committed to iterating and improving our work in this space
column33:
and doing whatâs right for our community.
For more information visit the Ads Transparency Center FAQs.Â

column3: "title": "How Twitter is fighting spam and malicious automation"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
How Twitter is fighting spam and malicious automation
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 26 June 2018\nLink copied successfully\nEvery day
column9: people come to Twitter to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening. One of the most important parts of our focus on improving the health of conversations on Twitter is ensuring people have access to credible
column10: relevant
column11: and high-quality information on Twitter. To help move toward this goal
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve introduced new measures to fight abuse and trolls
column13: new policies on hateful conduct and violent extremism
column14: and are bringing in new technology and staff to fight spam and abuse.\nBut we know there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s still a lot of work to be done. Inauthentic accounts
column15: spam
column16: and malicious automation disrupt everyone\u00e2\u0080\u0099s experience on Twitter
column17: and we will never be done with our efforts to identify and prevent attempts to manipulate conversations on our platform.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to share some recent progress and new measures for how we handle spam
column18: malicious automation
column19: and platform manipulation.\nNew processes for fighting malicious automation and spam\nTwitter fights spam and malicious automation strategically and at scale. Our focus is increasingly on proactively identifying problematic accounts and behavior rather than waiting until we receive a report. We focus on developing machine learning tools that identify and take action on networks of spammy or automated accounts automatically. This lets us tackle attempts to manipulate conversations on Twitter at scale
column20: across languages and time zones
column21: without relying on reactive reports. \nOur investments in this space are having a positive impact:\nIn May 2018
column22: our systems identified and challenged more than 9.9 million potentially spammy or automated accounts per week. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s up from 6.4 million in December 2017
column23:
and 3.2 million in September.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Due to technology and process improvements during the past year
column24: we are now removing 214% more accounts for violating our spam policies on a year-on-year basis.\nAt the same time
column25: the average number of spam reports we received through our reporting flow continued to drop \u00e2\u0080\u0094 from an average of approximately 25
column26: 000 per day in March
column27: to approximately 17
column28: 000 per day in May. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also seen a 10% drop in spam reports from search as a result of our recent changes. These decreases in reports received means people are encountering less spam in their timeline
column29: search
column30: and across the Twitter product.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also moving rapidly to curb spam and abuse originating via Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s APIs. In Q1 2018
column31: we suspended more than 142
column32: 000 applications in violation of our rules \u00e2\u0080\u0094 collectively responsible for more than 130 million low-quality
column33: spammy Tweets. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve maintained this pace of proactive action
column34: removing an average of more than 49
column35: 000 malicious applications per month in April and May. We are increasingly using automated and proactive detection methods to find misuses of our platform before they impact anyone\u00e2\u0080\u0099s experience. More than half of the applications we suspended in Q1 were suspended within one week of registration
column36:
many within hours.
Â 
These numbers tell us that our tools are working: Weâre preventing or catching more of this activity ourselves before you ever see it on Twitter.
Â 
Platform manipulation and spam are challenges we continue to face and which continue to evolve
column37: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re striving to be more transparent with you about our work. Today
column38:
weâre sharing four new steps weâre taking to address these issues:
Â 
1) Reducing the visibility of suspicious accounts in Tweet and account metrics
Â 
A common form of spammy and automated behavior is following accounts in coordinated
column39: bulk ways. Often accounts engaged in these activities are successfully caught by our automated detection tools (and removed from our active user metrics) shortly after the behavior begins. But we haven\u00e2\u0080\u0099t done enough in the past to make the impact of our detections and actions clear. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve started updating account metrics in near-real time: for example
column40: the number of followers an account has
column41: or the number of likes or Retweets a Tweet receives
column42: will be correctly updated when we take action on accounts.\n\u00c2\u00a0\nSo
column43: if we put an account into a read-only state (where the account can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t engage with others or Tweet) because our systems have detected it behaving suspiciously
column44: we now remove it from follower figures and engagement counts until it passes a challenge
column45: like confirming a phone number. We also display a warning on read-only accounts and prevent new accounts from following them to help prevent inadvertent exposure to potentially malicious content. If the account passes the challenge
column46: its footprint will be restored (though it may take a few hours). We are working to make these protections more transparent to anyone who may try to interact with an account in this read-only state.\n\u00c2\u00a0\nAs a result of these improvements
column47: some people may notice their own account metrics change more regularly. But we think this is an important shift in how we display Tweet and account information to ensure that malicious actors aren\u00e2\u0080\u0099t able to artificially boost an account\u00e2\u0080\u0099s credibility permanently by inflating metrics like the number of followers.\n\u00c2\u00a0\nStay tuned: In the coming weeks
column48:
we will have more to share about additional steps weâre taking to reduce the impact of this sort of activity on Twitter.
Â 
2) Improving our sign-up process
Â 
To make it harder to register spam accounts
column49:
weâre also going to require new accounts to confirm either an email address or phone number when they sign up to Twitter. This is an important change to defend against people who try to take advantage of our openness. We will be working closely with our Trust and Safety Council and other expert NGOs to ensure this change does not hurt someone in a high-risk environment where anonymity is important. Look for this to roll out later this year.
Â 
3) Auditing existing accounts for signs of automated sign-up
Â 
Weâre also conducting an audit to secure a number of legacy systems used to create accounts. Our goal is to ensure that every account created on Twitter has passed some simple
column50: automatic security checks designed to prevent automated signups. The new protections we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve developed as a result of this audit have already helped us prevent more than 50
column51: 000 spammy sign-ups per day.\n\u00c2\u00a0\nAs part of this audit
column52: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re imminently taking action to challenge a large number of suspected spam accounts that we caught as part of an investigation into misuse of an old part of the sign-up flow. These accounts are primarily follow spammers
column53: who in many cases appear to have automatically or bulk followed verified or other high-profile accounts suggested to new accounts during our signup flow. As a result of this action
column54: some people may see their follower counts drop; when we challenge an account
column55: follows originating from that account are hidden until the account owner passes that challenge. This does not mean accounts appearing to lose followers did anything wrong; they were the targets of spam that we are now cleaning up. We've recently been taking more steps to clean up spam and automated activity and close the loopholes they'd exploited
column56:
and are working to be more transparent about these kinds of actions.
Â 
4) Expansion of our malicious behavior detection systems
Â 
Weâre also now automating some processes where we see suspicious account activity
column57: like exceptionally high-volume Tweeting with the same hashtag
column58: or using the same @username without a reply from the account you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re mentioning. These tests vary in intensity
column59:
and at a simple level may involve the account owner completing a simple reCAPTCHA process or a password reset request. More complex cases are automatically passed to our team for review.
What you can do
Â 
There are important steps you can take to protect your security on Twitter:
Enable two-factor authentication. Instead of only entering a password to log in
column60: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll also enter a code which is sent to your mobile phone. This verification helps make sure that you
column61: and only you
column62:
can access your account.
Regularly review any third-party applications. You can review and revoke access for applications by visiting the Apps tab in your account settings on twitter.com.
Donât reuse your passwords across multiple platforms or websites. Have a unique password for each of your accounts.
You can also use a FIDO Universal 2nd Factor (U2F) security key for login verification when signing into Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Additionally
column63: if you believe you may have been incorrectly actioned by one of our automated spam detection systems
column64: you can use our appeals process to request a review of your case.\nNext steps\nGoing forward
column65: Twitter is continuing to invest across the board in our approach to these issues
column66: including leveraging machine learning technology and partnerships with third parties. We also look forward to soon announcing the results of our request for proposals for public health metrics research.\nThese issues are felt around the world
column67: from elections to emergency events and high-profile public conversations. As we have stated in recent announcements
column68:
the public health of the conversation on Twitter is a critical metric by which we will measure our success in these areas.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Continuing our commitment to health"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nContinuing our commitment to health\nThursday
column8: 21 June 2018\nLink copied successfully\nWe are committed to serving the public conversation and ensuring the conversation on Twitter is healthy. While our teams continue to focus on building a safer Twitter and partnering with outside experts to deliver on this commitment
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re exploring how we can work with even more urgency.\nToday
column10: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re very excited to announce that we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve agreed to acquire Smyte
column11: a San Francisco-based technology company that specializes in safety
column12: spam
column13: and security issues. Smyte\u00e2\u0080\u0099s team
column14: technology and company mission are aligned with our focus on improving the health of conversation on Twitter
column15: and we believe this will be a powerful addition to our ongoing work.\nFrom ensuring safety and security at some of the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s largest companies to specialized domain expertise
column16: Smyte\u00e2\u0080\u0099s years of experience with these issues brings valuable insight to our team. The Smyte team has dealt with many unique issues facing online safety and believes in the same proactive approach that we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re taking for Twitter: stopping abusive behavior before it impacts anyone\u00e2\u0080\u0099s experience. We can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t wait until they join our team to help us make changes that will further improve the health of the public conversation.\nSmyte\u00e2\u0080\u0099s products will help us address challenges in safety
column17:
spam and security more quickly and effectively. Their review tools and processes will be powerful additions to our own tools and technology that help us keep Twitter safe. Weâll integrate this technology to strengthen our systems and operations in the coming months.
Â 
The health of the conversation on Twitter remains our top priority and weâre looking forward to approaching this work with an expanded team and new technology.
Â 
Welcome to the team
column18:
Smyte!
Â

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "The power of creators on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
The power of creators on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 21 June 2018\nLink copied successfully\nThe concept of brands partnering with creators to produce ads is not something new. Take a scroll through the numerous social feeds on your phone and you are bound to see branded content from a creator. For marketers today
column9: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not \u00e2\u0080\u009cif\u00e2\u0080\u009d you should be partnering with creators but more so \u00e2\u0080\u009cwhy and how\u00e2\u0080\u009d to partner with them. What\u00e2\u0080\u0099s even more important for brands to understand is that there is a unique why and how for every platform - especially for Twitter.\nTo help brands and agencies better understand how to incorporate creator content into their Twitter strategy
column10: we partnered with Magna and IPG Media Lab on a Twitter-sponsored study to analyze what brands and marketers should know about working with creators
column11: how to optimize creator content
column12: and what they have to gain from working with creators.\nTHE WHY\nCreators are today\u00e2\u0080\u0099s celebrities. They are not just influential - they entertain
column13: inform and inspire audiences by sharing original content every single day. On Twitter
column14: they are more than just a part of \u00c2\u00a0\u00e2\u0080\u009cWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Happening.\u00e2\u0080\u009d In fact
column15: 2 of 3 Twitter users agree that creators actually change and shape culture*. In many instances
column16:
they are âWhatâs Happening.â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
More than any other platform
column17: Twitter is about conversation. Creators turn to Twitter to build a community
column18: and their followers come to the platform to connect directly with the creators they love the most. In fact
column19: 61% of Twitter users follow a creator
column20: more so than on any other platform*.\nWhen individuals who carry a wealth of influence and creativity become more accessible and their thoughts and conversations more transparent
column21: audiences begin to trust those individuals. People look to creators for recommendations over online reviews
column22: brand Tweets
column23: and traditional TV and digital ads when it comes to what to buy
column24: where to go
column25: and what to watch. Today\u00e2\u0080\u0099s word-of-mouth marketing is often driven by creators on Twitter.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cThe results of this media trial proved that creator content is a valuable asset for brands. To keep up with the fast-moving pace of social environments
column26: branded creator content is a quick
column27: easy
column28: and affordable way for advertisers to impact consumers
column29: \u00e2\u0080\u009d Kara Manatt
column30: SVP Intelligence Solutions & Strategy at MAGNA.\nTHE HOW\nCreators are unique in that they care just as much about the content they produce as the brand does - first and foremost
column31: original content is their livelihood. In order to ensure their content feels authentic
column32: 94% of creators look for brands that connect with their style and image*. They want to work with brands that share a common aesthetic
column33:
and partner to create content that feels true to their message and their audience.
Creators also want to be more than just a production resource - collaboration is key to successful creator-driven marketing campaigns. 93% of creators look for brands that want to hear their ideas and tap into their voice*. Creators are experts at eliciting a response from their audience and brands should trust this expertise. Provide guidelines but let the creator come back with ideas that feel genuine to their feed.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
WHAT MARKETERS HAVE TO GAIN
When you partner with creators in a way that feels authentic
column34:
all parties will benefit. Brand metrics are higher across the board when creators are recognized as genuine. These include:
+61% increase in brand favorability
+88% increase in purchase intent
+64% increase in recommendation intent*.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In fact
column35: branded content from creators drives increased view times for those ads on Twitter. Audiences on Twitter spend 24% more time watching an ad from a creator
column36: because they are more genuine and trustworthy*. This in turn drives significant impact to lower funnel metrics. Twitter users who recall an ad from a creator show a +39% increase in brand favorability
column37: and +41% increase in purchase intent
column38:
versus ads recalled that were produced by brands*. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
MAKE IT HAPPEN
Finally
column39: once you understand \u00e2\u0080\u009cwhy\u00e2\u0080\u009d and \u00e2\u0080\u009chow\u00e2\u0080\u009d to work with creators - you also need to determine the best way to connect with them. From a creator\u00e2\u0080\u0099s standpoint
column40: they\u00e2\u0080\u0099d much rather work with experts in the space who can effectively translate the brand\u00e2\u0080\u0099s needs while supporting creators\u00e2\u0080\u0099 creative integrity.\nFor brands on Twitter
column41: Niche is your solution. Niche is Twitter's talented team of Strategists and Content Managers who connect brands on Twitter with the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s best creators to reach an audience through premium
column42: original content. Niche has one of the largest and most diverse community of creators in the world and understands fully how to optimize branded creator content across any category.\nIn addition to custom content needs
column43: Twitter also just launched Creator Originals
column44: a new program that enables creators to produce their own high-end content series. Brands can partner now with creators on programs
column45: in line with our in-stream video sponsorship offerings.\nCreators are what's happening on Twitter - and with Niche
column46: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s easier than ever to partner with them for powerful branded content.\nMETHODOLOGY\nWe conducted a research study with Magna and IPG Media Lab in a two-phased approach
column47: using a creator perspective and consumer perspective. In Phase 1
column48: the creator perspective
column49: we partnered with Niche to survey creators in the US and UK and understand the creator experience of making content and the process in working with brands (n=171). In Phase 2
column50: the consumer perspective
column51: we surveyed participants in the US from a representative online panel via a mobile survey (n=3
column52:
251). We first asked demographic and media consumption behavior questions and then participants were asked to view their Twitter feed to determine their ad experience. We tested promoted content and leveraged a post experience survey to measure traditional brand metrics. This was done across 12 brands and 9 industry verticals.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
*Twitter + Magna IPG Media Lab
column53: \u00e2\u0080\u0098Art of the Creator\u00e2\u0080\u0099
column54:
2018 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "#Transparency update: Twitter shares more national security letters"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
#Transparency update: Twitter shares more national security letters
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 20 June 2018\nLink copied successfully\nAt Twitter
column9: we work every day to advance our longstanding commitment to transparency. \u00c2\u00a0We believe that reporting national security requests in government-mandated bands does not provide meaningful transparency to the public or those using our service
column10: and curtails speech on issues of public importance. \u00c2\u00a0Today
column11: we are able to share information about some of our recent efforts.\nAs explained in our last blog post on this topic
column12: Twitter is using a process created by the USA FREEDOM ACT to ask the US Department of Justice (\u00e2\u0080\u009cDOJ\u00e2\u0080\u009d) to lift -- or
column13: alternatively
column14: justify in court -- non-disclosure obligations in connection with National Security Letter (\u00e2\u0080\u009cNSL\u00e2\u0080\u009d) requests. \u00c2\u00a0We have been doing this since the process became available in 2015
column15: and today we are able to share an encouraging (and now unsealed) court order.\nThe case at issue involved the court\u00e2\u0080\u0099s review of a gag order that the DOJ argued should be kept in place indefinitely. \u00c2\u00a0While the court agreed with the DOJ that national security interests justified the gag order remaining in place
column16: the court also agreed with Twitter that \u00e2\u0080\u009c[t]here are important First Amendment concerns at stake\u00e2\u0080\u009d. \u00c2\u00a0To that end
column17: the court ultimately held that while the gag order may be appropriate now
column18: it should not stay in place indefinitely. The court ordered the DOJ to review the gag order every three years
column19: making clear that any non-disclosure obligation must be narrowly tailored to a finite time period for review.\nIn addition to sharing this ruling
column20: we can now publish and provide user notice to the affected account-holders for seven more NSLs (10-271500
column26: 10-315095) \u00c2\u00a0where the gag orders have been lifted in response to our petitions
column27: as well as publish and provide user notice to the affected account-holders for two additional NSLs (15-419074
column28: 10-320727) where the DOJ has lifted any non-disclosure requirement. \u00c2\u00a0This brings the total number of NSLs that we have been able to publish since 2010 to 15. \u00c2\u00a0We will update the numbers in our US Report when we publish our next Transparency Report later this year.\nLastly
column29: while we are pleased to share these details with you today
column30: there is no mechanism by which we could ask that gag orders for any requests received under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (\u00e2\u0080\u009cFISA\u00e2\u0080\u009d) be reviewed or lifted. \u00c2\u00a0Nor are we able to publish the numbers of such requests
column31: to the extent we had received them
column32: except in bands. Our ongoing litigation in pursuit of greater transparency in this regard
column33: Twitter v. Sessions
column34: is continuing. \u00c2\u00a0We remain steadfast
column35: in Sessions
column36: in asserting that the restrictions on our ability to share information related to FISA requests (to the extent we had received them) with our users and the public are unconstitutional.\n We will continue to take practical steps to promote meaningful transparency
column37: and look forward to sharing more updates about these efforts as they become available. \u00c2\u00a0As always
column38:
you can learn more about our commitment to protecting free expression in our Help Center. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter

column7: "post_text": "Events\nWrapping up #E3 on Twitter\nWednesday
column8: 20 June 2018\nLink copied successfully\nGamers around the world were glued to Twitter last week to hear and talk about the breaking announcements
column9: trailers
column10: and gameplay reveals coming from the annual E3 expo (@E3) in Los Angeles. No matter what games were announced
column11: or what tournaments were happening
column12:
people came to Twitter to talk about it! 
Gaming conversation was fast and furious on Twitter. There was a 94% increase in overall gaming conversation during E3 compared to the previous week on Twitter.Â 
And there were nearly 15 million #E3 related Tweets last week. The highest spike in E3 conversation came during the Nintendo Direct press conference between 9-10 AM ET on June 12 with 890K Tweets. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The gaming conversation on Twitter spans the globe
column13:
and it was no different during #E3. These were the countries that Tweeted the most about the event.
United States
Japan
United Kingdom
Spain
France
A look at the most Tweeted about topics during the annual event offers a fascinating glimpse at what got gaming fans most excited.
Nintendo (@Nintendo)
Xbox (@Xbox)
Super Smash Bros. (#SuperSmashBros)
Fallout (@Fallout)
Playstation (@PlayStation)
Kingdom Hearts (@KINGDOMHEARTS)
Ubisoft (@Ubisoft)

In addition to being some of the most-discussed topics on Twitter

column3: "title": "Twitter Media: A new home for publishers on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Twitter Media: A new home for publishers on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 14 June 2018\nLink copied successfully\nPeople turn to Twitter to discover what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in the world. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a role we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re extremely proud of \u00e2\u0080\u0093 and one we know we can only accomplish in partnership with publishers. Without their coverage and commentary on the latest in news
column9: sports
column10: and entertainment
column11: there wouldn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t be nearly as much worthwhile content for us to read
column12: watch
column13: and Tweet about.\nWe may host the global conversation
column14: but it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s the journalists
column15: athletes
column16: actors
column17: musicians
column18: and other public figures who work with publishers that lead it. As a platform
column19: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s our job to support them with publishing tools
column20: best practices
column21: and revenue products that make the time and energy they invest in Twitter worthwhile.\nFor the last decade
column22: Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s content partnerships team has actively managed successful relationships with thousands of publishers around the world; consulting on everything from content strategy to revenue growth
column23: account management
column24: and security.\nToday
column25: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to announce the launch of Twitter Media
column26: a new website for publishers to learn how to get the most out of Twitter. Twitter Media allows us to scale our team\u00e2\u0080\u0099s work by giving content publishers a resource that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s both inspirational and practical
column27: featuring:\nBest practices from the most successful content publishers across Twitter
column28: curated by Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s news
column29: sports
column30:
and entertainment partnerships teams.
The latest information about new products and features designed specifically for content publishers.
An easy-to-navigate help section curating answers to the most common questions we get from content publishers every day.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Todayâs launch is just the start. Twitter Media will also be regularly updated with case studies to share success stories from innovative partnerships
column31: as well as a blog focused on helping content publishers stay up-to-date with the latest tools for publishers on Twitter.\nFor the content publishers we already work with
column32: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re confident our new site can provide answers when you need them and free up time for us to dedicate to bigger
column33: bolder collaborations. And for content publishers that we haven\u00e2\u0080\u0099t yet partnered with

column3: "title": " See what\u2019s happening!"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
 See whatâs happening!
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 13 June 2018\nLink copied successfully\nPeople come to Twitter to see and discuss what matters to them \u00e2\u0080\u0094 from breaking news to the day\u00e2\u0080\u0099s events and memes. This is because whatever is happening in the world
column9: is happening on Twitter \u00e2\u0080\u0094 with real-time conversation. There\u00e2\u0080\u0099s no better example than #NBATwitter. Check it out!\nRight now if you want to follow #NBATwitter
column10: or any news
column11: you have to find the relevant accounts
column12: hashtags
column13: or Moments to follow. But this could be easier. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been working to change how you discover all the information around news
column14: events
column15: and stories
column16: and today
column17: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sharing a few steps forward. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be easier to find and follow the big events and stories you care about in your timeline
column18: notifications
column19: and Explore. Also
column20: there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a new look and feel for Moments showing everything you\u00e2\u0080\u0099d want to see.\nWhere It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s at\nHere are a few ways we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re making relevant breaking news
column21: events
column22: and stories easier to discover.\nExploring Your Interests\nExplore helps you discover more of what matters to you. We heard from you that Explore would be easier navigate if it was organized by topic instead of content type (video
column23: articles
column24: etc). We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re now experimenting with topic tabs in Explore so it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s easier to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in news and entertainment
column25: and what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s most relevant to you. Available in the coming months to everyone in the US on iOS and Android.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also launching updates to search to make it simpler to find what you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re looking for. Starting today
column26: at the top of search results
column27: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll see related news
column28: events
column29: or stories and be able to tap in to get a recap and see the latest discussion
column30:
videos or scores.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Your Timeline + News
Last year
column31: we introduced \u00e2\u0080\u009cHappening now\u00e2\u0080\u009d at the top of the timeline for sports
column32: so if your team is playing you can follow along with Tweets about the game and the score
column33: all in one place. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re now expanding this to include Tweets about breaking and personalized news. At the top of your timeline
column34: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll see news that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s relevant to you along with the surrounding Tweets and videos. Available in the coming months to everyone in the US on iOS and Android.\nPersonalized News + Events Notifications\nWe want Twitter to be the fastest way to see the latest news around the things you care about. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been sending breaking news notifications to keep people in the know
column35: in the moment. Now we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re experimenting with sending notifications to you based on your interests (like who you follow and what you Tweet about)
column36:
so you wonât miss a beat. You can always turn off these notifications by going to your recommendations settings and toggling to not see news. Available in the coming weeks to everyone in the US on iOS and Android.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            A personalized news notification takes you to whatâs happening with all of the Tweets and related video in one place. 
          
          
        
All Together Now
Moments launched in 2015 as a way to discover and learn about whatâs happening â no matter which accounts you follow. More than one thousand Moments are created every week
column37: and they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re now available in 16 markets and five languages. These collections of Tweets are a great way to understand and catch up with a story and the discussion around it.\nNew Look\nRight now
column38: you swipe horizontally to read Moments
column39: but our research showed us that Moments are easier to use vertically
column40: just like your timeline. In our tests of this new look
column41: we saw significantly more people using and returning to Moments. So
column42: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re starting to introduce this new vertical timeline experience for Moments.\nSome Moments \u00e2\u0080\u0094 including Moments outside of the US
column43: Sponsored Moments and Moments created by you \u00e2\u0080\u0094 will temporarily continue to be horizontal as we roll out this change.\nMore Tweets\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re rolling out multiple timelines in some US Moments to help you see all the best Tweets surrounding a story: a recap timeline showing Tweets you may have missed
column44: another showing the latest
column45: as well as top commentary when it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s available. If there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a live video
column46: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll see it there
column47: too. You may have already noticed these changes for some sports games
column48: but now you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll start to see them for more news and events as well.\nAnd
column49: for the World Cup...\nYou can keep up with every shot
column50: save
column51: and goal on Twitter with our dedicated World Cup page and individual pages for every game
column52: including scores
column53: Tweets
column54: videos
column55: and Moments. You can find these pages at the top of your timeline
column56: in search
column57: or in Explore! Available today on Twitter for iOS and Android as well as mobile.twitter.com in English
column58: Spanish

column61: Korean

and Arabic.
This Tweet is unavailable

            Searching for World Cup brings you to relevant scores
column67:
Tweets and videos about the latest games.  
          
          
        
Â 
Weâre keeping you informed about what matters by showing the Tweets
column68: conversations
column69:
and perspectives around topics you care about. Our goal is to make following whatâs happening as easy as following an account. Hope you like these updates and that youâll let us know what you think â @ me! Â

column3: "title": "Expanding In-Stream Video Ads to more advertisers globally"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Expanding In-Stream Video Ads to more advertisers globally
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 12 June 2018\nLink copied successfully\nIn today\u00e2\u0080\u0099s media landscape
column9: consumers are in the driver\u00e2\u0080\u0099s seat as they consume content when and where they want. As a marketer
column10: you need to find new ways to capture people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s attention on their terms. Twitter's In-Stream Video Ads connect brands to compelling
column11: brand-safe video content
column12: allowing marketers to capture consumers' attention when they are most receptive. Today
column13: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re making In-Stream Video Ads available to all advertisers \u00e2\u0080\u0094 including self-serve \u00e2\u0080\u0094 in 12 global markets: Australia
column14: Brazil
column15: Canada
column16: France
column17: India
column18: Japan
column19: Mexico
column20: Saudi Arabia
column21: Spain
column22: United Arab Emirates
column23: United Kingdom
column24:
and United States.Â Â  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Align with premium
column25: brand-safe videos to connect with your audience\nIn-Stream Video Ads allow marketers to connect with their audience through pre-roll ads that kick off the videos people love. In the United States
column26: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve partnered with more than 200 of the best video publishers in the world
column27: including top TV networks
column28: teams from major sports leagues
column29: and professional news outlets like Business Insider
column30: CNN
column31: Cond\u00c3\u00a9 Nast Entertainment
column32: Fox News
column33: Fox Sports
column34: Hearst Magazines Digital Media
column35: IGN
column36: Meredith Corporation
column37: and Reuters. Every day
column38: they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sharing brand-safe videos that your audience is eager to discover. From catching must-see sports highlights to watching clips of top TV shows
column39: people on Twitter love that they can watch whatâs happening. Â  Â  This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. Your browser does not support the video element. Play Play Pause Seek 0% buffered 00:00 Current time 00:00 Duration 00:00 Toggle Mute Volume Pizza Hut used In-Stream Video Ads to promote its Hut Rewards program. This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. New research shows the effectiveness of In-Stream Video Ads Time and again
column40: In-Stream Video Ad campaigns drive positive shifts in key brand metrics for advertisers. Based on U.S. Nielsen Brand Effect data
column41: people who saw In-Stream Video Ads on Twitter were 70% more likely to recall the brand\u00e2\u0080\u0099s ad
column42: 28% more likely to be aware of the advertiser\u00e2\u0080\u0099s brand
column43: and had a 6% higher purchase intent (versus those not exposed to video ads).\u00c2\u00a0\nAdvertisers are able to achieve these positive results because the mindset of the audience on Twitter is extremely unique \u00e2\u0080\u0094 these aren\u00e2\u0080\u0099t people who sit back and watch the world just scroll by. They\u00e2\u0080\u0099re engaged. They\u00e2\u0080\u0099re curious. On average
column44:
we see that people are 31% more likely to remember what they see on Twitter versus general online browsing. Weâre excited to roll In-Stream Video Ads out to more advertisers and help them achieve their KPIs. 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
For marketers wondering how this new video ad product will work in tandem with their existing Twitter video ad campaigns
column45: we have you covered. We partnered with Dentsu Aegis (@DentsuAegis) and Kantar Millward Brown (@K_MillwardBrown) and found that increased frequency of exposure to multiple video ad formats (e.g. In-Stream Video Ads + Promoted Video) increases brand health metrics across the funnel. In the U.S.
column46: exposure to two video ad formats versus one video ad format improves ad recall by 19 percentage points (pp)
column47: brand awareness by 4.7pp
column48:
and purchase intent by 3.1pp.
Â 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
âDAN has been working with Twitter on behalf of more than a dozen brands and seen great success. Twitter's unique value is clear: brands can reach audiences watching premium
column49: brand-safe digital video. In-Stream Video Ads have allowed us to guarantee our clients can reach their target audiences at scale.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nMichael Law\nEVP
column50: Managing Director
column51: US Media Investment
column52: Dentsu Aegis Network (DAN)\nGetting started is simple\nExtending your video ad campaign to Twitter is easy. With In-Stream Video Ads
column53: no community management is needed
column54: and marketers with video ads can start a campaign at ads.twitter.com.\nFor marketers that want to create Twitter-specific video ads
column55: but lack the time
column56: resources
column57: or insights
column58: Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Fuel team provides editing services to optimize creative without losing impact. This service can also be leveraged in conjunction with research studies for robust campaign performance analytics. To date
column59: early results show lift in brand metrics performing well above benchmarks.\nTo learn more about our video ad solutions
column60: reach out to your Twitter account representative
column61:
or head to marketing.twitter.com/video.
Â

Events

            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 4 June 2018\nLink copied successfully\nTwice a year
column9: our teams around the world come together for a day of service we call #TwitterForGood Day. Since Twitter's inception
column10: giving back to our communities has been an integral part of our culture. From NGO training workshops in Dublin
column11: volunteering with the Red Cross in Tokyo
column12: to hosting a sport challenge with the Center for Addiction and Mental Health Sport Challenge in Toronto
column13: these service days celebrate our partner organizations and inspire us continue giving back all year long.\nBelow are some highlights from our recent series of #TwitterForGood Days. For more on how Twitter employees and our partners spent the day
column14: check out this Moment.\nAPAC - Sydney\n@TwitterAU spent the day with Oz Harvest
column15: an organization dedicated to food rescue through collecting quality excess food from commercial outlets and delivering it directly to more than 1
column16:
000 charities supporting people in need across the country. Through âCook for a Causeâ Twitter employees created hundred of meals using rescued food that otherwise would have been destined for landfills.
This Tweet is unavailable

column19:
especially children and women. The team organized activities for children and hosted a Twitter 101 workshop.
This Tweet is unavailable

column21: Twitter employees joined together to conduct a series of personalised Twitter 101 workshops for NGOs in Singapore
column22: such as with Transient Workers Count Too.\nAPAC - Tokyo\n@TwitterJP visited a welfare center run by Japanese Red Cross Society to spend time with elderly people who rely on the center for support. The team spent time chatting and playing games with residents. Other volunteers also spent time with the Tokyo Suicide Prevention Center
column23:
our partner for #WeHearYou campaign to raise awareness of services available to individuals considering suicide. Twitter employees had the opportunity to hear about the experiences of those dealing with such thoughts and how to best support them.

logging any vacant buildings that could possibly be refurbished and used for housing. This app was launched in Dublin in March by Twitter co-founder @biz.

column3: "title": "Increasing transparency for political campaigning ads on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Increasing transparency for political campaigning ads on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 24 May 2018\nLink copied successfully\nWe believe transparency is key for both the people using our service and advertisers to feel confident in our platform. As we stated last year
column9: we are committed to enforcing stricter policies for political advertisers and providing clear
column10: transparent disclosure for all ads on Twitter
column11: with more details for political campaigning ads.\nToday
column12: we are launching our Political Campaigning Policy in the United States to provide clear insight into how we define political content and who is advertising political content on Twitter. \nWhat will this policy entail?\nAs part of this new policy
column13: we will require advertisers who want to run political campaigning ads for Federal elections to self-identify and certify that they are located in the US Candidates and committees will have to provide their FEC ID
column14: and non-FEC registered organizations and individuals will have to submit a notarized form. We will send a letter to the mailing address registered with the FEC
column15: business
column16: or individual to validate the identity and location of all political campaigning advertisers. In addition
column17: we will not allow foreign nationals to target political ads to people who are identified as being \u00c2\u00a0in the US.\nAdditionally
column18: handles used for political campaigning advertising will have to comply with stricter requirements. The handle\u00e2\u0080\u0099s profile photo
column19: header photo
column20: and website must be consistent with its online presence and the Twitter bio must include a website that provides valid contact information.\nWe will also be including a visual badge and disclaimer information on promoted content from certified accounts in the near future. This will allow users to easily identify political campaigning ads
column21: know who paid for them
column22:
and whether it was authorized by a candidate.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Sample iOS Experience  
          
          
        
          
            Sample iOS Experience  
          
          
        
This complements our recent announcement around US election labels
column23: which will appear on the campaign Twitter accounts of candidates running for state Governor
column24: or for the US Senate or US House of Representatives
column25: during the 2018 US midterm general election. These labels contain relevant information about a political candidate
column26: including the office the candidate is running for
column27: the state the office is located in
column28: district number (when applicable)
column29: and will be clearly identifiable with a small icon of a government building.\nWhen will enforcement begin?\nEnforcement of this policy will begin later this summer
column30: after which only certified advertisers will be allowed to run political campaigning ads. Political advertisers can apply now for certification.\nWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s next?\nAs stated earlier this year
column31: we will be launching an Ads Transparency Center this summer. The Ads Transparency Center will provide insight into all ads running on Twitter
column32: with even more details on political campaigning ads
column33: including ad spend and targeting demographics.\nIssue ads will fall under a separate upcoming policy. This allows us to have a nuanced approach to transparency that is mindful of the inherent difference between political and issue-oriented advertising campaigns. Given the global nature of our company
column34:
we are also looking into how these policies can be enforced internationally and will have more to share in the future.
This is just the beginning of our efforts in increased transparency for all advertising on Twitter. We will continue to iterate and improve our efforts in this space and will be providing updates along the way.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet
Twitter logo icon

transparency
government
policy
ATC

column3: "title": "Introducing US Election Labels for Midterm Candidates"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Introducing US Election Labels for Midterm Candidates
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 23 May 2018\nLink copied successfully\nWhen people are looking for news and information
column9: they turn to Twitter to find out what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in the world right now. This is especially true during elections
column10: where Twitter has become the first place voters go to seek accurate information
column11: resources
column12: and breaking news from journalists
column13: political candidates
column14: and elected officials.\nWe understand the significance of this responsibility and our teams are building new ways for people who use Twitter to identify original sources and authentic information.\nWith that goal in mind
column15: today we are introducing US election labels for specified candidates running in the 2018 US midterm general election.\nWhat are US election labels?\nLabels contain relevant information about a political candidate
column16: including the office the candidate is running for
column17: the state the office is located in
column18: district number (when applicable)
column19:
and will be clearly identifiable with a small icon of a government building. The label will appear on the Twitter Profile page of the candidate and alongside all Tweets sent or Retweeted by the account everywhere Tweets are visible â including Tweets embedded off of Twitter.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Which candidates will qualify for US election labels?
Labels appear on the campaign Twitter accounts of candidates running for state Governor
column20: or for the US Senate or US House of Representatives
column21: during the 2018 US midterm general election.\n\u00c2\u00a0\nTwitter is partnering with Ballotpedia
column22: a non-profit
column23: civic organization that publishes nonpartisan information on federal
column24: state
column25: and local politics
column26:
to help identify the campaign Twitter accounts of candidates once they qualify for the general election ballot for an applicable office.
Â 
When will US election labels appear?
Â 
Labels will begin to appear after May 30 on the campaign Twitter accounts of candidates who have already qualified for the general election ballot for an applicable office.
Â 
This will continue on a rolling basis as states continue to hold primary elections and candidates officially qualify for the general election ballot.
Â 
What are the next steps?
Â 
We are launching this tool initially for specified offices during the 2018 US midterm general election.
Â 
Providing the public with authentic
column27: trustworthy information is crucial to the democratic process
column28: and we are committed to furthering that goal through the tools we continue to build.\nUpdate: When election labels first launched
column29:
applicable candidates were required to opt-in to the program in order to receive a label. That process has subsequently changed so that applicable candidates are now notified when they qualify for a label and are given seven days to opt-out before it is applied.
Â 
Â 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet
