column7: "post_text": "Events\nEmbrace #Ramadan with various Twitter-only activations\nTuesday
column8: 15 May 2018\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s public nature allows Muslims all over the world to access real-time information and connect with one another during #Ramadan. From faith and wellness to food and entertainment
column9:
live conversations unfold during the holy month keeping everyone informed about #WhatsHappening in the moment.Â Â 
Hereâs what we have planned to make this yearâs #Ramadan experience on Twitter your best one yet:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Want to add more character to your conversations? Include the following hashtags in your Tweets during the holy month to unlock a newly-designed crescent moon emoji.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Last year
column10: we launched two additional emojis that were a great success
column11: so we decided to bring them again to you with a new design. The first is an illustration of a date with a glass of yoghurt
column12:
which is commonly used to break fast.
This Tweet is unavailable

The second emoji is that of a #Ramadan-themed lantern.
This Tweet is unavailable

column13:
brought to you by the Ministry of Culture and Information in Saudi Arabia.

column15: #HawanahZein. The show will take place in broadcast partnership with YallaFeed and will focus on what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in the Arab world on Twitter during the month of Ramadan. Sponsored by Unilever
column16: it will air every Monday and Thursday from 12am - 12.20am KSA via @YallaFeed. The first episode will be streamed on May 17. This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. Your browser does not support the video element. Play Play Pause Seek 0% buffered 00:00 Current time 00:00 Duration 00:00 Toggle Mute Volume Weâre also launching a Ramadan TV Direct Message experience on Twitter. TV viewers can send a Direct Message to the Arabic lifestyle publication @Layalina that will automatically display a variety of categories to choose from; âChannelsâ

column19: viewers will automatically receive a message that will include a list of series
column20: TV channels
column21:
timings as well as a daily recap of their favorite series based on their selection.

In Indonesia

column24: is activating a Direct Message experience developed by GDI Lab (@gdilab) to make it easier for Indonesians to find Ramadan-related information on Twitter. This includes information about prayer times
column25: Ramadan food recipes and related information that helps Indonesians during homecoming travel.\n@netmediatama TV is integrating Twitter within its Sohoor programming
column26: \u00e2\u0080\u009cIni Sahur\u00e2\u0080\u009d to allow live audiences to engage with celebrity guests and hosts on its show in real-time. \nPartnering with @sabistriming

Indonesians can engage with sports program #BalbalanShow every Thursday at 5pm and with @tipsom2 at 8pm for lifestyle related news. If you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re a sport fan

or lifestyle enthusiast; our #BlueRoom content will enrich your Ramadan experience.

column3: "title": " Serving healthy conversation "
column7:
"post_text": "Product
 Serving healthy conversation 
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 15 May 2018\nLink copied successfully\nIn March
column9: we introduced our new approach to improve the health of the public conversation on Twitter. One important issue we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been working to address is what some might refer to as \u00e2\u0080\u009ctrolls.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Some troll-like behavior is fun
column10: good
column11: and humorous. What we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re talking about today are troll-like behaviors that distort and detract from the public conversation on Twitter
column12: particularly in communal areas like conversations and search. Some of these accounts and Tweets violate our policies
column13: and
column14: in those cases
column15: we take action on them. Others don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t but are behaving in ways that distort the conversation.\nTo put this in context
column16: fewer than 1% of accounts make up the majority of accounts reported for abuse
column17: but a lot of what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s reported does not violate our rules. While still a small overall number
column18: these accounts have a disproportionately large \u00e2\u0080\u0093 and negative \u00e2\u0080\u0093 impact on people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s experience on Twitter. The challenge for us has been: how can we proactively address these disruptive behaviors that do not violate our policies but negatively impact the health of the conversation?\nA new approach\nToday
column19: we use policies
column20: human review processes
column21: and machine learning to help us determine how Tweets are organized and presented in communal places like conversations and search. Now
column22: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re tackling issues of behaviors that distort and detract from the public conversation in those areas by integrating new behavioral signals into how Tweets are presented. By using new tools to address this conduct from a behavioral perspective
column23: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re able to improve the health of the conversation
column24: and everyone\u00e2\u0080\u0099s experience on Twitter
column25: without waiting for people who use Twitter to report potential issues to us.\nThere are many new signals we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re taking in
column26: most of which are not visible externally. Just a few examples include if an account has not confirmed their email address
column27: if the same person signs up for multiple accounts simultaneously
column28: accounts that repeatedly Tweet and mention accounts that don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t follow them
column29: or behavior that might indicate a coordinated attack. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also looking at how accounts are connected to those that violate our rules and how they interact with each other.\nThese signals will now be considered in how we organize and present content in communal areas like conversation and search. Because this content doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t violate our policies
column30: it will remain on Twitter
column31: and will be available if you click on \u00e2\u0080\u009cShow more replies\u00e2\u0080\u009d or choose to see everything in your search setting. The result is that people contributing to the healthy conversation will be more visible in conversations and search.\nResults\nIn our early testing in markets around the world
column32: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve already seen this new approach have a positive impact
column33: resulting in a 4% drop in abuse reports from search and 8% fewer abuse reports from conversations. That means fewer people are seeing Tweets that disrupt their experience on Twitter.\nOur work is far from done. This is only one part of our work to improve the health of the conversation and to make everyone\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Twitter experience better. This technology and our team will learn over time and will make mistakes. There will be false positives and things that we miss; our goal is to learn fast and make our processes and tools smarter. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to be open and honest about the mistakes we make and the progress we are making. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re encouraged by the results we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen so far
column34:
but also recognize that this is just one step on a much longer journey to improve the overall health of our service and your experience on it.

World Press Freedom Day 2018
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 9 May 2018\nLink copied successfully\nOn May 3 the world celebrated the 25th anniversary of World Press Freedom Day
column9: originally designated by the United Nations in 1993. This day serves as an annual reminder about the importance of freedom of the press in elevating public discourse
column10: illuminating issues of civic importance
column11: holding public officials accountable
column12: and strengthening democracy across the world. World Press Freedom Day carries special significance in the wake of the killing of ten journalists in Afghanistan on April 30 -the bloodiest day for reporters since the war began. \n\u00c2\u00a0\nTwitter was created 12 years ago to be a platform where anyone -- no matter where they are in the world -- can answer the question
column13: \u00e2\u0080\u009cWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening right now?\u00e2\u0080\u009d Today journalists
column14: NGOs
column15: and defenders of the free press play a vital part in answering that question on Twitter. Twitter stands with journalists as they practice their profession in precarious circumstances to bear witness to history and give insight into what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in their corner of the world. \u00c2\u00a0\n\u00c2\u00a0\nFor World Press Freedom Day 2018 Twitter activated a special #WorldPressFreedomDay emoji to help amplify individual voices coming together to share why they stand together in defense of press freedom. People who use Twitter across the world
column16: including journalists
column17: NGOs
column18: and government officials
column19:
united around this hashtag to stand up for a free press. Â

and during interviews:

column3: "title": "Keeping your account secure"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Keeping your account secure
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 3 May 2018\nLink copied successfully\nWhen you set a password for your Twitter account
column9: we use technology that masks it so no one at the company can see it. We recently identified a bug that stored passwords unmasked in an internal log. We have fixed the bug
column10: and our investigation shows no indication of breach or misuse by anyone.\nOut of an abundance of caution
column11: we ask that you consider changing your password on all services where you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve used this password. You can change your Twitter password anytime by going to the password\u00c2\u00a0settings\u00c2\u00a0page.\nAbout The Bug\nWe mask passwords through a process called hashing using a function known as bcrypt
column12: which replaces the actual password with a random set of numbers and letters that are stored in Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s system. This allows our systems to validate your account credentials without revealing your password. This is an industry standard.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nDue to a bug
column13: passwords were written to an internal log before completing the hashing process. We found this error ourselves
column14: removed the passwords
column15: and are implementing plans to prevent this bug from happening again.\nTips on Account Security\nAgain
column16: although we have no reason to believe password information ever left Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s systems or was misused by anyone
column17:
there are a few steps you can take to help us keep your account safe:
Change your password on Twitter and on any other service where you may have used the same password.
Use a strong password that you donât reuse on other websites.
Enable login verification
column18: also known as two factor authentication. This is the single best action you can take to increase your account security.\nUse a password manager to make sure you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re using strong
column19: unique passwords everywhere.\nWe are very sorry this happened. We recognize and appreciate the trust you place in us
column20:
and are committed to earning that trust every day.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter

column8: 1 May 2018\nLink copied successfully\nIn 2015
column9: we introduced Twitter to Windows users in the Microsoft store for mobile and desktop. Today we are proud to announce an updated experience through Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Progressive Web App (PWA).\nWith this new app
column10: we leveraged Microsoft\u00e2\u0080\u0099s support for Progressive Web Apps to bring users a better
column11: faster and improved experience they\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve come to expect from Twitter. This new app has been optimized for the Windows 10 April 2018 Update. Once you install the latest update you will notice that we streamlined the in-app experience with a more consistent look and feel. And
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve added several highly-requested features
column13:
like:
Extended character limit to 280 characters
Access to the Explore tab to find topics relevant to your interests
Ability to bookmark Tweets to be read later
Improved accessibility for screen readers
And much more
This Tweet is unavailable

This release represents a renewed commitment to Windows that has been long overdue and is part of a longer-term strategy to reach greater feature parity to all of our platforms. We wanted to make sure the app represented a modern Twitter experience
column14: while taking advantage of unique Windows features
column15: like support for Windows native APIs such as share integration
column16: pinned tiles
column17: jump links
column18: and more. We want to continue providing our Microsoft users with the latest and greatest
column19: and will be adding additional features like night mode
column20: in the coming weeks and months.\nWe encourage everyone to update the Windows app as soon as you update your OS as previous versions will no longer be available for download starting today and no longer supported starting June 1st. \u00c2\u00a0If you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re running Windows 8.1 or below

column3: "title": "Continuing Our Commitments to Privacy & Transparency"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Continuing Our Commitments to Privacy & Transparency
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 24 April 2018\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s purpose is to keep the world informed by serving the public conversation. We work hard to build a great experience for people Tweeting
column9: and seeing Tweets all over the world
column10: and protecting the privacy of the people who use Twitter every day. We believe you should know the types of data you share with us and how we use it. Most importantly
column11: you should have meaningful control over both. We want to empower you to make the best decisions about the information that you share with us and to ensure you feel confident that your data is protected and secure. As Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Data Protection Officer
column12: I will be working to continue our longstanding commitment to protecting you and upholding your right to privacy.\nHistory of Our Privacy Policies\nFrom the beginning
column13: Twitter has been a global platform for people to make themselves heard and to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening. We are proud of our history of partnering with civil society and standing up to governments to protect and defend the people that use our services
column14: and we continue to evolve our efforts around documenting our work.\nWe also recognize that to enjoy real freedom of expression
column15: you also need and deserve meaningful privacy and security controls. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s this very philosophy that has informed the process of updating and revising our Privacy Policy for everyone who uses Twitter around the world. \u00c2\u00a0We used this same philosophy in preparing our approach to the EU\u00e2\u0080\u0099s General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)
column16: which comes into effect next month.\nUpcoming Changes\nStarting this month
column17: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be introducing some changes to make it easier to manage your personal information on Twitter. As a first step
column18:
weâve updated our Privacy Policy to make it visually clear and easy to use. Youâll also see a download button at the top of the page that allows you to get a plain text version if you prefer. Itâs optimized for both mobile and web.
We want our Privacy Policy to be easy to understand and follow. What youâll see as you navigate through the policy is that we have broken it into seven main sections. This makes up the core of our approach.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Plain language.
Weâve expanded and revised content throughout the updated Privacy Policy to make sure that some of the more legalistic or technical language is as clear as possible. For example
column19: we think it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s absolutely essential that you know exactly what we mean when we refer to location data or data from advertising partners.\nPrivacy settings.\nWoven throughout are direct links to your core privacy and security settings
column20: which are accessible at any time when you are logged into Twitter. Here you can see what data Twitter has relating to your account and you can decide whether you want to share it or not. Over time
column21: as we learn how people use these controls
column22: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to work to improve them and Twitter as a whole. \u00c2\u00a0\nA conversation.\nWe welcome your comments and questions about our data practices. Within the Privacy Policy
column23: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll find an efficient way to contact Twitter directly about any privacy concerns you may have. When you contact Twitter
column24: only the Data Protection Officer (me) and my team have access to your questions. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll also keep you posted on our latest updates from @Policy.\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important to note that the new Privacy Policy will take effect on May 25th and will apply globally. By using our services on or after that date
column25: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be agreeing to these updates and Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s overall Terms of Service.\nNext Steps\nOn May 25th
column26: people who live in the EU who log into their Twitter account will see a prompt that will explain that we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve updated our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy to reflect the EU\u00e2\u0080\u0099s General Data Protection Regulation. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll also show you a simple chart that categorizes the legal basis for the personal data we process. Specifically
column27: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be encouraged to review our updated policies in full. You\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll then be brought to your individual Settings and Privacy section
column28: where we will ask you to review your key current settings. You can leave them all as they are
column29: modify each
column30: and learn more about any of the individual settings before making a change - the choice is entirely in your hands. \nRemember
column31: everyone around the world can use the controls we highlight to limit the information we collect about you or how we use it
column32: and change the settings at any time. For now
column33:
we encourage everyone to educate and empower themselves by reading our forthcoming Privacy Policy in full and to make your voice heard. 
Thank you for reading and thank you for your trust.
Â 
Â

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Serving the Public Conversation During Breaking Events"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Serving the Public Conversation During Breaking Events
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 5 April 2018\nLink copied successfully\nPeople come to Twitter first to learn about news and events unfolding in real-time
column9: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to ensuring that the information they receive is credible and authentic. Whether it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s real-time rescue efforts of Hurricane Harvey survivors in Texas
column10: capacity-building with Indian NGOs who aid flooded communities
column11: verifying credible voices after major events
column12: or sending prompts to French citizens in the wake of the November 2015 terrorist attacks in Paris
column13: our goal is to provide support to people in times of crisis
column14: and show people what matters most.\nOver the past few months
column15: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve refined our tools
column16: improved the speed of our response
column17: and identified areas where we can improve. In light of the horrific attack at YouTube headquarters this week
column18: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re sharing more detail on how we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re tackling an especially difficult and volatile challenge: our response to people who are deliberately manipulating the conversation on Twitter in the immediate aftermath of tragedies like this. In the 24 hours since this incident was first reported on Twitter there were more than 1.3 million Tweets about it
column19: reflecting just how quickly these conversations unfold and the sheer volume of information that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s shared.\nWhat Happened\nWhen information from the shooting at YouTube HQ started to appear on Twitter
column20: we saw credible and relevant information from individuals and news organizations. We also saw accounts deliberately sharing deceptive
column21: malicious information
column22: sometimes organizing on other networks to do so.\nThere are various policies we rely on in these types of situations
column23: but we do not have a policy under which Twitter validates content authenticity or accuracy. As we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve previously shared
column24: we strongly believe Twitter should not be the arbiter of truth. However
column25: we do see information shared on the service in a way that violates many of our existing policies
column26: as happened in the immediate aftermath of the attack in San Bruno. During these types of situations
column27: some of the ways we evaluate content include:\nIs the content posted to harass or abuse another person
column28:
violating our rules on abusive behavior?
Is this meant to incite fear against a protected category as outlined in our hateful conduct policy?
Could misrepresenting someone in this way cause real-world harm to the person who is targeted per our rules on violent threats?
Is this account attempting to manipulate or disrupt the conversation and violating our rules against spam?
Can we detect if this account owner has been previously suspended? As outlined in our range of enforcement options
column29: when someone is suspended from Twitter
column30: the former account owner is not allowed to create new accounts.\nUsing these policies and enforcement options as our rationale for evaluating the conversation surrounding the YouTube shooting
column31: we immediately started requiring account owners to remove Tweets \u00e2\u0080\u0094 many within minutes of their initial creation \u00e2\u0080\u0094 for violating our policies on abusive behavior. We also suspended hundreds of accounts for harassing others or purposely manipulating conversations about the event. Immediately following a crisis
column32: we rapidly implement proactive
column33: automated systems to prevent people who had been previously suspended from creating additional accounts to spam or harass others
column34: and to help surface potentially violating Tweets and accounts to our team for review.\nWhile we were removing Tweets and accounts that broke our rules
column35: our team was also focused on identifying and surfacing relevant and credible content people could trust. Moments highlighting reliable information were available in 16 countries and in five different languages \u00e2\u0080\u0094 many within 10 minutes of the first Tweets \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and also surfaced within top trends related to the situation. Throughout the incident and the following day
column36:
we continued to surface updates as they became available.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Where We Go From Here
This work is ongoing. We are continuing to explore and invest in what more we can do with our technology
column37: enforcement options
column38: and policies \u00e2\u0080\u0093 not just in the U.S.
column39: but to everyone we serve around the world. Initial ideas include better use of our technology to catch people working to evade a suspension and identifying malicious
column40: automated accounts
column41:
and more quickly activating our team to ensure a human review element continues to be present within our all of automated processes.
We're committed to continuing to improve and to holding ourselves accountable as we work to make Twitter better for everyone. Weâre looking forward to sharing more soon.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Expanding and building #TwitterTransparency"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nExpanding and building #TwitterTransparency\nThursday
column8: 5 April 2018\nLink copied successfully\nWith our 12th biannual Twitter Transparency Report
column9: we continue to expand and build upon our commitment to providing meaningful transparency about requests we receive to disclose account information or remove content. In particular
column10: we are announcing updates on our work to permanently suspend terrorist accounts from Twitter
column11: more granular data on our country-withheld content policy
column12: and expanded reporting on requests for account information.\nOver 1.2 Million Accounts Suspended for Terrorist Content Since August 2015 \nDuring the reporting period of July 1
column13: 2017 through December 31
column15: a total of 274
column16: 460 accounts were permanently suspended for violations related to the promotion of terrorism. This is down 8.4% from the volume shared in the previous reporting period and is the second consecutive reporting period in which we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen a drop in the number of accounts being suspended for this reason. We continue to see the positive
column17: significant impact of years of hard work making our site an undesirable place for those seeking to promote terrorism
column18: resulting in this type of activity increasingly shifting away from Twitter.\nBetween August 1
column19: 2015 and December 31
column21: we suspended 1
column23: 357 accounts from Twitter for violations related to the promotion of terrorism.\u00c2\u00a0 Of those 274
column24: 460 accounts suspended in the last reporting period
column25: 93% were flagged by internal
column26: proprietary tools
column27: and 74% of those accounts were suspended before their first Tweet. Government reports of violations related to the promotion of terrorism represent less than 0.2% of all suspensions in the most recent reporting period and reflect a 50% reduction in accounts reported compared to the previous reporting period.\nIncreasing Country Withheld Content Transparency\nIn December 2017
column28: we updated our in-product messaging about withheld content to more precisely explain the reason for withholding. Subsequently
column29: we began to differentiate between legal demands (e.g.
column30: court orders) and reports based on local law(s) (e.g.
column31: reports alleging the illegality of content in a particular country). These changes are now reflected in this latest Transparency Report
column32: which includes details about removal requests from trusted reporters and non-governmental organizations that we reviewed for potential violations of local law(s). More details are available in the expanded Removal Requests report.\nExpanding US County-Level Transparency Reporting\nIn our last Transparency Report
column33: we introduced a breakdown of non-federal information requests from California at the county level. We are now expanding this section to include counties from the other top non-federal requesters: Florida
column34: Maryland
column35: New York
column36: and Virginia.\nLegal Threats to Freedom of Expression\nWith the passage of new legislation and ongoing regulatory discussions taking place around the world about the future of public discourse online
column37: we are seeing a potential chilling effect with regards to freedom of expression. According to Human Rights Watch
column38: the wave of regulatory pressure in Europe and beyond is setting an emerging precedent and creating a \u00e2\u0080\u009cdomino effect\u00e2\u0080\u009d as \u00e2\u0080\u009cgovernments around the world increasingly look to restrict online speech by forcing social media companies to act as their censors.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nAs regulators explore further potential restrictions
column39: transparency is one of the most important ways we can continue to protect freedom of expression. Twitter is proud of our industry-leading policies regarding transparency about content restrictions. This includes our practice of uploading actioned requests to withhold content to Lumen
column40: an independent database that collects and analyzes removal requests for content online (unless we are prohibited from doing so
column41: e.g.
column42: if we receive a court order under seal). Lumen serves as a critical transparency resource as more freedom of expression comes under fire
column43: by making such requests available for public review. \u00c2\u00a0Additionally
column44: upon receipt of requests to withhold content
column45: we promptly notify affected users (unless
column46: like with our Lumen uploads
column47: we are otherwise prohibited from doing so).\nPublic Health and Transparency\nOur commitment to transparency around how we enforce our Terms of Service and the Twitter Rules is part of our effort to increase the collective health
column48: openness
column49: and civility of public conversation around the world
column50: and to hold ourselves publicly accountable toward progress. As we explore how we can best measure the health of the public conversation
column51:
we will look for ways to provide transparency around any new public health metrics. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet

column7: "post_text": "Events\nTake the field with @MLB on Twitter in 2018\nTuesday
column8: 3 April 2018\nLink copied successfully\nA new Major League Baseball season is here as fans of all 30 @MLB teams were following every season-opening pitch on Opening Day last week. A historic Opening Day such as this is a reminder that fans around the world will turn to Twitter to follow their favorite teams
column9: players and chatter about the news on and off the diamond in real time.\nNo matter where their allegiances lie
column10: all fans can count on Twitter for nonstop baseball action. Once again during the 2018 season
column11: live streams of weekly @MLB games will happen on Twitter.\n@MLB will launch its weekly Twitter game of the week on Thursday
column12: April 5
column13: with out-of-market live streaming of the Texas Rangers (@Rangers) taking on the Oakland Athletics (@Athletics) at 3:35 PM ET. As part of a renewed partnership with MLB
column14: this game is the first of the weekly day-game live streams of out-of-market MLB games Twitter will make available once per week throughout the 2018 season.\nThe weekly games will be available in the United States for free to logged-in and logged-out users on Twitter and connected devices via live.twitter.com/MLB and @MLB. Each weekly stream will be a simulcast of a participating team\u00e2\u0080\u0099s local television broadcast. Twitter will offer advertising packages for the content to be made available to sponsors.\nAgain this year
column15: MLB will also make real-time game highlights available for fans from @MLB on Twitter throughout the season
column16:
offering additional ways to follow all of the baseball action this season at home or on the go. Spanish highlights will also be available from @LasMayores throughout 2018. 
Below is the April schedule for the Twitter MLB Game of the Week (subject to change).

column3: "title": "Introducing Timestamps: A new way to share live videos"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Introducing Timestamps: A new way to share live videos
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 29 March 2018\nLink copied successfully\nBrevity is the soul of Twitter. Today we're introducing an easy way to Tweet that brief moment of what matters from longer
column9: live videos.\nSometimes
column10: we want to draw attention to the specific moment in a live video that made us think
column11: surprised us
column12: or made us laugh. Previously
column13: we could only Tweet an entire live video
column14:
which made it difficult to discuss what matters most. We saw people Tweeting with the specific time in the video directing us to the part they wanted us to watch.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
So
column15: we built Timestamps which lets anyone Tweet a live or replay video starting from the exact moment they want to discuss.\nSharing Timestamps is easy. When you tap to share a live video
column16: you can easily slide back to the exact time you want your audience to watch. From there
column17: add your thoughts
column18: and Tweet it to the world. This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. Your browser does not support the video element. Play Play Pause Seek 0% buffered 00:00 Current time 00:00 Duration 00:00 Toggle Mute Volume Anyone seeing your Tweet will start watching at the time within the video you shared. If the broadcast is still live
column19: they can easily skip to what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening by tapping \u00e2\u0080\u009clive\u00e2\u0080\u009d at any time. The feature is available for any live video
column20: whether from a professional content publisher or someone broadcasting from their phone.\nPeople have always used Twitter to talk about the things they experience. With Timestamps
column21: now we can show rather than just tell everyone what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening. This update is rolling out today on Twitter for Android and iOS
column22:
Twitter.com and Periscope; read more about how to share from Periscope here.

column3: "title": "Black History is #WhatsHappening"
column7: "post_text": "Events\nBlack History is #WhatsHappening\nTuesday
column8: 27 March 2018\nLink copied successfully\nBlack History Month is an annual celebration which highlights the achievements of Black communities in America. At Twitter
column9: @Blackbirds
column10: our Business Resource Group (BRG) for members and allies of the African diaspora at Twitter
column11: led the way in planning events along with other BRGs
column12: Teams and Twitter offices. This year's theme was #GlowUp
column13: and Tweeps participated in over 30 #BlackHistoryMonth events
column14:
ranging from professional development workshops to self-care meet-ups and fireside chats with industry and community figures.
Hereâs a look at some of the highlights:
Community EngagementÂ  Â 
The Public Policy team hosted Civil Rights legend
column15: @RepJohnLewis
column17: Between Harlem and Heaven
column18: as well as his African-inspired recipes
column19: with the event #AskChefJJ.\nTwitter worked with with Disney to host a live Q&A with the cast of Black Panther and screening of the film
column20:
which is the most Tweeted about movie of all time.
Twitter hosted over 100 professionals from the community for a night of thought provoking poetry night @TwitterSF
Recruiting #BeTheChange Â Â 
As part of their #BeTheChange series
column21:
@TwitterU hosted change makers @deray and @LeonFordSpeaks to meet with local students @TwitterNYC and @TwitterDC.
Â 
Service
To kickoff #BlackHistoryMonth
column23: @Blackbirds engaged with their local community by serving breakfast at @NYCommonPantry.\nTwitter believes in the unmatched power of the individual\u00e2\u0080\u0099s voice. The platform allows users to share stories
column24: learn more about the world
column25: and connect with others across time and space. As a company
column26: we are committed to #GrowTogether through diversity and we will use the momentum gained from #BlackHistoryMonth to continue to guide us forward.\nAlthough we celebrate #BlackHistoryMonth
column27: we recognize that Black history is being made every month of the year. If you want to know #WhatsHappening
column28:
make sure to follow @Blackbirds! Â Â 
Â 
Â 
Â

column3: "title": "Growing Together at Twitter"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nGrowing Together at Twitter\nFriday
column8: 2 March 2018\nLink copied successfully\nAt Twitter
column9: we see an incredibly vibrant and diverse conversation on our service every day
column10: and we strive to reflect this within our company. We know our best work comes from having a diverse workforce and we are constantly seeking new perspectives to make our company stronger.\nA New Approach\nWhen I joined Twitter in 2017
column11: my first priority was to listen and learn. I spent time with leaders and employees around the world
column12: assessing our strategy around inclusion and diversity and aligning with the newly formed people leadership team. Across the board I saw passion
column13: authenticity
column14: and a deep commitment. A solid foundation was in place \u00e2\u0080\u0093 but the world is changing fast
column15: and we still have more to do.\nGiven the unique role Twitter plays in the world
column16: we decided to approach the concept of diversity differently. Our goal is to create a more inclusive culture and diverse workforce by developing a strategy that begins with building a foundation of respect and understanding. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re focused on powering positive change by fostering respectful conversations
column17: creating deeper human connections
column18: and encouraging diverse interactions across the company. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re calling this strategy Intersectionality
column19: Culture and Diversity (ICD) and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re making it a part of everything we do at Twitter.\nA New Campaign\nAs part of this broader ICD strategy we introduced #GrowTogether
column20: a campaign that encourages our people around the world to make personal commitments toward fostering an inclusive workplace. From day-to-day work practices and policies
column21: to people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s engagement with leadership and with each other
column22: we aim to create and sustain a commitment to inclusion in everything we do.\nTo kick off
column23: we began a listening tour across our offices globally
column24: mindful that the experience of inclusion is not the same around the world
column25: or even across all of our U.S. offices. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re activating programming for our people to foster intersectionality and respect for similarities and differences
column26: enabling and encouraging everyone to bring every part of themselves to work. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also learning about what makes each office unique and special
column27:
as well as what Twitter can do better to make their experiences more inclusive. 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Inside
column28: Out\nIn addition to implementing #GrowTogether
column29: we furthered our commitment to a more inclusive world by fostering important conversations on our service
column30: creating programs that build a culture of inclusion
column31: and partnering with organizations that are focused on building more diverse workplaces across the broader tech industry.\nWe harnessed the power of our platform to develop global campaigns celebrating diversity
column32: including #HereWeAre
column33: #SheInspiresMe
column34: #HispanicHeritageMonth
column35: #PrideIsHappening and #ForTheCulture. These hashtags serve as a helpful tool to build community around important issues
column36: creating momentum that leads to movements.\nWe continued partnering with organizations such as Girls Who Code and Code2040 and hosted the 2017 Women Who Code Connect Conference. We also attended some of the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s largest gatherings of diverse tech talent including ADCOLOR
column37: AfroTech
column38: National Center for Women & Information Technology
column39: and Tech Inclusion
column40: with the goal of fostering professional development within Twitter and meeting and recruiting diverse talent.\nWith our University Recruiting team
column41: we followed diverse talent to strengthen our pipeline and had active presences at Grace Hopper
column42: National Society of Black Engineers
column43: and the Society of Hispanic Engineers
column44: always looking for more ways to find the next generation of diverse tech leaders.\nWe created and implemented new programs: #EarlyBird focused on first-year students interested in computer science who identify as Black
column45: Hispanic/Latinx and/or Native American
column46: #TechProud brought together second year students interested in computer sciences who identify as LGBTQIA+
column47: and #DevelopHER invited second year female students interested in computer science to Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0\nOur Business Resource Groups (BRGs
column48: formerly Employee Resource Groups) are instrumental to fostering diverse communities at Twitter and providing programming to help us celebrate the cultures and identities of our people. Both on the platform and off
column49: @TwitterAlas
column50: @TwitterAsians @Blackbirds
column51: @TwitterOpen
column52: @TwitterParents
column53: @TwitterStripes
column54: and @TwitterWomen create spaces where individuals and allies can come together. Our partnership with the BRGs
column56: more closely aligned their 2018 efforts with our business goals.\nIn 2017
column57: \u00c2\u00a0the @TwitterWomen #SheInspiresMe highlighted the power of women on our service.\nFor the second year
column58: @TwitterOpen\u00e2\u0080\u0099s work help us achieve 100% compliance with Human Rights Campaign's Corporate Equality Index.\nFor more on how our BRGs spent 2017
column59: check out these Moments: @TwitterAlas
column60: @TwitterAsians
column61: \u00c2\u00a0@Blackbirds
column62: @TwitterOpen
column63: @TwitterParents
column64: @TwitterStripes
column65: and @TwitterWomen\nOur 2017 Results\nWith our commitment to creating an even more inclusive and diverse community at Twitter
column66:
weâve seen progress in hiring and career development and encouraged company-wide commitments to a more inclusive culture.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Our Goals
We know we have more work to do
column67: so we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re making some changes to our goals and how we report them moving forward. As part of our new approach to ICD
column68: we took a critical look at our workforce and reframed our goals to put specific focus on increasing overall women
column69: Black
column70: and Latinx representation
column71: areas which continue to be underrepresented in tech. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve set our goals for a two year period
column72: which allows us to better assess our progress
column73: develop specific programming
column74:
and adapt our strategies along the way. We will continue to publicly report our progress regularly as we work to achieve these goals over the next two years.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
While these goals allow us to focus on three key areas
column75: they are just part of our overall ICD strategy. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re implementing strategies to source diverse talent
column76: putting forth programs that create shared ownership across all functions
column77: and integrating an intersectional mindset into our business culture. We want to help people learn from others different from themselves
column78: have respectful conversations
column79: and make more diverse connections with people around the world.\nICD is becoming an integral part of what we do at every level of the company \u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00c2\u00a0to see what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re up to
column80:
follow us @TwitterTogether.
Â 
Â 
Â 
UPDATE:Â We released our diversity report this morning which included a graph that caused some confusion. We want to apologize and clarify.
Consistent with prior years
column81: we disclosed percentages of a category we labeled as Underrepresented Minorities (URM)
column82: which included all non-white and non-asian employees.\nURM also included employees who declined to self-identify
column83: which was not clear in the report and appeared to conflict with the race/ethnicity breakdown we reported. Based on feedback
column84: we realized this was confusing and\u00e2\u0080\u008b we \u00e2\u0080\u008bremoved URM percentages from our report. \u00e2\u0080\u008b\nThe race/ethnicity breakdown in the report is more accurate and granular than URM which we had already decided to move away from. Our new goals put specific focus on increasing overall women
column86: and Latinx representation\u00e2\u0080\u008b at Twitter
column87:
and we're holding ourselves accountable.
Â 
EEO-1 Report
Our EEO-1 report is prepared annually to conform to US government requirements. Those requirements categorize job functions in ways that differ from how Twitter and other companies look at their workforces
column88:
and direct the use of visual identification with respect to employees who have not self identified. Our diversity report provides the best insights into our workforce and many of our key efforts to advance our commitment to inclusion and diversity. 
Click here to see our 2017 EEO-1 report.
Â

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Twitter health metrics proposal submission"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Twitter health metrics proposal submission
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 1 March 2018\nLink copied successfully\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committing to helping increase the collective health
column9: openness
column10: and civility of public conversation around the world
column11: and to hold ourselves publicly accountable toward progress. By measuring our contribution to the overall health of the public conversation
column12: we believe we can more holistically approach and measure our impact on the world for years to come.\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s health will be built and measured by how we help encourage more healthy debate
column13: conversations
column14: and critical thinking; conversely
column15: abuse
column16: spam and manipulation will detract from it. We are looking to partner with outside experts to help us identify how we measure the health of Twitter
column17: keep us accountable to share our progress with the world and establish a way forward for the long-term.\nThis approach is inspired by work from others in the industry. Cortico
column18: a non-profit research organization
column19: has spent time to more deeply understand the concept of measuring conversational health and developed four indicators to measure it: shared attention
column20: shared reality
column21: variety of opinion
column22: and receptivity. We believe that we can identify indicators of conversational health that are even more specific to Twitter and its impact.\nWe don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t have all of the answers and cannot do this alone
column23: but know that the outcome will be stronger when we look to experts around the world for counsel and support. If you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re interested in helping us define what health means for Twitter and how we should approach measuring it
column24: please submit your proposal through the form below by Friday
column25: April 13.\nTo Apply\nApplicants should submit a proposal through the online form available below by Friday
column26: April 13
column27: that includes:\nContact information (name
column28: email
column29: organizational details)\nYour proposed health metrics
column30: and methods for capturing
column31: measuring
column32: evaluating and reporting on such metrics\nAnticipated resource requirements and methodology\nProposed output from your proposal and estimated time needed to capture
column33: measure and evaluate health metrics\nRelevant
column34: peer-reviewed
column35:
publications and papers
Please make clear in your proposal if this is a joint application with another institution.
Award
Successful applicants will collaborate directly with Twitterâs team
column36: receive public data access and meaningful funding for their research. Funding will be provided as an unrestricted gift to the proposer\u00e2\u0080\u0099s organization(s)
column37: to be provided in full at the start of the project.\nOur expectation is that successful projects will produce peer-reviewed
column38: publicly available
column39: open-access research articles and open source software whenever possible.\nTimeline\nSubmissions are due Friday
column40: April 13
column41: and selected applicants will be invited to share further details on their proposals during May and June. We expect to announce the first selected projects in July.\nTerms of Agreement\nThis proposal request in no way constitutes an agreement between Twitter and any applicant. \u00c2\u00a0The issuance of this proposal request does not imply that Twitter is making an offer to do business. Twitter reserves the right
column42: in its sole discretion
column43: to cancel this solicitation and proposal request at any time during the process. \u00c2\u00a0This proposal request is not and shall not be considered an \u00e2\u0080\u009cagreement to negotiate.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Twitter reserves the right to make any award
column44: group of awards
column45: or no award as it determines in its sole discretion. Twitter may
column46: in its discretion
column47: amend
column48: supplement
column49: terminate
column50: modify
column51: negotiate or otherwise change any provision or part of this proposal request
column52: including but not limited to the evaluation criteria
column53: the process used for evaluation
column54: and/or the expected timeline
column55: at any time prior. Any award of this contract will be made to applicant(s) at the sole discretion of Twitter after consideration of the factors stated above.\u00c2\u00a0 Twitter shall provide only public Twitter data (which shall be used solely for the purposes stated above) and such use shall be subject to additional terms and conditions (including
column56: but not limited to
column57: terms similar to Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Developer Terms). Further terms may be included in a contract with successful applications.\nUPDATE: Proposal submission period ended on April 13
column58:
2018.

column3: "title": "An easier way to save and share Tweets"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
An easier way to save and share Tweets
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 28 February 2018\nLink copied successfully\nFrom articles and threads to videos and GIFs
column9: timelines are packed with Tweets that you don't always have time to fully explore in the moment. You\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve told us you want to save them for later.\nHello
column10: Bookmarks!\nToday
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re introducing Bookmarks
column12: an easy way to save Tweets for quick access later. But wait
column13: there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s more! Today\u00e2\u0080\u0099s update makes sharing better
column14: too. With our new \u00e2\u0080\u009cshare\u00e2\u0080\u009d icon on every Tweet
column15: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be able to bookmark a Tweet
column16: share via Direct Message
column17: or share off of Twitter any number of ways. Because we put all sharing actions together in one place
column18: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s easier to save and share privately or publicly \u00e2\u0080\u0094 in the moment
column19: or later.\nHow It Works\nTo bookmark a Tweet
column20: tap the share icon under the Tweet and select
column21: \u00e2\u0080\u009cAdd Tweet to Bookmarks\u00e2\u0080\u009d. To find it later
column22: tap \u00e2\u0080\u009cBookmarks\u00e2\u0080\u009d from your profile icon menu. You can remove Tweets from your Bookmarks at any time. Also
column23: only you can see what you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve bookmarked. Learn more about how to bookmark in our\u00c2\u00a0Help Center. \nBookmarks help people keep up with the best of Twitter. You can save a Tweet with a live morning show like Buzzfeed\u00e2\u0080\u0099s #AM2DM to watch at another time
column24: bookmark a thread from @Lin_Manuel about new Hamilton music to come back to
column25: and save Tweets with links to interesting articles for later reading or sharing. You\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll no doubt show us more creative uses for Bookmarks than we ever imagined! (You have a tendency to do that on Twitter.)\nBetter Because of Your Feedback\nWe Tweeted ongoing updates as we built Bookmarks so we could incorporate your input as we worked. By working this way
column26: we learned that you like to save replies so you can answer later and that you may share a Tweet hours or days later after you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve bookmarked it. Thank you for being part of this process \u00e2\u0080\u0094 your feedback was valuable in building this update
column27: and it made it all the more fun for us as we built a new feature for you. As a result
column28: we all have an easier way to save
column29: share
column30: and stay informed.\nBookmarks are now rolling out globally on Twitter for iOS and Android
column31: Twitter Lite
column32:
and mobile.twitter.com. Thanks for your collaboration to make Bookmarks happen. Happy bookmarking!
https://twitter.com/Twitter/status/968908969019260928 
https://twitter.com/TwitterEng/status/968909261563506688 
Â 
Â

column3: "title": "Update on Amplify Publisher Program requirements"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Update on Amplify Publisher Program requirements
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 22 February 2018\nLink copied successfully\nPublishers who share content on Twitter are a critical part of the rich conversation happening on the platform each day. We believe that a healthy ecosystem for publishers is paramount to helping people see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in the world
column9: and we will continue to help publishers succeed. Because of our revenue-share model
column10: success on both ends comes from true partnership. After nearly 5 years investing in Amplify and new digital creator models
column11: we are proud of how our efforts have grown
column12: now extending to over ten markets across the globe. Many publishers are seeing record revenue
column13: with a 60 percent year over year increase in 2017 payout to publishers through our suite of monetization products: In-Stream Video Ads and Sponsorships
column14: Periscope Super Hearts and Niche.\n\u00c2\u00a0\nThe Amplify Publisher Program was created to make it easy for publishers to monetize video on Twitter
column15: and also turn-key for advertisers to align with brand-safe content. By working closely with the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s premiere TV networks
column16: sports leagues and teams
column17: digital publishers
column18: advertisers and agencies
column19: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve gained an understanding of our partners\u00e2\u0080\u0099 needs.\n\u00c2\u00a0\nToday
column20: we are sharing an update to our eligibility requirements for new and existing publishers as part of the Amplify Publisher Program. These requirements
column21: which apply to In-Stream Video Ads and Sponsorships
column22: will strengthen our partnership with those who adhere to Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Safe for Ads guidelines
column23:
newly updated today. We believe this will provide more clarity on what is acceptable to be monetized.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Premium publishers must meet the following criteria:
Be verified
Publish brand-safe content according toÂ Safe For AdsÂ content guidelines
Be an active Twitter video publisher
Accept the Amplify Publisher Program Terms & Conditions
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
These eligibility requirements ensure that brands can reach their target audience while aligning with premium publisher content. Marketers often have to choose between quality and scale when they choose to advertise
column24:
but can get both by leveraging In-Stream Video Ads on Twitter.
Â 
Amplify Publisher Program is just one of the many ways publishers and creators can monetize their content on Twitter. Programs likeÂ Periscope Super HeartsÂ andÂ NicheÂ also empower publishers to extend their reach and give people an opportunity to make a career out of their content.
Â 
Changes to the program requirements will be enacted in the coming weeks. Publishers can reach out to their partner manager with any questions.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Bridging the gap between the consumer and the advertiser"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Bridging the gap between the consumer and the advertiser
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 14 February 2018\nLink copied successfully\nAs we look ahead to 2018
column9: I could not be more excited with what we have carved out. More than ever
column10: we will be focused on developing new products and features that truly help advertisers leverage the unique strengths of Twitter - helping brands be what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nGetting back to basics: connecting the consumer with the advertiser.\nTo ensure a clearer focus as a team
column11: we needed to strip ourselves from thinking product-first
column12: and go deep in understanding our customers\u00e2\u0080\u0099 (and clients\u00e2\u0080\u0099) emotional and functional needs.\nWe did this by first understanding at the core
column13: why do people come to Twitter? We know that they come to see and talk about what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening - that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s what makes Twitter special. By developing stronger synergies and really understanding where consumers are spending their time and how they are spending their time
column14: we will be able to build the best advertising solutions that truly leverage what makes Twitter unique and different.\nUnderstanding how to scale our platform.\nFrom finding the intersection between the consumer and advertiser
column15: we then took a step back to understand what our role is specifically for brands. We found that brands come to Twitter for three main reasons:\nTo launch something new to the marketplace
column16: such as a product or new campaign.\nTo connect with what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening
column17: and what people are talking about.\nTo promote their brand story
column18: and ongoing branding campaigns.\nEach of these pillars help grow a brand\u00e2\u0080\u0099s business by achieving specific goals
column19: whether it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s raising awareness around a new product
column20: engaging with existing and new customers
column21: or simply having a cohesive brand voice. By honing in on these three categories
column22: and understanding how the consumer falls under each
column23: we can focus on that sweet spot that sits between the consumer and the advertiser.\nOver the course of 2017
column24: we launched key product enhancements that have helped us better fulfill these advertiser needs
column25: such as:\nPromoting your brand\u00e2\u0080\u0099s story with more effective formats. With the recently introduced Video Website Card
column26: we have made it easy for people to learn more about a brand by allowing them to tap right into deeper content directly through a brand\u00e2\u0080\u0099s video. And since the video continues to play while the site is loading
column27: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen significant increases in time spent on the site.\nConnecting with what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening via live event sponsorships. To further connect with what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening
column28: Twitter offers a unique opportunity for brands to sponsor events
column29: whether it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s in the lead-up
column30: during
column31: or after. This is a great way to connect in real-time with what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening
column32: and brands such as HP are finding success with this innovative type of sponsorship. Â  Â  This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. Your browser does not support the video element. Play Play Pause Seek 0% buffered 00:00 Current time 00:00 Duration 00:00 Toggle Mute Volume Whatâs next? As we look ahead to 2018
column33:
we want to continue to drive the consumer-advertiser intersection and make it easier than ever for brands to reach their objectives. We will do so by focusing on the following:
Investing in innovative formats that empower brands to express themselves. We will continue to create advertising solutions that are unique while still embracing formats that we know work.
Improving advertiser's ability to target audiences through increased machine learning and new planning tools. We will enable advertisers to reach new audiences by launching new targeting products built on our unique Twitter data. We will also improve planning and forecasting tools to help advertisers accurately predict what their campaigns will achieve before they launch.
Making it easier to advertise on Twitter by developing a more seamless way to buy. We are going to continue to make it easier to buy on Twitter to ensure a seamless experience from the very beginning. We are also testing new ways to buy ads
column34: including third-party demand
column35: and are currently learning from these tests.\nWe are going back to basics
column36: while using our machine learning capabilities to help connect our advertisers to the best and most relevant content and customers. We are excited for what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s to come
column37:
and will be providing regular updates along the way. Hereâs to a great 2018!

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Twitter Celebrates #SaferInternetDay 2018 "
column7: "post_text": "Company\nTwitter Celebrates #SaferInternetDay 2018 \nThursday
column8: 8 February 2018\nLink copied successfully\nThe theme for Safer Internet Day 2018 (@safeinternetday) - a better Internet starts with you - speaks to our values as a platform. Twitter shows the world what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening. We all contribute
column9: we all have our part to play.\nSafety is an integral part of everything we do as a company. We recognize that to express yourself on our platform
column10: you must feel safe. Over the past 12 months
column11: we've introduced a range of new policies and tools to improve Twitter for everyone
column12: including refinements to the core of our product. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also launched a brand new Safety Center and met and engaged with our Trust & Safety Council for the first ever Twitter Trust & Safety Summit
column13: with the goal of soliciting their direct
column14: expert feedback on our vision for a safer Twitter.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re seeing results. By leveraging our technology
column15: improving our core functionality
column16: and introducing a host of brand new features
column17: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen a marked improvement. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also providing better user education and demonstrating increased transparency around our decision-making and the philosophy behind the Twitter Rules.\nTo celebrate the global conversation around internet safety
column18: we launched a special emoji that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s activated by using the hashtags #SaferInternetDay and #SID2018. The emoji helped to unify and strengthen the conversation around Safer Internet Day
column19: encouraging users to create
column20: connect
column21: and share respect online. So far
column22: there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s been more than 100
column23: 000 Tweets using the dedicated hashtags
column24: generating 6
column26:
275 impressions.  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Â 
Colin Crowell
column27: VP
column28: Global Public Policy & Corporate Philanthropy
column29: Twitter
column30: commented:\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cSafer Internet Day salutes the unparalleled potential and opportunity of the internet. This potential
column31: if harnessed creatively
column32: safely
column33: and securely
column34: can further the public good and elevate civic conversation worldwide. To get there
column35: we must work together as it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s our shared responsibility. For our part
column36: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve taken big strides forward over the last year across our policies
column37: product
column38: and educational outreach to improve the Twitter experience for everyone. For now
column39: we thank our partners across the globe for their ongoing support and counsel. They make us better and we value their insights and expertise greatly. Create
column40: connect
column41: and share respect using the hashtags #SaferInternetDay and #SID2018.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nSarah Willoughby
column42: Insafe Team at European Schoolnet (EUN)
column43: commented: \u00e2\u0080\u009cTwitter has always been strong supporters of Safer Internet Day and
column44: as coordinators of the Insafe network of helplines and awareness centres
column45: we very much value the relationship that we have with them. Raising awareness of the benefits but also the challenges of the internet and online communications is crucial
column46: and the SID emoji helps to highlight our messages and encourage public discussion
column47: dialogue and debate.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nIn Europe
column48: @TwitterDublin and @TwitterUK worked with the Insafe Team to coordinate the launch and promotion of the global #SaferInternetDay emoji
column49: while also supporting the promotion of content through @safeinternetday and @UK_SIC. Across the continent
column50: we supported partners such as @Webwise in Ireland and @klicksafe in Germany through our Ads for Good program
column51: ensuring that their voice and core message was elevated on Safer Internet Day and beyond.\nIn Singapore
column52: @TwitterSG hosted the Singapore Media Literacy Council\u00e2\u0080\u0099s launch of its 2018 #BetterInternetSG campaign. Together with key social outreach organisations and the Digital Quotient Institute
column53: @TwitterSG will partner with the Media Literacy Council throughout 2018
column54: conducting digital literacy workshops for parents. With our support
column55:
a parentsâ resource for the online space will also be created in all four official languages of Singapore. This targeted resource will include Twitter safety tips and best practices.
Â

In Indonesia
column56: we invited\u00c2\u00a0@DamarJuniarto\u00c2\u00a0from the South East Asia Freedom of Expression Network (@SAFEnetvoice) to write a guest\u00c2\u00a0blog\u00c2\u00a0and to share some tips to stay safe on the internet. We then amplified this across Indonesia using\u00c2\u00a0@TwitterID. There is also ongoing discussion of collaboration with SAFEnet for a possible joint campaign during Safer Internet Month later this year. \nIn India

column59: @MumbaiPolice

and @YouthKiAwaaz to use the emoji to drive civic conversation.

column100: more secure environment online

and amplified Safernet's content through @TwitterBrasil.

column39: data and buzz

column3: "title": "Twitter invites brands to compete in first-ever #BrandBowl"
column7: "post_text": "Events\nTwitter invites brands to compete in first-ever #BrandBowl\nMonday
column8:
29 January 2018
Link copied successfully
#SB52 is whatâs happening.
Thereâs no better place than Twitter to reach consumers during major live moments - and the Super Bowl is no exception. Last year alone
column9: there were 27.6 million Tweets about the Super Bowl
column10: and 5.6 billion views of those Tweets.\nAs one of the crown jewels of live events
column11: Twitter is the place to turn to be a part of what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening around the big game. Twitter sees close to a 20% lift in unique visitors during the Super Bowl. And that audience isn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t just passively checking Twitter during the game
column12: they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re spending significant time keeping up with and joining the commentary. In fact
column13: during the game
column14: Twitter sees a +14% increase in time spent in the app*. Simply put
column15:
users know that watching the Super Bowl is a significantly better experience when youâre watching it with Twitter and millions of others across the world.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Introducing #BrandBowl52**
We all know that the Super Bowl isnât just about the game
column16: but also about the creative ads in between the big plays and touchdowns. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why today we are announcing the first-ever #BrandBowl - Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s official competition and service to honor the best-in-class campaigns as played out on Twitter.\nStarting today
column17: people will be able to Retweet a Tweet from @TwitterMKTG to be notified when new spots air in real-time during the game. On gameday
column18: subscribers will receive automated notifications after each quarter with a Twitter Moment that will feature the ad spots that aired in that quarter. After the game
column19:
people will get a final notification alerting them to explore the winners of #BrandBowl52.
Â 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Winners and Prizes
Winners will be broken into the following categories:
#MVP: Brand with the highest percentage of all brand related Tweets during #SB52
#Blitz: Brand who drove the highest velocity of most Tweets-per-minute
#QuarterBack:Brand with the most Retweets on a single Tweet during #SB52
#Interception: Brand without a national TV spot that drove the highest % of brand conversation
We will also honor brands that have received the highest percentage of all in-game brand conversation versus category competitors across the following industries: CPG
column20: dining
column21: entertainment
column22: technology & telecommunications
column23: automotive
column24: alc-bev
column25: home & healthcare
column26: financial services
column27: retail
column28: and travel.\nWinners will receive a suite of exclusive ad products and custom consumer research opportunities to fuel their future Twitter campaigns in 2018
column29: as well as special inclusion in\u00c2\u00a0BuzzFeed News' live morning show
column30: AM to DM
column31: the morning after gameday. Additionally
column32: all winning brands will receive custom trophies for their brand headquarters
column33: media
column34: and creative agencies.\nBe sure to tune back here following the game and to\u00c2\u00a0BuzzFeed News' AM to DM the morning after to find out who the winners are. Let the games begin
column35:
and be sure to follow along on Twitter!
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
*Twitter changes the live TV sports viewing experience
column36: 2017\n**Methodology: Only brands who have enrolled in the Twitter #BrandBowl52 competition will be eligible for inclusion in the Super Subscribe Moment and prize consideration. A team of data scientists from Twitter's Semantic Core team will be monitoring the conversation from coin flip to the final whistle of the game
column37:
tracking the brands and ad spots driving the conversation on Twitter.

column3: "title": "Bridging the gap between the consumer and the advertiser"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Bridging the gap between the consumer and the advertiser
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 14 February 2018\nLink copied successfully\nAs we look ahead to 2018
column9: I could not be more excited with what we have carved out. More than ever
column10: we will be focused on developing new products and features that truly help advertisers leverage the unique strengths of Twitter - helping brands be what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nGetting back to basics: connecting the consumer with the advertiser.\nTo ensure a clearer focus as a team
column11: we needed to strip ourselves from thinking product-first
column12: and go deep in understanding our customers\u00e2\u0080\u0099 (and clients\u00e2\u0080\u0099) emotional and functional needs.\nWe did this by first understanding at the core
column13: why do people come to Twitter? We know that they come to see and talk about what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening - that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s what makes Twitter special. By developing stronger synergies and really understanding where consumers are spending their time and how they are spending their time
column14: we will be able to build the best advertising solutions that truly leverage what makes Twitter unique and different.\nUnderstanding how to scale our platform.\nFrom finding the intersection between the consumer and advertiser
column15: we then took a step back to understand what our role is specifically for brands. We found that brands come to Twitter for three main reasons:\nTo launch something new to the marketplace
column16: such as a product or new campaign.\nTo connect with what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening
column17: and what people are talking about.\nTo promote their brand story
column18: and ongoing branding campaigns.\nEach of these pillars help grow a brand\u00e2\u0080\u0099s business by achieving specific goals
column19: whether it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s raising awareness around a new product
column20: engaging with existing and new customers
column21: or simply having a cohesive brand voice. By honing in on these three categories
column22: and understanding how the consumer falls under each
column23: we can focus on that sweet spot that sits between the consumer and the advertiser.\nOver the course of 2017
column24: we launched key product enhancements that have helped us better fulfill these advertiser needs
column25: such as:\nPromoting your brand\u00e2\u0080\u0099s story with more effective formats. With the recently introduced Video Website Card
column26: we have made it easy for people to learn more about a brand by allowing them to tap right into deeper content directly through a brand\u00e2\u0080\u0099s video. And since the video continues to play while the site is loading
column27: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen significant increases in time spent on the site.\nConnecting with what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening via live event sponsorships. To further connect with what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening
column28: Twitter offers a unique opportunity for brands to sponsor events
column29: whether it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s in the lead-up
column30: during
column31: or after. This is a great way to connect in real-time with what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening
column32: and brands such as HP are finding success with this innovative type of sponsorship. Â  Â  This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. Your browser does not support the video element. Play Play Pause Seek 0% buffered 00:00 Current time 00:00 Duration 00:00 Toggle Mute Volume Whatâs next? As we look ahead to 2018
column33:
we want to continue to drive the consumer-advertiser intersection and make it easier than ever for brands to reach their objectives. We will do so by focusing on the following:
Investing in innovative formats that empower brands to express themselves. We will continue to create advertising solutions that are unique while still embracing formats that we know work.
Improving advertiser's ability to target audiences through increased machine learning and new planning tools. We will enable advertisers to reach new audiences by launching new targeting products built on our unique Twitter data. We will also improve planning and forecasting tools to help advertisers accurately predict what their campaigns will achieve before they launch.
Making it easier to advertise on Twitter by developing a more seamless way to buy. We are going to continue to make it easier to buy on Twitter to ensure a seamless experience from the very beginning. We are also testing new ways to buy ads
column34: including third-party demand
column35: and are currently learning from these tests.\nWe are going back to basics
column36: while using our machine learning capabilities to help connect our advertisers to the best and most relevant content and customers. We are excited for what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s to come
column37:
and will be providing regular updates along the way. Hereâs to a great 2018!
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
