column3: "title": "Twitter Celebrates #SaferInternetDay 2018 "
column7: "post_text": "Company\nTwitter Celebrates #SaferInternetDay 2018 \nThursday
column8: 8 February 2018\nLink copied successfully\nThe theme for Safer Internet Day 2018 (@safeinternetday) - a better Internet starts with you - speaks to our values as a platform. Twitter shows the world what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening. We all contribute
column9: we all have our part to play.\nSafety is an integral part of everything we do as a company. We recognize that to express yourself on our platform
column10: you must feel safe. Over the past 12 months
column11: we've introduced a range of new policies and tools to improve Twitter for everyone
column12: including refinements to the core of our product. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also launched a brand new Safety Center and met and engaged with our Trust & Safety Council for the first ever Twitter Trust & Safety Summit
column13: with the goal of soliciting their direct
column14: expert feedback on our vision for a safer Twitter.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re seeing results. By leveraging our technology
column15: improving our core functionality
column16: and introducing a host of brand new features
column17: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen a marked improvement. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also providing better user education and demonstrating increased transparency around our decision-making and the philosophy behind the Twitter Rules.\nTo celebrate the global conversation around internet safety
column18: we launched a special emoji that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s activated by using the hashtags #SaferInternetDay and #SID2018. The emoji helped to unify and strengthen the conversation around Safer Internet Day
column19: encouraging users to create
column20: connect
column21: and share respect online. So far
column22: there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s been more than 100
column23: 000 Tweets using the dedicated hashtags
column24: generating 6
column26:
275 impressions.  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Â 
Colin Crowell
column27: VP
column28: Global Public Policy & Corporate Philanthropy
column29: Twitter
column30: commented:\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cSafer Internet Day salutes the unparalleled potential and opportunity of the internet. This potential
column31: if harnessed creatively
column32: safely
column33: and securely
column34: can further the public good and elevate civic conversation worldwide. To get there
column35: we must work together as it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s our shared responsibility. For our part
column36: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve taken big strides forward over the last year across our policies
column37: product
column38: and educational outreach to improve the Twitter experience for everyone. For now
column39: we thank our partners across the globe for their ongoing support and counsel. They make us better and we value their insights and expertise greatly. Create
column40: connect
column41: and share respect using the hashtags #SaferInternetDay and #SID2018.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nSarah Willoughby
column42: Insafe Team at European Schoolnet (EUN)
column43: commented: \u00e2\u0080\u009cTwitter has always been strong supporters of Safer Internet Day and
column44: as coordinators of the Insafe network of helplines and awareness centres
column45: we very much value the relationship that we have with them. Raising awareness of the benefits but also the challenges of the internet and online communications is crucial
column46: and the SID emoji helps to highlight our messages and encourage public discussion
column47: dialogue and debate.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nIn Europe
column48: @TwitterDublin and @TwitterUK worked with the Insafe Team to coordinate the launch and promotion of the global #SaferInternetDay emoji
column49: while also supporting the promotion of content through @safeinternetday and @UK_SIC. Across the continent
column50: we supported partners such as @Webwise in Ireland and @klicksafe in Germany through our Ads for Good program
column51: ensuring that their voice and core message was elevated on Safer Internet Day and beyond.\nIn Singapore
column52: @TwitterSG hosted the Singapore Media Literacy Council\u00e2\u0080\u0099s launch of its 2018 #BetterInternetSG campaign. Together with key social outreach organisations and the Digital Quotient Institute
column53: @TwitterSG will partner with the Media Literacy Council throughout 2018
column54: conducting digital literacy workshops for parents. With our support
column55:
a parentsâ resource for the online space will also be created in all four official languages of Singapore. This targeted resource will include Twitter safety tips and best practices.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Â 
In Indonesia
column56: we invited\u00c2\u00a0@DamarJuniarto\u00c2\u00a0from the South East Asia Freedom of Expression Network (@SAFEnetvoice) to write a guest\u00c2\u00a0blog\u00c2\u00a0and to share some tips to stay safe on the internet. We then amplified this across Indonesia using\u00c2\u00a0@TwitterID. There is also ongoing discussion of collaboration with SAFEnet for a possible joint campaign during Safer Internet Month later this year. \nIn India
column57: we worked with Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology (@GoI_MEITY) and hosted a Twitter Q&A on cyber security questions
column58: using #SaferInternetDay. The Director General of @IndianCERT (Computer Emergency Response Team) answered a range of questions and provided safety tips on avoiding phishing attacks and reporting cyber crime. We also worked with law enforcement agencies like @Uppolice
column59: @MumbaiPolice
column60: and @BlrCityPolice
column61: as well as NGO partners @CSR_India
column62: @INBreakthrough
column63:
and @YouthKiAwaaz to use the emoji to drive civic conversation.

In KSA
column64: @TwitterMENA worked in cooperation with \u00c2\u00a0@CITC_SA
column65: the Saudi Communication and Information Technology Commission. While celebrating #SID2018
column66:
CITC launched an exclusive awareness campaign on Twitter that included tips directed to parents and young internet users on how to have a safe online experience.

In Korea
column67: @TwitterKorea collaborated with Korea Internet & Security Agency and news organization BoAn News to produce two blog posts aimed at promoting information and personal security
column68: and Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s tools to promote and enhance a safe experience on the platform. @TwitterKorea also awarded an Ads for Good grant to partner Open Net
column69: who advocate for core digital values of equal access
column70: freedom of expression
column71: and transparency in Korea.\nIn Japan
column72: @TwitterJP delivered a presentation at the Safer Internet Day 2018 symposium
column73: in which multiple stakeholders including the Ministry of Internal Affairs & Communications (MIC)
column74: Ministry of Justice (MOJ)
column75: National Police Agency (NPA)
column76: Ministry of Economy

column86: we worked with our safety partners to promote helpful tips and best practices about how to stay safe on Twitter. For example

@Reachout_AUS was able to let kids know theyâre not alone online and to learn Reachoutâs top five tips for how to deal with cyberbullying. @TwitterAU also put together a dedicated Twitter Moment that was updated over the course #SID2018. We sought to create just a snapshot of the vital work our safety partners are doing to support people across Australia and New Zealand.

column97: we attended @Safernet event hub in S\u00c3\u00a3o Paulo in which they discussed freedom of expression

and amplified Safernet's content through @TwitterBrasil.
Check out our continuing updates to promote a safer Twitter at @TwitterSafety.

column3: "title": "Twitter invites brands to compete in first-ever #BrandBowl"
column7: "post_text": "Events\nTwitter invites brands to compete in first-ever #BrandBowl\nMonday
column8:
29 January 2018
Link copied successfully
#SB52 is whatâs happening.
Thereâs no better place than Twitter to reach consumers during major live moments - and the Super Bowl is no exception. Last year alone
column9: there were 27.6 million Tweets about the Super Bowl
column10: and 5.6 billion views of those Tweets.\nAs one of the crown jewels of live events
column11: Twitter is the place to turn to be a part of what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening around the big game. Twitter sees close to a 20% lift in unique visitors during the Super Bowl. And that audience isn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t just passively checking Twitter during the game
column12: they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re spending significant time keeping up with and joining the commentary. In fact
column13: during the game
column14: Twitter sees a +14% increase in time spent in the app*. Simply put
column15:
users know that watching the Super Bowl is a significantly better experience when youâre watching it with Twitter and millions of others across the world.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Introducing #BrandBowl52**
We all know that the Super Bowl isnât just about the game
column16: but also about the creative ads in between the big plays and touchdowns. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why today we are announcing the first-ever #BrandBowl - Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s official competition and service to honor the best-in-class campaigns as played out on Twitter.\nStarting today
column17: people will be able to Retweet a Tweet from @TwitterMKTG to be notified when new spots air in real-time during the game. On gameday
column18: subscribers will receive automated notifications after each quarter with a Twitter Moment that will feature the ad spots that aired in that quarter. After the game
column19:
people will get a final notification alerting them to explore the winners of #BrandBowl52.
Â 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Winners and Prizes
Winners will be broken into the following categories:
#MVP: Brand with the highest percentage of all brand related Tweets during #SB52
#Blitz: Brand who drove the highest velocity of most Tweets-per-minute
#QuarterBack:Brand with the most Retweets on a single Tweet during #SB52
#Interception: Brand without a national TV spot that drove the highest % of brand conversation
We will also honor brands that have received the highest percentage of all in-game brand conversation versus category competitors across the following industries: CPG
column20: dining
column21: entertainment
column22: technology & telecommunications
column23: automotive
column24: alc-bev
column25: home & healthcare
column26: financial services
column27: retail
column28: and travel.\nWinners will receive a suite of exclusive ad products and custom consumer research opportunities to fuel their future Twitter campaigns in 2018
column29: as well as special inclusion in\u00c2\u00a0BuzzFeed News' live morning show
column30: AM to DM
column31: the morning after gameday. Additionally
column32: all winning brands will receive custom trophies for their brand headquarters
column33: media
column34: and creative agencies.\nBe sure to tune back here following the game and to\u00c2\u00a0BuzzFeed News' AM to DM the morning after to find out who the winners are. Let the games begin
column35:
and be sure to follow along on Twitter!
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
*Twitter changes the live TV sports viewing experience
column36: 2017\n**Methodology: Only brands who have enrolled in the Twitter #BrandBowl52 competition will be eligible for inclusion in the Super Subscribe Moment and prize consideration. A team of data scientists from Twitter's Semantic Core team will be monitoring the conversation from coin flip to the final whistle of the game
column37:
tracking the brands and ad spots driving the conversation on Twitter.  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet

column3: "title": "Nice Threads"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Nice Threads
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 12 December 2017\nLink copied successfully\nAt Twitter
column9: we have a history of studying how people use our service and then creating features to make what they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re doing easier. The Retweet
column10: '@reply'
column11: and hashtag are examples of this. A few years ago we noticed people creatively stitching Tweets together to share more information or tell a longer story \u00e2\u0080\u0093 like this. We saw this approach (which we call \u00e2\u0080\u009cthreading\u00e2\u0080\u009d) as an innovative way to present a train of thought
column12: made up of connected but individual elements.\nNow
column13: hundreds of thousands of threads are Tweeted every day! But this method of Tweeting
column14: while effective and popular
column15: can be tricky for some to create and it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s often tough to read or discover all the Tweets in a thread. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re thrilled to share that we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re making it simpler to thread Tweets together
column16: and to find threads
column17:
so itâs easier to express yourself on Twitter and stay informed.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâve made it easy to create a thread by adding a plus button in the composer
column18: so you can connect your thoughts and publish your threaded Tweets all at the same time. You can continue adding more Tweets to your published thread at any time with the new \u00e2\u0080\u009cAdd another Tweet\u00e2\u0080\u009d button. Additionally
column19: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s now simpler to spot a thread \u00e2\u0080\u0093 we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve added an obvious \u00e2\u0080\u009cShow this thread\u00e2\u0080\u009d label.\nA few weeks ago
column20: we expanded our character count to make it easier for people to fit what they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re thinking into a Tweet. But we know people also may want to serialize a longer story or thought
column21: or provide ongoing commentary on an event or topic. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s where this update to threads comes in! You\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been using threads in creative ways like these for years \u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00c2\u00a0the ways and reasons to thread your Tweets are limited only by your imagination.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re rolling out these updates to everyone on iOS
column22: Android
column23: and Twitter.com in the coming weeks. Make sure to update your app to check it out. Also
column24:
thank you â threads are a nod to the creativity of the Twitter community. Tweet us what you think!
Â

column3: "title": "Update on the Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism "
column7: "post_text": "Events\nUpdate on the Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism \nMonday
column8: 4 December 2017\nLink copied successfully\nAt last year's EU Internet Forum
column9: Facebook
column10: Microsoft
column11: Twitter and YouTube declared our joint determination to curb the spread of terrorist content online. Over the past year
column12: we have formalized this partnership with the launch of the Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism (GIFCT). We hosted our first meeting in August where representatives from the tech industry
column13: government and non-governmental organizations came together to focus on three key areas: technological approaches
column14: knowledge sharing
column15: and research. Since then
column16: we have participated in a Heads of State meeting at the UN General Assembly in September and the G7 Interior Ministers meeting in October
column17: and we look forward to hosting a GIFCT event and attending the EU Internet Forum in Brussels on the 6th of December.  The GIFCT is committed to working on technological solutions to help thwart terrorists' use of our services
column18: and has built on the groundwork laid by the EU Internet Forum
column19: particularly through a shared industry hash database
column20: where companies can create \u00e2\u0080\u009cdigital fingerprints\u00e2\u0080\u009d for terrorist content and share it with participating companies.   The database
column21: which we announced our commitment to building last December and became operational last spring
column22: now contains more than 40
column23: 000 hashes. It allows member companies to use those hashes to identify and remove matching content \u00e2\u0080\u0094 videos and images \u00e2\u0080\u0094 that violate our respective policies or
column24: in some cases
column25: block terrorist content before it is even posted.   We are pleased that Ask.fm
column26: Cloudinary
column27: Instagram
column28: Justpaste.it
column29: LinkedIn
column30: Oath
column31: and Snap have also recently joined this hash-sharing consortium
column32: and we will continue our work to add additional companies throughout 2018.  In order to disrupt the distribution of terrorist content across the internet
column33: companies have invested in collaborating and sharing expertise with one another. GIFCT's knowledge-sharing work has grown quickly in large measure because companies recognize that in countering terrorism online we face many of the same challenges.   Although our companies have been sharing best practices around counterterrorism for several years
column34: in recent months GIFCT has provided a more formal structure to accelerate and strengthen this work. In collaboration with the Tech Against Terror initiative \u00e2\u0080\u0094 which recently launched a Knowledge Sharing Platform with the support of GIFCT and the UN Counter-Terrorism Committee Executive Directorate \u00e2\u0080\u0094 we have held workshops for smaller tech companies in order to share best practices on how to disrupt the spread of violent extremist content online.   Our initial goal for 2017 was to work with 50 smaller tech companies to to share best practices on how to disrupt the spread of violent extremist material. We have exceeded that goal
column35: engaging with 68 companies over the past several months through workshops in San Francisco
column36: New York
column37: and Jakarta
column38: plus another workshop next week in Brussels on the sidelines of the EU Internet Forum.   We recognize that our work is far from done
column39:
but we are confident that we are heading in the right direction. We will continue to provide updates as we forge new partnerships and develop new technology in the face of this global challenge. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter

column3: "title": "The High Stakes for Net Neutrality"
column7:
"post_text": "Events
The High Stakes for Net Neutrality
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 1 December 2017\nLink copied successfully\nEarlier this year we shared why Twitter
column9: as a company
column10: strongly supports Net Neutrality. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s critical to enabling free expression
column11: fostering innovation
column12: enhancing public safety
column13: and maintaining U.S. global leadership on Internet issues. This summer
column14: the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) announced its plan to roll back Net Neutrality protections and solicited feedback from the American people about its proposal. The public opposition has been overwhelming
column15: and Twitter joined millions of people in urging the FCC to rethink its plan.\nIf approved
column16: Chairman Pai\u00e2\u0080\u0099s proposal will gut Net Neutrality
column17: removing the FCC\u00e2\u0080\u0099s current rules preventing Internet Service Providers (ISPs) from blocking content
column18: slowing down Internet speeds
column19: and engaging in \u00e2\u0080\u009cpaid prioritization\u00e2\u0080\u009d -- the development of discriminatory fast & slow lanes on the Internet with gratuitous new fees.\nIn today\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Internet economy
column20: a rollback of Net Neutrality means businesses and startups that operate online or use platforms like Twitter to reach customers would be at the mercy of ISPs for vital communication exchanges.\nFor the millions of people who use Twitter to share their thoughts
column21: start movements
column22: speak truth to power
column23: or find out what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in the world
column24: the lack of strong Net Neutrality rules means ISPs have the final word when it comes to the openness of the Internet.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen robust public engagement - from diverse perspectives - around this issue on Twitter
column25:
including:
3.5 million Tweets in the past month on #NetNeutrality
2.5 million Tweets about #NetNeutrality since Chairman Pai unveiled the details of his proposal last Tuesday
Half a million Tweets on the #NetNeutrality Day of Action in July 2017
According to multiple polls
column26: Americans across the political spectrum support Net Neutrality. As a federal agency
column27: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s the FCC\u00e2\u0080\u0099s job to represent the public interest and consumers
column28: the overwhelming majority of whom want strong Net Neutrality rules.\nEarlier this week
column29: FCC Chairman Pai attempted to distract people away from the serious defects of his proposal by taking swipes at Twitter that were misleading. Given the serious deficiencies of the Chairman\u00e2\u0080\u0099s plan
column30: his tactics to distract people from it are understandable. \u00c2\u00a0The truth is we are impartial and believe strongly in impartiality. The Twitter platform doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t take sides. \u00c2\u00a0Diverse perspectives are present every day and treated equally so users can see every side. \u00c2\u00a0And the Twitter Rules apply to everyone equally. \u00c2\u00a0We note that the Chairman uses Twitter and liberally quoted Tweets in his recent speech. \u00c2\u00a0His voice and perspective are important and his presence on Twitter is most welcome. \u00c2\u00a0We hope he will revert to substantive discussions regarding the impact of his plan.\u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nAs a global platform
column31: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen what happens when governments take steps to artificially constrain consumer choice and throttle innovation online. Today
column32:
itâs undeniable that the majority of Americans want strong Net Neutrality rules and understand the serious negative impact the Chairmanâs proposal will have for an open Internet. Â Twitter will continue to fight for an open Internet for all. Â  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet

column7:
"post_text": "Product
Twitter Lite in the Google Play Store in 24 more countries
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 30 November 2017\nLink copied successfully\nIn April
column9: we launched Twitter Lite
column10: a new mobile web experience that minimizes data usage
column11: loads quicker on slower connections
column12: and is more resilient on unreliable mobile networks. Since then we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen an increase in engagement \u00e2\u0080\u0094 for example
column13: Tweets sent from Twitter Lite have increased more than 50%. Over the past few months
column14: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve added safety and performance improvements in addition to features including GIF search
column15: ranked Home timeline
column16: and more.\nWe wanted to make Twitter Lite more discoverable
column17: so in September we tested making it available in the Google Play Store in the Philippines. Through on-the-ground user research and Play Store reviews
column18: we received a lot of valuable feedback. People using the app valued its small size
column19: quick loading
column20: and minimal data usage. Based on these positive results
column21: we have decided to bring it to more people around the world. \nStarting today
column22: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re adding Twitter Lite to the Google Play Store in 24 more countries across Africa
column23: Asia
column24: Europe
column25: Middle East
column26: and Latin America
column27: specifically: Algeria
column28: Bangladesh
column29: Bolivia
column30: Brazil
column31: Chile
column32: Colombia
column33: Costa Rica
column34: Ecuador
column35: Egypt
column36: Israel
column37: Kazakhstan
column38: Mexico
column39: Malaysia
column40: Nigeria
column41: Nepal
column42: Panama
column43: Peru
column44: Serbia
column45: El Salvador
column46: South Africa
column47: Thailand
column48: Tunisia
column49: Tanzania
column50: and Venezuela. \nWhether you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re using Twitter Lite on the mobile web or through the Google Play Store
column51: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s fast
column52: takes up less space
column53: and is data-friendly:\nLoads quickly on 2G and 3G networks
column54: and offers offline support in case you temporarily lose your connection\nMinimizes data usage
column55:
and offers a data saver mode to download only the images or videos you want to see
Reduces install size to under 3MB so it doesnât take much room on your phone
Â 
No matter where you are in the world
column56: we want to make Twitter the best way for you to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in the world and talk about it. You can use Twitter and Twitter Lite to get real-time updates on news
column57: sports
column58: entertainment
column59: politics
column60:
and other topics that matter most to you. Download Twitter Lite from the Play Store today! 
Â

column3: "title": "#TechWomen17 Is Happening"
column7:
"post_text": "Events
#TechWomen17 Is Happening
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 27 November 2017\nLink copied successfully\nTechWomen
column9: an initiative of the U.S. Department of State\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs (ECA)
column10: \u00c2\u00a0aims to empower
column11: connect
column12: and support the next generation of women leaders in STEM. Twitter has been involved since the inception of the program six years ago
column13: hosting women from 20 different countries.Through this program
column14:
women around the world spent six weeks in a mentorship and exchange program with their professional counterparts in the United States.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
"TechWomen is a community of women professionals bonded by the desire to share our life experiences and the responsibility we all feel to pay it forward. We develop and discover life long relationships and connections
column15: across the globe
column16: that we didn't know existed. In my case
column17: I met Amy
column18: my long lost sister from Kenya
column19: and last year
column20: I found a daughter in Nargiza from Kyrgyzstan. As a member of TechWomen
column21:
we have family all over the world."
Kiko 
â@kikoltdcomâ
This year
column22: a team of one impact coach
column23: three cultural mentors
column24: and 11 professional mentors supported the following 5 Emerging Leaders (ELs) at Twitter: Imen Ammar from Tunisia
column25: Ala\u00e2\u0080\u0099a Agha Karss from Jordan
column26: Sara Hassan from Pakistan
column27: Razan Qraini from Palestinian Territories
column28:
and Meriem Touami from Algeria.  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weeks before they even arrived in San Francisco
column29: ELs and their professional mentors worked together to develop individual projects. When they stepped into Twitter HQ on September 25
column30: they hit the ground running and made big strides on projects ranging from investigating the Arabic user experience on Twitter to planning a coding bootcamp program. Not to be left out
column31:
Twitter employees Â from as far as London met with the ELs in order to support these amazing women.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
"Through the TechWomen program
column32: I spent four weeks at Twitter
column33: working to define a strategy to adopt agile methodologies within Algerian teams. I was amazed by the Twitter spirit and mindset. Everyone is always trying to help everyone in every possible way. I was also introduced to their feedback culture
column34:
sharing constructive information on a daily basis. This really motivates me and gives me hope to create a similar environment in Algeria."
Meriem
â@NaaLeaaâ
TechWomen is also focused on making an impact in each ELâs home country. This is why groups of women from each country also worked together to formulate an action plan -- a venture to address a socio-economic challenge in their community. On October 13
column36:
21 groups presented their plan to compete for 5 seed grants. Our very own Alaâa Agha Karss was part of a winning team with their plan to increase university enrollment for orphans in Jordan. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In your action plan
column37: you have to work for your home country
column38: touch the pain of it
column39: and try to find the cure. The atmosphere of the challenging spirit of all participants encourages you to implement your action plan
column40:
whether you win funding or not.
Ala'a
â@AlaaAghaKarssâ
It would have been a shame to spend weeks in the Bay Area and miss out on local attractions. Our cultural mentors made sure that ELs were able to relax and enjoy their temporary home by organizing activities. Trips to the Exploratorium
column41: Golden Gate Bridge
column42:
and a hackathon at Carnegie Mellon Silicon Valley provided a welcome break to the nonstop work on individual projects and action plans. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
I had the privilege of spending time with our ELs both at work and at my groupâs events. I also had the opportunity to connect with mentors and ELs from other companies at the cultural events. It was a wonderful experience exploring the Bay Area with the ELs and learning about their lives
column43: work
column44: and passions.\nJenny \nEngineer
column45: Twitter\n\u00e2\u0080\u008e@jenny__lin\u00e2\u0080\u008e\nThe San Francisco portion of the program culminated in the Community Celebration. Twitter HQ transformed into a party worthy of 100 global women technologists
column46: complete with an action plan gallery and a processional of 20 flags. We even had a surprise appearance from Twitter-hosted 2015 TechWomen Alumna Raghd Magdy from Egypt and her mentor
column47:
Jen Fraser. 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
âThe impact of the program is recognized over the years following the exchange

column54:
starting with their own communities.

column8: 17 November 2017\nLink copied successfully\nGiving back has been a priority of Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s since the company started over 11 years ago. While there are often employees out volunteering in our local communities
column9: twice a year we have company-wide #TwitterForGood Days. During our Fall #TwitterForGood Days
column10: teams from around the world came together to partner with organizations that are integral to bettering our communities. From meal preparation to digital literacy classes
column11: from urban clean up and youth empowerment initiatives and more
column12: Twitter staff \u00c2\u00a0teamed up with nonprofits that dedicate themselves to doing incredible work locally and impacting the world in a positive
column13:
tangible way.Â Â 
Hereâs a snapshot of some of the ways our employees spent the time across the globe Â Weâve also captured it all in this short Twitter Moment.
Â 
Â

including the internal observation deck and the 4D experience.

and to reinforce positive digital citizenship. Â

Cryptocurrency: The Discussion on Twitter Keeps Growing
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 15 November 2017\nLink copied successfully\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s hard to imagine a more polarizing topic debated in the finance community than the utility of decentralized networks and cryptocurrencies. Whether you believe that Bitcoin ($BTC) will be a central fixture in the transfer of money
column9: or think it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s all just a bunch of hype
column10:
cryptocurrencies are a topic that is sure to spark a heated debate in your timeline.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Over the last year
column11:
weâve seen the cryptocurrency conversation on Twitter grow at unprecedented rates. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Everyone is weighing in on the debate
column12:
from Goldman Sachsâ CEO Lloyd Blankfein 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
 . . .To Twitterâs own Jack Dorsey 
This Tweet is unavailable

. . . To the self appointed Chairman of the Twitter Federal Reserve
column13:
Josh Brown of Ritholtz Wealth Management  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
If youâre keeping track at home
column14:
Quartzâ scorecard of the financial bigwigs still looks like a bit mixed:  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
One thing we do know
column15: is that in a market where huge price swings are commonplace
column16: forks happen on a regular basis
column17: and rumors run wild
column18: Twitter is the place to stay informed. In talking with Joe Gits of Social Market Analytics his take is the following:\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cTwitter is clearly taking the lead as the home for discussions related to new monetary technologies. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re seeing Bitcoin ($BTC) conversation volume alone exceeding that of the FANG stocks (Facebook $FB
column19: Apple $AAPL
column20: Netflix $NFLX
column21: Google $GOOG) on a daily basis. We are also observing the influence of crypto technology on other blockchain related equities. Semiconductor stocks like $NVDA and $AMD are greatly impacted by the increase in mining related products.\n\u00c2\u00a0\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s great to see the diversity in conversation
column22: as the discussion isn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t just about about cryptocurrencies. We see discussion related to broader blockchain technologies
column23: protocols and investment outlook on transformative digital assets as a whole.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\n\u00c2\u00a0\nWe look forward to seeing the great predictive models Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Finance Data Partners build using analytics related to investor conversation. With that in mind
column24:
we leave you with one question:

column3: "title": "Twitter\u2019s Contribution to Media Literacy Week"
column7:
"post_text": "Events
Twitterâs Contribution to Media Literacy Week
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 10 November 2017\nLink copied successfully\nMedia Literacy Week is an annual event that takes place every November in the US and Canada. The week puts a spotlight on the importance of digital and media literacy as a key component in the education of children and young people.  Working with schools
column9: libraries
column10: and educational associations and organizations
column11: Media Literacy Week participants seek to inspire a leap in Canadian and US citizens\u00e2\u0080\u0099 thinking towards media education as an important \u00e2\u0080\u0093 and innovative \u00e2\u0080\u0093 approach towards creating thoughtful
column12: engaged and informed young people.  This initiative provides online citizens with a focal point for media-related activities and
column13: at the same time
column14: showcases the creative ways that digital and media literacy are being integrated into classrooms and communities across the world.\nTo celebrate this year\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Media Literacy Week
column15: Twitter joined a number of initiatives with our partners @MediaSmarts and @MediaLiteracyEd for the third consecutive year. Last year
column16:
we held a Digital Citizenship Summit that brought together educators from around the world.  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We started the week unveiling a dedicated Twitter Emoji with the hashtags #MediaLitWk
column17:
#MLW17 and #getsmartonline:
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In the US we collaborated with the National Association for Media Literacy Education to host the closing Media Literacy Week event to celebrate the positive ways that US youth are using social media and to share best practices recommendations between educators and civil society experts. 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In Canada
column18: Twitter partnered with @MediaSmarts at their annual opening event at Lisgar Collegiate Institute in Ottawa
column19:
where over 100 high school students participated in a number of hands-on workshops including one on Twitter and online empowerment. 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Beyond our contribution to this week
column20: at Twitter we have the immense privilege of working with safety organizations who are experts on Media Literacy like Common Sense Media
column21: Connectsafely
column22: or Childnet. With their input
column23: we have been able to develop a guide for educators. As people turn to Twitter to find and share ideas about teaching and learning
column24: we wanted to create a resource geared to help educators make the most of Twitter in the classroom by connecting them to lessons
column25: ideas
column26: and experiences that can support their vital work. We unveiled the resource at NAMLE\u00e2\u0080\u0099s annual conference in Chicago earlier this year and it is available for download in English and French.\nIn EMEA
column27: @TwitterDublin hosted UNICEF Ireland and 50 high school students for a special all-day event focused on digital literacy and active citizenship. Students were taught how to verify information sources
column28:
safeguard their online reputation and break down digital divides. Guest speakers talked about their learning experience with online platforms and how theyâve come to develop the knowledge required to effectively leverage Twitter to advocate on issues theyâre passionate about.  
Â 
Â 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
To ensure the students came away with practical guidance
column29: we gave the group some worksheets featuring web pages and stories that appeared on real sites. We then asked them to distinguish between advertorial and editorial content
column30:
and to say whether claim stated as fact gave any evidence to that fact. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The event received national media attention. TV
column31: press
column32:
and radio reporters attended and quizzed the students and facilitators on the importance of digital literacy education.  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
While online engagement continues to get more complex
column33: we hope to contribute to the media literacy effort by empowering users to build critical thinking abilities and connecting them to resources. Our ultimate goal is for any user \u00e2\u0080\u0093within Twitter or anywhere online\u00e2\u0080\u0093 to have control over their online experience within the ever-changing digital landscape.\n\u00c2\u00a0\nIf you are interested in learning more about Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s media literacy efforts
column34: check our Neighbor Nest where we provide digital literacy workshops to address the needs of low-income users who lack crucial computer skills. While the digital literacy classes cover basic computer and Internet search skills we recognize this is a critical first step to understand how we consume information. No matter the level of digital literacy
column35: we recognize that everyone can benefit from guidelines about constructive online behavior and also provide a digital citizenship workshop to address these needs. In this workshop
column36: Neighbor Nest staff and Twitter volunteers cover topics such as online abuse
column37: media literacy
column38: account security
column39:
and reputation management.
You can see the best content and tweets in this Moment: Celebrating Media Literacy Week.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

#OnlyOnTwitter

column3: "title": "Tweeting Made Easier"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Tweeting Made Easier
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 7 November 2017\nLink copied successfully\nIn September
column9: we launched a test that expanded the 140 character limit so every person around the world could express themselves easily in a Tweet. Our goal was to make this possible while ensuring we keep the speed and brevity that makes Twitter
column10: Twitter. Looking at all the data
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to share we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve achieved this goal and are rolling the change out to all languages where cramming was an issue.*\nDuring the first few days of the test many people Tweeted the full 280 limit because it was new and novel
column12: but soon after behavior normalized (more on this below). We saw when people needed to use more than 140 characters
column13: they Tweeted more easily and more often. But importantly
column14: people Tweeted below 140 most of the time and the brevity of Twitter remained.\nHighlights are below and in our additional blogs about our experimentation process
column15: extensive data analysis
column16: research
column17: and design work.\nEasier to Tweet\nHistorically
column18: 9% of Tweets in English hit the character limit. This reflects the challenge of fitting a thought into a Tweet
column19: often resulting in lots of time spent editing and even at times abandoning Tweets before sending. With the expanded character count
column20: this problem was massively reduced \u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00c2\u00a0that number dropped to only 1% of Tweets running up against the limit. Since we saw Tweets hit the character limit less often
column21: we believe people spent less time editing their Tweets in the composer. This shows that more space makes it easier for people to fit thoughts in a Tweet
column22: so they could say what they want to say
column23:
and send Tweets faster than before. You can see this happening in the graph below.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Keeping Twitterâs brevity
We âÂ and many of you â were concerned that timelines may fill up with 280 character Tweets
column24: and people with the new limit would always use up the whole space. But that didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t happen. Only 5% of Tweets sent were longer than 140 characters and only 2% were over 190 characters. As a result
column25: your timeline reading experience should not substantially change
column26: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll still see about the same amount of Tweets in your timeline. For reference
column27: in the timeline
column28:
Tweets with an image or poll usually take up more space than a 190 character Tweet.
Itâs worth emphasizing again that people in the test got very excited about the extra space in the beginning andÂ many Tweets went way beyond 140. People did silly (creative!) things like writing just a few characters per line to make their Tweets extra large. It was a temporary effect and didnât last long. We expect to see some of this novelty effect spike again with this weekâs launch and expect it to resume to normal behavior soon after.
Engagement
In addition to more Tweeting
column29: people who had more room to Tweet received more engagement (Likes
column30: Retweets
column31: @mentions)
column32: got more followers
column33: and spent more time on Twitter. People in the experiment told us that a higher character limit made them feel more satisfied with how they expressed themselves on Twitter
column34: their ability to find good content
column35: and Twitter overall.\nWe are making this change after listening and observing a problem our global community was having (it wasn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t easy enough to Tweet!)
column36: studying data to understand how we could improve
column37: trying it out
column38: and listening to your feedback. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue listening and working to make Twitter easier for everyone while making sure we keep what you love.\n*Japanese
column39: Korean
column40: and Chinese will continue to have 140 characters because cramming is not an issue in these languages. In fact
column41: these languages have always been able to say more with their Tweets because of the density of their writing systems. We shared more about this thinking and our research here.\n**On this graph
column42: there is a small bump in the red line (which represents the group with 280 characters) at 140 because these people were also using older Twitter clients which didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t have the ability to send longer Tweets
column43:
so they continued to hit the 140 character limit. This graph is for English-only Tweets.
Â

Today is the first Tuesday of November in the U.S. so it is Election Day ââ and local elections are happening in all 50 states across the country.
In September
column9: Twitter partnered with National Voter Registration Day (@NatlVoterRegDay) to host a discussion about the importance of staying connected
column10: both online and in the polling booth
column11: with the first step always being voter registration.\nAs Americans across across the U.S. turn out to vote
column12: Twitter can be a resource to help you cast your ballot
column13: follow accounts for U.S. secretary of state offices and voter information
column14: and share your civic engagement experience by Tweeting #iVoted to unlock a custom emoji.\nFor the fourth year in a row
column15: Twitter is continuing our partnership with The Pew Charitable Trusts\u00e2\u0080\u0099 Voting Information Project (@VotingInfo) to make it easier for you to locate your polling place and make your voice heard at the ballot box. Through https://www.gettothepolls.com/

you can enter in your address to locate your local polling place.

column3: "title": "#HolidayIsHappening: Twitter launches first holiday insights campaign"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
#HolidayIsHappening: Twitter launches first holiday insights campaign
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 7 November 2017\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter will provide real-time holiday insights
column9: powered by Brandwatch
column10: throughout November and December 2017. \n#HolidayIsHappening on Twitter.\u00c2\u00a0From discovering new gift ideas and recipes
column11: to Tweeting about what ugly sweater to wear
column12: to sharing what shows to binge watch while home for the holidays
column13: the conversation is taking place on Twitter. This year
column14: Twitter is partnering with Brandwatch and Cheddar to keep holiday enthusiasts up to date on what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s hot and what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not this season.\nWe will be sharing these insights as quickly as the conversations are unfolding on Twitter
column15: uncovering trends found on holiday shopping behavior and offering brands ways to hone in on these behaviors for a successful holiday season on Twitter. These insights will include the hottest gifts
column16: the most talked about brands of the week
column17: top Tweeted emojis
column18: and most mentioned hashtags
column19: spanning across various categories
column20: such as gadgets and toys
column21: auto
column22: fashion
column23: entertainment
column24: and food and drink.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll also be listening to what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in real-time to unveil what people are talking about during the biggest moments of the holiday season
column25: such as what recipes to make for Thanksgiving or what brands people are talking about ahead of Cyber Monday. Through Brandwatch
column26: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be sorting through holiday-related Tweets and focus on the ones that show purchase intent. That way
column27:
weâre able to see what people want to actually buy this season and give brands and marketers actionable insights to optimize their campaigns in real time.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
How to Stay Informed this Holiday Season
You can keep up to date all season long through the following channels:
@TwitterMktg #HolidayIsHappening Chatbot: Marketers can sign up to receive actionable insights around whatâs hot (and whatâs not) by using a new #HolidayIsHappening chatbot. These insights will be delivered right to their Direct Message inbox
column28: with tips on how to use these insights to best optimize their campaigns. Topics include what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s trending during the holidays with a deep-dive on gadgets and toys
column29: fashion
column30: entertainment
column31: food and drinks
column32: and auto.\nCheddar #HolidayIsHappening News Desk: Kicking off on November 9th at 3pm ET
column33: Cheddar will be featuring the #HolidayIsHappening news desk highlighting in-the-moment insights.\u00c2\u00a0Each segment will feature a different take on the holidays by listening to what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening on Twitter. Tune in on @cheddar every Tuesday and Friday between 3 and 4pm ET.\nTwitter will also be hand-delivering these insights to select agencies in New York City via an interactive #HolidayIsHappening experience starting today through November 9th.\nDon\u00e2\u0080\u0099t forget to tune in to Cheddar this Thursday
column34: November 9th as Twitter Global VP of Revenue and Operations Matt Derella and Cheddar CEO
column35: Jon Steinberg take you through whatâs trending (so you donât get your niece a Fidget Spinner when all of the other kids are getting a Fingerling). And follow @TwitterMktg to discover what people are talking about this holiday season to make sure your ads are relevant and targeted. #HolidayIsHappening Â  This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. column3: "title": "Clarifying the Twitter Rules"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nClarifying the Twitter Rules\nFriday
column8: 3 November 2017\nLink copied successfully\nOnline behavior continues to evolve and change
column9: and at Twitter
column10: we have to ensure those changes are reflected in our rules in a way that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s easy to adhere to and understand. Today
column11: we're publishing a new version of the Twitter Rules to clarify our policies and how we enforce them. While the fundamentals of our policies and our approach have not changed
column12: this updated version presents our rules with more details and examples. In the weeks ahead
column13:
weâll launch separate pages for each of our policies to provide even more context about what each policy covers and our rationale for enforcement.
Some of the biggest updates include the following:
Abusive behavior
We are making it clear that context â including if the behavior is targeted
column14: if a report has been filed and by whom
column15: and if the Tweet itself is newsworthy and in the legitimate public interest \u00c2\u00a0\u00e2\u0080\u0094 is crucial when evaluating abusive behavior and determining appropriate enforcement actions. Expect more detail on how we review and enforce all of our policies and the range of enforcement options in a separate update on November 14.\nSelf-harm\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve always shared resources with people experiencing suicidal or self-harming thoughts when we learn of such behavior
column16: and removed any Tweets that encourage or promote suicide games. Our updated policy on suicide and self-harm clarifies how strictly we enforce this policy
column17: and how we communicate with anyone promoting or encouraging this type of behavior.\nSpam and related behaviors\nWe are more clearly defining spam
column18: how it behaves on Twitter
column19: and sharing the factors we consider when reviewing accounts that may be spam. As part of this update
column20: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also clarifying that when we review accounts that demonstrate spam-like behavior
column21: we focus on behavioral signals
column22: not the factual accuracy of the information they share.\nGraphic violence and adult content\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re providing more specific detail around the types of content we consider to be \u00e2\u0080\u009cgraphic violence\u00e2\u0080\u009d or \u00e2\u0080\u009cadult content.\u00e2\u0080\u009d We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also updating our media policy Help Center page so it includes examples that help set expectations around the types of content covered by this policy. Please note that the media policy will be updated again on November 22
column23: to account for hateful imagery.\nWe have worked on this clarified version of our rules for the past few months to ensure it takes into account the latest trends in online behavior
column24: considers different cultural and social contexts
column25: and properly sets expectations around what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s allowed on Twitter. We incorporated feedback from our global Trust and Safety Council
column26: who provided important guidance about how to best present our policies to the world. On November 22
column27: we will share another version of our rules
column28: which will include new policies around violent groups
column29: hateful imagery
column30: and abusive usernames. We are constantly evaluating our rules and iterating to make them clearer. As always
column31: we appreciate your feedback
column32: and we are looking forward to continuing working to make Twitter safer
column33:
together.  
Â

          This Tweet is unavailable.

#OnlyOnTwitter

column3: "title": "US Senate Committee on the Judiciary: Opening Remarks"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
US Senate Committee on the Judiciary: Opening Remarks
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 31 October 2017\nLink copied successfully\nUS Senate Committee on the Judiciary
column9: Subcommittee on Crime and Terrorism: Opening Remarks from Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s General Counsel
column10: Sean Edgett.\u00c2\u00a0 \nChairman Graham
column11: Ranking Member Whitehouse
column12: and Members of the Committee:\nTwitter understands the importance of the Committee\u00e2\u0080\u0099s inquiry into extremist content and Russian disinformation in the 2016 election
column13: and we appreciate the opportunity to appear here today.\nThe events underlying this hearing have been deeply concerning to our company and the broader Twitter community. \u00c2\u00a0We are committed to providing a service that fosters and facilitates free and open democratic debate and that promotes positive change in the world. \u00c2\u00a0We are troubled by reports that the power of Twitter was misused by a foreign actor for the purpose of influencing the US presidential election and undermining public faith in the democratic process.\nThe abuse of our platform to attempt state-sponsored manipulation of elections is a new challenge for us\u00e2\u0080\u0094and one that we are determined to meet. \u00c2\u00a0Today
column14: we intend to show the Committee how serious we are about addressing this new threat by explaining the work we are doing to understand what happened and to ensure it does not happen again.\nAt the time of the 2016 election
column15: we observed and acted on instances of automated and malicious activity. \u00c2\u00a0As we learned more about the scope of the broader problem
column16: we resolved to strengthen our systems going forward. \u00c2\u00a0Elections continue all the time
column17: so our first priority was to do all we could to block and remove malicious activity from interfering with our users\u00e2\u0080\u0099 experience. \u00c2\u00a0We created dedicated teams within Twitter to enhance the quality of the information our users see and to block malicious activity whenever and wherever we find it. \u00c2\u00a0Those teams continue to work every day to ensure Twitter remains a safe
column18: open
column19: transparent
column20: and positive platform.\nWe have also launched a retrospective review to find Russian efforts to influence the 2016 election through automation
column21: coordinated activity
column22: and advertising. While that review is still underway
column23: we have made the decision to share what we know
column24: today
column25: in the interests of transparency and out of appreciation for the urgency of this matter. \u00c2\u00a0We do so recognizing that our findings may be supplemented as we work with Committee staff and other companies
column26: discover more facts
column27: and gain a greater understanding of these events.\u00c2\u00a0 \u00c2\u00a0\nMy written testimony details the methodology and current findings of the retrospective review in detail. \u00c2\u00a0We studied Tweets from the period September 1 to November 15
column28: 2016. \u00c2\u00a0During that time
column29:
we did find automated and coordinated activity of interest. Â We determined that the number of accounts we could link to Russia and that were Tweeting election-related content was comparatively smallâaround one one-hundredth of a percent of total Twitter accounts at the time we studied.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
One third of one percent of the election-related Tweets people saw came from Russian-linked automated accounts. Â We did
column30: however
column31: observe instances where Russian-linked activity was more pronounced
column32:
and we have uncovered more accounts linked to the Russian-based Internet Research Agency as a result of our review.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We also determined that advertising by Russia Today and seven small accounts was related to the election and violated either the policies in effect at the time or that have since been implemented. Â We have banned all of those users as advertisers
column33: and we will donate the revenue to academic research into the use of Twitter during elections and for civic engagement.\nWe are making meaningful improvements based on our findings. \u00c2\u00a0Last week
column34: we announced industry-leading changes to our advertising policies that will help protect our platform from unwanted content. \u00c2\u00a0We are also enhancing our safety policies
column35: sharpening our tools for stopping malicious activity
column36: and increasing transparency to promote public understanding of all these areas. \u00c2\u00a0These improvements will further our efforts to fight both terrorist content and disinformation. \u00c2\u00a0We will continue confronting these challenges for as long as malicious actors seek to abuse our system and will need to evolve to stay ahead of new tactics. \n\u00c2\u00a0\nWe have heard the concerns about Russian actors\u00e2\u0080\u0099 use of Twitter to disrupt the 2016 election and about our commitment to addressing this issue. \u00c2\u00a0Twitter believes that any activity of that kind\u00e2\u0080\u0094regardless of magnitude\u00e2\u0080\u0094is unacceptable
column37: and we agree that we must do better to prevent it. \u00c2\u00a0We hope that our appearance today and the description of the work we have undertaken demonstrates our commitment to working with you
column38: our industry partners
column39: and other stakeholders to ensure that the experience of 2016 never happens again.\nCooperation to combat this challenge is essential. \u00c2\u00a0We cannot defeat this evolving
column40: shared threat alone. \u00c2\u00a0As with most technology-based threats
column41: the best approach is to combine information and ideas to increase our collective knowledge. \u00c2\u00a0Working with the broader community
column42: we will continue to test
column43: to learn
column44: to share
column45:
and to improve so that our product remains effective and safe.
I look forward to answering your questions.
 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter
Tweet
Twitter logo icon
Tags:
government
policy

column40: shared threat alone. \u00c2\u00a0As with most technology-based threats
column41: the best approach is to combine information and ideas to increase our collective knowledge. \u00c2\u00a0Working with the broader community
column42: we will continue to test
column43: to learn
column44: to share
column45:
and to improve so that our product remains effective and safe.
I look forward to answering your questions.

column3: "title": "Announcement: RT and Sputnik Advertising"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nAnnouncement: RT and Sputnik Advertising\nThursday
column8: 26 October 2017\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter has made the policy decision to off-board advertising from all accounts owned by Russia Today (RT) and Sputnik
column9: effective immediately. This decision was based on the retrospective work we've been doing around the 2016 US election\u00c2\u00a0and the US intelligence community\u00e2\u0080\u0099s conclusion that both RT and Sputnik attempted to interfere with the election on behalf of the Russian government. We did not come to this decision lightly
column10: and are taking this step now as part of our ongoing commitment to help protect the integrity of the user experience on Twitter. \nEarly this year
column11: the US intelligence community named RT and Sputnik as implementing state-sponsored Russian efforts to interfere with and disrupt the 2016 Presidential election
column12: which is not something we want on Twitter. This decision is restricted to these two entities based our internal investigation of their behavior as well as their inclusion in the January 2017 DNI report. This decision does not apply to any other advertisers. RT and Sputnik may remain organic users on our platform
column13: in accordance with the Twitter Rules.\nTwitter has also decided to take the $1.9 million we are projected to have earned from RT global advertising since they became an advertiser in 2011
column14: which includes the $274
column15: 100 in 2016 US-based advertising that we highlighted in our September 28 blog post
column16: and donate those funds to support external research into the use of Twitter in civic engagement and elections
column17: including use of malicious automation and misinformation
column18:
with an initial focus on elections and automation. We will have more details to share on this disbursement soon. Â 
Â 
Â

column3: "title": "New transparency for ads on Twitter"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
New transparency for ads on Twitter
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 24 October 2017\nLink copied successfully\nToday
column9: we're announcing steps to dramatically increase transparency for all ads on Twitter
column10: including political ads and issue-based ads. We will also be improving controls for our customers and adopting stricter advertising policies.\u00c2\u00a0\nAll Ads: Advertising Transparency Center\nIn the coming weeks
column11: we will launch an industry-leading transparency center that will offer everyone visibility into who is advertising on Twitter
column12: details behind those ads
column13: and tools to share your feedback with us.\nSpecifically
column14: the Transparency Center will show:\nAll ads that are currently running on Twitter
column15:
including Promoted-Only ads
How long ads have been running
Ad creative associated with those campaigns
Ads targeted to you
column16: as well as personalized information on which ads you are eligible to receive based on targeting\nPeople can also report inappropriate ads or give negative feedback (i.e. \u00e2\u0080\u009cI don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t like this ad\u00e2\u0080\u009d) for every ad running on Twitter
column17: whether the ad targets you or not. This feedback will help us more quickly remove inappropriate ads from Twitter
column18: and show you more relevant ads in your timeline.\nPolitical (Electioneering) Ads\nElectioneering ads are those that refer to a clearly identified candidate (or party associated with that candidate) for any elected office.* To make it clear when you are seeing or engaging with an electioneering ad
column19:
we will now require that electioneering advertisers identify their campaigns as such. We will also change the look and feel of these ads and include a visual political ad indicator.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
             An example of what a future political ad may look like 
          
          
        
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In the Transparency Center
column20: there will be a special section for electioneering ads that will include:\nAll ads that are currently running or that have run on Twitter
column21:
including Promoted-Only ads
Disclosure on total campaign ad spend by advertiser
Transparency about the identity of the organization funding the campaign
Targeting demographics
column22: such as age
column23:
gender and geography
Historical data about all electioneering ad spending by advertiser
We are also updating our policies for electioneering advertisers to:
Include stricter requirements on who can serve these ads and limit targeting options
Require electioneering advertisers to self-identify as such
Introduce stronger penalties for advertisers who violate policies
Regarding Issue-Based Ads
We are committed to stricter policies and transparency around issue-based ads. There is currently no clear industry definition for issue-based ads but we will work with our peer companies
column24: other industry leaders
column25: policy makers
column26: and ad partners to clearly define them quickly and integrate them into the new approach mentioned above.\nThe Way Forward\nWe will make these updates first in the US
column27: and then roll them out globally. We will share our progress here with all of you along the way.\nLast week
column28: Senators Mark Warner (D-VA)
column29: Amy Klobuchar (D-MN) and John McCain (R-AZ) and Representatives Derek Kilmer (D-WA)
column30:
and Mike Coffman (R-CO) introduced theÂ Honest Ads Act legislation. We thank these members and others for their foresight in drawing attention to these issues as well as Chairman Hurd (R-TX) for holding a public hearing today on political advertising laws and regulations to facilitate a thoughtful discussion on disclosure policy. We look forward to engaging with Members of Congress and other key stakeholders on these issues as the legislative process continues.
Â 
*âElectioneering Advertisementsâ Definition
Twitter is basing our definition of âelectioneeringâ ads on the FECâs existing definition: this means ads that refer to a clearly identified candidate (or party associated with that candidate) for any elected office
column31:
are targeted to the relevant electorate for that federal candidate and are publicly distributed within 30 days of a primary election or 60 days of a general election. This policy will also apply to ads on our platform that run at any time and expressly advocate for a clearly identified political candidate.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "How policy changes work"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nHow policy changes work\nFriday
column8: 20 October 2017\nLink copied successfully\nYesterday
column9: we published a calendar of our safety work and many people had questions about how we determine timelines and when we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re planning to introduce changes. We write one set of rules for the hundreds of millions of people who use Twitter and the hundreds of millions of Tweets sent every day. Given that scale
column10: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve built a process that gives us time to recognize the impact of what these changes mean for everyone.\nMaking a policy change requires in-depth research around trends in online behavior
column11: developing language that sets expectations around what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s allowed
column12: and reviewer guidelines that can be enforced across millions of Tweets. Once drafted
column13: we gather feedback from our teams and Trust & Safety Council. We gather input from around the world so that we can consider diverse
column14: global perspectives around the changing nature of online speech
column15: including how our rules are applied and interpreted in different cultural and social contexts. We then test the proposed rule with samples of potentially abusive Tweets to measure the policy effectiveness and once we determine it meets our expectations
column16: build and operationalize product changes to support the update. Finally
column17: we train our global review teams
column18: update the Twitter Rules
column19:
and start enforcing it.
We hope this helps explain our process and why itâs important to be thoughtful and deliberate about changes to our safety policies.
Â 
Â 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Twitter
#OnlyOnTwitter

Thursday
column10: 19 October 2017\nLink copied successfully\nOur Brand Strategy team partners with top Twitter clients to create experiences that deliver outsized attention and impact on the platform. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve focused on this mission for several years \u00e2\u0080\u0094 helping best-in-class brands drive impactful experiences at scale. Today
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re proud to announce that we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve expanded the team to support even more brands with a new arm offering end-to-end creative consulting and support
column12: #Fuel.  Brands want to move at the speed of culture
column13: and this team is designed to address that need. #Fuel is an agile
column14: rapid-response hub that responds quickly to creative briefs. The team develops content strategy to help set the strategic foundation
column15: builds creative ideas to drive participation with brands
column16: and drives video editing to help assets work harder in the feed. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve worked on more than 100 campaigns over the past few months with early brand partners.  Content strategy Twitter is the first place people go to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening and what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s being talked about. They come leaned in with a discovery mindset
column17: and that offers marketers a critical moment of receptivity. According to research from IPG
column18: video ads in a curated social feed like Twitter are perceived to be more relevant and less intrusive than similarly skippable units on other platforms. Video ads on Twitter are also found to be almost 2X as memorable when compared to the same ads on other premium sites.  The #Fuel team helps brands develop their content strategy to connect with consumers and drive business impact. In Twitter Planning Studios
column19: strategists work with brand partners to map moments of receptivity
column20: develop content pillars
column21: and apply creative best practices that earn attention in the fast-moving feed.\n\u00c2\u00a0\nCreative ideas While consumers skip uninteresting ads
column22: they don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t skip experiences. Twitter is unique in that brands can create experiences that enable participation and drive conversation. The #Fuel team helps brands realize their creative potential through Twitter products like conversational video
column23: chatbots
column24: and auto-response campaigns that deliver custom content.\nAdditionally
column25: the #Fuel team is helping brand partners develop their live-stream strategy. We worked with Converse to strengthen how they connect with their consumers

column3: "title": "Make your videos work harder with the Video Website Card"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Make your videos work harder with the Video Website Card
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 17 October 2017\nLink copied successfully\nAs users have come to expect more personalized interactions with brands
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re increasingly hearing from brands that they want to create more seamless user experiences for consumers along various stages of the path to conversion. Today we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re introducing the Video Website Card
column10: a creative format that combines the power of video with the ability to drive users back to a site to learn more or take action in the moment.  The Video Website Card is designed to work across a variety of brand objectives
column11: as well as in the gray spaces that often exist between objectives. So whether a brand is pairing the Video Website Card with the high reach of First View to announce a product launch
column12: inviting travelers to click through to learn more about a featured destination
column13: or showcasing game play to drive advance sales of a new video game
column14: the Video Website Card removes friction for the consumer to engage
column15: learn
column16:
or convert at their own rate.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
With the Video Website Card
column17: businesses can:\nAttract qualified consumers with immersive auto-playing video showcasing their brand\u00e2\u0080\u0099s value
column18: product
column19: or service before a person clicks through. Overall in the beta
column20: the Video Website Card achieved a 2X higher clickthrough rate than the industry benchmark for mobile video ads. Gupta Media (@GuptaMedia) partnered across several beta clients
column21: including Republic Records (@RepublicRecords)
column22:
who used the Video Website Card to drive digital streams of hip-hop artist AminÃ©âs (@heyamine) debut album âGood For You.â
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The Video Website Card allowed us to utilize eye-catching clips from AminÃ©âs music video to capture attention in user timelines and link them directly to Spotify where they could listen to the full track. We drove 53K clicks to Spotify at $0.04 cost per click â and saw a bonus 303K video views. Based on the success from campaigns like this one
column23: we expect to incorporate these ads into our strategy whenever possible going forward.\nAaron Bogucki\nVP of Digital Media
column24:
Republic Records
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Extend brand engagement beyond the end of the video with creative designed to drive consumers to your site to learn more or take action. For example
column25: Bank of America (@BofA_Tips) used fun vignettes to showcase the features of its mobile banking app
column26:
and directed those who wanted more details back to its site. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We loved that fan engagement does not end with the video. We could showcase the benefits of the Bank of America app and then allow those who are interested  to click and learn more while weâre top of mind. In our campaigns
column27: we were able to drive thousands of incremental visitors to our site\nChris Smith\nSVP
column28: Enterprise Social Media Marketing\n\u00c2\u00a0\nKeep consumers\u00e2\u0080\u0099 attention as they move down the funnel. On mobile
column29: the video anchors to the top of the screen and continues to play while the website loads below it. By bridging this experience
column30: we saw a significant reduction in the number of users who quickly abandoned the site while it was still loading. In fact
column31: beta participants saw an average 60% increase in user retention over industry averages.\nJaguar USA (@JaguarUSA) used this format to hook users with a video featuring the sleek design of the F-type
column32:
and then invited them to learn more on their site. 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The Video Website Card allowed us to visually showcase the new 2018 Jaguar F-TYPE and also direct consumers to the site to explore its features and start to build their own. The experience of allowing the user to continue to watch the video while the site loaded was sleek and drove 25% more efficient traffic to our website compared to using a static image.
Brady Fain
Social Media Specialist
column33: Jaguar Land Rover North America\n(Source: 1.Twitter internal data; eMarketer video ad CTR benchmark on mobile
column34: Q2 2017; 2. Twitter internal data; Doubleclick 'The Need for Mobile Speed' 2016
column35: comparing % of users who dwell \u00c2\u00a0> 3 seconds after a page starts loading)\n The Video Website Card features an auto-playing video
column36: a customizable headline
column37: and destination URL paired with a large tap target. Advertisers can elect to run this creative unit on the video views
column38: website clicks
column39: or awareness objectives to optimize and pay for the action they care about the most. For example
column40: a movie studio that wants to launch a new movie may run the Video Website Card optimizing for video views on the trailer early in the campaign when their primary goal is driving awareness
column41:
and optimize for website clicks later in the campaign when the movie is in theatres and their primary goal is ticket sales.Â Â  
 The Video Website Card is now available to all advertisers globally. Reach out to your account team or visit our Help Center to learn more and get started today at ads.twitter.com.
