column3: "title": "Twitter partners with Cybersmile on inaugural #TweetForACause initiative"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Twitter partners with Cybersmile on inaugural #TweetForACause initiative
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 12 October 2017\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter
column9: powered by Niche\u00e2\u0080\u0099s powerful global content creator network
column10: and Cybersmile are partnering up to kick-off #TweetForACause
column11: Twitter's first-ever pro-bono creator initiative. The inaugural campaign will drive awareness around Cybersmile's mission to combat cyberbullying and online abuse.\nTwitter is launching its first #TweetForACause campaign tapping into the powerful voices of Niche\u00e2\u0080\u0099s global creator network
column12: which the company acquired in 2015. The #TweetForACause initiative will be the first in an ongoing semi-annual series. Future NGO partners will be selected based on their alignment to Twitter for Good\u00e2\u0080\u0099s philanthropic mission
column13: and each activation will be powered by Niche\u00e2\u0080\u0099s global creator network. As part of its inaugural campaign
column14: Niche creators will be driving awareness for Cybersmile\u00e2\u0080\u0099s efforts in preventing cyberbullying and online abuse.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cWe couldn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t think of a better partner than Cybersmile to kick off Niche\u00e2\u0080\u0099s #TweetForACause pro bono initiative
column15: particularly as we continue to honor Bullying Prevention Month in October. We are humbled to be a part of their mission to combat cyberbullying through the voices of our most influential and trusted content creators
column16: \u00e2\u0080\u009d Leah Feygin
column17: Sr. Brand Strategist
column18: Twitter.\nAs a creator-first network
column19: Niche has seen firsthand how creators have had to deal with issues relating to cyberbullying and aims to have a positive impact by sparking conversation around Cybersmile's mission
column20: particularly during Bullying Prevention Month. \n\u00e2\u0080\u009cWe are honored and excited to be included as the launch partner for Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s new bi-annual #TweetForACause initiative. With the inclusion in Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s new #TweetForACause initiative
column21: awareness of Cybersmile and our work will be raised to millions of new people around the world - potentially changing and even saving huge numbers of lives in the short and long term.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Scott Freeman
column22: CEO
column23: The Cybersmile Foundation. \nStarting on October 12th
column24:
content creators from the US and UK will utilize the collective power of the Twitter platform to create and share original content that encourages internet users to support and promote Cybersmileâs work around the world. Creators include:
Josh Peck
King Bach
Misshattan
Trey Kennedy
Sara Hopkins
UsTheDuo
Ollie McKendrick
Ben Waddleton
Make sure you follow along on their handles and @CybersmileHQ - and get involved using #TweetForACause!
Â

column3: "title": "#Promote Innovation Challenge: Announcing the 2017 Winners"
column7:
"post_text": "Events
#Promote Innovation Challenge: Announcing the 2017 Winners
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 4 October 2017\nLink copied successfully\nIn May
column9: we announced that the 2017 #Promote Innovation Challenge would highlight marketing solutions leading the industry in three categories: Content + Creative
column10: Video
column11: and Ad Tech. We were blown away by the quality and diversity of entries and faced the difficult task of selecting just three finalists in each category to move forward toward the $100
column12: 000 cash prizes.\n\u00c2\u00a0\nWe think of our partner ecosystem as an extension of our own product team
column13:
working collaboratively to make marketing better on Twitter. Each of the selected finalistsâ products address critical advertiser needs and create opportunities for brands to powerfully engage Twitterâs global audience.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Last week
column14:
we invited all nine finalists to @TwitterNYC to meet with the Twitter team and cap off the 2017 #Promote Innovation Challenge with live presentations. Each finalist had eight minutes to present their solutions before a live audience and a judging panel of Twitterâs key executive decision makers.  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The 2017 #Promote Innovation Challenge judging panel included: Matt Derella (VP
column15: Sales)
column16: Gui Ribenboim (VP
column17: Global Client Solutions)
column18: Silvia Manak (Sr. Director
column19: Corporate Development)
column20: Jen Prince (Sr. Director
column21: Media & Entertainment)
column22: Wook Chung (Director
column23: Product Management)
column24: and Bobby Grasberger (Sr. Manager
column25:
Brand Strategy). 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
2017 #Promote Innovation Challenge Finalists Content + Creative WINNER: Social Native Social Native's content engine enables brands to generate high volumes of content on demand. Their creative optimization platform utilizes cutting edge technologies to help companies predict content relevancy and performance.
Finalist: Curalate Curalate's Showroom turns any paid or organic Tweet into a shoppable
column26: personalized storefront in seconds
column27: in order to help marketers drive more qualified site traffic & revenue from Twitter.\nFinalist: Conversable Conversable is the enterprise conversational intelligence platform for launching automated chat bots and voice bots. \u00c2\u00a0\nVideo WINNER: VidMob VidMob is a global platform that connects Twitter marketers to a network of expert video creators available
column28: on demand. \u00c2\u00a0They offer the fastest
column29: most cost efficient way to produce a large volume of high performance video ads.\nFinalist: Animoto Animoto's online video builder makes it easy for anyone to create powerful and professional videos. \u00c2\u00a0Marketers around the world use Animoto to turn content they already have into high-performing videos that stand out in a video-first world.\nFinalist: Vidsy Vidsy is the new way to create. Powered by a disruptive tech platform and harnessing a new generation of creators
column30:
Vidsy help's the world's leading brands create quality video ads at scale. Â 
Ad Tech WINNER: CyberAgent AIRTRACK is a leading provider for geo location services in Japan. The collaboration between Twitter and AIRTRACK has a big impact against the shift to digital of promotional budget.
Finalist: 4C Activate audiences designed to engage and convert using real insight about real people through a combination of customer intelligence and 4Câs proprietary data science.
Finalist: Sprinklr Always On Campaigns connects campaign management and data insight by automating the process of audience identification
column31: ad sequencing
column32: and optimization. Advertisers can create a relevant sequence of ads in a unified workflow to guide consumers down the funnel based on their conversions on and off Twitter.\nCongratulations to our 2017 #Promote Innovation Challenge winners: Social Native (Content + Creative)
column33: Vidmob (Video)
column34:
and Cyberagent (Ad Tech)!
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As we close out #Promote2017
column35:
weâd like to thank our partners for their innovative contributions and continued partnership. Weâre excited to continue to work together to find creative solutions for marketers on Twitter.

column3: "title": "During #HispanicHeritage
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/company/2017/HispanicHeritage2017"
column8: "post_text": "Company\nDuring #HispanicHeritage
column9:
immigration is âwhatâs happeningâ
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column10:
2 October 2017
Link copied successfully
Â 
Twitter is where inclusion lives; this is what we stated on our blog at the beginning of this year
column11: sharing the work we are doing towards inclusion and staying true to our 2015 commitment to a more diverse Twitter. We realized early on that in order to better serve our users
column12: the makeup of our company has to reflect not only the openness and global nature of the platform
column13: but also the diversity of our users. Living up to this responsibility
column14: and to continue engaging with our community
column15: we joined this year\u00e2\u0080\u0099s #HispanicHeritage celebration.\nEvery year
column16: from September 15th to October 15th
column17: the United States celebrates the positive influence that the Hispanic community has had on American society. This year
column18: although the Hispanic community is going through tumultuous political times
column19: this known vibrant community can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t be stopped from celebrating its roots and contributions to US culture. This is
column20: however
column21: without setting aside its most pressing issue: immigration reforms.\nAround the company
column22: the theme ran true with various events. San Francisco
column23: hosted a Fireside Chat with the amazing Latinx advocate and former White House aid to President Obama
column24: Alejandra Campoverdi (@ACampoverdi). New York
column25: will be hosting a \u00e2\u0080\u009cLatinx Marketing Panel\u00e2\u0080\u009d on October 5th
column26: to discuss the importance and influence of this growing audience for marketers. These and other gatherings
column27: panels
column28: dance classes
column29:
and movie screenings focusing on Hispanic culture will be happening throughout this month.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
@TwitterDC we also joined this celebration. We started by supporting our partner
column30: the National Hispanic Foundation for the Arts on their annual Quorum Call and Noche de Gala
column31: to support the advancement of Latinos in the media
column32: telecommunications
column33: and entertainment industries. Likewise
column34: to keep supporting our non-profit partners and grow our community
column35:
we hosted an all-Spanish â first one in DC â âSafety and Best Practicesâ training for organizations working with the Hispanic community in DC.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Â 
These days when we think about Hispanics in the US
column36: we no only think about food
column37: music
column38: telenovelas
column39: and the Spanish language; we also think about immigration reform. For this reason
column40: the highlight of our event was a panel hosted with the purpose of discussing the influence of Hispanics in US culture
column41: media
column42: and politics. Yet
column43: the conversation focused on immigration
column44: and the issues that immigrants
column45: especially those from Latin America
column46: are currently facing.\n\u00c2\u00a0\nWe had the pleasure of hosting Michelin Awarded Chef Jos\u00c3\u00a9 Andr\u00c3\u00a9s (@ChefJoseAndres); seven-time Emmy Award Winner and White House Correspondent for Univision
column47: Janet Rodr\u00c3\u00adguez (@JanRodriguezTV); and senior advisor at the Carlos Slim Foundation and former Mayor of Nogales
column48: Arizona
column49:
Marco Lopez (@1MarcoLopez).
Â 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The discussion began with our panelists sharing their stories of how they âcrossed the borderâ
column50: which were not the dramatic and nostalgic tales that you would expect. Janet Rodriguez came from Cuba when she was 12
column51: and she remembers getting ready for this move through her young years in Cuba. Marco Lopez grew up right on the border
column52: between Nogales
column53: Sonora and Nogales
column54: Arizona and his move to \u00e2\u0080\u0098the other side\u00e2\u0080\u0099 felt almost natural. Jos\u00c3\u00a9 Andr\u00c3\u00a9s on his part came from Spain as a cook
column55: and although he faced some paperwork issues
column56: he was finally sponsored and obtained his Green Card.\nOur panelists
column57: as many other Hispanics
column58: have stayed close to their roots
column59: and used the different means they have
column60: given their profession and networks
column61: to support the later generations of immigrants that have come to the US.\nGetting more specific on their areas of expertise
column62: Janet Rodriguez highlighted the importance of accurate and neutral journalism: \u00e2\u0080\u009cYou have to be really careful and responsible
column63: and aware that these news affect real people's lives.\u00e2\u0080\u009d She also mentioned the importance of social media
column64: as a tool for immigrants and especially now for DACA kids to raise their voices and tell their stories.\nSpeaking about the influence of immigrants in the US
column65: Jos\u00c3\u00a9 Andr\u00c3\u00a9s pointed out that there was no other place where you could find more diversity than in the United States: \u00e2\u0080\u009cIt is truly a melting pot and it's a beautiful thing to see. America embraces immigration
column66: it has become what it is because it is a nation of immigrants that embraces differences. Let's put aside the negative voices that say immigration is not good.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nTo close up
column67: Marco Lopez reminded us that
column68: although the topic of immigration reform is what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening
column69: Hispanic heritage is not about pinpointing the issues of the Hispanic community in the US. It is about celebrating Hispanic tradition and culture
column70: and that \u00e2\u0080\u009cimmigration is not what defines us.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nTwitter allows us to learn
column71: tell stories
column72: and connect
column73: and there isn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t a more appropriate time to highlight these attributes than during a month to celebrate the cultural diversity that makes us who we are. As we approach the end of Hispanic Heritage Month
column74: we hope the public and open nature of our platform keeps empowering voices
column75: and provoking a greater understanding of the needs and expectations of our society \u00e2\u0080\u009cnot in spite of our differences
column76:
but because of them.â (Building a more inclusive Twitter in 2016).
Our inspiring panel was live streamed on Periscope. Watch it here. We also compiled the best content and Tweets in this Moment: Celebrating Hispanic Heritage for a recap.  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Update: Russian interference in the 2016 US presidential election"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nUpdate: Russian interference in the 2016 US presidential election\nThursday
column8: 28 September 2017\nLink copied successfully\nEarlier this summer we outlined some of our work to combat bots and networks of manipulation on Twitter. Since then
column9: we have received a number of questions about how malicious bots and misinformation networks on Twitter may have been used in the context of the 2016 US presidential elections.\nTwitter deeply respects the integrity of the election process
column10: which is a cornerstone for all democracies. We will continue to strengthen Twitter against attempted manipulation
column11: including malicious automated accounts and spam
column12: as well as other activities that violate our Terms of Service.\nTwitter is in dialogue with congressional committees with respect to investigations into Russian interference in the 2016 US election. Today
column13: Twitter Vice President for Public Policy Colin Crowell met with staff from Senate Select Committee on Intelligence and House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence to discuss these issues. This is an ongoing process and we will continue to collaborate with investigators.\nDue to the nature of these inquiries
column14: we may not always be able to publicly share what we discuss with investigators. And there will always be tools or methods we cannot talk about
column15: because doing so would only help bad actors circumvent them. But we know there is a huge appetite for more transparency into how Twitter fights bots and manipulative networks. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll do our best to keep you informed of both our findings on these specific issues and
column16: more broadly
column17: our efforts to fight bots
column18: spam
column19: and malicious information networks on Twitter.\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important to note our work to fight both malicious bots and misinformation goes beyond any one specific election
column20: event
column21: or time period. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve spent years working to identify and remove spammy or malicious accounts and applications on Twitter. And we continue to improve our internal systems to detect and prevent new forms of spam and malicious automation
column22: in real time
column23: while also expanding our efforts to educate the public on how to identify and use quality content on Twitter.\nToday we are sharing a lot of information that is meant for a wide range of audiences. There are many ways to approach these issues
column24: whether you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re a concerned US voter
column25: a journalist
column26: a developer
column27: etc. We are sharing as much as we can at this stage because of our commitment to be as transparent as possible.\nWith hundreds of millions of Tweets globally every day
column28: scaling these efforts continues to be a challenge. We will continue to look into these matters on an ongoing basis
column29: and we fully anticipate having more to share as we look into further requests for information. Here are some initial findings that we would like to share publicly at this stage:\nOur Internal Inquiries\nOf the roughly 450 accounts that Facebook recently shared as a part of their review
column30: we concluded that 22 had corresponding accounts on Twitter. All of those identified accounts had already been or immediately were suspended from Twitter for breaking our rules
column31: most for violating our prohibitions against spam.\nIn addition
column32: from those accounts we found an additional 179 related or linked accounts
column33: and took action on the ones we found in violation of our rules. Neither the original accounts shared by Facebook
column34: nor the additional related accounts we identified
column35: were registered as advertisers on Twitter. However
column36: we continue to investigate these issues
column37: and will take action on anything that violates our Terms of Service.\nRussia Today\nThe US intelligence community released a report in January
column39: highlighting the role that RT (Russia Today)
column40: which has strong links to the Russian government
column41: allegedly played in seeking to interfere in the 2016 US election and undermine trust in American democracy. RT has accounts on Twitter and tweets regularly. The open nature of the Twitter platform means this activity was public.\nToday we proactively shared with committee staff a round-up of ads that three RT accounts (@RT_com
column42: @RT_America
column43: and @ActualidadRT) targeted to the US market in 2016. As of our meetings today we believe this is the complete list from these three accounts within that time frame
column44: but we are continuing to review our internal data and will report back to the committees as we have more to share.\nBased on our findings thus far
column45: RT spent $274
column46: 100 in US ads in 2016. \u00c2\u00a0In that year
column47: the @RT_com
column48: @RT_America
column49: and @ActualidadRT accounts promoted 1
column50: 823 Tweets that definitely or potentially targeted the US market. These campaigns were directed at followers of mainstream media and primarily promoted RT Tweets regarding news stories.\nElection Vote Issues\nWe are concerned about violations of our Terms of Service and US law with respect to interference in the exercise of voting rights. When we become aware of such activity we take appropriate and timely action. During the 2016 election
column51: we removed Tweets that were attempting to suppress or otherwise interfere with the exercise of voting rights
column52: including the right to have a vote counted
column53: by circulating intentionally misleading information.\nFor instance: when we were alerted to Hillary Clinton \u00e2\u0080\u009ctext-to-vote\u00e2\u0080\u009d examples
column54: we proactively tweeted reminders that one cannot vote via text
column55: examined the content reported to us
column56: used our proprietary tools to search for linked accounts that violated our rules
column57: and
column58: after careful review
column59: took action on thousands of Tweets and accounts. We have not found accounts associated with this activity to have obvious Russian origin but some of the accounts appear to have been automated. We have shared examples of the content of these removed Tweets with congressional investigators.\nPolitical Advertising Disclosure\nWe note recent calls for increased public disclosure with respect to political advertisements on social media
column60: including Twitter. Twitter supports making political advertising more transparent to our users and the public.\nInternally
column61: we already have stricter policies for advertising campaigns on Twitter than we do for organic content. We also have existing specific policies and review mechanisms for campaign ads
column62: but will examine them with an eye to improving them. We welcome the opportunity to work with the FEC and leaders in Congress to review and strengthen guidelines for political advertising on social media.\nAutomated Traffic & Spam\nEvery online platform has to deal with spam
column63: and there is no silver bullet. For example
column64: the Internet Society estimated in October 2015 that up to 85 percent of all global email is spam -- and that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s after decades of every email platform in the world tackling this challenge. Obviously email is very different from Tweets
column65: but it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s important to understand the scale of what we are dealing with
column66: and that this is a global issue for all platforms.\nRussia and other post-Soviet states have been a primary source of automated and spammy content on Twitter for many years. Content that violates our rules with respect to automated accounts and spam can have a highly negative effect on user experience
column67: and we have long taken substantial action to stem that flow.\nAs patterns of malicious activity evolve
column68: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re adapting to meet them head-on. On average
column69: our automated systems catch more than 3.2 million suspicious accounts globally per week \u00e2\u0080\u0094 more than double the amount we detected this time last year. As our detection of automated accounts and content has improved
column70: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re better able to catch malicious accounts when they log into Twitter or first start to create spam. We have not and do not include spam accounts that we have identified in the active user numbers that we report to shareholders. As we have said
column71: we estimate that false or spam accounts represent less than 5% of our MAUs.\nThese are just some of our tools:\nThe most effective way to fight suspicious bots is stopping them before they start. To do this
column72: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve built systems to identify suspicious attempts to log in to Twitter
column73: including signs that a login may be automated or scripted. These techniques now help us catch about 450
column74: 000 suspicious logins per day. Importantly
column75: much of this defensive work is done through machine learning and automated processes on our back end
column76: and we have been able to significantly improve our automatic spam and bot-detection tools
column77: resulting in a 64% year-over-year increase in suspicious logins we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re able to detect.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re investing in systems to stop bad content at its source if its point of origin corresponds with a known bad actor. However
column78: the use of proxy servers
column79: VPNs
column80: and other forms of authentication
column81: especially outside of the United States
column82: may obscure the true origin of traffic on Twitter. We are working on better identifying the true origins of traffic and blocking activity from suspicious sources.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also improving how we detect and cluster accounts that were created by a single entity or a single suspicious source. We used these techniques to stop more than 5.7 million spammy follows from a single source just last week (9/21/2017).\nDetecting non-human activity patterns: Using signals like the frequency and timing of Tweets and engagements
column83: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve built models that can detect whether an activity on Twitter is likely automated. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re expanding how we use these signals to restrict how users see suspicious accounts.\nCompromised account detection: To stop bad actors from exploiting otherwise healthy accounts to spread malicious content
column84: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re investing in new ways to identify potentially compromised accounts. For example
column85: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re building systems to detect when login activity is inconsistent with a user\u00e2\u0080\u0099s typical behavior
column86: to help get compromised accounts back under the control of their owners.\nChecking suspicious content: Accounts and content detected by our systems are subject to a number of enforcement actions and limitations including: being placed in a \u00e2\u0080\u009cread only\u00e2\u0080\u009d mode pending authentication
column87: having the reach of Tweets limited based on suspicious origin or low quality content
column88: the removal of associated content
column89: and account suspension.\nThird-party apps: We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also continuing to invest in proactively identifying and taking action against applications that violate our developer policies -- including bots and automated apps. While some bots can provide a vital public utility in times of crisis and natural disaster
column90: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re committed to combatting the minority of apps that create spam and abuse via our API. Since June 2017
column92: 000 malicious applications for abusing our API
column93: collectively responsible for more than 1.5 billion low-quality Tweets this year.\nPreventing false positives: Any automated system for detecting spam or bots has a chance of false positives
column94: and it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s our goal to bring this as low as possible. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we typically give users caught by our spam detections an opportunity to verify that they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re legitimate before we suspend them from the platform. During this window
column95: accounts may still appear on Twitter and via our public API
column96: even though they are not able to create new Tweets and engagements. We also limit the visibility of these accounts and their content in both Search and Trends.\nImproving phone verification: When we detect suspicious activity from an account
column97: we may require that user to verify their phone number to regain access to Twitter. But
column98: as spammers have adapted their techniques
column99: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve found that not all phone numbers are equally trustworthy. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve improved our phone reputation system to identify suspicious carriers and numbers and prevent their repeated use to pass verification challenges.\nA note about third-party research:\nStudies of the impact of bots and automation on Twitter necessarily and systematically under-represent our enforcement actions because these defensive actions are not visible via our API
column100: and because they take place shortly after content is created and delivered via our streaming API. Furthermore
column101: researchers using an API often overlook the substantial in-product features that prioritize the most relevant content. Based on user interests and choices
column102: we limit the visibility of low-quality content using tools such as Quality Filter and Safe Search -- both of which are on by default for all of Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s users and active for more than 97% of users.\nHuman-Directed Accounts\nWhile we have made important progress addressing spam and other forms of malicious automation on Twitter
column103: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve identified new and emerging challenges dealing with non-automated content -- i.e.
column104: human-directed accounts instead of bots -- that coordinate their activities to spread information.\nWhen large numbers of human-directed accounts act in coordinated fashion
column105: it can have an effect similar to that of spam. That doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t mean that these accounts aren\u00e2\u0080\u0099t violating our Terms of Service -- in some cases
column106: they are -- but we have to approach this problem differently than we do bots and other forms of automated content. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s much trickier to identify non-automated coordination
column107: and the risks of inadvertently silencing legitimate activity are much higher. We are continuing to work on this
column108: and are committed to getting better at it.\nGaming Trending Topics\nAttempting to game trending topics is a practice as old as Trends on Twitter themselves
column109: and over the years we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve invested heavily in thwarting spam and other automated attempts to manipulate Trends. We take active measures to protect against trend gaming
column110: such as excluding automated Tweets and users from our calculations of a Trend.\nImportantly
column111: as spammers change their tactics we actively modify our technological tools to address such situations. Since June 2017
column112: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been able to detect an average of 130
column113: 000 accounts per day who are attempting to manipulate Trends -- and have taken steps to prevent that impact. This is an area where saying more about those steps would only help bad actors
column114: but we will keep looking for new ways to illustrate with examples the important progress we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made on this front.\nElectoral Outreach\nWe engage with national election commissions regularly and consistently bolster our security and agent review coverage during key moments of election cycles around the world. We will continue to do this
column115: and expand our outreach so that we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve got strong
column116: clear escalation processes in place for all potentialities during major elections and global political events.\nSupporting Media Literacy and Accurate Emergency Information\nIn our increasingly polarized public sphere
column117: we believe developing critical media skills is more important than ever. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we are creating a dedicated media literacy program to demonstrate how Twitter can be an indispensable educational tool. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also sponsoring
column119: and hosting a Media Literacy Week in some of our key markets.\nFrom the Zika Virus to Hurricane Harvey
column120: Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s real-time nature is vital in emergency scenarios and can save lives. We want to ensure factual information is elevated across our platform in times of crisis. As part of our flagship philanthropic initiative
column121: we continue to fund promoted campaigns
column123: that promote disaster relief efforts and elevate vital communication from reliable sources during emergencies.\nFinally
column124: whether it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s our formal partnerships with Bloomberg News
column125: or our journalistic NGO training and outreach with the likes of Reporters without Borders
column127: and the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press
column128: we have redoubled our engagement on critical questions of modern journalism. We will continue to work with reporters and media organizations to ensure that Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s real-time capacity for dispelling untruths is built into the approach of newsrooms and established media outlets worldwide.\nNext Steps\nOver the coming weeks and months
column129: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be rolling out several changes to the actions we take when we detect spammy or suspicious activity
column130: including introducing new and escalating enforcements for suspicious logins
column133: and shortening the amount of time suspicious accounts remain visible on Twitter while pending confirmation. These are not meant to be definitive solutions. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been fighting against these issues for years
column134: and as long as there are people trying to manipulate Twitter
column135: we will be working hard to stop them.\nTwitter is where the world goes to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening. We are a platform founded on a commitment to transparency and we take that legacy and responsibility seriously. We will continue to work with official inquiries into these issues
column136:
and to share updates publicly as we are able.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Empowering Freedom of Expression for National Voter Registration Day"
column7:
"post_text": "Events
Empowering Freedom of Expression for National Voter Registration Day
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 27 September 2017\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter stands for freedom of expression and speaking truth to power
column9: two essential principles for civic engagement. What better way to reinforce these principles than registering to vote
column10: so that you can make your voice heard on Election Day?\nThis year
column11: local elections are happening in all 50 states across the U.S. And for the second year in a row
column12: Twitter partnered with National Voter Registration Day (@NatlVoterRegDay) to host a discussion about the importance of staying connected
column13: both online and in the polling booth
column14: in celebration of this national day of action. We convened panelists and audience members from government
column15: corporate
column16:
and nonprofit sectors at our DC office to share insights on the importance of ongoing political engagement-- with the first step always being voter registration.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Through our conversation in person and online between representatives from Rock The Vote
column17: BET
column18: National League of Cities
column19: and National Association of State Election Directors
column20: we heard the experts trade best practices about voter registration efforts. The common challenge-- and opportunity-- is finding voters where they organically spend their time
column21: to get them both to register and turn out at the polls. In 2017
column22:
that means going to social media platforms like Twitter to connect with eligible voters and helping them register to vote.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
There was a lot of conversation around ensuring that youth and college students know how powerful their voices are and how important it is for young people to vote and be engaged with their communities. Local elections have a strong
column23: tangible impact on their communities
column24: and are are the strongest way to let your local officials know what matters to you. City leaders have a duty to keep their constituents informed both with changes to voting and to affirm your right to participate in the electoral process. A key strategy recommendation for staying in the know
column25:
and being a part of the action was to simply stay engaged on Twitter.  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Equal access to pertinent information is a key component in participating in a democracy. Twitter makes it easier for everyone to know about voting and registering by supporting local and national organizations with that mission. These partnerships lead to tools that make registering to vote as simple as sending a tweet. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
And on Tuesday September 26
column26: National Voter Registration Day
column27:
celebrities and influencers across the U.S. mobilized voters on Twitter: 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Even though the 2016 election feels very recent for a lot of people
column28: there are now state and local elections happening in every state
column29: including gubernatorial races in Virginia and New Jersey and mayoral races in major cities like Atlanta
column30: Boston
column31: New York
column32: and Seattle. This discussion illustrates how essential Twitter is to keep users informed about their local leaders
column33: rights as a voter
column34:
and ways to get involved with the electoral process. Civic engagement is whatâs happening now! We hope you will get involved.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
To keep up with the conversation
column35:
check out #BeVocalVoteLocal and #NationalVoterRegistrationDay. And donât forget to register to vote!

column3: "title": "Giving you more characters to express yourself "
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Giving you more characters to express yourself 
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 26 September 2017\nLink copied successfully\nTrying to cram your thoughts into a Tweet \u00e2\u0080\u0093 we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve all been there
column9: and it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a pain.\n\u00c2\u00a0\nInterestingly
column10: this isn't a problem everywhere people Tweet. For example
column11: when I (Aliza) Tweet in English
column12: I quickly run into the 140 character limit and have to edit my Tweet down so it fits. Sometimes
column13: I have to remove a word that conveys an important meaning or emotion
column14: or I don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t send my Tweet at all. But when Iku Tweets in Japanese
column15: he doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t have the same problem. He finishes sharing his thought and still has room to spare. This is because in languages like Japanese
column16: Korean
column17: and Chinese you can convey about double the amount of information in one character as you can in many other languages
column18: like English
column19: Spanish
column20: Portuguese
column21: or French. \n\u00c2\u00a0\nWe want every person around the world to easily express themselves on Twitter
column22: so we're doing something new: we're going to try out a longer limit
column23: 280 characters
column24: in languages impacted by cramming (which is all except Japanese
column25: Chinese
column26: and Korean). \n\u00c2\u00a0\nAlthough this is only available to a small group right now
column27:
we want to be transparent about why we are excited to try this. Here are some of our findings:
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We see that a small percent of Tweets sent in Japanese have 140 characters (only 0.4%). But in English
column28: a much higher percentage of Tweets have 140 characters (9%). Most Japanese Tweets are 15 characters while most English Tweets are 34. Our research shows us that the character limit is a major cause of frustration for people Tweeting in English
column29: but it is not for those Tweeting in Japanese. Also
column30: in all markets
column31: when people don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t have to cram their thoughts into 140 characters and actually have some to spare
column32: we see more people Tweeting \u00e2\u0080\u0093 which is awesome! \n\u00c2\u00a0\nAlthough we feel confident about our data and the positive impact this change will have
column33: we want to try it out with a small group of people before we make a decision to launch to everyone. What matters most is that this works for our community \u00e2\u0080\u0093 we will be collecting data and gathering feedback along the way. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re hoping fewer Tweets run into the character limit
column34:
which should make it easier for everyone to Tweet.
Â 
Twitter is about brevity. It's what makes it such a great way to see what's happening. Tweets get right to the point with the information or thoughts that matter. That is something we will never change. 
 We understand since many of you have been Tweeting for years
column35: there may be an emotional attachment to 140 characters \u00e2\u0080\u0093 we felt it
column36: too. But we tried this
column37: saw the power of what it will do
column38: and fell in love with this new
column39: still brief
column40: constraint. We are excited to share this today
column41:
and we will keep you posted about what we see and what comes next. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Here are 140 (left) and 280 (right) character Tweets in the timeline.  
          
          
        
          
            Showing the same Tweet in different languages.

column3: "title": "Guest blogpost: Inferring Jakarta Commuting Statistics from Twitter Data"
column7: "post_text": "Events\nGuest blogpost: Inferring Jakarta Commuting Statistics from Twitter Data\nFriday
column8:
22 September 2017
Link copied successfully
          
            Photo credit: Seika 
          
          
        
Â 
Every day
column9: people around the world post hundreds of millions of Tweets in dozens of languages. They \u00c2\u00a0can provide real-time information on many issues including the cost of food
column10: availability of jobs
column11: access to health care
column12: quality of education
column13: and reports of natural disasters. There are few places on earth as prolific with Twitter usage than the Indonesian capital
column14: Jakarta. \nAs the United Nations
column15: its member states and its peoples
column16: pursue the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)
column17: we need to make much better use of the treasure troves of insights captured in big data sources to measure progress against these global goals. Drawing on the agreement signed between the United Nations Global Pulse (@UNGlobalPulse) and Twitter in 2016 to support efforts to achieve the SDGs
column18: Pulse Lab Jakarta (@PulseLabJakarta)
column19: a data innovation lab of the United Nations and the Government of Indonesia and part of the UN Global Pulse network
column20: used Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s data stream to test a new method that has the potential to turn social conversations on Twitter into actionable information for city administrations.\n@PulseLabJakarta
column21: partnered with the team from Jakarta Smart City (@JSCLounge) and the Indonesian Institute of Statistics to look at whether aggregated data from social media could help provide information on the movements of commuters within the Greater Jakarta area in order to better inform public officials on daily commuter patterns so as to optimize public transport.\nTransport policy in a megacity\nJabodetabek
column22: as locals fondly refer to the Greater Jakarta area
column23: includes the settlements of Jakarta
column24: Bogor
column25: Depok
column26: Tangerang and Bekasi. Jakarta
column27: itself
column28: is split into five administrative cities: North
column29: South
column30: East
column31: West and Central. Population estimates for the settlements range from 10 million for Jakarta
column32: to over 30 million for the broader metropolitan area.\nThe scale of the population and the state of the transport infrastructure makes the daily commute a common complaint among residents. The city administration is working to improve the commuting experience with significant investments in transport infrastructure
column33: such as the new Jakarta MRT.\nTo inform these infrastructure investments and to understand the rhythm of the city
column34: the Indonesian Bureau of Statistics conducted the first Jakarta commuting survey in 2014. The survey filled an initial data gap
column35: but from design to delivery
column36: it was one year before the results were available.\nFilling the data gaps\nThe challenge of data relevance in urban planning is not unique to Jakarta
column37: and has spurred many attempts to use other types of data to produce similar statistics. The most promising projects use geolocated information such as GPS devices
column38: sensors
column39: social media and mobile phone data.\nIn Indonesia
column40: social media is recognised as a promising data source to understand macro patterns of human behaviour while protecting individual privacy. This is especially true of Jakarta
column41: once dubbed the \u00e2\u0080\u009cTwitter Capital of the World\u00e2\u0080\u009d due to the millions of Tweets generated in the city every day. @PulseLabJakarta used this opportunity to test whether the locational information from social media can reveal commuting patterns in the Greater Jakarta area.\nFirst we produced Origin-Destination statistics for the ten cities in Greater Jakarta from accounts of users who voluntarily included geolocation information in their Tweets and then analyzed the nature of the commutes between such geographic areas.\nSecond
column42: we calibrated the initial result based on the population distribution and Twitter usage distribution.\nFinally
column43: we verified the result with the official commuting statistics produced by the Indonesian Bureau of Statistics.\nOrigin-destination analysis\nWe collected all location-stamped Tweets posted in Greater Jakarta from Twitter data sets and subsetted Tweets posted between 1st January 2014 and 30th May 2014
column44: considering that the official commuting survey was conducted during the first quarter of 2014.\nAnalyzing de-personalized usage patterns
column45: we inferred two locations: origin and destination
column46: both at sub-district level. Origin location was inferred as the most Tweeted sub-district location between 9:00 pm and 7:00 am. Destination location was determined as the most Tweeted sub-district location during weekdays
column47: excluding the origin location.\nUsing this approach
column48: among the 1
column50: 927 unique users who voluntarily posted location-stamped Tweets in Greater Jakarta during the five months from January 2014
column51: we found the origin and destination information for 305
column52: 761 users at the sub-district level (i.e. we were not zooming in any further). This represents about 2.8 per cent of the whole population
column53: and 14 per cent of the commuting population in Greater Jakarta.\nDue to the unequal penetration rates of Twitter
column54: we mapped the origin-destination information at sub-district level to city level
column55: and calibrated the information based on the population data from the ten cities. After calibration
column56: the cross correlation score between the two forms of statistics
column57: official statistics and the statistics from our approach
column58:
improved from 0.92 to 0.97.
The chord diagram shows that Twitter is a promising source of data for inferring commuting statistics in Greater Jakarta.
Â 
Â 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Chord diagram: official commuter flows (left)
column59:
commuting statistics inferred from Twitter (right) 
          
          
        
Results in full
Table C shows the rank difference between official statistics from the Community Survey (Table A) and the information inferred from Twitter (Table B). Â This table suggests that the approach produces broadly reliable predictions. For instance
column60:
the value for SJ â CJ is calculated as â0â because the two statistics are the same. 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            (Left to right) Table A: Official statistics from the Commuting Survey 2014 on the per cent of commuters from the ten cities in Greater Jakarta to the five cities in Jakarta. Table B: Commuting Stats 
          
          
        
Pulse Lab Jakarta is working to improve the method with better calibration using other demographic variables
column61: as well as expanding research by analysing commuting data from Transjakarta
column62: which is the Bus Rapid Transit system in Jakarta.\nThis research was originally presented at NetMob 2017
column63: a conference on the scientific analysis of mobile phone datasets
column64: and more recently at the Asia-Pacific Economic Statistics Week. Our partner in this research
column65: the Institute of Statistics
column66: which is part of Statistics Indonesia
column67:
is planning to use this method to enhance commuting statistics produced by the Government henceforth.
We are pleased to be able to showcase how our partnership with Twitter using #DataforGood is making a positive contribution to the Sustainable Development Goals and we are delighted to be able to work with the Government of Indonesia and partners from the UN to harness new digital data sources for better decision making.
* Pulse Lab Jakarta is a data innovation lab that works to leverage new digital data sources for development and humanitarian action. The Lab is a joint innovation initiative of the United Nations and the Government of Indonesia and is part of the UN Global Pulse network. PLJ works on experimenting with new methodologies and approaches to inform and support achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals. PLJ can be contacted by email: plj@un.or.id or through our website: http://www.unglobalpulse.org
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "New data
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/company/2017/new-data-insights-twitters-latest-transparency-report"
column8: "post_text": "Company\nNew data
column9:
new insights: Twitterâs latest #Transparency Report
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column10: 19 September 2017\nLink copied successfully\nWith our 11th biannual Twitter Transparency Report
column11: Twitter has expanded on work announced in our last #TTR to share more information about government Terms of Service requests we receive and how we handle such requests. In March of 2017
column12: we introduced a new section covering government TOS reports
column13: but it was limited to government requests to remove content under our prohibition of the promotion of terrorism. Today
column14: we have expanded this section to cover a broader array of categories under the Twitter Rules
column15: adding: abusive behavior
column16: copyright
column17: and trademark.\nGovernment TOS reports filed under areas covered by the \u00e2\u0080\u0098Abusive Behavior\u00e2\u0080\u0099 section of the Twitter Rules accounted for 98% of global government TOS reports. We took action in response to 13% of these requests
column18: with the majority of requests resulting in no content removal. This was due to a variety of reasons
column19: such as the reporter failing to identify content on Twitter or our investigation finding that the reported content did not violate our Terms. As we take an objective approach to processing global Terms of Service reports
column20: the fact that the reporters in these cases happened to be government officials had no bearing on whether any action was taken under our Rules.\nRemoving terrorist content\nThe second largest volume
column21: a little more than 2% of global reports
column22: fell within the promotion of terrorism category. Under this category of reports
column23: we are referring to accounts that actively incite or promote violence associated with internationally recognized terrorist organizations
column24: promote internationally recognized terrorist organizations
column25: and accounts attempting to evade prior enforcement.\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s continued commitment to eliminate such activity from our platform has resulted in an 80% reduction in accounts reported by governments compared to the previous reporting period of July 1
column26: 2016 through December 31
column27: 2016. Notably
column28: government requests accounted for less than 1% of account suspensions for the promotion of terrorism during the first half of this year. Instead
column29: 95% of these account suspensions were the result of our internal efforts to combat this content with proprietary tools
column30: up from 74% in our last Transparency Report. Between accounts surfaced by both our internal tools and government reports
column31: Twitter removed 299
column32: 649 accounts during this reporting period
column33: a 20% drop from the previous reporting period. Notably
column34: 75% of these accounts were suspended before posting their first Tweet.\nWe have suspended a total of 935
column35: 897 accounts for the promotion of terrorism in the period of August 1
column36: 2015 through June 30
column37: 2017. For more details
column38: please refer to our latest government TOS reports section.\nIncreasing transparency\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also updated the remainder of our biannual report with data covering January through June
column39: 2017. During this time
column40: Twitter received 6% more global government requests for account information that affected 3% fewer accounts than in the previous period
column41: including requests that originated from four new countries: Nepal
column42: Paraguay
column43: Panama
column44: and Uruguay. In addition
column45: we received approximately 3% more global legal requests to remove content impacting 8% more accounts compared to the previous reporting period. These included requests from nine new countries: Bahrain
column46: Croatia
column47: Finland
column48: Nepal
column49: Paraguay
column50: Poland
column51: Qatar
column52: Ukraine
column53: and Uruguay.\nBroadening and deepening our US transparency reporting\nIn addition
column54: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve continued to expand our US country report. In this latest version
column55: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve included a breakdown of California state information requests at the county level
column56: with plans to introduce this section to other states in future reports. Notably
column57: Los Angeles County came in as the top requesting county
column58: submitting 44% of total California state information requests. Providing this increased level of granularity should further help our users get a better idea of how frequently their local authorities seek user account information.\nUS law and #Transparency\nAs in past reports
column59: Twitter is not reporting national security requests in the bands mandated by the USAFA. Where gag orders on National Security Letters have been lifted
column60: we have included the actual numbers of requests. With regard to other national security requests we may have received
column61: we continue to litigate government restrictions preventing us from sharing more granular information in our case Twitter v. Sessions (f.k.a. Twitter v. Lynch). In February 2017
column62: a hearing was held on the government\u00e2\u0080\u0099s motion for summary judgment
column63: where the US government argued that the case should be decided in its favor because it had met the applicable requirements for showing that Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s 2014 draft Transparency Report was properly classified. On July 6
column65: the court denied the government's motion for a summary judgment finding that the government submission did not satisfy the requirements of the First Amendment. On September 5
column67: the government filed a motion for reconsideration
column68: motivated primarily by the 9th Circuit decision in \u00c2\u00a0EFF\u00e2\u0080\u0099s NSL litigation. Twitter will be filing its opposition to the government motion shortly.\nTwitter will continue to act on our commitment to #transparency
column69:
and we encourage you to read more about all these updates in our latest report.

column3: "title": "#Ferguson - Three Years On"
column7:
"post_text": "Events
#Ferguson - Three Years On
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 30 August 2017\nLink copied successfully\nThis month marks the third anniversary of the Ferguson protests
column9: which began following the fatal shooting of Mike Brown. For nearly three weeks
column10: people from all around the world gathered on Twitter to reflect and report on what was happening in Missouri.\nWe asked people who were in Ferguson at the time about their experiences during the summer of 2014
column11: and how they used Twitter to tell their story.\nWesley Lowery
column12: Washington Post national reporter\nLowery is a Washington Post reporter
column13: who recently published a book on his experiences covering Ferguson. His reporting on police brutality for the Post won him a Pulitzer Prize in 2016.\nBrittany Packnett
column14: Social activist\nPacknett is a St. Louis native. She co-founded Campaign Zero
column15: a comprehensive policy platform to end police violence
column16: and served as a member of President Obama\u00e2\u0080\u0099s 21st Century Policing Taskforce.\nFor many people around the world
column17: your Tweets allowed them to stay informed during the protests in Ferguson. Why was Twitter where you chose to share this story?\nWesley Lowery: Twitter was the medium where this story was playing out \u00e2\u0080\u0093 it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s where the photos and text accounts of the shooting itself had been published
column18: and where live updates each night of the protests were living. Ferguson
column19: more than any other story I\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve covered
column20: felt like it was playing out primarily on Twitter
column21: and so it was only appropriate to utilize it heavily in my reporting.\nBrittany Packnett: Twitter
column22: above all other platforms
column23: allowed us to be quick
column24: informative and truthful. We could report the truth of what was happening on the street and counteract the problematic reporting coming from mainstream media. Twitter saved our lives: without live streaming and support coming from around the world
column25: there were many nights our lives were in jeopardy-and we could have been fatally harmed and have the police report it was our fault.\nWhile you were in Ferguson
column26: in the thick of it
column27: or even from a distance
column28: what was a way you used Twitter that you would not have originally anticipated?\nWL: What a lot of folks not on the ground didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t realize was the pure scope of the demonstrations. There were days where there were more than a thousand people in the street from the afternoon until the early hours of the morning. And the gatherings stretched for blocks
column29: making it hard to explain everything that was happening at all times. The \u00e2\u0080\u009cprotest\u00e2\u0080\u009d could consist of a church group singing hymns in one spot
column30: and then another group calmly discussing politics in another spot
column31: and then an officer arguing with some young men somewhere else
column32: and then at the other end of the street someone throwing rocks. As a reporter
column33: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s impossible to be in all of those places at the same time
column34: but it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s still my responsibility to account for the totality of what is happening on the ground. Twitter allowed me to follow closely the accounts of other folks \u00e2\u0080\u0093 reporters
column35: activists
column36: residents \u00e2\u0080\u0093 who may have a different vantage point that I did
column37: allowing me to gain understanding from what they were documenting in real time.\nBP: I knew to use Twitter and hashtags to get the word out \u00e2\u0080\u0093 I did not anticipate how we\u00e2\u0080\u0099d be able to receive resources and advice from people all across the world. When I learned what to do after we were tear gassed
column38: it was because people from Palestine taught us how. \u00c2\u00a0Sadly
column39: what we endured is a more typical in several corners of the world \u00e2\u0080\u0093 and they knew better how to handle these chemical agents than we did. Cards
column40: letters
column41: funds
column42: food
column43: cold weather gear \u00e2\u0080\u0093 all that and more sustained us
column44: because of the ways in which the Twitter community showed up for us.\nHow is / was Twitter a tool for your advocacy?\nWL: In a story like Ferguson
column45: that \u00e2\u0080\u009cadvocacy\u00e2\u0080\u009d role of the press is one of advocating for more information. What we
column46: as well as so many of the people of Ferguson
column47: wanted during those early days was an explanation: Why was this young man dead? What had happened? Who was the officer? What evidence was available? Those questions typically are asked in emails and press conferences
column48: but what Twitter allowed was for them to be asked publicly \u00e2\u0080\u0093 in open spaces
column49: where those inquires could be magnified and where public pressure could build.\nBP: Protest is telling the truth out loud and in public: we can tell an uninterrupted and unapologetic truth through Twitter. \u00c2\u00a0We can chart our own course
column50: dictate our own terms
column51: and be independent of any other interests
column52: ensuring that our truth is free
column53: just as we fight to be.\nHow do you think that the events of three years ago changed the way people use Twitter
column54: if any?\nBP: People began to realize that \u00e2\u0080\u009chashtag activism\u00e2\u0080\u009d has real power. \u00c2\u00a0It is not an inactive
column55: latent contribution-it is active participation. Everyone who Tweeted #Ferguson or #MikeBrown helped us put pressure on everyone from the White House to presidential candidates to mayors
column56: governors and the media. Without each Tweet
column57: the consistent killing of Black and Brown people by the police would not have been mainstream media
column58: as it is today. \u00c2\u00a0Each follow
column59: each Tweet
column60: each Retweet was a choice-and a declaration that black lives do indeed matter to millions of people. \u00c2\u00a0  \nAfter three years
column61: where do we go from here?\nWL: One of the things birthed of Ferguson was a new effort to quantify police violence. The unrest in Ferguson and elsewhere prompted multiple attempts to begin comprehensively tracking fatal encounters with police
column62: including the fatal police shooting database launched by myself and my colleagues at The Washington Post. We now know much more than we did in 2014 about the frequency of police shootings
column63: who is being killed
column64: and under what circumstances. That said
column65: the number of shootings remains relatively flat. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s very likely that about the same number of people will be killed by police this year as the year Mike Brown was killed. Having the data is one step
column66: but what comes next is implementing action plans to address the root causes of many of these fatal encounters \u00e2\u0080\u0093 police training and resourcing
column67: the availability of firearms
column68: mental health
column69: and implicit bias.\nBP: We keep pressing. \u00c2\u00a0With love and with power: forward
column70:
always.
Â 
Â 
Â 
Â 
Â

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Who Run The World? Girls."
column7:
"post_text": "Events
Who Run The World? Girls.
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 24 August 2017\nLink copied successfully\nWhen we come to work at Twitter
column9: we want to ensure that voices across the organization are heard and identities are represented. For the women working on the engineering side of our company
column10: much of that means working to ensure more women have access to careers in this space
column11: and the tools early on to navigate the industry. Luckily
column12: we work in a place that encourages this mindset
column13: and that is why it is so important to invest time in organizations like Girls Who Code.\nFor the fifth consecutive year
column14: Twitter has partnered with Girls Who Code
column15: an organization committed to closing gender disparities in computer science. Since we began our partnership with Girls Who Code
column16: we have hosted 10 summer programs including San Francisco
column17: Boston
column18: New York
column19: and as of this year
column20: Seattle. This year
column21:
40 high school girls in the San Francisco and Seattle areas had the chance to spend their summer with us and learn more about working in the tech space. 
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
"I had heard of Girls Who Code from my friend
column22: who was a former student
column23: and one day went to their website. Within a couple of seconds I knew I had to get involved. This summer was one of the best experiences I could have been a part of and I have Twitter
column24: the teaching staff and the girls to thank for that. The girls were kind
column25: curious and resilient; traits I think are essential when you're learning something new.\" -Chely Cordova
column26:
GWC SF Teaching Assistant
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The girls spent the first five weeks of the program learning computer science fundamentals â there is no requirement to be familiar with computer science beforehandâand the last two weeks developing their own projects. They learned how to code in a variety of different programming languages
column27: and got an inside look at the industry through speaker events
column28:
Â networking opportunities and industry field trips.  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.

This Tweet is unavailable

"Because of Twitter
column29: I was lucky enough to spend 7 weeks inspiring young women to be brave
column30: take chances
column31: support each other
column32: build things
column33: and yes
column34: learn to code. We were responsible for taking a classroom of 20 high school students from diverse backgrounds who have never programmed before and had 7 weeks to get them to the point where they can make some truly impressive projects and presentations. The girls were lucky to be in a place like Twitter where they could easily get feedback on what they are working on or on what path their lives could take from their mentors and other Twitter role models. \" - Kayla Meduna
column35:
Girls Who Code SIP Instructor at Twitter Seattle

A key part of the program focused on mentorship. Each girl received regular mentoring sessions with full-time female Twitter employees
column36:
to receive career advice and ask any questions they might have.

column40: Girls Who Code seemed like a program for others
column41: something I couldn't do
column42: but now I realize I am a girl who codes

Supporting organizations like Girls Who Code is core to Twitterâs mission. We want to help make sure girls everywhere know they have what it takes to one day excel in this industry. As more and more jobs move toward tech
column45:
we want to help ensure a future where no doors are closed for those looking for opportunities.

column3: "title": "The hashtag at 10 years young"
column7: "post_text": "Product\nThe hashtag at 10 years young\nWednesday
column8: 23 August 2017\nLink copied successfully\nThe hashtag was born on Twitter 10 years ago today
column9: and it has become one of the most recognizable and widely used symbols of our time. Here\u00e2\u0080\u0099s how.\nIn the summer of 2007
column10: a web marketing specialist and avid user of Twitter
column11: Chris Messina walked into our grungy office at 164 South Park (yes
column12: people would just walk in back then) and made a suggestion to me and a few other Twitter employees who were sitting nearby. We were working frantically to fix a tech issue that had brought Twitter down
column13: as was often the case in those early days.\nMany iconic features of Twitter have been created over the years by listening and watching what people who use Twitter do with it and then working to make it easier and better for them\u00e2\u0080\u0094we still do this today. Back in those early days
column14: Jack and I even published our phone numbers on the front page. So
column15: although we were somewhat frenzied
column16: we wanted to give Chris a few minutes and hear him out.\nHis proposal was simple
column17: useful
column18: and fun\u00e2\u0080\u0094just like Twitter. Because brevity is essential on Twitter
column19: he suggested using the \u00e2\u0080\u009cpound\u00e2\u0080\u009d or \u00e2\u0080\u009chash\u00e2\u0080\u009d character common on phones (this was pre-iPhone) to create groups of related Tweets. It was an undeniably elegant proposal
column20: but I really needed to get back to work. I turned back to my computer screen to help get Twitter back up and running
column21: hurriedly ending the conversation with a sarcastic
column22: \u00e2\u0080\u009cSure
column23: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll get right on that.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nThankfully
column24: Chris didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t take offense to my reaction
column25: he simply started doing what he had proposed. On August 23rd
column27: the hashtag came into existence with this Tweet and eventually caught on across the platform. We hyperlinked hashtags on Twitter making them easier and better for all.\nSince it first appeared on Twitter
column28: the hashtag has dramatically evolved \u00e2\u0080\u0094 from grouping Tweets
column29: to adding quirky commentary
column30: to sparking social movements and global conversations. Using hashtags on Twitter
column31: people worldwide have made this platform their microphone
column32: shaped culture
column33: and changed the world.\nCombined with the power and influence of Twitter
column34: the hashtag empowers everyone to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in the world and what people are talking about. It allows people from all over the planet to share their voice and join global conversations. When something happens in the world
column35: it happens on Twitter.\nHappy tenth birthday
column36: hashtag. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re glad we never called you by your technically correct name
column37:
âOctothorp.â
https://twitter.com/Twitter/status/900327630863577089 
Â

column3: "title": "Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism to hold first meeting "
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism to hold first meeting 
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 31 July 2017\nLink copied successfully\nThe Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism is holding its first workshop on August 1
column9: 2017 in San Francisco
column10: where representatives from the tech industry
column11: government
column12: and non-governmental organizations are coming together to share information and best practices about how to counter the threat of terrorist content online.\u00c2\u00a0  Formed last month\u00c2\u00a0by Facebook
column13: Microsoft
column14: Twitter
column15: and YouTube
column16: the Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism formalizes and structures how our companies work together to curtail the spread of terrorism and violent extremism on our hosted consumer services. Building on the work started within the EU Internet Forum and the\u00c2\u00a0shared industry hash database
column17: the GIFCT is fostering collaboration with smaller tech companies
column18: civil society groups and academics
column19: and governments.\nIn addition to the founding companies of the GIFCT
column20: more than two dozen other technology companies and NGOs will be participating in Tuesday's meeting. We also welcome\u00c2\u00a0United Kingdom Home Secretary Rt Hon Amber Rudd MP and United States Acting Secretary of Homeland Security Elaine Duke\u00c2\u00a0\u00e2\u0080\u0094 as well as representatives from Australia
column21: Canada
column22: the European Union
column23: and the United Nations \u00e2\u0080\u0094 to discuss mutual areas of cooperation.\nAt Tuesday's meeting we will be\u00c2\u00a0formalizing our goals for collaboration\u00c2\u00a0and identifying
column24: alongside smaller companies
column25: the specific areas of support needed as part of the GIFCT's core workplan. Our mission is to substantially disrupt terrorists' ability to use the Internet in furthering their causes
column26: while also respecting human rights. This disruption includes addressing the promotion of terrorism
column27: dissemination of propaganda
column28: and the exploitation of real-world events through online platforms. To achieve this
column29: we will join forces around three strategies:\u00c2\u00a0\nEmploying and leveraging technology\nSharing knowledge
column30: information and best practices
column31: and\nConducting and funding research\nIn the next several months
column32:
we also aim to achieve the following:
Secure the participation of five additional companies to the industry hash-sharing database for violent terrorist imagery; two of which have already joined: Snap Inc. and Justpaste.it
Reach 50 companiesÂ to share best practices on how to counter terrorism online through theÂ Tech Against TerrorismÂ project in partnership with ICT4Peace and the UN Counter Terrorism Executive Directorate
Conduct four knowledge-sharing workshops â starting in San Francisco today
column33: with plans for further meetings later this year in other locations around the world\nWe believe that the\u00c2\u00a0best approach to tackling online terrorism is to collaborate\u00c2\u00a0with each other and with external actors
column34:
including civil society and government. We look forward to further cooperation as we develop a joint strategic plan over time.

column3: "title": "Our Safety Work: Results Update"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Our Safety Work: Results Update
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 20 July 2017\nLink copied successfully\nOur commitment to move faster to make Twitter safer started in January. First
column9: we conducted research to understand the issues at a deeper level
column10: then we made a range of product updates. We then convened our Trust and Safety Council to gather feedback and help guide us as we move forward.  While there is still much work to be done
column11: people are experiencing significantly less abuse on Twitter today than they were six months ago. What follows is some new data on the progress we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made
column12: what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve learned
column13: and our plans to continue improving.  Increasing Action on Abusive Accounts  We promised to do more with our technology. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re now taking action on 10x the number of abusive accounts every day compared to the same time last year. We also now limit account functionality or place suspensions on thousands more abusive accounts each day.  There are repeat offenders who create new accounts after being suspended for violations. Our new systems
column14: in the last four months alone
column15: have removed twice the number of these types of accounts. Beyond the technology
column16: our teams are continuing to review content daily and improve how we enforce our policies.  Driving Change in Behavior  Communication about problematic Tweets
column17: especially to the people who send them
column18: is key. Accounts that demonstrate abusive behavior are now limited for a time
column19: and told why. Accounts that we put into this period of limited functionality generate 25% fewer abuse reports
column20: and approximately 65% of these accounts are in this state just once.  Providing Personalized Controls  We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve introduced new ways to customize your experience
column21: including notification filters and muting keywords. Our Quality Filter has led to fewer unwanted interactions: blocks after @mentions from people you don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t follow are down 40%. These numbers will vary
column22: but the approach is having a positive impact.  We have consistent harassment definitions and policies that apply to everyone. However
column23: people define abuse differently
column24: so using these new tools
column25: every person has control of what they see and experience on Twitter.  What Happens Next  More improvement
column26: transparency
column27: and speed. Online safety is an issue best solved in partnership with others
column28: so we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to collaborate with our Trust & Safety Council
column29: industry experts
column30:
and academics to solicit ongoing feedback. We are committed to making Twitter a safe place for free expression.

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column8: 20 July 2017\nLink copied successfully\nAround the world
column9: June represents Pride Month - where people come together to celebrate love and acceptance in all its forms. Millions around the world took part in parades
column10: marches
column11: and festivities but for us
column12: Pride is more than that. While many took part physically
column13: the conversation on Twitter crossed borders
column14: uniting people from all over the world in determination. Through TwitterOpen
column15: our LGBTQIA Employee Resource Group
column16: we \u00c2\u00a0took a moment to measure both the progress occurring everyday and the work that still needs to be done to achieve the kind of world we strive for. As people around the world united on Twitter to celebrate and support LGBTQIA communities
column17: we participated in and hosted events to commemorate this month.\nWe kicked off Pride Month by unveiling the new Emojis. This year the Emoji included pink and blue stripes
column18: to reflect our allyship with Trans people
column19: which appeared every time someone Tweeted out with #PrideIsHappening #Pride2017 \u00c2\u00a0#LoveIsLove Throughout the month
column20:
these hashtags were used over 6 million times.

column24:
and get a glimpse of what opportunities lie ahead.
Â

we hosted a screening of Gigi Gorgeousâ new documentary.

In our New York Office

and Chelsea Shorte (Tagg Nation) joined TwitterOpen in a conversation about Protecting Pride and the ways to ensure that the authenticity of Pride is not lost.

Now the staple of Pride Month

Twitter is where inclusion lives
