column3: "title": "Join the Fight for #NetNeutrality"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Join the Fight for #NetNeutrality
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 11 July 2017\nLink copied successfully\nThe Internet is the most successful medium for innovation and free expression ever invented.  This success has been built upon the Internet\u00e2\u0080\u0099s open architecture
column9: the ability of entrepreneurs to innovate without asking permission
column10: and for such innovators to do so without fear of discrimination. \u00c2\u00a0In general
column11: these principles mean that Internet Service Providers (ISPs) are obligated to treat and transmit all bits equally
column12: regardless of origin
column13: content
column14: or destination. Net Neutrality is foundational to competitive
column15: free enterprise
column16: entrepreneurial market entry \u00e2\u0080\u0093 and reaching global customers. You don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t have to be a big shot to compete. Anyone with a great idea
column17: a unique perspective to share
column18: and a compelling vision can get in the game.  Without the guiding principles of Net Neutrality
column19: it is entirely possible Twitter would not have come from a somewhat quirky experimental 140-character SMS service to where we are today
column20: an international company with thousands of employees and a service that incorporates pictures
column21: video
column22: and live streaming and connects the world to every side of what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening.  Net Neutrality is essential for the more than 3.2 billion people across the globe who use the Internet
column23: which touches nearly all aspects of the global economy. \u00c2\u00a0In the US economy alone
column24: with an estimated 274 million smartphones and tablets and millions of residential and business broadband connections
column25: the Internet fueled approximately 6% of GDP in 2014 according to a recent Internet Association economic paper.  The Open Internet rules put in place by the FCC in 2015 are based upon a solid legal framework that has been sustained by the courts. The FCC Net Neutrality rules effectively safeguard the open Internet as an engine of innovation and investment and as a global platform for free expression.  Notwithstanding the unbridled economic and innovative activity unleashed by the open Internet
column26: the FCC is moving quickly through a rulemaking process to gut the core entrepreneurial and consumer protections that are the heart of the innovation economy.  The FCC should abandon its misguided effort to obviate all the work that has been done on behalf of all Internet users.  Supporting Free Speech and Expression Online  Free expression is part of our company DNA. \u00c2\u00a0We are the platform that lets users see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening and to see all sides. Whether it be music
column27: sports
column28: news or entertainment
column29: being able to see every side of a topic makes Twitter unlike any other platform or service in the world. \u00c2\u00a0  Net Neutrality is one of the most important free expression issues of our time because without Net Neutrality
column30: ISPs would be able to charge content providers more to access the Internet or to reach other users
column31: frustrating the free flow of information. \u00c2\u00a0Moreover
column32: without Net Neutrality in force
column33: ISPs would even be able to block content they don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t like
column34: reject apps and content that compete with their own offerings
column35: and arbitrarily discriminate against particular content providers by prioritizing certain Internet traffic over theirs. This is especially critical for smaller and noncommercial voices
column36: who would be unable to pay a new ISP broadband toll for \u00e2\u0080\u009cfast lane\u00e2\u0080\u009d service. Relegating certain content to the backwaters of the Internet in second or third-tier status reduces the visibility and impact of important voices in the local
column37: national
column38:
or global media mix.

          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
*Editor's note: As of November 2017
column39:
Twitter has increased the character count of Tweets in certain languages to make it easier to share whatâs happening.

column8: 28 June 2017\nLink copied successfully\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re back for the month of June with a brand new set of CEOs
column9: thought leaders
column10: and policy experts who are all creating compelling content & sharing opinions about the financial world on Twitter. In June we saw another great batch of market moving Tweets
column11: covering topics ranging from mergers and acquisitions to unexpected election results. As always
column12: our goal is to surface great insights and some of the best
column13: most compelling content on Twitter. There is no better way to do that than letting our partners showcase the innovative solutions they build using Twitter Data and the corresponding value gained by financial professionals.\nOnce again we will be hearing from Mark Dimont (@mdimont)
column14: Product Manager for Bloomberg Terminal News Applications (@TheTerminal)
column15:
who will walk us through some of the most financially relevant and compelling Tweets that occurred throughout the month.
Weâll turn it over to Mark to share some insights:
____________________________________________________________________
Itâs great to be back on the Twitter blog showcasing some of the ways finance and social media intersect. As I mentioned back in April
column16: at Bloomberg I send a recurring note to my colleagues called \u00e2\u0080\u009cThis Week in Social\u00e2\u0080\u009d that aggregates Tweets from finance that are particularly popular
column17: novel or compelling.\nIn my last post
column18: I focused on \u00e2\u0080\u009cbreaking\u00e2\u0080\u009d Tweets
column19: singular moments that moved markets and stock prices. For this post

took to Twitter to solicit ideas for how he should deploy his capital:

joined Twitter and posted his first Tweet. The Tweet emphasized a policy disagreement with the US and set the tone for future communications:

or is brand new to the platform.

We all remember the 'telephone' game in elementary school. Each link is a loss of true content."

column3: "title": "Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 26 June 2017\nLink copied successfully\nToday
column9: Facebook
column10: Microsoft
column11: Twitter and YouTube are announcing the formation of the Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism
column12: which will help us continue to make our hosted consumer services hostile to terrorists and violent extremists.  The spread of terrorism and violent extremism is a pressing global problem and a critical challenge for us all. We take these issues very seriously
column13: and each of our companies have developed policies and removal practices that enable us to take a hard line against terrorist or violent extremist content on our hosted consumer services. We believe that by working together
column14: sharing the best technological and operational elements of our individual efforts
column15: we can have a greater impact on the threat of terrorist content online.  The new forum builds on initiatives including the EU Internet Forum and the Shared Industry Hash Database; discussions with the UK government; and the conclusions of the recent G7 and European Council meetings. \u00c2\u00a0It will formalise and structure existing and future areas of collaboration between our companies and foster cooperation with smaller tech companies
column16: civil society groups and academics
column17: governments and supra-national bodies such as the EU and the UN.  The scope of our work will evolve over time as we will need to be responsive to the ever-evolving terrorist and extremist tactics. Initially
column18: however
column19: our work will focus on: \u00c2\u00a0\nTechnological solutions: our companies will work together to refine and improve existing joint technical work
column20: such as the Shared Industry Hash Database; exchange best practices as we develop and implement new content detection and classification techniques using machine learning; and define standard transparency reporting methods for terrorist content removals.\nResearch: we will commission research to inform our counter-speech efforts and guide future technical and policy decisions around the removal of terrorist content.\nKnowledge-sharing: we will work with counter-terrorism experts including governments
column21: civil society groups
column22: academics and other companies to engage in shared learning about terrorism. And through a joint partnership with the UN Security Council Counter-Terrorism Executive Directorate (UN CTED) and the ICT4Peace Initiative
column23: we are establishing a broad knowledge-sharing network to:\nEngage with smaller companies: we will help them develop the technology and processes necessary to tackle terrorist and extremist content online.\nDevelop best practices: we already partner with organizations such as the Center for Strategic and International Studies
column24: Anti-Defamation League and Global Network Initiative to identify how best to counter extremism and online hate
column25: while respecting freedom of expression and privacy. We can socialise these best practices
column26: and develop additional shared learnings on topics such as community guideline development
column27: and policy enforcement.\nCounterspeech: each of us already has robust counterspeech initiatives in place (e.g.
column28: YouTube\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Creators for Change
column29: Jigsaw\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Redirect method
column30: Facebook\u00e2\u0080\u0099s P2P and OCCI
column31: Microsoft\u00e2\u0080\u0099s partnership with the Institute for Strategic Dialogue for counter-narratives on Bing
column32: Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s global NGO training programme). The forum we have established allows us to learn from and contribute to one another\u00e2\u0080\u0099s counterspeech efforts
column33:
and discuss how to further empower and train civil society organisations and individuals who may be engaged in similar work and support ongoing efforts such as the Civil society empowerment project (CSEP).
We will be hosting a series of learning workshops in partnership with UN CTED/ICT4Peace in Silicon Valley and around the world to drive these areas of collaboration.
Further information on all of the above initiatives will be shared in due course.
Â 
Â

column3: "title": "Our First Trust & Safety Council Summit"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Our First Trust & Safety Council Summit
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8:
21 June 2017
Link copied successfully
We recently convenedÂ members of our Trust & Safety Council at Twitterâs HQ in San Francisco for our first Trust & Safety Council Summit. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The Trust & Safety Council helps support and inform our commitment to ensuring that people feel safe expressing themselves on Twitter. Itâs made up of safety advocates
column9: academics
column10: researchers
column11: grassroots advocacy organizations and nonprofits focusing on a range of online safety issues - from child protection and media literacy to hate speech and gender-based harassment.  Since the Council was established in February 2016
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve had ongoing conversations on our products
column13: policies and programs with our members. In particular
column14: they provided us with invaluable feedback as we launched new policies and features
column15:
and refocused our efforts on leveraging our technology to improve safety on Twitter.  The Summit was designed to bring our partners together to provide them with further updates on the progress weâve made and to explore how we can continue to work together to foster a safer Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
35 members of the Council from 13 different countries attended across two days. We held breakout sessions dedicated to our policies
column16: product and programs
column17: fireside chats with Council members
column18: and interactive workshops to focus on the complexity of the issues we face as the global conversation evolves on Twitter. The candid
column19: constructive
column20: and open nature of the discussions provided the perfect opportunity for our teams to listen
column21: learn
column22:
and reflect on how we can continue to improve.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The Summit also included a fireside chat between Jack and online safety and counter-speech advocate Megan Phelps-Roper. Megan
column23: who recently joined the Council
column24: shared her story and discussed how the interactions she had on Twitter directly led to her seeing other perspectives
column25: and ultimately informed her decision to leave the Westboro Baptist Church. She also shared her views on the power of empathy and counter-speech online
column26:
and even how she found her husband on Twitter. Meganâs humble articulation of why itâs vital to see every side is deeply compelling and it's a perspective that informs everything we do as a company. You can rewatch the interview here. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We look forward to continuing our work with the Trust & Safety Council as we build safer communities and show every side. A special thank you to each and every one of the Council members for their enthusiasm
column27: candidness
column28:
and invaluable expertise. You are making our teams â and our platform â better for everyone.  Some highlights of the Summit can be found here. Follow the discussions we had and learn more about our partners at #TSCS17.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "#SeeEverySide"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
#SeeEverySide
                By
                
  
  
Monday
column8: 19 June 2017\nLink copied successfully\nLast year
column9: we set out to clearly define who we are and express the uniqueness and power of our brand. We started by speaking with the people who love Twitter and use it every day
column10: and we emerged with something that wasn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t new but rather what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve always been.\nTwitter is what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening and what people are talking about all over the world. We rolled out our new expression digitally
column11: across all our channels and beyond. Those new to Twitter started to understand what Twitter is for
column12: our customers told us we felt more \u00e2\u0080\u009cTwittery
column13: \u00e2\u0080\u009d and our brand partners are excited about their opportunity to be \u00e2\u0080\u009cwhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nOur identity and role in the world today is more relevant than it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s ever been and we wanted to go a step further. We asked our most passionate customers what they love most about Twitter
column14: what makes Twitter special for them.\nWhat they said was powerful: Twitter lets me see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening from every point of view
column15: all perspectives
column16: every side. Whether it be music
column17: sports
column18: news or entertainment
column19: being able to see every side of a topic
column20: makes Twitter unlike any other platform or service in the world.\nOur new campaign aims to capture that very sentiment as we kick off on TV tonight with @chancetherapper. Chance\u00e2\u0080\u0099s authentic use of Twitter is powerful as is his fandom and the conversation that surrounds him. We spotlight the voices of fans
column21: press
column22: influencers and artists - every side of the conversation - at the speed of Twitter.\nhttps://twitter.com/Twitter/status/876758738975195136 \nIn the next few weeks
column23:
we will also be launching films showing every side of sports and news.
https://twitter.com/Twitter/status/876730182744387584
https://twitter.com/Twitter/status/876729877772238848
This week
column24: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also launching our brand story in Japan through a TV campaign that contextualizes \u00e2\u0080\u009cwhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening\u00e2\u0080\u009d and the power of seeing multiple perspectives from the 40 million who use Twitter in Japan.\nhttps://twitter.com/TwitterJP/status/876554586051330048 \nOver the coming weeks and months we'll continue to tell our story and the stories of people all over the world who are on Twitter
column25:
from every side. Thank you for being a part of it.
#SeeEverySide

column3: "title": "Check out our new look!"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Check out our new look!
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 15 June 2017\nLink copied successfully\nLast year
column9: we told you exactly who we are (Twitter is what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening!) and refreshed our brand. Today
column10: with lots of feedback and ideas from you
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re refreshing our product too and making it feel lighter
column12: faster
column13: and easier to use. We listened closely and kept what you love. And for the things you didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t
column14:
we took a new approach to fix and make better.  Our new look:Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
These are some of the changes rolling out across twitter.com
column15: Twitter for iOS
column16: Twitter for Android
column17: TweetDeck
column18: and Twitter Lite over the coming days and weeks. Here\u00e2\u0080\u0099s what you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll see:\nProfile
column19: additional accounts
column20: settings
column21: and privacy \u00e2\u0080\u0093 all in one place! A new side navigation menu and fewer tabs at the bottom of our app = less clutter and easier browsing. You told us you loved this change on Android last year and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to now bring it to iOS.\nLinks to articles and websites now open in Safari\u00e2\u0080\u0099s viewer in the Twitter app so you can easily access accounts on websites you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re already signed into.*\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve refined our typography to make it more consistent
column22: and added bolder headlines to make it easier to focus on what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening. Also
column23: rounded profile photos make it clearer to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s being said and who\u00e2\u0080\u0099s saying it.\nMore intuitive icons make it easier to engage with Tweets \u00e2\u0080\u0093 especially if you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re coming to Twitter for the first time. For example
column24: people thought the reply icon
column25: an arrow
column26: meant delete or go back to a previous page. We switched to a speech bubble
column27: a symbol most know and love. We also made the icons lighter for more seamless interaction.\nTweets now update instantly with reply
column28: Retweet
column29: and like counts so you can see conversations as they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re happening \u00e2\u0080\u0093 live.**\nAlso
column30: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll see additional accessibility choices such as increased color contrast and the option to always open supported links in Safari Reader view.*\nAs always
column31: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to listen to your feedback and we have more design updates coming soon. Together
column32:
weâll continue to make Twitter even better!
*iOS only **Not available on twitter.com and Twitter Lite

column3: "title": "Our approach to bots and misinformation "
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Our approach to bots and misinformation 
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 14 June 2017\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s job is to keep people informed about what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in the world. As such
column9: we care deeply about the issue of misinformation and its potentially harmful effect on the civic and political discourse that is core to our mission.  Fake news has become a catchphrase used to describe everything from manufactured news stories
column10: incorrect information and state-supported propaganda
column11: to news some people don't like or points of view with which people disagree.  Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s open and real-time nature is a powerful antidote to the spreading of all types of false information. This is important because we cannot distinguish whether every single Tweet from every person is truthful or not. We
column12: as a company
column13: should not be the arbiter of truth. Journalists
column14: experts and engaged citizens Tweet side-by-side correcting and challenging public discourse in seconds. These vital interactions happen on Twitter every day
column15: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re working to ensure we are surfacing the highest quality and most relevant content and context first.  Bots  While bots can be a positive and vital tool
column16: from customer support to public safety
column17: we strictly prohibit the use of bots and other networks of manipulation to undermine the core functionality of our service. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been doubling down on our efforts here
column18: expanding our team and resources
column19: and building new tools and processes. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to iterate
column20: learn
column21: and make improvements on a rolling basis to ensure our tech is effective in the face of new challenges.  We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re working hard to detect spammy behaviors at source
column22: such as the mass distribution of Tweets or attempts to manipulate trending topics. We also reduce the visibility of potentially spammy Tweets or accounts while we investigate whether a policy violation has occurred. When we do detect duplicative
column23: or suspicious activity
column24: we suspend accounts. We also frequently take action against applications that abuse the public API to automate activity on Twitter
column25: stopping potentially manipulative bots at the source.  It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s worth noting that in order to respond to this challenge efficiently and to ensure people cannot circumvent these safeguards
column26: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re unable to share the details of these internal signals in our public API. While this means research conducted by third parties about the impact of bots on Twitter is often inaccurate and methodologically flawed
column27:
we must protect the future effectiveness of our work.  Weâre committed to doing our part and weâll continue to share updates along the way.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet

column3: "title": "Businesses can now add buttons to drive actions in Direct Messages"
column7: "post_text": "Product\nBusinesses can now add buttons to drive actions in Direct Messages\nTuesday
column8: 13 June 2017\nLink copied successfully\nToday we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re giving businesses one more tool they need to create great customer experiences in Direct Messages. Now
column9: businesses can attach buttons to messages to make it easy for people to take actions outside of the Direct Message conversation \u00e2\u0080\u0093 like composing a Tweet
column10: following an account
column11:
or opening a website within the Twitter app.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
For many businesses
column12: delivering a great customer experience through a bot in Direct Messages depends on helping people complete a task other than sending a message. These tasks can include:\nTweeting about your bot: At the right point in the conversation
column13: people might want to Tweet to share a coupon or offer
column14: challenge their followers to a game
column15: or tell the world about new content they just discovered -- like a new product or an exclusive movie clip. The unique combination of public and private messaging on Twitter makes it easy for people to become brand advocates by Tweeting about an experience. And by combining this feature with the new Direct Message Card
column16: those Tweets can then help other users discover and start talking to your bot.\nVisiting a website: After discovering content or making a choice in a Direct Message
column17: people might need to visit a website (e.g.
column18: a payment page to complete a transaction). Buttons that point to web links open a native browser within the Twitter app
column19: so that once a person completes an action
column20: they can come right back into the Direct Message to continue the conversation.\nFollowing accounts: With the ability to turn on the setting for \u00e2\u0080\u0098Receive Direct Messages from anyone\u00e2\u0080\u0099 not everyone who engages with your bot necessarily follows your account. Buttons let you direct people to your profile page to follow your account
column21: and encourage people who engage with your bot to then follow your Tweets.\nStarting a conversation with a different account you own: Some businesses use multiple accounts on Twitter for different purposes
column22: and at times it makes sense to ask a user to send a Direct Message to another account. For instance
column23: a brand might run a marketing-related bot in Direct Messages in one account but provide customer service through another account. Now a button can be used to seamlessly guide users into a new conversation.\nUp to three buttons can be attached to any message and they can be used to open any web URL
column24: including links to other features in the Twitter app. Businesses can fully customize the call-to-action text on a button
column25: including the use of emojis.\nBusinesses are already getting creative with how these buttons are used. For example
column26: Focus Features has a bot that showcases trailers for their upcoming movies
column27: lets people buy movie tickets
column28: enables people to join their rewards program
column29: and even connects people to a human to answer questions. For their new movie The Beguiled
column30: the bot has additional features where people can play a trivia game to get more excited about the release. After completing a quiz
column31:
people are encouraged to share their score and invite their followers to engage with the bot as well.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitter provides a unique and powerful platform for us to directly engage with our core audience and we're excited about the ability to turn that audience into an organic source of discovery for our bot. Weâre proud to partner with Massively in the development and launch of our Focus Features Bot.
Joshua Kornblit
SVP Digital Marketing
column32: Focus Features\nSTXfilms has created a unique bot for the upcoming sci-fi action adventure
column33: Luc Besson\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets. The bot enables people to engage in a conversation with characters from the movie
column34: and even go through training to join Valerian and Laureline in the fight to save Alpha. Once people get far enough into the storyline
column35: they get a message with a button attached that lets them know they can unlock exclusive content if they share the bot with their followers through a Tweet. This Tweet is unavailable This Tweet is unavailable. Your browser does not support the video element. Play Play Pause Seek 0% buffered 00:00 Current time 00:00 Duration 00:00 Toggle Mute Volume Movies are discovered on Twitter in real time. People watch the trailer
column36: Tweet their thoughts
column37: read the reactions of others
column38: and engage with the movie
column39: cast and crew directly. We're excited to extend the Valerian experience on Twitter with a rich and engaging Direct Message bot. The new ability to get people to share the experience with their followers allows for more engagement
column40: excitement
column41: and conversation about Valerian.\nRamzy Zeidan\nVP
column42: Digital Marketing
column43: STXfilms\nButtons on messages will begin rolling out today and will soon be visible across our iOS
column44: Android and desktop web clients. Alongside Direct Message Cards
column45: welcome messages
column46: quick replies
column47: custom profiles
column48: location sharing and Customer Feedback Cards
column49: this feature adds to the canvas available for businesses to create innovative customer experiences in Twitter Direct Messages. Like these other features
column50: it is only supported via our developer API. To get started using buttons on messages
column51:
check out details on our developer blog or speak with your bot or customer service solution provider. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

#OnlyOnTwitter

column3: "title": "Consumer Insights for Finance with Twitter Data"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Consumer Insights for Finance with Twitter Data
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 7 June 2017\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter is all about what is happening in the world. Since it's founding over 11 years ago
column9: the platform has always been a candid snapshot of what the entire world is thinking about on any topic
column10: at any point in time. With users across the globe sending out billions of Tweets every week
column11: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s easy to imagine how that information can be aggregated and analyzed to better understand consumer preferences
column12: and how those opinions expressed through Tweets can offer insights related to future company performance. In our last blog post
column13: we highlighted how Bloomberg identifies Tweets from across the globe to help their users stay ahead of major market-moving events.\nIn this post
column14: we wanted to invite LikeFolio (@LikeFolio) to share some of the innovative work they are doing to help uncover deep insights related to consumer behaviors on Twitter. \u00c2\u00a0 \u00c2\u00a0\nBy creating a highly structured product and brand map
column15: LikeFolio is able to aggregate consumer conversations on Twitter related to specific companies and their products. As companies release new goods and services
column16: Twitter users share their thoughts
column17: opinions and reactions in real time. That data is then compiled and analyzed to predict how successful those offerings will be
column18: and how those predictions confirm or contradict Wall Street expectations. Looking at the results over time
column19: LikeFolio has been able to help investors detect shifts in consumer behavior well before the market has factored them into the stock price.\nI\u00e2\u0080\u0099d like to let Andy Swan (@AndySwan)
column20: co-founder of LikeFolio
column21:
tell you about some of the interesting insights theyâve observed over the past few months:
__________________________________________________________________ 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitter has always been a place where interesting and diverse conversations happen. While some users discuss news stories or current events
column22: other users talk about their daily personal lives. Those conversations can range from excitement about upcoming product launches
column23: to experiences while riding on an airplane. LikeFolio looks to sift through that information
column24: to understand how customers are engaging with brands
column25: and how that can change over time. Let me show you what I mean. \nWhere\u00e2\u0080\u0099s the (social media) beef?\nThe restaurant chain Wendy\u00e2\u0080\u0099s has rewritten the book on social media in 2017
column26: going on the offensive when it comes to their food offerings relative to the competition
column27:
includingâ¦  Those that question their commitment to qualityâ¦
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As well as their competitorsâ¦. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Their customers are liking it
column28: engaging with the company at impressive rates
column29: and even racking up world-record numbers of Retweets in exchange for delicious chicken nuggets.  But has this massive social buzz moved the needle for Wendy\u00e2\u0080\u0099s in terms of how consumers see the brand?  For this
column30: we reference LikeFolio\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Consumer Happiness Score for the company. \u00c2\u00a0This score is determined by looking at the Tweets mentioning Wendy\u00e2\u0080\u0099s and its proprietary brands/products and determining if the person authoring the Tweet was speaking positively or negatively about the company. \u00c2\u00a0  This sentiment data is expressed as a percent positive score from 0-100 as calculated using the following equation: \u00c2\u00a0(# of positive Tweets)/(# positive Tweets + # of negative Tweets). \u00c2\u00a0Note that neutral Tweets are not considered in this metric.  The higher the score
column31:
the more positive Tweeters are about the brand/product/cashtag. Â   Hereâs what Wendyâs consumer happiness level has looked like over the past six months:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As you can see from the graph above
column32: Wendy\u00e2\u0080\u0099s saw a huge increase in overall mentions near the beginning of the year (green and red bars). \u00c2\u00a0But even as mention volume spiked
column33: the percentage of those Tweets that were positive in nature (purple line) also grew. \u00c2\u00a0This 1-2 punch of increased mention volume and higher Consumer Happiness Score is usually a very positive sign for a company\u00e2\u0080\u0099s future growth.  This mention boom has clearly been good for their social metrics\u00e2\u0080\u00a6 but has it translated into an increase in customers ringing the cash register?  To answer
column34: we looked into purchase intent mentions\u00c2\u00a0about Wendy\u00e2\u0080\u0099s on Twitter
column35: and compared it to McDonald\u00e2\u0080\u0099s as a baseline.\u00c2\u00a0 Instead of just looking at the volume of conversation
column36:
we focused exclusively on Tweets that strongly indicate a user is actually buying food from the restaurantÂ at that moment.  The results were fascinatingâ¦.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As you can see
column37: the Wendy\u00e2\u0080\u0099s approach to Twitter started paying dividends at the start of the year.  The spike in January is impressive
column38: but what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s really impressive is how the purchase intent metrics for Wendy\u00e2\u0080\u0099s actually stabilized at a higher baseline than they ever reached in 2016
column39: closing the gap with their biggest rival McDonald\u00e2\u0080\u0099s.  It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s safe to say Wendy\u00e2\u0080\u0099s has a new approach to marketing
column40:
and their fans are really liking it.
___________________________________________________________________ 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
As you can see

Information that was previously immeasurable using publicly available insights and technology is now being analyzed and disseminated throughout the financial services industry in realtime. Thanks to the power of Twitter Data

as we are excited to showcase additional innovative solutions brought to you by Twitterâs financial data community over the coming months.

column3: "title": "Does Baseball\u2019s No-Hitter Jinx Exist?"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Does Baseballâs No-Hitter Jinx Exist?
                By
                
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 7 June 2017\nLink copied successfully\nLast weekend\u00e2\u0080\u0099s no-hitter by Edinson Volquez brought up a frequent debate amongst baseball fans: is the no-hitter jinx real? This \u00e2\u0080\u009cunwritten rule\u00e2\u0080\u009d is that if you mention that a pitcher\u00e2\u0080\u0099s hurling a no-hitter
column9: it won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t come to fruition. This is often practiced by teammates in the dugout
column10: fans in the stadium
column11: broadcasters covering the game from the stadium
column12:
and of course by fans on Twitter. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We decided to get to the bottom of this longtime legend. If you see a no-hitter in progress this year
column13: are you free to talk (or Tweet!) about it
column14: or are you going to be the jinx? Let\u00e2\u0080\u0099s take a look at the data to find out.\nThere\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not quite a feasible way to measure how much conversation there is out in the world about a (potential) no-hitter
column15: but Twitter data serves as a great proxy in this case. And since - to some! - the folklore allows for creative turns of phrase (\u00e2\u0080\u009cno runners have reached base other than a walk\u00e2\u0080\u009d)
column16: just not the words \u00e2\u0080\u009cno hitter\u00e2\u0080\u009d
column17: there\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a simple way to query the conversation by looking for the number of Tweets that use that particular phrasing (along with a few hashtagged versions & alternate spellings). We want to explore the relationship between the number of Tweets mentioning a no-hitter in progress
column18: and whether the no-hitter was successfully completed.\nTo dig into the jinx theory
column19: we focused on the 2015 season
column20: which had 34 no-hit bids (defined for this research as no hits through six complete innings) and seven completed no-hitters
column21:
giving us more games to base the analysis on than last yearâs season with just one no-hitter or the one so far this season. (Thank you to Baseball Reference @Baseball_Ref for compiling game data.)
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Looking at volume level from the entire game time will include Tweets that either celebrate a successful no-hitter or react to it getting broken up. To remove those surges and to standardize the time period for each game
column22: we opted to focus on the amount of Tweets in approximately the first seven innings of the game. We measured the number of no-hitter Tweets from start-of-game through 40 minutes before final pitch for a broken-up no-hitter (in 2015
column23: the average MLB game was around 3 hours
column24: which means that each inning lasts approx. 20 minutes) and 32 minutes for a completed no-hitter (average no-hitter game time was 2:31).\nHere\u00e2\u0080\u0099s what the pace of conversation looks like for a no-hitter compared to one that got broken up
column25:
focusing on two of @Max_Scherzerâs outings (he also had an additional no-hitter *and* an additional no-hit bid that season):
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Now itâs time to zero in on the potential jinx. First
column26: we checked how many Tweets mention \u00e2\u0080\u009cno hitter\u00e2\u0080\u009d on an average in-season day in 2015 (excluding days that saw a no-hitter or bid): around 700. Games that had a no-hitter into the 7th
column27: but did not end as a no-hitter
column28: saw around 2
column29: 500 Tweets in the -30min window. And no-hitters? Those had over 5
column30:
000 Tweets in the -32min window. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
So what does that tell us? There are more than twice as many Tweets saying the specific phrase âno-hitterâ in (approximately) the first 6 innings for games that are indeed successful no-hitters than there are in games that fail to see it through. In other words: based on Twitter data
column31: talking about a no-hitter does not jinx it. (But we won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t go so far as to suggest a new superstition that you have to Tweet about a no-hitter in order to make it happen\u00e2\u0080\u00a6)\nNext time you see a no-hitter in progress (I\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be crossing my fingers that it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s coming from my @SFGiants)
column32: feel free to Tweet about it! In fact
column33:
you may just jinx it if you donât.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@TwitterData
@TwitterSports
#mlb
#nohitter

column3: "title": "Twitter NeighborNest Turns Two"
column7: "post_text": "Events\nTwitter NeighborNest Turns Two\nThursday
column8: 1 June 2017\nLink copied successfully\nMay 2017 marked the second birthday of the NeighborNest
column9: Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s family-friendly community learning center dedicated to creating new opportunities through technology for residents of the Tenderloin
column10: mid-Market and SOMA neighborhoods of San Francisco. The NeighborNest was created with the intention of people coming together based on a shared love of learning and technology. Two years on
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re encouraged by how our mission has come to life and excited for the journey ahead.\nWe listened closely to the community\u00e2\u0080\u0099s needs to ensure we could best fulfill this purpose
column12: leveraging Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s expertise in technology and our partners\u00e2\u0080\u0099 expertise in social services. Since its doors opened in 2015
column13: we have hosted more than 7
column14: 000 visits and provided more than 2
column15: 000 hours of programming
column16: \u00c2\u00a0including coding classes
column17: social media training for nonprofits
column18: a citizenship and media literacy curriculum.\nWe marked this milestone by celebrating our #NestFest on Twitter
column19: taking advantage of what the platform does best -- bringing everyone near and far together for a shared purpose. We also had an intimate celebration with families from the community and volunteers over a movie
column20: pizza
column21:
and cake.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Learn
An important aspect of our approach is meeting people where they are
column22: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve done this in various ways: working with adults intimidated by attending classes
column23: welcoming volunteers who want to share their love for coding but aren\u00e2\u0080\u0099t used to being around kids
column24: and training nonprofits who want to share their work
column25: but have limited knowledge of Twitter. \u00c2\u00a0\u00c2\u00a0\nThrough the digital literacy programs we offer at the NeighborNest
column26: we are helping adult learners with little or no prior exposure to computers achieve IT proficiency
column27: which can in turn improve their employment prospects. Our Twitter volunteers have led a Coding for Kids and Digital Citizenship program
column28: which reinforces the importance of early education for youth and families. Additionally
column29: the NeighborNest hosts Twitter for Nonprofits
column30: helping partners leverage Twitter to advance their mission.\nThe NeighborNest serves as a window for Twitter volunteers to see and experience the community\u00e2\u0080\u0099s history
column31: and the resilience of its residents in the face of everyday adversity. More importantly
column32: perhaps
column33: it has shown us what a big a difference little things can make: a welcoming space
column34: healthy snacks
column35: time invested
column36: and hands-on assistance.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cI enjoy coming to the Nest because there are always computers open...I can make myself a cup of coffee or grab a water bottle. If my daughter is with me and I need to focus on something
column37: the staff is able to watch after her. I can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t find that kind of support anywhere else.\u00e2\u0080\u009d - Andrea
column38: client\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cWorking at the NeighborNest has reinforced just how big of an impact we can make by donating our time
column39: and you don't need a background in computers to help someone uplevel their technology skills.\u00e2\u0080\u009d - Greg
column40:
volunteer
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Connect
The NeighborNest has emerged as a collaborative
column41: diverse
column42: and commonly frequented space for Twitter employees and members of the community. Visitors and volunteers come to the NeighborNest for skills-based training
column43: family-oriented programs
column44: and various activities
column45: but often end up creating connections and fostering a support system amongst clients and volunteers.\nWhile families from different programs get to know each other
column46: share community resources
column47: and forge new friendships
column48: nonprofit staff members meet new people
column49: learn about each other\u00e2\u0080\u0099s work
column50: and exchange best practices. Volunteers tell us that the NeighborNest has enabled them to feel more connected to both their community and their colleagues.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cPersonally
column51: I get a lot of joy helping out the nonprofits and also make great connections!\u00e2\u0080\u009d - Betty
column52:
volunteer
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Grow
The growth experienced at the NeighborNest has surpassed simply learning new information and skills. As a result of our workshops
column53: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen a notable increase in people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s confidence
column54: their eagerness to take on new tasks
column55: and they approach job interviews with their head held a little higher.\nAfter regular visits to the NeighborNest
column56: children who used to cling to their parents now immediately run into the play area and have developed critical social skills that have helped them become more pre-school ready. These kids have become more independent as a result of time spent at the childcare area while their parents attend class in the next room.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cThe time at the Nest has been well spent. Our self-esteem has been elevated through excellent programs on housing
column57: computer classes and one on one personal help. I believe our daughter
column58: when she grows up
column59: will always have fond memories of this beautiful place called NeighborNest.\u00e2\u0080\u009d - Dave
column60: client\nTwitter employees have also expressed personal and professional growth as a result of volunteering. Exposure to a thriving community and the chance to interact with the people and organizations that make this part of San Francisco so unique - this is a vital part of our company philosophy. Twitter for Nonprofits workshop volunteers have come to understand our services better
column61: how organizations are using them
column62:
and ways to equip nonprofits in leveraging product features to better amplify their mission-driven work.
âIt helps me take a step back and see the larger picture. This subsequently motivates me to work harder at Twitter. It also makes me very grateful that Twitter cares about the community and the neighborhood.â - Twitter volunteer
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Everyday
column63: the NeighborNest harnesses the power of people coming together \u00e2\u0080\u0093 the idea that actions are more impactful with the support of others
column64: and goals less daunting. This approach has helped shape our purpose and our path has unfolded organically. We continue to listen to our community and employees and do our best to meet their needs. We lean on respective experts to evaluate our efforts and we adjust as needed. Through this process
column65: we not only build digital literacy skills
column66: but also awareness
column67: empathy
column68: and profound connections.\nHappy birthday
column69:
NeighborNest! 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Here's what's happening for #Ramadan on Twitter"
column7: "post_text": "Events\nHere's what's happening for #Ramadan on Twitter\nFriday
column8: 26 May 2017\nLink copied successfully\nOn Twitter
column9: live conversations during the holy month of #Ramadan come to life for Muslims across the world. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s the time of year when people connect with one another regardless of location or language
column10: over mutually shared values and interests; from information on fasting
column11:
to learning how to lend a hand to those in need. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
This year
column12:
weâre rolling out various initiatives to help create a more fulfilling Ramadan experience for everyone on Twitter. 
Several Ramadan themed emojis are available on Twitter throughout the holy month to make the #Ramadan conversations more fun. Include any of the following hashtags in your Tweets and youâll see a crescent moon appear next to these terms. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The second emoji embodies the spirit of iftar as it illustrates a date along with a glass bottle of yoghurt
column13:
which are commonly used to break fast. Include any of the following hashtags in your Tweets and youâll see the emoji appear next to these terms. The last emoji is a visual of a lantern that embodies the cultural spirit of the holy month.  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
On Periscope
column14: we have also released custom Periscope hearts for the month of Ramadan to make the #Ramadan live video broadcasts more enjoyable. Simply include any of the following hashtags to the title of your broadcast
column15: and when your viewers tap the screen
column16:
the hearts will transform into crescent moons.  
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In the Middle East
column17: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re launching the first Ramadan TV guide bot on Twitter. Ramadan TV viewers can send a Direct Message to the Arabic entertainment news portal @FilFan that will automatically display a variety of categories to choose from; \u00e2\u0080\u0098Channels\u00e2\u0080\u0099
column19: \u00e2\u0080\u0098TV shows\u00e2\u0080\u0099 and \u00e2\u0080\u0098Now showing\u00e2\u0080\u0099. Once selected
column20: viewers will automatically receive a message that will include a list of series
column21: TV channels
column22:
timings as well as a daily recap of their favorite series based on their selection. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In addition
column23: exclusive Ramadan Q&As will take place with celebrities and experts across the region giving fans an opportunity to engage in a live video conversation around popular topics. From entertainment and culture to religion and health
column24: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s all happening on Twitter.\nThe first ever Ramadan-themed live 360 videos will take place on Twitter by multiple broadcasters; showcasing the spirit of Ramadan through an immersive experience; from tents to souqs and charitable activities. You can easily move your device or scroll your finger across the video Tweets to explore every angle shared of the locations.\nAs for TV
column25: look out for a Ramadan mini-series
column26: live episodes and behind the scenes content that will be shared on Twitter.\nIn Indonesia
column27: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re partnering with several partners to enliven the Ramadan experience and making it easier for Indonesians to find Ramadan-related information on Twitter. \n1.\u00c2\u00a0@MasakTV will provide daily video recipes during Ramadan. By Tweeting #masakapa (what to eat) to @MasakTV
column28: you will receive Ramadan related recipe videos. By Tweeting #jajandimana (eat out) along with the name of a cuisine or dish to @MasakTV
column29: you will receive an auto-reply with recommendation of the nearest restaurants serving that. \n2.\u00c2\u00a0We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re partnering with leading radio stations in the country
column30: @Jak101fm and @gen987fm
column31: to host regular Periscope and Q&A sessions - all to be broadcasted via their Twitter accounts. \u00c2\u00a0The radio stations will also have regular challenge sessions where their listeners needs to answer by sending photos and video via Twitter. \n3.\u00c2\u00a0@netmediatama TV will be integrating Twitter within its Sohoor programming for one of the most popular variety shows Ini Sahur (@Ini_Talkshow) to allow live audience to engage with the celebrity guests and hosts in real-time. People can also send a Direct Message to @netmediatama to get daily prayer time
column32: iftar time
column33: and video of short sermon in their DMs. \n4.\u00c2\u00a0@TravellerKaskus
column34: part of @Kaskus - one of Indonesia\u00e2\u0080\u0099s largest online communities
column35: will be broadcasting regular content on Periscope and video on Twitter while waiting for Iftar. The topics will vary each week and will be related to Ramadan: from tips on what to do during iftar
column36: unique iftar food from different cities in Indonesia
column37:
to preparation of mudik or homecoming season. 
We wish Muslims all around the world another blessed #Ramadan in 2017.

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Drive discovery of bots and other customer experiences in Direct Message"
column7:
"post_text": "medTint
Drive discovery of bots and other customer experiences in Direct Message
                By
                
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 23 May 2017\nLink copied successfully\nToday
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re launching a new
column10: customizable Direct Message Card that businesses can use to promote and share bots and other customer experiences built in Direct Messages. Increasingly
column11: businesses are using Direct Messages to create rich
column12: personalized interactions that deepen relationships with consumers
column13: ranging from customer acquisition to fun
column14: engaging bots such as the first ever March Madness bracket builder in Direct Messages (#WendysBracket). This new card will help businesses drive discovery of such experiences both through Promoted Tweets and organic sharing.\nUsing a Direct Message Card
column15: businesses can capture people's attention with engaging image or video creatives
column16: and include up to four fully customizable call-to-action buttons. Each call-to-action button takes the user into a specific experience within Direct Messages. With Direct Message Cards running in Promoted Tweet campaigns
column17: businesses can take advantage of Twitter Ads' full targeting suite to find a relevant audience to pull into personalized conversations at scale. Businesses can also turn their audience into advocates by encouraging them to share the experience in their own voice through a Tweet.\nSeveral brands around the world are launching Promoted Tweet campaigns using the Direct Message Card this week to drive discovery of the experiences they have built. Patr\u00c3\u00b3n Tequila
column18: a leading spirits brands
column19: is using the Direct Message Card to entice people to engage with their messaging bot \u00e2\u0080\u0094 Bot-Tender \u00e2\u0080\u0094 which creates personalized cocktail recommendations based on responses to questions around occasion
column20: flavor
column21:
and even emoji. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The PatrÃ³n consumerâs online interactions have become part of the product experience itself. Before spirits drinkers ever open a bottle or order at a bar
column22: they research recipes and educate themselves on the process behind the product. Twitter is the perfect platform to create unique
column23: simple
column24: yet compelling moments that connect with audiences during this journey
column25: in real-time. Through the new Direct Message Cards we can further drive compelling engagement with our consumers.\nAdrian Parker\nVice President
column26: Marketing at Patr\u00c3\u00b3n Spirits Company\nJollyChic
column27: an ecommerce shopping app
column28: will offer target customers in select markets a special discount coupon for purchases through a #JollyRamadan Direct Message Card. Customers will be able to shop the sale of the day
column29: browse retail options
column30: contact customer service for support
column31: and even download the JollyChic app via Direct Messages.\nThe Direct Message Card is a robust discovery tool that complements other features we have built to make Direct Messages a powerful canvas for brands to build personalized and scalable conversational experiences
column32: including Welcome Messages
column33: Quick Replies
column34: Custom Profiles
column35:
Location Sharing and more. Weâre excited to provide brands with additional tools to create new ways of engaging and building deeper relationships with their audiences on Twitter.
The Direct Message Card is currently available in limited beta to Twitter advertisers. Interested in using it? Contact your Twitter representative today for more information.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@TwitterMktg
Tweet

column3: "title": "Building new data controls and updating our privacy policy"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Building new data controls and updating our privacy policy
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 17 May 2017\nLink copied successfully\nAs we work to make our content more relevant to people on Twitter
column9: we also want to offer the best and most transparent privacy and data controls.\nToday
column10: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re announcing a suite of industry-leading tools to give you more access to your information and greater
column11:
more granular control over how itâs used. Weâve also updated ourÂ Privacy PolicyÂ to reflect the improvements that weâve made to Twitter.
Here are the most important updates rolling out in the coming days:
Tools
Increased transparency:Â Weâre expanding Your Twitter DataÂ to give you the most transparent access to your Twitter information to date
column12: including demographic and interest data
column13: and advertisers that have included you in their\u00c2\u00a0tailored audiences\u00c2\u00a0on Twitter. Each category of data will be clearly marked
column14:
and you will be able to view or modify this data directly.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
New controls:Â Weâre launching newÂ Personalization and DataÂ settings that offer even more granular control over how we use your data
column15:
including how we personalize your Twitter experience and whether information may be shared through certain partnerships. You can use these controls to better personalize your experience on Twitter and opt out of various types of data usage and sharing with a single switch.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Personalization across your devices:Â When you log in
column16: we will associate your device with your account for purposes such as authentication and personalization. We may also personalize your experience based on information from other devices besides the ones you use to log into Twitter - you can turn this off in your\u00c2\u00a0Personalization and Data\u00c2\u00a0settings. For example
column17: if you visit websites with sports content on your laptop
column18: you can use this setting to help control whether we show you sports-related ads on Twitter for Android or iOS.\nPolicy\nWeb data:\u00c2\u00a0We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve expanded how we use and store data from other websites that integrate Twitter content
column19: like embedded Tweets. This will allow us to further improve and personalize our services
column20: connecting you with the stories
column21: brands and organic content you care about most. We do not store web page visit data for users who are in the European Union and EFTA States. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also excited to announce that we will be participating in the\u00c2\u00a0Swiss-US Privacy Shield\u00c2\u00a0and adhering to the Digital Advertising Alliance\u00e2\u0080\u0099s\u00c2\u00a0Self-Regulatory Principles for Online Behavioral Advertising.\nData sharing:\u00c2\u00a0We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve updated how how we share non-personal
column22: aggregated
column23: and device-level data
column24: including through some select\u00c2\u00a0partnership agreements\u00c2\u00a0that allow the data to be linked to your name
column25: email
column26: or other personal information \u00e2\u0080\u0093 but only when you give your consent to those partners.\nPrivacy is built into our DNA as a company and it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s something we take an active role in promoting and advocating for across the world. We partner with\u00c2\u00a0civil society
column27:
weÂ stand up to governments and we continue to evolve our efforts aroundÂ transparency. This commitment will continue as we build our industry leadership on this issue.
Weâre continuing to make updates and grow our business in a way that can improve your Twitter experience and which dovetails with our heartbeat as company - a commitment to protecting and defending your privacy.
For more information visit ourÂ Help Center.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet

column3: "title": "#TwitterForGood Day"
column7:
"post_text": "Events
#TwitterForGood Day
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 12 May 2017\nLink copied successfully\nLast Friday
column9: Twitter employees around the world participated in our biannual #TwitterForGood Day \u00e2\u0080\u0093 an opportunity to partner with nonprofits and neighbors
column10: to strengthen our relationships
column11: and work together to improve our communities. We partner with organizations that do incredible work and address a wide range of needs. Our teams participated in projects that ranged from preparing meals to cleaning up parks and community centers
column12: solidifying our commitment to the communities we serve around the world.  This day is a reminder that we are all connected. As activist Lilla Watson says
column13: \u00e2\u0080\u009cIf you have come here to help me
column14: you are wasting your time. But if you have come because your liberation is bound up with mine
column15: then let us work together.\u00e2\u0080\u009d  Through #TwitterForGood
column16: and the work we do every day
column17: Twitter employees across the globe not only serve our communities but also laugh
column18: learn
column19:
and deepen our connections with organizations making lives better in the places we live and work.  Read on to see some highlights from our recent series of #TwitterForGood Days.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
APAC  Training Students on the Importance of Online Safety (Jakarta
column20:
Indonesia): @TwitterID partnered with Tempo Institute (@TempoInstitute) to lead a session for Jagat Arsy International School students (@jagatarsyibs) on how to use and stay safe on Twitter. The activity was part of a roadshow held by Tempo Institute to raise awareness about how to be better Internet users.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Empowering Young People (Sydney
column21: Australia): The @TwitterAU team spent the day at the Police Citizens Youth Club (@PCYCNSW)
column22: one of Australia\u00e2\u0080\u0099s leading youth-focused organisations
column23: offering a range of fitness
column24: leisure
column25: and drop-in opportunities for young people and adults alike. There
column26: they helped restore the the garden
column27:
providing a green space for the young people visiting the center every day.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
EMEA  Highlighting Press Freedom Around the World (Paris
column28: France): On March 24
column29: @TwitterFrance spent the day working alongside Reporters Without Borders (@RSF_Inter)
column30: helping the team organize photo albums documenting freedom of the press around the world
column31: packing and preparing more than 1
column32:
000 albums.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Promoting #WearAHatDay with Brain Tumour Ireland (Dublin
column33: Ireland): @TwitterDublin partnered with its Charity of the Year
column34: Brain Tumour Ireland (@braintumourIRL) to promote #WearAHatDay. Twitter employees \u00c2\u00a0wore their finest headwear
column35: and encouraged others across the country to do the same by sharing selfies and updates throughout the day. The initiative was covered in national print and broadcast media
column36: was the number one trend in Ireland
column37:
with notable participants including Irish Rugby and the Dublin Fire Brigade. âBrain Tumour Ireland was honoured to be chosen by Twitter Dublin as their Charity of Year. The #TwitterforGood day was great for us in terms of raising awareness of brain tumours and raising funds for patient support and research. Thanks to all at Twitter Dublin for their hard work on this!â
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
USA  Coordinating Lunch for Adults Living With Chronic Illness (San Francisco): Catholic Charities Peter Claver Community (@CatholicCSF) is a comprehensive on-site residential care facility for chronically homeless adults living with disabling HIV/AIDS
column38: mental health and addiction. Opened in 1985
column39: the program marked one of the earliest attempts by any organization to aggressively serve those sick and dying from HIV/AIDS. Twitter employees coordinated lunch for over 30 residents
column40: helping the community center cook
column41: prepare
column42:
and serve meals.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Visiting the Boys & Girls Clubs SF - Tenderloin Clubhouse (San Francisco): Twitter employees @TwitterSF joined the Boys & Girls Clubsâ Tenderloin Clubhouse
column43: where employees played with the kids
column44: organized a movie afternoon
column45: and took the group to Boeddeker Park. Twitter team members also had the opportunity to learn more about the programs available at the Club
column46: and the different ways they work to serve over 1
column47: 600 youth (ages 6-18) per day. Ahead of #TwitterForGood Day
column48:
members of the Club also spent the day at Twitter HQ.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Providing Meals with Meals on Wheels (San Francisco): @TwitterSF partnered with Meals on Wheels San Francisco (@MOWSF) to provide homebound senior citizens and adults with disabilities a full weekendâs worth for food
column49: relieving thousands of meals drivers who would otherwise deliver goods throughout the weekend. Twitter employees also had the opportunity to meet members of the Meals on Wheels San Francisco team including drivers
column50: social workers
column51: nutritionists
column52: community partners
column53: volunteers
column54: donors
column55:
and advocates who serve as a formidable force against senior neglect and malnutrition.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Volunteering at the Humane Rescue Alliance (Washington
column56: D.C.): Among one of the #TwitterForGood Day efforts in Washington DC
column57: members of the @TwitterDC team spent the day at \u00e2\u0080\u008bthe \u00e2\u0080\u008bHumane Rescue Alliance (@HumaneRescue)\u00e2\u0080\u008b
column58: \u00e2\u0080\u008b\u00e2\u0080\u008ba\u00e2\u0080\u008b local 501(c)3 \u00e2\u0080\u008banimal welfare organization. There
column59: they spent the day playing with the animals
column60: worked together to create enrichment toys and provided valuable human interaction with animals to prepare the animals for adoption. The group also learned more about organization\u00e2\u0080\u0099s work in the community
column61: \u00e2\u0080\u008b \u00e2\u0080\u008bfrom medical to humane law enforcement to adoption
column62:
as well as the importance of Twitter andâ social media on increasing their chances of adoption.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Sorting donations at Little Essentials (New York): Established in 2011
column63: Little Essentials (@LittlEssentials) seeks to improve the health and safety of children living in poverty by providing urgently needed resources and parenting education to their families. Over the last six years
column64: they have helped more than 25
column65:
000 children in New York City by providing direct support to their families. Twitter employees from @TwitterNYC helped the Little Essentials team sort through donations for some of the most vulnerable children in the area.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Giving Away Backpacks at Public School with State Bags (New York): On #TwitterforGood Day
column66: team members from the New York office spent the day with the State Bags team
column67: helping kids stuff their new bags with donated items such as school supplies
column68: socks
column69:
and healthy snacks. @StateBags is a Brooklyn-born organization that supplies hand-delivered bags to American children in need.Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Cleaning Up Central Park (New York): Twitter employees from @TwitterNYC worked on the landscaping and beautification of Heckscher Playground in Central Park. There
column70: they worked alongside Central Park Conservancy gardeners
column71:
raking and weeding in the park to help restore the southeast wall of the playground.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
CANADA  Helping Local Nonprofits Use Twitter (Toronto
column72: Ontario): Throughout the day
column73: employees @TwitterCanada worked with various nonprofits
column74: to help them use Twitter more efficiently for their organization. In the morning
column75: the team met with executives from The Maddie Project
column76: an organization dedicated to sparking conversation and reducing the stigma around youth mental health. The Maddie Project shared an overview of their organization and important data around youth struggling with mental health
column77: and the group brainstormed on how we can best leverage our internal expertise and Twitter to help drive awareness for youth mental health.  In the afternoon
column78: @TwitterCanada hosted teams from more than 40 nonprofit organizations across the Greater Toronto Area for an immersive hands-on Twitter workshop. People from different teams led how-to presentations
column79: interactive exercises
column80: discussions and interactions
column81:
to help the organizations optimize their brand on Twitter.
Â 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
LATAM  Bringing Joy to Children with Cancer (SÃ£o Paulo
column82: Brazil): Twitter employees from @TwitterBrasil provided a morning full of fun and joy to the children of ITACI hospital (@beabaorg) - Institute for the Treatment of Childhood Cancer. Activities included painting
column84: building playdough sculptures
column86:
and donating personal hygiene kits.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Training Non-Profits on Twitter best practices (SÃ£o Paulo
column87: Brazil): @TwitterBrasil employees trained a series of nonprofits in the country on best practices on how to use the Twitter platform to disseminate their messages
column88: creating a call to action for fundraising
column89:
among other goals. Each NGO sat with an individual Twitter employee who walked them through tips and offered suggestions and advice for their accounts.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
A Day with the Association for Persons with Cerebral Palsy (Mexico City
column90: Mexico): @TwitterLatAm employees visited The Association for Persons with Cerebral Palsy (@apacdf) where they assisted APAC teachers
column92: helped feed pupils
column93:
and painted with them. Our team also underwent a sensitivity workshop to learn how to interact with people with cerebral palsy with dignity and mutual respect.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.

@Twitter

column3: "title": "#NuggsForCarter is now the most Retweeted Tweet of all time"
column7:
"post_text": "Events
#NuggsForCarter is now the most Retweeted Tweet of all time
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 9 May 2017\nLink copied successfully\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s official. Carter Wilkerson\u00e2\u0080\u0099s (@carterjwm) call for a year\u00e2\u0080\u0099s supply of free nuggets from @Wendys has become the Tweet heard around the world. With 3.42M Retweets
column9:
it has officially surpassed Ellenâs infamous selfie as the most Retweeted Tweet of all time. The top three most Retweeted Tweets now rank as follows: 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
But how did one high schoolerâs plea for nuggets become whatâs happening? Letâs take a look at where it all began.
It all started with a simple Tweet from @carterjwm asking @Wendys how many Retweets would be needed for a yearâs supply of free nuggets. To which Wendyâs responded
column10: \u00e2\u0080\u009c18 million.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cConsider it done
column11: \u00e2\u0080\u009d Carter said. \nAs he embarked on a journey to reach his goal
column12: the world chimed in to help Carter on his quest. Top brands
column13: celebrities and influencers got behind his efforts
column14: including @tyleroakley
column15: @debbyryan
column16: @Zedd
column17: @marcorubio
column18: @kathygriffin
column19: @jaketapper
column20: @zaralarsson
column21: @Busyphilipps2
column22: @microsoft
column23: @amazon
column24:
and @hollisterco.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Carter Wilkerson has become more popular than ever. On April 1
column25: he had 138 followers. He now has over 100
column27: he is officially verified on Twitter
column28:
and #NuggsForCarter has a custom emoji featuring a box of Wendyâs nuggets. Carter and his family knew the world stage provided an opportunity for them to do something more than just eat some nuggets. They wanted to make an impact. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
I want to give back. I am so blessed to have an opportunity to use my voice to support something I believe in. And really grateful to everyone who Retweeted my post. They made this happen.
Carter Wilkerson
â@carterjwmâ
As a nod to his success
column29: @Wendys will provide Carter with a gift card for a year\u00e2\u0080\u0099s worth of free nuggets and a $100
column30: 000 donation in Carter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s name to the Dave Thomas Foundation for Adoption (@DTFA)
column31:
which finds loving homes for children in foster care. Carter is raising additional dollars for the cause on his website nuggsforcarter.com. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Wendyâs has a long history of leveraging Twitter to communicate with people. From the first-ever interactive March Madness Bracket run entirely through Twitterâs Direct Messages
column32: to a livestreamed
column33: behind-the-scenes look at how to make the Baconator featuring influencer Cody Johns
column34:
Wendyâs is consistently using their unique brand voice to connect with a wide audience.
 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We could not be more excited for Carter for having broken the record of the most Retweeted Tweet of all time. We love Twitter because it lets us talk with people in real and fun ways
column35: and they have been loving us back as a result.\nKurt Kane\nChief Concept and Marketing Officer
column36: The Wendy\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Company \nCongratulations
column37: Carter! For those that need an extra serving of #NuggsForCarter
column38:
weâll leave you with a few more Tweets from people and brands that joined the conversation: 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@carterjwm
@Wendys
#NuggsforCarter
