column3: "title": "#PressFreedom 2017"
column7:
"post_text": "medTint
Events
#PressFreedom 2017
                By
                
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 3 May 2017\nLink copied successfully\nToday we celebrate journalism and the importance of #pressfreedom in elevating public discourse
column9: illuminating issues of civic importance
column10: and speaking truth to power.\nOver the course of the past 48 hours we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve participated in and hosted events to celebrate journalism worldwide and the bravery of those that continue to practice their vital vocation in what are increasingly precarious circumstances in many parts of the world. Today
column11: in particular
column12: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been enlivened by the use of our platform by reporters
column13:
news organisations and journalism NGOs to amplify the importance of a free press.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The significance of what our media do everyday cannot be overstated; they are our eyes and ears in the pursuit of truth and the disseminators of the stories that define our world. They make sense of the intersecting threads that bind communities together and hold a light up to the noblest and darkest facets of our humanity. From the citizen reporter bringing grassroots events to mainstream attention
column14:
to the global newsroom presenting a birdâs-eye view of the shifting sands of geopolitics and beyond - we stand with you.
Thank you for continuing to use Twitter to tell stories. Your work is vital now more than ever. Check out the Moment below for a sample of some of the activities we were engaged in to celebrate #pressfreedom and the wider conversation thatâs taking place across hundreds of thousands of Twitter accounts worldwide:
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter

#WorldPressFreedom2017

Finance Tweets of the Month: April 2017
            By
            
  
  
          
            and
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 3 May 2017\nLink copied successfully\nWe often receive questions about how Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s developer partners are using Twitter Data to modernize the investment decision-making process. While there are countless ways in which they have innovated using Twitter Data over the past 10 years
column9: we thought it would be helpful to hear from some of Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s most trusted finance partners directly.\nThis will be the first of what will become an ongoing series of guest blog posts. Our goal is twofold: first
column10: we want to continue to surface great insights and some of the best
column11: most compelling content on Twitter. The second is to showcase all the great work and diverse perspectives our partners are bringing to Twitter and the value gained by financial professionals.\nOne organization Twitter works very closely with is Bloomberg
column12: which has done incredible work bringing the power of Twitter Data directly onto the Bloomberg Terminal and who we just partnered with to launch a new global live video breaking news network exclusively on Twitter. Bloomberg (@TheTerminal) leverages Twitter Data at scale to help quantify market trends
column13: calculate investor sentiment on an individual company level
column14: and inform their users of breaking business news & current events as they unfold on Twitter. All of this helps Bloomberg Terminal subscribers generate ideas and maintain comprehensive access to real-time information on global markets within one fully integrated market data solution.\nThis first guest blog post in our series features Mark Dimont (@mdimont)
column15: Product Manager for Bloomberg Terminal News Applications (@TheTerminal)
column16: who will walk us through some of the most financially relevant Tweets over the month of April.\nWe hope you enjoy
column17: and be sure to look for additional partners and guest bloggers in the coming months. And now we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll turn it over to Mark:\n\u00e2\u0080\u0094\nAt Bloomberg
column18: I send a recurring note to my colleagues called \u00e2\u0080\u009cThis Week in Social.\u00e2\u0080\u009d The email aggregates items from financial social media that are particularly popular
column19: novel
column20: interesting or compelling. For this blog collaboration with Twitter I have compiled some of the best content from these notes for the full month of April.\n \nTweets of the Month: CEOs
column21: Short-Sellers
column22: and Journalists talk stocks and move markets\nThese \u00e2\u0080\u009cTweets of the Month\u00e2\u0080\u009d represent a collection of the most popular
column23: compelling
column24: and impactful Tweets for the month of April in the finance world. Some of these may have made national news
column25: while others might have flown completely under the radar of mainstream media. We saw some great content this month in terms of Tweets that had a material impact both on the markets as well as mindshare of the financial community at large.\nElon Musk responds to short-sellers following Tesla record results: One of the pre-eminent and most active executives we see on Twitter is Elon Musk (CEO of Tesla
column26: Solarcity
column27: and SpaceX). He is informal
column28: blunt and not afraid to talk stocks. After Tesla\u00e2\u0080\u0099s earnings this month
column29:
he responded to short sellers in Tesla as the stock climbed.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Stock moves related to Tweets about Westar Energy and Great Plains Energy merger: Twitter is a powerful outlet for regional news and reporters
column30: and is frequently the source for breaking market moving content. In this case a local Kansas reporter covering a court case impacting the merger of Westar Energy and Great Plains Energy tweeted the following directly from the courtroom. Shortly thereafter Westar Energy dropped 4.5% post-market
column31:
and the following day it fell as much as 7.7% on the New York Stock Exchange 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Short Sellers Opinions have Impact on Stocks: Earlier this month
column32:
short-seller Marc Cohodes tweeted his view of Equitable Group and helped to propel its stock price substantially lower. The opinions of short-sellers in social media can dramatically impact stock prices and at times be predictive of very large moves in security prices. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Richmond Fedâs Lacker announces immediate departure:  The actions of the US Federal Reserve Bank are watched closely on Wall Street and when this news of the abrupt resignation of the President of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond broke on Twitter
column33:
it quickly got the attention of investors around the world â as his votes as a member of the FOMC impacted interest rates and US monetary policy. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitter Finance Around the World: Government Ministers use Twitter as a way to reach their Constituents
Compelling and relevant content for the finance world is not just confined to domestic issues. The global nature of finance lends itself to comment from the myriad of world leaders and CEOâs on Twitter. This month is no exception with important Tweets on everything from the French election to the Foreign Minister of Iran.
There was a flurry of interesting content in April around the French Election: The French Election was broadly watched by Wall Street and social media proved an excellent source for differentiated content. Poll results appeared rapidly (and often first) on social media
column34: and even the candidates themselves were taking to Twitter throughout the election. Leading candidate
column35: Emmanuel Macron
column36:
used the platform to reach his supporters and give his thanks and encouragement.

 (TRANSLATION: Blairo Maggi: I have good news! Jamaica and Barbados reopened the meat market for Brazil. Mexico opened the market for rice.)
Foreign Minister of Iran Tweeted about US/Syria conflict: It is not uncommon for global governmental officials to use Twitter as a mechanism to communicate with the public (and other governments). Following the US airstrike on Syria
column37: Iran\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Foreign Minister used Twitter as a mechanism to reach out the world
column38:
to express his countryâs positions.

Indian Business News breaks layoffs at large auto manufacturer:  It is common for news bureaus around the world to use social media as a destination for important financial bulletins.

Twitter User to Watch
We wanted to highlight one user a month who is especially newsworthy

column41: the founder of Bridgewater \u00e2\u0080\u0093 one of the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s largest and most successful hedge funds \u00e2\u0080\u0093 joined Twitter
column42: noting his enthusiasm for sharing his thoughts with his followers. Ray will undoubtedly be a \u00e2\u0080\u009cmust follow\u00e2\u0080\u009d for finance and business professionals alike
column43:
offering a potential glimpse inside one of the sharpest minds on Wall Street. 
Jack welcomes Ray Dalio to the platform:

column8: 2 May 2017\nLink copied successfully\nToday at our first-ever Digital Content NewFronts

column10: news and entertainment
column11: which will bring hundreds of hours of new premium video content to Twitter.\nToday\u00e2\u0080\u0099s announcements include new exclusive original live programming
column12: live games and events
column13: live syndications
column14: extensions of existing live deals
column15:
and new always-on live streaming content onto the platform. This presents new opportunities for brands to reach passionate and engaged audiences by sponsoring premium video content at scale.
This Tweet is unavailable

Growing premium video on Twitter People have always come to Twitter to see and talk about whatâs happening. Over the last four years
column16: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve brought users video content around the things they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re already discussing on the platform
column17: working with the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s top TV networks

Brands align with all of this content to reach engaged audiences at scale.\nOur live video and Amplify business now work hand-in-hand as we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve grown our premium video business to more than 200 premium video publishers across the most active segments on Twitter \u00e2\u0080\u0094 from sports and esports
column22: to news
column23: creators and entertainment. And we couldn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t be more excited about the success we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re seeing. In fact

With these new content offerings

column3: "title": "How In-Stream Video Ads on Twitter help marketers tell their story"
column7:
"post_text": "Events
How In-Stream Video Ads on Twitter help marketers tell their story
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 18 April 2017\nLink copied successfully\nIt should come as no surprise that consumers are watching more video on their mobile devices than ever. What you may not know is that video impressions on Twitter grew significantly from Q3 to Q4 2016 as Twitter is fast becoming the place for people to tune in and watch what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening. Today
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re rolling out In-Stream Video Ads and sharing new research that shows Twitter video ads help marketers reach their audience and drive powerful results.\nIn-Stream Video Ads help marketers tell their story\nTwitter is home to brand-safe video from hundreds of the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s top publishers. That means brands can now run In-Stream Video Ads to align with videos \u00e2\u0080\u0094 highlights clips and live-streams \u00e2\u0080\u0094 from Amplify partners
column10: including top TV networks
column11: major sports leagues
column12: major publishing houses and magazines
column13: and professional news outlets. This includes pre-roll and mid-roll ads.\nIn recent experiments
column14: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been automatically promoting videos with high engagement from select publishers. Not only does this drive more views for the publisher
column15:
it also allows advertisers to get their message in front of a larger target audience. We have seen early success in the US and look forward to rolling this out more widely in the year ahead.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
New research on the effectiveness of video ads
Time and again Twitter video ad campaigns drive positive shifts in key brand metrics for advertisers. Across 406 Nielsen Brand Effect studies
column16: those who saw video ads on Twitter were 50% more likely to be aware of the advertiser\u00e2\u0080\u0099s brand
column17: feel 14% more favorable about the brand
column18: and had 18% higher purchase intent (versus those not exposed to video ads).\nWhy? People come to Twitter in a discovery mindset
column19: making them more attentive
column20: responsive
column21:
and trusting of the video ad content they see on Twitter in comparison to competing platforms. This leads to video ads on Twitter being almost 2X as memorable when compared to the same ads on other premium sites.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Helping marketers measure their impact
As we shared last week
column22: we are helping marketers measure the impact of their video campaigns by continuing to invest in measurement. This includes relationships with industry-leading third-party measurement providers to understand whether video ads they run on Twitter are viewable and were delivered to the audience they intended to reach.\nInvesting in the video experience\nAs a company
column23: we are making video experiences even better for consumers
column24: publishers
column25: and advertisers. We are investing in the video viewing experience through updates to our platform
column26: content development
column27: and video ad solutions.\nWe are poised to continue telling this story to the industry on May 1
column29: at the Digital Content NewFronts in New York
column30: where we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll share more about Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s video content partners and long-term plans.\nGet Started\nTo learn more about our video ad solutions
column31:
reach out to your Twitter account representative.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet

column3: "title": "Introducing Custom Hearts: a New Way to Amplify Your Campaign"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Introducing Custom Hearts: a New Way to Amplify Your Campaign
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 10 April 2017\nLink copied successfully\nStarting today
column9: we are offering brands an immersive and personalized way to integrate their campaigns into video via Custom Hearts on live and on-demand Periscope video. As video continues to play a prominent role in brands\u00e2\u0080\u0099 campaigns and content strategy
column10: activating Custom Hearts is a new way for brands to visually and natively amplify their campaigns within live video.\nPeriscope hearts are unique to the live video experience on Twitter and Periscope and allow anyone in the audience to engage and show support for the broadcaster by tapping to send hearts. Now
column11: via Custom Hearts
column12: Periscope hearts can be tailored to a brand\u00e2\u0080\u0099s campaign
column13: opening up an organic way for branded content to be present throughout a live experience. Custom Hearts are present throughout the entire video and are sent by the audience by tapping the screen
column14: giving brands an opportunity to capture a high number of engagements and allowing people to express their enthusiasm for the content while amplifying the brand\u00e2\u0080\u0099s message.\nHow it Works Custom Hearts provide brands an opportunity to add more branding to their Periscope Broadcasts through custom graphics that display natively amongst standard Periscope hearts and are activated through a specific hashtag in the broadcast\u00e2\u0080\u0099s title. Once activated
column15: the Custom Heart design is then natively mixed in with the standard hearts. Custom Hearts can be used alone or combined with pre-roll ads in brand sponsorships of broadcasts.\nIntroducing Custom Hearts at the #F8Premiere NBC Universal is the first brand to integrate custom hearts in live video as part of its campaign for \u00e2\u0080\u009cThe Fate of the Furious
column16: \u00e2\u0080\u009d the eighth film in The Fast and Furious series
column17: sharing exclusive looks at the cast
column18: events and experiences surrounding the film. Throughout its broadcasts
column19:
@FastFurious has integrated an âF8â Custom Heart for fans to spread the love (tap into the video to see the F8 hearts).

column3: "title": "Introducing Twitter Lite"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Introducing Twitter Lite
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 6 April 2017\nLink copied successfully\nEvery day
column9: millions of people around the world use Twitter to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening right now. However
column10: there are several barriers to using Twitter
column11: including slow mobile networks
column12: expensive data plans
column13: or lack of storage on mobile devices. While smartphone adoption grew to 3.8 billion connections by the end of 2016
column14: 45% of mobile connections are still on slower 2G networks
column15: according to GSMA.\nToday
column16: we are rolling out Twitter Lite
column17: a new mobile web experience which minimizes data usage
column18: loads quickly on slower connections
column19: is resilient on unreliable mobile networks
column20: and takes up less than 1MB on your device. We also optimized it for speed
column21: with up to 30% faster launch times as well as quicker navigation throughout Twitter. Twitter Lite provides the key features of Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0094your timeline
column22: Tweets
column23: Direct Messages
column24: trends
column25: profiles
column26: media uploads
column27: notifications
column28: and more. With Twitter Lite
column29:
we are making Twitter more accessible to millions of peopleâall you need is a smartphone or tablet with a browser.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In addition
column30: we have added a data saver mode
column31: which further reduces the amount of mobile data used. In this mode
column32: you will see a preview of images and videos before choosing which ones to fully load. This can reduce your data usage by up to 70%
column33:
making it more affordable for you to use Twitter in areas where mobile data is expensive. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitter Lite has additional features in Google Chrome and other modern browsers on Android devices. You can now receive a wide range of push notifications
column34: so you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be alerted to what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening on Twitter throughout the day. Twitter Lite also offers offline support
column35: so you will not be interrupted while using Twitter if you temporarily lose your connection. You can also add Twitter Lite to your device\u00e2\u0080\u0099s home screen
column36:
so you can launch Twitter quickly with just one tap. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Starting today
column37: Twitter Lite is available globally by visiting mobile.twitter.com on your smartphone or tablet. You can find more information about Twitter Lite at lite.twitter.com. A more in-depth look at how we built Twitter Lite can be found here.\nTwitter Lite is a great way for many people in emerging markets across Asia Pacific
column38: Latin America and Africa to experience Twitter for the first time on their mobile devices. Today in India
column39: we have partnered with Vodafone
column40: one of the country\u00e2\u0080\u0099s largest telecom operators with over 200 million subscribers
column41: to promote Twitter Lite to their customers as a way to get live sports updates on Indian Premier League matches
column42: teams
column43: and players as the cricket season kicks off. More details about Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s partnership with Vodafone in India can be found here.\nWe are working hard to bring more exciting updates to Twitter Lite for people worldwide and to develop more partnerships in emerging markets to make it useful. No matter where you are in the world
column44: we want to make Twitter the best way for you to get real-time updates on news
column45: sports
column46: entertainment
column47: politics
column48:
and other topics that matter most to you.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

#twitterlite

except in select international territories. Each weekly stream will be a simulcast of the home teamâs television broadcast.
Fridayâs game is the first of weekly Friday night live streams of out-of-market MLB games Twitter will make available free as part of its partnership with MLBAM.
Below is the April schedule for the Twitter MLB Game of the Week (subject to change).

column3: "title": "Businesses can now share and request locations in Direct Messages"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Businesses can now share and request locations in Direct Messages
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 3 April 2017\nLink copied successfully\nStarting today
column9: businesses building on our Direct Messages platform can request and share locations with people. Alongside quick replies
column10: welcome messages and Customer Feedback Cards
column11: this is yet another feature in the canvas we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re providing for businesses to create great human- and bot-powered customer experiences on Twitter.\nPeople have complete control over the location information they share with a business. Businesses must first ask a person to share a location. That person can then choose to ignore the request
column12: share a precise location
column13:
or pick a place name from a list â regardless of whether or not they are physically there.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
For many businesses
column14: delivering a great customer experience depends on understanding location for context \u00e2\u0080\u0094 whether to engage with a location-aware bot or to get better customer service. For example
column15:
TGI Fridays has made it quick and easy to find a local store from which to place an order or make a reservation using Direct Messages. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitterâs innovative tools enable us to create a digital experience that seamlessly allows people to engage with TGI Fridays while on-the-go . . . With the new location sharing feature
column16: coupled with our Conversable partnership
column17: we are able to simplify the process of finding a nearby Fridays
column18: book a reservation or place an order to go.\nSherif Mityas\nVP for Strategy and Brand Initiatives
column19: TGI Fridays\nHelping people find a location nearby makes perfect sense for brick-and-mortar businesses.Wingstop also offers similar functionality in Direct Messages. Now that businesses can easily incorporate location sharing into their customer experiences
column20: expect to see other innovative location-aware use cases in Direct Messages.\nOur new Direct Message APIs
column21: currently in private beta
column22: now include the ability to request and share locations. If you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re a business looking to use this feature
column23:
please show us youâre interested here. Developers looking to build on our new APIs can apply for access here.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet

column3: "title": "Rethinking our default profile photo"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Rethinking our default profile photo
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 31 March 2017\nLink copied successfully\nFor the past seven years
column9: everyone who has created an account on Twitter starts out with their default profile photo as an egg. This was a playful way to reference how eggs hatch into birds that send all the Tweets you see on Twitter! But now it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s time for something new \u00e2\u0080\u0093 something that encourages people to upload their own photos for more personal expression. So today
column10: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re introducing a new default profile photo.\nThere are a few reasons why we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re doing this:\nLast year we refreshed our brand
column11: with a new look and feel highlighting the diversity and expressiveness of the people around the world who make up the Twitter community
column12: in all its color and vibrancy. As part of our work to bring these ideas into the product
column13: we realized it was time to change the default profile photo
column14: to help prompt more self-expression.\nWe noticed that some people kept the egg default profile photo because they thought it was fun and cute
column15: but we want people to use this space to show us who they are! The new default image feels more like an empty state or placeholder
column16: and we hope it encourages people to upload images that express themselves.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve noticed patterns of behavior with accounts that are created only to harass others \u00e2\u0080\u0093 often they don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t take the time to personalize their accounts. This has created an association between the default egg profile photo and negative behavior
column17: which isn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t fair to people who are still new to Twitter and haven\u00e2\u0080\u0099t yet personalized their profile photo.\nHow We Did It Our first step was to look back at all of Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s default profile photos throughout the years. We originally chose the egg
column18: with a different colored background for each new account
column19: because we wanted something that was playful
column20: fun
column21:
and unique.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Twitter default profile photo
column22:
through the years 
          
          
        
For the new default profile photo
column23: we decided that we wanted to use people\u00e2\u0080\u0099s existing expectations for default profile photos and how they serve as a temporary placeholder. From this process
column24:
we identified a set of traits the new default profile photo should have:
Generic
Universal
Serious
Unbranded
Temporary
Inclusive
We went through many iterations to develop the new profile photo to make sure it displayed those traits. First
column25: we explored gray
column26: generic images to communicate that this profile photo is intended to be temporary. We looked at figures
column27: photos
column28: and patterns. For the figures
column29: we thought about combinations of very common
column30: circular shapes \u00e2\u0080\u0093 these were a good starting point because they didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t have any notable physical attributes. Because photos are usually communicated with a landscape icon
column31: we felt that this was also a good route to explore. We additionally considered a simple
column32:
line-based pattern to try something without a figure.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
After deciding on a figure
column33: we began our refinements. We had to determine how to bring inclusivity into our single default profile photo
column34: given that we don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t require people to specify their gender on Twitter. We felt that the circle of the head in the figure still seemed masculine
column35: even though it technically had no design characteristics to indicate that it was a man. So for inspiration
column36: we looked at how women are portrayed in generic
column37: wayfinding iconography
column38: such as bathroom signs
column39:
and noticed that the only difference between the sexes is the shape of their clothing. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Bathroom sign iconography 
          
          
        
Regardless
column40: people have come to associate the circle head with masculinity
column41: and because of this association
column42: we felt that it was important to explore alternate head shapes. We reviewed many variations of our figure
column43: altering both the head and shoulders to feel more inclusive to all genders. When the shoulders were wider
column44: the image felt overly masculine
column45: so we decreased the width of the shoulders and adjusted the height of the figure. As a result of these iterations
column46: we ended with a more gender-balanced figure. We chose grays because they feel temporary
column47: generic
column48: and universal. With that
column49: we included a higher contrast color combination to make this image accessible for those with visual impairments. Because of its coloring
column50:
the new profile photo also gives less prominence to accounts with a default profile photo.
 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          
            Progression from our initial to final figure 
          
          
        
          
            New default profile photo 
          
          
        
We hope this new default profile photo encourages more people to express themselves on Twitter! Weâre always happy to hear your feedback
column51:
let @design know what you think. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet

design
user experience

column3: "title": "Now on Twitter: 140 characters for your replies"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Now on Twitter: 140 characters for your replies
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 30 March 2017\nLink copied successfully\nRemember how we told you we were working on ways to let you to express more with 140 characters? Since then
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve introduced two updates
column10: and today we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re rolling out another. Now
column11: when you reply to someone or a group
column12: those @usernames won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t count toward your Tweet\u00e2\u0080\u0099s 140 characters.\nWith this change
column13: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve simplified conversations in a few ways:\nWho you are replying to will appear above the Tweet text rather than within the Tweet text itself
column14: so you have more characters to have conversations.\nYou can tap on \u00e2\u0080\u009cReplying to\u00e2\u0080\u00a6\u00e2\u0080\u009d to easily see and control who\u00e2\u0080\u0099s part of your conversation.\nWhen reading a conversation
column15: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll actually see what people are saying
column16: rather than seeing lots of @usernames at the start of a Tweet.\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s now easier to follow a conversation
column17: so you can focus on what a discussion is about
column18: and who is having it. Also
column19: with all 140 characters for your replies
column20:
you have more room to participate in group conversations.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The updates weâre making today are based on feedback from all of you as well as research and experimentation. In our tests of this new experience
column21:
we found that people engage more with conversations on Twitter.
Our work isnât finished â weâll continue to think about how we can improve conversations and make Twitter easier to use. You can find more details about how replies work in our help center. This update is rolling out now on twitter.com as well as on Twitter for iOS and Android. Make sure to update your app to check it out.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
*Editor's note: As of November 2017
column22:
Twitter has increased the character count of Tweets in certain languages to make it easier to share whatâs happening. 
Â

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "Expanding Pre-Roll Ads to Periscope Video"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Expanding Pre-Roll Ads to Periscope Video
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 28 March 2017\nLink copied successfully\nAs video viewership on Twitter continues to grow
column9: video has become an increasingly important channel for publishers
column10: creators and brands to reach their audiences. Today
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re introducing a new opportunity for publishers and creators to monetize their content
column12: and for brands to advertise against it
column13: with pre-roll ads on Periscope video within Twitter. \nHow It Works Pre-roll ads on Periscope video enable brands to marry their message with specific broadcasts from creators and publishers. The same control that brands have to design their campaigns through the Amplify program will be extended to the new opportunities created with these ads. The experience will mirror how ads currently appear on all Twitter video: when consumers scroll through their timelines or search for content from a specific publishers or creators
column14: Periscope videos - live and replay - can start with a short ad.\nAds on Periscope videos are a new way to use live and on-demand video to reach audiences at the most relevant moments. Periscope\u00e2\u0080\u0099s authentic and interactive nature brings people immediately into compelling live experiences and the conversation that surrounds them. From 360 degree and professionally-produced broadcasts to spontaneous mobile live video
column15: stories can be shared through a range of video content.\nFor creators and publishers that use Periscope to go live on Twitter every day
column16: these pre-roll ads present a new way to monetize their video content. For marketers
column17: they have a new source of brand-safe video advertising beyond what was previously available
column18: including ads during live streaming programs from select premium publishers
column19: Promoted Tweets with Periscope video and custom Amplify campaigns with premium content creators.\nGet Started Ads on Periscope videos are now available to select advertisers through custom Amplify packages
column20: and will roll out more broadly in the coming months. To learn more
column21:
contact your Twitter representative about packages that include this new offering.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet

column3: "title": "Our tenth Twitter #Transparency Report"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Our tenth Twitter #Transparency Report
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8: 21 March 2017\nLink copied successfully\nToday
column9: we are publishing our latest Twitter Transparency Report with updated data covering the latter half of 2016. This is also our tenth report
column10: a milestone that seemed a long way off when we announced our first report back in July 2012. A lot has changed over the past five years
column11: both at Twitter and around the world. But the need for transparency into government and company actions has never been more important given the current climate of continued crackdowns on freedom of expression and limitations on citizens rights around the globe. On the positive side
column12: it has been encouraging to see transparency reports become a mainstay of the technology industry
column13: with more than 60 reports now in existence. This backdrop continues to inspire us to provide more meaningful data and insights into requests we receive that impact our users worldwide.\nOne area we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re pleased to introduce into our report going forward is a new section in the US report covering national security requests. As recently noted
column14: we were able to reveal the existence of two national security letters after the FBI informed us that the gag orders had been lifted. We also spoke about Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s attempt to use the statutory means provided in the USA Freedom Act to seek more transparency into similar NSL requests. Shortly after that post
column15: we received word that the DOJ and FBI responded to our USA Freedom Act notices regarding three additional NSLs lifting the accompanying gag orders. Subsequently
column16: we provided notice
column17: including a copy of the data we produced
column18: to the users affected by these requests. As we continue to push for more transparency in how we can speak about national security requests
column19: we will update this new section in future transparency reports.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also adding a new section to our legal removals report covering requests to remove content from verified journalists and other media/news outlets. Given the concerning global trend of various governments cracking down on press freedom
column20: we want to shine a brighter light on these requests. During this reporting period
column21: Twitter received 88 legal requests from around the world directing us to remove content posted by verified journalists or news outlet accounts. We did not take any action on the majority of these requests
column22: with limited exceptions in Germany and Turkey
column23: the latter of which accounted for 88% of all requests of this nature. For example
column24: we were compelled to withhold Tweets sharing graphic imagery following terror attacks in Turkey in response to a court order. More details about these requests are available in our report.\nBehind the scenes
column25: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve begun the necessary work to include details about terms of service requests we receive from official government requesters through our standard customer support channels (as opposed to the data we already include based on legal requests). For now
column26: we have added the new government terms of service section to this report with information covering government requests and our response to removing content that violates the Twitter Rules relating to the promotion of terrorism. It also includes an update on the company\u00e2\u0080\u0099s continued work to remove terrorist content from our platform beyond government reports.\nAlong with the new data and the latest reporting numbers for the second half of 2016
column27: there are also a range of other updates across the report. For example
column28: in our global information requests report
column29: we now break out the number of emergency disclosure requests and preservation requests we receive by country. In our legal removals report
column30: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve included more specificity around requests to remove Periscope and Vine content. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve also added a new section covering our EU Trusted Reporters program.\nWhile we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to have reached our tenth report
column31:
there is still plenty of work to be done. Weâre more committed than ever to improve our approach and to give the world more meaningful insights and data to better understand the complex global issues we face every day. Transparency will always be part of our DNA and we welcome your feedback.
You can read our latest report now.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet
Twitter logo icon
Tags:

transparency

column3: "title": "140journos partners with Twitter to promote online safety & citizen jour"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
140journos partners with Twitter to promote online safety & citizen jour
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 9 March 2017\nLink copied successfully\nBack in 2011
column9: we were a group of college students who were angry with the level of self-censorship that existed within the mainstream Turkish media. Twitter felt like the natural home for our journalistic initiatives and at the time was becoming increasingly popular in Turkey. We were impressed by the thoroughness of communication and possibility for meaningful interaction. I remember we would ask ourselves
column10: \u00e2\u0080\u009cI\u00e2\u0080\u0099m sending a Tweet to a minister and he\u00e2\u0080\u0099s going to see it?\u00e2\u0080\u009d. From communicating with newly established accounts
column11: to the president of the country
column12: it felt liberating and gave us a tool to bypass the political bureaucracy in seconds. That was the captivating catalyst for us - real connection
column13: real accountability.\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s why we established @140journos.\nToday 520 out of 550 Turkish parliamentarians have active Twitter accounts. From Twitter diplomacy and domestic sports
column14: to celebrities and trending topics
column15: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a vital medium for understanding the social fabric of Turkey today. Tweets served as the primary vehicle for sharing live developments and information on the failed coup attempt last July. Tweets posted by @140journos were viewed 600 million times in 2016 alone. From day one
column16: Twitter has been a true home for our important work.\nNow we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re collaborating with the brand we love.\nWith a format simply entitled #
column17: 140journos has organized a series of educational workshops across Turkey with the support of Twitter. The workshop series is intended to teach university students about the basics of citizen journalism as well as online safety. Within the scope of #
column18: 140journos\u00e2\u0080\u0099 editors visited universities in cities where there is interest in citizen journalism
column19: as well as potential for greater Twitter usage.\nWe developed a custom curriculum
column20: including: Turkey and social media usage; how to use Twitter 101
column21: keeping up with the conversation in Turkey through Twitter; best-practice journalism on social media; public opinion formation; and keeping communication safe on Twitter.\nTo demonstrate how Twitter is a safe and fun place for all kinds of conversations
column22: our number one priority during the tour has been demonstrating the various reporting functionalities. Along with features like mute and block
column23: people have the tools to moderate and control their own experience on the platform. After sharing these presentations
column24: the 140journos team organized workshops on how to join Twitter for those in attendance who did not yet have an account of their own.\nHours of presentations
column25: hundreds of students
column26: thousands of miles in order to create a platform for students to meet and interact with the iconic bald ibis puppet of 140journos and the legendary Twitter bird - it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s been an amazing tour.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited for our continued partnership with our friends at Twitter. Whether you are conducting a journalistic project like us
column27: or just sharing what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in the moment
column28:
Twitter is where the world speaks.
You can read about Twitterâs latest update on safety here.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet
Twitter logo icon
Tags:
journalism
partnerships
policy

column3: "title": "#SheInspiresMe: Celebrating International Women\u2019s Day"
column7:
"post_text": "Events
#SheInspiresMe: Celebrating International Womenâs Day
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 8 March 2017\nLink copied successfully\nToday marks #IWD2017: this year\u00e2\u0080\u0099s International Women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Day
column9: a time to celebrate the accomplishments of women around the world while also acknowledging the progress that remains ahead. Twitter is \u00e2\u0080\u009cWhat\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Happening\u00e2\u0080\u009d across the globe \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve seen happening throughout the past year is powerful voices and movements come together to speak up for women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s rights. In honor of International Women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Day and Women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s History Month
column10:
spotlight the women who inspire you with the hashtag #SheInspiresMe which will trigger a custom #WomensDay emoji. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
While March 8th is the annual occasion of International Womenâs Day
column11: we also wanted to look back on the powerful conversations about women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s issues that have taken place on Twitter all year long. In 2016
column12: there were 25% more Tweets about \u00e2\u0080\u009cfeminism\u00e2\u0080\u009d or \u00e2\u0080\u009cwomen\u00e2\u0080\u0099s rights\u00e2\u0080\u009d (and translations of those phrases in 10 languages) than in 2015 \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and so far this year
column13:
the conversation has almost doubled from the same time period last year. These are the top days where mentions of âfeminismâhappened: 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Throughout the year
column14: activists and citizens have come to Twitter to discuss the issues facing women in their communities
column15: countries
column16: and industries. Women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s participation and equality in the workforce has been one prominent conversation on Twitter this year: #DressLikeAWoman in the US (which drew over half a million Tweets in a few days)
column17: #WakingTheFeminist in Ireland
column18: and #Planeta5050 in Brazil
column19: were some of the hashtags tackling employment issues. The topic of #EqualPay was also an area of focus - there have been more than 2 million Tweets about it
column20:
with hashtags such as #gleichistmehr in Germany and #3ìSTOP in Korea. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
And in a year that saw the first female candidate to top a major Presidential ticket in the United States
column21: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s no surprise that issues around women in politics and important issues to female voters were popular discussion topics on Twitter
column22: with conversations such as #NastyWoman in the US
column23: #LabanLeni in the Philippines
column24: #Ploumen4women in the Netherlands
column25: and #BeraniPeduli in Indonesia. Women were also encouraged to speak out about political issues with hashtags including #CanYouHearUsNow (to draw attention to Muslim women in the United States)
column26: #BeraniPeduli (educating women about politics and fight for women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s representation in politics)
column27:
and #ElectWomen (supporting Irish women running for office). 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Another powerful topic has been that of womenâs safety and ability to freely occupy public spaces â we saw conversations around this theme all across the globe. #ActionsMatter is a movement in Canada dedicated to eradicating violence against women by empowering citizens to take a stand. In the US
column28: hashtags such as #StopTransMurders and #WeJustNeedToPee draw attention to trans issues and the threats of violence they regularly face
column29: while others such as #WhyWomenDontReport provide a space for women to speak about sexual assault. In Italy
column30: #potreiessereio and #\u00c3\u00a8oradichiederescusa have drawn awareness to violence against women; in India
column31: #IWillGoOut advocated for women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s safety when walking alone; in Indonesia
column32: #jtubuhkuotoritasku
column33:
a movement to celebrate and respect womenâs body without judgement. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Millions of Tweets have also been sent with hashtags that are meant to shine a light on inspiring women and their accomplishments. Popular hashtags in the US
column34: #BlackGirlMagic was used over 1 million times last year
column35: and #ShePersisted has had 850
column36: 000 Tweets in the past month. Elsewhere around the world
column37: hashtags like #\u00eb\u0082\u0098\u00eb\u008a\u0094\u00ed\u008e\u0098\u00eb\u00af\u00b8\u00eb\u008b\u0088\u00ec\u008a\u00a4\u00ed\u008a\u00b8\u00eb\u008b\u00a4 (Korea)
column38: #SheLeadsIndia (India)
column39: #PerempuanBersatu (Indonesia)
column40:
#ÙØ­Ù_ÙØ§Ø¯Ø±Ø§Øª (Middle East) and #CelebratingWomen (Australia) are also places to celebrate and unite women. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The #WomensMarch rallies that took place in January of this year were also made an impact on Twitter. On the day of the marches alone
column41: there were 11.5 million Tweets mentioning #WomensMarch and the local affiliates.\nWith conversations like these - and a great many more - women and allies around the world are joining together on Twitter to share experiences
column42: challenges and successes. They are sharing what they want to see change
column43: fostering dialogue and debate
column44:
and amplifying their voices to new audiences. Follow @TwitterWomen to see some of the top Tweets & topics about #WomensDay and throughout Womenâs History Month.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter

#DressLikeAWoman

column7:
"post_text": "Events
Twitter at #MWC17: Hereâs what happened
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column8: 6 March 2017\nLink copied successfully\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s been a huge week at Mobile World Congress in Barcelona with brands taking the wraps off of huge launches
column9: including the return of the much loved @Nokia3310. Every player in the tech industry has been here talking about everything from exciting new mobile devices
column10: to 5G
column11: connected cars
column12:
drones and robots.
People have been turning to Twitter all week to see whatâs happening. There have been more than 780K Tweets mentioning #MWC17 since conversation started to build last week.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The Twitter team has been in Barcelona throughout the week capturing some of the buzz and delivering a host of diverse content. There have been daily Periscopes with @CNBC
column13: Twitter Moments and live Periscope 360 broadcasts with some big names.\nPeriscope 360\nTo help highlight how Twitter brings people closer to their passions
column14: we partnered with sports
column15: news and entertainment celebrities from Barcelona for a series of Live Periscope 360 broadcasts. These i ncluded a tour of the@FCBarcelona stadium
column16: a walk to the famous Gaud\u00c3\u00ad house\u00e2\u0080\u009cLa Pedrera\u00e2\u0080\u009d and watching the @policia hostage rescue team show us their skills in a thrilling demonstration.\nLive daily recap with CNBC\nCNBC\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Tech Correspondent @ArjunKharpal joined us everyday for a live Periscope to give us his view about the big announcements and stories at #MWC17. We also went live with @nokia CMO Barry French (@bhfrench)
column17: who talked to Twitter about the huge buzz surrounding the company at this year\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Congress.\nYou can watch them all here:Monday recap
column18:
Tuesday recap and Wednesday recap.
Video on Twitter
Mobile World Congress for Twitter was all about video. It has transformed the way people express themselves on the platform and how brands are able to connect with their audience.
Video is a big part of Twitter and the creative possibilities for brands to influence their audience are almost endless.
This Tweet is unavailable

          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
It happened in a Moment
You can find out more about what we were up to in our series of Twitter Moments highlighting the biggest stories of the day here

You can see them all here in our Moment.

column3: "title": "Our Latest Update on Safety"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Our Latest Update on Safety
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 1 March 2017\nLink copied successfully\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re continuing our work to make Twitter safer
column9: moving faster than ever to do so. During the past few weeks alone
column10: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made a number of changes on this front including updating how you can report abusive Tweets
column11: stopping the creation of new abusive accounts
column12: implementing safer search results
column13: collapsing abusive or low-quality Tweets
column14: and reducing notifications from conversations started by people you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve blocked or muted. We\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve already seen an impact from these updates and we appreciate and value all of your feedback along the way. \nThis week we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re introducing additional updates that leverage our technology to reduce abusive content
column15: give you more tools to control your experience
column16: and communicate more clearly about actions we take.\nLeveraging our technology to reduce abusive content\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re working to identify accounts as they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re engaging in abusive behavior
column17: even if this behavior hasn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t been reported to us. Then
column18: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re taking action by limiting certain account functionality for a set amount of time
column19: such as allowing only their followers to see their Tweets. For example
column20: this change could come into effect if an account is repeatedly Tweeting without solicitation at non-followers or engaging in patterns of abusive behavior that is in violation of the Twitter Rules. Our platform supports the freedom to share any viewpoint
column21: but if an account continues to repeatedly violate the Twitter Rules
column22: we will consider taking further action.\nWe aim to only act on accounts when we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re confident
column23: based on our algorithms
column24: that their behavior is abusive. Since these tools are new we will sometimes make mistakes
column25: but know that we are actively working to improve and iterate on them everyday.\nGiving you more control with additional tools\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also introducing new filtering options for your notifications to give you more control over what you see from certain types of accounts
column26: like those without a profile photo
column27: unverified email addresses or phone numbers. Many people requested more filter options for their notifications
column28:
and weâre excited to bring these to everyone on Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâre also expanding the mute feature to build on the work we did in November which lets you remove certain keywords
column29: phrases
column30: or entire conversations from your notifications. Now
column31: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be able to mute from your home timeline and you can decide how long this content is muted \u00e2\u0080\u0093 one day
column32: one week
column33: one month
column34:
or indefinitely. This was another big request from you and weâre looking forward to rolling it out.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Communicating more clearly about the actions we take
Weâre continuing to improve the transparency and openness of our reporting process. Youâll start to hear more from us about accounts or Tweets that youâve reported to our support teams â both when you report harassment directed at you or another account. You will be notified when weâve received your report and informed if we take further action. This will all be visible in your notifications tab on our app.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâre learning a lot as we continue our work to make Twitter safer â not just from the changes we ship but also from the mistakes we make
column35: and of course
column36: from feedback you share.\nWe appreciate your patience and support
column37: especially as we roll out these changes globally and in every language represented on the platform in the coming days and weeks. More to come soon and in the meantime
column38:
watch for additional updates from @TwitterSafety. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@TwitterSafety
@Twitter
@TwitterEng
Tweet

column3: "title": "Personalize customer experiences in Direct Messages"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Personalize customer experiences in Direct Messages
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 22 February 2017\nLink copied successfully\nPeople love reaching out to businesses on Twitter because they can get connected to real people when they need help. Today
column9: Twitter is launching a new feature \u00e2\u0080\u0093 custom profiles in Direct Messages \u00e2\u0080\u0093 that allows businesses to better emphasize that human element in private conversations
column10:
as well as more clearly indicate when a bot is speaking. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Our first partner to launch using this feature is T-Mobile
column11: who has a long history of innovating to create great customer experiences on Twitter. Years ago
column12: T-Mobile started using customers\u00e2\u0080\u0099 real names and agents\u00e2\u0080\u0099 initials in customer service-related Tweets. Last year
column13: they started adding agents\u00e2\u0080\u0099 pictures and names to Tweet replies by linking to custom bio web pages for each agent. Now
column14: @TMobileHelp is the first account to use custom profiles in Direct Messages
column15: making private conversations more human and personal by showing the real face
column16: name
column17:
and title of the care agent who is speaking. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The award-winning T-Mobile team is famous for care because weâre constantly looking for ways to improve and personalize the customer experience. Weâre proud to be the first company to deliver an even more personalized experience through Twitter custom profiles.
Callie Field
Executive Vice President of Customer Care
column18: T-Mobile\nAccording to our research
column19: personalized experiences with a human connection can create significant benefits for businesses. 77% of people are likely to recommend a brand following a personalized customer service interaction on Twitter. Additionally
column20: people are 19% more likely to feel like they\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve reached a resolution and 22% more likely to be satisfied compared to those who had impersonal interactions with a business on Twitter.\nWhile T-Mobile uses custom profiles to highlight the human aspect of their service
column21: custom profiles also create the opportunity for businesses to add personality to automated experiences by incorporating real or fictional characters
column22: like branded bots. Custom profiles can help people identify when they are speaking to a human versus not
column23: which helps manage their expectations about the types of replies they might receive.\nThe new versions of our Direct Message APIs
column24: currently in private beta
column25:
now include support for custom profiles. If youâre a business looking to enable custom profiles in Direct Messages please let us youâre interested here. Developers looking to build on the new API platform can apply for access here.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet

column7:
"post_text": "lowTint
Events
Twitter at #MWC17: Itâs Whatâs Happening
                By
                
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 22 February 2017\nLink copied successfully\nNext week Twitter will be in Barcelona for this year\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Mobile World Congress. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a massive global event that brings more than 100
column9: 000 people together for the latest in mobile technology. The devices at the heart of #MWC17 are also at the heart of Twitter
column10: which connects a growing global audience to what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening.\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s What\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Happening\nWhether you want to find out what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in the world of politics
column11: the latest trends during London Fashion Week or what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening on the ground at #MWC17
column12: Twitter is the best way to keep up with the things you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re most interested in and passionate about. This is why it is listed as the number 1 News App on the App store in Spain
column13: France
column14: the UK and many other countries.\nWhat people love about Twitter is what we love about it. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s an open
column15: public and live platform where people get to hear about what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in the world fast. And we don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t only mean breaking news first
column16: we also mean the conversation and memes that often follow global stories everyday.\nLive Video\nOver the last year we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been working to redefine what \u00e2\u0080\u009clive\u00e2\u0080\u009d means on Twitter. We started with Periscope
column17: integrating it into Twitter with the live button and making it easy for anyone to share an experience in real-time. People have transported us to breaking news stories
column18: celebrations and monumental moments. We added to that by offering people the opportunity to make what they share even more immersive with live 360 video.\nWe have also taken Live Video further by streaming premium content
column19: which combines with the power of Twitter conversation. From the NFL
column20: to 6 Nations rugby games
column21: to market coverage from Bloomberg
column22: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll find it live on Twitter. And we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also bringing more live moments from our content partners
column23:
like top-flight football coverage from Sky Sports. All great opportunities for brands to be a part of the moment.
Discovery Mindset
Whatâs really unique about the people on Twitter is the discovery mindset they have when they come to the platform. Theyâre on Twitter looking for great content and stories.
A discovery mindset means that people on the platform are more attentive
column24: more responsive and more trusting of the content they see on Twitter in comparison to how they are elsewhere. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s great news for brands
column25: as it makes for the perfect environment to connect with consumers. In fact
column26: recent neuroscience research results shows that a discovery mindset and video combine very effectively to produce results that massively outperform online norms
column27:
making video on Twitter a more effective tool than ever before.
See you at #MWC17
At #MWC17 weâll have some really exciting content to share with you. Weâll be going live throughout the week. Weâll be working with great creators who will be taking you all over the city. And weâll be sharing great video stories and daily updates. See you there.
Find us at the Twitter Networking Garden outside Hall 8.

column3: "title": "An Update on Safety"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
An Update on Safety
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8:
7 February 2017
Link copied successfully
Making Twitter a safer place is our primary focus. We stand for freedom of expression and people being able to see all sides of any topic. Thatâs put in jeopardy when abuse and harassment stifle and silence those voices. We wonât tolerate it and weâre launching new efforts to stop it.
Building on the work we began in November
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re continuing to work on ways to give people more control over what they see on Twitter. Last week
column10: we introduced an improvement to reporting abusive Tweets that gives people experiencing targeted harassment more ways to report it.\nToday
column11: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re announcing three changes: stopping the creation of new abusive accounts
column12: bringing forward safer search results
column13: and collapsing potentially abusive or low-quality Tweets.\nStopping the creation of new abusive accounts: We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re taking steps to identify people who have been permanently suspended and stop them from creating new accounts. This focuses more effectively on some of the most prevalent and damaging forms of behavior
column14: particularly accounts that are created only to abuse and harass others.\nIntroducing safer search results: We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re also working on \u00e2\u0080\u0098safe search\u00e2\u0080\u0099 which removes Tweets that contain potentially sensitive content and Tweets from blocked and muted accounts from search results. While this type of content will be discoverable if you want to find it
column15:
it wonât clutter search results any longer. Learn more in our help center.
Collapsing potentially abusive or low-quality Tweets: Our team has also been working on identifying and collapsing potentially abusive and low-quality replies so the most relevant conversations are brought forward. These Tweet replies will still be accessible to those who seek them out. You can expect to see this change rolling out in the coming weeks.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In the days and weeks ahead
column16: we will continue to roll out product changes \u00e2\u0080\u0093 some changes will be visible and some less so \u00e2\u0080\u0093 and will update you on progress every step of the way. With every change
column17: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll learn
column18: iterate
column19: and continue to move at this speed until we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve made a significant impact that people can feel.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re listening and want your feedback so we can learn faster
column20: build smarter
column21:
and make meaningful progress.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@TwitterSafety
@Twitter
@TwitterEng

column3: "title": "Twitter marks Data Privacy Day with events in the US and Europe"
column7: "post_text": "Company\nTwitter marks Data Privacy Day with events in the US and Europe\nFriday
column8: 3 February 2017\nLink copied successfully\nA commitment to protecting the privacy of account holders is built into the DNA of Twitter. As such
column9: this Data Privacy Day (@DataPrivacyDay)
column10: which falls on January 28 each year
column11: we backed the overall mission to raise awareness of privacy issues and data protection best practices. This message reaches a broad variety of actors in society - individuals
column12: families and corporations - as all of them have an interest in protecting their data and privacy. To mark the day
column13: we held an event at our San Francisco headquarters and in Dublin
column14: our headquarters for Europe
column15: the Middle East and Africa.\nIn the US
column16: we partnered with the National Cyber Security Alliance (@StaySafeOnline) to bring together top privacy experts from around the country. The event featured TED-style talks
column17:
segments and interviews focusing on the latest privacy issues for consumers and business.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Twitter has a strong history of collaboration with NCSA. They are members of our Trust and Safety Council
column18: providing us with ongoing advice and we have partnered on initiatives like #LockDownYourLogin and National Cyber Security Awareness Month. @StaySafeOnline put together a compelling program
column19: which included themed discussions on Scams
column20: ID Theft and Fraud
column21:
How to Read a Privacy Policy in Less Than 60 Seconds and Growing Up Online and the Need for Teaching Privacy in Schools. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Our Director of Privacy
column22: @lpirri
column23: joined the Women in Privacy panel and discussed her passion for the subject
column24: as well as positive uses of the Twitter platform like #PositionOfStrength
column25:
our womenâs empowerment initiative. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
In Ireland
column26: the Minister for Data Protection and European Affairs
column27: Dara Murphy (@DaraMurphyFG)
column28: visited Twitter Dublin for a LIVE Periscope Q&A. As questions came in on the hashtag #AskDara
column29: John Kennedy (@MrJohnFKennedy) of Silicon Republic interviewed the Minister on the EU-US Privacy Shield
column30: the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)
column31:
and Irelandâs regional role as hub for multinational and homegrown tech companies. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Just as Data Protection Day focuses on initiatives to promote awareness among businesses
column32: families and individuals on their rights and obligations
column33:
the Minister discussed how that kind of work is being rolled out in Ireland. Over 470 viewers joined the broadcast. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "#Transparency update: Twitter discloses national security letters"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
#Transparency update: Twitter discloses national security letters
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 27 January 2017\nLink copied successfully\nToday
column9: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re able to speak openly about two national security requests for the first time
column10: specifically two national security letters (NSLs). These NSLs were accompanied by gag orders when they were served (one in 2015
column11: one in 2016)
column12: preventing us from notifying the impacted account holders or publicly disclosing their existence. The FBI recently informed us that the gag orders have been lifted and that we may notify the account holders.\nWe have provided each of the account holders with copies of the relevant NSLs (certain information redacted to protect privacy) as well as the account data we were compelled to produce. While the actual NSLs request a large amount of data
column13: Twitter provides a very limited set of data in response to NSLs consistent with federal law and interpretive guidance from the U.S. Department of Justice.\nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099re encouraged by the lifting of these two gag orders and those recently disclosed by Cloudflare
column14: Google
column15: the Internet Archive
column16: and Yahoo!. However
column17: Twitter remains unsatisfied with restrictions on our right to speak more freely about national security requests we may receive. We continue to push for the legal ability to speak more openly on this topic in our lawsuit against the U.S. government
column18: Twitter v. Lynch.\nWe continue to believe that reporting in government-mandated bands does not provide meaningful transparency to the public or those using our service. However
column19: the government argues that any numerical reporting more detailed than the bands in the USA Freedom Act would be classified and as such not protected by the First Amendment. They further argue that Twitter is not entitled to obtain information from the government about the processes followed in classifying a version Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s 2013 Transparency Report or in classifying/declassifying decisions associated with the allowed bands. We would like a meaningful opportunity to challenge government restrictions when \u00e2\u0080\u009cclassification\u00e2\u0080\u009d prevents speech on issues of public importance.\nOur next hearing in the Lynch case is scheduled for February 14
column20: 2017. Concurrently
column21: Twitter is using the statutory means provided in the USA Freedom Act to seek more transparency into similar NSL requests
column22:
and will provide updates as they become available. You can read more information about our commitment to protecting free expression in our Help Center.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
#transparency
Tweet
Twitter logo icon
Tags:
policy
transparency

column3: "title": "dick clark productions and Twitter Partner to Live Stream Red Carpet"
column7:
"post_text": "Events
dick clark productions and Twitter Partner to Live Stream Red Carpet
            By
            
  
  
Friday
column8: 27 January 2017\nLink copied successfully\nSAN FRANCISCO
column9: Jan. 23
column10: 2017 \u00e2\u0080\u0094 dick clark productions (dcp) and Twitter announced today they will again partner to live stream programming from upcoming award shows exclusively on Twitter. The programming
column11: produced by dick clark productions and dcp partners
column12: will be available globally for logged-in and logged-out audiences on Twitter and connected devices. \nThe programming will kick off with the official two-hour red carpet pre-show for the 52nd Academy of Country Music Awards on April 2nd
column13: produced by the Academy of Country Music and dcp. Subsequent red carpet pre-shows will be exclusively live streamed for the Billboard Music Awards on May 21st and the American Music Awards in November. Twitter will also live stream the 7th Annual Streamy Awards in partnership with dcp and Tubefilter
column14: which will air in the fall of 2017.\nThe red carpet pre-shows will feature exclusive interviews with talent
column15: and will integrate Twitter fan and celebrity show-related conversations into the live programs. Questions sourced from Twitter will also enable fans to participate in each red carpet special. Further details on each program will be made available as they approach.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cTwitter is where conversations about award shows happen live
column16: \u00e2\u0080\u009d said Anthony Noto
column17: COO at Twitter. \u00e2\u0080\u009cAfter a successful collaboration with the Hollywood Foreign Press Association and dick clark productions on our exclusive Golden Globes red carpet show
column18: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to partner again with dcp to bring more live programming to Twitter.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cWe are thrilled with the success of the Golden Globes red carpet pre-show and look forward to working with Twitter on additional shows
column19: \u00e2\u0080\u009d said Mike Mahan
column20: President
column21: dick clark productions. \u00e2\u0080\u009cBy offering a unique online viewing opportunity
column22: we are able to expand the audience experience and generate deeper
column23: more compelling conversation.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nThe live streams will include advertising packages with TV style commercial ad spots. Sales packages will also include the opportunities for advertisers and sponsors to promote original clips produced by dick clark productions.\nThe Hollywood Foreign Press Association
column24: dick clark productions and Twitter previously partnered for an exclusive live official pre-show to the Golden Globe Awards
column25: which garnered 2.7 million unique viewers.\nAbout Twitter
column26: Inc.\nTwitter
column27: Inc. (NYSE: TWTR) is what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in the world right now. From breaking news and entertainment to sports and politics
column28: from big events to everyday interests. If it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening anywhere
column29: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening first on Twitter. Twitter is where the full story unfolds with all the live commentary and where live events come to life unlike anywhere else. Twitter is available in more than 40 languages around the world. The service can be accessed at Twitter.com
column30: on a variety of mobile devices and via SMS. For more information
column31: visit about.twitter.com or follow @twitter.\nAbout dick clark productions:\ndick clark productions (dcp) is the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s largest producer and proprietor of televised live event entertainment programming with the \u00e2\u0080\u009cAcademy of Country Music Awards
column32: \u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\u009cAmerican Music Awards
column33: \u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\u009cBillboard Music Awards
column34: \u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\u009cDick Clark\u00e2\u0080\u0099s New Year\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Rockin\u00e2\u0080\u0099 Eve with Ryan Seacrest
column35: \u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\u009cGolden Globe Awards
column36: \u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\u009cHollywood Film Awards
column37: \u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\u009cMiss America\u00e2\u0080\u009d and the \u00e2\u0080\u009cStreamy Awards.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Weekly television programming includes \u00e2\u0080\u009cSo You Think You Can Dance\u00e2\u0080\u009d from 19 Entertainment and dcp. dcp also owns one of the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s most unique and extensive entertainment archive libraries with more than 55 years of award-winning shows
column38: historic programs
column39: specials
column40: performances and legendary programming. For additional information
column41: visit www.dickclark.com.\nOriginally distributed via PR Newswire on January 23
column42:
2017.

column3: "title": "Explore"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Explore
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 26 January 2017\nLink copied successfully\nThere are many ways to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening on Twitter. Outside of your timeline
column9: trends show you what topics are being discussed right now
column10: Moments capture the most popular stories so you can catch up
column11: and search helps you find anything and everything.\nUntil today
column12: you had to go to a few different places to find each of these experiences. As part of our continued efforts to make it easier to see what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening
column13: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re bringing all these together. Very soon
column14: you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be able to find trends
column15: Moments
column16: search
column17: and the best of live video
column18: all within the new Explore tab.\nOver the past year
column19: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been exploring different ways to make it simpler for people to find and use trends
column20: Moments
column21: and search. During our research process
column22: people told us that the new Explore tab helped them easily find news
column23: what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s trending
column24: and what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s popular right now.\nNothing is going away \u00e2\u0080\u0093 we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re just making it easier to find what you want. Explore will begin rolling out today on Twitter for iOS
column25: and in the coming weeks on Twitter for Android. Make sure you have the latest version of your app to check it out. And of course
column26: we will continue to listen to your feedback to make Explore even better
column27:
based on your thoughts and some ideas we have up our sleeve!
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@TwitterEng 
Tweet

research
