column3: "title": "Building a more inclusive Twitter in 2016"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
Building a more inclusive Twitter in 2016
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 19 January 2017\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter is where inclusion lives; where movements form
column9: information is shared and change happens
column10: all in real time. The world has seen this with conversations around #BlackLivesMatter
column11: #SheInspiresMe
column12: #LoveIsLove
column13: #OrlandoStrong
column14: #BlackWomenDidThat
column15: and many more. And we are focused on that spirit of inclusion in our workplace.\nThroughout 2016
column16: we implemented practices that advance our commitment
column17: identified and acted on vulnerabilities that prevent it
column18: and partnered with organizations that can help us ensure that we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re building a diverse and inclusive workforce. Here\u00e2\u0080\u0099s some of what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been up to:\nRecognizing the importance of focusing on behaviors that stand in the way of inclusion
column19: we partnered with Paradigm to deliver live inclusion and unconscious bias workshops to our employees around the world. These workshops are facilitated by experts in the field and offer a space for employees to learn about how bias can come into play at work
column20: openly share perspectives
column21:
as well as develop strategies and skills for actively managing bias.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We facilitate trainings at a lot of companies. Twitter had a unique interest in tracking the long-term impact of their trainings
column22:
allowing us to learn that content designed both to raise awareness and to manage bias resulted in actual behavioral change in employees.
Joelle Emerson
CEO of Paradigm
Our leadership team and Board grew
column23: becoming more representative of the people and communities that use our service. And our CEO
column24: Jack Dorsey
column25:
was named the Thurgood Marshall College Fund CEO of The Year.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Reaching and moving beyond our goals also depends on an investment in our people and their growth. So we have piloted new programs focused on the development
column26: visibility
column27: and sponsorship of women and underrepresented minorities in different areas. We recognize the power of the leadership stories of our women
column28: and annually name several as MAKERS. And in 2016
column29:
all our open country head positions were filled by women.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We put ourselves where the talent is
column30: and we showed up in force at Grace Hopper Celebration of Women in Computing
column31: National Society of Black Engineers\u00e2\u0080\u0099 (NSBE) annual convention
column32: and the Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers Conference (SHPE). We launched a partnership with CODE2040
column33: focused on minority software engineering students. We updated our career site with a new inclusion and diversity section. To mitigate against unconscious bias and optimize for inclusion
column34: we made strategic changes to our technical interview process
column35: and implemented software-based tools to both increase our candidate pool and improve our job descriptions. We also built out a dedicated university diversity recruiting function to reach more students
column36: creating tailored plans for each region as well as Twitter-specific onsite programs like #FirstFlight for potential university recruits. Our goal is to create an even stronger sense of belonging in our interview process.\nWe don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t presume to have all the answers. So
column37: we seek to learn from organizations that reach different communities in their day-to-day work or who invest in the next generation of talent. We support ADCOLOR (focused on diversity in creative fields)
column38: Tech Women
column39: Lesbians Who Tech
column40: AfroTech
column41: the National Center for Women & Information Technology
column42: and Girls Who Code
column43: to name a few.\nWe expanded how we think about parental responsibilities and leave
column44: updating our policy to provide up to 20 weeks paid leave to all parents globally
column45: regardless of gender or gender identity and inclusive of adoption
column46: natural birth
column47: or surrogacy.\nOur culture of inclusion has been made stronger by our Employee Resource Groups (ERGs). Whether influencing how important decisions about the workforce are made
column48: strengthening communities internally
column49: impacting how we show up on and off Twitter
column50: or recruiting diverse talent
column51: ERGs are central to our commitment to inclusion and diversity. They have a total following of close to one million on Twitter
column52:
and they engage with these followers regularly as well as invite in communities around us for events and topical discussions.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
@TwitterWomen
column53: which in 2016 brought together all women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s groups at Twitter
column54: developed our global #SheInspiresMe campaign around International Women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Day. Thanks to the work of @TwitterAlas (Hispanic and Latinx employees) and @Blackbirds
column55: we brought the community to Twitter during #HispanicHeritageMonth and #BlackHistoryMonth with custom emojis. And because of an initiative by @Blackbirds
column56: our widely recognized emoji for #BlackHistoryMonth lives on following the #PhilandoCastile and #AltonSterling tragedies. @TwitterOpen (LGBTQ employees) helped us achieve an HRC Corporate Equality Index perfect score and receive the Visionary Award by the Trevor Project
column57: focused on anti-bullying initiatives. Following the tragedy in Orlando
column58: @TwitterOpen and @TwitterAlas co-hosted a vigil to create awareness
column59: reflection
column60:
and remembrance.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We also introduced two new ERGs: Twitter Parents and Twitter Stripes (supporting our Veteran community). And coming soon
column61: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be welcoming a new group supporting Asian employees.\nLastly
column62: we hired an ERG Program Manager to work directly with our ERGs to support their strategies and impact.\nFor 2016
column63: we sought to push ourselves in a distinguishing way and set measurable goals
column64: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re happy to share that we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve met or surpassed many of these. With our commitment we have seen progress in hiring and career development
column65: culture
column66: policies and
column67: as a result
column68:
increases in overall representation of women and underrepresented minorities.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
*We are also focused on sexual orientation and gender identity. In 2016 for the first time
column69: we gave all US new hires the opportunity to self-identify as LGBTQ. While this data collection is new and therefore limited
column70: we wanted those who chose to identify to be counted. Of employees answering
column71: 10% identified as LGBTQ. As more employees respond in 2017
column72: we expect to have a more complete picture.\nWe know that the effects of our actions \u00e2\u0080\u0094 many of which were new for 2016 \u00e2\u0080\u0094 cannot be immediate. We are focused on sustained efforts that will help us draw more diverse talent
column73: create great experiences and careers
column74: and foster a culture of belonging that fully lives up to the spirit of community on Twitter itself. And we will continue to come together with and learn from our industry peers
column75: in the spirit of doing better not just for ourselves but for the industry as a greater whole.\nOur commitment to inclusion and diversity is fundamental to who we are and crucial to the effectiveness of our service. One-and-done measurements don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t apply here
column76: so we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re again setting representation goals for 2017. Also
column77: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re going further by adding a new goal
column78: for underrepresented minorities in non-tech roles. Whatever the goal area
column79: we will continue to be broadly focused on inclusion
column80: prioritizing intersectionality and specific underrepresented groups
column81:
and acting on different opportunities for our different business functions. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
U.S. Congressman John Lewis
column82: who recently visited us to share civil rights movement experiences captured in his award-winning \u00e2\u0080\u009cMarch\u00e2\u0080\u009d trilogy
column83: reminded us that \u00e2\u0080\u009cwe all live in the same house \u00e2\u0080\u00a6 the world house. We are one people
column84: we are one family
column85: we must look up [at] each other and build that beloved community
column86: that beloved world.\u00e2\u0080\u009d We seek to live up to the spirit of this truth \u00e2\u0080\u0093 creating a workplace that fosters belonging and enables everyone at Twitter to thrive. Not in spite of their differences
column87:
but because of them.
Click here to see our September 2016 EEO-1 report.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
@Blackbirds
@TwitterForWomen
@TwitterOpen
#LoveIsLove
Tweet

Tags:
diversity
Twitter culture

column3: "title": "Twitter and PBS NewsHour Partner to Live Stream Coverage of Inauguration"
column7:
"post_text": "Events
Twitter and PBS NewsHour Partner to Live Stream Coverage of Inauguration
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 19 January 2017\nLink copied successfully\nWASHINGTON and SAN FRANCISCO
column9: Jan. 12
column10: 2017 - PBS NewsHour in partnership with Twitter will live stream special coverage of Inauguration Day 2017 on Twitter from 11am \u00e2\u0080\u0093 5pm ET on Friday
column11: January 20
column12: 2017. The special broadcast will be anchored by managing editor Judy Woodruff
column13: with NewsHour correspondents John Yang reporting from the steps of the U.S. Capitol and Lisa Desjardins from the National Mall. NewsHour\u00e2\u0080\u0099s livestream will include the swearing in of the 45th President of the United States Donald J. Trump and the 48th Vice President of the United States Mike Pence on the steps of the U.S. Capitol
column14: the Inaugural Address and Parade
column15: and the arrival of President-elect Trump at the White House.\nNewsHour\u00e2\u0080\u0099s broadcast coverage will live stream on Twitter globally at inauguration.twitter.com and @NewsHour and will be available to both Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s logged-in and logged out audience.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cWe are delighted to partner with Twitter for Inauguration Day coverage
column16: \u00e2\u0080\u009d said Sara Just
column17: NewsHour\u00e2\u0080\u0099s executive producer and WETA SVP. \u00e2\u0080\u009cThe peaceful transition of power from one president to the next is a powerful moment in the American democratic process. And this year
column18: it comes at a time when the country is embroiled in political discourse like we have rarely seen. Streaming public broadcasting\u00e2\u0080\u0099s thoughtful coverage on Twitter will allow more Americans to experience the inauguration and join in discussion around it.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cTwitter is where news and politics are discussed in real time every day
column19: and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re excited to collaborate with PBS NewsHour around this historic event to bring public broadcasting\u00e2\u0080\u0099s live coverage to Twitter
column20: \u00e2\u0080\u009d said Anthony Noto
column21: COO at Twitter. \u00e2\u0080\u009cNewsHour\u00e2\u0080\u0099s broadcast will integrate dependable
column22: thorough coverage with the live Inauguration Day conversation on Twitter.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nJoining Woodruff in studio will be a panel of guests including New York Times columnist David Brooks; syndicated columnist Mark Shields; the Cook Political Report\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Amy Walter; PBS NewsHour Weekend special correspondent Jeff Greenfield; chair of the American Conservative Union Matt Schlapp; interim director of GW\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Graduate School of Political Management Lara Brown
column23: and senior advisor and national spokesperson for @MoveOn Karine Jean-Pierre.\nPBS is Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s exclusive live streaming partner for Inauguration Day. As part of the live stream
column24: comprehensive sponsorship packages will be available via Twitter.\nAbout Twitter
column25: Inc. Twitter
column26: Inc. (NYSE: TWTR) is what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in the world right now. From breaking news and entertainment to sports and politics
column27: from big events to everyday interests. If it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening anywhere
column28: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening first on Twitter. Twitter is where the full story unfolds with all the live commentary and where live events come to life unlike anywhere else. Twitter is available in more than 40 languages around the world. The service can be accessed at Twitter.com
column29: on a variety of mobile devices and via SMS. For more information
column30: visit about.twitter.com or follow @twitter.\nAbout PBS PBS NewsHour is seen by over four million weekly viewers and is also available online
column31: via public radio in select markets
column32: and via podcast. PBS NewsHour is a production of NewsHour Productions LLC
column33: a wholly-owned non-profit subsidiary of WETA Washington
column34: D.C.
column35: in association with WNET in New York. Major funding for PBS NewsHour is provided by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting
column36: PBS and public television viewers. Major corporate funding is provided by BNSF
column37: Lincoln Financial Group
column38: and XQ Institute
column39: with additional support from Alfred P. Sloan Foundation
column40: Carnegie Corporation of New York
column41: the J. Paul Getty Trust
column42: the S.D. Bechtel
column43: Jr. Foundation
column44: the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation
column45: the Lemelson Foundation
column46: National Science Foundation
column47: The Rockefeller Foundation
column48: the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation
column49: Ford Foundation
column50: Skoll Foundation
column51: Friends of the NewsHour and others. More information on PBS NewsHour is available at www.pbs.org/newshour.\nOriginally distributed  via PR Newswire on January 12
column52:
2017.

          This Tweet is unavailable.

column3: "title": "PGA TOUR Announces Twitter as Global Live Stream Distribution Platform"
column7:
"post_text": "Events
PGA TOUR Announces Twitter as Global Live Stream Distribution Platform
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 19 January 2017\nLink copied successfully\nPONTE VEDRA BEACH
column9: Fla. and SAN FRANCISCO
column10: Jan. 5
column11: 2017 \u00e2\u0080\u0094 Following a successful live streaming collaboration during the 2016 FedExCup Playoffs
column12: the PGA TOUR has announced that Twitter will be the exclusive global platform to distribute
column13: on a free basis
column14: more than 70 hours of live competition coverage across 31 tournaments through the remainder of the 2016-17 Season.\nTwitter will begin live streaming at the CareerBuilder Challenge on January 19 and conclude at the season-ending TOUR Championship. Coverage typically will include the first 60 to 90 minutes from the early Thursday and Friday morning hours of PGA TOUR LIVE\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Over-The-Top (OTT) subscription window
column15: on a global basis. This coverage will include pre-game analysis
column16: interviews
column17: range coverage
column18: and live competition from the first two holes of each day\u00e2\u0080\u0099s PGA TOUR LIVE Marquee Groups.\nThe live streams will be available globally to Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s logged-in and logged-out audience on Twitter and connected devices and can be found at PGATourLive.twitter.com and on @PGATour. The partnership also includes opportunities for advertisers
column19: including packages with television style mid-roll spots
column20: combined with original clips produced by the PGA TOUR
column21: available for sponsorship and promotion on Twitter.\nThe partnership also includes an extension of the PGA TOUR and Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Amplify program
column22: with PGA TOUR increasing its highlight videos and regular content creation across Twitter and Periscope.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cTwitter and the PGA TOUR have been working together on Twitter Amplify for many years now
column23: and the program has been a tremendous success for both companies
column24: \u00e2\u0080\u009d said Rick Anderson
column25: Chief Media Officer of the PGA TOUR. \u00e2\u0080\u009cStreaming PGA TOUR LIVE programming to Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s global audience
column26: as well as the millions of users who follow @PGATOUR and hundreds of PGA TOUR player accounts
column27: will provide new and innovative ways for sports fans to engage with our premium OTT offering.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cThe PGA TOUR continues to transform the experience for fans on Twitter
column28: a place where golf conversation is happening live in real time every day
column29: \u00e2\u0080\u009d said Anthony Noto
column30: COO at Twitter. \u00e2\u0080\u009cOur collaboration with the PGA TOUR will provide fans all over the world access to watch live streaming PGA TOUR events on Twitter while following the conversation all on one screen.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nThe PGA TOUR teamed with Twitter to offer portions of PGA TOUR LIVE\u00e2\u0080\u0099s premium window during the opening rounds of the first two events of the 2016 FedExCup Playoffs.\nAbout Twitter
column31: Inc.\nTwitter
column32: Inc. (NYSE: TWTR) is what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening in the world right now. From breaking news and entertainment to sports and politics
column33: from big events to everyday interests. If it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening anywhere
column34: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s happening first on Twitter. Twitter is where the full story unfolds with all the live commentary and where live events come to life unlike anywhere else. Twitter is available in more than 40 languages around the world. The service can be accessed at Twitter.com
column35: on a variety of mobile devices and via SMS. For more information
column36: visit about.twitter.com or follow @twitter.\nAbout PGA TOUR LIVE\nPGA TOUR LIVE is the PGA TOUR\u00e2\u0080\u0099s first-ever Over-The-Top subscription service that was unveiled on July 30
column37: 2015. Fans can download from the App Store or Google Play. PGA TOUR LIVE is priced at $5.99 per month or $39.99 for the entire year and is available on iPhone
column38: iPad
column39: Apple TV
column40: Android smartphones and tablets or any computer via PGATOURLIVE.com.\nIn addition to its exclusive live coverage of the TOUR\u00e2\u0080\u0099s biggest stars at more than 30 tournaments during the 2016-17 TOUR season
column41: including the entire FedExCup Playoffs
column42: PGA TOUR LIVE features integrated statistics
column43: round replays
column44: simulcasts of CBS weekend coverage
column45: and access to PGA TOUR video archives. PGA TOUR LIVE was developed in partnership with BAMTech
column46: MLBAM\u00e2\u0080\u0099s technology arm.\nVisit pgatourlive.com for a full schedule.\nOriginally distributed via PR Newswire on January 5
column47:
2017.

column3: "title": "Bringing #CES2017 straight to you
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/events/2017/bringing-ces2017-straight-to-you-live-from-vegas"
column8: "post_text": "Events\nBringing #CES2017 straight to you
column9:
live from Vegas
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column10: 2 January 2017\nLink copied successfully\nWhen CES(aka the Consumer Electronics Show) rolls around every year in early January
column11: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s an event of epic proportions with close to 200
column12: 000 people flocking to Las Vegas to experience the event firsthand.\nAnd why not? Tech is now a pervasive part of our everyday
column13: increasingly mobile lives. The mobiles we carry bring us music
column14: news
column15: and sports
column16: and connect us to the world around us
column17: in many cases
column18: live and in the moment. Increasingly
column19: the world around us runs on tech
column20: too
column21: from smart homes with smart devices to the cars we drive (or that drive us). Needless to say
column22:
the tech at CES is relevant to our daily lives now more than ever.
Hereâs what weâll be bringing you live from #CES2017.
Live daily tech news from #CES2017 in partnership with The Verge
If youâre not attending (or if you are and canât possibly tour the nearly 2.5 million net square feet of exhibit space)
column23: join The Verge live on Twitter for a tech-packed 90-minute show on Jan. 4
column25:
and 6 at 4:30pm PT/7:30pm ET.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tune in to the show in 360 video
With Periscopeâs 360 video news last week
column26: the live experience will feel even more real as you teleport into unique experiences live from the CES floor. You can expect some exciting views and broadcasts from around the globe with live music
column27: art
column28:
and some far-flung destinations that will bring this new 360 view to life.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Industry perspectives from influencers and celebrities
During the event
column29: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be talking to influencers and celebs from the sports
column30: tech
column31: advertising
column32: and music industries
column33: including four-time Super Bowl winning quarterback Joe Montana and hip hop star/entrepreneur Rick Ross. They\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be sharing some of their favorite finds from CES and discussing how the intersection of tech is changing their industries and lives.\nStorytime with Twitter\nJoin Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s CMO Leslie Berland on Jan. 6 from 2:15-2:45pm PT
column34: streaming live from the ARIA Ballroom
column35:
for her C Space Storyteller segment where sheâll discuss ways that Twitter is telling its own unique story and how tapping into âwhatâs happeningâ pushes the boundaries of conventional storytelling.
Tune in to Twitterâs Head of Planning and Creative Agency Development Stacy Mineroâs talk at CES as part of Varietyâs Entertainment Summit. The topic?Love at First Sight on Social with new research and best practices from brands for creating âlove at first sightâ in social feeds.
Follow @TwitterAds and #CES2017 so you donât miss a thing.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
#CES2017
Tweet

column8: 22 December 2016\nLink copied successfully\nWe are constantly monitoring our campaign reporting to ensure 100% accuracy. Through that process
column9: we discovered a technical error due to a Twitter product update to Android clients that affected some video ad campaigns from November 7 to December 12. The issue has been fixed but we wanted to share more details on what the impact was to our advertising partners.\nOnce we discovered the issue
column10: we resolved it and communicated the impact to affected partners. Given this was a technical error
column11: not a policy or definition issue
column12:
we are confident it has been resolved.
We will continue to monitor our systems to proactively identify issues. We value our customersâ trust in our service and will continue to provide support and transparency in our partnership.

column3: "title": "#TwitterForGood Day around the world"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
#TwitterForGood Day around the world
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 22 December 2016\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter has always sought to encourage a culture of volunteering and public service among its employees. The public nature of the platform
column9: and the innumerable ways in which it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s harnessed for good
column10: motivates employees to lend their talents to initiatives large and small across the world. Previously
column11: this culture was celebrated on a biannual basis with #FridayForGood. Now
column12: because of the perennial character of our volunteering culture
column13: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re calling these days of service #TwitterForGood Days. Just as before
column14:
our teams across the globe offer their time and skills to causes and campaigns in their local area. The customs and needs of the local community are foremost in our consideration as we endeavor to put down meaningful roots wherever we have an office. Read on to see some highlights from our recent series of #TwitterForGood Days. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
AMERICAS:
Coding for Kids at Twitter NeighborNest (San Francisco)
The Twitter NeighborNest (@NeighborNest) is Twitterâs family-friendly technology learning center located right across the street from HQ. On #TwitterForGood Day
column15: Tweeps taught children from Catholic Charities (@CatholicCSF) how to code in Scratch on a Raspberry Pi and using analog blocks
column16:
giving children a multidimensional overview of coding.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Networking and Coding Intro at Code Tenderloin (San Francisco)
Code Tenderloin (@codetenderloin) is a job readiness and workforce development program that helps Tenderloin residents cross Market Street and acquire positions in technology companies. On #TwitterForGood Day
column17: Tweeps participated in a networking event with alumni of the program
column18: many of whom are currently in entry-level jobs and searching for the next career step. The event was followed by an introductory workshop on coding and software skills to give participants a glimpse into what working as an engineer is like. Participants from Code Tenderloin then paired off with Tweeps for additional demonstrations of skills and networking. Everyone loved it so much that the event ran more than an hour over time!\nDiscussing Careers in Tech with Veterans (San Francisco)\nGiven that #TwitterForGood Day fell on Veterans Day this year
column19:
Tweeps on the University Recruiting (@TwitterU) team came together with veterans in the Bay to discuss careers in tech and at Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Building Solar Kits with Lighting for Literacy and Hands on Bay Area (San Francisco)
This #TwitterForGood Day
column20: @TwitterSF partnered with Lighting for Literacy and Hands On Bay Area (@handsonbayarea) to put together solar kits that will help power the world. Tweeps were given all the tools and materials and guided through the process of putting the kits together. Things got a bit competitive
column21:
but all in the spirit of giving back and promoting environmentally sustainable energy solutions.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Supporting low income and homeless families (Boulder)
@TwitterBoulder celebrated 11/11 by assisting the Family Learning Center (@flcboulder)
column22: a resource for families of limited incomes and diverse cultures
column23: to complete projects that they typically do not have the time or capacity for once the school year begins. Tweeps at the Boulder office also made 150 Meal Care Bags with @ThereWithCare for families experiencing medical crises
column24:
and joined the cooking crew at Bridge House (@bobridgehouse) to prepare a meals for homeless men and women in Boulder.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Building a Greener City (Washington DC)
@TwitterDC worked on a beautification project at a local high schoolâs garden in partnership with City Blossom
column25: a nonprofit that integrates community-oriented gardening
column26: education
column27:
youth entrepreneurship opportunities and interactive art to create green spaces throughout Washington DC.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Supporting American Youth (New York City)
Some @TwitterNYC Tweeps spent their afternoon with @StateBags
column28: handing out backpacks with essential school supplies to children in Red Hook
column29:
Brooklyn. @StateBags is a Brooklyn-born one-for-one program that combats the challenging conditions of American children and encourages self-empowerment and community enrichment.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
A Fun Afternoon with Senior Citizens (SÃ£o Paulo)
Tweeps @TwitterBrasil hosted a series of projects
column30: including visiting senior citizens at a nursing home called Residencial Israelita Albert Einstein. Tweeps played bingo
column31:
handed out donations and walked their new friends through the mechanics of Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
APAC:
Unleashing Creativity with Children (India)
Tweeps from @TwitterIndia went to schools in Delhi and Mumbai where @FeedingIndiaâs âHunger Heroesâ routinely deliver food to children
column32: guaranteeing them a hot and delicious meal for the day. Tweeps spent time with the children
column33: decorating pots and planting saplings around the school
column34:
unleashing the creativity of both the children and tweeps! Tweeps also sponsored the meal of the day.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Revitalizing the Kumamoto Tourist Economy (Japan)
Since a massive earthquake hit the Kumamoto prefecture
column35: the number of tourists in the area has decreased. This October
column36:
the Twitter Japan office celebrated #OctoberForGood and for three weeks Tweeps raised awareness of local small businesses in Kumamoto. Kumamoto is known as the secret fashion capital of Japan and efforts were made to help revitalize the local economy and sustain these small businesses. Tweeps also trained local businesses on how to use Twitter as a campaigning to raise their profile and secure sales.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
EMEA:
Hands-On NGO Training (Dublin)
@TwitterDublin kicked off #TwitterForGood Day by hosting a group of NGOs and nonprofit organizations for a training session
column37: where Tweeps covered best practices for campaigning on the platform
column38: reviewed case studies exhibiting success
column39:
and then transitioned into a discussion on how the Twitter platform has been able to support and highlight the work of the organizations present.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Protecting the welfare of animals (Spain)
In Spain
column40: animal welfare was the priority of our @TwitterSpain team. They partnered with @CiviClub and encouraged Spanish users to Tweet about #TwitterForGood and @CiviClub. The more Tweets they saw
column41: the more fodder was donated to the Asociaci\u00c3\u00b3n Nacional Amigos de los Animales (@asociacion_anaa). By the end of the day
column42:
enough Tweets were sent for two tonnes of fodder.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
#FridayForGood
#TwitterForGood
#OctoberForGood
Tweet

community outreach

Twitter culture

column3: "title": "The most exciting goals of EURO 2016"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
The most exciting goals of EURO 2016
                By
                
  
  
Friday
column8: 16 December 2016\nLink copied successfully\nIn a football (soccer) tournament
column9: it is all about goals. Goals decide the matches
column10: and make the crowd go wild. However
column11: not every goal has equal impact
column12: both in the match and on the fans.\nWith Twitter we can gauge the excitement caused by each goal during #EURO2016 by looking at the spikes in Tweet volume after each goal. The greater the spike
column13: the more reaction it inspired among fans. This visualization shows every goal of EURO
column14: when it happened
column15: who scored it
column16: how it affected the score
column17:
and the corresponding reaction on Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We used peak detection algorithm to detect spikes and snap goals to the closest spikes. There are many ways we can measure âexcitementâ. Using raw number of Tweets could be one way
column18: but we chose to normalized the data such that each goal is measured as a percentage of total Tweets in that game
column19: in order to make the goals comparable across the entire tournament. Otherwise
column20: any goal in later matches will easily beat the group stage goals
column21: as those matches attract many more viewers. However
column22: using percentage overcompensated for the matches with fewer viewers so we had to add another weight to adjust the value based on total volume in a match.\nThe excitement level of a goal can be due to many factors
column23: as you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll see in the viz:\nImpact: How much a goal affects the course of the game can determine the reactions to it. Goals that takes the lead are indicated in red
column24: and in general caused more excitement (higher spikes).\nTiming: Goals closer to the end of the game tend (towards the right side of the viz) to have higher spikes. For example
column25: double goals from France duo Griezmann and Payet in the 90\u00e2\u0080\u0099 and 90+6\u00e2\u0080\u0099 minutes against Albania.\nBeauty: Slovakia\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Marek Hamsik\u00e2\u0080\u0099s thunderous strike from a tight angle against Russia hits the inner post and bounce in. Totally worth watching over and over.\nSurprise: Underdog goals seem to also get fans excited and cause outsize reactions. For example
column26: McGinn\u00e2\u0080\u0099s goal which gave N. Ireland its first win in major tournament
column27:
and Icelandâs winning goal in the last match of group stage both had notable spikes.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Here are some ways you can navigate the viz:
Hover (desktop) / Tap on (mobile) any goal to see all the goals from that match.
Filter matches by team
column28: to see every goal they scored or conceded throughout the tournament. Goals scored by the team are highlighted in yellow.\nFilter matches by stage
column29: to see only the knockout or group stage goals.\nFilter goals by name
column30:
to find goals from player you are interested in.
Combine the filters above
Visit https://interactive.twitter.com/euro2016/ and explore the viz for yourself.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
#EURO2016 
Tweet

data

trends

Friday
column8: 11 November 2016\nLink copied successfully\nSaying that we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re happy to announce the winners of the first #TwitterAwards is a huge understatement. These awards recognize the marketers
column9: the idea people
column10:
the innovators and the creators all over the world who work tirelessly to create ingenious campaigns. The winners taking home trophies are simply the best of the best.
Here are the five campaigns taking home gold awards. Congrats to all the winners!
#LIVEÂ award:Â Ready. Set. Race Brand:Â @NASCAR Agency:Â @Ogilvy
@NASCAR set a record for the largest social media spike in history; it was all about fast cars and faster thumbs.
Credits: Ogilvy & Mather
column11: NASCAR\n#CREATIVITY award:\u00c2\u00a0#LiveIntheMovies Brand:\u00c2\u00a0@Airbnb Agency:\u00c2\u00a0@TBWAChiatLA\nDuring Oscars weekend

and incorporate rich media into responses to provide help when and where people need it most.
Credits: Apple

column24: adjusted the price of a Snickers bar accordingly and delivered more than 30 million earned media impressions during its five-week campaign.\nCredits: Clemenger BBDO Melbourne

column3: "title": "Speed up customer service with quick replies & welcome messages"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Speed up customer service with quick replies & welcome messages
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8:
1 November 2016
Link copied successfully
Weâre excited to announce two new features to create better conversational experiences between businesses and people on Twitter. Quick replies and welcome messages in Direct Messages make it easier for businesses to guide people to better outcomes through a combination of simple automation and human service.
These features are designed to help businesses create rich
column9: responsive
column10:
full-service experiences that directly advance the work of customer service teams and open up new possibilities for how people engage with businesses on Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Introducing Welcome Messages and Quick Replies
Welcome messages let businesses greet people and set expectations as they enter a Direct Message conversationâwithout requiring people to send the first message. Businesses can create multiple welcome messages and deep link directly to a specific greeting from Tweets
column11: websites
column12: or apps. Welcome messages help businesses demonstrate their commitment to service and help people learn what options exist to engage with a business in Direct Messages.\nQuick replies let businesses prompt people with the best ways to reply to a Direct Message
column13: whether by choosing from a list of options or guiding users to enter specific text values.\nWhen quick replies and welcome messages are used together
column14: businesses can reduce wait times and educate people on the best ways to interact with them. For example
column15: they can enable faster resolutions by helping customers more easily provide information to solve problems before an agent sees the first message
column16:
or they can simplify automated services and transactional flows that were difficult in the past.
Connecting Brands and Consumers Companies including Evernote and Pizza Hut are launching new experiences in Direct Messages that make use of these features.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
At Evernote
column17: it is very important to us that we provide the best possible experience across our channels. We are excited about the new features Twitter has developed. The ability to welcome our valued customers and capture their issues before they contact one of our agents helps to streamline the process
column18:
accelerate resolution time and reduce customer effort.
Gerald Hastie
Director of Global Customer Service at Evernote
The new Pizza Hut social ordering platform is another example of making it easy for our customer to order their favorites from Pizza Hut. We are constantly pursuing ways to simplify our ordering experience. This platform allows our consumers to quickly order or get information within Twitter where they are already spending a great deal of their time.
Baron Concors
Global Chief Digital Officer at Pizza Hut
Developer Solutions Weâve worked closely with Assist
column19: Audiense
column20: Conversable
column21: Conversocial
column22: Dexter
column23: Hobbynote
column24: Lithium
column25: Massively
column26: Proxima
column27: RozieAI
column28: Spredfast
column29: Sprinklr
column30: and Sprout Social tobring these features to market. If you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re interested in creating automated experiences in Direct Messages for your business
column31:
contact those companies directly for more information. Weâre working with a wider group of partners who will offer solutions to their customers soon as well. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The features that Twitter has built into Direct Messages will help people get better experiences with businesses on the platform. At Assist
column32:
weâre excited to use Twitterâs new features to build innovative solutions that bring faster service and solutions for brands on Twitter.
Shane Mac
Co-Founder & CEO at Assist
Get Started These features start rolling out today. For people on Twitter with the latest version of our app
column33: they will start to see these features in Direct Message conversations with accounts like @EvernoteHelps
column34: @PizzaHut
column35: @AirbnbHelp
column36: @SpotifyCares
column37: @NortonSupport
column38: @Tesco
column39: @TfLTravelAlerts
column40: @WeatherNetwork
column41: and @AirTailor.\nIf you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re a business that provides support in Direct Messages
column42: you can set a default welcome message today in the support settings page of Twitter Dashboardto greet people when they start a conversation.\nThe developer APIs that power these features are currently in private beta. If you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re a developer and are interested in building these types of solutions in Direct Messages
column43:
you can sign up and apply foraccess here.

column3: "title": "Study: Twitter customer care increases willingness to pay"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Study: Twitter customer care increases willingness to pay
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 5 October 2016\nLink copied successfully\nPeople love getting customer service from businesses on Twitter
column9: but what is the value to businesses for providing that service? While it might seem intuitive that customers who get great help will spend more with that business in the future
column10: new research actually quantifies that lift and helps businesses understand how to capture that value. This post shares highlights from our research
column11: as well as tips to help customer service teams take advantage of the findings.\nRequests for customer service emerged as an early behavior on Twitter
column12: and Tweets have become a mainstream method for reaching out to businesses. Millions of people talk to businesses publicly each month via Tweets. To understand the impact of these customer service interactions on customer relationships
column13: we designed a research study in partnership with Applied Marketing Science to figure out the potential revenue benefit to businesses who help their customers via Twitter.\nLate last year
column14: we began this work focused on the US airline industry
column15: which found that customers who received replies from an airline demonstrated stronger satisfaction and recommendation ratings\u00e2\u0080\u0094and were also willing to pay a significantly higher price for a future ticket.\nMore recently
column16: we expanded the project to replicate this research with the US quick service restaurant (QSR) and telecom industries. We found that
column17: similar to the airline industry
column18: customers who received replies were more satisfied with their experience
column19: more willing to recommend the business
column20:
and willing to pay more money for that businessâs products in the futureâespecially if the consumer received a response quickly.
We used the same rigorous conjoint analysis methodology for all verticals we analyzed.
Responding to Tweets boosts willingness to spend
Businesses create a massive opportunity for themselves when they acknowledge customer service-related Tweets from consumers. When a customer Tweets at a business and receives a response
column21:
they are willing to spend 3â20% more on an average priced item from that business in the future.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tip:If you need to discuss a private topic with a person who mentions your business in a Tweet
column22: reply with a Direct Message deep link so you can invite customers into private
column23: 1:1 conversations.Make sure to acknowledge the person appropriately by being personal
column24: friendly and human.\nResponding also increases word of mouth activity
column25: likeliness to recommend
column26: and customer satisfaction\nIn addition to revenue potential
column27: customers who receive service via Twitter will create measurable upper-funnel impact. Customers are 44% more likely to share their experiences\u00e2\u0080\u0094both online as well as offline\u00e2\u0080\u0094after receiving a response from a business on Twitter. Further
column28: they are 30% more likely to recommend the business
column29:
and respond an entire point higher (2.66 vs 3.66) on customer satisfaction surveys.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tip:Learn and grow â Twitterâs customer feedback tools let people privately share their opinions after a service interaction. Businesses can collect customer satisfaction and Net Promoter ScoreÂ® data that can be compared across traditional service channels.
The fastest responses generate the greatest revenue impact
While any response is better than none
column30: it pays to reply rapidly. When an airline responded to a customer\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Tweet in less than six minutes
column31: the customer was willing to pay almost $20 more for that airline in the future. Similarly
column32: in the telco industry
column33: customers are willing to pay $17 more per month for a phone plan if they receive a reply within four minutes
column34:
but are only willing to pay only $3.52 more if they have to wait over 20 minutes.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tip:Set expectations about being responsive. Twitter has a new support indicator and message button which allow businesses to help people understand when they can expect a response and to make sure they know they have the option to start a private conversation.
Donât be afraid of negative Tweets!
It turns out that responding to negative Tweets can create major positive impacts. 69% of people who Tweeted negatively say they feel more favorable when a business replies to their concern. And among telco customers
column35: conversations that started with a negative Tweet resulted in higher brand favorability as well as 3X higher willingness to pay for their monthly wireless plan
column36:
compared to those whose original Tweet was positive.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tip:Consider prioritizing responses to negative Tweets over positive Tweets
column37: but don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t ignore customer praise! Any response helps increase willingness to pay
column38: so respond to every Tweet that you can. By responding quickly to negative Tweets
column39: you can maximize your potential for impact.\nCustomer service on Twitter benefits both businesses and customers\nBusinesses might love these benefits
column40: but research shows customer service on Twitter is better for customers
column41:
too.Aspect Research found that consumers like coming to Twitter because they perceive it as significantly less frustrating than other customer service channels â even preferring it slightly more than in-person interactions.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Businesses have known for years that great customer service engenders brand loyalty; this research shows a wide range of additional benefits to businesses. And these benefits come at a lower cost compared to other channels: according to McKinsey & Company
column42: support interactions on social cost 1/6th of those in a call center. Combined with the revenue potential
column43: favorability
column44: satisfaction
column45: and recommendation impact of these interactions
column46: businesses can benefit significantly from investing in helping their customers on Twitter.\nMethodology\nA total of 3
column47: 139 people who use Twitter completed the conjoint exercises. In addition to people who Tweeted at the top brands
column48: we made sure to include those who had customer service interactions via traditional channels\u00e2\u0080\u0094like 1-800 numbers\u00e2\u0080\u0094as well as those who were customers in these industries during the test period but had no customer service interactions on any channel. We then used these results to develop a model that measured exactly how much shoppers valued each brand.\nNet Promoter
column49: NPS
column50: and the NPS-related emoticons are registered trademarks
column51: and Net Promoter Score and Net Promoter System are service marks
column52: of Bain & Company
column53: Inc.
column54: Satmetrix Systems
column55:
Inc. and Fred Reichheld.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet
Twitter logo icon

research
marketing

column3: "title": "Introducing the new Website Conversions objective"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Introducing the new Website Conversions objective
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 28 September 2016\nLink copied successfully\nToday
column9: we are announcing two changes to our campaign options for direct response advertisers in the US. First
column10: we are introducing a new campaign objective in beta
column11: the Website Conversions objective
column12: that is designed to help advertisers drive cost-efficient conversions at scale. Second
column13:
we are renaming our existing Website Clicks or Conversions objective to the Website Visits objective to better reflect the actions that this objective drives. This change is to the name only â the objective will contain the same features and customization options. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Performance and scale for retargeting campaigns Weâve built the Website Conversions objective with performance-focused marketers in mind using what weâve learned in working with successful direct response advertisers. The result is a solution that helps Twitter advertisers see better performance and greater scale in campaigns.
This solution is especially effective for advertisers who want to retarget website visitors to drive more conversions. Advertisers using this objective to retarget their website visitors on mobile and desktop receive
column14: on average
column15: 2.5X the volume of conversions versus similar campaigns using the Website Clicks or Conversions objective.\nHow it works Website Conversions campaigns use data from Twitter website tags and Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s interest and intent signals to optimize your campaign to deliver more conversions while meeting your cost-per-conversion goal. You\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll reach your audience on Twitter and extend your campaign to thousands of apps and websites so you can drive conversions across devices and environments.\nThese changes build on our investments over the past few years
column16:
now making it possible for you to reach your customers and drive conversions everywhere. These include both the ongoing enhancements weâve made to our website tag to help you more effectively target your audience and measure conversions and to the Twitter Audience Platform to help you reach that audience wherever they are (even if theyâre not logged in on Twitter). Weâre now also leveraging TellApartâs expertise in predictive shopping and bidding to help you reach the right audience to maximize conversions on your site.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Advertiser success In early testing
column17:
weâve heard positive feedback from conversions-focused clients who have run Website Conversions campaigns: 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâve been very pleased with the performance of our Website Conversions campaigns on Twitter and have seen meaningful improvements in both scale and efficiency. Relative to comparable Washington Post campaigns
column18: we are now getting more than 5X as many conversions at a cost per conversion that is 88% below our campaign goal based on internal benchmarks. By using this new objective
column19: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been able to leverage Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s customer data signals to reach our customers and drive cost-efficient digital subscriptions across both mobile and web.\nPedram Farsaii\nDigital Marketing Manager
column20: The Washington Post \nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve used the Website Conversions objective to retarget our website visitors and generate cost-efficient conversions for our business on Twitter. Over the course of our campaigns
column21: our cost per conversion has been 26% below our targets and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been able to drive new
column22: incremental customer sales across both mobile and desktop.\nNell Lanman\nDigital Marketing Manager
column23: UNTUCKit \nGetStarted The newWebsite Conversions objective is now available in beta to advertisers in the US. Over the coming months
column24: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to make enhancements to this new objective based on your feedback and will look to expand availability to advertisers in additional regions. To get started with the Website Conversions objective
column25:
visit ads.twitter.com/getstarted. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tweet

column3: "title": "Bringing #CES2017 straight to you
column7: "path": "https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/events/2017/bringing-ces2017-straight-to-you-live-from-vegas"
column8: "post_text": "Events\nBringing #CES2017 straight to you
column9:
live from Vegas
            By
            
  
  
Monday
column10: 2 January 2017\nLink copied successfully\nWhen CES(aka the Consumer Electronics Show) rolls around every year in early January
column11: it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s an event of epic proportions with close to 200
column12: 000 people flocking to Las Vegas to experience the event firsthand.\nAnd why not? Tech is now a pervasive part of our everyday
column13: increasingly mobile lives. The mobiles we carry bring us music
column14: news
column15: and sports
column16: and connect us to the world around us
column17: in many cases
column18: live and in the moment. Increasingly
column19: the world around us runs on tech
column20: too
column21: from smart homes with smart devices to the cars we drive (or that drive us). Needless to say
column22:
the tech at CES is relevant to our daily lives now more than ever.
Hereâs what weâll be bringing you live from #CES2017.
Live daily tech news from #CES2017 in partnership with The Verge
If youâre not attending (or if you are and canât possibly tour the nearly 2.5 million net square feet of exhibit space)
column23: join The Verge live on Twitter for a tech-packed 90-minute show on Jan. 4
column25:
and 6 at 4:30pm PT/7:30pm ET.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tune in to the show in 360 video
With Periscopeâs 360 video news last week
column26: the live experience will feel even more real as you teleport into unique experiences live from the CES floor. You can expect some exciting views and broadcasts from around the globe with live music
column27: art
column28:
and some far-flung destinations that will bring this new 360 view to life.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Industry perspectives from influencers and celebrities
During the event
column29: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be talking to influencers and celebs from the sports
column30: tech
column31: advertising
column32: and music industries
column33: including four-time Super Bowl winning quarterback Joe Montana and hip hop star/entrepreneur Rick Ross. They\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll be sharing some of their favorite finds from CES and discussing how the intersection of tech is changing their industries and lives.\nStorytime with Twitter\nJoin Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s CMO Leslie Berland on Jan. 6 from 2:15-2:45pm PT
column34: streaming live from the ARIA Ballroom
column35:
for her C Space Storyteller segment where sheâll discuss ways that Twitter is telling its own unique story and how tapping into âwhatâs happeningâ pushes the boundaries of conventional storytelling.
Tune in to Twitterâs Head of Planning and Creative Agency Development Stacy Mineroâs talk at CES as part of Varietyâs Entertainment Summit. The topic?Love at First Sight on Social with new research and best practices from brands for creating âlove at first sightâ in social feeds.
Follow @TwitterAds and #CES2017 so you donât miss a thing.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.

#CES2017

The issue has been fixed but we wanted to share more details on what the impact was to our advertising partners.\nOnce we discovered the issue

column3: "title": "#TwitterForGood Day around the world"
column7:
"post_text": "Company
#TwitterForGood Day around the world
            By
            
  
  
Thursday
column8: 22 December 2016\nLink copied successfully\nTwitter has always sought to encourage a culture of volunteering and public service among its employees. The public nature of the platform
column9: and the innumerable ways in which it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s harnessed for good
column10: motivates employees to lend their talents to initiatives large and small across the world. Previously
column11: this culture was celebrated on a biannual basis with #FridayForGood. Now
column12: because of the perennial character of our volunteering culture
column13: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re calling these days of service #TwitterForGood Days. Just as before
column14:
our teams across the globe offer their time and skills to causes and campaigns in their local area. The customs and needs of the local community are foremost in our consideration as we endeavor to put down meaningful roots wherever we have an office. Read on to see some highlights from our recent series of #TwitterForGood Days. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
AMERICAS:
Coding for Kids at Twitter NeighborNest (San Francisco)
The Twitter NeighborNest (@NeighborNest) is Twitterâs family-friendly technology learning center located right across the street from HQ. On #TwitterForGood Day
column15: Tweeps taught children from Catholic Charities (@CatholicCSF) how to code in Scratch on a Raspberry Pi and using analog blocks
column16:
giving children a multidimensional overview of coding.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Networking and Coding Intro at Code Tenderloin (San Francisco)
Code Tenderloin (@codetenderloin) is a job readiness and workforce development program that helps Tenderloin residents cross Market Street and acquire positions in technology companies. On #TwitterForGood Day
column17: Tweeps participated in a networking event with alumni of the program
column18: many of whom are currently in entry-level jobs and searching for the next career step. The event was followed by an introductory workshop on coding and software skills to give participants a glimpse into what working as an engineer is like. Participants from Code Tenderloin then paired off with Tweeps for additional demonstrations of skills and networking. Everyone loved it so much that the event ran more than an hour over time!\nDiscussing Careers in Tech with Veterans (San Francisco)\nGiven that #TwitterForGood Day fell on Veterans Day this year
column19:
Tweeps on the University Recruiting (@TwitterU) team came together with veterans in the Bay to discuss careers in tech and at Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Building Solar Kits with Lighting for Literacy and Hands on Bay Area (San Francisco)
This #TwitterForGood Day
column20: @TwitterSF partnered with Lighting for Literacy and Hands On Bay Area (@handsonbayarea) to put together solar kits that will help power the world. Tweeps were given all the tools and materials and guided through the process of putting the kits together. Things got a bit competitive
column21:
but all in the spirit of giving back and promoting environmentally sustainable energy solutions.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Supporting low income and homeless families (Boulder)
@TwitterBoulder celebrated 11/11 by assisting the Family Learning Center (@flcboulder)
column22: a resource for families of limited incomes and diverse cultures
column23: to complete projects that they typically do not have the time or capacity for once the school year begins. Tweeps at the Boulder office also made 150 Meal Care Bags with @ThereWithCare for families experiencing medical crises
column24:
and joined the cooking crew at Bridge House (@bobridgehouse) to prepare a meals for homeless men and women in Boulder.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Building a Greener City (Washington DC)
@TwitterDC worked on a beautification project at a local high schoolâs garden in partnership with City Blossom
column25: a nonprofit that integrates community-oriented gardening
column26: education
column27:
youth entrepreneurship opportunities and interactive art to create green spaces throughout Washington DC.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Supporting American Youth (New York City)
Some @TwitterNYC Tweeps spent their afternoon with @StateBags
column28: handing out backpacks with essential school supplies to children in Red Hook
column29:
Brooklyn. @StateBags is a Brooklyn-born one-for-one program that combats the challenging conditions of American children and encourages self-empowerment and community enrichment.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
A Fun Afternoon with Senior Citizens (SÃ£o Paulo)
Tweeps @TwitterBrasil hosted a series of projects
column30: including visiting senior citizens at a nursing home called Residencial Israelita Albert Einstein. Tweeps played bingo
column31:
handed out donations and walked their new friends through the mechanics of Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
APAC:
Unleashing Creativity with Children (India)
Tweeps from @TwitterIndia went to schools in Delhi and Mumbai where @FeedingIndiaâs âHunger Heroesâ routinely deliver food to children
column32: guaranteeing them a hot and delicious meal for the day. Tweeps spent time with the children
column33: decorating pots and planting saplings around the school
column34:
unleashing the creativity of both the children and tweeps! Tweeps also sponsored the meal of the day.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Revitalizing the Kumamoto Tourist Economy (Japan)
Since a massive earthquake hit the Kumamoto prefecture
column35: the number of tourists in the area has decreased. This October
column36:
the Twitter Japan office celebrated #OctoberForGood and for three weeks Tweeps raised awareness of local small businesses in Kumamoto. Kumamoto is known as the secret fashion capital of Japan and efforts were made to help revitalize the local economy and sustain these small businesses. Tweeps also trained local businesses on how to use Twitter as a campaigning to raise their profile and secure sales.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
EMEA:
Hands-On NGO Training (Dublin)
@TwitterDublin kicked off #TwitterForGood Day by hosting a group of NGOs and nonprofit organizations for a training session
column37: where Tweeps covered best practices for campaigning on the platform
column38: reviewed case studies exhibiting success
column39:
and then transitioned into a discussion on how the Twitter platform has been able to support and highlight the work of the organizations present.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Protecting the welfare of animals (Spain)
In Spain
column40: animal welfare was the priority of our @TwitterSpain team. They partnered with @CiviClub and encouraged Spanish users to Tweet about #TwitterForGood and @CiviClub. The more Tweets they saw
column41: the more fodder was donated to the Asociaci\u00c3\u00b3n Nacional Amigos de los Animales (@asociacion_anaa). By the end of the day
column42:
enough Tweets were sent for two tonnes of fodder.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter

#TwitterForGood
#OctoberForGood

column3: "title": "The most exciting goals of EURO 2016"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
The most exciting goals of EURO 2016
                By
                
  
  
Friday
column8: 16 December 2016\nLink copied successfully\nIn a football (soccer) tournament
column9: it is all about goals. Goals decide the matches
column10: and make the crowd go wild. However
column11: not every goal has equal impact
column12: both in the match and on the fans.\nWith Twitter we can gauge the excitement caused by each goal during #EURO2016 by looking at the spikes in Tweet volume after each goal. The greater the spike
column13: the more reaction it inspired among fans. This visualization shows every goal of EURO
column14: when it happened
column15: who scored it
column16: how it affected the score
column17:
and the corresponding reaction on Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
We used peak detection algorithm to detect spikes and snap goals to the closest spikes. There are many ways we can measure âexcitementâ. Using raw number of Tweets could be one way
column18: but we chose to normalized the data such that each goal is measured as a percentage of total Tweets in that game
column19: in order to make the goals comparable across the entire tournament. Otherwise
column20: any goal in later matches will easily beat the group stage goals
column21: as those matches attract many more viewers. However
column22: using percentage overcompensated for the matches with fewer viewers so we had to add another weight to adjust the value based on total volume in a match.\nThe excitement level of a goal can be due to many factors
column23: as you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll see in the viz:\nImpact: How much a goal affects the course of the game can determine the reactions to it. Goals that takes the lead are indicated in red
column24: and in general caused more excitement (higher spikes).\nTiming: Goals closer to the end of the game tend (towards the right side of the viz) to have higher spikes. For example
column25: double goals from France duo Griezmann and Payet in the 90\u00e2\u0080\u0099 and 90+6\u00e2\u0080\u0099 minutes against Albania.\nBeauty: Slovakia\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Marek Hamsik\u00e2\u0080\u0099s thunderous strike from a tight angle against Russia hits the inner post and bounce in. Totally worth watching over and over.\nSurprise: Underdog goals seem to also get fans excited and cause outsize reactions. For example
column26: McGinn\u00e2\u0080\u0099s goal which gave N. Ireland its first win in major tournament
column27:
and Icelandâs winning goal in the last match of group stage both had notable spikes.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Here are some ways you can navigate the viz:
Hover (desktop) / Tap on (mobile) any goal to see all the goals from that match.
Filter matches by team
column28: to see every goal they scored or conceded throughout the tournament. Goals scored by the team are highlighted in yellow.\nFilter matches by stage
column29: to see only the knockout or group stage goals.\nFilter goals by name
column30:
to find goals from player you are interested in.
Combine the filters above
Visit https://interactive.twitter.com/euro2016/ and explore the viz for yourself.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Only on Twitter
#EURO2016 
Tweet
Twitter logo icon

data
sports
trends

column3: "title": "Speed up customer service with quick replies & welcome messages"
column7:
"post_text": "Product
Speed up customer service with quick replies & welcome messages
            By
            
  
  
Tuesday
column8:
1 November 2016
Link copied successfully
Weâre excited to announce two new features to create better conversational experiences between businesses and people on Twitter. Quick replies and welcome messages in Direct Messages make it easier for businesses to guide people to better outcomes through a combination of simple automation and human service.
These features are designed to help businesses create rich
column9: responsive
column10:
full-service experiences that directly advance the work of customer service teams and open up new possibilities for how people engage with businesses on Twitter.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Introducing Welcome Messages and Quick Replies
Welcome messages let businesses greet people and set expectations as they enter a Direct Message conversationâwithout requiring people to send the first message. Businesses can create multiple welcome messages and deep link directly to a specific greeting from Tweets
column11: websites
column12: or apps. Welcome messages help businesses demonstrate their commitment to service and help people learn what options exist to engage with a business in Direct Messages.\nQuick replies let businesses prompt people with the best ways to reply to a Direct Message
column13: whether by choosing from a list of options or guiding users to enter specific text values.\nWhen quick replies and welcome messages are used together
column14: businesses can reduce wait times and educate people on the best ways to interact with them. For example
column15: they can enable faster resolutions by helping customers more easily provide information to solve problems before an agent sees the first message
column16:
or they can simplify automated services and transactional flows that were difficult in the past.
Connecting Brands and Consumers Companies including Evernote and Pizza Hut are launching new experiences in Direct Messages that make use of these features.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
At Evernote
column17: it is very important to us that we provide the best possible experience across our channels. We are excited about the new features Twitter has developed. The ability to welcome our valued customers and capture their issues before they contact one of our agents helps to streamline the process
column18:
accelerate resolution time and reduce customer effort.
Gerald Hastie
Director of Global Customer Service at Evernote
The new Pizza Hut social ordering platform is another example of making it easy for our customer to order their favorites from Pizza Hut. We are constantly pursuing ways to simplify our ordering experience. This platform allows our consumers to quickly order or get information within Twitter where they are already spending a great deal of their time.
Baron Concors
Global Chief Digital Officer at Pizza Hut
Developer Solutions Weâve worked closely with Assist
column19: Audiense
column20: Conversable
column21: Conversocial
column22: Dexter
column23: Hobbynote
column24: Lithium
column25: Massively
column26: Proxima
column27: RozieAI
column28: Spredfast
column29: Sprinklr
column30: and Sprout Social tobring these features to market. If you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re interested in creating automated experiences in Direct Messages for your business
column31:
contact those companies directly for more information. Weâre working with a wider group of partners who will offer solutions to their customers soon as well. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
The features that Twitter has built into Direct Messages will help people get better experiences with businesses on the platform. At Assist
column32:
weâre excited to use Twitterâs new features to build innovative solutions that bring faster service and solutions for brands on Twitter.
Shane Mac
Co-Founder & CEO at Assist
Get Started These features start rolling out today. For people on Twitter with the latest version of our app
column33: they will start to see these features in Direct Message conversations with accounts like @EvernoteHelps
column34: @PizzaHut
column35: @AirbnbHelp
column36: @SpotifyCares
column37: @NortonSupport
column38: @Tesco
column39: @TfLTravelAlerts
column40: @WeatherNetwork
column41: and @AirTailor.\nIf you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re a business that provides support in Direct Messages
column42: you can set a default welcome message today in the support settings page of Twitter Dashboardto greet people when they start a conversation.\nThe developer APIs that power these features are currently in private beta. If you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re a developer and are interested in building these types of solutions in Direct Messages
column43:
you can sign up and apply foraccess here.
