column3: "title": "Study: Twitter customer care increases willingness to pay"
column7:
"post_text": "Insights
Study: Twitter customer care increases willingness to pay
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 5 October 2016\nLink copied successfully\nPeople love getting customer service from businesses on Twitter
column9: but what is the value to businesses for providing that service? While it might seem intuitive that customers who get great help will spend more with that business in the future
column10: new research actually quantifies that lift and helps businesses understand how to capture that value. This post shares highlights from our research
column11: as well as tips to help customer service teams take advantage of the findings.\nRequests for customer service emerged as an early behavior on Twitter
column12: and Tweets have become a mainstream method for reaching out to businesses. Millions of people talk to businesses publicly each month via Tweets. To understand the impact of these customer service interactions on customer relationships
column13: we designed a research study in partnership with Applied Marketing Science to figure out the potential revenue benefit to businesses who help their customers via Twitter.\nLate last year
column14: we began this work focused on the US airline industry
column15: which found that customers who received replies from an airline demonstrated stronger satisfaction and recommendation ratings\u00e2\u0080\u0094and were also willing to pay a significantly higher price for a future ticket.\nMore recently
column16: we expanded the project to replicate this research with the US quick service restaurant (QSR) and telecom industries. We found that
column17: similar to the airline industry
column18: customers who received replies were more satisfied with their experience
column19: more willing to recommend the business
column20:
and willing to pay more money for that businessâs products in the futureâespecially if the consumer received a response quickly.
We used the same rigorous conjoint analysis methodology for all verticals we analyzed.
Responding to Tweets boosts willingness to spend
Businesses create a massive opportunity for themselves when they acknowledge customer service-related Tweets from consumers. When a customer Tweets at a business and receives a response
column21:
they are willing to spend 3â20% more on an average priced item from that business in the future.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tip:If you need to discuss a private topic with a person who mentions your business in a Tweet
column22: reply with a Direct Message deep link so you can invite customers into private
column23: 1:1 conversations.Make sure to acknowledge the person appropriately by being personal
column24: friendly and human.\nResponding also increases word of mouth activity
column25: likeliness to recommend
column26: and customer satisfaction\nIn addition to revenue potential
column27: customers who receive service via Twitter will create measurable upper-funnel impact. Customers are 44% more likely to share their experiences\u00e2\u0080\u0094both online as well as offline\u00e2\u0080\u0094after receiving a response from a business on Twitter. Further
column28: they are 30% more likely to recommend the business
column29:
and respond an entire point higher (2.66 vs 3.66) on customer satisfaction surveys.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tip:Learn and grow â Twitterâs customer feedback tools let people privately share their opinions after a service interaction. Businesses can collect customer satisfaction and Net Promoter ScoreÂ® data that can be compared across traditional service channels.
The fastest responses generate the greatest revenue impact
While any response is better than none
column30: it pays to reply rapidly. When an airline responded to a customer\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Tweet in less than six minutes
column31: the customer was willing to pay almost $20 more for that airline in the future. Similarly
column32: in the telco industry
column33: customers are willing to pay $17 more per month for a phone plan if they receive a reply within four minutes
column34:
but are only willing to pay only $3.52 more if they have to wait over 20 minutes.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tip:Set expectations about being responsive. Twitter has a new support indicator and message button which allow businesses to help people understand when they can expect a response and to make sure they know they have the option to start a private conversation.
Donât be afraid of negative Tweets!
It turns out that responding to negative Tweets can create major positive impacts. 69% of people who Tweeted negatively say they feel more favorable when a business replies to their concern. And among telco customers
column35: conversations that started with a negative Tweet resulted in higher brand favorability as well as 3X higher willingness to pay for their monthly wireless plan
column36:
compared to those whose original Tweet was positive.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Tip:Consider prioritizing responses to negative Tweets over positive Tweets
column37: but don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t ignore customer praise! Any response helps increase willingness to pay
column38: so respond to every Tweet that you can. By responding quickly to negative Tweets
column39: you can maximize your potential for impact.\nCustomer service on Twitter benefits both businesses and customers\nBusinesses might love these benefits
column40: but research shows customer service on Twitter is better for customers
column41:
too.Aspect Research found that consumers like coming to Twitter because they perceive it as significantly less frustrating than other customer service channels â even preferring it slightly more than in-person interactions.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Businesses have known for years that great customer service engenders brand loyalty; this research shows a wide range of additional benefits to businesses. And these benefits come at a lower cost compared to other channels: according to McKinsey & Company
column42: support interactions on social cost 1/6th of those in a call center. Combined with the revenue potential
column43: favorability
column44: satisfaction
column45: and recommendation impact of these interactions
column46: businesses can benefit significantly from investing in helping their customers on Twitter.\nMethodology\nA total of 3
column47: 139 people who use Twitter completed the conjoint exercises. In addition to people who Tweeted at the top brands
column48: we made sure to include those who had customer service interactions via traditional channels\u00e2\u0080\u0094like 1-800 numbers\u00e2\u0080\u0094as well as those who were customers in these industries during the test period but had no customer service interactions on any channel. We then used these results to develop a model that measured exactly how much shoppers valued each brand.\nNet Promoter

"post_text": "Product
Introducing the new Website Conversions objective
            By
            
  
  
Wednesday
column8: 28 September 2016\nLink copied successfully\nToday
column9: we are announcing two changes to our campaign options for direct response advertisers in the US. First
column10: we are introducing a new campaign objective in beta
column11: the Website Conversions objective
column12: that is designed to help advertisers drive cost-efficient conversions at scale. Second
column13:
we are renaming our existing Website Clicks or Conversions objective to the Website Visits objective to better reflect the actions that this objective drives. This change is to the name only â the objective will contain the same features and customization options. 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Performance and scale for retargeting campaigns Weâve built the Website Conversions objective with performance-focused marketers in mind using what weâve learned in working with successful direct response advertisers. The result is a solution that helps Twitter advertisers see better performance and greater scale in campaigns.
This solution is especially effective for advertisers who want to retarget website visitors to drive more conversions. Advertisers using this objective to retarget their website visitors on mobile and desktop receive
column14: on average
column15: 2.5X the volume of conversions versus similar campaigns using the Website Clicks or Conversions objective.\nHow it works Website Conversions campaigns use data from Twitter website tags and Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s interest and intent signals to optimize your campaign to deliver more conversions while meeting your cost-per-conversion goal. You\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll reach your audience on Twitter and extend your campaign to thousands of apps and websites so you can drive conversions across devices and environments.\nThese changes build on our investments over the past few years
column16:
now making it possible for you to reach your customers and drive conversions everywhere. These include both the ongoing enhancements weâve made to our website tag to help you more effectively target your audience and measure conversions and to the Twitter Audience Platform to help you reach that audience wherever they are (even if theyâre not logged in on Twitter). Weâre now also leveraging TellApartâs expertise in predictive shopping and bidding to help you reach the right audience to maximize conversions on your site.
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Advertiser success In early testing
column17:
weâve heard positive feedback from conversions-focused clients who have run Website Conversions campaigns: 
This Tweet is unavailable
          This Tweet is unavailable.
        
Weâve been very pleased with the performance of our Website Conversions campaigns on Twitter and have seen meaningful improvements in both scale and efficiency. Relative to comparable Washington Post campaigns
column18: we are now getting more than 5X as many conversions at a cost per conversion that is 88% below our campaign goal based on internal benchmarks. By using this new objective
column19: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been able to leverage Twitter\u00e2\u0080\u0099s customer data signals to reach our customers and drive cost-efficient digital subscriptions across both mobile and web.\nPedram Farsaii\nDigital Marketing Manager
column20: The Washington Post \nWe\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve used the Website Conversions objective to retarget our website visitors and generate cost-efficient conversions for our business on Twitter. Over the course of our campaigns
column21: our cost per conversion has been 26% below our targets and we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve been able to drive new
column22: incremental customer sales across both mobile and desktop.\nNell Lanman\nDigital Marketing Manager
column23: UNTUCKit \nGetStarted The newWebsite Conversions objective is now available in beta to advertisers in the US. Over the coming months
column24: we\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll continue to make enhancements to this new objective based on your feedback and will look to expand availability to advertisers in additional regions. To get started with the Website Conversions objective
column25:
visit ads.twitter.com/getstarted.
